Summary of nerve Innervation for the Hand		"<div>Similar to the wrist, muscles on the posterior surface of the hand are innervated mostly by the radial nerve. Anteriorly, muscles on the thumb side are supplied primarily by the median nerve, and muscles on the little finger side are supplied primarily by the ulnar nerve.</div><div><br /></div><div><div><br /></div><div><br /></div><div>The adductor pollicis muscle appears to be the exception; it is innervated by the ulnar nerve rather than the median nerve like all the other thumb (pollicis) muscles.</div></div><div><br /></div><div>The flexor digitorum profundus muscle receives its innervation from both the median and ulnar nerve, as do the lumbricals.</div><div><img src=""213-1.jpg"" /></div>"																			hand muscle_UE
Summary of nerve Innervation for wrist		"<div>The radial nerve innervates the posterior muscles. The median nerve innervates the anterior muscles on the thumb side, and the ulnar nerve innervates muscles on the ulnar side.</div><div><img src=""paste-74826920230913.jpg"" /></div>"																			nerves wrist
Summary of Nerve Innervation&nbsp;elbow/forearm		"<div>Terminal nerves of the brachial plexus innervate all muscles of the elbow. The musculocutaneous nerve innervates muscles of the anterior arm involved with elbow flexion.&nbsp;</div><div>The radial nerve travels through the axilla and around the middle portion of the humerus to innervate the posterior surface of the arm, forearm, and hand. It is responsible for all elbow extension.&nbsp;</div><div>The median nerve descends the arm anteriorly, sending branches to the pronator muscles.&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-81097572483073.jpg"" /></div>"																			elbow_forearm muscle_UE nerves
Nerve innervation shoulder joint		"<img src=""paste-81685983002625.jpg"" />"																			nerves shoulder,
nerve innervation for shoulder girdle muscles, chart		"<img src=""paste-82257213652993.jpg"" />"																			nerves shoulder,
Sternocleidomastoid Muscle &nbsp;(SCM)	"<img src=""248-1.jpg"" />"	<div>Sternocleidomastoid Muscle &nbsp;(SCM)</div><div>O &nbsp;Sternum and clavicle</div><div>I &nbsp;Mastoid process</div><div>A &nbsp;Bilaterally: flexes neck, hyperextends head</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; Unilaterally: laterally bends the neck; rotates face to the opposite side</div><div>N &nbsp;Accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI); second and third cervical nerves</div>																			muscle_trunk palp2
Scalene Muscles	"<img src=""249-1 (1).jpg"" />"	"<div>Scalene Muscles</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>First and second ribs</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Bilaterally: assists in neck flexion</div><div>&nbsp;&nbsp;Unilaterally: neck lateral bending</div><div>N&nbsp;Lower cervical nerves (C3 to C8)</div>"																			muscle_trunk
Splenius Capitis &amp;&nbsp;Splenius Cervicis Muscles	"<img src=""251-1.jpg"" />"	"<div>Splenius Capitis Muscles</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Lower half of nuchal ligament; spinous processes of C7 through T3</div><div>I&nbsp;Lateral occipital bone; mastoid process</div><div>A&nbsp;Bilaterally: extend head and neck</div><div>Unilaterally: laterally bend and rotate the face to same side</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Middle and lower cervical nerves</div><div><br /></div><div>Splenius Cervicis Muscles</div><div>O&nbsp;Spinous processes of T3 through T6</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Transverse processes of C1 through C3</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Bilaterally: extend neck</div><div>Unilaterally: laterally bend and rotate the face to same side</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Middle and lower cervical nerves</div>"																			muscle_trunk

Iliopsoas Muscle	"<div>The iliopsoas muscle is made up of the&nbsp;</div><div>psoas major and the iliacus</div><div><img src=""304-1.jpg"" /></div>"	"<div>The iliopsoas muscle is made up of the&nbsp;</div><div>psoas major and the iliacus</div><div>Iliopsoas Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Iliac fossa, anterior and lateral surfaces of T12 through L5</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>&nbsp;Lesser trochanter</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Hip flexion</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Iliacus portion: femoral nerve (L2, L3)</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>&nbsp; &nbsp;Psoas major portion: L2 and L3</div>"																			Hip Muscle_LE palp2
Rectus Femoris Muscle	"<img src=""305-1.jpg"" /><div>rectus femoris muscle is part of the quadriceps muscle group and is the only one of that group to cross the hip joint. Its proximal attachment is on the AIIS. It runs almost straight down the thigh, where it is joined by the three vasti muscles to blend into the quadriceps tendon (also called the patellar tendon). This tendon encases the patella, crosses the knee joint, and attaches to the tibial tuberosity. The rectus femoris muscle is a prime mover in hip flexion and knee extension.</div>"	"<div>Rectus Femoris Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>AIIS</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Tibial tuberosity</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Hip flexion, knee extension</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Femoral nerve (L2, L3, L4)</div>"																			Hip knee Muscle_LE
Sartorius Muscle	"&nbsp;longest muscle in the body<div><img src=""305-2.jpg"" /></div>"	"<div>Sartorius Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>ASIS</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Proximal medial aspect of tibia</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Combination of hip flexion, abduction, lateral rotation, and knee flexion (It is most efficient when doing all four motions at the same time. An example of this motion is when you cross your legs by putting one foot on the opposite knee.)</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Femoral nerve (L2, L3)</div>"																			Hip Muscle_LE palp2

Nerve innervation of the hip muscles	"<img src=""paste-29875792510977.jpg"" />"	<div>The femoral nerve innervates muscles on the anterior surface of the hip and thigh region (hip flexors).&nbsp;</div><div>The obturator nerve innervates hip adductors on the medial side.&nbsp;</div><div>The superior gluteal nerve supplies the hip abductors on the lateral side.&nbsp;</div><div>The hamstring muscles, which are hip extensors and are located posteriorly, receive innervation from the tibial portion of the sciatic nerve.</div><div><br /></div><div>There are exceptions, gluteus maximus....</div>																			Hip nerves

Nerve innervation for the knee muscles	"<img src=""paste-36013300776961.jpg"" />"	The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps muscle group, and the sciatic nerve innervates the hamstring muscle group.																			knee nerves

Nerve innervation of the foot muscles	"<div><img src=""paste-50504520433665.jpg"" /></div>"	Those muscles located on the posterior leg and plantar surface of the foot receive innervation from the tibial nerve. The lateral plantar branch of the tibial nerve innervates muscles located on the lateral side, and the medial plantar branch innervates those on the medial side.																			ankle nerves
Temporalis Muscle	"<img src=""231-1.jpg"" />"	"<div>Temporalis Muscle</div><div>O&nbsp;Temporal fossa</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Coronoid process and ramus of mandible</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Bilaterally: elevation, retrusion (posterior fibers)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;<span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Unilaterally: ipsilateral lateral deviation</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Masseter Muscle	"<img src=""231-2.jpg"" />"	"<div>Masseter Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Zygomatic arch of temporal bone and zygomatic process of maxilla</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Angle of the ramus and coronoid process of mandible</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Bilaterally: elevation</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>&nbsp; &nbsp;Unilaterally: ipsilateral lateral deviation</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Medial Pterygoid Muscle	"<img src=""231-3.jpg"" /><div>The medial pterygoid is located on the medial side (inside) of the mandibular ramus, whereas the more superficial masseter is on the lateral side (outside). The medial pterygoid arises from the medial side of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the tuberosity of the maxilla. It runs inferiorly, laterally, and posteriorly to attach on the medial side of the ramus and angle of the mandible&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>Medial Pterygoid Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and tuberosity of the maxilla</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Ramus and angle of the mandible</div><div>A&nbsp;Bilaterally: elevation, protrusion</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;Unilaterally: contralateral lateral deviation</div><div>N&nbsp;Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Lateral Pterygoid Muscle	"<img src=""231-3.jpg"" /><div><br><div><br></div></div>"	"<div>Lateral Pterygoid Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Lateral pterygoid plate and greater wing of the sphenoid</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Mandibular condyle and articular disk</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Bilaterally: depression, protrusion</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>&nbsp; &nbsp;Unilaterally:: contralateral lateral deviation</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Mylohyoid Muscle	"<img src=""232-2.jpg"" /><div>The suprahyoid muscles, as their name implies, are a group of muscles located above the hyoid bone. They connect the hyoid bone to the skull, primarily to the mandible. Individually, these muscles are known as the mylohyoid, geniohyoid, stylohyoid, and digastric muscles. Although their primary function is to elevate the hyoid during swallowing, they can assist in mandibular depression when they reverse their muscle action, which requires the infrahyoid muscles to stabilize the hyoid bone. Therefore, these muscles will be described here in terms of their importance to the TMJ only.</div>"	"<div>Mylohyoid Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Interior medial mandible</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Hyoid</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Assists in depressing mandible</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Branch of trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Geniohyoid Muscle	"<img src=""232-2.jpg"" /><div>The suprahyoid muscles, as their name implies, are a group of muscles located above the hyoid bone. They connect the hyoid bone to the skull, primarily to the mandible. Individually, these muscles are known as the mylohyoid, geniohyoid, stylohyoid, and digastric muscles. Although their primary function is to elevate the hyoid during swallowing, they can assist in mandibular depression when they reverse their muscle action, which requires the infrahyoid muscles to stabilize the hyoid bone. Therefore, these muscles will be described here in terms of their importance to the TMJ only.</div>"	"<div>Geniohyoid Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Mental spine of mandible</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Hyoid</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Assists in depressing mandible</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>C1 via hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Stylohyoid Muscle	"<img src=""paste-58858231824385.jpg"" />"	"<div>Stylohyoid Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Styloid process of temporal bone</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Hyoid</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Assists in depressing mandible</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Branch of facial nerve (cranial nerve VII)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Digastric Muscle	"<img src=""233-2.jpg"" />"	"<div>Digastric Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Anterior: internal inferior mandible</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Posterior: mastoid process</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Via pulleylike tendon to hyoid</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Assists in depressing mandible</div><div>N&nbsp;Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and branch of facial nerve (cranial nerve VII)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Sternohyoid Muscle	"<img src=""233-1.jpg"" />"	"<div>Sternohyoid Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Medial end of clavicle, sternoclavicular ligament, and manubrium of sternum</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Inferior border of hyoid bone</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Stabilize hyoid bone</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>C1 to C3 via hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Thyrohyoid Muscle	"<img src=""233-1.jpg"" />"	"<div>Thyrohyoid Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Thyroid cartilage</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Inferior border of hyoid bone</div><div>A&nbsp;Stabilize hyoid bone</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>C1 to C3 via hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ
Omohyoid Muscle	"<img src=""233-1.jpg"" />"	"<div>Omohyoid Muscle</div><div>O <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Superior border of the scapula</div><div>I <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Inferior border of hyoid bone</div><div>A <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>Stabilize hyoid bone</div><div>N <span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>C1 to C3 via hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII)</div>"																			semester2 TMJ

Suboccipital muscles	"<img src=""7c005_f109f.jpg"" />"	<div><b>Attachments: Originates</b> from the spinous process of the C2 vertebrae (axis)</div><div><b>inserts</b> into the lateral part of the inferior nuchal line of the occipital bone.</div><div><b>Actions:</b> Extension and rotation of the head.</div><div><b>Innervation:</b> Suboccipital nerve (posterior ramus of C1).</div>																			muscle_trunk palp2

"{{c1::Hyperesthesia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;An increased sensitivity to a stimulus</span>"																					
"{{c1::<strong>Radiculopathy</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;A pathologic process affecting the spinal nerve roots</span>"	"<img src=""small_5369.jpg"">"																				
"<strong>Chronic pain</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Pain lasting for a period of more than&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3 months}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;originating from underlyin</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">g pathology, but symptoms remain past the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::tissue healing process}}"																					
"{{c1::<strong>Hyperalgesia</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Exaggerated pain response from a stimulus that normally elicits pain</span>"																					
"{{c1::<strong>Dysesthesia</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;An unpleasant sensation that is either evoked or spontaneous in nature</span>"																					
"{{c1::<strong>Allodynia</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Pain elicited from a nonpainful stimulus</span>"																					
"{{c1::<strong>Neuralgia</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Pain in a distribution of a nerve or nerves</span>"	"<img src=""images-5d71996eae22088791cd1d527805c47d9f1b5ca8.jpg"">"																				
"{{c1::CRPS Type II}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;follows a known traumatic nerve injury; formerly known as&nbsp;</span>{{c2::causalgia}}"	<div><strong>Definition</strong>&nbsp;– Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is defined as a disorder of the extremities characterized by regional pain that is disproportionate in time or degree to the usual course of any known trauma or other lesion. The pain is not restricted to a specific nerve territory or dermatome and usually has a distal predominance of abnormal sensory, motor, sudomotor, vasomotor, and/or trophic findings. The syndrome shows variable progression over time.&nbsp;</div><div></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Pathogenesis</strong>&nbsp;– The etiology and pathophysiology of CRPS are unknown. Proposed mechanisms include classic inflammation, neurogenic inflammation, and maladaptive changes in pain perception at the level of the central nervous system.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div><strong>Epidemiology</strong>&nbsp;– CRPS is more common in females than in males. The most frequent inciting events for CRPS are fractures and soft tissue injuries. CRPS seldom occurs in the absence of an identifiable trigger.&nbsp;</div><div></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Clinical features</strong>&nbsp;– The main clinical symptoms of CRPS are pain, sensory changes, motor impairments, autonomic symptoms, and trophic changes in the affected limb. Of these, pain is typically the most prominent and debilitating symptom.</div>																				
"{{c1::CRPS Type I}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;follows a nonneurological traumatic injury; formerly known as&nbsp;</span>{{c3::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">reflex sympathetic dystrophy (</span>RSD<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Sudeck’s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;atrophy</span>"	<div><strong>Definition</strong>&nbsp;– Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is defined as a disorder of the extremities characterized by regional pain that is disproportionate in time or degree to the usual course of any known trauma or other lesion. The pain is not restricted to a specific nerve territory or dermatome and usually has a distal predominance of abnormal sensory, motor, sudomotor, vasomotor, and/or trophic findings. The syndrome shows variable progression over time.&nbsp;</div><div></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Pathogenesis</strong>&nbsp;– The etiology and pathophysiology of CRPS are unknown. Proposed mechanisms include classic inflammation, neurogenic inflammation, and maladaptive changes in pain perception at the level of the central nervous system.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div><strong>Epidemiology</strong>&nbsp;– CRPS is more common in females than in males. The most frequent inciting events for CRPS are fractures and soft tissue injuries. CRPS seldom occurs in the absence of an identifiable trigger.&nbsp;</div><div></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Clinical features</strong>&nbsp;– The main clinical symptoms of CRPS are pain, sensory changes, motor impairments, autonomic symptoms, and trophic changes in the affected limb. Of these, pain is typically the most prominent and debilitating symptom.</div>																				
"{{c1::<strong>Transduction</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Conversion of stimuli to nociceptive electrical impulses.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Afferent sensory neurons known as nociceptors transmit pain signals to the&nbsp;</span>CNS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Nociceptor types include mechanical, thermal (heat/cold), and chemical.</span></div>"																					
<div>{{c1::<strong>Transmission</strong>:}}&nbsp;Electrical activity conducted through the nervous system</div><div><br></div><div>Peripheral sensory cells and dorsal root ganglion (DRG) → spinal neurons → brainstem, thalamus, and diencephalic structures</div>																					
"{{c1::<strong>Modulation</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Alteration of neural activity along transmission, which occurs in&nbsp;</span>DRG<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, spinal cord, and supraspinal structures</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Supraspinal modulation occurs in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">periaqueductal gray (</span>PAG<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">rostral ventromedial medulla (</span>RVM<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pathway;&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">descending feed back</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">can be inhibitory or excitatory</span></div>"	"<img src=""image01725.jpeg"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Opioid receptor types</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Kappa:}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Analgesia, sedation, psychotomimetic effects, dyspnea, respiratory depression, <u>euphoria, dysphoria</u></span><br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-15 at 8.52.53 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Opioid receptor types</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Mu</span><sub>1</sub><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Analgesia</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Delta:}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Analgesia, spinal analgesia</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-15 at 8.52.53 PM.png"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Opioid receptor types</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Mu</span><sub>2</sub><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Respiratory depression, sedation, vomiting, euphoria, anorexia, physical dependence, pruritus</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-15 at 8.52.53 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">pKa =&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pH at which 50% of the drug is ionized}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. The&nbsp;</span>{{c2::nonionized}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;form crosses lipid membranes easily. The&nbsp;</span>{{c3::lower}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;the pKa, the faster the onset.</span>"

"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Opioid MOA</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">bind to mu, kappa, and delta in the&nbsp;</span>CNS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and peripheral tissues;&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">they&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pre::pre/post}}synaptically {{c1::decrease::incr/decr}} the influx of {{c1::calcium::K+/Ca2+}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to reduce NT release in&nbsp;</span>{{c2::sensory C-fibers}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::post::pre/post}}synaptically<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::increase::incr/decr}} the transport of {{c1::potassium::K+/Ca2+}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">to hyperpolarize&nbsp;</span>{{c2::2nd order neurons}}</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""qBYlK8TWw5peCfx284IpaQ_b.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Buprenorphine (Subutex) or Suboxone (</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">contains naloxone).</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">mu&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">p</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">artial-agonist</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;kappa&nbsp;</span>{{c1::antagonist}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and delta&nbsp;</span>{{c1::antagonist}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span></div>"																					
"NSAIDs reversibly<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;inhibit&nbsp;</span>{{c1::COX-1<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;/&nbsp;</span>COX-2<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;enzymes::2</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, which produce&nbsp;</span>{{c2::thromboxane / prostaglandins::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;involved in inflammatory response after tissue injury.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Some&nbsp;</span>NSAIDs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;display more&nbsp;</span>COX-2<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;selectivity than others, reducing&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c3::GI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;side effects</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div><div>{{c3::plt inhibition}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c3::kidney dysfunction}}<br></div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-15 at 6.12.07 PM.png""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig11_3.png""><div><br></div>"																				
{{c1::meloxicam}} most COX2<div><br></div><div>{{c2::ketorolac}} least COX2</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-15 at 6.18.25 PM.png"">"																				
"<strong>Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)&nbsp;</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Inhibit&nbsp;</span>{{c1::serotonergic and noradrenergic reuptake::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, acting at the level of the brainstem on the pain-suppressing mechanism of the descending bulbospinal tracts</span>"	"<div><img src=""8zMRAuR0.v6hcwapWckWXQ_b.png""><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)&nbsp;</strong>{{c1::Anticholinergic and antihistaminic::2 pharm mechanism}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;side effects often dictate patient tolerance.</span>"	"<img src=""8zMRAuR0.v6hcwapWckWXQ_b.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Carisoprodol}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">—central acting muscle relaxant that blocks interneuronal activity in the descending reticular formation and dorsal horn of the spinal cord to depress polysynaptic reflexes.</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Use with caution: Increasingly abused due to meprobamate, its primary metabolite, which is a controlled substance</span>"																				
"<strong>Gabapentin</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(Neurontin</span><sup>®</sup><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) and&nbsp;</span><strong>Pregabalin</strong>&nbsp;(Lyrica<sup>®</sup>) interacts with the {{c1::α2δ subunit of L-type calcium}} channels.&nbsp;&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Used in postherpetic neuralgia, diabetic neuropathy,&nbsp;SCI&nbsp;pain, and fibromyalgia.<div><br></div><div>Side effects: {{c2::Somnolence, dizziness, edema::3}}, and dry mouth</div></div>"	"<img src=""-2T1iCQAegOIRXb1ePOMtA_b.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Myofascial pain}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Localized and +/- referred soft tissue pain, arising from trigger points, that can exhibit sensory, motor, and autonomic symptoms. can arise from a combination of biomechanical</span>"																					
"{{c1::Migraine with aura (classic)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Focal neurological symptoms preceding or accompanying headaches</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Visual disturbances (bright spots, dark spots, tunnel vision), tremor, pallor, vertigo, unilateral numbness or weakness, transient aphasia</span>"																				
"{{c1::Cortical spreading depression (CSD)}}<strong>&nbsp;theory</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: A phenomenon defined as a wave of neuronal depolarization in the cortical gray matter followed by neuronal activity suppression, resulting in blood flow changes</span>"																					
<div><strong>Valproic acid</strong>&nbsp;(Depakote<sup>®</sup>) increases {{c1::gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA)}} effects and may inhibit&nbsp;NMDA/glutamate receptors. Used for antimanic, antidepressant, impulsivity, seizures, and migraine prophylaxis.</div><div><br></div><div>Side effects: {{c4::Thrombocytopenia::heme}}, neutropenia, anemia, {{c3::tremor::neuro}}, {{c3::dizziness::neuro}}, sedation, {{c2::hepatitis, and pancreatitis::2 end organ}}.&nbsp;</div>	"<div>Complete blood count (CBC) and liver function tests should be obtained prior to initiation.<br></div><img src=""vpqj1Ym2i3tAacgYmGvXvA_b.png"">"																				
"{{c1::<strong>Neurovascular</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><strong>theory&nbsp;</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">trigeminal ganglion stim by&nbsp;</span>CSD<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;causes release of neurotransmitters: Substance P, neurokinin A, and calcitonin gene-related peptide (</span>CGRP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">).</span>"																					
"{{c1::<strong>Vascular</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><strong>theory&nbsp;</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Intracranial vasoconstriction results in ischemia, which then causes the aura that precedes migraines. Subsequent rebound vasodilation and activation of perivascular nociceptors result in the migraine&nbsp;</span>HA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.</span>"																					
"{{c1::Post-mastectomy pain syndrome:}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;aka&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Intercostobrachial neuralgia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(T1–T2).&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Chronic neuropathic pain that develops shortly after or several months postsurgery.&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Prevalence is higher after lumpectomy than mastectomy and especially when axillary lymph node dissection has been performed.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Pain is localized to the axilla, shoulder, arm, and/or chest wall.</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lymphedema: Usually develops within&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;years after breast cancer surgery.&nbsp; of the arm along with fatigue.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Causes a heavy sensation or aching discomfort in the arm, swelling of the affected arm/upper chest, and/or numbness/tingling</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Recommended treatment is a lymphedema therapy program combining massage, skin care, exercise, and compression garments.</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::Costopleural syndrome:}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Severe, intractable chest pain that is a common symptom in pleural mesothelioma.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font></div><div>{{c2::Percutaneous cervical cordotomy}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;has shown to relieve pain</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Can progress relentlessly during the course of the cancer and is hard to control.</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Characteristically pleuritic, lateralized, dull, or diffuse;&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">neuropathic components present secondary to entrapment of thoracic, autonomic, or brachial plexus nerves.</span></div>"																				
World Health Organization (WHO) (Analgesic Ladder for Cancer Pain Relief)<div><br></div><div>Mild to moderate pain: {{c1::Nonopioid analgesics}}&nbsp;</div><div>Moderate pain: {{c2::Short-acting opioids}}&nbsp;</div><div>Moderate to severe pain: {{c3::long-acting opioids}}&nbsp;</div>	World Health Organization (WHO) (Analgesic Ladder for Cancer Pain Relief)<div><br></div><div>Mild to moderate pain: Nonopioid analgesics ± adjuvant</div><div>Moderate pain: Short-acting opioids ± nonopioid analgesics ± adjuvant</div><div>Moderate to severe pain: Short- and long-acting opioids ± nonopioid analgesics ± adjuvan</div>																				
"<strong>Baclofen</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">—activates&nbsp;</span>{{c1::GABA-B}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;receptors in the brain, reducing excitatory neurotransmitter release in both the brain and spinal cord.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Strong evidence for use in spasticity.</span>"																				
{{c1::Nociceptive Pain}} can be both {{c2::somatic}} and {{c2::visceral}}&nbsp;	"<table><tbody><tr><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><br>&nbsp;NOCICEPTIVE/SOMATIC PAIN</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">VISCERAL PAIN</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; NEUROPATHIC/CENTRAL PAIN</th></tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Description</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><div><ul><li><div>Deep somatic pain: dull/aching</div></li><li><div>Superficial somatic pain: sharp, pricking</div></li><li><div>Burning, localized, reproducible</div></li></ul></div></td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><div><ul><li><div>Crampy and dull</div></li><li><div>Vague in location</div></li></ul></div></td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><div><ul><li><div>Burning, tingling, shooting, stabbing, electric-like</div></li><li><div>May be associated with numbness, tingling</div></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Causes</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><div><ul><li><div>Noxious perception from tissue damage can originate from the skin, muscle, bone, or fascia</div></li><li><div>Mediated by somatic nervous system</div></li></ul></div></td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><div><ul><li><div>Internal structures of solid or hollow organs/autonomic nervous system. Gastrointestinal</div></li><li><div>Mediated by&nbsp;ANS</div></li></ul></div></td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><div><ul><li><div>Primary lesion or dysfunction of the pain-sensing nervous system (CNS&nbsp;or&nbsp;PNS)</div></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>"																				
"{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Dorsal root entry zone (</span>DREZ<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) lesioning</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: A surgical technique that selectively destroys neurons located in the posterolateral spinal cord.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is used to treat medically refractory chronic pain syndromes associated with neurons that develop paroxysmal hyperactivity</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">following deafferentation injury (e.g., brachial plexus avulsion).</span></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw785/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-540-69960-6_133/MediaObjects/978-3-540-69960-6_133_Fig2_HTML.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::Cordotomy:}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;A surgical procedure that ablates the spinothalamic tract. </span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Used for severe pain secondary to cancer (especially for pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">where treatment to level 3 of the World Health Organization (</span>WHO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) pain ladder is ineffective.</span></div><div><img src=""WJSP-5-111-g003.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::Punctate midline myelotomy:}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;A neuroablative procedure that interrupts the midline of the dorsal column (which contains a pathway for nociceptive visceral signals)&nbsp;</span>"	"t<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">o treat intractable abdominal and pelvic cancer pain.</span>"																				
"{{c1::Cingulotomy:}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Bilateral target the cortex (part of the limbic system).</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">anterior cingulate</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>was used to treat psychiatric disorders such as obsessive-compulsive disorder and depression. It was more recently used for acute cancer pain when other methods have failed.</span>"																				
"<div><div><b>IASP&nbsp;Diagnostic Criteria for&nbsp;CRPS</b></div></div><table><tbody><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><ol><li><div>Presence of an {{c1::initiating noxious event}} or a cause of {{c1::immobilization}}</div></li><li><div>Continuing {{c2::pain}}, {{c2::allodynia}}, or {{c2::hyperalgesia}} in which the pain is {{c4::disproportionate}} to any known inciting event.</div></li><li><div>Evidence at some time of {{c3::edema}}, changes in {{c3::skin blood flow}}, or abnormal {{c2::sudomotor}} activity in the region of pain (can be sign or symptom).</div></li><li><div>This diagnosis is excluded by {{c4::the existence of other conditions causing the pain}}<br></div></li></ol></td></tr></tbody></table>"																					
"<b>CRPS treatments</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::physical therapy}} is a hallmark of successful management</div><div><br></div><div><u>Medications:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::NSAIDs::Drug Class}}, {{c2::TCA's::Drug Class}}, {{c2::gabapentin}} (Up to date)</div><div>{{c3::opioids}} (<font color=""#fc0006"">limited data</font>), topical {{c3::dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)}}, and oral {{c3::<span style=""font-style: italic;"">N</span>-acetylcysteine (NAC)}} (cuccurrolo)</div><div><br></div><div><u>Interventional:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::sympathetic nerve blocks}} may be useful</div><div>{{c5::intrathecal baclofen}} and {{c5::spinal cord stimulation (SCS)}} suported by case reports</div><div>{{c6::IV ketamine / lidocaine}} used in refractory cases</div>"	"Functional restoration in a multidisciplinary setting (PT, OT, pt education, and psych eval)<div><br></div><div><div><strong>Medication options&nbsp;</strong>– For patients with early CRPS who require treatment for pain, we suggest starting with one (or more) of the following agents (<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/grade/6?title=Grade%202C&amp;topicKey=NEURO%2F5630"">Grade 2C</a>):</div><div></div><div>-<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/ibuprofen-drug-information?search=CRPS&amp;topicRef=5630&amp;source=see_link"">Ibuprofen</a>&nbsp;400 to 800 mg three times a day or&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/naproxen-drug-information?search=CRPS&amp;topicRef=5630&amp;source=see_link"">naproxen</a>&nbsp;250 to 500 mg twice daily&nbsp;</div><div></div><div>-An adjunctive medication for neuropathic pain, such as&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/gabapentin-drug-information?search=CRPS&amp;topicRef=5630&amp;source=see_link"">gabapentin</a>,&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/amitriptyline-drug-information?search=CRPS&amp;topicRef=5630&amp;source=see_link"">amitriptyline</a>, or&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/nortriptyline-drug-information?search=CRPS&amp;topicRef=5630&amp;source=see_link"">nortriptyline</a>&nbsp;</div><div></div><div>-A short-term bisphosphonate course for patients with early CRPS who have pain and abnormal uptake on bone scan&nbsp;</div><div></div><div>-Topical&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/lidocaine-drug-information?search=CRPS&amp;topicRef=5630&amp;source=see_link"">lidocaine</a>&nbsp;cream (2 to 5%) or topical&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/capsaicin-drug-information?search=CRPS&amp;topicRef=5630&amp;source=see_link"">capsaicin</a>&nbsp;cream (0.075%)&nbsp;</div></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Interventional procedures</b>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">trigger/tender point injections</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">regional sympathetic nerve block</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">spinal cord stimulation</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">epidural&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/clonidine-drug-information?search=CRPS&amp;topicRef=5630&amp;source=see_link"">clonidine</a></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">chemical or mechanical sympathectomy, among others.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">The published evidence for these methods, though generally limited and of low quality, does not support their efficacy. However, in the author's clinical experience, a number of patients derive meaningful benefit from these interventional procedures.</span><br></div>"																				
<div>Birth length doubles by approximately age {{c1::4}} years and triples by age {{c2::13}} years.</div>																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">average child grows approximately&nbsp;</span>{{c1::10}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;inches in the first year of life,&nbsp;</span>{{c2::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;inches in the second</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">4 inches (7.5 to 10 cm) in the third, and approximately&nbsp;</span>{{c3::2 to 3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;inches (5 to 7.5 cm) per year thereafter until puberty.</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Within the first <u>few days</u> of life, the newborn&nbsp;</span>{{c1::loses up to 10}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of birth weight</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Birth weight&nbsp;</span>{{c1::doubles}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;between 4 and 5 months of age,&nbsp;</span>{{c2::triples}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;by the end of the 1<sup>st</sup> year, and&nbsp;</span>{{c4::quadruples}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;by the end of the child’s 2<sup>nd</sup> year.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Between ages 2 and 9 years, the annual increment in weight averages about&nbsp;</span>{{c3::5 lb}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;per year</span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">anterior fontanelle normally closes by ~&nbsp;</span>{{c1::12}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months of age (but may close by 3 months or remain open until 18) months</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">posterior fontanelle usually closes by&nbsp;</span>{{c2::4}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months (but in some children may not be palpable at birth)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""X2604-F-19.png"">"																				
"<div><h3>REFLEX DEVELOPMENT</h3></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">pres. at birth, after 1st 6 to 8 months of life as the&nbsp;</span>CNS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;matures, these&nbsp;</span>{{c1::primitive reflexes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are gradually suppressed</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Concurrently, more sophisticated&nbsp;</span>{{c2::postural responses}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;emerge between 2 and 14 months, incorporated into motor</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<div><h3><span style=""font-size: 20px;""><u>primitive Reflex Development</u></span><br></h3><div><table><tbody><tr><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">REFLEX</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">STIMULUS</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">RESPONSE</th><th by arm flexion and adduction</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">4–6 months</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Persists in&nbsp;CNS&nbsp;pathology, static encephalopathy</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Rooting</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Stroking lips or around mouth</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Moving mouth, head toward stimulus in search of nipple</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">4 months</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Diminished in&nbsp;CNS&nbsp;pathology, may persist in&nbsp;CNS&nbsp;pathology</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Positive supporting</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Light pressure or weight bearing on plantar surface</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Legs extend for partial support of body weight</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">3–5 months replaced by volitional weight bearing with support</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Obligatory or hyperactive abnormal at any age; early sign of lower extremity spasticity; may be associated with scissoring</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png"">&nbsp;Asymmetric tonic neck</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Head turning to side</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Extremities extend on face side, flex on occiput side (“fencer position”)</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">6–7 months</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Obligatory response abnormal at any age, persists in static encephalopathy</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Symmetric tonic neck</td><td colspan=""1"" any age, persists in static encephalopathy</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&nbsp;</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Neck extension</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Arms extend, legs flex</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&nbsp;</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&nbsp;</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1""><img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png"">&nbsp;Palmar grasp</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Touch or pressure on palm or stretching finger flexors</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Flexion of all fingers (hand fisting)</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">5–6 months</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Diminished in&nbsp;CNS&nbsp;suppression, absent in&nbsp;LMN&nbsp;paralysis; persists/hyperactive in spasticity</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Plantar grasp</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Pressure on sole distal to metatarsal heads</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Flexion of all toes</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">12–14 months when walking is achieved</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Diminished in&nbsp;CNS&nbsp;suppression; absent in&nbsp;LMN&nbsp;paralysis; persists/hyperactive in spasticity</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Automatic neonatal walking</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">On vertical support plantar contact and passive tilting of body forward side to side</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Alternating automatic steps with support</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">3–4 months</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Variable activity in normal infants; absent in&nbsp;LMN&nbsp;paralysis</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Placement or placing</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Tactile contact on dorsum of foot or hand</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Extremity flexion to place hand or foot over an obstacle</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Before end of first year</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Absent in&nbsp;LMN&nbsp;paralysis or with lower extremity spasticity</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Neck righting or body derotational</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Neck rotation in supine</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Sequential body rotation from shoulder to pelvis toward direction of face</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">4 months replaced by volitional rolling</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Nonsequential leg rolling suggests increased tone</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Tonic labyrinthine</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Head position in space, strongest at 45 degrees from horizontal Supine or prone</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Predominant extensor tone (while supine)<br><br>Predominant flexor tone (while prone)</td><td "{{c1::The Moro reflex}}<br><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34); background-color: rgb(248, 249, 250);"">&nbsp;1) the reflex is initiated by pulling the infant up from the floor and then releasing him; 2) he spreads his arms 3) he pulls his arms in</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bilateral_symmetry#Bilateral_symmetry"">Bilateral</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;absence of the reflex may be linked to damage to the infant's&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_nervous_system"">central nervous system</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">, while a unilateral absence could mean an injury due to&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birth_trauma_(physical)"">birth trauma</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;(e.g., a&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clavicle_fracture"">fractured clavicle</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;or injury to the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachial_plexus"">brachial plexus</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">).&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erb%27s_palsy"">Erb's palsy</a></div><div><img src=""sddefault.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::asymmetrical <u>tonic neck&nbsp;</u>reflex}}<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">, (</span>reflex)&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">When the child's head is turned to the side, the arm on ipsilateral will extend and the opposite arm will flex&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><sup></sup>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">also known as 'fencing posture'</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">or the reflex continues to be triggered past six months of age, the child may have a disorder of the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_motor_neuron"">upper motor neurons</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">.</span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""220px-Asymmetrical_tonic_neck_reflex_(ATNR)_in_a_two-week-old_female.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::tonic
labyrinthine reflex.}} (reflex) This pattern, facilitated by the supine posi-
tion of the head, demonstrates lower extremity symmetrical
extension with upper extremity shoulder abduction and exter-
nal rotation.&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">tilting the head back while lying on the back causes the back to stiffen and even arch backwards, the legs to straighten, stiffen, and push together, the toes to point, the arms to bend at the elbows and wrists</span><br></div><img src=""tlr-prone.jpg""><img src=""tlr-supine.jpg"">"																				
"<table><tbody><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">{{c1::Head righting}}</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Visual and vestibular</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Align face/head vertical, mouth horizontal.</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Prone - Supine: {{c2::2-4::2mo range}} months</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Delays or absent in&nbsp;CNS&nbsp;immaturity or damage</td></tr></tbody></table>"	"<img src=""neck-reflex.jpg""><img src=""labyrinthine-reflex.jpg""><img src=""occulo.jpg""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">responsible for maintaining the head in an upright position with eyes facing forward and level with the ears. It is reflex triggered by the position of the otoliths in the labyrinths</span><br></div>"																				
"<table><tbody><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">{{c1::body righting}}</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Tactile, vestibular proprioceptive</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Align body parts in anatomic position relative to each other and gravity.</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">{{c2::4-6::2mo range}} months<br></td></tr></tbody></table>"	"<div><div><img src=""body-righting.jpg""></div></div><div><div><div>7 MONTHS<br>Helps from sitting to standing</div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">response of the body to pressure stimulation. The body will right itself <u>independently</u> of the head, so this reflex modifies the neck righting reflex.</span><br></div>"

"<div>ISPO&nbsp;Classification System</div><div><br></div><div>Classifies limb deficiencies as either {{c1::transverse or longitudinal::2 directions}}</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">transverse level is named&nbsp;</span>{{c2::after::before or after}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;the segment beyond which there is no skeletal portion.</span><br></div>"	"<br><div><img src=""gr1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>originial classification</u> uses classic terms include the following</span><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Amelia}}—absence of a limb</div>"	"<img src=""DA2C31FF1-1.png"">"																				
"Frantz Classification<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Describes deficiencies as either terminal, or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::intercalary}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, denoting the absence of intermediate parts</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""DA2C31FF1-1.png"">"																				
"Transradial Deficiency<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Prosthetic fitting should occurr at around&nbsp;</span>{{c1:: 7}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months.</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">more sophisticated prosthesis is provided around&nbsp;</span>{{c2::12}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months.</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"most common<div><img src=""paste-db2c5d5bb968ad693e3919a456f8567246c50827.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Krukenberg}}<strong>&nbsp;procedure</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;reconstructs the forearm for children with absent hands by separating the ulna and the radius&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""rr3Jj9C.gif"">"																				
"Transhumeral Deficiency<div><br></div><div>Body-powered hooks are used successfully at {{c1::2 to 3}} years old when the child has the cognitive ability to operate them</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">by&nbsp;</span>{{c2::4 to 5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;years of age, a body-powered elbow may be used</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-86de74aff8ed6222861d76014bf814fcf4bc5c6b.jpg""><img src=""paste-ec2c329aae4c775b73776b3021392b52720ab1db.jpg"">"																				
"<div><div>{{c1::Vilkke}}<strong>&nbsp;procedure</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Attaches a toe to the residual limb to create a pincer grip</span><b><br></b></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">""UE revision amputation req&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">in 10% of&nbsp;</span>UE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;congenital limb deficiencies""</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span><br></div>"	"<img src=""1-s2.0-S0363502318301606-gr6.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">congenital fibular deficiency&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">creates a problem with limb length discrepancy.&nbsp; If leg length inequality is severe, a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Syme’s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;amputation may be performed</span></div>"	"<img src=""https://media.springernature.com/full/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs00064-011-0042-x/MediaObjects/64_2011_42_Fig1_HTML.gif"">"

"Fitting Timetable of Lower Extremity Amputee<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">fit with a prosthesis at&nbsp;</span>{{c1::9}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">knee joint is usually added as early as&nbsp;</span>{{c2::18}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months of age</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">when ready to pull up to standing position</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is advisable to fit a jointless, above-the-knee prosthesis to the toddler</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><br></div></div>"

"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Cerebral palsy (</span>CP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) is a disorder of movement control and posture resulting from a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::nonprogressive}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;UMN lesion to an immature brain</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">but is also associated with cognitive and sensory associated problems</span><div><img src=""paste-ada4b3d187e62d9abd490329848ecff803769167.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"CP can&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">occur in utero (prenatal period), near time of delivery (perinatal period), or within the first&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;years of life</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Majority of&nbsp;</span>CP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cases (70%–80%) occur during the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pre-:: pre, peri, or post}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;natal period.&nbsp;</span>"	"<ul><li><div><strong>Prenatal intracranial hemorrhage</strong>:</div><div><ul><li><div>Outcome depends on degree of associated parenchymal injury.</div></li></ul></div><div></div></li><li><div><strong>Placental complications</strong></div></li><li><div><strong>Gestational toxins</strong>:</div><div><ul><li><div>Iodine deficiency can lead to diplegia.</div></li><li><div>Organic mercury intoxication can lead to quadriplegia.</div></li></ul></div></li><li><div><strong>Congenital malformations of the brain and cerebral vascular occlusions during fetal life</strong></div></li><li><div><strong>Acquired congenital infections (TORCH)</strong><span style=""font-weight: bold;"">:</span></div></li><li><div><strong>Prenatal hypoxic-ischemic injury&nbsp;</strong></div></li></ul>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">complications of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Premature birth}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;remains the most common antecedent of&nbsp;</span>CP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;during the <b>peri</b>-natal period&nbsp;</span>"	<ul><li><div>Fragile brain vasculature</div></li><li><div>Physical stresses of immaturity that predispose children to compromise of cerebral blood flow</div></li><li><div>Blood vessels in the watershed zone next to the lateral ventricles in the capillaries of the germinal matrix that are particularly vulnerable</div></li></ul><div>Complications of FULL TERM</div><div><ul><li><div><strong>Hyperbilirubinemia</strong>: (kernicterus)</div></li><li><div><strong>Difficult/traumatic delivery</strong>&nbsp;(SDH&nbsp;can result in&nbsp;CP&nbsp;(spastic hemiplegia type))</div></li><li><div><strong>Infection</strong></div><div></div></li><li><div><strong>Seizures</strong></div></li><li><div><strong>Bradycardia and hypoxia</strong></div></li></ul></div>																				
"{{c1::spastic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>CP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;exhibits significant (</span>UMN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) signs, such as hyperreflexia/clonus &amp;&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">persistent primitive reflexes</span>"	"ie.&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Extensor Babinski response (abnormal at &gt;2 years old)</span>"																				
"{{c1::Diplegic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Spastic CP Most common type </span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">seen in <u>premature</u> infants</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(Little’s Disease) and most common overall</span><div><img src=""1450208373_1_orig.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<strong>Diplegic CP</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;due to hypoperfusion of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::germinal matrix}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the periventricular region of the premature fetus</span>"	"<img src=""The-periventricular-anatomy-The-germinal-matrix-is-a-thin-layer-of-gray-matter-in-green.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Diplegic CP caused by&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Periventricular Leukomalacia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. This region of white matter is traversed by the descending fibers of the motor cortex.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::corona radiata}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, descending fibers from the motor cortex are arranged with serving the&nbsp;</span>LE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;medially and&nbsp;</span>UE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;laterally</span></div>"	"<img src=""f76c49c68f4512eea441287b79978dc4.jpg""><br><div><img src=""PVL-Periventricular-Leukomalacia.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Diplegic spastic cp gait pattern includes classic&nbsp;</span>{{c1::scissoring}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;gait with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::toe}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;walking</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">characterized by the knees and thighs pressed together or crossing each other while walking...&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">hip adductors remain contracted, internal hip rotation stops leg separation</span></div><div><div><img src=""Scissoring-gait-Flexed-knees-due-to-contracted-gastrocnemius-Adducted-legs-due-to.png""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
"physical exam <u>diplegic CP</u>&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Mild&nbsp;</span>{{c1::coordination}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;problems&nbsp;</span>UEs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::UMN}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;findings in&nbsp;</span>LEs"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Primarily&nbsp;</span>LE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;&gt;&gt;&nbsp;</span>UE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;involvement</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">CP pt's present w/ early&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hypotonia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;followed by development of spasticity</span>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Premature
infants often have lower muscle tone that should improve
with time.&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"tetraplegic spastic cp cuased by major ischemic event&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>or {{c1::Parasagittal}}<strong>&nbsp;cerebral injury</strong><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">—(bilateral cortical zones</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, causing necrosis within the border watershed zones)</span></div>"	"<div><br></div><div>more profound PVL than diplegic CP<br></div><img src=""3-s2.0-B9780323428767000181-f018-009-9780323428767.jpg""><div><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">spastic&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hemiplegia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;CP one side of the body is involved, (usually the arm more than the leg.)</span>"	"<img src=""1450208373_1_orig.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Dyskinetic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;type CP are characterized by abnormal extrapyramidal movement&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">secondary to dysregulation of tone, postural control, and coordination&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<img src=""1450208373_1_orig.png"">"																				
"most dyskinetic type CP is<strong>&nbsp;</strong>associated with {{c1::kernicterus<font color=""#333333"">::cause</font>}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(neonatal hyperbilirubinemia causing bilirubin deposition in the basal ganglia).</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">also Diffuse anoxia resulting in hypoxia of the basal ganglia</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""u3ix3ugosgi31.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::dyskinetic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;type CP has high incidence of sensorineural hearing loss&nbsp;</span>"																					
"{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gross motor function classification system&nbsp;</span>GMFCS}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is a functionally based system to standardize function in the&nbsp;</span>CP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;child.</span>"	"<img src=""Five-Gross-Motor-Function-Classification-System-GMFCS-Expanded-and-Revised-levels-as.png"">"																				
"3 neuro complications of CP include (not snesory, weakness etc)<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">1.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ocular findings}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">2.&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Seizures}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">3.&nbsp;</span>{{c3::mental retardation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Spastic diplegia</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">strabismus/visual deficit in 50%</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Seizures occur in 20% to 25%&nbsp; (50% in tetra)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">cognitive impairment found in 30% (mental retardation in tetra)</span></div>"																				
<div>Spastic CP <b>Walk prognosis</b></div>hemiplegic: ambualtion acieved by {{c1::2}} years<div>diplegic: {{c2::Most}} ambulate—some require assistive devices</div><div>tretraplegic: {{c3::one fourth::fraction}} are completely diabled</div>	1/4 independent. 1/2 assistive devices																				
"<b>walk prognosis in CP</b><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch10#bid_10_2"">Alexander (2010)</a>:<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;independent&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sitting}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::crawl}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;occurs by age 2, prognosis for ambulation is good</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Persistence of <u>&gt;</u></span>{{c2::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or more primitive reflexes at&nbsp;</span>{{c2::18}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is a poor prognostic sign</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Persistence of three or more primitive reflexes at 18 to 24 months is a poor prognostic sign</span>"

"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Mixed type&nbsp;</span>CP<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The most common mixed type is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::spastic athetoid}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">exhibit patterns of both spastic and dyskinetic types of&nbsp;</span>CP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(predominant dyskinetic movement pattern with an underlying component of spasticity)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"

"CP spasticity&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Tone-reducing ankle–foot orthoses (</span>TRAFOs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;aid in gait by controlling the equinus or equinovarus deformity</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-8a504e194d1d325d68aadf878cf8a71437df391f.png""><img src=""Varus_Illustration.png""><div><ul><li><div>Designed to decrease abnormal reflexes</div></li><li><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Full-length foot plate</span>&nbsp;extends past the toe to discourage toe flexion.</div></li><li><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Metatarsal support</span>&nbsp;discourages stimulation to a particularly reflexogenic area of the foot.</div></li><li><div>They are most effective during gait, but use during rest helps prevent contractures.</div></li></ul><div><img src=""introd-ampll-orthosis-draliaa-78-638.jpg""><br></div></div>"																				
"<div>CP spasticity bracing</div><div><br></div>KAFO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>HKAFO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;braces&nbsp;</span>{{c1::do&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">not:: do or do not</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;significantly improve gait</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">but they do decrease deformity</span><div><img src=""paste-053b5e435dbad80b2a1e78d32ff4e0fc133c234b.jpg""><img src=""paste-43c631137144c4c571856b38844be16f08744d33.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Baclofen MOA&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">acts as a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::GABA}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;agonist at</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;at&nbsp;</span>{{c1::GABA<sub>B</sub>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;receptors in spinal cord</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">↓ release of excitatory neurotransmitters from afferent terminals</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Baclofen&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">PRECAUTIONS =&nbsp;</span>{{c1::seizure::major}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">May lower seizure threshold; abrupt withdrawal may precipitate seizures or hallucinations</span><div><img src=""Side-effects-of-baclofen-1030x619.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Dantrolene MOA</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">↓ release of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::calcium}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;from&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sarcoplasmic reticulum}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Unique among spasticity medications with <u>peripheral site</u> of action, acting at the level of the muscle itself</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Classically preferred drug for spasticity of cerebral origin (stroke,&nbsp;</span>CP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, head injury)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Baclofen (Lioresal) side fx</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Sedation/drowsiness}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may be dose limiting factor</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	<ul><li><div>Weakness</div></li><li><div>GI&nbsp;symptoms (constipation)</div></li><li><div>Tremor</div></li><li><div>Insomnia</div></li><li><div>Confusion</div></li></ul>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Dantrolene sodium (Dantrium)&nbsp; major precaution =&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Liver toxicity}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::LFTs}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;should be monitored</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">in approximately 1% of patients. Highest risk in females over 30 yr, on high doses (&gt;300 mg), for &gt;2 mo.</span><div><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Diazepam (Valium) MOA</span><br><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); background-color: rgb(229, 242, 246);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">facilitates&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">effects on the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::GABA<sub>A</sub>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;receptor</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); background-color: rgb(229, 242, 246);""><br></span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); background-color: rgb(229, 242, 246);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">overall effect results in membrane hyperpolarization and decreased neuronal firing</span><br></div><img src=""pP4P3a1ipOBjnrz5rE5t0w.png""><br>"

"CP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of all disability levels&nbsp;</span>{{c1::are::are or are not}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;capable of near-normal reproduction</span>"
