What TBI tests are used in Neuropsychological testing?<br>Which are the most widely used? (bold)	<b>-Halstead–Reitan Neuropsychological Battery (HRNB)</b>- test designed to assess brain damage<br><b>-WAIS–R:</b> 11 subtests (six determine verbal IQ and five determine performance IQ); WAIS–R is<br>the most frequently used measure of general IQ. (The revised version of the WAIS–R is known<br>as WAIS–III.)<br>–– WAIS–III components:<br>nn Verbal IQ = vocabulary, similarities, arithmetic, digit span, information, comprehension,<br>letter–number sequencing<br>nn Performance IQ = picture completion, digit–symbol coding, block design, matrix reasoning,<br>picture arrangement, object assembly<br>-MMPI T/F personality questionare<br>-Token test-auditory comprehension and language production

Persistent post-concussion syndrome is used to describe symptoms lasting...?	over 3 to 6 months																				
Arm abduction is achieved through what two joint movements?	Glenohumeral and scapulothoracic joint motion																				
During shoulder abduction, what is the ratio of glenohumeral motion:scapulothoracic motion?<br>Why is this necessary?	2:1 degrees<br>Scapulothoracic motion allows glenoid to rotate, permits glenohumeral abduction without impingement.																				
What is the most common direction of glenohumeral instability?	Anterior																				
What direction of shoulder instability is caused by abduction and external rotation, is more common in the younger population, and may involve axillary nerve injury?	Anterior																				
What direction of glenohumeral instability is caused by landing on a forward flexed adducted arm?	Posterior																				
What direction of glenohumeral instability presents with the arm in adducted interal rotated position?	Posterior																				
What GH instability may occur as the result of a seizure?	Posterior																				
What causes a Hill-Sachs lesion?	"<img src=""paste-c27e7592a4c0b2fae63c27125bbadd973bcd83cc.jpg"">"																				
How is the O'Brien test performed?<br>What does it test for?	"<img src=""paste.png""><br>-With the arm internally rotated, forward flexed, adducted 15 degrees examiner applies a downward force to the pronated arm, then applies a downward force to the supinated arm.<br>-SLAP lesions"																				
Where do rotator cuff tears primarily occur?<br>Why is this a common region?	The supraspinatus tendon<br>-Chronic impingment, poor blood supply																				
Pain with throwing a baseball or swimming/ other repetitive features may indicate what lesion?	Rotator cuff tears																				
What motion does the humerus perform during shoulder abduction?<br>What does abduction do to the greater tuberosity?	"External rotation<br>Forces it under the acromion<br><img src=""paste-e9ef91ed942bb16c17dbc93c91c3587dc4ad9965.jpg""><br>"																				
What imaging study is the gold standard to evaluate integrity of the rotator cuff?<br>What can be added to evaluate the labrum?	MRI<br>Gadolinium contrast 																				
What are arthograms used for in shoulder injuries?	Assessing full thickness tears, unable to delineate the size or partial tears

In shoulder arthrodesis, what angle is the fusion position in?	50 degree abduction<br>30 degree forward flexion<br>50 degree internal rotation																				
Biceps tendon rupture occurs most commonly where?<br>What is the Popeye sign?<br>Who is most at risk?	"-Proximal end of long head of biceps tendon<br>-Retracted biceps muscle<br>-Adults &gt;40 years old w/chronic impingement<br><img src=""paste-50bdea93bf054fccde06b3f7051c33ebf0607432.jpg"">"

What is required when performing Electroejaculation in SCI patients?	Medical supervision																				
What are the causes of poor semen quality in SCI?	"<img src=""paste-0d1491c738164e5f19eba803d5fcd86c20b0b4c5.jpg"">"																				
Female sexual stimulation is mediated by what neurological levels?	Stimulation of the genital region, including clitoris, labia majora, and labia minora, causes<br>afferent signals to travel via the pudendal nerve into the S2–S4 segments.																				
What is the cause of decreased libido post SCI?	Decreased libido is reported after SCI and is likely due to a combination of psychological and physical changes after injury including a change in self-image and altered sensation in the<br>genital region.																				
In female SCI is fertility impaired?	No																				
In female SCI, what may be the only clinical manifestation of labor?<br>Tx?	-AD<br>-T10 epidural up until 12 hours post delivery or until AD resolves																				
How is the GI affected in UMN SCI?<br>Most common complications?	"<img src=""paste-f7f57a227611d3cd3b870d17448f2d7418d7545f.jpg"">"																				
What is the gastrocolic reflex?	–– Contraction of the colon occurring with gastric distention<br>–– When feasible, SCI patients should be instructed to perform their bowel programs 20 to 30 minutes<br>after a meal. Increased colonic activity occurs in the first 30 to 60 minutes after a meal (usually within 15 minutes).																				
What is the rectocolic reflex?<br>How is this applied during SCI?	–– Occurs when rectal contents stretch the bowel wall reflexively, relaxing the internal anal sphincter and leading to left colonic contraction<br>–– Suppositories and digital stimulation cause the bowel wall to stretch and take advantage of this<br>reflex.<br>–– Note this reflex can be manipulated by digital stimulation of the rectum.<br>–– Digital stimulation is accomplished by gently inserting a gloved, lubricated finger into the rectum, and slowly rotating the finger in a clockwise circular motion until relaxation of the bowel wall is felt or stool/flatus passes (approximately 1 minute).																				
What are the key components of a bowel program in SCI?	"<img src=""paste-4699ca7f14faff0650e97dca006ecb234d65375d.jpg"">"																				
What is SMA syndrome?<br>What are predisposing factors?	"<img src=""paste-e4770d574b2d332e90dde24b268fe162a8ab4f3f.jpg""><br><img src=""paste-884c3b306c2d3f7ae3ee41c6f34b9673d6f40a36.jpg"">"																				
Sx of SMA syndrome?<br>Dx?<br>Tx?<br>Other etiologies?	"<img src=""paste-529c0bdb2bec0c6d8e39bdbc3836ea9cd428fff4.jpg"">"																				
What calcium complications can occur post SCI?<br>Tx?	Hypercalcemia- 4-8 weeks post SCI<br>Tx: IV NS, Pamidronate, Furosemide																				
What bone density anomalies may occur as complications in SCI?<br>Tx?<br>	Osteoporosis<br>Tx: Vitamin D supplementation<br>Fractures (2/2 above)<br>Tx: non-operatively with soft padded splints																				
Assc. between Cardiovascular dz in SCI?	Occurs more frequently and at an earlier age																				
Hyperglycemia and metabolic syndrome assc. in SCI?	up to 70% show insulin resistance<br>Interventions- FES, lifestyle interventions																				
What are the most frequent respiratory complications in SCI?	Pneumonia, atelectasis, ventilatory failure																				
Leading cause of death in SCI patients in acute and chronic phase of recovery? 	Respiratory: Acute- PE, chronically-Pneumonia

Most common joints affected by heterotopic ossification in SCI?	Hip&gt;Knee&gt;shoulder&gt;Elbow<br>(Most common to least common)																				
When is onset of HO in SCI?	1-3 months post-injury most common, peaks at 2 months<br>Can present after 6 months, if it occurs after 1 year usually associated with a fracture, DVT, or pressure injury.<br><br>HO at 2 mo																				
What is Gold standard diagnostic test for dvts in SCI?	LE venogram																				
What is gold standard diagnosis for a PE? 	Pulmonary arteriogram

What rates does pain occur in the SCI patient?	60-80%, functionally disabling from 18-44%

What is the association between CTS and SCI?	21-65% with paraplegia &gt; tetraplegia																				
How does Posttraumatic Syringomyelia: Posttraumatic Cystic Myelopathy progress?<br>How does it appear on MRI?	Cephalad to caudal direction<br>-MRI: elongated cavity in higher percentage of cases																				
What is the most common cause of progressive myelopathy after TSCI?	Posttraumatic Syringomyelia: Posttraumatic Cystic Myelopathy																				
Most common presenting symptom in posttraumatic syringomyelia?	Pain, aching/burning, worse with coughing, sneezing, straining, sitting&gt;supine position																				
Earliest sign of post-traumatic syringomyelia?	Ascending loss of DTRs<br>Ascending sensory loss																				
Gold Standard dx of postraumatic syringomyelia?	MRI with gadolinium																				
What Tendon transfer procedures is commonly performed for a C5 level injury?	Brachioradialis to Extensor carpi radialis brevis<br>-improves wrist extension<br>Deltoid to triceps<br>-adds elbow extension																				
What Tendon transfers procedures are performed for a C6 lesion?	"<img src=""paste-209860d7cf57eac5267754834c60278e3c2d9400.jpg"">"																				
What tendon transfer procedures are performed for a C7 lesion?	-Brachioradialis to FPL: thumb flexion<br>-ECRL/FCU to FDP: restore finger flexion																				
Tendon transfer procedure for a C8 lesion?	Claw hand- lumbrical bar to prevent hyperextension of MCPs.																				
TBI co-occurs with SCI in what percent of cases?	24-74%																				
Depression rates in SCI?	20-45%, occurs within first month

What is double limb support?	Time spent in which both feet are in contact with the ground- 20% of normal gait cycle.<br>Disappears during running.																				
What is Cadence?	Number of steps per unit time<br>

"{{c1::C5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is overall the most common level of SCI</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::T12}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the most common level of injury of paraplegia</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Over the last 20 years, cases of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::incomplete tetraplegia::SCI incomplete/complete para/tetra}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;have increased</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">while complete paraplegia and complete tetraplegia have decreased</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">prob increase in falls/ elderly CCS</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">At 1 year post SCI — ~&nbsp;</span>{{c1::15 (12% to 18%)::%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are employed; 25.8% at 5 years, and at 10 years postinjury—35% are employed</span>"																					
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>SCI causes of death</u>&nbsp;</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">1.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Respiratory disorders (w/ PNA</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;being the most common)</span>}}<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">2.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Heart disease}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">3.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::septicemia (PU's, UTI, resp)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	VTE is up there/included in resp&nbsp;																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Spinocerebellar tract function =&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<u>unconscious</u>&nbsp;proprioception}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Muscular position and tone, unconscious proprioception</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_2.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lateral corticospinal tract.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Motor: Theorized to have motor fibers running, medial&nbsp;</span>{{c1::cervical::cervical/sacral}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;→ lateral&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sacral::cervical/saral}}"	"<div>the opposite of hommonculus and DCML</div><img src=""background-information-musculoskeletal-key-within-spinal-cord-cross-section-tracts.jpg""><img src=""00878.jpeg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lateral spinothalamic:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Pain}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::thermal}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;sensation</span>"	"<img src=""dorsal-column-10-728.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Ventral spinothalamic:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">sensation of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::crude touch}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pressure}}"	"<img src=""dorsal-column-10-728.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Anterior corticospinal tract.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Motor:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Neck}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::trunk}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;movements</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_2.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">posterior columns&nbsp;</span>{{c1::light touch}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::vibration}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::concious proprioception}}<div><br></div><div>(Function)</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_2.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Radicular (segmental)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;arteries are branches of local arteries (vertebral, intercostals) that enter through the intervertebral foramina</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_4.png"">"																				
"{{c1::artery of Adamkiewicz}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;major blood supply to&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">lower two-thirds of the spinal cord</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">generally arises from the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::left intercostal::left/right name}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;artery at the level of</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;T9–L3&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<img src=""4723f937e8990051682aacdfc4bddcd77408ab5e.jpg""><img src=""1-s2.0-S0741521406005489-gr1.jpg""><img src=""Spinal-arterial-anatomy-showing-the-artery-of-Adamkiewicz-11.png""><div><br></div>"																				
"Flexion Injuries = {{c1::Vertebral body compression/ anterior wedge::2 fx names}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;fracture (commonly C5)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may project into the spinal canal (retropulsion), which may result in injury to the nerve root and/or cord</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">""not vertebral level, name of fx type""</font></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_13.png""><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_5.png"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>flexion / rotation injury</b>&nbsp;</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Unilateral facet dislocation.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::C5–C6::2 vertebrae level}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;most common level</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">un</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">stable if the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">posterior longitudinal ligament (</span>PLL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is disrupted</span></div>"	"&gt;50% vertebral body displaced and more likely complete when double facet vs single facet<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_6.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>hyper-extension</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::C4–C5::2 vertebrae}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the most commonly affected</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">stable injury:&nbsp;</span>{{c2::anterior longitudinal ligament}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may be disrupted</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may result in a&nbsp;</span>{{c3::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">central cord syndrome (</span>CCS)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_8.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Transverse Meylitis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: inflammation of the spinal cord with varying weakness, sensory, autonomic, and reflex abnormalities</span>"	"<img src=""Transverse-myelitis.jpg"">"																				
TRANSVERSE MYELITIS: prognosis rule of {{c1::1/3}}'s&nbsp;	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">one-third </span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">recover completely</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">one-third do not improve at all</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">one-third improve but with significant residual neurological deficit</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">NMO aka&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Devic’s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;disease&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">causes a combination of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::optic neuritis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::transverse myelitis}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">it is a fairly uncommon disease of the central nervous system (</span>CNS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) that affects the optic nerves and the spinal cord</span><div><img src=""Neuromyelitis Optica.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"epidural abscess prognosis:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">patients who are paraplegic or tetraplegic for over&nbsp;</span>{{c1::36}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;hours usually do not recover</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most common tumors that arise within the spinal cord (intradural) are&nbsp;</span>{{c1::primary::mets/primary}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;tumors</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most common tumors to involve the spinal canal (extradural) are&nbsp;</span>{{c1::metastatic::mets/primary}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;tumors&nbsp;</span></div>"	"mets are<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;approximately 25 times more prevalent than primary neoplasms</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Intradural neoplasms are further divided into those that are&nbsp;</span>{{c1::intramedullary}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, arising from the substance of the spinal cord&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::extramedullary}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;arising from elements extrinsic to the spinal cord</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Nerve sheath tumors, meningiomas, and filum terminale ependymomas account for most of primary extramedullary neoplasms and are usually considered benign and amenable to complete surgical resection</span><div><img src=""SpinalTumorTypes.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Glial tumors, such as&nbsp;</span>{{c1::astrocytomas}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ependymomas}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, represent up to 80% of <u>intramedullary</u> spinal cord tumors</span>"	"<img src=""paste-55129d0e7560f2487a7fbcaf645ab6cf88180433.jpg""><div>extramedullary: are shwanoa's and menigiomas&nbsp;</div>"																				
"{{c1::Extradural}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>tumors&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">are largely comprised of spinal metastases and primary bony tumors.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>"	"95% of spinal cancer&nbsp;<div><img src=""SpinalTumorTypes.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">extramedullary lesions are&nbsp;</span>{{c1::schwannomas/neurofibromas}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::meningiomas}}"	"<div>intra-medullary: astrocytoma and ependymoma&nbsp;</div><img src=""F3.large-4520b2b20859d604af394dd0f2f3f73ff714bfdf.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">There is a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lower::higher/lower}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;incidence of medical complications</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in patients with&nbsp;</span>NT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">-</span>SCI"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">spasticity, orthostasis, deep vein thrombosis (</span>DVT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">), pressure injuries, autonomic dysreflexia (</span>AD<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">), and wound infections during rehabilitation</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(</span>LOS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) are shorter for persons with&nbsp;</span>NT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;injury secondary to tumors, but (</span>FIM<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) and home discharge rates are overall comparable to traumatic&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Spinal Orthosis</b>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>most restrictive to least restrictive</u>&nbsp;</span></div>{{c4::Halo}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div>{{c5::Minerva}}<br></div><div>{{c1::four Poster}}</div><div>{{c2::SOMI}}</div><div>{{c3::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">head-cervical orthoses (</span>HCOs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}</div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">think alphabetical: H -&gt; M -&gt; P -&gt; S</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">SOMI sterno-occipital mandibular immobilizer</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(</span>HCOs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) are often used postsurgery in&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and include the Philadelphia</span><sup>®</sup><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, Aspen</span><sup>®</sup><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, Aspen Vista</span><sup>®</sup><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, Miami J</span><sup>®</sup><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and Johnson Malibu</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>halo<img src=""paste-398c594b0dc1dd2f3bcbe9e80409dbc80ba8e193.jpg"">minerva<img src=""paste-02b6f70b3d35133d3c3c1a3a5a648cb47eb1c47f.jpg"">four poster&nbsp;<img src=""paste-3b0026bff991f213726989c2c113c153b5d09f00.jpg"">somi<img src=""paste-d1209e556e77fb8965bb7cd86c670830b0615dfd.jpg""></div>"																				
"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_9.png""><br><div>{{c1::Jefferson}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;fracture of C</span>{{c1::1}}<br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rigid orthosis (i.e., Halo vest) if it is a stable fracture. Unstable fractures will require surgery</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Dens&nbsp; fracture of C2</b></span><div><font color=""#333333""><b><br></b></font><div>Type I: Fracture through the {{c1::tip of dens}}. {{c2::<u>No treatment</u> usually required::tx}}</div><div><br></div><div>Type II (most common): Fracture through the {{c1::base of odontoid}}. {{c3::Usually treated with a Halo vest, but <u>surgery may be required</u>::tx2}}</div></div><div><br><div>Type III: Fracture through the {{c1::odontoid into the vertebra}}. {{c4::Usually treated with a <u>Halo vest</u>. heals the best::tx2}}</div></div>"	"<div><img src=""7862tn.jpg""><br></div><br>"																				
"<div>{{c1::Chance}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;fracture</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_12.png""><br>"	seldom cuases neuro damage&nbsp;																				
"{{c1::Delayed plantar&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">response</span>}}<strong>&nbsp;</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is a</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pathologic reflex&nbsp;(first movement of great toe is flexion, adduction of the other toes)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Same area as for the Babinski sign but requires&nbsp;</span>{{c2::deep pressure}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">there is a high correlation with poor&nbsp;</span>{{c3::LE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;recovery</span>}}</div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Same area as for the Babinski sign but requires deep pressure rather than a light stimulus</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">there is a high correlation with complete injuries with poor prognosis for lower extremity (</span>LE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) recovery</span></div></div>"																				
"<b>Spinal Shock</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Initial reflex activity is noted within&nbsp;</span>{{c4::24}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;hrs</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">1st return of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::delayed plantar response}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;followed by the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::BCR}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and then&nbsp;</span>{{c3::anal wink}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">A positive Babinski sign may be noted at a later time</span><br></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Stage 3 of spinal shock</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Early hyperreflexia—on average, muscle stretch reflexes return after&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3 weeks}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Some reflexes (e.g., bladder) may not return for up to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::3 months}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(or later) after injury</span></div>"	Duration/Phases of Spinal Shock<div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Phase 1</strong>: Areflexia of all reflexes below&nbsp;SCI&nbsp;level, which typically lasts for 24 hours. Reflexes begin to return within 24 hours.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Phase 2</strong>: Initial reflex activity is noted, usually with the return of the delayed plantar response followed by the&nbsp;BCR&nbsp;and the anal wink. A positive Babinski sign may be noted at a later time.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Phase 3</strong>: Early hyperreflexia—on average, muscle stretch reflexes return after 2 to 3 weeks. Some reflexes (e.g., bladder) may not return for up to 3 months (or later) after injury.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Phase 4</strong>: Spasticity/Hyperreflexia—muscle stretch reflexes become hyperactive with the presence of pathologic reflexes below the lesion, resulting in spasticity.</div>																				
"<b>BCR/anal wink</b> reflex i<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">f not present by 24 hours,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::LMN}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;injury may be suspected</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_15.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Recovery from CCS</span><div><br></div><div>{{c1::LEs}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;recover first and to a greater extent. followed by improvement in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::bladder function}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, then proximal to distal&nbsp;</span>{{c1::UE<font color=""#333333"">s</font>}}</div>"	"<div>""down to up, in to out""</div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-08 at 11.24.10 AM.png"">"																				
"CCS&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">greater motor weakness in the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::upper limbs}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;than the opposite</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">variable loss of sensation, bowel, and bladder function</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">it was felt </span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">neuroanatomy of the corticospinal tract having a cervical distribution medially and sacral distribution laterally, thereby affecting UEs more </span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(more recently, </span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">felt to be a predominantly white matter injury)</span><div><img src=""paste-4bb10a8f4a5a518ad6c81bafb06440630c3bbb0c.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">SCI lesions above&nbsp;</span>{{c1::T8::vertebral level}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, cannot regulate and maintain normal body temperature</span>"	<strong>temp-eight-ture</strong>																				
"<b>Orthostatic HOTN mechanism</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Aortic/carotid baroreceptors}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;sense decrease in&nbsp;</span>BP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Brainstem}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;unable to send message through SCI&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">to cause sympathetic outflow and vasoconstriction of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::splanchnic bed}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">lessens with time due to development of spinal postural reflexes&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">allow for vasoconstriction due to improved autoregulation of cerebrovascular circulation in the presence of perfusion pressure</span><img src=""gr1_lrg-40c35f53dfca479bc121dbc32c2874e168aafa1e.jpg""></div>"																				
"<b>Autonomic dysreflexia MOA</b><div><br></div><div>{{c2::noxious stimuli}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cuases local relfex response 2/2&nbsp;</span>{{c2::hypersensitivity of receptors}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;below the level of the lesion</span><br><div><br></div><div>{{c1::brainstem}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;unable to send inhibitory sympathetic signal through&nbsp;</span>{{c1::intermediolateral column}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to allow vasodilation of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::splanchnic bed}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Bradycardia, while classic, is not always seen, and tachycardia, including arrhythmias (i.e., atrial fibrillation), may occur more frequently</span><div><img src=""Mechanism-of-autonomic-dysreflexia-in-a-person-with-spinal-cord-injury-at-the-level-of.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""1200px-Medulla_spinalis_-_Substantia_grisea_-_English.svg.png""><img src=""3-s2.0-B9780123858702000342-f34-04-9780123858702.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">AD Occurs after&nbsp;</span>{{c3::spinal shock}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and may appear within&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2 to 4::#-# range}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;weeks postinjury</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>If</b> it occurs in a patient, it will present within&nbsp;</span>{{c2::the 1st year}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in &gt;90% of cases</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">SCI UDS:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lower motor neuron}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;bladder dysfunction</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_24.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<strong>1</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. Absent bulbocavernosus reflex.&nbsp;</span><strong>2</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. Major detrusor contractions are absent.&nbsp;</span><strong>3</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. No pelvic floor muscle activity external urethral sphincter.&nbsp;</span><strong>4</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. Large bladder capacity.</span>"																				
"SCI UDS {{c1::complete UMN uninhibited}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;neurogenic bladder dysfunction</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_25.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"eg. CVA/TBI<div><strong>1</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. Brisk bulbocavernosus reflex.&nbsp;</span><strong>2</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. Spontaneous detrusor contraction at reduced bladder capacity.&nbsp;</span><strong>3</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. Silence of pelvic floor muscles external urethral sphincter.</span><br></div>"																				
"SCI UDS {{c1::Detrusor/external urethral sphincter dyssynergia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;bladder dysfunction&nbsp;</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_26b.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">1. Brisk bulbocavernosus reflex. 2. Bladder capacity is reduced. 3. High intravesical pressure during detrusor contraction. 4. Detrusor/external urethral sphincter dyssynergia with marked electrical activity of the pelvic floor muscles during detrusor contraction.</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Bladder wall&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hypertrophy}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp; can make vesicoureteral junction become incompetent, permitting reflux of urine</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">causes the course of the distal ureter to become progressively perpendicular to the inner surface of the bladder</span><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_27.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">SCI UTI complication&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">— earliest change: ir</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">regular,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::thickened}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;bladder wall and small diverticuli</span>"	"<ul><li><div><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); background: var(--field-bg);"">VUR: 10% to 30% of poorly managed bladders leads to pyelonephritis, renal stones.</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); background: var(--field-bg);"">Hydronephrosis and hydroureters caused by outlet obstruction</span></div><div><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); background: var(--field-bg);"">Overdistended, areflexic bladder</span></div><div><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); background: var(--field-bg);"">Reduced bladder compliance</span></div><div><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); background: var(--field-bg);"">Kidney and bladder stones</span></div></li></ul>"																				
"SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may obtain <u>reflexogenic</u> erections</span><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Occur in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::&gt;90}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of men with complete and incomplete&nbsp;</span>UMN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;lesions;&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">up to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::25}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% with complete&nbsp;</span>LMN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">independently of conscious awareness and supraspinal input</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">secondary to manual stimulation of the genital region (however, once stimulation has been removed, the erection may no longer be sustained</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may obtain&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>psychogenic</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;erections</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Present in approximately&nbsp;</span>{{c1::50}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of men with incomplete&nbsp;</span>UMN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;lesions</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::25}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% with complete&nbsp;</span>LMN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;lesion</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">effects from erotic stimuli that result in cortical modulation of the sacral reflex ar</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Not usually seen in patients with complete&nbsp;</span>UMN"																				
"SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, the ability to <u>ejaculate</u> is less than the ability to obtain an erection</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Approximately&nbsp;</span>{{c1:: 10% (~5% to 15)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of men with complete&nbsp;</span>UMN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;lesions</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and&nbsp;</span>{{c1:: 20% (~18)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% with complete&nbsp;</span>LMN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;lesions have ejaculations</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Sperm retrieval in SCI men who are unable to ejaculate</span><br><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">1.)&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Penile vibratory stimulation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">2.)&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Electroejaculation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">3.)&nbsp;</span>{{c3::Surgical sperm removal}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Immediately following&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, amenorrhea occurs in 85% of women</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">return of menstruation within&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6 to 12::#-# range}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months after injury</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">likelihood of pregnancy after&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::unchanged::&gt;/=/&lt;}}"																					
"AD in pregnancy t<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">reatment of choice is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::epidural anesthesia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">extending to T10 level (</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Uterine innervation arises)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">12 hours after the delivery or until&nbsp;</span>AD<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;resolves</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<span style=""caret-color: rgb(51, 51, 51); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">intrinsic e</span>nteric}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>nervous system&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is composed of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Auerbach}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">’s (myenteric; primarily&nbsp;</span>{{c3::motor}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Meissner}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">’s (submucosal; primarily&nbsp;</span>{{c3::sensory}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">main division of the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system"">autonomic nervous system</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;(ANS)&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">It is capable of acting independently of the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sympathetic_nervous_system"">sympathetic</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parasympathetic_nervous_system"">parasympathetic nervous systems</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">, although it may be influenced by them</span><br></div><img src=""_-9b2248ad808418fb60ff5a6ced50a6cd9dfe397a.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">PS GI innervations is via the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::vagus nerve}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;which innervates proximal to mid-transverse colon</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pelvic nerve}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;which originate from S2–S4 and innervates the descending colon and rectum</span></div>"	"<div>pelvic aka&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">splanchnic nerves</span></div><img src=""Previous-studies-and-GI-parasympathetic-innervation-Parasympathetic-innervation-of-the.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Sympathetic GI innervation projects through the hypogastric nerve via&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">pre-vertebral</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;ganglia</span>}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">celiac,</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;superior mesenteric, and inferior mesenteric</span><br></div><div><img src=""3-s2.0-B0123868602006808-gr1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">somatic innervation from the pudendal nerve (S2–S4), which gives volitional control to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::EAS::SCI GI}}"	"IAS is smooth muscle under control of S and PS&nbsp;<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig7_28.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>UMN</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>&nbsp;lesion</b> such as&nbsp;</span>SCI causing <b>neurogenic bowel</b><div><br></div><div>EAS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cannot be voluntarily relaxed with such injuries, and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pelvic floor}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;muscles become spastic</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">nerve connections between the spinal cord and colon, as well as&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Auerbach’s (myenteric)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;plexus, remain intact.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Stool still propelled by reflex activity</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""maxresdefault-e9bdc465a2686218c8cfdb9a7c14f4e7b1471b2b.jpg"">"																				
"<b>LMN</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>&nbsp;lesion</b> (eg.&nbsp;</span>Cauda Equina) <b>neurogenic bowel</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Auerbach’s (myenteric) plexus coordinates the movement of stool. However,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::movement is slower}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Overall, constipation results with incontinence due to flaccid&nbsp;</span>{{c2::EAS}}<br></div>"																					
"{{c1::ADYNAMIC ILEUS aka GASTRIC ATONY::GI complication}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Occurs in approximately half of&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;patients, resulting from spinal shock</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Adynamic ileus usually presents immediately following&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(can be delayed 24–48 hours) and typically resolves within 1 week</span>"																				
"<b>Adynamic ileus treatment&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Nasogastric tube}}</div><div>{{c2::IV fluids / NPO::2}}</div><div>{{c3::Parenteral nutrition}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: var(--field-fg); font-family: -apple-system-body; background: var(--field-bg);"">if &gt;3 days</span></div><div>{{c4::metoclopromide / erythromycin::2}}</div><div>{{c5::Neostigmine}}</div>"	<div>Management:</div><div><br></div><div>Nasogastric tube (NGT) suction to prevent&nbsp;GI&nbsp;dilation and respiratory compromise for persistent abdominal distention</div><div>IV fluids</div><div>Parenteral nutrition if &gt;3 days</div><div>If longer, metoclopromide and/or erythromycin can be used to stimulate peristalsis if other interventions are unsuccessful (metoclopromide works primarily in the stomach)</div><div>Neostigmine for refractory cases of pseudo-obstruction</div>																				
"<b>SCI GI complications</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">If cecum is dilated&nbsp;</span>{{c1::&gt;12}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cm, consider&nbsp;</span>{{c2::GI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and Surgical&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">consults</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">::2</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"risk for <font color=""#fc0006"">ischemia/perforation</font><div>""stat consult"" if can't be seen or&nbsp;<u>direct transfer</u>, SEND OUT!</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">senna stimulate peristalsis by acting on&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Auerbach’s plexus (primarily motor)}}"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Bisacodyl (Dulcolax</span><sup>®</sup><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) is in an oil base that stimulates peristalsis and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sensory nerve endings}}"																					
"Gastrocolic reflex: SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pts instructed to perform bowel program&nbsp;</span>{{c1::30 minutes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after a meal</span>"	20 to 30 minutes																				
"{{c1::Suppositories and digital stimulation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;take advantage of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::rectocolic reflex}}"																					
<div><b>{{c1::SMA syndrome}}&nbsp;</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Predisposing factors include:</u></div><div>{{c4::Rapid weight loss}} decrease in protective fatty layer</div><div>{{c3::Prolonged supine}}. position&nbsp;common in tetraplegia.</div><div>{{c5::Spinal orthosis}} often presribed after spinal surgery</div><div>{{c2::Flaccid abdominal wall}} causes hyperextension of the back.</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Any condition that decreases the normal distance between the&nbsp;</span>SMA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and aorta&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(weight loss, supine position, Halo, flaccid abdominal wall)&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may result in compression of the duodenum, described as the nutcracker effect</span></div>"																				
"SMA syndrome <span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Diagnosis:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Upper gastrointestinal (</span>UGI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) series::text book answer</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">demonstrates abrupt <b>duodenal</b> obstruction <u>to barium flow</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div>&nbsp;A series of x-ray pictures of the upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including <b>the throat, esophagus, stomach, and the first part of the small intestine (duodenum)</b>. The x-ray pictures are taken after the patient drinks a liquid that contains barium sulfate (a silver-white metallic compound). &nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><img src=""paste-6fb10cb774f4499fcaf728e38a17cfc6c55092e1.jpg""><br></div>"

"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Glycerin suppositories:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Draw water}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;into stool and stretches rectal wall</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hypercalcemia usally appears&nbsp;</span>{{c1::4 to 8::2# range}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;weeks after&nbsp;</span>SCI/TBI"																					
"SCI hypercalcemia treatment&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Pamidronate}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is administered as a single IV infusion rapidly lowers serum calcium within 3 days</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(60 mg × 4 hours to 90 mg × 24 hours, depending on severity of hypercalcemia)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Can be repeated if needed</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The IV fluids can be discontinued 2 to 3 days after pamidronate is completed</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">limb fractures in SCI frequently treated with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::soft padded splints}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(e.g., a well-padded knee immobilizer for femoral supracondylar, femoral shaft, and proximal tibial fractures;&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and a well-padded ankle immobilizer for distal tibial fractures)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""#0b6aff"">depends on wether they are truly wt bearing or even use the limb for transfers</font></div><div><font color=""#0b6aff""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#0b6aff"">still obtain xray and send to ER/ortho etc</font></div>"																				
"{{c1::inability to clear secretions}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in </span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is a key factor in the development of pulmonary complications such as atelectasis and pneumonia</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">C3–C4: Respiratory failure secondary to disruption of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::diaphragmatic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;innervation, usually requiring&nbsp;</span>MV<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;early after injury.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">May be able to wean off ventilator</span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-02-06 at 11.32.30 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Injuries above&nbsp;</span>{{c1::C8}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Loss of all abdominal and intercostal muscles, impairment of inspiration and expiration (<u>mucous clr</u>)</span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-02-06 at 11.32.30 AM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">T1 through T5:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Intercostal m.}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;volitional function is lost (muscles of breathing)</span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-02-06 at 11.32.30 AM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">T5 through T12: Progressive loss of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::abdominal m.}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;function, impairing forceful expiration or cough</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">rectus abdominus, transversus abdominus, internal and external obliques (T4–L2)</span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-02-06 at 11.32.30 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"

INSPIRATORY MUSCLES<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Diaphragm}}</div><div>{{c2::External intercostals}}</div><div>{{c3::Accessory muscles: scalenes, SCM, trapezius::3}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-02-06 at 11.32.30 AM.png"">"																				
EXPIRATORY MUSCLES<div><br></div><div>{{c3::pectoralis major}}</div><div>{{c1::Internal intercostals}}</div><div>{{c2::Abdominal muscles}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>	"Abdominal muscles are primarily active during forceful expiration and coughing. "<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Inspiration in lung with insult to the phrenic nerve (opposite for nl lung)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">diaphragm moves&nbsp;</span>{{c1::up}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and abdomen moves&nbsp;</span>{{c1::in}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_30.png"">"																				
"<div>Tetraplegics usually develop {{c1::restrictive::obs/res}}<span style=""font-style: italic;"">&nbsp;lung patterns</span></div><div><br></div><div>All volumes shrink except {{c2::residual volume}}</div>"	"<img src=""Lungvolumes_Updated.png"">"																				
<div><b>Mechanically ventilate SCI when:</b></div><div><br></div><div>VC&nbsp;&lt;{{c1::1 L}}</div><div>PO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;&lt;{{c2::50}} mmHg</div><div>PCO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;&gt;{{c2::50}} mmHg</div><div>Severe {{c3::atelectasis}}</div><div>Decreased&nbsp;FVC&nbsp;&lt;{{c4::15 mL/kg}} body weight</div><div>RR &gt;{{c5::25-30}}</div>	"RR elevated RR may be the most important predictor<div>(25-30 more of a guidline for when to extubate)</div><div><img src=""https://medicine.uiowa.edu/iowaprotocols/sites/medicine.uiowa.edu.iowaprotocols/files/Lung%2520volumes.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">SCI pulm complication: once F</span>VC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;&gt;</span>{{c1::15 to 20::2#'s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;mL/kg, the individual can usually wean off ventilator</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">FVC and VC record similar information—</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">they both measure the amount of air you can&nbsp;</span><b>exhale</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">&nbsp;after maximally inhaling.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">But FVC refers to the amount of air you can exhale forcefully,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">while VC records the maximum amount of air exhaled when breathing normally.</span><br></div><img src=""Example-respiratory-measurements-highlighting-Forced-Vital-Capacity-FVC-Vital.png"">"																				
"{{c1::quad cough}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;— placing hand sides of upper abdomen applying pressure coordinated with cough&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>

aka&nbsp;{{c1::Manual cough assist}}&nbsp;&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">suctioning may cause increased vagal tone leading to bradycardia, only suction when you&nbsp;</span>{{c1::withdraw catheter}}<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Suctioning does not adequately clear the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::left}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;lung</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">due to the left main stem bronchus branching off at a 40-degree to 50-degree angle&nbsp;</span><div><img src=""paste-36e701310d031ecd1b9922a73a5fb6d049974a0c.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::insufflation–exsufflation}}<span style=""caret-color: rgb(51, 51, 51); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;machine Aka&nbsp;</span>{{c1::cough assist}}<span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);"">&nbsp;clear secretions by applying a positive pressure, then quickly switch to a negative pressure</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">insufflation–exsufflation machine, prefferd by pt&nbsp;</span><br></div><img src=""paste-42dfc5f8f83001023cd74eae75db5674cb55d6f4.jpg""><img src=""images-6e811968f8164e848ac6c794aaa050ecf09edc06.jpg"">"																				
"{{c1::Glossopharyngeal breathing}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">—stroking air into lungs w/ lips, soft palate, mouth, tongue, pharynx, and larynx, followed by passive exhalation</span>"																					
"cough assist <u>c</u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>ontraindicated</u> in patients with susceptibility to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pneumothorax}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">history of bullous emphysema, pneumo-mediastinum, or known to have had any recent barotraum</span>"																				
"{{c1::Pneumobelt}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">—helps with exhalation. Inflatable, compresses the abdominal wall, diaphragm rises, and active respiration is produced</span>"	"<img src=""m_tobi3_c017f005.png""><img src=""2017_B_LunaBelt.webp"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Use of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::bronchodilators}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;an (med) adjunct of therapy facilitates secretion management and reversal of atelectasis in patients with acute&nbsp;</span>SCI"																					
{{c1::pneumovest}} = machine version of chest PT that uses high frequency osscilations&nbsp;	"It dislodges mucus from the bronchial walls, and helps move secretions and mucus from smaller to larger airways, where it can be coughed or suctioned out<div><img src=""Vest105_ai0372_0557_OL_Shad.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Useful indices for weaning include maximum inspiratory pressure (</span>MIP {or NIF}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) −</span>{{c1::20}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cm H</span><sub>2</sub><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">O or more negative</span>"	"<div>-60 is nl.</div><img src=""paste-070a2401489f697abdf2eb6aa852f52f0e99e669.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">use of higher tidal volumes in the range of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::15 to 20::#-#}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;mL/kg in patients with&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;had been recommended</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">use of these larger tidal volumes from usual can be applied without any increase in side effects</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">as long as pressure plateaus are maintained below 30 cm H</span><sub>2</sub><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">O to prevent atelectasis&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and the patient does not have adult respiratory distress syndrome</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">method with the highest success rates for weaning off&nbsp;</span>MV in SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::progressive free breathing}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">with or without the use of positive end-expiratory positive pressure (</span>PEEP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">; 5 cm H</span><sub>2</sub><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">O or less)</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>two types of pacing available:</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(a)&nbsp;</span>{{c1::phrenic nerve}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(b)&nbsp;</span>{{c2::direct diaphragmatic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""gr1-a373b7cbd318e82dbfb94b843be876903689b532.jpg""><img src=""what-is-a-diaphragm-pacing-system.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>phrenic nerve pacing (or diaphragmatic pacing)</b><br></div><div><br></div>{{c1::EMG<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of diaphragm::dx test</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is important to rule out damage to the phrenic nerve nucleus if considering pacing for ventilation</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>may be a candidate:</u>&nbsp;(No damage):&nbsp;Lesions affecting {{c2::C2 and above}}&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>NOT&nbsp;a candidate:</u>&nbsp;(Yes damage):&nbsp;Lesions affecting {{c2::C3–C5}}</div>"	"<div><strong><u>No damage to phrenic nerve nucleus</u></strong></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Lesion above the phrenic nerve nucleus innervation (C2 and above)</strong></div><div><br></div><div>Diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerve (C3–C5) (nerve roots “C3, C4, C5 keep you alive”).</div><div><br></div><div>Lesion affecting the phrenic nerve can be determined by electrodiagnostic studies including nerve conduction of the phrenic nerve or&nbsp;EMG&nbsp;of the diaphragm.</div><div><br></div><div>If phrenic nerve nuclei are intact and an&nbsp;<u><font color=""#fc0009"">UMN&nbsp;injury</font></u> occurs, the patient <u>may be a candidate</u> for phrenic nerve or diaphragmatic pacing. See “Phrenic Nerve Pacing” and “Diaphragmatic Pacing”.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong><u>Damage to the phrenic nerve</u></strong></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Lesions affecting C3–C5 nerve roots or phrenic nerve nucleus</strong></div><div><br></div><div>Determined by electrodiagnostic studies as previously noted</div><div><br></div><div>If there is a&nbsp;<u><font color=""#fc0006"">LMN&nbsp;injury</font></u> to the phrenic nerve, the patient is&nbsp;<u>NOT&nbsp;a candidate</u> for phrenic nerve pacing unless nerve grafts are utilized.</div>"																				
"OSA in SCI<br><br><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Optimal work-up would include&nbsp;</span>{{c1::overnight oximetry}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, followed by a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sleep study}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, if abnormal</span><br></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">HO: most common joint involved in&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Hip}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hip #1 in TBI also&nbsp;</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(anteromedial aspects) followed by the knee/shoulder/elbow</span><br><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(in order of occurrence)</span><br></div><div><img src=""Progressive-extent-of-heterotopic-ossification-around-the-right-hip-is-seen-tracking-down.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
SCI/TBI HO usualy occurs at {{c1::2 months}} post injury&nbsp;	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The 1 to 3 months status post-injury is most common; peak at 2 months</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">can present after first 6 months.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">When occurs after 1 year, is usually associated with an acute fracture,&nbsp;</span>DVT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, or pressure injury. Usually has a more benign course</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::triple phase bone scan}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;for&nbsp;</span>HO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the most sensitive for diagnosis</span>"	"<div>flow, blood pool, bone</div><img src=""c3e0ef839186387c12f56dfb3911b5_jumbo.jpeg"">"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">HO&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">PLAIN X-RAYS</span></b></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Plain film detects&nbsp;</span>HO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after at least&nbsp;</span>{{c1::10 days}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after clinical signs are observed</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>Require {{c2::3}} weeks to {{c2::2}} months postinjury to reveal&nbsp;HO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div>Useful to confirm {{c3::maturity}} of&nbsp;HO<br></div>"	<div>same for TBI/SCI</div>

"{{c1::FES::therapy modality}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is a relative contraindication during the <u>acute phase</u> of&nbsp;</span>HO"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">HO bisphosphonate tx dose may be based upon the initial&nbsp;</span>{{c1::CPK}} and {{c1::CRP}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;blood test result</span>"	<div>Normal&nbsp;CPK: Etidronate 20 mg/kg/day × 3 months, and then 10 mg/kg/day for another 3 months</div><div><br></div><div>Elevated&nbsp;CPK: etidronate 20 mg/kg/day × 6 months</div><div><br></div><div>In addition, some recommend that if&nbsp;CPK&nbsp;is elevated (or&nbsp;CRP&nbsp;&gt;8), etidronate is used in high dose in addition to&nbsp;NSAIDs&nbsp;(e.g., naproxen 375 mg&nbsp;TID&nbsp;or indomethacin 75 mg/day).&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>When&nbsp;CRP&nbsp;&lt;2 or&nbsp;CPK&nbsp;normalizes, the individual can stop&nbsp;NSAIDs&nbsp;and continue etidronate for 6 months.</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Monitor&nbsp;</span>{{c1::phosphate}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;levels if using a bisphosphonate for HO</span>"																					
"PE&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gold standard dx</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Pulmonary arteriogram}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">Pulmonary angiography is medical fluoroscopic procedure used to visualize the pulmonary arteries and much less frequently, the pulmonary veins. Conventional pulmonary angiography is a minimally invasive procedure performed most frequently by an interventional radiologist or interventional cardiologist</span><br><div><img src=""c015_f001.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">SCD's if placement</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;delayed &gt;</span>{{c2::72}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;hours, you MUST&nbsp;</span>{{c1::doppler u/s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;before putting on compression devices</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">venous duplex scan&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">rule out&nbsp;</span>DVT"

Can still use mechanical devices.</span>"																				
SCI pt going to OR for fusion hold {{c1::one dose::time frame}} chemoprophylaxis	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hold dose morning of surgery and resume the next day</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">A box warning exists regarding the risk of spinal or epidural hematoma formation in patients who receive&nbsp;</span>LMWH<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. (Important to clear with surgeon when&nbsp;</span>LMWH<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;can be initiated if patient has undergone spinal surgery.</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch07#bid_7_3"">Consortium for Spinal Cord Medicine (2016)</a><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;clinical practice guidelines recommend&nbsp;</span>{{c1::LMWH}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to be initiated as acute care chemoprophylaxis&nbsp;</span>"																					
<div><strong>Indications for mechanoprophylaxis (IVC&nbsp;filter)</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Failed anticoagulant*}}</div><div>{{c3::+DVT &amp; Contraindication to chemo-ppx}}</div><div>High-level complete tetraplegia with {{c1::poor cardiopulmonary reserve}}</div>	only indicated for&nbsp;PE&nbsp;prophylaxis. Does not prevent&nbsp;DVT&nbsp;formation<div><br></div><div>only after DVT is found.&nbsp; Not prophylactic</div><div><br></div><div>*VTE on anticoagulant (controversy if shortly after initiation) !switch to Warfarin/LMWH</div>																				
"<div><strong>Duration of&nbsp;DVT&nbsp;prophylaxis in&nbsp;SCI</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div><u>Incomplete&nbsp;SCI&nbsp;and ambulating:</u></div><div>{{c1::continue until discharge}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Complete&nbsp;SCI:</u></div><div>Continue at least {{c2::8 weeks}} post-injury in {{c3::complete motor injury <font color=""#fc0006"">[AIS A/B]</font> (uncomplicated) or incomplete <font color=""#fc0006"">[C/D]</font> (not ambulatory)::2}}</div><div>Continue at least {{c2::12 weeks}} post-injury in {{c3::complete motor injury&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(252, 0, 6);"">[AIS A/B]&nbsp;</span>(w/ other risk factors)}}&nbsp;</div>"	"risk factors = lower limb fracture, history of thrombosis, cancer, heart failure, obesity, or age &gt;70<div><br></div><div><div>

<div><b>SCI Consortium (<font color=""#fc0006"">conflict</font>??)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>The optimal duration of thromboprophylaxis
following SCI remains unclear,</div><div><br></div><div>we recommend that ppx be provided for a minimum of <b>8
weeks</b> after SCI associated with <u>limited mobility</u></div><div><br></div><div>Factors suggesting
longer duration of ppx include: <u>motor
complete injuries</u>, lower-extremity fractures, older
age, previous VTE, cancer, and obesity.&nbsp;</div>
