"SCI pt with&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">proximal&nbsp;</span>DVT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">OAC treatment continued for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Same as in non-sci pt</span><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::LE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;venogram</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the gold standard dx for&nbsp;</span>LE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>DVTs"	"<em>Venography</em><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">&nbsp;is an x-ray examination that uses an injection of contrast material to show how blood flows through your veins.</span><div><img src=""gr1_lrg.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div><strong>Electrical Stimulation (E-Stim) (or&nbsp;FES) in&nbsp;SCI&nbsp;Has 2 General Uses</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>to avoid complications of {{c1::muscle inactivity}}</div><div><br></div><div>producing extremity motion for {{c2::functional activities}}</div>	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png"">&nbsp;FES&nbsp;can be used to provide a <u>cardiovascular conditioning program</u></div><div><br></div><div>Increase muscle bulk, strength, and endurance</div><div><br></div><div>Produce motion for&nbsp;UE&nbsp;activity, bladder function, standing, and ambulation</div><div><img src=""rt300-gentleman-demonstrating-fes-system-from-his-wheelchair.jpg""><img src=""2018-01-22-8-51-08-160-5a664ebc2a1ea20bc83fa4e2.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"chronic SCI report MSK<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pain: most common joint is the</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::shoulder}}"	<div>usually due to use as a weight-bearing joint and overuse syndromes:</div><div><br></div><div><u>Ddx</u></div><div>Tendonitis/bursitis</div><div>Rotator cuff impingement/tear</div><div>Impingement syndrome</div><div>Subacromial bursitis</div><div>Capsulitis</div><div>Myofascial pain</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">SCI <u>neuropathic pain</u>&nbsp;that&nbsp;</span>{{c2::1st appears}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, or&nbsp;</span>{{c2::changes significantly in character/severity}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;&gt;</span>{{c3::1}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;year after injury</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">a thorough evaluation should take place to search for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::treatable causes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>treatable causes of neuropathic pain:</u></span><div><font color=""#333333"">peripheral nerve entrapment (CTS)<br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">nerve root compression&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">spinal cord compression&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">tethering</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">syringomyelia</span></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Guidelines for management of SCI neuropathic pain include the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::CanPain}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Clinical Practice Guidelines</span>"	"<table><tbody><tr><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">RECOMMENDATION</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">FIRST LINE</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">SECOND LINE</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">THIRD LINE</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">FOURTH LINE</th></tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Strong recommendation</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Pregabalin<br><br>Gabapentin<br><br>Amitriptyline (TCAs)</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Tramadol<br><br>Lamotrigine (for incomplete cord lesion)</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&nbsp;</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&nbsp;</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Weak recommendation</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&nbsp;</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&nbsp;</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">tDCS + VI</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">TENS<br><br>Oxycodone<br><br>DREZ&nbsp;ablation</td></tr></tbody></table>"																				
<u>Duration/Phases of Spinal Shock</u><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Phase 1</strong>: {{c1::Areflexia}}&nbsp;</div><div><strong>Phase 2</strong>: {{c2::Initial reflex activity (eg. BCR)::+1 ex.}}&nbsp;</div><div><strong>Phase 3</strong>: {{c3::Early hyperreflexia (eg. muscle stretch reflex)}}</div><div><strong>Phase 4</strong>: {{c4::Spasticity/Hyperreflexia}}</div>	<div><strong>Phase 1</strong>: Areflexia of all reflexes below&nbsp;SCI&nbsp;level, which typically lasts for 24 hours. Reflexes begin to return within 24 hours.</div><div><strong>Phase 2</strong>: Initial reflex activity is noted, usually with the return of the delayed plantar response followed by the&nbsp;BCR&nbsp;and the anal wink. A positive Babinski sign may be noted at a later time.</div><div><strong>Phase 3</strong>: Early hyperreflexia—on average, muscle stretch reflexes return after 2 to 3 weeks. Some reflexes (e.g., bladder) may not return for up to 3 months (or later) after injury.</div><div><strong>Phase 4</strong>: Spasticity/Hyperreflexia—muscle stretch reflexes become hyperactive with the presence of pathologic reflexes below the lesion, resulting in spasticity.</div>																				
"<b>SCI Visceral / Nociceptive Pain</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Dull, aching, or cramping type pain&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">located in the thorax or abdomen</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>always consider the ddx:</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::UTI}}</div><div>{{c2::nephrolithiasis}}</div><div>{{c3::impaction}}</div><div>{{c4::appendicitis*}}</div>"	*and other surgical emergency eg acute cholesystitis&nbsp;																				
"{{c1::Pregabalin}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the only medication FDA approved for the indication of neuropathic pain in&nbsp;</span>SCI"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">carpal tunnel syndrome (</span>CTS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) pt's with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::paraplegia::para/tetra}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are more affected&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Nearly <b>two-thirds</b> of patients with&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;develop&nbsp;</span>UE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;compression neuropathie</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Increases with the length of time from injury&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most commonly median and ulnar neuropathies</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most common cause of progressive myelopathy after a&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::post-traumatic syringomyelia}}"	"<b>development of a fluid-filled cyst (syrinx) within spinal cord</b><div><img src=""paste-a813b23780bde318d2055e84d18ca66c4e1e9e80.jpg""><b><br></b></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Syrinx mechanism:</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::subarachnoid scarring}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;with resultant obstruction of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::CSF<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;flow</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Reactive ependymal cell proliferation causes segmental closures in the canal, with distention and movement of&nbsp;</span>CSF<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;into the gray matter of the spinal cord</span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-18 at 3.43.58 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Cavitation of the spinal cord usually begins at&nbsp;</span>{{c1::the level of the injury}}<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">progresses in a&nbsp;</span>{{c2::cephalad and caudal direction::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">cephalad or caudal direction</span>}}</div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Post-traumatic syringomyelia&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Most common presenting symptom is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pain}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Aching or burning, often worse with <u>coughing</u>, sneezing, straining, and usually in the <u>sitting</u> rather than in the supine position</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Post-traumatic syringomyelia</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Most common</u> presenting <u>Phys-ex</u> sign is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ascending loss of&nbsp;</span>DTRs}}</div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Other exam findings include</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Ascending sensory level loss}}&nbsp;<br></div><div>{{c2::pain/temp loss ""cape-like"" (<b>Dissociated sensory loss</b>)}}<br></div><div>{{c3::Weakness}}&nbsp;</div></div><div>↑ or ↓ {{c3::spasticity}}</div><div>{{c4::Horner’s}} syndrome<br></div>"	"<div>Ascending sensory level loss is common<br></div><div><b><u>Dissociated sensory loss</u></b> (<font color=""#fc0006"">impaired pain and temperature sensation</font> but intact light touch, etc. ""cape like"")<br></div><div>Weakness occurs but rarely in isolation (ant. horn cell injury)<br></div><div>Horner's: damage to lateral horn&nbsp;</div><div>Additional findings: hyperhidrosis,&nbsp;AD, loss of reflex bladder, worsening HO,&nbsp;reduced respiratory drive, diaphragmatic paralysis, <u>CN</u> dysfunction<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-22 at 2.38.47 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Posttraumatic syringomyelia one&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Additional finding&nbsp;</span>{{c1::↑ spasticity}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Additional findings: ↑ or ↓ spasticity, hyperhidrosis,&nbsp;</span>AD<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, loss of reflex bladder, worsening heteotopic ossification, new Horner’s syndrome, reduced respiratory drive, diaphragmatic paralysis, cranial nerve dysfunction</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Posttraumatic syringomyelia&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">gold standard dx&nbsp;</span>{{c1::MRI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;with gadolinium::test &amp; specifier</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""images-52c56fc33375c01084338ec2827fd67a191880be.jpg""><img src=""paste-0816ba653f731d3af9225fa447aadb6b1b36e1b0.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Posttraumatic syringomyelia</b></span><div><br></div><div>Indications for surgery include {{c1::progressive neurological decline}} or {{c2::severe intractable pain}}</div><div><br></div><div>most common surgical intervention is {{c3::shunting}}&nbsp;<br></div>"	"<div>ex. syringo-subarachnoid, syringo-pleural, or syringo-peritoneal</div><div><br></div><div>followed by reconstruction of the subarachnoid space with dissection of arachnoiditis/meningeal scarring, and duraplasty.</div><div><img src=""large.png""><br></div><div><img src=""full-2020.12.SPINE201826f6.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Typical Syrinx tx includes</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Close monitoring with {{c3::neuro-checks}} and {{c3::serial MRI's}}</div><div><br></div><div>as well as {{c1::symptomatic relief}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and {{c2::activity restrictions}}</div>	Avoid maneuvers that <b>↑ intrathoracic/abdominal pressure</b>, such as...&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>weight lifting; anterior weight shifts; and Valsalva, Crede, and quad coughing</div><div><br></div><div>especially if these <u>exacerbate symptoms</u></div>																				
SCI w/ syringomeylia&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Avoid activites that {{c1::↑ intrathoracic/abdominal pressure}} such as...&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::weight lifting}}</div><div>{{c1::Crede}}<br></div><div>{{c1::quad coughing}}<br></div>	Avoid maneuvers that ↑ intrathoracic/abdominal pressure, such as...<div><br><div>weight lifting; anterior weight shifts; and Valsalva, Crede,&nbsp;<u>especially if these exacerbate symptoms.</u></div></div>																				
"{{c1::Charcot spine}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Spinal trauma and analgesia below the level of injury causes</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;joint destruction</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">rare progressive disorder of vertebral joint degeneration that occurs in the setting of any condition characterized by decreased afferent innervation</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">&nbsp;with loss of deep pain and proprioceptive sensation in the vertebral column</span><div><img src=""JCVJS-9-9-g001.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); background-color: rgb(255, 252, 240);"">Sagittal computed tomography (a) and magnetic resonance imaging (b) demonstrated bony destruction affecting L3 and L4 consistent with a Charcot spine</span><br></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Colon layer location</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Auerbach’s:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::muscularis propria}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Meissner’s:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::submucosa}}</div>"	"<br><div><img src=""11841""><img src=""dcb84006e37327c85bfb78c520e346f1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::tendon transfer}} procedure<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is when a functioning muscle and its tendon are rerouted into tendon of paralyzed muscle&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""tendon+transfer+-+edited+copy+2+watermarked.png"">"																				
"{{c1::nerve transfer}} procedure<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;a motor fascicle/branch, typically from a major peripheral nerve, is cut and coapted into the motor fascicle/branch of a paralyzed muscle</span>"	"<img src=""nerve+transfer+edited+3+copy+watermarked.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Tendon transfers are generally delayed for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::1 year}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to allow neurological stabilization</span>"																					
<div>Components of preoperative evaluation for tendon transfers:</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Strength}}</div><div>{{c1::Sensation}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::ROM}}</div><div>{{c2::Spasticity}}</div><div>{{c3::Behavioral evaluation}}</div>	"<div><b>Components of preoperative evaluation for tendon transfers:</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Strength</u>: Including shoulder (needed for hand placement). See Modified International Classification of the Upper Limb in Tetraplegia given in&nbsp;<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch07#tab7_12"">Table 7–12</a>.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Sensation</u>: Weber two-point discrimination test at pulp of thumb (Grade of O-Cu or simply O) given based on ability or inability to distinguish objects &lt;10 mm apart, respectively. A grade of O-Cu is predictive of sufficient proprioception to allow hand function without visual cues for ease of&nbsp;ADLs.</div><div><br></div><div><u>ROM</u>: Including shoulder (needed for hand placement, and in consideration for posterior deltoid or biceps to triceps transfers); hand/wrist (ROM&nbsp;should be full for all procedures involving the hand).</div><div><br></div><div><u>Spasticity</u>: Should be minimal or absent in proposed transfer muscles.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Behavioral evaluation</u>: Extremely important, as recovery phase involves immobilization, restriction of previously noted activities, and potential need for more assistance from caregivers.</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">muscles with a grade of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or less are not considered for transfer</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">because muscles being transferred generally lose 1 strength grade</span>"																				
"<b>Tendon Transfer C5</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Brachioradialis to ECRB::2 muscles}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: wrist extension (improve lifting objects, feeding, grooming, hygiene)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::Deltoid to triceps::2 muscles}}&nbsp; <span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">transferring, pressure relief</span></div>"																					
"<b>Tendon Transfer C6</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::Brachioradialis to FPL::2 muscles}}<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Restore lateral pinch /</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;grasp&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Provides better function and preferable to Moberg or ""</span>{{c2::key grip}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-style: italic;"">”&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">procedure</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">tenodesis of the flexor pollicis longus tendon to the radius,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">release of the A1 pulley, and percutaneous pin fixation of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb</span><br></div><div><img src=""paste-eb41ae939bc4d598b90ff0e23d9fa530fb0b3728.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""2-Figure2-1.png""><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><img src=""tendon+transfer+-+edited+copy+2+watermarked.png"">"																				
"<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rerouting of biceps brachii around&nbsp;</span>{{c1::radial neck::anatomic loc}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Corrects&nbsp;</span>{{c2::supination}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;contracture of forearm that may occur in AIS C5 - C6&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div>becuase pronator teres is <u>C6</u>-C7</div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-22 at 11.00.27 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>Tendon Transfer C7</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::ECRL (or FCU) to the&nbsp;FDP::2 muscles}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Restores finger flexion</span><br></div>"																					
"AIS C8 (tendon transfer rarely needed)<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Intrinsic minus or “claw hand” may be addressed with a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lumbrical bar}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, preventing hyperextension of&nbsp;</span>MCPs<br></div>"	"<div>this can be done surgically as well</div><div><img src=""slide_12.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(10, 10, 10);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 10, 10);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 10, 10);"">deformity is produced by imbalance of the intrinsic &amp; extrinsics;</span><br><span style=""color: rgb(10, 10, 10);"">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;-&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://www.wheelessonline.com/bones/hand/intrinsic-muscles-of-the-hand/"">intrinsic</a><span style=""color: rgb(10, 10, 10);"">&nbsp;muscles markedly weakened or paralyzed to produce claw deformity;</span><br><span style=""color: rgb(10, 10, 10);"">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;- long extensor muscles hyperextend the MCP joint, &amp; long flexor muscles flex the PIP and DIP joints</span><div><img src=""BZDGmbkIUAAuoN0.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(10, 10, 10);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><strong>Tendon Transfer</strong></div><div><strong>post-operative management</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>extremity usually {{c1::Casted}}&nbsp;for a few weeks</div><div><br></div><div>change to a removeable {{c2::thermoplastic splint}}</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); font-family: -apple-system-body; background: var(--field-bg);"">Biofeedback and electrical stimulation for {{c3::muscle reeducation}}</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); font-family: -apple-system-body; background: var(--field-bg);""><br></span></div><div>cleared for heavy resistance activites after {{c4::3 months}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-2b745e54c4f3f17f8f269a8d4eec09cc78695b67.jpg""><div>fabricated to protect transfer site from&nbsp;<span style=""color: var(--field-fg); font-family: -apple-system-body; background: var(--field-bg);"">overstretching once cleared for&nbsp;ROM</span></div>
"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">incidence of concomitant </span>{{c1::TBI::other rehab dx}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is reported between 24% and 74%</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Historical factors, (e.g.,&nbsp;</span>MVC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">), loc, higher&nbsp;</span>NLI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, posttraumatic amnesia,</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;abnl (</span>GCS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">care aken to utilize medications with minimal cognitive impact. ie baclofen routinely used in&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>high BP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may signal the presence of&nbsp;</span>AD<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;“sympathetic storm""</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Depression occurs in <u>20% to 45%</u> of those w/ SCI and usually occurs within the 1st&nbsp;</span>{{c1::month}}"																					
"{{c1::suicide}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the leading cause of death in individuals with&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in the <u>youngest</u> age groups</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">suicide rate for individuals with&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is approximately 3 to 5× the age- and sex-specific suicide rate</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Pressure injuries commonly develop</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in persons with&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;within the first&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;years&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_32.png"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Common locations of pressure ulcers (descending)...</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>{{c1::sacrum}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">followed by the</span><div>{{c2::ischium}}</div><div>{{c3::heels}}</div><div>{{c4::trochanters}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_32.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In children, the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::occiput}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the most frequent site of pressure injuries</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig7_32.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Stage I PU:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">localized area of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::nonblanchable erythema}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Blanchable erythema or changes in sensation, temperature, or firmness may precede visual changes.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Color changes&nbsp;</span>DO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>NOT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;include purple or maroon discoloration</span><br></div><img src=""2a8c2a329c6993c1b9585fd9482df8bc.jpg""><img src=""Pressureulcerstages.jpg"">"																				
"Stage 2 PU:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Partial-thickness loss of skin with&nbsp;</span>exposed&nbsp;{{c1::epidermis &amp; dermis::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">wound bed is viable, pink or red, moist, and may also present as an intact or ruptured serum-filled blister</span><br><div><img src=""2a8c2a329c6993c1b9585fd9482df8bc.jpg""><img src=""Pressureulcerstages.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"Stage 3 PU:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Full-thickness loss of skin into&nbsp;</span>{{c1::subcutaneous}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;aka&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hypodermis}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">layer,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">in which&nbsp;</span>{{c1::adipose}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is visible in the ulcer&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">granulation tissue and epibole (rolled wound edges) are often present</span><div><img src=""2a8c2a329c6993c1b9585fd9482df8bc.jpg""><img src=""Pressureulcerstages.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Stage 4 PU</b>:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Full-thickness skin and tissue loss with exposed&nbsp;</span>{{c1::muscle, tendon, or bone::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in the ulcer</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Slough and/or eschar may be visible.&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Epibole}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(rolled edges),&nbsp;</span>{{c2::undermining}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and/or tunneling often occur</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<br><div><img src=""2a8c2a329c6993c1b9585fd9482df8bc.jpg""><img src=""Pressureulcerstages.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Unstageable PU: Full-thickness where extent of tissue damage is obscured by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::slough or eschar::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Once removed, a Stage 3 or Stage 4 pressure injury will be revealed.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Stable eschar on the heel or ischemic limb should not be softened or removed</span></div><div><img src=""12032019vldpressureulcers.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::Deep tissue pressure injury}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Intact or nonintact skin with localized area of persistent nonblanchable deep&nbsp;</span>{{c2::red, <u>maroon</u>, or purple::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;discoloration&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or epidermal separation revealing a dark wound bed or blood-filled blister</span><div><img src=""Pressureulcerdrawing.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most important risk factors for developing pressure injuries are&nbsp;</span>{{c1::persistent}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><strong>pressure</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::shear}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;forces</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Prolonged pressure over bony prominences,&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">exceeding&nbsp;</span>{{c1::capillary}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pressure&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">results in subsequent&nbsp;</span>{{c2::tissue ischemia}}<div><br></div><div>

<span style=""caret-color: rgb(51, 51, 51); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">continuously for&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-family: -apple-system-body; font-size: -apple-system-body; font-style: -apple-system-body; font-variant-caps: -apple-system-body; background: var(--field-bg); caret-color: rgb(51, 51, 51); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">{{c3::2&nbsp;<span style=""background: var(--field-bg);"">hours</span>}}&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-family: -apple-system-body; font-size: -apple-system-body; font-style: -apple-system-body; font-variant-caps: -apple-system-body; caret-color: rgb(51, 51, 51); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or more</span><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); font-family: -apple-system-body; background: var(--field-bg);"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, results in occlusion of the microvessels of the dermis. </span><font color=""#fc0006"">~25 mm Hg</font><div><font color=""#fc0006""><br></font><div><img src=""2108_Capillary_ExchangeN.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
"{{c1::Muscle::m<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">uscle/skin</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is more susceptible to pressure ischemia</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Medications for PU severe cases fall in 2 categoreis:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<font color=""#0014ff"">supplements</font>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::appetite stimulants}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"vitamin C<div>copper&nbsp;</div><div>zinc</div><div>arginine&nbsp;</div><div>glutamine&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Marinol (THC)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">megesterol (progesterone)&nbsp;</span></div>"

"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(</span>AHCPR<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) found only&nbsp;</span>{{c1::electrical stimulation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;merited recommendation for nonhealing pressure injuries</span><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">↑ circulation, granulation, with ↓ bacterial count</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"other modalities include: Wound-Vac,&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">hyperbaric oxygen; infrared, ultraviolet, and low-energy laser irradiation; and ultrasonography</span><div><br></div>"

"{{c1::Pedicled perforator}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;flaps: blood supply to the skin and subcutaneous tissue</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">A perforator flap is a cutaneous or subcutaneous flap that is vascularized by one (or more) perforating vessels arising from underlying deeper vessels.</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">aims to minimize damage to donor site, improvement upon prior methods that arose from better understanding of tissue circulation&nbsp;</span></div><img src=""on002-001-9780323243223.jpg"">"

"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most common overall SCI injury&nbsp;</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></span>{{c1::incomplete tetraplegia::complete/incomplete/tetra/para}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span>"	<div>47.2% incomplete tetraplegia</div><div>20.4% incomplete paraplegia</div><div>20.2% complete paraplegia</div><div>11.5% complete tetraplegia</div>																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">2nd most common overall SCI injury</span><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::incomplete paraplegia::complete/incomplete tetra/para}}<br></div>"	"<div>47.2% incomplete tetraplegia<br></div><div><div>20.4% incomplete paraplegia</div><div>20.2% complete paraplegia</div><div>11.5% complete tetraplegia <font color=""#fc0006"">thankfully this is the rarest&nbsp;</font></div></div>"																				
<div><strong>SCI HO Treatment options</strong>:&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::ROM::conservative}}</div><div>{{c2::Etidronate}} × 6 months&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::NSAIDs}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Warfarin::rare med}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Radiation}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Surgery}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div><b>No definitive standard treatment. Recommendations include the following:</b></div><div><br></div><div><b>ROM:</b> maintain functional range. Once the acute inflammatory period is over (i.e., warmth, erythema)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Etidronate:</b> no definitive recommended treatment protocol. Some suggest that the dose may be based upon the initial&nbsp;CPK&nbsp;blood test&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><b>NSAIDs:</b> if&nbsp;CPK&nbsp;is elevated (or&nbsp;CRP&nbsp;&gt;8) use&nbsp;e.g., naproxen 375 mg&nbsp;TID&nbsp;or indomethacin 75 mg/day.&nbsp;</div><div>- When&nbsp;CRP&nbsp;&lt;2 or&nbsp;CPK&nbsp;normalizes, the individual can stop&nbsp;NSAIDs&nbsp;and continue etidronate for 6 months.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Warfarin:</b> has been used but rarely is a primary treatment. It decreases the formation of osteocalcin.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Radiation therapy:</b> Prevents HO&nbsp;recurrence after surgery. Not often used acutely. Risks: wound healing, osteonecrosis, and sarcoma.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Surgery:&nbsp;</b>considered when&nbsp;HO&nbsp;severely limits&nbsp;function. (12–18 months postinjury with normal bone scan). <font color=""#fc0006"">postop tx bisphosphonates for 3 to 12 months,&nbsp;NSAIDS&nbsp;for 6 weeks or more, and/or radiation</font></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">3rd most common overall SCI injury</span><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::complete paraplegia::complete/incomplete tetra/para}}</div>"	"<div>47.2% incomplete tetraplegia<br></div><div><div>20.4% incomplete paraplegia</div><div>20.2% complete paraplegia</div><div>11.5% complete tetraplegia&nbsp;<font color=""#fc0006"">thankfully this is the rarest&nbsp;</font></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">single most common cause of death and injury in automobile accidents is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ejection from the vehicle}}"	Approximately 2.8 million&nbsp;TBIs&nbsp;occur in the United States annually.<div><br></div><div>Of the 2.5 million, 81% were&nbsp;ED&nbsp;visits, 16.3% were hospitalizations, and 3% were deaths&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Male to female ratio → 2.5:1.</div><div><br></div><div>Mortality in males is three to four times higher than in females</div>																				
TBI Age distribution is {{c1::bimodal::epidemiology}}	<div>Peak ages: 0 to 5 years,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>with second peak in the elderly (age 65 and older); older group has a higher mortality rate.</div>																				
"{{c1::Violence/assault}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the 2nd most common cause of&nbsp;</span>TBI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in young adults</span>"																					
Ethyl alcohol (ETOH) use is clearly related to&nbsp;TBI.<div><br></div><div>Alcohol is detected in blood in up to {{c1::85}}% of&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients</div>	ETOH&nbsp;blood levels of 0.10% or higher in 51% to 72% of patients at the time of the injury&nbsp;																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">CDC</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>The 1st most common cause of&nbsp;</span>TBI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">-related <u>hospitalizations</u> are&nbsp;</span>{{c1::falls}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(52%)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and the 2nd most common cause is</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::MVC's}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(20%)</span></div>"	"Centers for Disease Control and Prevention <a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_12"">2014</a>&nbsp;Data (<font color=""#fc0006"">*</font>Model systems data is more similar to SCI (2010)<div><br></div><div>Falls is the leading cause of traumatic brain injury; 48% of all&nbsp;TBI-related emergency department visits are due to falls.</div><div><br></div><div>The second leading cause of&nbsp;TBI-related emergency department visits is being struck by or against an object (about 17%).</div><div><br></div><div>The first and second most common causes of&nbsp;TBI-related hospitalizations are falls (52%) and motor vehicle crashes (20%).</div><div><br></div><div>The leading cause of&nbsp;TBI-related deaths in 2014 was due to intentional self-harm (33%).</div>"																				
"<div><b>TBI&nbsp;Model System National Database Statistics (1989–2011)<br></b></div><div><br></div><div><u>TBI Etiology:</u></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::MVA}}: 53%</div><div>{{c1::Falls}}: 24%</div><div>{{c1::Violence}}: 13%</div><div><br></div><div><b>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_12"">2014</a>&nbsp;Data)</b><br></div><div>{{c1::Falls}} leading cause of traumatic brain injury<br></div>"	"<div><b>TBI&nbsp;Model System National Database Statistics (1989–2011)</b></div><div><br></div><div>same as sci<br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_12"">2014</a>&nbsp;Data)</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>Falls is the leading cause of traumatic brain injury; 48% of all&nbsp;TBI-related emergency department visits are due to falls.</div><div><br></div><div>2nd leading cause of&nbsp;TBI-related emergency department visits is being struck by or against an object (about 17%).</div><div><br></div><div>The first and second most common causes of&nbsp;TBI-related hospitalizations are falls (52%) and motor vehicle crashes (20%).</div><div><br></div><div>The leading cause of&nbsp;TBI-related deaths in 2014 was due to intentional self-harm (33%).</div>"																				
TBI Marital status:<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Not married}} (68%)</div>	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png"">&nbsp;Single (46%) &gt; married (33%) &gt; divorced (16%) &gt; widowed/separated (5%)</div>"																				
<div><strong>TBI Severity</strong>:&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::90}}% of injuries are classified as mild.</div>	"Even among those <u>hospitalized</u>, 75% will have a Glasgow Coma Scale <b>(GCS) &gt;13</b><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">ED&nbsp;visits</span>: <u>Nonadmissions</u> outnumber&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;admissions by <b>4 times.</b></div><div><br></div><div>The rate of&nbsp;ED&nbsp;visits for&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;is greatest in those between the ages 0 and 4 years.</div></div>"																				
TBI <b>Primary</b> Injury<div><br></div><div>{{c1::coup contra coup*}}</div><div>{{c2::Contusions (Bruising of the cortical tissue)}}</div><div>{{c3::Diffuse axonal injury (DAI)}}<br></div>	Direct disruption of the brain parenchyma from the shear forces of the impact. It occurs immediately and is not amenable to medication&nbsp;<div><i>*SAE question</i></div>																				
"<div><b>Diffuse axonal injury (DAI)</b></div><div><br></div><div>Immediate disruption of axons due to {{c1::acceleration–deceleration}} and {{c1::rotational}} forces&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>that cause {{c1::shearing}} upon impact</div><div><br></div><div>there is also evidence of a secondary {{c2::axotomy}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">coupling of injury to these structures leads to the picture of&nbsp;</span>{{c3::white matter}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c4::punctate petechial hemorrhages}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(characterisitic of&nbsp;</span>DAI)<br></div>"	"<div>Shearing: 2/2 different densities of white vs gray matter</div><div><br></div>2nd axotomy: 2/2 increased axolemmal permeability, calcium influx, and cytoskeletal abnormalities that propagate post injury<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">Secondary axotomy is&nbsp;</span><b>an active process that some have compared with programmed cell death</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">, and refers specifically to the phenomenon whereby an injured axon remains in structural continuity immediately following injury but enters a 'pathological cascade' of responses that lead to axotomy at least some hours later</span><br></div><div><img src=""Neuron_undergoing_chromatolysis.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div>{{c1::Impact depolarization}}:</div><div><br></div><div>Massive surge in extracellular {{c2::potassium::ion}} and {{c2::glutamate::NT}} release&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>occurs after severe head injury and leads to excitotoxicity (secondary injury).</div>																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">TBI Common Location of contusions&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">include&nbsp;</span>{{c1::inferior-frontal lobe}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::anterior-temporal lobe}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig2_1.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">TBI Common locations of&nbsp;</span>DAI include...<div><br></div><div>{{c1::corpus callosum}}</div><div>{{c2::central white matter}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::mid-brain}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig2_2.png"">"																				
SCI duration of DVT ppx <b>&gt; 8 weeks</b><div><br></div><div>motor complete (AIS A/B) +</div><div><br></div><div><u>risk factors</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::lower limb fracture}}</div><div>{{c2::history of VTE}}</div><div>{{c3::cancer}}</div><div>{{c5::heart failure}}</div><div>{{c4::obesity}}</div><div>age &gt;{{c4::70}}<br></div>	<u>attendings and cucurrulo say:</u><div>AIS D or ambulating: stop at d/c</div><div>Not ambulatory or AIS B and A simple: 8 weeks</div><div>AIS A or B + risk: 12 weeks</div><div><br></div><div><u>however, based on SCI consortium</u></div><div>I would make the case for 12 wks in AIS A/B based on any of the aforementioned&nbsp;</div><div>unless there is some exceptional bleeding risk</div>																				
TBI {{c1::Secondary Injury}}<div><br></div><div>Cascade of biochemical, cellular, and molecular events,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>which include both endogenous cerebral damage as well as extracerebral damage that comes with trauma.&nbsp;</div>	<b>Mechanisms of secondary injury include the following</b><div><br></div><div>1. Ischemia, excitotoxicity, energy failure, and resultant apoptosis</div><div><br></div><div>- Excitotoxicity is the process by which neuronal damage occurs due to a massive surge in neurotransmitters (also see “Diffuse Injury” section).</div><div><br></div><div>2. Secondary cerebral swelling (brain swelling and brain edema):</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>- Brain swelling</strong>&nbsp;occurs early on after acute head injury (within 24 hours) due to an increase in cerebral blood volume (intravascular blood). Identified on&nbsp;CT&nbsp;as collapse of ventricular system and loss of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cisterns around the midbrain.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>- Brain edema</strong>&nbsp;occurs later after head injury (in comparison to brain swelling) due to an increase in brain volume secondary to increased brain water content ⇒ extravascular fluid. There are two types of brain edema:</div><div><br></div><div>3. Axonal injury</div><div><br></div><div>4. Inflammation and regeneration</div>																				
"<b>Mechanisms of TBI 2<span style=""font-size: 16.6667px;""><sup>0</sup></span>&nbsp;injury include the following</b><div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Ischemia}}</div><div><br></div><div>2. {{c2::excitotoxicity}}</div><div><br></div><div>3. {{c3::cerebral swelling/edema}}</div><div><br></div><div>4. {{c4::Axonal injury}}</div><div><br></div><div>5. {{c5::Inflammation and regeneration}}</div>"	<b>Mechanisms of secondary injury include the following</b><div><br></div><div>1. Ischemia, excitotoxicity, energy failure, and resultant apoptosis</div><div><br></div><div>- Excitotoxicity is the process by which neuronal damage occurs due to a massive surge in neurotransmitters (also see “Diffuse Injury” section).</div><div><br></div><div>2. Secondary cerebral swelling (brain swelling and brain edema):</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>- Brain swelling</strong>&nbsp;occurs early on after acute head injury (within 24 hours) due to an increase in cerebral blood volume (intravascular blood). Identified on&nbsp;CT&nbsp;as collapse of ventricular system and loss of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cisterns around the midbrain.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>- Brain edema</strong>&nbsp;occurs later after head injury (in comparison to brain swelling) due to an increase in brain volume secondary to increased brain water content ⇒ extravascular fluid. There are two types of brain edema:</div><div><br></div><div>3. Axonal injury</div><div><br></div><div>4. Inflammation and regeneration</div>																				
<b>Mechanisms of TBI secondary injury</b>&nbsp;<b>&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b><div>{{c1::cerebral swelling}}: (occurs {{c4::early [w/in 24 hours]}}) due to an increase in cerebral {{c4::intravascular}} blood volume&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Identified on&nbsp;CT&nbsp;as collapse of&nbsp;{{c2::ventricular system}} and loss of {{c3::CSF cisterns}} around the {{c5::midbrain}}.</div></div>	"<img src=""fetch.php""><img src=""latest.jpg"">"																				
<b>Mechanisms of TBI secondary injury</b>&nbsp;<b>&nbsp;</b><div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div>{{c1::cerebral edema}}: occurs {{c3::later::early/late}} due to an increase in brain volume&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>secondary to increased brain water content ⇒ {{c2::extravascular}} fluid.&nbsp;</div></div>	<div>There are two sub-types&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div>vasogenic and ctyogenic																				
"<div><b>brain edema:</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>{{c1::Vasogenic edema:}}</u><br></div><div>Due to outpouring of protein-rich fluid through damaged vessels</div><div>{{c2::Extra}}-cellular edema</div><div>Related to {{c3::cerebral contusion}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>{{c1::Cytogenic edema:}}</u><br></div><div>Related to {{c3::hypoxic/ischemic}} brain damage</div><div>Due to failing of the cells’ energy supply system ⇒ ↑ cell-wall pumping system ⇒ {{c2::intra}}-cellular edema</div>"	"<img src=""Schematic-demonstrating-cytotoxic-and-vasogenic-cerebral-edema.png""><img src=""FI8osisX0AAGSPf.jpg""><img src=""SBKCZRPu3O-3pFkuhPkvGQ.png""><img src=""yy2.jpg"">"																				
{{c1::Focal Injury}}<div><br></div><div>Localized damage in the brain occurring immediately after TBI and easily visualized by&nbsp;CT&nbsp;or&nbsp;MRI</div><div>- ex.Cerebral contusions</div><div>(Not Primary Injury)</div>	Occurs when the brain impacts the inner table of the skull																				
"<b>{{c2::Focal ischemia}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">after a traumatic&nbsp;</span><u>SAH</u>&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">occurs secondary to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::vasospasms}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">of the arteries&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or from&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">direct&nbsp;</span>physical compression}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"																					
"<strong>Epidural hematoma (EDH)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Occurs commonly (90%) with a skull fracture in the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::temporal bone}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">crossing the vascular territory of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::middle meningeal}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;artery (60%–90%)&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or veins (middle meningeal vein, diploic veins, or venous sinus; 10%–40%).&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hematoma expansion is slowed by the tight adherence of the dura to the skull</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Clinically presents with a lucid interval (50%) prior to rapid deterioration</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_3.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<strong>Subdural hematoma (SDH)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Occurs in 30% of severe head trauma.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">They result from shearing of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::bridging veins}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;between the pia-arachnoid and the dura.&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">They are usually larger in the <u>elderly</u> due to generalized loss of brain parenchyma</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_4.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>SDH chronicity</b><br><div><br></div><div>Acute&nbsp;SDH: {{c1::Immediately symptomatic::not a time}} lesions</div>																					
"<strong>SAH</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Etiology</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ruptured&nbsp;</span>{{c5::cerebral aneurysms}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">leakage from&nbsp;</span>{{c1::IPH}}</div><div>{{c4::trauma}}<br></div><div>{{c3::AVMs}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>CT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;findings demonstrate blood within the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::cisterns}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;around the brainstem and the subarachnoid space within 24 hours.&nbsp;</span></div></div>"	"CT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;sensitivity decreases to 30% 2 weeks after the initial bleed</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_5.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><b>DAI&nbsp;classification is based on severity:</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Grade I</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Widespread {{c1::white matter/axonal}} damage but no {{c2::focal abnormalities on imaging}}</div>"	"<div><br></div><div><div><img src=""3-Table1-1.png""><br></div><div><img src=""jti-31-051f2.gif""><br></div><div><img src=""fnins-17-1077858-g001.jpg""></div></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_2.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::DAI}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the leading cause of morbidity in TBI including impairments in: cognition, behavior, arousal, and coma</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The severity of impairments depends on the magnitude, duration, and direction of angular acceleration of the initial impact</span><div><img src=""paste-686564f6a7048eaf55797fb81f11636c3a5cd21d.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">DAI is the most common cause of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::unconsciousness}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;during and following the first 24 hours of TBI</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Mortality rate of patients who are initially <u>comatose</u> from a gunshot wound to the head is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::90}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">%</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">more than two times the mortality rate of closed head injury (</span>CHI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span><div><br></div><div>Deficits are focal and correspond to the area of injury&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>If the brain is penetrated at the lower levels of the brainstem, death is instantaneous&nbsp;</div>"																				
"<div><h3>PENETRATING HEAD INJURIES</h3></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Focal or focal and generalized seizures occur in the early phase of the injury in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::20}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of cases</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Risk of long-term posttraumatic epilepsy (</span>PTE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) is <u>higher in penetrating</u> head injuries compared to nonpenetrating injuries</span>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); background: var(--field-bg);"">{{c2::Neuronal regeneration}} or {{c1::neuronal (collateral) sprouting}}: component of plasticity</span><br></div><div><br></div><div>Intact axons establish synaptic connections through dendritic and axonal {{c1::sprouting::same}} in areas where damage has occurred.</div><div><br></div>"	<div>May enhance recovery of function, may contribute to unwanted symptoms,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>or may be neutral (with no increase or decrease of function)</div><div><br></div><div>Thought to occur weeks to months postinjury</div>																				
<div>{{c2::Functional reorganization}} or {{c1::unmasking reorganization}}: component of <u>plasticity</u>&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div>Healthy neural structures not formerly used for a given purpose are developed (or reassigned)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>to do functions formerly subserved by the lesioned area<br></div>	(terms used interchangeably)																				
<b>Plasticity occurs via two mechanisms...</b><div><br></div><div><strong>1.)&nbsp;</strong>{{c1::unmasking}}<strong>&nbsp;</strong></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>2.)&nbsp;</strong>{{c2::Neuronal sprouting}}</div>	"<div><strong>Brain plasticity → Remember “PUNS”</strong></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">P</span>lasticity =&nbsp;<span style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">U</span>nmasking +&nbsp;<span style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">N</span>euronal sprouting</strong></div>"																				
<div>{{c1::Synaptic Alterations}} (TBI recovery mechanism)</div><div><br></div><div>Includes diaschisis and increased sensitivity to neurotransmitter levels</div>																					
"<b>{{c1::diaschisis}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>(TBI recovery mechanism)<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">damage to one region of the </span>CNS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;that produces altered function in <u>uninjured</u> areas of the brain</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">if there is a <u>connection</u> between the two sites (through fiber tracts).&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Function is lost in <u>both</u> injured and in morphologically intact brain tissue</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Example of diaschisis: Injury to site A will produce inhibition of function at site B, which was not severed by the initial injury&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Recovery of functions controlled by <b>site B will parallel recovery of site A</b></span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_6.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div>"																				
<div><b>{{c1::Functional/Behavioral Substitution}}</b> (TBI revovery mechanism)</div><div><br></div><div>Techniques/new strategies learned to compensate for deficits and to achieve a particular task</div>																					
<b>{{c1::Redundancy}} </b>(TBI revovery mechanism)<div><br></div><div>Recovery of function based on activity of uninjured brain areas (latent areas)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>that <u>normally would</u> contribute to that function&nbsp;<br></div>	(and are capable of subserving that function)																				
<b>{{c1::Vicariation&nbsp;}}</b>&nbsp;(TBI revovery mechanism)<div><br></div><div>Functions taken over by brain areas <u>not</u> originally managing that function.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>These areas alter their properties in order to subserve that function.</div>																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Syrinx Pain is Aching or burning,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">often worse with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::straining}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sitting}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;position</span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Consciousness is a function of the ascending&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">reticular activating system (</span>RAS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::cerebral cortex}}"																					
"RAS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is composed of cell bodies in the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::central reticular core}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::upper brainstem (mainly midbrain)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and their projections to widespread areas of the cerebral cortex via both the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::thalamic::same}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::extrathalamic::same}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pathways</span></div>"	"<img src=""reticularactivatingsystem1b62e.jpeg_;"">"																				
<h3>DISORDERS OF CONSCIOUSNESS</h3><u>Coma</u><div>Awake: {{c1::No}}</div><div>Aware: {{c1::No}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-19 at 8.18.06 AM.png"">"																				
<h3>DISORDERS OF CONSCIOUSNESS</h3><u>Vegetative State</u><div>Awake: {{c1::Yes}}</div><div>Aware: {{c1::No}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-19 at 8.18.06 AM.png"">"																				
<h3>DISORDERS OF CONSCIOUSNESS</h3><u>Minimally Conscious State</u><div>Awake: {{c1::Yes}}</div><div>Aware: {{c1::Yes, inconsistent but reproducible}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-19 at 8.18.06 AM.png"">"																				
<b>Coma&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div>sleep: {{c1::N::Y/N}}</div><div>eyes: {{c1::closed::open/closed}}</div><div>response to pain: {{c1::N::Y/N}}</div><div>language comprehension: {{c1::N::Y/N}}</div>	"<div>Lack of wakefulness as evidenced by the lack of sleep wake cycles on&nbsp;EEG</div><div><br></div><div>Patient’s eyes remain closed.</div><div><br></div><div>There is&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">no</span>&nbsp;spontaneous purposeful movement or ability to discretely localize noxious stimuli.</div><div><br></div><div>No evidence of language comprehension or expression</div>"																				
<b>Coma</b>&nbsp;can last {{c1::2}} to {{c1::4 weeks}} for people who do not emerge	After 4 weeks they will either die or emerge&nbsp;																				
<b>Vegetative State</b><div><br></div><div>Characterized by the resumption of the {{c1::sleep–wake cycle on&nbsp;EEG}}</div><div><br></div><div>evidence of purposeful behavior: {{c1::N::Y/N}}</div><div><br></div><div>Patient opens eyes {{c3::spontaneously}} or with {{c3::noxious stimuli}}</div><div><br></div><div><div>Presence of verbal / auditory startle {{c4::Y (random)::Y/N}}</div><div><br></div><div>Movement is {{c5::reflexive/patterned::description}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Response to stimuli</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Pain response - <b>only</b> {{c2::withdraw}}&nbsp;<b>No</b>&nbsp;{{c2::localization}}</div></div><div>Visual Response -&nbsp;<b>No/rare</b>&nbsp;{{c2::tracking}}</div>	"<img src=""4-Table1-1.png"">"																				
<b>Neuropathology of vegetative state (VS)</b><div><br></div><div>Related to {{c1::diffuse cortical injury}}</div><div><br></div><div>Bilateral {{c2:: thalamic}} lesions are prominent findings in&nbsp;VS.</div>																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the term&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<u>persistent</u> vegetative state}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(redefined by the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_54"">Multi-Society Task Force on&nbsp;PVS, 1994</a><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is still currently used in the United States for&nbsp;</span>VS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;that is present ≥</span>{{c2::1 month}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after a traumatic or nontraumatic brain injury</span></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-20 at 1.35.43 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The Task Force also introduced the term&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>permanent</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>&nbsp;VS</b> to denote <u>irreversibility</u>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">after&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months following&nbsp;</span>{{c1::non-traumatic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;brain injury and&nbsp;</span></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::12}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months following&nbsp;</span>{{c1::traumatic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;brain injury</span></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-20 at 1.35.43 PM.png""><div>terms falling out of favor, especially in Europe.&nbsp; should not necessarily be discussed with families&nbsp;</div>"																				
<b>Minimally Conscious State</b><div><br></div><div>Patient shows minimal but <u>{{c6::definite}}</u>&nbsp;evidence of self or exhibits environmental awareness.</div><div><br></div><div>Patient shows evidence of <u>{{c6::inconsistent}}</u>&nbsp;but reproducible (or sustained) purposeful behaviors.</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Simple command following}}</div><div>{{c2::Object manipulation}}</div><div>{{c3::Intelligible verbalization}}</div><div>{{c4::Gestural or verbal yes/no responses}}</div><div>{{c5::Visual fixation (pursuit)}}</div><div>{{c5::Smooth tracking}}</div><div>{{c7::Emotional response (contingent)}}&nbsp;<br></div><div>response to pain: {{c8::localization}}</div>	"Emotional or motor behaviors that are contingent upon the presence of <u>specific eliciting stimuli</u><div><br></div><div>(e.g., patient will cry or get agitated [and behavior is reproducible]&nbsp;</div><div>only after hearing voices of family members but not with voices of hospital staff) ""or seeing pics of family""</div><div><img src=""4-Table1-1.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Emergence from&nbsp;MCS&nbsp;typically signaled by:</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Consistent command following}}</div><div>{{c2::Functional object use}}</div><div>{{c3::Reliable use of a communication system}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-16 at 12.22.05 PM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-16 at 12.21.54 PM.png""></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">There&nbsp;</span>{{c1::is no::is/is no}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;evidence to support that any kind of therapy-based program&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(e.g., coma stimulation/sensory stimulation program) will induce or accelerate the cessation of coma or&nbsp;</span>VS</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Nevertheless, an organized treatment approach to low-functioning patients permits a quantifiable assessment of responses to stimulation&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and early recognition of changes or improvements in response to therapeutic interventions or through spontaneous recovery</span></div>"																				
<b>Treatment of d/o of consciousness</b><div><br></div><div><u>Preventive therapeutic interventions may be implemented</u>:</div><div><br></div><div>Manage {{c1::bowel}} and&nbsp;{{c1::bladder function}}</div><div>Maintain {{c2::nutrition}}</div><div>Maintain {{c2::skin integrity}}</div><div>Control {{c3::spasticity}}</div><div>Prevent {{c3::contractures}}</div>																					
<b>Treatment of d/o of consciousness</b><div><br></div><div><div><u>Pharmacologic interventions:</u></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Elimination of sedating meds}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Addition of neuro-stimulants}}</div></div>	<div>Elimination of unnecessary medicines (e.g., benzodiazepines, H-2 blockers, dopamine blockers, pain medications, etc.)&nbsp;</div><div>and selection of agents with fewest adverse effects on cognitive and neurologic recovery</div><div><br></div><div>Addition of agents to potentially enhance specific cognitive and physical functions</div><div><br></div><div>In patients emerging out of coma or&nbsp;VS, the recovery process may be (theoretically) hastened through the use of pharmacotherap</div>																				
<b>TBI treatment</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Elimination of sedating medicines (class):</u></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::benzodiazepines::class}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::H-2 blockers::class}}</div><div>{{c5::seizure meds eg. keppra (if indicated)::1 ex.}}<br></div><div>{{c3::agitation meds eg. seroquel::1 ex.}}</div><div>{{c7::storming meds eg. clonidine::1 ex.}}</div><div>{{c4::pain meds eg. robaxin::1 ex.}}</div><div>{{c6::spacticity meds eg. baclofen::1 ex.}}</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">only evidence for 7 days of Keppra (can ask NSGRY)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>D2-blockers<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(eg, Seroqule qHS),&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">incease dose of Trazodone (if insomnia worsens)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">clonidine, alt. increase propranolol&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">pain medications (oxycodone, Robaxin), etc.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">switch baclofen to dantrolene&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and selection of agents with fewest adverse effects on cognitive recovery</span></div>"																				
TBI treatment&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><div>{{c1::Sensory stimulation}}:</div><div><br></div><div>all five senses addressed one at a time, in specific therapy sessions and/or in the environmental state and developed in the room</div></div>	<div>widely used despite little evidence of efficacy as previously mentioned</div><div><br></div><div>Avoid overstimulation (educate family)</div><div><br></div><div>Patient may have adverse responses ↑ confusion or agitation ↑ reflex responses or avoidance reactions, which interfere w/ performance</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Decerebrate posture: There is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::extension}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the upper&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">extremities</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::extension}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;lower extremities</span>"	"think vertebrate = lower than the cortex&nbsp;<div><b>A</b><br><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_7.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Decorticate posture: There is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::flexion}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the upper extremities and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::extension}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the lower extremities</span>"	"cortex means bark: outter most or ""up""<div><b>B</b><br><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_7.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Decerebrate posture etiology: lesions to...</b></span><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::midbrain}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::cerebellum}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::posterior fossa}}&nbsp;</div>"	unlike the higher structures seen in decorticate posture&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div><div>cerebral hemisphere</div><div>white matter / internal capsule</div><div>thalamic lesions</div></div>																				
<div><b>Decerebrate posture phys-ex</b> (beyond extended UE and LE)</div><div><br></div><u>In its fully developed form, it consists of</u>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::opisthotonus}}</div><div>{{c2::clenched jaw}}</div><div>{{c3::internal rotation}} of arms</div><div>{{c3::plantar flexion}} of foot</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(60, 64, 67);""><b>opisthotonus:&nbsp;</b></span>spasm of the muscles causing backward arching of the head, neck, and spine,&nbsp;</div><div>as in severe tetanus, some kinds of meningitis, and strychnine poisoning</div><div><img src=""paste-748ba0e74a27a09b8db3815d720f070a25b79ec0.jpg""><img src=""paste-6307a9422520d1569d26a68a76a0ab74ecd660dc.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Decorticate posture: etiology lesions to,</span><div><br></div><div>{{c1::cerebral hemisphere}}</div><div>{{c1::white matter / internal capsule}}</div><div>{{c1::thalamic lesions}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Posturing due to lesions at a higher level (than in decerebrate posture)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div>midbrain&nbsp;</div><div>cerebellum</div><div>posterior fossa</div></div>"																				
<div><b>Severity of&nbsp;TBI:</b></div><div><br></div><div>Moderate&nbsp;TBI:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score {{c1::9}} to {{c1::12}}</div>	<div><b>Severity of&nbsp;TBI:</b><br></div><div>Severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;(coma):&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 3 to 8</div><div>Moderate&nbsp;TBI:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 9 to 12</div><div>Mild&nbsp;TBI:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 13 to 15</div><div><br></div><div><br></div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Of the 3 items in&nbsp;</span><b>GCS</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">best&nbsp;</span>{{c1::motor}}<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;response</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, particularly&nbsp;</span>{{c2::2 weeks}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;postinjury, is the best acute predictor of <u>outcome</u>.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">best&nbsp;</span>{{c1::verbal}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;response was the 2nd-best acute predictor of outcome</span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lower&nbsp;</span>GCS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;scores are associated with worse outcomes&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">based on the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">best&nbsp;</span>GCS}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;within the 1st&nbsp;</span>{{c1::24}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;hours</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Using the highest&nbsp;</span>GCS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;score within the first few hours after the injury is preferred,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">low early scores often before cardiopulmonary resuscitation [</span>CPR<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">] and&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">confounding factors such as sedatives or paralytic agents for intubation&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
<div>Relationship between best&nbsp;<b>GCS</b>&nbsp;score and <b>outcome</b> as measured on the <b>Glasgow Outcome Scale</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>GCS&nbsp;score {{c2::3}} to {{c2::4}}: <u>Death or&nbsp;VS</u>&nbsp;in {{c1::90}}% of patients</div>	"These data are often missing, as patients arrive paralyzed and intubated<div><br></div><div><div>GCS&nbsp;score 3 to 4: Death or&nbsp;VS&nbsp;in 87% of patients</div><div>GCS&nbsp;score 5 to 7: Death or&nbsp;VS&nbsp;in 53% and moderate or good recovery in 34%</div><div>GCS&nbsp;score 8 to 10: Moderate or good recovery in 68%</div><div>GCS&nbsp;score 11: Moderate or good recovery in 87%</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-20 at 3.13.28 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Glasgow–{{c1::Liege}}</b> scale:&nbsp;proposed the addition of the brainstem reflex scale to the&nbsp;GCS.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Fronto-orbicular reflex (orbicularis oculi): Orbicularis oculi contraction on percussion of the glabella</div><div><br></div><div>Vertical oculocephalic and horizontal oculocephalic or oculovestibular reflex: “Doll’s eye” maneuver</div><div><br></div><div>Pupillary light reflex</div><div><br></div><div>Oculocardiac reflex: Bradycardia induced by increasing pressure on the eyeball</div>	The Glasgow–Liege scale has been tested for reliability and prognostic power and has been shown to amplify the information provided by the standard&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;in comatose patients																				
<div>Fronto-orbicular reflex:&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Orbicularis oculi contraction on percussion of the glabella}}</div>	"<b>glabellar reflex</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">, also known as the ""</span><b>glabellar tap sign</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">"", is a&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primitive_reflex"">primitive reflex</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;elicited by repetitive tapping of the&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);""><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glabella"">glabella</a> —</span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);""> the smooth part of the forehead above the nose and between the eyebrows.</span><sup><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glabellar_reflex#cite_note-Talley_2018_p.-1"">[1]</a></sup><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;Subjects respond to the first several taps by&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blinking"">blinking</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">; if tapping were to then be made to persist, in cognitively intact individuals this would lead to habituation and consequent suppression of blinking. If instead the blinking were to persist along with the tapping, this is known as&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myerson%27s_sign"">Myerson's sign</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">, and is abnormal and a&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frontal_release_sign"">sign of frontal release</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">; it is often seen in people who have&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parkinson%27s_disease"">Parkinson's disease</a><div><img src=""images-cbcfe60a84535c7fad0351f0fe8a2cc652a345fb.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div>Oculocardiac reflex:&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Bradycardia induced by increasing pressure on the eyeball}}<br></div>	"<div><br></div><img src=""oculocardiac-reflex.jpg"">"																				
<div>Vertical and horizontal oculocephalic reflex:&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::horizontal head movement results in eyes that move with the face (as opposed to correcting)}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""7Pa6dj.BZ5RcZiOR5nZS8g.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Metabolic::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Metabolic/Anoxic</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;causes of coma have a better prognosis.&nbsp;</span>"
