"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>The likelihood of good recovery COMA</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is &lt;</span>{{c2::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% in those who have suffered&nbsp;</span>{{c1::SAH<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or stroke</span>}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">about&nbsp;</span>{{c2::10}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% in those with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hypoxic–ischemic injury}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">but as high as&nbsp;</span>{{c2::25}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% in those with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::metabolic causes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"																					
<b>Coma Duration</b><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Severe disability}} is unlikely when coma lasts &lt;{{c1::2}} weeks</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Good recovery}} is unlikely when coma lasts &gt;{{c1::4}} weeks</div>	<div>time to following commands (TTFC)</div><div><br></div>Defining “coma” in this way is outdated&nbsp;																				
"<b>Posttraumatic Amnesia</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Threshold values</span>:</u></div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Severe disability}} is unlikely when&nbsp;PTA&nbsp;lasts &lt;{{c1::2 months}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Good recovery}} is unlikely when&nbsp;PTA&nbsp;lasts &gt;{{c1::3 months}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png"">&nbsp;Resolution of&nbsp;PTA&nbsp;clinically corresponds to the period when&nbsp;<div><br><div>incorporation of ongoing daily events occurs in the working memory</div></div>"																				
"<b>Post-traumatic Amnesia</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>PTA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;correlates strongly with the length of coma (and with&nbsp;</span>GOS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">in patients with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::DAI::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">contusions/DAI</span>}}</div>"																					
"{{c1::Galveston Orientation and Amnesia Test (GOAT)}}<strong>:</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;it is a standard technique for assessing&nbsp;</span>PTA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is a brief, structured interview that quantifies the patient’s orientation and recall of recent events</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">developed by Harvey Levin and colleagues</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-23 at 8.40.56 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The end of&nbsp;</span>PTA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;can be defined as the date when the patient scores&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">≥75</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in the&nbsp;</span>GOAT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">consecutive days</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-23 at 8.40.56 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The period of&nbsp;</span>PTA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is defined as the number of days beginning at&nbsp;</span>{{c1::the end of the coma}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to the time the of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">2 days of <u>&gt;</u>&nbsp;75&nbsp;</span>GOAT}}"	End of coma or when icu sedation ended<div><br></div><div>Will not make a big difference for prognosis&nbsp;</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Once a GOAT score of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::70}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is achieved,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::neuropsychological test}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;data usually are reliable for further rehabilitation and postdismissal planning</span></div>"																					
<div>{{c1::Orientation Log (O–Log)}}: an alternative to GOAT for assessment of&nbsp;PTA</div><div><br></div><div>addressed problems related to GOAT including {{c2::unequal weighting}} of scored items</div>	"The O–Log was developed because of some of the problems related to the&nbsp;GOAT, including unequal weighting of scored items, difficulty verifying some responses, and a lack of relevancy. The O–Log focuses on orientation to place, time, and circumstance and consists of 10 items scored 0 to 3.<div><br></div><div><div><u>Components:</u></div><div>Place: Type of place, name, and city</div><div>Time: Month, date, year, day of week, and time of day</div><div>Circumstance: Event that made the person require care and the deficits that have resulted.</div><div>Items are scored 0 to 3:3 = spontaneous/free recall; 2 = logical cuing; 1 = multiple choice, phonemic cuing; 0 = unable/incorrect/inappropriate</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-26 at 9.42.03 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Orientation Log (O–Log)</span><div><br></div><div>2 consecutive scores of {{c1::<u>&gt;</u>25}}&nbsp;and higher indicate the person is out of&nbsp;PTA.</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-26 at 9.42.03 PM.png"">"																				
"Duration of&nbsp;PTA&nbsp;<u>moderate</u> TBI<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&gt;</span>{{c1::1&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;day</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and &lt;</span>{{c1::7&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">days</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<table><tbody><tr><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">DURATION OF&nbsp;PTA</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">SEVERITY OF&nbsp;TBI</th></tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">0–1 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Mild</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&gt;1 day and &lt;7 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Moderate</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&gt;7 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Severe</td></tr></tbody></table><br>"																				
"Indicators of Outcome After&nbsp;TBI<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Age ≥</span>{{c1::40}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;correlates with worse functional outcome when compared with younger patients</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Children and young adults tend to have a generally more positive prognosis than older adults.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">However, young children (&lt;5 years old) and older adults (&gt;65 years old) have greater mortality</span></div>"																				
"<strong>Rate of early recovery&nbsp;</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">has been found to be predictive of final outcome. 2 tests&nbsp;</span><div><br></div><div>{{c1::JFK<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Coma Recovery</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Scale&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Disability Rating}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Scale</span></div>"																					
<div><strong>Pupillary reaction to light</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::50}}% of patients with reactive pupils after&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;achieve moderate disability to good recovery (in&nbsp;DRS&nbsp;scale)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>versus {{c2::4}}% with nonreactive pupils</div><div><br></div><div>Similarly, the presence of {{c3::conjugate eye movement}} is a positive prognostic indicator</div>	"<b>Conjugate eye movement</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;refers to motor coordination of the eyes that allows for bilateral fixation on a single object. A conjugate eye movement is a movement of both eyes in the same direction to maintain binocular gaze (also referred to as “yoked” eye movement)</span><div><img src=""Horizontal+eye+movements.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);""><br></span></div>"																				
"TBI:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Most recovery usually occurs within the first&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6 months}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;postinjury</span>"																					
<div>Long-term use of {{c1::phenytoin::AED}} has been reported to have adverse cognitive effects&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and neurobehavioral effects in severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients compared to placebo group<br></div>																					
"{{c1::Disability Rating Scale}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: head injury predictor scale with</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Documented correlation between acute predictors of outcome and&nbsp;</span>GOS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;score at 6 months and at 12 months</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"developed specifically for brain injury.&nbsp; It provides a quantitative index of disability.<div>It is more sensitive to clinical changes than&nbsp;GOS.</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.44.47 PM.png""><br><div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.40.08 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.40.21 PM.png""><br></div></div></div>"																				
the DRS is a {{c1::30}}-point scale covering the following eight dimensions&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Eye opening</div><div>Verbalization/communication</div><div>Motor responsiveness</div><div>Feeding*</div><div>Toileting*</div><div>Grooming*</div><div>Overall level of functioning/dependence</div><div>Employability</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.44.47 PM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.40.08 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.40.21 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>DRS</b> provides a quantitative index of {{c2::disability}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>It is more sensitive to {{c1::clinical changes}} than&nbsp;GOS</div><div><br></div><div>Limitations: Not a real indicator of {{c3::functional abilities}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.40.08 PM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.40.21 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Rancho Los Amigos}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">global scale that focuses on&nbsp;</span>{{c3::cognitive recovery}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::behavior}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after&nbsp;</span>TBI"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rancho Los Amigos Levels of Cognitive Function Scale (Rancho or&nbsp;</span>LCFS)<div><img src=""ranchos.jpg""><br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-05-30 at 7.54.17 PM.png""></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Levels of Cognitive Function Scale (</span>Ranchos<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;has&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lower::higher/equal/lower}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;validity and reliability than the&nbsp;</span>DRS"																					
"<div>{{c1::Functional Independence Measure}}:<br></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Ordinal scale with 18 items and seven levels to assess physical and cognitive function</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-06-02 at 3.14.03 PM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-06-02 at 3.14.17 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>{{c1::Revised&nbsp;JFK&nbsp;Coma Recovery Scale}}:</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>Theorizes {{c3::hierarchical responses}} (from generalized to cognitively mediated)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>including {{c2::25}} items in {{c2::6}} categories</div>	"<div>:Auditory, visual, motor, oromotor/verbal, communication, and arousal<br></div><div><img src=""https://els-jbs-prod-cdn.jbs.elsevierhealth.com/cms/attachment/2062129846/2063653080/gr1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div>Predicting outcomes TBI</div><div><br></div><div>JFK Coma Recovery Scale (CRS) {{c1::&gt;::&gt;/=/&lt;}} Disability Rating scale</div>	<div>showed stronger correlations with outcome (as measured by the&nbsp;DRS) than initial, one-time scores.&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div>The change as a percentage of total score was greater for the&nbsp;CRS&nbsp;than for the&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;or&nbsp;DRS																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Prior to the development of the&nbsp;</span>CT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;scan,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::neuropsychological assessment}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;was utilized to determine the presence, location, and type of brain lesion a patient had</span></div>"																					
"{{c1::Halstead–Reitan}}<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Neuropsychological Battery</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is used as a diagnostic test for all kinds of brain damage.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">initially designed to assess frontal-lobe disorders by&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_40"">Halstead (1947)</a><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_60"">Reitan (1970–1974)</a><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, added some tests and recommended it for all kinds of brain damage</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Good recovery is unlikely when&nbsp;</span>{{c1::bilateral}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hemispheric}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">lesions are found on early&nbsp;</span>MRI"																					
<b>Resuscitation (ABCs) TBI</b><div><br></div><div><u>Oxygenation (breathing):</u></div><div>PO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;should be kept between {{c1::100}} and {{c1::120}} mmHg.</div><div>PCO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;should be kept between {{c2::28}} and {{c2::32}} mmHg.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Circulation:</u></div><div>Keep central perfusion pressure (CPP) &gt;{{c3::60}} mmHg</div>	Remember:&nbsp;CPP&nbsp;= mean arterial pressure (MAP) – intracranial pressure (ICP)																				
"TBI Laboratory Studies:<div><br></div><div>beyond CBC, ABG, CMP</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::ETOH<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and drug::2</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;screens can provide useful data</span><br></div>"																					
<div>Brain MRI in TBI</div><div><br></div><div>Can define {{c1::nonhemorrhagic}} lesions of the brain as opposed to CT&nbsp;</div>	vs CT which can not! eg. cortical contusions, subcortical gray matter injury, and brainstem lesions<div><br></div><div>Takes much longer (45 vs. 5 minutes) than a head&nbsp;CT</div><div><br></div><div>does not really affect early decision-making<br></div>																				
<div>Anisocoria: May indicate impending {{c1::transtentorial herniation}} to the {{c2::ipsilateral}} side<br></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-06-05 at 5.24.31 PM.png"">"																				
"<b>etiology of anisicoria</b>&nbsp;(<u>mydriasis</u>) (2/2 CN3 palsy)<div><div>(excluding miosis contralateral side, meds, and physiologic)<br></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><div>{{c1::Ischemia 2/2 DM}}</div><div>{{c2::Uncal herniation}}</div><div>{{c3::PCA aneurysm}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Cavernous sinus thrombosis}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c5::Midbrain stroke}}&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>CN III has both motor (central) and
parasympathetic (peripheral) components.</b></div><div><font color=""#8fbfbf"">DM&nbsp;</font>Ischemia: pupil sparing</div><div>Uncal herniation: ipsilateral weakness / coma</div><div>PCA aneurysm: sudden-onset headache</div><div>Cavernous sinus thrombosis: proptosis, involvement of CNs IV, V1/V2, VI</div><div>Midbrain stroke: contralateral hemiplegia&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-24 at 8.36.21 AM.png""><br></div><div>w/u urgent or emergent depending on suspected cause</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-24 at 8.40.25 AM.png""><br></div><div><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"{{c1::Bilateral fixed dilated::3 characterisitcs (ominous sign)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pupils indicate a poor outcome in TBI</span>"	"<div>pinpoint pupils = pons or meds<br></div><div><img src=""321686_2200-800x1200.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gaze deviations point&nbsp;</span>{{c1::toward}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;the site of the lesion in <u>TBI</u></span>"	"<div><img src=""f016-014-9780323340441.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Rhythmic eye movements::ocular finding}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;might indicate a seizure in TBI</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Loss of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::corneal-blink}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::oculo-cephalic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;brain-stem reflexes are indicative of a severe&nbsp;</span>TBI"																					
"<div><strong>Respiratory patterns in TBI</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>initially present with hyperventilation which&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may indicate increasing&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ICP}}<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">followed by irregular breathing patterns called&nbsp;</span>{{c2::apnea}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">bradycardia, and then the&nbsp;</span>{{c3::Cheynes–Stokes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pattern of breathing</span></div>"	"<img src=""30b92a_989e7b2393c54354bbf9be6b6675280e.jpg"">"																				
"{{c1::Cheyne-Stokes}}<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">: respiration characterized by&nbsp;</span><b>alternating apnea and hyperventilation during sleep,&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>mostly in the N1 and N2 sleep, and also when awake<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">.&nbsp;</span></div>"	"assoc w/ CHF and cerebral ischemia&nbsp;<br><div><img src=""30b92a_989e7b2393c54354bbf9be6b6675280e.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>TBI sedation&nbsp;</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Benzodiazepines::class}} have minimal hemodynamic effects,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and {{c1::lorazepam::specific med}} does not diminish the respiratory drive.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>They have <u>{{c2::NO}}</u>&nbsp;direct effect on decreasing&nbsp;ICP</div>"	but long-term use can delay neurologic recovery.																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>TBI sedation</b></span></div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></span>{{c1::Barbiturates::class}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;can be used to induce a coma and decrease the metabolic requirements of the brain.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Pentobarbital::drug}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;can also control&nbsp;</span>ICP</div>"																					
"<div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Sedation TBI</b></span></div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></span>{{c1::propofol infusion}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;provides same&nbsp;</span>CNS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;depression as barbiturates&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::does::does/does not}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cause hemodynamic / respiratory depression&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may cause effect through the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::GABA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><sub>A</sub>::MOA}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;system. </span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and its short half-life can allow for frequent neurologic examinations</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">should be used only in hemodynamically stable patients&nbsp;</span><font color=""#333333""><br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">has a relatively favorable side effect profile with a rapid return to consciousness after the infusion is discontinued</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
<b>Evaluation of&nbsp;ICP</b><div><br></div><div>In a normal adult, reclining with the head and the trunk elevated to 45 degrees, normal&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;is {{c1::~3 (2 - 5)}} mmHg.</div><div><br></div><div>ICP&nbsp;levels up to {{c2::15}} mmHg are considered harmless.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Elevated&nbsp;ICP</u>: Defined as&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;&gt;{{c3::20}} mmHg for more than {{c3::5}} minutes</div>	<div>Common after severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;(53% reported in a recent series)</div>																				
<div><u>ICP pathophys</u></div><div><br></div>mass lesion causes {{c1::distortion}} of the brain tissue<div><br></div><div>and a reduction of the {{c1::CSF&nbsp;volume}}<div><br></div><div>↑&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;in the closed skull → {{c2::cerebral ischemia}} and formation of {{c2::herniations}}</div></div>	75% of patients with severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;die due to mass effect on tissue, shift, the development of internal hernias, and secondary damage to the&nbsp;CNS.<div><br></div><div>If unchecked, ↑&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;may cause death mainly because of deformation of tissue, brain shifts, herniation, and cerebral ischemia.</div>																				
<div>When&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;&gt;{{c1::40}} mmHg, there is neurological dysfunction and impairment of the brain’s <u>electrical activity</u></div><div><br></div><div>An&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;&gt;{{c1::60}} mmHg is invariably <u>fatal</u>.&nbsp;</div>	<div>Pressures of 20 to 40 mmHg are associated with increased morbidity.</div>																				
TBI acute evalualtion<div><br></div><div>Fever, hyperglycemia, and seizures can worsen {{c1::cerebral edema}} by ↑&nbsp;{{c1::ICP}}</div>																					
"CPP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;=&nbsp;</span>{{c1::MAP}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;–&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ICP}}"	"CPP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is calculated by subtracting&nbsp;</span>ICP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;from mean arterial pressure (</span>MAP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">):</span><div><img src=""images-602715d4f6771f42e4beda51a781ad683c06bf29.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div><b>Indications for Continuous Monitoring of <u>Intracranial Pressure</u> and for <u>Artificial Ventilation</u></b></div><div><br></div><div>1. Patient in coma (GCS&nbsp;&lt;8) and with CT&nbsp;findings of&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c4::↑&nbsp;ICP}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>2. Deep coma (GCS&nbsp;&lt;6) without {{c2::hematoma}}</div><div><br></div><div>3. Severe {{c3::chest &amp; facial injuries}}&nbsp;<strong>and</strong>&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;&lt;12</div><div><br></div><div>4. After {{c1::evacuation of&nbsp;IC&nbsp;hemorrhage}}&nbsp;if patient in coma (GCS&nbsp;&lt;8) beforehand<br></div>																					
<b>FACTORS THAT MAY INCREASE&nbsp;<u>ICP</u></b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Turning head}}</div><div>{{c2::Loud noise}}</div><div>{{c3::Vigorous PT}}</div><div>{{c4::Chest PT}}</div><div>{{c5::Suctioning}}</div><div>{{c6::Elevated BP}}</div>	Turning head: especially to <u>left</u> side if patient is completely horizontal or head down																				
<b>METHODS USED TO MONITOR&nbsp;ICP</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Papilledema}}</div><div>{{c2::CT}}</div><div>{{c3::Lumbar puncture*}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Intraventricular&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;monitor}}<br></div>	"<b>METHODS USED TO MONITOR&nbsp;ICP</b><div><br></div><div><u>Papilledema</u>: Rare in the acute stage after brain injury despite the fact that ↑&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;is frequent.</div><div>Usually occurs <font color=""#fc0006"">bilaterally</font></div><div>May indicate presence of intracranial <font color=""#fc0006"">mass lesion</font></div><div>Develops within <font color=""#fc0006"">12 to 24 hours</font> in cases of brain trauma and hemorrhage,&nbsp;</div><div>but, if pronounced, it usually signifies brain tumor or abscess, that is, a lesion of <font color=""#fc0006"">longer duration</font>.</div><div><br></div><div><u>CT&nbsp;scan </u>(see earlier)—if&nbsp;CT&nbsp;scan equivocal, cisternography may be done.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Lumbar puncture (LP)</u> if no papilledema (must rule out mass lesion first)</div><div>LP&nbsp;carries a certain <font color=""#0014ff"">risk*</font> of causing fatal shift of brain tissue (i.e., herniation) in the setting of ↑&nbsp;ICP.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Intraventricular&nbsp;ICP&nbsp;monitoring </u>(see “ICP&nbsp;Management” section) in severe&nbsp;TBI</div>"																				
"ICP&nbsp;MANAGEMENT<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">rec use of intraventricular&nbsp;</span>ICP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;catheters to monitor&nbsp;</span>ICPs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::severe}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;TBI or those with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">abnormal&nbsp;</span>CT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;scans</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div>"	may add more to this																				
"ICP MGMT<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">use of steroids&nbsp;</span>{{c1::is not::is/is not}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;recommended.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">based on the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::CRASH}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;trial&nbsp;</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">CRASH trial showed a significant increase in 2-week mortality in those given systemic steroids during the acute phase</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Barbiturates and decompressive craniotomies decrease&nbsp;</span>ICPs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">they&nbsp;</span>{{c1::do not::do/do not}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;affect mortality and morbidity</span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hypothermia may be used to ↓&nbsp;</span>ICP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and it may protect brain tissue by lowering&nbsp;</span>{{c1::cerebral metabolism}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_50"">Marion et al. (1997)</a><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">—treatment with hypothermia&nbsp;</span>{{c2::was::was/was not}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">associated with improved outcome</span></div>"	"<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_50"">Marion et al. (1997)</a><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">—treatment with hypothermia for 24 hours in severe&nbsp;</span>TBI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;patients (</span>GCS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;5–7) associated with improved outcome</span>"																				
<b>TBI surgical indications</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Penetrating injury}}</div><div>{{c4::Compound depressed skull fracture}}</div><div>{{c2::Epidural/Subdural hematoma}}</div><div>{{c3::Focal contusion}}</div><div>{{c5::intracerebral hemorrhage}}<br></div>	may want add more here&nbsp;																				
<b>Emergency Craniotomy</b><div><br></div><div>Definitive care for significant traumatic {{c1::epidural}} and&nbsp;{{c1::SDHs}}</div><div><br></div><div>Performed mainly to remove the {{c2::source of mass effect (or increasing&nbsp;ICP)}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>or to {{c3::clean/debride open}} wounds&nbsp;<br></div>	"40% of patients with a&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;&lt;9 will have intracranial hematomas.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Comatose patients who underwent surgery within 4 hours had better outcomes.</div><div><img src=""ElhM4zqXEAIcM9y.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Emergency Burr Hole</b><div><br></div><div>Indicated for a rapidly deteriorating patient who exhibits signs of {{c1::transtentorial herniation}}</div><div><br></div><div>caused by an expanding epidural or&nbsp;SDH</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-a9c2c7c5ee2ad9c8837fe073e84a3a2e7d237844.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Burr+Holes+Before+After.jpg""><br></div><br>"																				
"<b>{{c5::Uncal herniation}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;results when the medial part of the temporal lobe specifically,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::para-hippocampal gyrus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is displaced over the edge of the ipsilateral&nbsp;</span>{{c2::tentorium<font color=""#fc2307""><b>*</b></font>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;so as to compress...&nbsp;</span></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">cerebral cortex</span><br></div><div>{{c4::sub-thalamus<b><font color=""#fc0006"">^</font></b>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>CN3</div><div>{{c3::midbrain}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Occurs as a result of increased <u>supratentorial</u> pressure.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is commonly associated with <u>hematoma</u> (subdural or epidural) secondary to <u>trauma</u> or to a brain <u>tumor</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><font color=""#fc2307""><b>*</b></font><b>an <u>invagination of the meningeal layer</u> of the dura mater that separates the cerebral hemispheres from the cerebellum / brainstem</b></div><div><b><font color=""#fc0006"">^</font></b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;</span><b>subthalamus is&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">part of the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diencephalon"">diencephalon</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);""><span style=""font-size: 16.6667px;"">&nbsp;(also epi, hypo, and thalamus).</span></span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;Its most prominent structure is the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subthalamic_nucleus"">subthalamic nucleus</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">.</span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_8.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><img src=""diencephalon-definition-location-function_01002013_140001.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>Uncal herniation of the medial temporal lobe produces:</b></div><div><br></div><div>Stretching of {{c1::CN&nbsp;3}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>{{c5::Ipsilateral}}</u> hemiparesis due to pressure on the {{c2::corticospinal tract}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>located in the {{c5::contralateral::ipsi/contra}} {{c4::crus cerebri<font color=""#fc2307"">*</font>}} of the {{c4::cerebral peduncles<font color=""#fc2307""><b>+</b></font>}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>{{c5::Contralateral}}</u> hemiparesis due to pressure on the {{c5::ipsilateral}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c3::precentral motor cortex}} or {{c3::internal capsule}}</div>"	"In an uncal herniation, <u>reduced consciousness</u> and <u>bilateral motor</u> signs appear relatively <b>late</b><div><br></div><div>Central <u>hyperventilation</u> may also occur <b>late</b> in uncal herniation</div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#fc2307"" style=""font-weight: bold;"">*</font><u style=""font-weight: bold;"">anterior portion of the&nbsp;cerebral peduncle</u><b>&nbsp;</b>which contains the motor tracts, travelling from the cerebral cortex to the pons and spine<br></div><div><br></div><div><b><font color=""#fc2307"">+</font>2&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">stalks that attach the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cerebrum"">cerebrum</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;to the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brainstem"">brainstem</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">at the front of the&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midbrain"">midbrain</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;which arise from the ventral&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pons"">pons</a><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 34);"">&nbsp;and contain sensory/motor&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nerve_tract"">tracts</a><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_8.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Gray689.png""><img src=""Cn3nucleus.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Epilepsy: In a nontraumatic setting</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is a condition characterized by recurrent, at least&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, seizures&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">that are&nbsp;</span>{{c1::24}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;hours apart</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">without&nbsp;</span>{{c1::identifiable cause}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div></div>"																					
{{c1::Posttraumatic seizures (PTS)}}: Refers to a single recurrent seizure after&nbsp;TBI																					
PT Seizures are classified by onset.<div><br></div><div>Immediate&nbsp;PTS: Occurs within the first {{c1::24}} hours postinjury</div>	<div><b>PT Seizures are classified by onset</b><br></div><div>Immediate&nbsp;PTS: Occurs within the first 24 hours postinjury</div><div>Early&nbsp;PTS: Occurs within the first week (24 hours to 7 days)</div><div>Late&nbsp;PTS: Occurs after the first week</div>																				
<div>PT Seizures are classified by onset<br></div><div><br></div><div>Early&nbsp;PTS: Occurs within {{c1::24 hours}} to {{c1::7 days}}</div>	<div><b>PT Seizures are classified by onset</b><br></div><div>Immediate&nbsp;PTS: Occurs within the first 24 hours postinjury</div><div>Early&nbsp;PTS: Occurs within the first week (24 hours to 7 days)</div><div>Late&nbsp;PTS: Occurs after the first week</div>																				
<div>PT Seizures are classified by onset<br></div><div><br></div><div>Late&nbsp;PTS: Occurs after {{c1::7 days}}</div>	<div>PT Seizures are classified by onset<br></div><div><br></div><div>Immediate&nbsp;PTS: Occurs within the first 24 hours postinjury</div><div>Early&nbsp;PTS: Occurs within the first week (24 hours to 7 days)</div><div>Late&nbsp;PTS: Occurs after the first week</div>																				
"<div><b>PTS</b>&nbsp;are <u>classified</u> as:</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Partial seizure}} (simple if preserved consciousness; complex if consciousness is impaired)</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Generalized seizure}} (grand mal or tonic–clonic)</div>"	"<img src=""c1290620b8a411eab422e1ef3c39c091-Webp.net-resizeimage.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Majority of&nbsp;</span>PTS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are&nbsp;</span>{{c1::simple}} {{c1::partial}} (seizure type)<div><br></div><div>meaning the patient is {{c1::conscious}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<img src=""a509797ac98f46_6-Seizures.png"">"																				
"<b>Post traumatic seizure</b><div><br><div>{{c1::5}}% of hospitalized&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients (closed-head injury) have late&nbsp;PTS.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::5}}% of hospitalized&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients have one or more seizures in the first week after the injury (early&nbsp;PTS;&nbsp;<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_61"">Rosenthal et al., 1990</a>).</div></div></div>"																					
<b>Post traumatic seizure</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::50}}% of&nbsp;PTS&nbsp;occur within 1 year</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::80}}% occur within 2 years<br></div><div><br></div><div>Most&nbsp;PTS&nbsp;occur {{c2::1}} to {{c2::3}} months postinjury</div>	75% to 80% occur within 2 years																				
"<b>Post traumatic seizure</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>
of all patients who have PTS</u>&nbsp;<b><br></b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::50}}% will have only 1 seizure&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::25}}% have no more than 3 episodes</div></div>"	thus 25% have &gt;3																				
<b>Risk Factors Associated With <u>Late</u> Posttraumatic Seizures</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Penetrating head injury}}: 33% to 50%</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Intracranial hematoma}}: 25% to 30%</div><div><br></div><div>{{c3::Early&nbsp;PTS (&gt;24 hours to 7 days)}}: 25%</div><div><br></div><div>{{c4::Depressed skull fracture}}: 3% to 70%</div><div><br></div><div>{{c5::Prolonged coma or&nbsp;PTA (&gt;24 hours)}}: 35%</div>	"<div><u>Other risk factors:</u></div><div>Dural tearing / Presence of foreign bodies</div><div>Focal signs such as aphasia and hemiplegia</div><div>Age / Alcohol abuse / Use of&nbsp;TCAs</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_9.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Diagnosis of Posttraumatic Epilepsy</b><div><br></div><div>Clinical exam/findings</div><div>{{c1::EEG}}</div><div>{{c2::Prolactin lv.}}</div>	<div>EEG: (standard, sleep-deprived, 24 hour)<br></div><div>Prolactin level: ↑ prolactin level confirms true seizure activity, but normal level does not rule out seizure activity</div>																				
<b>Seizure Prophylaxis</b><div><br></div><div>Greatest risk of development of&nbsp;PTS&nbsp;in the first {{c1::2 years::long term}} postinjury</div><div><br></div><div>Phenytoin and valproic acid have been proven effective <u>only</u> for the {{c2::first 7 days}}&nbsp;</div>	"Prophylactic use of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) has <u>not</u> been proven effective in prospective, randomized, controlled studies.<div><br></div><div>Phenytoin and VA only decreases the incidence of <u>early&nbsp;PTS</u>. No benefit seen with prophylaxis for more than 1 week.<br><div><br></div><div>There is also no proof of change in overall outcome with prophylactic use of phenytoin (<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_70"">Temkin et al., 1990</a>) and evidence it may <b>delay recovery</b><br></div></div>"																				
"{{c1::levetiracetam (Keppra)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: commonly used as first-line treatment.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">has demonstrated comparable efficacy to phenytoin for early&nbsp;</span>PTS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;prophylaxis</span></div>"																					
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In 1997 Haltiner, Temkin, and Dikeman showed that&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">after the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::first}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;episode of <u>late</u>&nbsp;</span>PTS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, the probability of recurrent late&nbsp;</span>PTS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is up to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::85}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% within 2 years</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">thus <b>therapeutic anticonvulsant</b> medications are usually started once late seizures occur</span>"																				
"thereputic dose AED's i<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">n the&nbsp;</span>TBI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;population</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::carbamazepine}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::valproic acid}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are often preferred to medications that are more sedating&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or associated with cognitive impairment (such as <u>phenobarbital and phenytoin</u>).&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Their superiority over phenytoin has been debated,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">but the differences among these three agents are probably minimal;&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">carbamazepine may be as sedating as phenytoin</span></div>"																				
<div>{{c1::Phenobarbital}} is clearly associated with greater cognitive impairment and should not be used for PTS tx in TBI</div>	Long-term use of phenytoin has been associated with adverse cognitive effects.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Animal and clinical (extrapolated from strokes) studies suggest that phenytoin may impede recovery from brain injury&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>not 1st line</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">2nd-generation anticonvulsants, such as gabapentin and lamotrigine,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may also be used for tx of&nbsp;</span>PTS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;as&nbsp;</span>{{c1::adjuvant agents}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">not approved yet for monotherapy</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">appear to have fewer cognitive side effects.</span></div>"																				
TBI pt w/ hx of <u>late seizure</u>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>It is reasonable to consider withdrawal of antiepileptic drugs after a {{c1::2-year, seizure-free interval}}</div>	Increased risk of recurrence for those with more frequent PTS recurrences and...&nbsp;<div>treatment with &gt; 1 AED</div><div>HX of generalized tonic–clonic seizures</div><div>abnormal or epileptiform discharges on prewithdrawal&nbsp;EEG</div>																				
TBI pt with PTS recurrence despite tx with AED's<div><br></div><div><b>Advanced PTS treatments</b></div><div>1. {{c1::surgical resection}}<br><div>2. {{c1::Vagal nerve stimulation}}</div><div><br></div></div>	<div>The multicenter Study of Epilepsy Surgery reports that resective surgery significantly reduced seizure recurrence after medial temporal (77% 1-year remission) and neocortical resection (56% 1-year remission). There was also significant improvement in terms of quality of life and social functioning.</div><div><br></div><div>Vagal nerve stimulation (VNS), deep brain stimulation of the thalamic anterior nucleus, and responsive neurostimulation are neuromodulatory therapies which offer significant reductions in seizure frequency for patients with partial epilepsy.</div><div><br></div><div>VNS&nbsp;is approved by the&nbsp;FDA&nbsp;for adjunctive treatment of intractable partial seizures in patients over 12 years old.</div><div><br></div><div>Surgery is a very effective treatment for intractable frontal lobe epilepsy (FLE) secondary to encephalomalacias</div>																				
"<div><b>Paroxsysmal Autonomic Instability (PAI aka PSH)</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u style="""">3 Sy / 2 phys-ex</u>&nbsp;</div>{{c1::HTN}}<div>{{c1::tachycardia}}<br></div><div>{{c1::hyperthermia}}<br></div><div>{{c2::spasticity}}<br></div><div>{{c2::perspiration}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">due to a surge of circulating catecholamines released from trauma to&nbsp;</span>{{c4::autoregulatory centers}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">usually occurs within&nbsp;</span>{{c5::2 weeks}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the injury</span></div>"	"<img src=""gr2.jpg"">"																				
<b>Sympathetic storming management</b><div><br></div><div><div>{{c1::Bromocriptine}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Analgesics (morphine / gaba)}}</div><div><div>{{c1::Dantrolene}}&nbsp;<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Propranolol}}</div><div>{{c1::Amantadine}}&nbsp;<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>the 2 tx categories are {{c2::abortive}} and {{c2::preventive}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div><b><i>Bad P.A.</i></b></div><div>Lipophilic beta-blockers for&nbsp;HTN/tachycardia<br></div><div><div>Dantrolene sodium for malignant hyperthermia<br></div><div>NSAIDs&nbsp;(indomethacin), acetaminophen (to adress noxious stimuli)</div><div>Cooling blankets, nasogastric tube (NGT), IVF (for sweating)</div><div>Dopamine agonists: Amantadine, bromocriptine:</div><div>Anterior hypothalamus—temperature sensitive</div><div>Posterior hypothalamus—heat dissipation center</div></div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">may want to add more here ie UTD or pinto article</font></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-10-08 at 10.30.45 AM.png""><font color=""#fc0006""><br></font></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-10-08 at 10.31.13 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div>{{c1::ventriculomegaly::hydrocephalus/ventriculomegaly}} is common after severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;(40%–72%)</div>	"<div>However, true posttraumatic hydrocephalus (PTH) is relatively rare. Incidence is 3.9% to 8%.<br></div><div><br></div>Ventriculomegaly is 2/2 to cerebral atrophy and focal infarction of brain tissue&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">(<u>ex vacuo</u></span><u>&nbsp;changes</u>)<div><img src=""Hydrocephalus-final-02.png""><br></div>"																				
<div>PTH&nbsp;in&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients is most often of the {{c1::communicating::communicating/non-communicating}} type</div>	"aka or normal-pressure&nbsp;hydrocephalus<div>non-comm - cerebral aquaeduct</div><div>comm - arachnoid granulations&nbsp;<br><div><img src=""EulW3eFXUAMg3fB.jpg""><br></div></div><div><img src=""EulW25WXAAALo3D.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div>PT Hydrocephalus symptoms:</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::HA}}</div><div>{{c2::vomiting}}</div><div>{{c3::confusion}}<br></div>	"Classic triad of incontinence, ataxia/gait disturbance, and dementia of NPH is of little help, especially in severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;cases.<div><br></div><div>sx's appear to be that of increased ICP</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-30 at 10.47.07 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"CTH&nbsp;to r/o hydrocephalus should be considered if there is {{c1::deterioration of cognition/behavior or function::2}}<div><br></div><div><u>CT&nbsp;findings include...</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Periventricular lucency<font color=""#0851ff"" style=""""><b>*</b></font>}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::sulcal effacement<b><font color=""#0851ff"">^</font></b>}}</div><div>{{c4::uniform ventricular dilation}}</div>"	"<div><b style=""""><font color=""#0851ff"">*</font></b><font color=""#202124"">PVL:&nbsp;</font>decreased attenuation level, or “blurring,” around the peri-ventricular area on CT, or T2 hyperintensity on MRI<br></div><div><b style=""""><font color=""#0851ff"">^</font></b><font color=""#3d3d3d"">SE: 2/2 lesion exerting mass effect that pushes adjacent gyri together</font><br></div>Treatment:&nbsp;LP, shunt placement<div><div><img src=""periventricular-wmh.png""><img src=""gr1_lrg-abef7bc19895848c7e02afd998bc6bbde1c81f31.jpg""></div></div><div><img src=""Hydrocephalus-final-02.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Hydrocephalus-final-03.png""><br></div>"																				
TBI 3 Most frequently affected CN's&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Olfactory nerve (CN&nbsp;I)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Facial nerve (CN&nbsp;VII)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Vestibulo-cochlear nerve (CN&nbsp;VIII)}}<br></div>	"CNs affected with <u>intermediate frequency</u>:<div>Optic nerve (CN&nbsp;II)<br></div><div>Oculomotor nerves (CN&nbsp;IV &gt;&nbsp;CN&nbsp;III &gt;&nbsp;CN&nbsp;VI)</div><div><br></div><div><u>Rarely involved&nbsp;CNs</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>Trigeminal nerve (CN&nbsp;V)</div><div>lower&nbsp;CNs (9, 10, 11)</div><div><img src=""book008_sec1_fig483.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"																				
CN1 most often damaged by blunt head trauma due to tearing of the olfactory nerve filaments<div>&nbsp;</div><div>in the {{c1::cribriform plate}} of the {{c1::ethmoid bone}} through which they traverse<br></div>	"Symptoms: Anosmia and an apparent loss of taste<div><br></div><div>Overall incidence approximately 7% and increases with the&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;severity (19.4% in moderate&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;and 24.5% in severe&nbsp;TBI)</div><div><img src=""shutterstock_1048580027-400x276.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::CN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;I</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;injury is the only&nbsp;</span>CN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;neuropathy present in <u>mild</u>&nbsp;</span>TBI"	Prob no treatment??<div>Cacosomia can be treated with gabapentin</div><div>ENT for olfactory retraining??&nbsp;</div>																				
Anosmia: Complete loss of smell<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Dysnosmia}}: Impaired sense of smell</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Hyposmia}}: Partial loss of smell</div>																					
<div>{{c1::Parosmia}}: Sensation of smell in the absence of stimulus</div>																					
{{c1::Cacosmia}}: Awareness of disagreeable or unusually offensive odor that does not exist;&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>may be part of an aura prior to a seizure onset</div>																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In higher level patients,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::CN1}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pathology</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">could present with&nbsp;</span>{{c3::decrease in appetite, weight loss, and/or altered feeding pattern}}</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Recovery occurs in &gt;</span>{{c2::1/3::fraction}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of cases, usually during the first&nbsp;</span>{{c2::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months</span><br></div>"	"<font color=""#333333"">assoc w/&nbsp;</font>CSF&nbsp;rhinorrhea"																				
<b>CN&nbsp;VII (FACIAL NERVE)</b><div><br></div><div>The facial nerve <u>innervates the following four components</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Tactile sensation ~external ear}}<br></div><div>Taste ant 2/3 of the tongue</div><div>Muscles of facial expression</div><div>Salivary and lacrimal glands</div><div><br></div>	It is especially vulnerable to penetrating or blunt trauma to the head because of its long, tortuous course through the temporal bone<div><br></div><div>cry, taste pie, wink your eye&nbsp;</div>																				
<b>CN&nbsp;VIII (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE)</b><div><br></div><div>Damage to the nerve results in {{c2::loss of hearing}}, or in {{c1::vertigo}} and {{c1::nystagmus}}&nbsp;</div>	coming on immediately after the trauma																				
<b>CN&nbsp;II (OPTIC NERVE)</b><div><br></div><div><u>Partial damage</u> may result in...</div><div>{{c1::scotomas}}</div><div>{{c2::blurred vision}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::monocular blindness}}</div>	If&nbsp;CN&nbsp;II is <u>completely involved</u> or transected, patient will develop complete blindness&nbsp;<div><br><div>(pupil dilated, unreactive to direct light but reactive to light stimulus to the opposite eye [consensual light reflex])</div></div>																				
"{{c2::Agitation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is a subtype of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::delirium}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;occurring during the state of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::PTA}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and is characterized by excesses of behavior</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">including some combination of aggression, akathisia, disinhibition, and/or emotional lability</span><div><br></div><div>Occurs as patients become more responsive in early stages of recovery</div>"																				
Agitation Usually lasts 1 to {{c1::14}} days but can last longer	About 2 weeks, “ride the storm”&nbsp;																				
agitation most commonly occurs with {{c1::fronto-temporal}} lesions	which coordinate arousal, attention, executive control, memory, and limbic behavioral functions																				
When a TBI pt becomes agitated it is important to {{c1::clearly identify the behvior}}	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The generic word&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">agitation</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is not enough; identify the problem behavior</span>"																				
<div>Objective measurement is critical. Posttraumatic agitation can be quantified with 2 Scales</div><div><br></div><div>1.) {{c1::Agitated Behavior Scale (ABS)}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.) {{c2::Overt Agitation Severity Scale (OASS)}}</div>	<div>Agitated Behavior Scale (ABS): Designed for serial assessment of agitated patients. Ratings are based on behavioral observations made after an 8-hour nursing shift or therapy treatment session. Consists of 14 items or behaviors rated between one (absent) and four (present to an extreme). Scoring: Below 21: normal; 22 to 28: mild agitation; 29 to 35: moderate agitation; 35 to 54: severe agitation.</div><div><br></div><div>Overt Agitation Severity Scale (OASS): Contains 47 observable characteristics of agitation to assess its severity. Behavior subgroups are scored one to four (mild–severe) and multiplied by their frequency for a composite score</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Agitated Behavior Scale (</span>ABS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">): Designed for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::serial assessment}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of agitated patients&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Ratings are based on behavioral observations made after an&nbsp;</span>{{c1::8-hour nursing shift}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Consists of 14 items or behaviors rated between one (absent) and four (present to an extreme).&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Scoring: Below 21: normal; 22 to 28: mild agitation; 29 to 35: moderate agitation; 35 to 54: severe agitation</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Environmental Management of Posttraumatic Agitation</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Reduce the level of stimulation in the environment</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Remove noxious stimuli}}&nbsp;<br></div><div>Place patient in quiet room</div><div>Limit unnecessary sounds — (TV, radio, talking)</div><div>Limit number of visitors</div><div>Staff to behave in a calm and reassuring manner</div><div>{{c2::Limit number and length of therapy sessions}}</div><div>{{c2::Provide therapies in patient room/quiet gym}}</div>"	Remove noxious stimuli if possible—tubes, catheters, restraints, traction asap																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Environmental Management of Posttraumatic Agitation</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Protect patient from harming self or others</u></span></div><div>{{c3::4-side rails}}</div><div>Place patient in {{c2::a floor bed/net bed}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Virtual sitter}}</div><div>Assign {{c4::1:1 or 1:2 sitter}}&nbsp;</div><div>Place&nbsp;{{c1::patient in locked ward}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Agitated, nonambulatory patients often benefit from the use of a floor <b>(Craig) bed</b>.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Mattresses can be placed on the floor with 3- to 4-foot padded walls on four sides that allow the patient to roll around</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The use of a floor bed with 1:1 supervision and with the use of mitts and a helmet (if necessary) often <u>eliminates the need for restraints</u></span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_10.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Environmental Management of Posttraumatic Agitation</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div><u>Reduce patient’s cognitive confusion:</u></div><div>One person speaking to patient at a time</div><div>Maintain {{c1::same staff}}&nbsp;</div><div>Communicate with patient briefly and simply, one idea at a time</div></div>"	Minimize contact with unfamiliar staff. same therapists if possible																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Environmental Management of Posttraumatic Agitation</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><div>tolerate {{c1::restlessness}} when possible</div></div>"	<div>Allow patient to thrash about in floor bed.</div><div><br></div><div>Allow patient to pace around unit with 1:1 supervision.</div><div><br></div><div>Allow confused patient to be verbally inappropriate.</div>																				
{{c1::Mesolimbic}}: Decreased dopamine, decreased positive symptoms	"<img src=""a_03_cl_que_1a.gif"">"																				
{{c1::Mesocortical}}: Decreased dopamine, increased negative symptoms	"<img src=""a_03_cl_que_1a.gif"">"																				
{{c1::Nigrostriatal}}: Decreased dopamine, increased movement disorders	"<div>stride = movement</div><img src=""a_03_cl_que_1a.gif"">"																				
{{c1::Tuberoinfundibular}}: Decreased dopamine, increased prolactin	"<div>tuber = white</div><img src=""a_03_cl_que_1a.gif"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Antipsychotic medications can potentially cause&nbsp;</span>neuroleptic malignant<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;syndrome (sy:&nbsp;</span>{{c2::fever}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span>{{c2::leukocytosis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and muscle stiffness)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">→ treat with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::dantrolene}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::beta-blockers}}</div>"	"<img src=""B77ohIAypLI8nzvQQlJPhA_b.png"">"																				
"suspect dual diagnosis in SCI pt based on...<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">mech of injury (e.g.,&nbsp;</span>MVC w/ head strike<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<br></div><div>{{c1::loc}}<br></div><div>{{c2::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">higher&nbsp;</span>NLI}}</div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">abnl (</span>GCS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<i><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></i></div>"																					
"2 consideration in dual diagnosis sci pt<div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::avoid sedating meds (ie baclofen)::meds}}<br><div><i><div>{{c2::high BP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may signal </span>AD<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Storm::vitals</span>}}<br></div></i></div></div>"	"<i><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">care taken to utilize medications with minimal cognitive impact. ie baclofen routinely used in&nbsp;</span>SCI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>high BP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may signal the presence of&nbsp;</span>AD<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;“sympathetic storm""</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may need follow up in concussion clinic or neuro-cog testing</span></div></i>"																				
<b>Treatment of Agitation in Posttraumatic Agitation</b><div><br></div><div>after identifying the exact behavior you must first, Identify if {{c1::its an emergency}}&nbsp;</div>	issue that requires immediate intervention (severity, potential risk, and acuity) danger to self or others																				
<b>Treatment of Post-traumatic Agitation</b>&nbsp;<div><br><div><u>Consider possible differential diagnosis</u>:</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Drug withdrawal}}</div><div>{{c2::Delirium tremens}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Infection}}</div><div>{{c4::Pain}}</div><div>{{c5::Hypoxia}}</div><div>{{c6::Seizure}}</div></div><div>{{c7::New neuro-event}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div><u>same w/u as encephalopahty</u></div><div><font color=""#095cff"">sleep wake cycle&nbsp;</font></div><div><font color=""#095cff"">paradoxically neuro stimulants can hlep (increase &gt; Ranchos 4)&nbsp;</font></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 6.32.50 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 6.33.13 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Treatment of Posttraumatic Agitation</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><u>Acute/Emergency Medication management:</u></div><div><br></div><div>Minimize cognitive-impairing medications: {{c1::benzodiazepines}} and {{c1::typical-antipsychotics}}</div><div><br></div><div>For immediate effect if there is significant risk of injury to person or property, use: {{c2::Atypical-antipsychotic}}</div></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 6.32.50 PM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 6.33.13 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>TBI Agitation Medication management:</b><div><br></div><div><u>Maintenance with</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::anticonvulsants::class}}</div><div>{{c1::beta-blockers::class}}</div><div>{{c1::atypical-antipsychotics::class}}</div><div>{{c2::trazodone}}</div><div>{{c2::SSRIs::class}}</div><div>rarely {{c3::lithium}}</div><div>For more mild agitation, {{c3::buspirone}}</div>	"<div>Reassessment with objective measures<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 6.32.50 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 6.33.13 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>HO Differential Diagnosis</b><div>{{c1::DVT}}</div><div>{{c2::tumor}}</div><div>{{c3::septic joint}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::hematoma}}</div><div>{{c5::cellulitis}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c6::fracture}}</div>																					
<b>HO Signs/Symptoms</b><div><br></div><div>Most common: {{c1::Pain}} and {{c1::↓&nbsp;ROM}}</div><div><br></div><div>Also: Local {{c2::swelling}}, {{c2::erythema}}, {{c2::warmth}}</div><div>{{c3::muscle guarding}}</div><div>{{c4::low-grade fever}}</div>																					
<b>HO DIAGNOSTIC TESTS</b><div><br></div><div>Serum {{c1::alkaline phosphatase}} elevation may be the earliest and least expensive method of detection of&nbsp;HO</div>	It has poor specificity (may be elevated for multiple reasons, such as fractures, hepatic dysfunction, etc																				
<b>HO triple phase bone scan</b><br><div><br></div><div>HO&nbsp;can be seen within the first {{c1::2}} to {{c1::4}} weeks after injury in Phase I (blood-flow phase) and Phase II (blood-pool phase)</div><div><br></div><div>seen in Phase III (static phase/delayed images) in {{c2::4}} to {{c2::8}} weeks, with normalization by {{c3::6}} to {{c3::12}} months</div>	"<img src=""paste-8e6487fb347c6f8af53e2c0cc94fcc49fe40b8e8.jpg"">"																				
<b>HO&nbsp;Prophylaxis</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::ROM&nbsp;exercises}}</div><div>{{c2::Control of spasticity}}</div><div>{{c3::NSAID}}</div><div>{{c4::Radiation}}</div>	<div>Radiation perioperatively to inhibit&nbsp;HO&nbsp;in total hip replacement patients; concerns about ↓ risk of neoplasia limit its use in younger patient populations</div><div><br></div><div>Radiation in&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients for&nbsp;HO&nbsp;prophylaxis would require essentially irradiation of the whole body (as&nbsp;HO&nbsp;can develop practically at any joint), which is not practical.</div>																				
<b>HO tx</b><div><br></div><div>Surgical resection usually postponed {{c1::12}} to {{c1::18}} months to allow maturation of&nbsp;HO</div>	Surgical resection of&nbsp;HO&nbsp;indicated only if function is the goal (e.g., hygiene, activities of daily living [ADLs], transfers)																				
{{c1::hypertension::abnl. vital sign}} is frequently observed post-TBI: Estimated incidence 11% to 25%	<div>Posttraumatic&nbsp;HTN&nbsp;usually resolves spontaneously. Long-term use of antihypertensive agents is rarely necessary.</div><div><br></div><div>Post-TBI&nbsp;HTN&nbsp;related to sympathetic hyperactivity usually seen in severe&nbsp;TBI—demonstrated by plasma and urine catecholamine levels</div>																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Cases of&nbsp;</span>HTN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;have been reported secondary to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hydrocephalus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;several&nbsp;</span>{{c2::years}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after&nbsp;</span>TBI<br></div>"																					
<div>post-TBI hypertension&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>If medication needed, {{c1::propranolol}} is recommended&nbsp;	<div><u>because:</u></div><div>Plasma catecholamine levels</div><div>Cardiac index</div><div>Myocardial oxygen demand</div><div>Heart rate</div><div>Improves pulmonary ventilation-perfusion inequality</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">in the&nbsp;</span>TBI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;population,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sudden death (2/2 PE)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;from&nbsp;</span>VTE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the 1st clinical sign in 70% to 80%</span>"	"VTE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is often clinically silent in the&nbsp;</span>TBI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;population</span><div><br></div><div>Incidence of&nbsp;DVT&nbsp;in&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;rehabilitation admissions is approximately 10% to 18% (Cifu et al.,&nbsp;<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_15"">1996</a>).</div>"																				
<u>Diagnostic Studies for&nbsp;DVT</u>&nbsp;<div>Doppler ultrasonography</div><div>{{c1::Impedance plethysmography (IPG)}}</div><div>{{c2::<sup>125</sup>I-fibrinogen scanning}}<br></div><div>Contrast venography (Gold standard)&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""10.3928_01477447-19901201-05-fig1.jpg""><img src=""paste-70e7250c0a3d2c070b197c883312b54c001a52a1.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-874f907c39a1d0c6a30096013e71009adea4a5a3.jpg""><br></div>"																				
Neurogenic bladder in TBI presents with {{c1::uninhibited detrusor reflex::pathophys}}&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>TBI&nbsp;patients are frequently incontinent, the urine volume is {{c2::reduced}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>postvoiding intravesicular volumes are {{c2::normal}}</div>	disinhibited type of neurogenic bladder<div><br></div><div>in reality likely more behavioarl and try to resist adding anti-cholinergic</div>																				
<u>neurogenic bladder TBI tx 2...</u><div>{{c1::timed-voiding}}</div><div><div>{{c1::Anticholinergics}}&nbsp;</div></div>	"<div>a time-void program is usually helpful, in which the patient is offered the urinal or commode at a regularly scheduled interval.</div><div><br></div><div>Anticholinergic meds (decreases detrusor tone → increases bladder capacity) may also be used.</div><div><img src=""3-s2.0-B9780323625395000205-f20-04-9780323625395.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Acute&nbsp;</span>TBI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and the resulting increase in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::muscle tone}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cause a state of hypermetabolism</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">which increases energy requirements from 100% to 140% of what is expected</span>"																				
<b>SDH chronicity</b><br><div><br></div><div><div>Subacute&nbsp;SDH: Those between {{c1::3 days}} and {{c1::3 weeks}}&nbsp;</div></div>																					
<b>SDH chronicity</b><br><div><br></div><div><div>Chronic&nbsp;SDH: Lesions &gt;{{c1::3 weeks}}&nbsp;</div></div>																					
"<div><b>DAI&nbsp;classification is based on severity:</b><br></div><div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Grade II</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Widespread white matter/axonal damage, and {{c1::focal}}&nbsp;findings, most common in the {{c1::corpus callosum}}</div></div>"	"<div><br></div><div><img src=""3-Table1-1.png""><br></div><div><img src=""jti-31-051f2.gif""><br></div><div><img src=""fnins-17-1077858-g001.jpg""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_2.png"">"																				
"<div><b>DAI&nbsp;classification is based on severity:</b></div><div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Grade III</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Damage involving the {{c1::brainstem}}</div></div>"	"<div><br></div><div><div><img src=""3-Table1-1.png""><br></div><div><img src=""jti-31-051f2.gif""><br></div><div><img src=""fnins-17-1077858-g001.jpg""></div></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig2_2.png"">"																				
What is the first line imaging for hip flexor strains?<br>Tx?	AP, Frog legs to exclude apophyseal avulsion<br>Tx- protected wb, icing, gentle ROM ASAP, strengthening when gait non-antalgic																				
Snapping hip syndrome- internal vs external?	External: tight ITB, gluteus Maximus over greater trochanter<br>Internal: Iliopsoas, less commonly labral tear																				
Most common type of hip dislocation?<br>MOI?<br>Common associated neural injury?<br>Complication?	Posterior<br>-Knee hitting dashboard, Flexed, adducted, medially rotated<br>-Sciatic nerve stretch/compression<br>-Watch for AVN																				
Posterior hip dislocation clinical presentation? Cannot perform what ROM? <br>Tx?	affected leg shorter, inability to adduct hip<br>Note: Orthopedic emergency																				
Imaging for suspected AVN of hip?<br>Findings?	MRI of both hips<br>T1- low signal intensity - rings, wedges, irregular configurations<br>T2- double line sign&nbsp;<br>																				
Posterior THA precautions?	Avoid hip flexion &gt;90 degrees, Adduction past midline, extreme internal rotation<br><br>(Posterior THA precautions opposite of Anterior THA precautions)																				
Anterior Total hip arthroplasty precautions?	Avoid hip extension and external rotation<br>(Posterior THA precautions opposite of Anterior THA precautions)																				
Most common type of hip fracture?<br>Clinical features?<br>Complications?	Intertrochanteric<br>Hip pain with ext rotated and shortened limb<br>-Post operative leg length&nbsp;discrepancy

flap}}: Rectangular flap rotates about its base to fill an adjacent defect</div>"	"<img src=""Classification-of-Flaps--4.png"">"

flap}}: Moved into a defect without lateral or rotational movement</div>"	"<img src=""Classification-of-Flaps--4.png"">"																				
{{c1::Resolution of&nbsp;PTA}}&nbsp;clinically corresponds to the period when,&nbsp;<div><br><div>incorporation of ongoing daily events occurs in the working memory</div></div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png"">&nbsp;"																				
What Fx does lowering the high frequency filter OR raising the low frequency do?	Decreases amplitude- 'squishes' waveform																				
Lowering high frequency filter does what besides lowering amplitude?	"Polongs onset and peak latencies<br>""I'm late because I was high"""																				
Raising the low frequency filter does what besides decrease amplitude?	"Shortens peak latency<br>""I peaked early at a low point in my life""<br>""amp-low-tude"""																				
What is normal CV in upper and lower extremities?<br>How does age change CV in EDx?	Upper: at least 50 m/s<br>Lower: at least 40 m/s<br>Past 50 CV decreases 2 m/s per decade																				
What are the criteria for normal F waves?&nbsp;<br>What do prolonged/absent F waves mean?	-F waves are normal if seen on 80% or more of stimulations, similar latency (all starting at same time)<br>-Prolonged/absent F waves are first sign of GBS																				
What do A waves mean?<br>Where do they appear?	-Reinnervation of the nerve to that muscle (prior nerve damage at some point)<br>-Between stim and F waves<br>																				
What electrode in EMG needs a separate reference electrode?	Monopolar<br>In concentric needles reference electrode is attached																				
Fasiculations WITH fibs and sharps=?	Pathology, i.e ALS																				
What does Myokymia sound like?<br>Significance?	Marching soldiers<br>Upper trunk radiation plexopathy<br>Less commonly compresssion neuropathy, rattlesnake venom																				
What do CRDs sound like?<br>Significance?	-Like a bug/cicada buzz?<br>-Ephaptic transmission<br>-Denervation by a motor unit, reinervation by other muscle, chronic radiculopathy, anterior horn cell, normal variant																				
What do myotonic discharges sound like?<br>Significance?	-Dive bomber<br>-Anything with myotonia in its name: Myotonic dystrophy, paramyotonia, myotonia congenita, hyperkalemic periodic paralysis, acid maltase deficiency																				
At max effort, how many motor units should you see?	4																				
How to calculate motor unit Hz ballpark estimate?	How many times a single MUAP shows on screen x 5																				
How to see decreased recruitment?<br>What does decreased recruitment sound like?<br>Decreased recruitment indicates what pathology?<br>Why?	-Increased firing rate of MUAPs up to 40-50 Hz from only 1-2 motor units<br>-'Machine gun' sound<br>-Axonal damage<br>-Fewer axons are left to supply muscle, leaving 'survivor' axons to recruit the same muscles<br><b>AKA Neuropathic recruitment pattern</b>																				
What counts as a polyphaic MUAP?<br>Significance?	-Crossing baseline 5 or more times<br>-Reinnervation																				
What is a LDLA?<br>Significance?	Long duration, large amplitude<br>Neuropathic MUAPs																				
What is a SDSA?	Increased, myopathic recruitment<br>serrated																				
Wallerian degeneration happens in which direction?	Anterograde<br>... To the walls																				
Wallerian degeneration completes by how many days?	5 motor<br>10 sensory																				
Retrograde degeneration commonly occurs in what illness?	Diabetes																				
After a new onset injury/complaint how long should an EMG be scheduled out?	4-6 weeks																				
What is Neurotmesis?<br>Prognosis?	Transection through the whole nerve<br>-Worst prognosis																				
What is Neurapraxia?<br>Prognosis?	-Focal demylination with conduction block<br>-Good prognosis, wait a few weeks for remylination																				
What is Axonotemesis?<br>Usually occurs due to?<br>Significant EMG findings?	-Axonal death<br>-Commonly occurs 2/2 crush/stretch injury<br>-Fibs and Sharps on EMG<br>-Note multiple axons connecting to same muscle during regeneration, strongest connection will 'win'																				
What is one cause of a neuroma?	Axonal regeneration in Neurotemesis

What is a MEPP?	"<img src=""paste-efe0cc1cb3ee0fc2e610edf26d1ae8bcde08d597.jpg"">"																				
What do fibs mean?<br>What do they sound like?	"Denervation of single muscle fibers<br>""Rain on a tin roof"""
