What do 5 or more baseline crossings represent?	Polyphasicity																				
What is the rule of 5s in normal motor unit action potential?	"Motor unit recruitment with increased Hz<br><img src=""paste-f7388312c8a44de53fb17801b3aad86d4a3c8432.jpg"">"																				
What does Early recruitment vs reduced recruitment mean?	"<img src=""paste-81738e80c91f51866cee24c375792a3e9760043f.jpg"">"																				
What is a normal Recruitment ratio?	"&lt;10<br><img src=""paste-9281a9aee045f91665145b3c48ef6ddd46208b85.jpg"">"																				
In radiculopathy, what do NCS show?	Typically normal<br>																				
What are some uncommon causes of Radiculopathy?	"<img src=""paste-6e2aaede4dae2629e2223dee8198290abefd4543.jpg"">"																				
F wave utility in radiculopathy?	Not sensitive or specific for radiculopathies																				
What is the optimal number of muscles to screen for a radiculopathy?	"6 (5 + Paraspinals)<br><img src=""paste-5610b25301fe81e0a0e191713b00a62124a0c20a.jpg"">"																				
What are FIB and PSW findings in radiculopathies?	"Found in 2 different muscles w/same roots<br><img src=""paste-8f0061b59a536e5aa7f61204e7d526d2e43e7a39.jpg"">"																				
Characteristics of C2-C3 radiculopathies?	Greater and lesser occipital nerve pain, respectively																				
"Sx in following muscles may indicate what root pathology?<br><img src=""paste-7329d14c6d37a4b3de4d3fcaf53baa682a35af0f.jpg"">"	C5 root, C4-C5 HNP																				
What muscle is innervated by C5 and not C6?&nbsp;	Rhomboids, Brachialis(?)

Volleyball more commonly<br>injures branches to the IS muscle.

"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">From 1989 to 1992 there were approximately 105,000 amputations of the&nbsp;</span>LE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">;&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">~</span>{{c1::1/3::fraction}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of those were toe amputations</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">32%</span>"																				
"<strong>Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">a ratio of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ankle systolic pressure}} to {{c1::brachial systolic pressure}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<img src=""1-s2.0-S0735109713019876-gr1.jpg"">"																				
<strong>Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)</strong><div><div><br></div><div>ABI&nbsp;{{c1::0.41}} to {{c1::0.70}}: Moderate&nbsp;PAD</div><div><br></div><div>ABI&nbsp;{{c1::0.00}} to {{c1::0.40}}: Severe&nbsp;PAD</div></div>	<div>ABI&nbsp;0.91 to 1.30: Normal<br></div><div><div><br></div><div>ABI&nbsp;0.71 to 0.90: Mild&nbsp;PAD</div><div><br></div><div>ABI&nbsp;0.41 to 0.70: Moderate&nbsp;PAD</div><div><br></div><div>ABI&nbsp;0.00 to 0.40: Severe&nbsp;PAD</div><div><br></div><div>ABI&nbsp;&gt;1.30 may suggest calcified, noncompressible vessels, which can produce false negative results. This is common in diabetics</div></div>																				
<div>ABI&nbsp;{{c1::0.91}} to {{c1::1.30}}: Normal<br></div><div><div><br></div><div>ABI&nbsp;{{c1::0.71}} to {{c1::0.90}}: Mild&nbsp;PAD</div></div>																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">If screening&nbsp;</span>ABI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is abnormal,&nbsp;</span><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Doppler waveform}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;analysis is performed to localize the lesion</span></div>"	"used once the area of interest is identified add more<div><img src=""paste-d565c4159c740434d11b6e9354971d62ed28f854.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""15949""><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(24, 33, 77);"">Doppler ultrasound showing typical triphasic waveform. Yellow arrow points to the Doppler sample volume. Red arrow points to the spectral window.</span><br></div><div><img src=""15950""><span style=""color: rgb(24, 33, 77);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(24, 33, 77);"">Doppler ultrasound of the right posterior tibial artery showing classic monophasic waveform. Peripheral arteries should never have monophasic waveforms. Note the red arrow pointing to spectral broadening.</span><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Doppler waveforms are obtained at multiple sites and a change in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::waveform}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><div><br></div><div>{{c2::peak velocity}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;from one level to the next is indicative of&nbsp;</span>PAD</div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(24, 33, 77);"">Doppler ultrasound showing typical triphasic waveform. Yellow arrow points to the Doppler sample volume. Red arrow points to the spectral window</span><br></div><div><img src=""15949""><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(24, 33, 77);"">Doppler ultrasound of the right posterior tibial artery showing classic monophasic waveform.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(24, 33, 77);"">Peripheral arteries should never have monophasic waveforms. Note the red arrow pointing to spectral broadening</span><br></div><div><img src=""15950""></div>"																				
{{c1::Intra-arterial contrast&nbsp;angiography}}&nbsp;is the Gold standard imaging test for&nbsp;PAD	"<img src=""image.png"">"																				
<strong>Intraarterial contrast angiography</strong><div><br></div><div>used for screening purposes: {{c1::No::Y/N}}&nbsp;</div>	"Invasive test with vascular complications&nbsp;<div><img src=""F26.png""><br></div><div>18 G needle access to the CFA</div><div><img src=""F29.png""><br></div>"																				
<div>{{c1::Myodesis}}: Muscles and fasciae are sutured directly to bone through drill holes</div>	"<img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/356438224/figure/fig2/AS:1098606656393216@1638939646155/Myoplasty-and-myodesis-in-TF-amputation-surgery-Left-myodesis-of-the-adductor-magnus.png"">"																				
<div><strong>Myodesis</strong>: Muscles and fasciae are sutured directly to bone through drill holes.</div><div><br></div><div>Residual limb is more {{c1::structurally stable}}</div><div><br></div><div>Contraindicated in {{c2::severe dysvascularity}}&nbsp;</div>	"in which the blood supply to the bone may be compromised<div><img src=""1-s2.0-S0363502311009907-gr8.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Myoplasty}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Opposing muscles are sutured to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::each other}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and to the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::periosteum at the end of the cut bone}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;with minimal tension</span></div>"	"<img src=""u024-0456-9780323568388.jpg""><div><img src=""pharmaceuticals-14-01133-g001.png""></div>"																				
<strong>Myoplasty</strong>: Opposing muscles are sutured to each other and to the periosteum at the end of the cut bone with minimal tension.<div><br></div><div>Pro: {{c2::takes less OR time}}</div><div><br></div><div>May be procedure of choice in {{c1::severe dysvascularity}}&nbsp;<br></div>	"<img src=""u024-0456-9780323568388.jpg"">"

"{{c1::Partial foot (ray)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;=&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Resection of a portion of up to three metatarsals and digits</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_8.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Lis franc}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;= Amputation at the tarsometatarsal junction</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_8.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Chopart}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;=&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Midtarsal amputation—only talus and calcaneus remain</span>"	"<div><br></div><div><img src=""FGLlwcgXMAItKVw.jpg""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_8.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Syme’s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;=&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Ankle disarticulation with attachment of heel pad to distal end of tibia;&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may include removal of malleoli and distal tibial/fibular flares</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_8.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Hemicorporectomy}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;=&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Amputation of both lower limbs and pelvis below L4/L5 level</span>"	"<img src=""2-Figure1-1-1e0c29d7d1ce93c7e8220960e0acf1e952cb31fa.png""><img src=""4-Figure4-1.png"">"																				
"UNSATISFACTORY LEVELS OF AMPUTATION<br><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Distal two-fifths of tibia (below gastroc-soleus musculature) =&nbsp;</span>{{c1::skin issues::problem}}<br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">added length of the lever arm at this level is outweighed in importance by difficulties of good skin and soft tissue management.</span>"																				
UNSATISFACTORY LEVELS OF AMPUTATION<br><div><br></div><div><div><u>very short below-the-knee amputation (BKA) proximal to the tibial tubercle</u></div><div>1.) {{c1::no strength::problem}}</div></div><div>2.) {{c2::knee flexion contracture}}&nbsp;</div>	Knee extension strength is lost, and the knee becomes valueless for stability and ambulation<div><br></div><div>The added length creates difficulties in prosthetic fit as compared to a knee disarticulation. Knee flexion contractures occur often</div>																				
<div><b>effective BKA prosthesis fitting</b><br></div><div><br></div>{{c3::active knee extension}} is present<div><br></div><div>the knee can be flexed through a range of {{c1::45}} degrees or more<div><br></div><div>surgery is performed at least {{c2::1}} cm below the tibial tubercle</div></div>	"Above this level, most patients will be better served by a knee disarticulation<div><br></div><div>*even w/ out knee extension, pt may use microprocessor knee w/ mechanical extension</div><div><img src=""paste-83f4b104dc2528e09e4eb0f3b39931b179aeb333.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"UNSATISFACTORY LEVELS FOR AMPUTATION<div><br></div><div><u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Very high above-knee amputation (</span>AKA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span></u></div><div>{{c1::flexion/abduction contracture::problem}}</div><div>{{c2::poor Socket fit::problem}}</div>"	"<div>transection is just a short distance below the lesser trochanter,&nbsp;</div><div>the limb tends to develop excessive flexion and abduction at the hip joint</div><div>as the <u>ADductors have been removed</u> but the more proximal ABductors remain</div><div><br></div><div>Socket fit may become a difficult problem.&nbsp;</div><div><u>Releasing the contractive deformity</u> through flexor and abductor muscle release at the hip can circumvent this surgeons prefer to leave a short segment of femur rather than amputate at the hip disarticulation level</div><div><img src=""paste-022fc60708885fcddb72ff76fe55a42087ff950f.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"PARTIAL TOE AMPUTATION, TOE DISARTICULATIONS<div><br></div><div>Advantage: {{c1::better mechanical advantage}}</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Disadvantage</span>: {{c2::may have a continuous progression of amputations}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>By preserving the length of the foot, there is a better mechanical advantage.<br></div><div><br></div><div>There is better gait pattern <u>compared to a transmetatarsal amputation</u> (TMA).</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Disadvantages</span>: Mostly seen in the vascular patient, including arterial sclerosis and diabetes. One must be assured that the vascular supply to the rest of the foot will be intact so as not to have a continuous progression of <u>amputations up to the transtibial level</u></div><div><br></div><div>Performed for deformity resulting from trauma to the toes, loss of tissue, <u>infection, gangrene due to frostbite, diabetes, arterial sclerosis, scleroderma, Buerger’s disease</u>, and similar conditions<br></div>"

c3177b2ec87f4df9838f21e8b2b93e22-ao-6		"<img src=""tmpq1aibk9_.png"" />"	"<img src=""c3177b2ec87f4df9838f21e8b2b93e22-ao-6-Q.svg"" />"						"<img src=""c3177b2ec87f4df9838f21e8b2b93e22-ao-6-A.svg"" />"	"<img src=""c3177b2ec87f4df9838f21e8b2b93e22-ao-O.svg"" />"											
"<strong>Lisfranc</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;amputation at the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::tarso-metatarsal junction}}"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-22 at 8.02.08 PM.png""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_9.png"">"																				
"<strong>Chopart:&nbsp;</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Only&nbsp;</span>{{c1::talus and calcaneus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;bones remain</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">amputation removes all the tarsals and the metatarsals, <u>thus dorsiflexors ar transferred</u></span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-22 at 8.04.06 PM.png""></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-22 at 8.05.06 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><font color=""#000000""><br></font></span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_9.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
"<strong>Pirogoff:&nbsp;</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::vertical calcaneal}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;amputation</span>"	"<div><img src=""img2.jpg""><img src=""Pirogoff+amputation+Calcaneal+fragment-tibia+arthrodesis.jpg""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_9.png"">"																				
"<strong>Boyd:</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::horizontal calcaneal}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;amputation</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_9.png"">"																				
"<strong>Boyd</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;amputation</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">amputations are not indicated in patients with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ischemia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::diabetes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">They may be indicated, at times, in patients with <u>trauma</u>, although their outcomes are still poor</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);"">Boyd’s amputation</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);"">retains the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::calcaneus}}<span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);"">&nbsp;and fuses it with the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::distal tibia}}<span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<img src=""3-Figure1-1-1c9a46bb4938e05424151274ec0dc920eb649931.png"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);""><b>Hind Foot amputations</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);""><u>ie: Symes, Pirogoff, Boyd's</u></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);""><br></span></div>provides a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::weight-bearing stump}}<span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);"">does not need&nbsp;</span>{{c1::a prosthesis}}<span style=""color: rgb(46, 55, 67);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);"">Boyd and Pirogoff hindfoot amputations are biomechanically and functionally identical to the Syme ankle disarticulation</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);"">difference is that part of the calcaneus remains, and it is fused into the ankle mortise</span><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);"">Prosthetic management of these levels is identical to that of the Syme procedure&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);"">except that the minimal shortage makes it impossible to use most commercially available prosthetic ankle and foot mechanisms</span><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);"">intended to create a residual limb that permitted distal end bearing</span><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);"">These levels are sometimes selected in developing parts of the world when more sophisticated prosthetic care is not available</span><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);"">When modern prostheses are available, these levels offer no pronounced advantages over the Syme</span></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs00064-011-0042-x/MediaObjects/64_2011_42_Fig1_HTML.gif""><span style=""color: rgb(23, 53, 109);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Midfoot Amputations</b></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><br></div><div><u>ie TMA, Lisfranc, and Chopart</u>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>remaining foot often develops a {{c1::equino-varus}}&nbsp;<span style=""font-family: -apple-system-body; background: var(--field-bg);"">deformity</span></div></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><br></div><div>resulting in excessive {{c3::anterior weight bearing}} with breakdown</div><div><br></div><div>Adequate {{c2::dorsiflexor tendon reattachment}} with {{c2::Achilles tendon lengthening}} has been advocated to prevent this deformity</div></span>"	"<img src=""c00118_f118-006-9781455753048.jpg""><div><img src=""Congenital-Talipes-Equinovarus-Clubfoot-Nursing-Cheat-Sheet.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>SYME’S AMPUTATION</b><div><br></div><div><div>essentially an {{c1::ankle disarticulation}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>with attachment of the {{c1::distal heel pad}} to the {{c1::end of the tibia}};&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>may include removal of the {{c2::malleoli and/or distal tibial/fibular flares::2}}</div></div>	"<div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Indications</span>: Trauma of the foot, congenital anomalies, tumors, and deformities&nbsp;<br></div><div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Disadvantages</span>: Healthy plantar heel skin is necessary for weight bearing in this area making it a difficult in the <u>dysvascular patient</u></div></div><div><img src=""c00118_f118-007af-9781455753048.jpg""><u><br></u></div>"																				
{{c1::Ray resection}}: amputation of the {{c2::toe (phalanx)}} along with all/part of the {{c2::meta-tarsal head}}	"<img src=""c00118_f118-003ac-9781455753048.jpg"">"																				
"<b>SYME’S AMPUTATION</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Pros</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::maintains limb length}}&nbsp;</div><div>preserves heel pad</div><div>{{c2::early prosthesis fitting}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::TDWB almost immediately}}</div><div>WB w/ out a prosthesis</div><div><br></div><div><u>Cons:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::↓ cosmesis}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::difficult to fit a prosthesis}}</div>"	<div>maintains the length of the limb</div><div><br></div><div>There is preservation of the heel pad, providing an excellent weight-bearing residual limb.</div><div><br></div><div>Early fitting of prosthesis is possible with excellent results.</div><div><br></div><div>Partial weight bearing of the residual limb is possible almost immediately after the procedure with a proper rigid casting (approximately within 24 hours)</div><div><br></div><div>↓ cosmesis (bulbous, bulky residual limb); fitting for a prosthesis may be more difficult than for other amputation levels<br></div>																				
<b>Transtibial Amputation/Below-Knee Amputation</b><div><br></div><div>BKA&nbsp;should be in the proximal {{c1::50}}% of the tibia</div><div><br></div><div>Within this range, preserving length is critical as long as {{c2::viable skin/muscle}} is available for {{c2::distal coverage}}</div>	The longer the below-the-knee residual limb, the greater will be its leverage, strength, and proprioceptive qualities<div><br></div><div>very short below-the-knee residual limb is <u>still far superior</u> to a knee disarticulation</div><div><br></div><div>satisfactory fitting with a below-the-knee prosthesis can be accomplished at levels as high as the tibial tuberosity<br></div>																				
"<b>Transtibial Amputation/Below-Knee Amputation</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">fibula should be cut&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2 to 3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cm shorter than the tibia</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">tibia should be&nbsp;</span>{{c2::beveled}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: var(--field-fg); font-family: -apple-system-body; background: var(--field-bg);"">{{c2::anteriorly}}</span><b><br></b></div>"	"<img src=""c00118_f118-010ae-9781455753048.jpg""><div><a><span style=""font-weight: bold;"">A,</span>&nbsp;Marking the skin incisions.&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold;"">B,</span>&nbsp;Fashioning the flaps after bone transection.&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold;"">C,</span>&nbsp;The soleus muscle is tailored to create a proper flap.&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold;"">D,</span>&nbsp;The posterior deep fascia is sutured to the anterior deep fascia and periosteum.&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold;"">E,</span>&nbsp;Closure of skin flaps.</a><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Ertl}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;procedure: a bone bridge/fusion between the tibia and fibula</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the advantage is potential for end-bearing in the prosthesis</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-e5bdcaddc34a531ff277cc832bc6b08ae672955a.jpg""><br></div><img src=""819bac51-f384-4556-91cb-8c96dc47e1be.png.jpeg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">when an amputation in the lower limb becomes necessary</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the importance of saving the knee joint cannot be overemphasized</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">However, a knee disarticulation may be prefferred in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::severe flexion contracture (&gt;50<sup>0</sup>)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::ischemic limb}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">knee disarticulation should be the procedure of choice</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">although a very short&nbsp;</span>BKA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may be fitted as a knee disarticulation with a bent-knee prosthesis</span></div>"																				
"<b>Knee Disarticulation</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Advantages</span>:</u></div><div>{{c1::Less trauma/Blood loss}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::excellent end-bearing quality}}</div><div>Prosthetic suspension is facilitated by the bulbous contour of the residual limb</div><div><br></div><div><u>Disadvantages:</u></div><div>{{c3::long skin flaps needed}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::difficulty w/ prosthesis*}}</div><div>poor cosmetic&nbsp;</div>"	<div>Relatively long flaps are necessary and healing may be impaired in the dysvascular patient.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>fine line of distinction between sufficient viable skin for coverage of a short BKA&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and sufficient viable skin for coverage of a knee disarticulation</div><div><br></div><div>*Recent advances in prosthetic knee mechanisms and socket design&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>now permit swing-and-stance phase control and cosmesis that equal available above-the-knee prostheses<br></div>																				
"<div><b>{{c1::Modified knee disarticulation}}:</b> Moderate trimming of the femoral condylar prominences and&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::patello-femoral arthrodesis}} in the intercondylar notch</div><div><br></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Advantages</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::allows standard socket fitting}}&nbsp;<br></div>"	"<span style=""font-style: italic;"">Advantages</span>: Conical residual limb with a large area for end bearing; allows standard suction-socket fitting without ischial weight bearing<br><div><img src=""1803-1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Transfemoral Amputation/Above Knee Amputation</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Approximately&nbsp;</span>{{c1::85}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of&nbsp;</span>AKAs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are secondary to vascular disease</span><br></div>"																					
"<b>Transfemoral Amputation/Above Knee Amputation</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hip flexion contracture is common in&nbsp;</span>AKA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, particularly with shorter residual limbs</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Up to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::20}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;degrees of flexion can be accommodated in the socket</span><b><br></b></div>"																					
"{{c1::Hemipelvectomy}}:<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;surgical removal of the entire lower limb plus all or a major portion of the ileum</span>"	"<img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs10029-020-02258-8/MediaObjects/10029_2020_2258_Fig1_HTML.png"">"																				
<b>Hip Disarticulation and Hemipelvectomy Amputations</b><div><br></div><div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;</div><div>most often for {{c1::malignant tumor}}&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::uncontrolled infection}}</div><div>{{c3::surgical conversion of congenital limb deformity}}</div></div><div>extensive trauma<br></div>	<div>Ablative surgery of this magnitude is indicated most often to eradicate a malignant tumor of the bone or soft tissues above the thigh, hip, or pelvic region</div><div><br></div><div>Other indications include...</div><div>extensive trauma or uncontrolled infection, especially gas gangrene</div><div>On rare occasions, surgical conversion of congenital limb deformity to hip disarticulation may improve prosthetic fit and function</div>																				
"<b>Hip Disarticulation and Hemipelvectomy Amputations</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">lost the&nbsp;</span>weight bearing of the<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ischial tuberosity}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">must now&nbsp;</span>bear weight on the&nbsp;{{c1::semisolid abdominal viscera}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Socket design for this amputation level must, therefore, produce weight forces in a manner that is tolerable to the amputee and not injurious to the viscera</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Many hemipelvectomy amputees reject the prosthesis because of the bulk and weight of the prosthesis and the energy expenditure required for ambulation</span></div><div><img src=""hemipelvectomy_prosthesis_img4.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""prosthetic-description-hemipelvectomy.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ideal shape for transtibial residual limb is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::cylindrical}}"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ideal shape for&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">transfemoral residual limb is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::conical}}"	Cone points up (proximal)																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Records should be kept of several circumferential measurements of the residual limb at specific distances&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">from the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::greater trochanter}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;for a transfemoral amputee&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or from the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">medial&nbsp;</span>knee joint line}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;for a transtibial amputee</span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">One of the main keys for success after an amputation is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::adequate wound healing}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Evaluating and optimizing</u>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">nutrition</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">anemia</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">diabetic control</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">antibiotic use maximize wound healing</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Amputation</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">an open incision or wound should be covered with a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Telfa}}<sup>®</sup><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pad under the shrinkage device or prosthesis&nbsp;</span></div>"	"guaze with special coating to keep it from adhering to the wound<div><br></div><div>it has a sticker on all four sides&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""8110mresBZL.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Amputation</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>chronically draining sinus</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">should be&nbsp;</span>{{c1::probed}}</div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#333333"">obtain&nbsp;</font>{{c1::imaging}}<font color=""#333333"">&nbsp;</font></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may be the result of a superficial abscess, a bone spur, or localized osteomyelitis.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The opening should be probed to determine its depth,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">plain films, MRIs, or bone scans should be obtained to determine bony involvement</span></div>"																				
"POSTOPERATIVE RESIDUAL LIMB MANAGEMENT<br><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">immediately post-op, a&nbsp;</span><u>{{c1::rigid dressing}}</u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;made from&nbsp;</span>{{c3::plaster}} or {{c3::fiberglass}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">must be placed</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Main Function</u></span></div><div>{{c2::prevents edema}}<br></div><div>{{c2::protects from trauma}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::prevents contracture}}<br></div><div>{{c2::decreases pain}}<br></div>"	"<div><img src=""Removable+rigid+dressing+(IPOP).jpg""></div>"																				
"<div><b>POSTOPERATIVE RESIDUAL LIMB MANAGEMENT</b><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>rigid dressings</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;removed for inspection or suture removal,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">must be replaced within&nbsp;</span>{{c1::minutes::time}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to prevent recurrence of edema</span></div></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Postoperative edema occurs within a few minutes, so immediate replacement of the dressing is necessary</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">""in reality patietn's are often not compliant wiith this, counsel them on the risks/benefits""</span></div></div><div><img src=""phoenix_amputee_stump_protector.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u style="""">Amputation Dressings Post-op</u></span></div><div>{{c5::telfa pad}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;+&nbsp;</span>{{c5::gauze (kirlex)}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Apply a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::single white sock}}</div><div>{{c2::shrinker}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c2::compressogrip stocking}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>{{c3::limb protector}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c3::removable rigid dressing}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">suspended by a&nbsp;</span>{{c4::stocking}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c4::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">supracondylar</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">cuff</span>}}<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">adjusted by&nbsp;</span>{{c4::adding or removing socks}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to maintain compression&nbsp;</span></div></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Provides good edema control with the advantage of allowing daily inspection</span><div><img src=""images-955c8587fa1dabff958c00fa6d26795152e0744c.jpg""><img src=""paste-943b40b24e2d70eb028c7b9301dcd10391a83625.jpg""><img src=""paste-f57d29553d68fc3611acc0efdd1202284bd46264.jpg""><img an option</div><div><img src=""SCE-LIMBGUARD-L_576_576.jpg""></div></div><div>see this thing used most often (Rooke for dysvascular patients) ""whool creates warmth for vasodialtion""</div><div>- it is off the shelf (S, M, L) and may fit most patient's</div><div>- it may indicate that the patient has <u>not</u> yet been set up with a prosthetic group (although often does)</div><div><div><img src=""ROOKE-BKA-RIGID-DRESSING-4.jpg""><br></div></div><div><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">When a rigid dressing is not being used,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::elastic bandages}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in a&nbsp;</span>{{c2::figure-8 wrap}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;formation should be used</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Elastic bandages are less effective shrinkage devices because patients fail to master the wrapping technique,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and it requires reapplication many times a day</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Poorly applied elastic bandages also can cause circumferential constriction with distal edema</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Double length 4-inch bandages should be used for the transtibial limb and double length 6-inch bandages for the transfemoral limb</span></div><div><img src=""en3287021.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div>POSTOPERATIVE RESIDUAL LIMB MANAGEMENT<br></div><div><br></div>{{c1::Elastic shrinker&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">socks</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;provide uniform compression</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">helps control pain and edema and facilitates healing</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">should fit snugly and reach the groin in the transfemoral amputee</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may cause skin damage with constriction if not properly fitted and maintained</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">compresso-grip usually provided in the inpatinet stay, provided after rehab d/c when wound is not draining&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">initially stabilizes limb volume (1st year), but can be warn life long (evening) to help with pain control&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""knit-rite_shrinker-228x300_0.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u style="""">shrinkage device</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>&nbsp;Time Frame</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">generally used after&nbsp;</span>{{c2::staples or sutures are removed}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div style=""""><br></div><div style="""">amputee&nbsp;should wear it&nbsp;{{c1::24}}&nbsp;hours a day for about the first {{c1::year}}&nbsp;</div><div style=""""><br></div><div style="""">can be discontinued {{c3::after fitting the definitive prosthesis}} if {{c3::amputee wears it regularly}}</div><div style=""""><br></div><div style="""">then switch to {{c4::nocturnal use}}&nbsp;</div></span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It can be used at night if overnight edema occurs forever&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div>24&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">hours a day</span>&nbsp;except for bathing</div></div><div><br></div><div>During the first <u>3 to 12 months</u> after amputation, the residuum will typically swell if a&nbsp;<u>shrinker</u>&nbsp;is not worn consistently<br></div><div><img src=""knit-rite_shrinker-228x300_0.png""></div><div>compresso grip is cheaper and okay if it gets blood on it. PT has on hand and used immediately post op</div><div><img src=""knit-rite-compressogrip-bk-prosthetic-shrinker.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-style: italic;""><b>Hip flexion contractures</b></span><div><font color=""#333333""><i><u><br></u></i></font></div><div>Amputees should {{c3::lie prone}}<font color=""#333333""><i><u><br></u></i></font></div><div><font color=""#333333""><i><u><br></u></i></font></div><div><font color=""#333333""><i><u>avoid</u></i></font>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::overly soft mattress::equipment}}</div><div>{{c4::pillows under the back or thigh}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c5::elevated HOB}}</div><div>standing with the transfemoral residual limb {{c2::resting on a crutch}}&nbsp;</div>"	"lie prone for 15 minutes 3x/day&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>if cannot lie prone should lie supine and actively extend the residual limb while flexing the contralateral leg</div><div><img src=""images.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Hip abduction contractures</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>:</u>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">amputee must not&nbsp;</span>{{c1::place a pillow between the legs}}</div>"																					
"<div><b style=""""><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Knee flexion contractures</span>:</b></div><div><u><br></u></div><div>transtibial amputee should sit with {{c4::a board under the wheelchair cushion}}<u><br></u></div><div><br></div><div><u>avoid</u></div><div>amputee must not lie {{c1::with the residual limb hanging over the edge of the bed}}</div><div>do not place {{c2::a pillow under the knee}}</div><div>avoid prolonged {{c3::sitting}}</div>"	"with a towel wrapped over the board<div><img src=""5242.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"POSTOPERATIVE RESIDUAL LIMB MANAGEMENT<br><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Crutch walking}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;with or without prosthesis promotes good&nbsp;</span>ROM</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">when feasible, is preferred over wheelchair mobility</span><br></div>"																					
<b>POSTOPERATIVE RESIDUAL LIMB MANAGEMENT</b><div><br></div><div><div>After {{c4::suture removal}}, the residual limb should be cleansed {{c1::daily::time frame}} with {{c2::bland soap}} and {{c2::warm water}}</div><div><br></div><div>limb should be {{c2::patted completely dry}} before the application of shrinkage device</div><div><br></div><div>preform {{c3::gentle massage}} daily&nbsp;</div></div>	gentle massage daily decreases sensitivity to pressure, and deep friction massage perpendicular to the scar prevents scar adhesions<div><br></div><div>shaving near residual limb should be discouraged</div>																				
<div>Ensure that the residual limb <u>scar has mobility</u> in all directions<br></div><div><div><br></div><div>Use a {{c1::thin layer of emollient}} to decrease the friction from massage</div><div><br></div><div>but discourage the use of {{c1::thick creams}}</div></div>	<div>For very dry skin, a thin emollient can be applied in the evening for absorption overnight</div>

<div>Socket changes are generally required&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>when the amputee needs {{c1::15}} ply or more
of socks</div>

<div>If the residual limb volume is stable for {{c1::8}} to {{c1::12}} weeks<b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b></div><div><br></div><div>then the time is appropriate for fitting of the <b>definitive
prosthesis</b></div><div><br></div><div>This occurs after pt has been fitted and using the {{c2::check/test socket}} &nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div>Which they may be fitted for in as little as&nbsp;{{c3::2}} to {{c3::4}} weeks clinically<b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b>may be fit with check socket as soon as surgeon clears for full weight bearing</div><div><br></div><div>*1.) may take many months but definitely less than 1 year (PM&amp;R recap)</div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>*2.) residual limb volume is stable for 8 to 12 weeks,
then the time is appropriate for fitting of the definitive
prosthesis, which usually occurs around 6 to 18 months
after surgery (Braddom)&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><br></div><div>pt may need 1-3 sockets made in the first 6 to 18 months after surgery before the limb stabilizes</div><div><br></div><div>Factors that affect limb volume include CHF, ESRD on dialysis, muscle atrophy, weight gain or loss&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Wearing the prosthesis will create a pumping action that will force fluid out of the residual limb and reduce its size (add socks during the day)</div><div><br></div><div>During the first 3 to 12 months after amputation, the residuum will typically swell if a <u>shrinker</u> is not worn consistently</div><div><img src=""Advantages-of-Using-a-Thermoplastic-Check-Socket-Featured-Image-768x350-c-default.jpg""><br></div><div>easy to adjust while pt is with prosthetist</div><div>cheap to make</div>"

<div>
<div>Amputee <u>Liner</u> care should include...&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>washing it
with {{c1::soap and water}} at the end of each day</div><div><br></div><div>spraying the inner part of the liner with {{c1::diluted rubbing alcohol}} 1x or 2x a week<br></div><div><br></div><div>drying should
occur with the {{c2::fabric}} side directed outward</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><u>outward position</u>&nbsp;</div><div>will protect the tacky inner area from <b>trapping dirt</b>, dust, and hair that can adversely affect the skin</div><div>the opposite can create <b>cracks in the gel</b> which trap air and damage the skin (requires new liner)<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>etoh 50/50</u></div><div>reduce the buildup of bacteria on the liner surface and help prevent residual limb infections<br></div><div><img src=""gel-liner.jpg""><br></div><div>cusion liner (needs another suspenion method)</div><div>locking liner (for pinsystem)</div><div>suction liner</div>"																				
<b>TEMPORARY (PREPARATORY/check socket) PROSTHESIS</b><div>Provides prosthetic fitting before the residual limb volume stabilizes</div><div><br></div><div>Helps in {{c1::shrinking/shaping residual limb}}</div><div>Allows for {{c1::early prosthetic training}}&nbsp;</div><div>May be used as {{c1::a trial}}</div><div><br></div><div>Usually used for {{c2::3}} to {{c2::6 months}} postsurgery—until maximal residual limb shrinkage has been achieved</div>	"(gait and functional training) and fine tuning of the prosthetic alignment as the amputee’s gait progresses<div><br></div><div>trial when there is uncertainty about a patient’s potential success at using a prosthesis<br></div><div><img src=""600px-Quadrilateral_socket_Transversal_view.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>PERMANENT (DEFINITIVE) PROSTHESIS</b><div><br></div><div>will typically need to be replaced about every {{c1::3}} to {{c1::5}} years</div><div><br></div><div>will often have more sophisticated componentry and a {{c2::cosmetic cover}}</div>	"When shaping and shrinking process has ended and residual limb volume has stabilized, a definitive or permanent prosthesis is made<div><img src=""laminated.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Prosthetic Prescription Essential Elements</span></div><div>{{c1::Socket}}</div><div>{{c1::Interface}}</div><div>{{c2::Suspension}}</div><div>{{c2::Pylon/frame}}</div><div><div>{{c3::Joints (hip/knee/ankle/foot)}}</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_12.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-12 at 11.36.28 AM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-12 at 11.37.54 AM.png""><br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-12 at 11.37.40 AM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-12 at 11.37.47 AM.png""><br></div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-12 at 11.38.16 AM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-12 at 11.38.03 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">standard socket used for the average&nbsp;</span>BKA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;amputee is the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">total-contact patellar-tendon bearing (tc</span>PTB<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;socket</span><div><br></div><div>has a bar in the anterior wall that applies pressure on the {{c1::patellar tendon}}</div><div><br></div><div>trim line extends medially and laterally to the {{c2::femoral condyles}}</div>"	"PTB&nbsp;socket is a custom-molded thermoplastic or laminated socket<div>distributes weight through convex buildups (bulges) over pressure-tolerant areas</div><div>provides concavities (relief areas) on pressure-sensitive areas</div><div><br></div><div><div>trim line extends anteriorly to the mid-patellar level and extends posteriorly to the level of the&nbsp;PTB&nbsp;bar</div><div><br></div><div>Despite its name, pressure equally distributed over pressure-tolerant areas, with more weight bearing in the area of the patellar tendon and the tibial flare</div><div>reduced weight bearing over the bony prominences, such as the tibial crest, distal end of the tibia, and head of the fibula</div><div><img src=""Socket_Patellar_Tendon_Bearing.png""><img src=""paste-bd10a106400cb0e4042cd04f6b64a2339fbcd1e8.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f25b8eccbc42ab58390702b4fa80928f1d796abe.jpg""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Clinically, the
typical transtibial socket design is a combination of both
the traditional PTB and the TSB design&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>"																				
<b>{{c1::Supracondylar cuff}}</b><strong>&nbsp;suspension</strong><div><b><br></b></div><div>For BKA<br><div><br></div><div>Consists of a strap that wraps circumferentially around the thigh</div><div><br></div><div>fitted immediately above the femoral epicondyles</div></div>	"<div>May be used with or without a fork strap and waist-belt suspension<br></div><img src=""nL31fzB09xZc7mPp3LeWkQ.jpg""><img src=""1420-2.jpg""><img src=""Transtibial+Prosthesis.jpg"">"																				
{{c1::Brim suspension::suspension category}}<div><br></div><div>PTB&nbsp;socket with medial and lateral walls extending above the femoral epicondyles for suspension</div><div><br></div><div>ex. PTB-SC and PTB-SP</div>	"<div><img src=""slX-.O.dA0ywhM3bFS6qGA.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Supracondylar brim suspension 2 types</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>1.) <u>{{c1::Supracondylar wedge}}</u><br></div>
<div>Provides extra&nbsp;ML&nbsp;support and is used
for {{c2::short residual limbs}}</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>2.)&nbsp;<u>{{c1::suprapatellar trim lines}}</u></div>
<div>Used for {{c2::controlling genu recurvatum}}<br></div>"	"Instead of removable medial brim or wedge, a compressible foam wedge buildup may be incorporated into the soft liner<div><img src=""paste-7cd3abbeadfd7ad6e64bcd2688096da8e466c5d2.jpg""><br></div><div><div>The suprapatellar trim line improves the suspension</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""images-0ae426e53661a5e86bcb6f37243bbe623dd88c5f.jpg""></div></div><div><img src=""19-Figure5-1.png""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Gel Sleeves}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;made of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::elastic materials}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font></div><div>rolled onto your thigh after the prosthesis is on, open ended on both sides<font color=""#333333""><br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may be used as a primary suspension system or in combination with another system</span></div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ex. neoprene, rubber, latex, or other&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><img src=""images-27cafa0f58fdd04075c2a3c8324629dbdd11e7ef.jpg""><img src=""paste-60332ece1c6f103149925cbc15dd35c12e03fe42.jpg""><img src=""alps-extreme-sleeve-alps-grip-gel_430x430.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Gel Sleeve</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Provides good suspension, fitting snugly over the proximal prosthesis and extending several inches up onto the thigh over the prosthetic sock</div><div><br></div><div>Should <u>not</u> be used as a primary suspension with decreased {{c1::ML&nbsp;knee stability}}</div><div><br></div><div>Increased {{c2::perspiration}} may be a problem</div>	"Not used as 1<sup>0</sup> with standard&nbsp;PTB&nbsp;sockets in very short residual limbs,&nbsp;or when hyperextension control is required<div><img src=""images-e01a5d4688990194e830ab3e7d0f2278f2b55b0a.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><div><b>{{c1::Pin Lock}}</b><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">&nbsp;Suspension
</span></div>
<div><br></div><div>requires a liner with a distal umbrella
of an embedded mesh matrix and a threaded attachment
site</div><div><br></div><div>which will then engage into a mechanism attached
to the prosthetic socket</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"can be either a clutch mechanism or rotary style. Locks can be either push or pull to unlock<div><br></div><div><u>gel liner</u> holds onto the patient and the pin locks into the prosthesis<br></div><div><br></div><div>biggest dis-advantage is the potential for distal distraction and <u>shearing forces on the tissues</u> of the residual limb<br></div><div><img src=""transtibial-suspension02.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<strong>Pin suspension</strong><div><br></div><div>excellent suspension system for amputees with greater&nbsp;{{c1::suspension demands}}</div>	"for example, athletes, and for those with short residual limbs, as well as excellent skin protection for the scarred residual limb<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>can
be very <u>easy to use</u> and offers an audible
click to reinforce engagement&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div><div><br></div><div><u>Expensive</u> because the gel liners are typically replaced annually<br></div></div><div><img src=""PinLockingSuspension-product.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>{{c1::Suction}}</b><strong>&nbsp;suspension</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>gel insert or liner with the use of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::a one-way expulsion valve}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in the distal aspect of the socket</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The valve allows air to escape from the socket but not enter</span><br></div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/338286862/figure/fig2/AS:858280368803842@1581641394740/llustration-depicting-AERO-liner-with-prosthesis-donning-procedure-1-Reflect-the-AERO.jpg"">"																				
<strong>Suction suspension</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>2 types</u></div><div>{{c1::passive (one way valve)}}<u><br></u></div><div>{{c1::active}} aka {{c1::vacuum}}</div>	"<img src=""250px-Engstrom-chp13-fig8e.png""><img src=""paste-efec011c5581d750b0a3f056acce28891bcf8058.jpg"">"																				
"<b>{{c2::Elevated Vacuum}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;suspension systems offer&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">enhanced suspension and contact</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">use a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::mechanical/manual}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::electric pump}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">to generate negative pressure between the limb and the socket</span></div>"	"<img src=""images-1237c5eb636a5e336e86af1fe33bec7bfda33db6.jpg""><img src=""paste-e1239976f9ab4c425d9918a8cd4b08f7d2d7b2bd.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-d09440917a09bba17c9f3952510f4feb5e8b5e71.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-12 at 11.46.06 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Suction suspension</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Main Advantage: Does not&nbsp;</span>{{c1::disturb normal circulation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;as much as pin suspension</span><strong><br></strong></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Does not create pressure distributions that are likely to disturb normal circulation and soft tissue fluid balance as much as pin suspension</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#333333"">""the limb will be ""sucked out and will not shrink and req more PLY as with other systems""&nbsp;<br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>otherwise advantages disadvantages are similar to pin</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div>Provides excellent suspension for amputees with greater suspension demands, for example, athletes, and for those with short residual limbs, as well as excellent skin protection for the scarred residual limb.</div><div>Disadvantage: Expensive, because gel liners are typically replaced annually<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-02-11 at 10_51_56 AM.png""><br></div><div><br></div></div>"																				
<b>{{c2::Thigh corset}}</b> (suspension system)<br><div><br></div><div>Connects a leather femoral cuff/straps to a&nbsp;PTB&nbsp;prosthesis through metal joints and side bars</div><div><br></div><div><u>Used when</u>&nbsp;</div><div>the {{c1::patellar tendon cannot tolerate weight bearing}}</div><div>the {{c1::knee joint is unstable or painful}}</div>	"to decrease distal residual limb weight bearing by 40% to 60%<div><img src=""41-Figure2.10-1.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>prosthetic interface options</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>2 categories: {{c1::soft interface}} or rarely&nbsp;{{c1::hard interface}} aka {{c1::skin fit}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>examples</u></div><div>{{c2::pelite liner::old}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::silicone liner::modern}}</div><div>{{c4::soft inserts::touble shooting}}&nbsp;</div>	"1.) <b>hard interface</b> eg. suction socket where the skin of the residual limb is in <u>direct contact</u> with the hard socket<div>""can be wet or dry fit"" can ""wrap limb in ace wrap and pull it through the suction hole""<br></div><div><br></div><div>2.) interface is typically silicone but can be switched to urethane to improve skin issues<br></div><div><br></div><div><b>modern prosthetic liners</b> provide protection against both shear forces, allow for adjustment and comfort when the residual limb volume changes.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>3.) <b>Soft inserts</b> are for patients with significant residual limb soft tissue atrophy with bony prominences</div><div>they can go under the liner or insider the socket</div><div><br></div><div>disadvantages of soft inserts are their susceptibility to wear and tear, their added bulkiness, and their ability to absorb odors.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp;<br></div><div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-12 at 11.37.54 AM.png""></div><div><img src=""64d.wRMy.1mZUtnTRDHW5w.png""><img src=""769810.fig.001.jpg""><br></div><div>Pelite, Dermo with shuttle lock, and Seal-In X5 liners<br></div><div><img src=""silipos-distal-end-pad-inside-socket-bottom-12005_daabb950-7799-421e-9047-b09e55799571_1024x1024_2x_jpg_large.webp""><img src=""calibrate-body-disc-gel_large.webp""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-ddb51bc72168057ebde26b224019d85ad58d5a8b.jpg""><br></div></div><div><h2>PELITE<sup>®</sup></h2><div>Expanded lightweight polyethylene foam, closed cell</div></div><div><img src=""PELITE.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>{{c1::lanyard strap}} suspension </b>aka {{c1::KISS system}}</div><div><br></div><div>a version of pin lock
suspension that uses velcro to attach gel liner to the socket</div><div><br></div><div>system requires that the patient has some {{c2::manual dexterity}}&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"fed through an opening in the distal portion of a prosthesis and fastened on the exterior portion of the socket<br><div><br></div><div>may be simpler than the pin lock to manage (elderly). They can sit while donning which is easier than coordinating the pin while on one leg<br></div><div><img src=""paste-e75f79b0f4aa71623c47bf23552f6eef72d58c6d.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Prosthetic Limb Frame Options</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span></div><div><u>{{c1::Endoskeletal}}</u> aka {{c2::modular}}&nbsp;</div><div>Advantage: {{c3::easy to modify}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>{{c1::Exoskeletal}}</u><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">&nbsp;</span>aka {{c2::crustacean}}<br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Advantage: {{c3::very durable}}&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Exoskeletal construction uses a rigid exterior lamination
from the socket down and has a lightweight filler inside.
This construction method is used less frequently, but pro-
vides the potential benefit of added strength for heavier
patients. Good for harsh enviornments</div><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>disadvantage: added weight, the
potential to limit foot and knee options, and the limited
ability to adjust alignment or repair components once the
construction is complete&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Endoskeletal pylons also allow the ability to finish the
prosthesis with a cover that provides a softer and more
realistic cosmetic appearance</div><div>lightweight and easy to modify</div><div><img src=""paste-fd1c7c3b8827f4e53daa6fcd0cc7dc1bd47701a5.jpg"">&nbsp;<img src=""c15.jpg""></div><div><img src=""ak13.gif""><br></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/351952791/figure/fig2/AS:1028611511435265@1622251503125/Exoskeletal-prostheses.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::SACH&nbsp;foot}}</b><br><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Compressible heel}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::wooden keel}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in this design allow it to simulate the motions of the ankle (""pseudo-plantar flexion"" at heel strike)&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">without actual ankle movement occurring</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>indicated for individuals in the K{{c3::1}} functional level&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<div><img src=""sach.jpg""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.09 AM.png""><br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.20 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.29 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.40 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::Single-axis foot}}</b><br><div><br></div><div>Movement occurs in one plane, the plantar flexion/dorsiflexion axis</div><div><br></div><div>movement is controlled by the use of internal {{c5::rubber bumpers}} that provide resistance<br></div><div><br></div><div>Typically used for {{c2::AKA}} to {{c2::increase knee stability}} or to {{c3::relieve pressure}} on {{c3::distal tibia for&nbsp;BKA}}</div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>indicated in individuals who are K{{c4::1}} level
ambulators&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<div>bumpers that provide resistance to dorsiflexion and plantar flexion<br></div><div><br></div><div>heavier than the&nbsp;SACH&nbsp;foot, and the internal components need periodic adjustment<br></div><div><img src=""1570990701_99ad91a35f_c.jpg""><img src=""16516@2x.webp""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.09 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.20 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.29 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.40 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><strong>Multiaxis foot</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>allows movement in {{c1::all 3}} planes&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>motion can
be obtained through a {{c2::flexible keel}} or through {{c2::true
mechanical joints}}</div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>indicated for
K{{c3::2}} level ambulators&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<div><font color=""#fc0006"">this is more theoretical than an actual prosthetic option</font></div><div><div><br></div><div>flexible keel foot allows the motion to occur within the keel itself as the ground reaction forces cause deformation of the foot&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>without the use of and true mechanically moving parts</div><div><br></div></div><div><br></div><div>req more maintenance, however, the improved function provided outweighs the disadvantages for an active amputee</div><div><img src=""paste-225f53ae6118dd417fad15d3dc26c5618b982435.jpg""><img src=""paste-1814c98de5a2f7bd6d8876f55616b2c3b15efbd9.jpg""><br></div><img src=""74912-10151178.jpg""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.20 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.29 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.40 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c2::<strong>SAFE</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(stationary ankle flexible endoskeleton)</span>}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>has no joint articulations but allows some inversion and eversion motion
through the {{c3::flexible keel}} of the foot</div><div><br></div><div>for K{{c1::2}} ambulators&nbsp;<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div>This provides greater ability to accommodate to uneven terrain<br></div><img src=""-VZ4AqhkP0krpi7fnelqcw.png""><img src=""4-cut-down.jpg""><div><div>•Stationary Attachment/ Solid Ankle,
Flexible Keel</div>
<div>•Several flexible keels allow
tri-planar movements mimicking “rollover,” supination &amp; eversion</div>
<div>•Stiff and stable during stance</div>
<div>•Good choice for elderly&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""slide37-l.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.20 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.29 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.40 AM.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<div>{{c5::<strong>STEN</strong>&nbsp;(<span style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">st</span>ored&nbsp;<span style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">en</span>ergy)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>a type of non-articulated ankle, energy storing foot</div><div><br><div>Used when {{c2::smooth rollover}} needed, made with a/an {{c1::Elastic(flexible) keel}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">cannot be used with&nbsp;</span>{{c3::Syme’s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;amputation</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>K{{c4::2}} users</div></div>"	"<img src=""4-cut-down.jpg""><img src=""paste-1e5ccd7a317738fbaa12cce76de83824dbd636e5.jpg""><div><div>•For those whose gait patterns
generate enough energy felt to be “worth” storing </div>
<div>•Elastic keels absorb energy during
mid- &amp; terminal stance; and release this during pre-swing and initial swing</div><div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.29 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.40 AM.png""><br></div></div></div>"																				
<strong>Energy storing/dynamic-response foot</strong>:<div><br></div><div>made of materials ({{c1::plastic or carbon fiber::2}}) that provide the capacity to store energy during weight-bearing&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and then return energy once the foot is off-loaded at toe push-off<br></div><div><div><div><br></div></div><div><div>indicated for {{c2::K3 and K4}} level ambulators&nbsp;</div></div></div>	"<div>Some energy-storing feet also include a <u>shock absorber</u> mechanism<br></div><div><br></div><div>can also provide similar motion as a <u>multiaxial foot</u>&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/251570003/figure/fig1/AS:491754202898432@1494254746013/Schematic-of-energy-storage-mechanism-of-ankle-foot-prosthesis.png""><br></div><div><img src=""vari-flex.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 9.45.41 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 8.24.40 AM.png""><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><br></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::Seattle foot::energy storing foot}}</b><br><div><br></div><div>Consists of a cantilevered plastic {{c2::C or U shaped}} {{c2::keel}}, which acts as a compressed spring</div><div><br></div><div>Smooth rollover, but&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">No&nbsp;</span>SACH<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;heel makes it difficult to change compressibility of heel</span></div>"	"<div>""not popular any more"" used when carbon fiber first became popular&nbsp;</div><img src=""4-cut-down.jpg""><img src=""seattle.jpg""><img src=""paste-821d2134601dd2e2b1bb4995cedce67bd5900dcc.jpg"">"																				
<b>{{c2::Flexfoot (Carbon fiber or fiberglass foot)::energy storing}}</b><br><div><br></div><div>The dynamic keel extends to {{c1::the bottom of the transtibial socket (and in&nbsp;AKA, to the level of the knee unit)}}</div><div><br></div><div><b>{{c2::Flex-walk::energy storing}}&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><div>attaches to the {{c1::shank at the ankle level}}</div>	"<div>Pylon and foot are incorporated into <u>one unit</u><br></div><div><br></div><div>similar in design to the Cheetah but for more day to day activities<br></div><div><br></div><div>eg: Running, jumping, vigorous sports, conserves energy<br></div><div>""requires more force to be put into the system and may not be best for all pt's""</div><div>eg. not that athletic but must walk on very uneven terrain --&gt; hydraulic ankle</div><img src=""deliveryService.jpg""><br><div><img src=""deliveryService-e2c7cc403130c4a51ebf72ed30668a6656f94239.jpg""></div><div><img src=""esp-flexisleeve-prosthetic-suspension-sleeve-KSESP5B_430x430.jpg""></div>"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Medicare’s Functional Levels of Ambulation for Amputees (K-Level)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></b></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>K1 = Limited to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::transfers}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::limited household&nbsp;<span style=""caret-color: rgb(51, 51, 51); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ambulator</span>}}<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Prosthesis type:</u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::Manual lock}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c2::stance-control}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;knee</span></div><div>{{c3::SACH}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c3::single-axis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;foot</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 10.29.14 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-14 at 10.40.22 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Medicare’s Functional Levels of Ambulation for Amputees (K-Level)</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">K0 =&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Nonambulatory (bedbound)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div>Prosthesis type: {{c1::not allowed}}</div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 10.29.14 AM.png"">"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Medicare’s Functional Levels of Ambulation for Amputees (K-Level)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></b></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><br></div><u>K2</u></span><div>{{c1::Unlimited household but limited community ambulator::2}}<div><div>
<div>

</div>
</div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Prosthesis type:</u></div><div>{{c2::Pneumatic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c2::polycentric}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;knee</span></div><div>{{c3::multi-axis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c3::Flexible Keel}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;foot</span><u><br></u></div></div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 10.29.14 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-14 at 10.40.22 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Medicare’s Functional Levels of Ambulation for Amputees (K-level)</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Funtional level</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">K3 =<b>&nbsp;</b></span>{{c1::Unlimited community ambulator, variable cadence, uneven terrain::3}}</div><div><br></div><div>K4 = {{c1::high energy sports/work}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Prosthetic type:</u></div><div>{{c2::Hydraulic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c2::micro-processor}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;knee</span></div><div>{{c2::energy-storing}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;foot</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-13 at 10.29.14 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-14 at 10.40.22 AM.png""><br></div>"
