"{{c1::torsion ball::ankle unit}}<div><img src=""pro-flex-xc-torsion.jpg""><br></div>"	provides some vertical shock absorption and rotation&nbsp;																				
"KNEE DISARTICULATION PROSTHESIS<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">problem is that the prosthetic knee’s center of rotation needs to go through the distal residual limb</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Fitting a knee unit distal to the residual limb has caused problems in the past,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">but the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::four-bar polycentric knee}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;has helped to solve the problem</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">socket in a knee disarticulation is usually a modified socket with partial-end bearing and some ischial weight bearing,</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and a soft socket liner with&nbsp;</span>SC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;buildups to provide suspension</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>polycentric knee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">unlike the single-axis knee, has an&nbsp;</span>{{c1::instantaneous center of rotation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;that changes w/ flex/ext</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">that is&nbsp;</span>{{c2::proximal}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::posterior}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to the knee unit itself</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">allows greater knee stability, a more symmetrical gait, and&nbsp;</span>{{c3::equal knee length}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;when sitting</span></div></div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>these knees
are available with hydraulic or pneumatic swing phase
control or without (k1)</div><div><br></div><div>good for knee disartic (long residual limb)&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/268191793/figure/fig1/AS:331651063271439@1456083183813/Instant-centres-of-rotation-for-several-polycentric-prosthetic-knees-6-8.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div><img src=""F000242f24-13ab-9781437719369.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>ISCHIAL CONTAINMENT SOCKET</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::ML}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;dimension is <u>narrower</u> than the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::anterior-posterior}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;measurement</span></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">this is opposed to the&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Quadrilateral Socket (Quad Socket).&nbsp;</span><u>used only rarely</u> today&nbsp;</div><div><strong>(A, B)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Quadrilateral transfemoral socket.&nbsp;</span></div><div><strong>(C, D)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Ischial containment transfemoral socket.</span><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_11.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-18 at 11.02.13 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<u>ISCHIAL CONTAINMENT SOCKET</u>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Narrow&nbsp;ML&nbsp;design was developed to provide a {{c1::normal anatomic (adducted) alignment}} of the femur inside the socket</div><div><br></div><div>The {{c2::ischial tuberosity::same}} is contained inside the socket,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>providing a bony lock between the {{c2::ischium::same}} and {{c2::greater trochanters}}</div>	"<div>Also known as a narrow&nbsp;ML&nbsp;socket or contoured adducted trochanteric-controlled alignment method (CAT-CAM) socket</div><div><br></div><div>Developed as the normal shape, normal alignment (NSNA) socket by Long; also developed as the&nbsp;CAT-CAM&nbsp;by Sabolich</div><div><br></div><div><div>Weight bearing is concentrated in the medial aspect of the ischium and the ischial ramus</div><div><br></div><div>The socket is preflexed 5 degrees to 7 degrees to maximize hip extensor muscle control</div><div><br></div><div>A maximum of 20-degree flexion is allowed to accommodate flexion contracture</div></div><div><img src=""F000242f24-04ab-9781437719369.jpg""><br></div><div><a>Long noted that for many individuals who wear a quadrilateral socket the transected femur was aligned in abduction as opposed to the normal adduction angle of the sound side femur&nbsp;<strong>(A)</strong>. Quad socket wearers typically walk with an unnaturally wide base.</a><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_11.png""><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Transfemoral amputation/above-the-knee amputation socket design.&nbsp;</span></div><div><strong>(A, B)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Quadrilateral transfemoral socket.&nbsp;</span><strong>(C, D)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Ischial containment transfemoral socket.</span></div>"																				
"{{c1::Cutouts in the outer frame::prosthetic component trouble shooting}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to accommodate bony areas or sensitive areas</span>"																					
"QUADRILATERAL TRANSFEMORAL SOCKET (QUAD SOCKET)<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It has a prominent bulge over the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Scarpa’s triangle}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;for wide pressure distribution</span><br></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Posterior socket has a flat, horizontal shelf on which the ischial tuberosity and the gluteal muscles rest</span><br></div><img src=""Borders-of-the-Femoral-Triangle.jpg"">"																				
<div>{{c1::Silesian belt::AKA suspension}}:</div><div><br></div><div>Can be worn as the primary or as a supplement if suction is not adequate</div><div><br></div><div>strap that attaches to the posterolateral area of the socket wall (near the greater trochanter)</div><div><br></div><div>passes around the back and over the opposite iliac crest</div><div><br></div><div>then attaches to the proximal anterior wall at the midline</div>	"<div>Provides good control of rotation<br></div><div><img src=""3-s2.0-B9780323625395000102-f10-04-9780323625395.jpg""><br></div><img src=""46-1.jpg""><br><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_12.png""><br></div>"																				
{{c1::TES&nbsp;belt::AKA suspension}}:<div><br></div><div>neoprene band attached to the prosthesis and pulled around the waist</div><div><br></div><div>Comfortable; enhances the rotational control of the prosthesis</div>	"<div><img src=""3-s2.0-B9780323625395000102-f10-04-9780323625395.jpg""><br></div><img src=""syncor-tes-belt-with-cut-out-above-knee-suspension-belt-TES-300.jpg""><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_12.png""><br></div>"																				
{{c1::Pelvic belt with hip joint::AKA suspension}}:<div><br></div><div>leather belt closely contoured about the iliac crests with a metal or plastic joint that connects to the socket</div><div><br></div><div>provides suspension as well as med/lat stability, use for shorter AKA's&nbsp;</div>	"Belt use over bypass graft surgery sites and in pregnant women is contraindicated<div><img src=""3-s2.0-B9780323625395000102-f10-04-9780323625395.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""F000242f24-10-9781437719369.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700; font-style: italic;"">Manual Locking Knee
</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700; font-style: italic;""><br></span></div>
<div>locks when {{c1::fully extended}}
and unlock {{c1::by pulling a lever}}&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Maximum stability for {{c2::debilitated/elderly amputee}}</div><div><br></div><div>Disadvantage: {{c3::Worst gait efficiency}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>K{{c2::1}} ambulators<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>compromised gait
mechanics that occur because the patient must walk with
a <u>straight leg</u></div><div><br></div><div>used when stability is the primary
issue for the patient or sometimes when bilateral fittings
are necessary&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 2.56.02 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""74842-5532623.jpg""><img src=""F000242f24-15-9781437719369.jpg""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<div><strong>Conventional, single-axis knee</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>K{{c3::1}} ambulators&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Excessive {{c1::heel rise}} in the early swing phase, as well as {{c1::terminal swing impact}} in the late swing phase, may occur at faster cadences</div><div><br></div><div>Amputee prevents knee buckling by {{c2::activating hip extensors}} to maintain knee in full extension</div><div><br></div><div>may be used in {{c4::kids::patient population}}</div>	"debilitated amputee or amputee with a short residual limb cannot adequately contract the hip extensors&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>and requires a knee that is set posterior to the trochanter knee ankle line</div><div><br></div><div>this alignment causes difficulty in flexion of the knee for the swing phase causing increased energy expenditure compared to other units</div><div><img src=""Uniaxial_knee_2.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 2.57.25 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::Stance-control knee}}: aka&nbsp;</b>{{c1::safety knee}}<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>single axis knee with a {{c2::weight-activated}} {{c2::locking}} mechanism</div></div></div></div></div></div>"	"<img src=""F000242f24-14a-9781437719369.jpg""><img src=""F000242f24-14b-9781437719369.jpg""><div><a>stance control knee unit with extension assist for a transfemoral prosthesis. As body weight is shifted on the prosthesis in early stance, compression of the spring causes the cylindrical brake bushing to engage and resist the knee flexion moment associated with loading response. This braking mechanism provides stability even if the knee is slightly flexed during weight shift. When the knee is unloaded in late stance/preswing, decompression of the spring leads to “unlocking” of the brake, allowing free knee flexion for limb clearance during swing phase</a><br></div>"																				
<b>Stance-control knee</b><div><b><br></b><div><div>patient applies weight during stance phase and knee locks automatically caused by an {{c3::internal braking system}}</div><div><br></div><div>For this to function appropriately, the knee cannot be flexed greater than {{c1::20 degrees}}</div><div><br></div><div>Design is for new amputees, amputees with {{c4::weak hip extensors}} or {{c4::geriatric}} amputees</div><div><br></div><div>for amputees who fall into the functional classification K{{c2::1}} level&nbsp;</div></div></div>	"<div>When the patient’s <u>weight shifts off the prosthesis to initiate swing phase</u>, the <b>knee unlocks</b> to allow flexion during swing phase<br></div><div><br></div><div>Stance control is not automatic, and the amputee must be able to initiate and maintain control of the knee</div><div><br></div><div>The <font color=""#fc0006"">knee will buckle</font> if allowed to <u>flex beyond 25</u> degrees in stance</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-19 at 2.27.45 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""F000242f24-14a-9781437719369.jpg""><img src=""F000242f24-14b-9781437719369.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>{{c2::Constant Friction}}</b><strong>&nbsp;Knee</strong><div><br></div><div>mechanisms used to {{c3::dampen}} the {{c3::pendular action}} of the prosthetic knee during the swing phase</div><div><br></div><div>to decrease the incidence of high heel rise in early swing, and decrease {{c5::terminal impact}} in late swing</div><div><br></div><div>Does not have {{c4::stance control}}</div><div><br></div><div>may be used in {{c6::kids}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>K{{c1::1}} ambulator</div>	"a screw used to adjust the friction to determine how fast or slow the knee swings<div><br></div><div>Too much friction prevents knee from flexing</div><div><br></div><div>Too little friction causes the knee to swing too easily; patient needs to vault</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-19 at 2.30.57 PM.png""><img src=""autumn68-a-15.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<u>SUSPENSION OF&nbsp;AKA&nbsp;PROSTHESIS</u>&nbsp;<div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Suction socket</strong>: (different from vacuum)</div><div><br></div><div>A {{c1::pull sock}} is used over the residual limb; the sock is passed through the valve hole and is used to assist in pulling the limb into the socket</div><div><br></div><div>then the one way valve is reattached</div>	"provided with a one-way valve at the distal end of the socket wall that allows air to escape but not to enter to ensure proper fitting<div><br></div><div><div>Donning a total suction prosthesis is performed while standing</div><div><br></div><div><b>Suction socket</b> use requires stable residual limb volume (size). (If volume ↑, it will prevent fit. If volume ↓, result is loss of suction.)&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><font color=""#fc0010"">thus not used for new amputtees</font></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Total suction socket</strong>: <u>Worn without socks</u> on residual limb. It provides the <u>best suspension</u> biomechanically and has better propriception</div><div>but requires minimal volume fluctuation, good hand strength and dexterity, good balance, and good skin integrity.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Partial suction socket</strong>: Uses a socket with a suction valve, <u>but it is worn with socks</u>, which reduces the airtight suction fit.</div><div><br></div><div>Provides less suspension than the total suction socket, requiring auxiliary suspension (e.g., Silesian belt or total elastic suspension [TES] belt)</div><div><br></div></div><div>""i think this is different from roll on liners ie vacuum or lanyard etc""</div><div><img src=""F000242f24-05-9781437719369.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<strong>Four-bar polycentric knee</strong>:<div><br></div><div>Ideal for patients with {{c1::very long residual limbs}} as well as {{c1::knee disarticulation}}</div><div><br></div><div>No stance control, but {{c2::inherently stable}}</div><div><br></div><div>for K{{c3::1}} ambulators</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);"">Instant Centre of Rotation (ICR) is situated much higher and posterior than the mechanical axes when the knee is in extension.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);"">To localize the ICR of a polycentric knee, we need to extend virtually the center lines of the lateral bars to the intersection&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);"">This causes a high level of stability in the knee against involuntary flexion during the heel strike.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);"">Standard polycentric knees have a single walking speed but when they included </span><font color=""#fc0009"">pneumatic/hydraulic features</font><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);"">, the patient can vary their cadence</span><br></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs13246-020-00882-3/MediaObjects/13246_2020_882_Fig4_HTML.jpg""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-20 at 10.10.48 AM.png"">"																				
"<strong>Fluid-Controlled Knee Units (air/oil)</strong><div><b><br></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Allow for variable cadence and stance phase flexion in gait</span></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Pneumatic}} units provide only swing phase control</div></div>"																					
<strong>Fluid-Controlled Knee Units (air/oil)</strong><div><b><br></b><div><div>{{c1::Hydraulic (oil)}} are helpful for the active amputee who can tolerate extra weight and expense</div><div><br></div><div>can provide {{c3::both swing and stance::swing/stance}} phase control<br></div><div><br></div></div><div>for K{{c2::3/4}} level ambulators&nbsp;</div></div>	"When weight is applied to the slightly flexed knee, the unit allows a slow yielding action instead of a precipitous collapse<div><br></div><div>This permits the young, agile amputee to descend ramps and stairs in a step-over-step manne<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-20 at 10.19.00 AM.png""><br></div></div>"																				
<div><strong>Microprocessor-control hydraulic knee</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>similar to other hydraulic knees, but has computer-programmed custom settings for each individual</div><div><br></div><div>calibrates the stability of the knee {{c1::50}} times per second to adapt to changing conditions and prevent falls</div><div><br></div><div>some have an {{c2::internal motor}} for {{c2::power generation}}, to assist with sit-to-stand, or for proximal weakness</div><div><br></div><div>generally indicated for K{{c3::3}}<br></div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>not designed
to be used for running or other high-activity sports</div><div><br></div><div>Micro-processor knees are generally indicated for those rated at a
functional index level K3 (but do have stance phase only for K2)</div><div><br></div><div>Advantages: Computer-adjusting knee for variable gait cycles Energy saving</div><div><br></div><div>Disadvantages: Highest cost, heavy, increased maintenance, inconvenience of daily charging, and unproven track record for dependability&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-20 at 10.19.06 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>HIP DISARTICULATION/HEMIPELVECTOMY</b><div><br></div><div>Amputees with &lt;{{c1::5}} cm of residual femur usually are fitted as hip disarticulation level amputees.</div><div><br></div><div>A&nbsp;{{c2::Canadian hip disarticulation prosthesis}}&nbsp;is the standard prosthesis for a hip disarticulation.</div>	"<img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/332118591/figure/fig2/AS:742876845711363@1554127050545/Photographs-showing-a-a-front-and-b-a-sagittal-view-of-the-patient-standing-with-the.jpg""><br><div><br></div><div><div>The socket of this prosthesis encloses the hemipelvis on the side of the amputation and extends around the hemipelvis of the nonamputated side, leaving an opening for the nonamputated&nbsp;LE.</div><div><br></div><div>There is a flexible anterior wall with an opening that allows the prosthesis to be donned. Weight bearing is on the ischial tuberosity of the amputated side.</div><div><br></div><div>Endoskeletal prosthetic components are preferred for this level of amputation to reduce the overall weight. The endoskeletal hip joint has an extension assist as does the knee unit, which usually is a stance-control knee.</div><div><br></div><div>Endoskeletal components may be made from aluminum, titanium, or carbon graphite composite.</div><div><br></div><div>Single-axis foot or&nbsp;SACH&nbsp;foot with a soft heel is used most often. The newer lightweight foot-ankle combination may be even a better option.</div><div><br></div><div>The prosthesis for a hemipelvectomy resembles that for the hip disarticulation socket except in the interior configuration of the socket.</div><div><br></div><div>In the hemipelvectomy, most of the weight bearing is by the soft tissues of the amputated side, with some of the weight bearing by the sacrum on the opposite ischial tuberosity.</div></div>"																				
"<span style=""font-style: italic;""><b>PRESSURE-TOLERANT AREAS</b></span>&nbsp;(<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch06#fig6_10"">A</a>, B, AND C)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Patellar tendon}}</div><div>{{c1::Medial tibial flare}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Anterior Compartment (Pretibial muscles)}}</div><div>{{c2::Lateral shaft of fibula}}</div><div>{{c2::Popliteal fossa (Gastroc-soleus muscles)}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_10.png"">"																				
"<span style=""font-style: italic;""><b>PRESSURE-SENSITIVE AREAS</b> (</span><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch06#fig6_10"">D</a>, E, AND F)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Patella}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Tibial tubercle (and condyles and distal tib)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Fibular head (and Distal fib)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Hamstring tendons}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_10.png"">"																				
<b>PARTIAL FOOT AMPUTATIONS</b><div><br></div><div>Amputation of the great toe requires a {{c1::molded insole}} with {{c1::arch support}} to maintain the alignment of the amputated foot</div><div><br></div><div><u>ray resections and&nbsp;TMAs</u></div><div>require {{c2::shoe fillers}} and&nbsp;<br></div><div>shoe modifications including {{c3::spring steel shank}} extending to the metatarsal heads&nbsp;</div><div>and a {{c3::rocker bottom sole}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Chopart, Lisfranc, and Boyd amputations</u>&nbsp;</div><div>use of a custom prosthetic foot with a {{c4::self-suspending split socket}}</div><div>A {{c4::AFO}} with partial foot prosthesis is another alternative.</div>	"<img src=""partial-foot.jpg""><img src=""chopart.jpg""><br><div><img src=""2987.fig.1.jpg""></div><div>chopart&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""3rockers_ROCKER-BOTTOM-POSTER-top-half-copy.jpg""></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Folliculitis::dx}}<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is a hair root infection resulting&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">from&nbsp;</span>{{c1::poor hygiene::etiology}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, sweating, poor socket fit, or pistoning</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is important to clean the area with antiseptic cleanser, to keep it dry, and to consider administration of oral antibiotics</span><br></div><div><img src=""300px-Isolated_folliculitis.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Boils</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">abscesses:</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;should be treated with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::limited prosthetic use::behvioral}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">as well as&nbsp;</span>{{c2::I&amp;D}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::oral antibiotics}}<b><br></b></div>"	"only wear during PT sessions, ie&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 31, 32);"">Unlike most cysts, boils are s<u>wollen, red, and sore</u>. pt may make a person feel weak or tired&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 31, 32);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 31, 32);"">several boils (faruncle) = carbuncles</span></div><div><img src=""hair-follicle-infections.png""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 31, 32);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><b><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Amputee&nbsp;</span>Dermatologic Issues</b></div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></span><u>{{c1::Epidermoid cysts}}</u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;occur when&nbsp;</span>{{c2::sebaceous glands}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are plugged by&nbsp;</span>{{c2::keratin}}<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">usually are not apparent until&nbsp;</span>{{c3::months or years}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after a prosthesis is worn&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may rarely require&nbsp;</span>{{c4::I&amp;D}}</div>"	"<div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Usually associated with the development with a tissue
roll that is subjected to mechanical shear from the socket</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">May be painful</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">May enlarge
and act as a foreign body with secondary infection and sinus tract development</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">AKAs</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Inguinal fold, adductor region, ischium</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">BKAs</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Anterior tibial surface, popliteal region</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Prevention:</span><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">good prosthetic fit, proper alignment, appropriate pressure relieves,
use of liner or socks, good hygiene</span><br></div></div><div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Treatment: skin hygiene, pressure relief, excision</span><br></div></div><div><img src=""Epidermoid_cyst09.jpg""><img src=""paste-b4764c70187c355495ee6733235af5f74fc899d0.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div><img src=""paste-6e19e27227801e8e18ab1b1198e60005e91c4505.jpg""><img src=""paste-a02ba3465d9aa0a6b3d663e137abc737f550e60b.jpg""><img src=""paste-8adbfe5bcf516216bd5817f109262b38525fb94b.jpg"">"

"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Tinea corporis</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;/&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">cruris</span>}}:<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;mainly result from sweating; they may be confirmed through culture or microscopy</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-21 at 4.00.24 PM.png""></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">treated by topical or oral fungicides, as well as by good residual limb and socket hygiene</span><div><img src=""paste-01beb2e86f7dc5afa84fe4ca5b086eaebf18f0fe.jpg""><img src=""300px-Tinea_cruris.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Hyperhidrosis</u></span>&nbsp;(excessive sweating) of the residual limb is a common problem after amputation</div><div><br></div><div>can be controlled with {{c1::prescription antiperspirants}}&nbsp;<br></div>"	"<div>Aluminum Chloride (e.g., Drysol<sup>®</sup>&nbsp;or Certain-Dry<sup>®</sup>)<br></div><div><br></div><div>astringents and rubbing alcohol should be avoided as they dry the skin excessively<br></div><div><br></div>Increased sweating on the residual limb may cause skin maceration, which in turn predisposes the skin to infection by bacteria and fungi<div><img src=""s-l1200.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><br><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>{{c1::Allergic contact dermatitis}}</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may arise from the detergents used to wash the limb socks, from lotions, or from agents used in the prosthetic manufacturing process</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Symptoms:&nbsp;erythema, burning, itching, local
inflammation, </span><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">vesiculation</span><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">, crusting and serous oozing</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Eczema may appear acutely with small blisters and later with scaling and erythema</span><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""paste-7949cd451f8d9e156de7246872c1d5015b5f8c9c.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><br><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>Allergic dermatitis</u></div><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Treatment:&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::removal of the causative agent}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Topical steroids}}</div></div>"	"+/-&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Cold compresses, antihistamine, anti-pruritic medications</span><div><img src=""paste-7949cd451f8d9e156de7246872c1d5015b5f8c9c.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Choke syndrome}}:</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">caused by&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">proximal&nbsp;</span>prosthetic socket&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">being too tight</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::distal lack of total contact}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(pathophys)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">leading to&nbsp;</span>{{c3::impairment of venous return}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">occurs most commonly at the distal transtibial residual limb due to atrophy over time&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and use of additional socks or when the residual limb becomes larger (excessive weight gain)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">improperly
wrapped elastic bandage, excess negative pressure from suction socket</span></div></div><div><img src=""paste-76d517037e9f2c59d7a90a1b48eafb7d1d8c6df0.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-21 at 4.04.22 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><br></div><div><u>Choke syndrome aka&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Stump Edema
Syndrome</span></u></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Findings on exam</strong>:&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::well-circumscribed}} {{c1::indurated}} area</div><div>if acute, edema can have {{c2::weeping/blistering}} of the skin&nbsp;</div><div>when chronic, the skin becomes thickened and hyperpigmented due to {{c3::hemosiderin accumulation}}</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Treatment</strong></div><div>{{c4::Relieving the proximal constriction}} and {{c4::restoring total contact}}</div>"	"<div><strong>Findings on exam</strong>:&nbsp;</div><div>Initially with wearing a prosthesis, the patient develops a well-circumscribed indurated area; if acute, edema can have weeping/blistering of the skin.&nbsp;</div><div>Area is tender to palpation and prone to cellulitis.&nbsp;</div><div>When chronic, the skin becomes thickened and hyperpigmented due to hemosiderin accumulation.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Treatment</strong>:&nbsp;</div><div>Relieving the proximal constriction and restoring total contact between the socket and residual limb&nbsp;</div><div>by reducing the number of socks and modification of the distal end pad.&nbsp;</div><div>Often a <u>new total contact socket is needed</u></div><div><img src=""paste-76d517037e9f2c59d7a90a1b48eafb7d1d8c6df0.jpg""><u><br></u></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><br></div><div><div>{{c1::Verrucous hyperplasia}}<span style=""font-style: italic;"">:</span>&nbsp;wartlike skin overgrowth of the residual distal limb,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>resulting from {{c2::inadequate socket wall contact::general/pathophys}} with subsequent edema formation</div></div>"	"<div>A <u>chronic&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">choke syndrome</span></u>&nbsp;may lead to verrucous hyperplasia of the distal residual limb skin<br></div><div><br></div><div>Relieving the proximal constriction and reestablishing total contact within the socket can <u>reverse these processes</u><br></div><div><img src=""paste-0775675d387cc5498e4561d3c89178a615c0337f.jpg""><img src=""paste-d4626c801eb4d02b6e1e8865482723547e07bb3a.jpg""><img src=""paste-d209474c31944c653553117c5691e094e3448f03.jpg""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_ufig6_1.png"">"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Reactive
Hyperemia}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">New prosthetic
wearers,&nbsp;</span>after walking with the prosthesis&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>may develop reddened areas that do not resolve
after a few minutes</div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Symptoms:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">tingling, warmth, and tightness</span></div>
<span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div>PE:&nbsp;limb is
flushed and warm</span><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div>"	"then the socket is creating excessive pressure on the residual limb in these locations&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>tx/prevention is compression wraps ""shrinker before prosthesis""</div><div><br></div><div>amputee wearing a total-contact socket must adapt to the heat, rub, and perspiration generated within the socket. to a degree this is inevitable.&nbsp; but prolonged ill fitting socket can ulcerate these areas or cause lichenification.&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""paste-90b05b91fa57ecd701197f51620b6f0c29f74b42.jpg""><img src=""PLATES2b10.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Amputee&nbsp;Dermatologic Issues</b><div><br></div><div><div>{{c1::Lichenification}}:<br></div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Occurs due to
excessive mechanical forces</span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Presents a
thickened, leathery skin&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">occurs
over pressure areas in the socket or along the brim</span></div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Symptoms:&nbsp;burning, itching or soreness</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);"">Treatment:&nbsp;<u>realignment</u> of the socket to reduce pressure or modification of the socket</span></div><div><img src=""paste-34edac17883922ae0165bc14e7b9d89acdb8c406.jpg""><img src=""paste-6e308c9ec53353dfc068080a985b86e497e22dcd.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(38, 38, 38);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::Stride length}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span></b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is the distance measured from heel strike to heel strike of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::the same foot}}</div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Linear distance between corresponding successive points of contact of the same foot</span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_1.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>{{c3::Step length}}<font color=""#333333"">:</font></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is distance measured from heel strike of one foot to heel strike of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::the other foot}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Normally, this length is approximately&nbsp;</span>{{c1::15}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::20}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;inches</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Linear distance in the plane of progression between corresponding successive contact points of opposite feet</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_1.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::Stance phase<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Time period during which the limb is in contact with the ground</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Stance phase is divided into five periods</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::Swing phase<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Time period during which the foot is in the air for limb advancement</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Swing phase is divided into three periods</span><br><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the distribution of time during the gait cycle at normal walking speed is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::60}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% for&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>stance phase</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::40}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% for&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>swing phase</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Walking faster&nbsp;</span>{{c2::increases}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;time spent in swing phase</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"																				
"<span style=""font-style: italic;""><strong>Double-limb support</strong></span>:&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Time period during which {{c2::both feet are in contact with the floor}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Usually comprises {{c1::20}}% of the normal gait cycle</div>"	"Both the beginning and end of the stance phase are considered to be the double-limb support<div>20% + 40% from single limb = the 60% stance phase&nbsp;<br><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/334287210/figure/fig5/AS:778194588291072@1562547456253/Human-gait-characteristics-a-Typical-gait-events-and-gait-phases-b-Thigh-angles.ppm""><br></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><strong>Single-limb support</strong></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Time period starts when the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::opposite foot is lifted for the swing phase}}</div>"	"<img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/334287210/figure/fig5/AS:778194588291072@1562547456253/Human-gait-characteristics-a-Typical-gait-events-and-gait-phases-b-Thigh-angles.ppm"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">When there is <b>no</b> longer a <u>double-limb support</u> period, the person is considered to be&nbsp;</span>{{c1::running}}"																					
<strong>Cadence</strong>: {{c1::Number of steps per unit of time}}	Comfortable walking speed = 80 m/min or 3 mph<div><br></div><div>Speed slows by either reducing the cadence or by decreasing step or stride length</div>																				
"<strong>Center of gravity (COG)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Typically located&nbsp;</span>{{c1::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cm anterior to the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::S2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;vertebra</span>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-14 at 10.53.55 AM.png""><img src=""paste-53b2e0ecb997e6d5254e5634c71157769dfc03b5.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""applsci-08-01167-g003.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The&nbsp;</span>COG<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is displaced&nbsp;</span>{{c1::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cm horizontally and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cm vertically during an average adult male step</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&lt;2 inches</span><br></div><img src=""CENTER+OF+MASS+DISPLACEMENT+15-13.jpg"">"																				
<strong>Base of support</strong>:&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Defined as the space outlined by {{c1::the feet}} and {{c1::any assistive device}} in contact with the ground</div><div><br></div><div>Falling is avoided if the&nbsp;{{c2::COG}}&nbsp;remains positioned over the base of support</div>	"Normal base of support (distance between heels) = 6 to 10 cm<div><img src=""infographic.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>STANCE PHASE: FIVE SUBDIVISIONS</b>&nbsp;<div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Initial contact}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Loading response}}</div><div>{{c1::Midstance}}</div><div>{{c1::Terminal stance}}</div><div>{{c1::Preswing}}</div></div>	"Remember:&nbsp;<strong>“I L</strong>ike&nbsp;<strong>M</strong>y&nbsp;<strong>T</strong>ea&nbsp;<strong>P</strong>resweetened”<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""><br></div>"																				
SWING PHASE: THREE SUBDIVISIONS&nbsp;<div><strong><br></strong></div><div>{{c1::Initial swing}}</div><div>{{c1::Midswing}}</div><div>{{c1::Terminal swing}}</div>	"Remember:&nbsp;<strong>“I</strong>n&nbsp;<strong>M</strong>y&nbsp;<strong>T</strong>eapot”<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The body has the lowest&nbsp;</span>COG<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;during&nbsp;</span>{{c1::loading response}}"	"<img src=""11-Figure5-1.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the body has the highest&nbsp;</span>COG<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;during&nbsp;</span>{{c1::midstance}}"	"<img src=""11-Figure5-1.png""><div><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Loading response</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Time period&nbsp;</span>{{c1::immediately following initial contact}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;up until&nbsp;</span>{{c1::the opposite leg is lifted off the ground}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">during which weight shift occurs</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><strong>Midstance</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Time period from&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lift of the opposite leg off the ground}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to the point where&nbsp;</span>{{c1::the ankles of both extremities are aligned in the frontal plane?}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"																				
<strong>Terminal stance</strong>:&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Time period from {{c1::ankle alignment in the frontal plane}} to {{c1::just prior to initial contact of the opposite (swinging) leg}}</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"																				
<strong>Preswing</strong>:&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Time period from {{c1::initial contact of the opposite leg}} to {{c1::just prior to lift of the ipsilateral extremity off the ground (unloading weight)}}</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"																				
<strong>Initial contact</strong>: {{c1::Instant the foot contacts the ground}}	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"																				
<strong>Initial swing</strong>: {{c1::Lift of the extremity from the ground}} to {{c1::position of maximum knee flexion}}	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"																				
<strong>Midswing</strong>: Immediately following {{c1::max knee flexion}} to {{c1::vertical tibia position}}	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"																				
<strong>Terminal swing</strong>: Following {{c1::vertical tibia position}} to {{c1::just prior to initial contact}}	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png"">"

"{{c1::determinants of gait}}&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">factors applied in normal human gait to minimize the excursion of the body’s&nbsp;</span>COG<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and reduce expenditure of energy</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.09.49 PM.png"">"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">six determinants of gait are:</span></b></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Pelvic rotation}}</div><div>{{c1::Pelvic tilt}}</div><div>{{c2::Knee flexion in stance phase}}</div><div>{{c2::Foot mechanisms}}</div><div>{{c2::Knee mechanisms}}</div><div>{{c1::Lateral displacement of the pelvis}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.09.49 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Determinants of Gait</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Pelvic rotation</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">pelvis rotates&nbsp;</span>{{c1::medially (anteriorly)::direction}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::swinging}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;leg side,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">""</span>{{c2::lengthening}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">"" the limb</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in the would-be lowest point of the gait cycle to prevent&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">a sudden drop of the&nbsp;</span>COG}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-033e6e88dff55588f1a424a1fa2674a11be65f9b.jpg""><img src=""paste-7fe1b83e9881717d13818d488b179777d9c16155.jpg""><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 11.49.13 AM.png""><br></div><div><div>Decreases number of times&nbsp; CoG drops vertically at IC/LR per unit
distance</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.09.49 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Determinants of Gait</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Pelvic tilt</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">pelvis on the side of the&nbsp;</span>swinging<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;leg is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lowered}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;degrees</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">this&nbsp;</span>{{c2::lowers}} the<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c2::COG}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;at Midstance</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-66c721b74c15622ab425abdc9174e51b298e2970.jpg""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.09.49 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Determinants of Gait</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Knee flexion in stance</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Early bending of the knee lowers the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::COG}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the body at&nbsp;</span>{{c1::midstance}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">which</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;decreases the&nbsp;</span>energy expenditure<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-189b7d5bc89216763fc25b8503242b2d87688a13.jpg""><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 12.03.26 PM.png""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.09.49 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Determinants of Gait</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Foot mechanisms</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">At heel strike, ankle plantar flexion&nbsp;</span>{{c1::smoothens}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;the curve of the falling pelvis.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">pivot points (rockers) at the heel and forefoot help to functionally&nbsp;</span>{{c2::lengthen}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;the stance limb at initial contact and preswing,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ankle rockers&nbsp;</span>{{c2::shorten}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;the limb at midstance</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-11 at 12.53.01 PM.png""><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(0, 32, 96);"">“</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 32, 96);"">Heel
Rocker” (Initial Contact) </span>– plantar flexion &amp; supination <span style=""color: red;"">lengthen
leg </span>(like
pelvic rotation); reducing CoM drop.</div>
<div></div>
<div></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(0, 32, 96);"">“</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 32, 96);"">Ankle
Rocker” (Loading Response/Mid-stance) </span>– pronation <font color=""#fc0006"">shortens
leg</font><span style=""color: yellow;""> </span>(like
knee flexion); <font color=""#fc0006""><b><u>lowers CoM</u></b></font>
&amp; propagates forward motion</div>
<div></div>
<div></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(0, 32, 96);"">“Toe
Rocker” (Terminal Stance) </span>– heel rise, plantar flexion &amp;
supination <font color=""#fc0006"">lengthen leg</font><span style=""color: yellow;""> </span>(with
knee mechanisms) to reduce CoM drop</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.09.49 PM.png"">"																				
"<b>Determinants of Gait</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Knee mechanisms</u></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">After midstance, the knee&nbsp;</span>{{c1::extends}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;as the ankle&nbsp;</span>{{c1::plantar flexes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">to restore the length to the leg and diminish the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::fall of the pelvis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;at the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::opposite::same/opposite}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;heel strike</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-12 at 9.30.22 AM.png""><img src=""paste-9e11f7dc1ac66157cfefc53da63f55eb3bc359b0.jpg""><img src=""paste-d45733c92856a6b3dd2e471dba33969889a88f36.jpg""></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(112, 48, 160); font-weight: bold;"">Knee Mechanisms” – </span><span style=""font-weight: bold;"">from
Midstance through Toe-off.&nbsp; </span></div>
<div>1.Knee
extension</div>
<div>2.Knee
lateral/varus thrust (works with lateral pelvic displacement)</div>
<div>3.External
tibial torsion (leads to foot supination)</div>
<div></div>
<div>Effect – Lengthens leg (similar to Pelvic
Rotation) to keep CoM
up/reduce drop-off at the end of stance phase (similar to Toe-rocker)&nbsp;</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.09.49 PM.png"">"																				
"<b>Determinants of Gait</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Lateral displacement of the pelvis</u></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">there is displacement toward the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::stance}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;limb</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">w/ net effect of the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::COM positioned over BOS}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-56255f1a87bb897975c2c7d93d69088fad3ff362.jpg""><br></div><div>
<div>Reduces Moment Arm of GRF on stance phase hip, <span style=""color: red;"">decreasing Glut Med
work.</span></div></div><div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">Only Gait Determinant working in <u>Horizontal</u>
Plane!</font></div></div><div><img src=""F000146f014-008-9781455709779.jpg""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.09.49 PM.png""><div><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Sagittal Plane Kinematics</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Hip:</u><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><br></div><div>reaches peak flexion
of just over 30 degrees just before {{c1::initial contact}}<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div>The hip undergoes gradual extension throughout stance phase. The hip reaches maximum extension of 10 degrees at the end of terminal stance. At the beginning of preswing, the hip begins to flex before the foot leaves contact with the ground. The hip gradually flexes during the swing phase reaching peak flexion of just over 30 degrees just before initial contact.<br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.57.31 PM.png"">"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Sagittal Plane Kinematics</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Knee:</u><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span></div><div>reaches maximum flexion of approximately 60 degrees during {{c1::midswing}}<span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"The knee begins the gait cycle with approximately 5 degrees of flexion at initial contact. The knee flexes slightly during loading response to 10 to 15 degrees. Once the limb is in single limb support at the beginning of midstance, the knee begins to extend and it reaches&nbsp;−5 degrees of full extension before beginning a period of rapid knee flexion at the end of stance phase and into initial swing phase. During swing phase, the knee reaches maximum flexion of approxi- mately 60 degrees during midswing before moving into a period of knee extension. The knee reaches full extension at the end of swing phase and begins to flex slightly just before initial contact.&nbsp;<br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.57.31 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Sagittal Plane Kinematics</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Ankle:</u><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><br></div><div>Peak dorsiflexion of 10
degrees occurs in {{c1::terminal stance (just before preswing)}}</div><div><br></div><div>plantar flexion reaches a maximum
of 20 degrees in {{c1::initial swing (just after toe off)}}&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div>think of this as <b>Just Before &amp; Just After <u>Pre-Swing</u></b></div><div><br></div>the ankle begins to plantar flex rapidly before the foot leaving contact with the floor.&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: 800;"">&nbsp;</span><div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 9.57.31 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::ground reaction force (GRF)}}</div><div><br></div><div>forces that occur across the hip, knee, and ankle joints
during the stance phase of the gait cycle&nbsp;<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-28 at 10.08.40 PM.png"">"																				
"<div>
<div>

<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Muscle Activity during Gait</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Initial Swing</u></div><div>{{c1::Hip flexors}}<span style=""font-weight: 800;"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::Hamstrings}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::quadriceps}}</div><div>{{c1::tib ant}}</div>
