</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 9.39.45 AM.png""><br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 9.10.11 AM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 9.10.30 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><strong>uncompensated <u>left</u> Trendelenburg gait</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::right pelvis drops}}<br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Example: Stand on <u>right</u> leg only—if pelvis drops on the<u> left side</u> (excessive pelvic tilt)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">because the ipsilateral hip abductors do not stabilize the pelvis to prevent the drop</span></div><div><img src=""YHqDbaw4MLDbcfPIwWFyzA.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><strong>compensated <u>left</u>&nbsp;Trendelenburg gait</strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::excessive lateral lean, trunk toward the weak side (left)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">to keep the&nbsp;</span>COG<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;over the stance leg</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">When a patient walks, if he or she leans his or her trunk to the right to prevent left pelvic drop</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><br><div><img src=""YHqDbaw4MLDbcfPIwWFyzA.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">a Trendelenberg gait becomes&nbsp;</span>{{c1::less evident}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;with faster walking&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">due to a shorter stance phase</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>his is in contrast to most other gait deviations</span>"																				
<b>Foot slap</b><div><br></div><div><u>causes</u></div><div>{{c1::moderately weak dorsiflexors}}<u><br></u></div>	DF on MMT that is a 3 or 4&nbsp;																				
"<b>Genu recurvatum</b><div><br></div><div><u>causes</u></div><div>{{c1::Weak quadriceps (short or spastic)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c2::plantar flexor spasticity/constracture}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">compensated&nbsp;</span>{{c3::hamstring}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;weakness</span><u><br></u></div>"	"<img src=""paste-6cb00105ac616edd1134f25d8b0962bb87c8d8da.jpg"">"																				
"<b>Excessive foot supination</b><br><div><br></div><div><u>causes</u></div><div>{{c1::fore foot valgus deformity (compensated)}}<br></div><div>{{c2::pes cavus}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">short limb</span><u><br></u></div>"	"<img src=""paste-2859f1354bbbd6c1eebcff8911641b66f9f7c648.jpg""><div><h3><u>Forefoot valgus</u></h3><table><tbody><tr><th><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">In uncompensated forefoot&nbsp;</span>valgus<span style=""font-weight: normal;"">&nbsp;(A), the plane of metatarsal heads is&nbsp;<u>everted</u>&nbsp;in relation to the rearfoot when the STJ is in neutral.</span><div><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">The person&nbsp;</span>compensates<span style=""font-weight: normal;"">&nbsp;(B) by&nbsp;<u>supinating</u>&nbsp;the&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Sub Talar Joint</span><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">&nbsp;during midstance then pronating during terminal stance.</span></div></th><th><img src=""fftvala.gif""></th><th><img src=""fftvalb.gif""></th></tr></tbody></table><div><div><b><u>Forefoot Varus</u></b></div><div><br><table><tbody><tr><th><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">In uncompensated forefoot&nbsp;</span>varus<span style=""font-weight: normal;"">&nbsp;(A), the plane of metatarsal heads is&nbsp;<u>inverted</u>&nbsp;in relation to the rearfoot's plane when the subtalar joint is neutral.</span><div><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">The person&nbsp;</span>compensates<span style=""font-weight: normal;"">&nbsp;(B) by&nbsp;<u>pronating</u>&nbsp;the Sub Talar Joint durng midstance and terminal stance to allow the first metatarsal to contact the ground.</span></div></th><th><img src=""fftvara.gif""></th><th><img src=""fftvarb.gif""></th></tr></tbody></table><h3><br></h3></div></div></div>"																				
"<div><b>trunk flexion</b><u><br></u></div><u><div><u><br></u></div>causes</u><div>{{c1::Weak gluteus maximus (and quadriceps)::2}}<br></div><div>{{c2::hip flexion contracture}}</div><div><br></div><div><b style="""">trunk extension</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>causes</u><br><div>{{c3::Weak hip extensor (and hip flexor)::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">hip pain</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">decreased knee&nbsp;</span>ROM</div></div>"	"<div><div><div><div><span style=""font-weight: bold;"">“Quad-avoidance” Gaits:</span></div><div><u>Truncal lean forward&nbsp;</u>brings GFR anterior to knee, causing recurvatum (antalgic knee, weak quad)</div><div><u>Truncal lean backward&nbsp;</u>&amp; short stance time on affected leg prevent loading response needs (weak quad, unstable antalgic knee)</div></div><div><img src=""paste-810647931f0635290284622d362bb1a54858ce16.png""><img src=""paste-ab41a99487ab06c5ff79ccb4e4e35e5d5aeec67c.jpg""></div></div><div><img src=""paste-2389d81a50695975b8b75e5ce064aba9b8261b27.jpg""><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(0, 32, 96); font-weight: bold;"">Gluteus Maximus Gait:</span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(0, 32, 96);"">Truncal lean backward at Initial
Contact negates need for gluteus max activation by moving GFR behind hip.</span></div></div><div><img src=""paste-44114cfd9feba40cbaffad2cb52cfbc33d6535c3.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>Excessive knee flexion</b><br></div><br><div><u>causes</u></div><div>{{c1::increased ankle dorsiflexion}}<u><br></u></div><div>{{c2::Hamstring contracture}}<br></div><div>{{c3::long limb}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">hip flexion contracture</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">weak plantar flexor</span>"																				
<div>Waddling gait<br></div><br><div><u>causes</u></div><div>{{c1::Bilateral gluteus medius weakness}}<br></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 10.05.50 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>Excessive foot pronation</b><div><br></div><div><u>causes</u><br><div>{{c1::Compensated (forefoot) varus deformity}}</div></div><div>{{c2::pes planus}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">long limb</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">decreased ankle dorsiflexion</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">weak tibialis posterior</span><br></div>"	"<div><b><u>Forefoot Varus</u></b></div><div><br><table><tbody><tr><th><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">In uncompensated forefoot </span>varus<span style=""font-weight: normal;""> (A), the plane of metatarsal heads is <u>inverted</u> in relation to the rearfoot's plane when the subtalar joint is neutral.</span><div><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">The person </span>compensates<span style=""font-weight: normal;""> (B) by <u>pronating</u> the Sub Talar Joint durng midstance and terminal stance to allow the first metatarsal to contact the ground.</span></div></th><th><img src=""fftvara.gif""></th><th><img src=""fftvarb.gif""></th></tr></tbody></table><h3><u style="""">Forefoot valgus</u></h3><table><tbody><tr><th><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">In uncompensated forefoot </span>valgus<span style=""font-weight: normal;""> (A), the plane of metatarsal heads is <u>everted</u> in relation to the rearfoot when the STJ is in neutral.</span><div><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">The person </span>compensates<span style=""font-weight: normal;""> (B) by <u>supinating</u> the&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Sub Talar Joint</span><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">&nbsp;during midstance then pronating during terminal stance.</span></div></th><th><img src=""fftvala.gif""></th><th><img src=""fftvalb.gif""><br></th></tr></tbody></table></div>"																				
Bouncing or exaggerated gait<div><br></div><div><u>causes</u><br><div>{{c1::gastroc spasticity / contracture}}</div></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 10.22.56 AM.png"">"																				
"<div><b>Steppage gait/foot drop</b><br></div><div><br></div><u>causes</u><br>Severely weak {{c1::dorsiflexors}}<br><div>{{c3::equinus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;deformity</span></div><div>{{c2::plantar flexor spasticity}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""steppage__gait.jpg"">"																				
"<div><b>Circumduction</b></div><div><br></div><u>causes<br></u><div>{{c1::Long limb}}</div><div>{{c2::stiff knee}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">abductor muscle shortening or overuse</span></div>"																					
"<div><b>Hip hiking</b></div><div><br></div><u>causes</u><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">long limb / ""functional long limb""</span></div><div>{{c4::hip flexor weakness}}<br></div><div>{{c1::weak hamstring}}<br></div><div>{{c2::quadratus lumborum shortening}}<br></div><div>{{c3::stiff knee / quad spasticity::2&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">functional long ~same</span>}}</div><div>{{c3::foot drop / PF tone:: 2&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">functional long</span>}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-bd3735696bb375d4294578fa3933c0297d5a20ae.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gait disturbances in Parkinson’s include&nbsp;</span>{{c1::stooped}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;posture and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::festinating}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;gait</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">rapid, small steps, done in an attempt to keep the center of gravity (COG) in between the feet&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">while the trunk leans forward involuntarily and shift the COG forward</span></div><div><img src=""250px-Sir_William_Richard_Gowers_Parkinson_Disease_sketch_1886.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>Gait Impairment in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy</b><div><br></div><div>Often characterized by {{c1::toe walking}}</div><div><br></div><div>Stance phase: <u>Plantar flexion</u> to maintain a weight line {{c3::posterior}} to the hip and {{c3::anterior}} to the knee</div><div><br></div><div>Compensatory for weak {{c4::knee extensors}}, or for increased lumbar lordosis which itself is compensating for weak {{c4::hip extensor}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Waddling gait}} and trunk lean over weight-bearing limb may occur due to hip abductor weakness</div>	"<img src=""2509144_orig.gif""><img src=""images-85988ed4d6ca5f9c08ebc1003a63b7b7172145ca.jpg"">"																				
"<b>Gait Impairment in Plantar Flexion Weakness</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>can be seen in:</u></span></div><div><div>{{c1::poliomyelitis}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Charcot–Marie–Tooth}}<br></div></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">injuries such as Achilles tendon rupture</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">tibial nerve injury</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">S1 radiculopathy</span></div>"																					
"<b>Gait Impairment in Plantar Flexion Weakness</b><div><br></div><div>Characterized by excessive ankle dorsiflexion and persistent&nbsp;{{c1::knee flexion}} during stance phase</div><div><br></div><div>Decreased stride length due to decreased or absent {{c2::heel rise}} and&nbsp;lack of&nbsp;{{c2::propulsion}}</div>
<div><br></div><div>Ipsilateral {{c3::pelvic drop}} in preswing, causing increased energy consumption&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-cabd598f3f095638d2a2950b438de8350ab873f1.jpg""><br></div><div>- Stance phase ""drop-off."" end of stance phase, uncontrolled dorsi-flexion
due to weak plantar-flexors&nbsp;</div><div>- causes CoG drop with shortened leg/knee
buckle</div><div><br></div><div><div>- Calcaneal gait – weight-bearing through heel &gt; midfoot, but not
forefoot due to metatarsalgia, or rigidity.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>- Shortened leg/no toe-rocker is result.</div></div><div><br></div><div>results in decreased walking speed and increased energy expenditure</div><div><br></div><div>more energy since the pelvis rises again during the stance phase of the normal contralateral leg</div><div><img src=""gait cycle.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Gait Impairment With Hip Flexion Contracture</b><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>compensation:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>increased {{c1::anterior pelvic tilt}}</div><div>decreased {{c2::contralateral}} {{c2::step length}}</div><div>{{c5::Bell-Clapper}} gait</div><div>increased {{c3::knee flexion}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>35-degree</u> contracture due to iliopsoas tightness results in a {{c4::60}}% increase energy consumption</div>	"<div>Hip flexion contracture can alter normal gait patterns due to the decreased hip extension range of motion (ROM)<br></div><div><img src=""paste-bfa3608d6452a0eaccef47396956afbe0e945e2e.jpg""></div><div>Bell-Claper Hip – fused or immobile hip
(hamstring shortening/spasticity); ipsilateral lumbar flattening &amp;
posterior pelvic tilt with thigh forward advancement.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>Restored lumbar lordosis with anterior pelvic
tilt upon thigh extension.&nbsp; Common in
spastic hemi-pares</div><div><img src=""Untitled+design+(3).png""></div>"																				
<b>WHEELCHAIR PROPULSION</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Measured the energy expenditure of wheelchair propulsion in patients with <u>paraplegia</u></div><div><br></div><div>there was only {{c1::9}}% increase in energy expenditure</div>																					
<b>CRUTCH WALKING</b><div><br></div><div>requires {{c1::more::more/less}} energy than walking with a prosthesis</div><div><br></div><div><div><u>UE Muscles that need strengthening in preparation</u></div><div>{{c2::Latissimus dorsi}}</div><div>{{c2::Triceps}}</div><div>{{c2::Pectoralis major}}</div></div>	<div>Quads</div><div>Hip extensors</div><div>Hip abductors</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Energy Expenditure of Different Levels of Amputation (trauma)&nbsp;</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Trans-tibial:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::20}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">%</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">bilateral TT:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::40}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">%</span></div><div><div>Trans-femoral: {{c1::60}}%</div><div>bilateral TF: {{c1::200}}%</div></div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 10.56.09 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Bone Problems</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">If the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::periosteum}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is incorrectly stripped during surgery or trauma,&nbsp;</span><u>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">bone&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">spurs</span>}}</u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may cause pressure and pain</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::Socket modifications}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;generally take care of the problem</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">However, in some cases, additional surgery may be neede</span><div><img src=""j_jaoa.2020.045_fig_001.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Bone Problems</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::Bone overgrowth}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::heterotopic ossification}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;occur&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most commonly in kids with acquired amputation and young adults with traumatic amputation</span><b><br></b></div>"																					
<b>Bone Problems</b><div><br></div><div>beyond spur, overgrowth, and HO</div><div><br></div><div>Bone pain may result from a {{c1::hypermobile fibula}} or {{c1::fibula that is left longer than the tibia}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>in a&nbsp;TFA, the femur may {{c2::extrude through the muscle}} if a balanced myodesis was not performed</div>	and present subcutaneously<div><br></div><div>If prosthetic adjustments, such as a flexible socket, are inadequate for the extruded femur, then surgical intervention might be needed</div>																				
<b>Acquired Upper Limb Amputations</b><div><b><br></b><div><u>MOST COMMON CAUSES</u></div><div>1. {{c1::Trauma}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Cancer/tumors}}</div><div>3. {{c1::Vascular complications of diseases}}</div></div>	Trauma is the leading cause of acquired amputation in the upper extremity (approximately 80%), occurring primarily in men ages 15 to 45 years																				
"<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Partial hand amputation</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;should be carefully planned</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">There is little value in salvaging a partial hand with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::no prehension (ability to hold/grasp)}}</div></div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Surgical reconstruction}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may be a more appropriate choice</span></div>"	"<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Partial hand amputation</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;should be carefully planned to ensure adequate residual sensation and movement</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">For these amputations, a prosthesis may not be necessary</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">reconstruction to preserve or enhance function while maintaining sensation in the residual partial hand</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""cirugía-reconstructiva-amputación-524x227.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::Mangled (Hand) Extremity Severity Score}}<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">may be used to decide whether to perform amputation in patients with injuries involving a (upper) limb</span></div>"	"<b>A score of 7 points or higher indicates the need for amputation</b><div><sup>a</sup><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Score doubled for ischemia &gt;6 hours</span><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-04 at 1.12.17 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-style: italic;""><b>Mangled hand</b>:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Amputation is considered if <u>irreparable</u> damage occurs to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::4}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the 6 basic parts&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(skin, vessels, skeleton, nerves, extensor, and flexor tendons)</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Initial goal: Save all feasible length</span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-04 at 1.12.17 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>WRIST DISARTICULATION</b><div><br></div><div>preserves full forearm {{c1::supination and pronation::action}}</div><div><br></div><div>A special thin wrist unit is used to {{c2::minimize overall length}}&nbsp;</div>	"Socket designs for this level are tapered and flattened distally to form an oval that allows the amputee full active supination and pronation<div><br></div><div>thus avoiding having to preposition the terminal device (TD) for functional activities</div><div><br></div><div>If cosmesis is of importance to the amputee, <u>a long, below-elbow amputation may be a more appropriate</u> amputation level<br></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">transmetacarpal amputation and wrist amputation</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are <u>seen less</u> because they have decreased functional outcomes</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">transmetacarpal may preserve some <u>wrist flexion and extension</u></span></div><div><a><img src=""B9780323072434000189_f018-002a-9780323072434.jpg"">&nbsp;<img src=""B9780323072434000189_f018-002b-9780323072434.jpg"">&nbsp;<img src=""B9780323072434000189_f018-002c-9780323072434.jpg"">&nbsp;<img src=""B9780323072434000189_f018-002d-9780323072434.jpg"">&nbsp;<img src=""B9780323072434000189_f018-002e-9780323072434.jpg""></a><br></div>"																				
fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-1		"<img src=""tmpb_ul__z6.png"" />"	"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-1-Q.svg"" />"						"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-1-A.svg"" />"	"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-O.svg"" />"											
fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-2		"<img src=""tmpb_ul__z6.png"" />"	"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-2-Q.svg"" />"						"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-2-A.svg"" />"	"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-O.svg"" />"											
fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-3		"<img src=""tmpb_ul__z6.png"" />"	"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-3-Q.svg"" />"						"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-3-A.svg"" />"	"<img src=""fe5aabde15b948f7aedd459cda370606-ao-O.svg"" />"											
"{{c1::Transradial}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;amputation is the most common UE level</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">allows a high level of functional recovery in the majority of cases</span><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-09 at 8.30.50 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""B9780323072434000189_f018-003-9780323072434.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>TRANSRADIAL</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::long forearm::length}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;residual limb is preferred when optimal body-powered prosthetic restoration is the goal</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is the ideal level for the patient who is expected to perform physically demanding work</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>short and very short</u> transradial amputation level can complicate suspension and limit elbow flexion strength and elbow&nbsp;</span>ROM<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_4.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Transradial</b><div><br></div><div>long below-elbow residual limb retains {{c1::60}} degrees to {{c1::120}} degrees of supination and pronation</div><div><br></div><div>residual limb length of {{c2::65}}% is preferred when optimal <u>{{c3::externally powered prosthetic}}</u><b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b> is the goal&nbsp;</div>"	"short below-the-elbow residual limb retains &lt;60 degrees<div><br></div><div>residual limb length of 60% to 70% is preferred when optimal <u>externally powered</u> prosthetic restoration is the goal<br></div><div><br></div><div>internally powered = implies body power (self contained)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>this length typically permits good function and cosmesis&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>while allowing adequate space for electronic components<b><font color=""#fc0006"">* myoelectric and micro-switch are 2 external power options</font></b><br></div><div><img src=""B9780323072434000189_f018-003-9780323072434.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>ELBOW DISARTICULATION</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Pros</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>reduces {{c1::rotation}}&nbsp;of the socket<br></div>
<div>less risk of {{c2::bone spur or HO}}<br></div><div><div>Allows greater {{c3::power}}</div></div><div>reduction in surgery time and blood loss</div><div><br></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Cons</span>:</u></div><div><div>impede the use of {{c4::externally powered elbow mechanisms}}&nbsp;</div></div><div>cosmetic appearance&nbsp;</div>"	"reduces the rotation of the socket on the residual limb, compared with a transhumeral level<div><br><div>improved prosthetic self-suspension (by permitting the use of a less encumbering socket)<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>bilateral transhumeral amputation is the alternative, elbow disarticulation is the more desirable level<br></div><div><br></div><div><a>broad flare of the humeral condyles can be grasped firmly by the prosthetic socket and humeral rotation can be transmitted to the prosthesis</a><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_3.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>TRANSHUMERAL</b>&nbsp;<div><br><div>{{c1::Longer residual limb}} length will give the best control and function with a prosthesis</div></div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_4.png"">"																				
<b>SHOULDER DISARTICULATION AND FOREQUARTER AMPUTATIONS</b><div><br></div><div>Functional prosthetic use is less successful because {{c1::suspension is difficult}}</div><div><br></div><div>Special consideration should be made for providing a {{c2::shoulder cap}} and ultralight passive prosthesis<br></div>	"<div>Fortunately, seen with less frequency than amputations of other levels</div><div><br></div><div>In most cases, they are necessary to remove a malignant lesion</div><div><br></div><div>cap allows wearing of regular clothes&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""C14-FF1-7.gif""><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12957-016-0973-7/MediaObjects/12957_2016_973_Fig2_HTML.gif""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Muscle Activity during Gait</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Loading Response</u><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::Gluteus <b>medius</b>}}</div><div>{{c1::Hamstrings}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Quadriceps}}</div><div>{{c1::Pre tibial m.}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.08.18 PM.png""><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">*The quadriceps changes from an eccentric to concentric contraction as it transitions from loading response to midstance.</span><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 9.10.11 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Muscle Activity during Gait</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Terminal Stance</u><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::Iliopsoas}}</div><div>{{c1::Glut med}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Gastroc}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.14.59 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 9.10.11 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Muscle Activity during Gait</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Pre Swing</u><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::Iliopsoas}}</div><div>{{c1::Quadriceps}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Gastroc}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.23.23 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 9.10.11 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Muscle Activity during Gait</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Mid Swing</u><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::Iliopsoas}}</div><div>{{c1::Hamstrings}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Pre-tibial}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.34.07 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.31.28 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Muscle Activity during Gait</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 800;""><br></span></div><div><u>Terminal Swing</u><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::Hamstrings}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Pre-tibial}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.39.51 PM.png""><div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.31.28 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_2.png""></div></div>"																				
<div><b>Ground Reaction Force DURING STATIC STANCE:</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>it passes</u></div><div>{{c1::BEHIND the}} hip</div><div>{{c1::in<b> FRONT</b> of}}&nbsp;knee</div><div>{{c1::in&nbsp;<b>FRONT </b>of}}&nbsp;ankle<br></div>	"<div>“TKA Line” Lower Body static alignment is “BFF”<br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.44.51 PM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.50.00 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Passive</strong>&nbsp;terminal devices:<div><br></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Passive hand</span>:</u></div><div><br></div><div>Intended for {{c1::cosmetic}} use only, but can also {{c1::assist with pushing or lifting}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>{{c2::Flexible passive}}&nbsp;terminal devices:</u></div><div><br></div><div>Mitt-shaped terminal devices can fit into a glove or mitt for sports and other activities</div>"	"<div>Lighter</div><div><br></div><div>Have no functional mechanisms and provide no grasp</div><div><br></div><div>Specialty terminal devices&nbsp;with adapters for sports equipment, hand tools, or kitchen utensill<br></div><div><img src=""TERMINAL+DEVICES+1.Passive+cosmetic+hand+,+flexible+mitts+2.Active+hook+devices+,+prosthetic+hand+a..jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Body-powered terminal devices</strong><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::voluntary opening (VO)}}: Most common and practical type</div>"	"<div>Device maintained in closed position by rubber bands or tension springs</div><div><br></div><div>The amputee uses cable-control harness powered by proximal muscles to open the terminal devices against the force of the rubber bands or spring.</div><div><br></div><div>To grasp, patient releases the opened terminal device on an object; the rubber bands or spring provide the prehensile force.</div><div><br></div><div>The pinch force is determined by the number and type of rubber bands or springs. Each rubber band provides about 1 lb. of pinch force.</div><div><br></div><div>To&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">c</span>ontrol the amount of prehensile force, the patient must generate a continued opening force.</div><div><img src=""A316495_1_En_85_Fig4_HTML.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div>Voluntary Opening terminal device:</div><div><br></div>The pinch force is determined by the number and type of {{c1::rubber bands or springs}}<div><br></div><div>Each provides about {{c1::1 lb.}} of pinch force</div>	"<img src=""A316495_1_En_85_Fig4_HTML.jpg"">"																				
<div><strong>Body-powered terminal devices</strong><br></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div>{{c1::Voluntary Closing (VC)}}: Most physiological function</div><div><br></div><div>maximum prehensile force is determined by {{c2::the strength of the individual}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>Device is maintained in an open position and has to be closed voluntarily by pulling with the cable on the harness system to grasp an object.</div><div><br></div><div>To release, the patient releases the pull on the harness, and a spring in the terminal device opens it.</div><div><br></div><div>Disadvantages: Prolonged prehension requires constant pull on the harness; the terminal device remains awkwardly open when not in use.<br></div><div><img src=""-17044-8K27-R71-4-frei-11-col-form-free.jpg-Default-WorkingFormat-467Wx467H""><br></div>"																				
"<div><strong>Externally powered (electric-powered) terminal devices</strong>:</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Myoelectric-controlled</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><br></div><div>Use {{c1::surface electrodes}} placed on the muscles of the residual limb</div><div><br></div><div><u>{{c2::Microswitch-controlled}}</u><br></div><div><br></div><div>Use either a push-button or a pull-button&nbsp;</div><div>to activate the terminal device&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>Devices can have a digital or proportional control system:</div><div><br></div><div>Digital control system: On/off system</div><div><br></div><div>Proportional control system: The stronger the muscle contraction producing the signal, the faster the action.</div><div><img src=""maxresdefault-63db4bfdee06bcac0984b8780d6c2aaa2cc5d18b.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"wrist&nbsp;{{c1::flexion unit}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: allows terminal device to be in the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::flexed::same}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">position, facilitating ability to perform activities close to the body</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">important for bilateral upper extremity amputees [</span>ADLs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">]: Feeding, wiping)</span></div></div>"	"<img src=""Upper-Extremity-Prostheses-35-320.jpg"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Electric wrist rotator units are generally considered for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::bilateral upper extremity amputees}}<br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">typically rotation function is passive</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The amputee rotates the terminal device in the wrist unit with his sound hand or by pushing against a part of the body or other surface&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">to produce either pronation or supination</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">wrist unit also permits interchange of the terminal devices</span></div><div><img src=""Quick-Disconnect-Wrist-MYA825LQD_1.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(78, 78, 78); background-color: rgb(247, 248, 249);"">The Quick Disconnect Wrist connects the myoelectric hand to a forearm and custom socket.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div><b>types of wrist units:</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::Locking wrists}}: permit manual rotation and then leaves the terminal device in its <u>fixed</u> position</div>	Advantage: prevents inadvertent rotation of the terminal device in the wrist unit when a heavy object is grasped																				
"<div><b>types of wrist units:</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Friction wrists}}: permit pronation and supination of the terminal device from a compressed rubber washer</div>"	"<img src=""Upper-Extremity-Prostheses-31-320.jpg""><div><div><div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Adam-Spiers-2/publication/277332478/figure/fig3/AS:571150360559616@1513184265903/Passive-Wrist-Mechanisms-of-a-Hosmer-Dorrance-HD-Friction-Wrist-R-15-b-HD-FW.png""></div><div><a href=""https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Three-degrees-of-freedom-DOF-of-the-healthy-human-wrist_fig1_277332478""></a></div></div></div><div><h1>Passive Wrist Mechanisms of (a) Hosmer Dorrance (HD) Friction Wrist (R) [15], (b) HD FW Flexion Friction Wrist (2R) [15], (c) Otto Bock Myolino Wrist (U*-an S joint with prevented rotation) [24] and (d) Motion Control MultiFlex Wrist (RU)[37]. (e) Body Powered (2R) HD 4-Function Wrist [15].&nbsp;</h1></div><div><br></div></div>"																				
"<div><b>Two types of wrist flexion units:</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>{{c1::Add-on}}:</u></div><div><br></div><div>worn between the wrist and the terminal device&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and allows manual positioning of the terminal device in either the straight or the flexed position.</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Combination type</u></span></div><div><br></div><div>combines a {{c2::friction wrist}} and a {{c2::wrist flexion}} component in one and provides for setting and locking in one position</div>"	"<div><div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Adam-Spiers-2/publication/277332478/figure/fig3/AS:571150360559616@1513184265903/Passive-Wrist-Mechanisms-of-a-Hosmer-Dorrance-HD-Friction-Wrist-R-15-b-HD-FW.png""></div><div><a href=""https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Three-degrees-of-freedom-DOF-of-the-healthy-human-wrist_fig1_277332478""></a></div></div></div><div><h1>Passive Wrist Mechanisms of (a) Hosmer Dorrance (HD) Friction Wrist (R) [15], (b) HD FW Flexion Friction Wrist (2R) [15], (c) Otto Bock Myolino Wrist (U*-an S joint with prevented rotation) [24] and (d) Motion Control MultiFlex Wrist (RU)[37]. (e) Body Powered (2R) HD 4-Function Wrist [15].</h1></div>"																				
What brain region do lacunar strokes and ICH occur most often?	Putamen																				
What is ICP goal in stroke?	ICP &lt;20 mmHg																				
CPP goal in stroke?	&gt;60 mmHG																				
What is formula for CPP?	MAP-ICP=CPP																				
What is the brainstem rule of 4s?	"<img src=""paste-f91a4918fd41e9eb49f2db3c7f69fdca574983d4.jpg"">"																				
Occlusion of what vessel causes Contralateral homonymous hemianopia?	PCA																				
What kind of strokes lack aphasia/cognitive deficits?	Brainstem strokes																				
In stroke recovery what stage has peak spasticity?	Stage 3																				
What is a key element in Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation?	"<img src=""paste-5d284efc3fe49db284db66de9a69652e6e92054e.jpg"">"																				
CIMT needs what&nbsp; to work?	10 degrees active wrist extension																				
Aspiration during swallowing occurs during what phase?	Pharyngeal																				
Torticullis commonly occurs with what hip abnormality?	Hip dysplasia																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">limited knee flexion <u>immediately&nbsp;after heel strike</u>&nbsp;(not throughout stance)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><u><br></u></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Heel wedge is too soft}}</div><div>{{c2::foot is too far anterior}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Stiffen heel wedge}}</div><div>{{c2::move foot posterior}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""paste-111fbfc282c4d05e9b3dbee98a00ebf23938461a.jpg""><img src=""paste-010f6be46a161da9611824891858f9c4251b46cd.jpg""><div><div>Observed in sagittal plane during
prosthetic stance phases </div>
<div><br></div>
<div><u>To improve forward momentum/ knee
flexion: </u></div>
<div>Stiffen
heel cushion</div>
<div>Move
foot posterior to socket</div>
<div>Build
more flexion into socket</div>
<div>Dorsi-flex
foot</div>
<div>Change
to solid ankle flexible keel/ endoskeleton foot</div>
<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-23 at 10.02.04 AM.png""><br></div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-22 at 9.27.15 PM.png""><br></div><div><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Extended knee <u>throughout</u> stance phase</span><br></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Too much plantar flexion}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Dorsiflex foot}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"<img src=""paste-b4dbcb575ab942dcf34645cbe32e65b8087dff60.jpg""><div><span style=""font-weight: bold;"">Genu recurvatum</span> – knee hyperextension&nbsp;</div><div>Causes
– weak KEs, compensated weak KFs, PF contracture or
spasticity</div><div><br></div><div><div><u>To reduce knee hyperextension:</u>&nbsp; </div>
<div>Stiffen heel cushion</div>
<div>Change to solid ankle flexible keel/endoskeleton foot</div>
<div>Move foot posterior to socket or knee</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-23 at 10.02.04 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-22 at 9.27.15 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Toe stays off the floor after initial contact (heel strike)</span><br></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Heel wedge too stiff}}<br></div><div>{{c2::foot too anterior}}<br></div><div>{{c3::too much dorsiflexion}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Soften heel wedge}}<br></div><div>{{c2::move foot posterior}}<br></div><div>{{c3::plantar flex foot}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-23 at 10.02.04 AM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">“Hill-climbing” sensation toward end of stance phase</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Foot too anterior}}<br></div><div>{{c2::too much plantar flexion}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Move foot posterior}}<br></div><div>{{c2::dorsiflex foot}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-23 at 10.02.04 AM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">High pressure against patella throughout most of stance phase</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Foot too plantar flexed}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Dorsiflex foot}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">heel is off the floor when patient stands</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Knee too forcefully and rapidly flexed after heel strike&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Heel wedge too stiff}}<br></div><div>{{c2::foot too far posterior}}<br></div><div>{{c3::foot too dorsiflexed}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Soften heel}}<br></div><div>{{c2::move foot anterior}}<br></div><div>{{c3::plantar flex foot}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">high pressure against anterodistal tibia at heel strike, and/or prolonged discomfort at this point</span><div><img src=""paste-13a52220a76a05e4aad4b4068d5815c3ff0ab362.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div>Observed in sagittal plane – knee
seems to buckle, shoulder seems to drop, push off through toe is
weak/insufficient </div>
<div><br></div><div><u>Solutions:</u>&nbsp;</div>
<div>Stiffen forefoot</div><div>change foot to appropriate weight category&nbsp;</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-23 at 10.02.04 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div>Hips level, but prosthesis ""seems short<font color=""#333333"">""</font><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Foot too far posterior}}<br></div><div></div><div>{{c2::foot too dorsiflexed}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Move foot anterior}}</div><div>{{c2::plantar flex foot}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"feels that way to the patient i guess??<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-23 at 10.02.25 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial <u>Amputee</u></b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">""Drop-off"" at end of stance phase</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Foot too far posterior}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Move foot anterior}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"Drop Off = Heel off&nbsp;<em>occurs too early causing early knee flexion</em><div><i><br></i></div><div><i>""seems same as excessive knee flexion/dorsiflexion/stiff heel/platar flexion weakness""</i></div><div><i>diagram: move foot anterior = move socket posterior&nbsp;<br></i><div><img src=""paste-13a52220a76a05e4aad4b4068d5815c3ff0ab362.jpg""><em><br></em></div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-23 at 10.02.25 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-22 at 9.27.15 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Valgus moment at knee (knock-knee) during stance phase</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Foot too outset}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Adducted socket}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Inset foot}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div>{{c2::Abduction of the socket}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-c4f21628cd20c792f189ee1ddd2e5aecbb0550c1.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c577f3b13e5f0d10b88f3510164d62cb2a360838.jpg""><br></div><div><div>Observed in coronal plane from front</div>
<div></div>
<div><br></div><div><u>Solutions: </u></div>
<div><font color=""#8ad0d6"">I</font>nset
foot compared to socket</div>
<div>Align
toe break to reduce out-toeing during all stance phases</div>
Add
ply socks or replace socket to improve fit (control)<br></div><div><br></div><div>Patient may complain of pain/pressure on proximal-lateral or distal-medial aspect of residual limb.</div><div><img src=""nihms510487f2a.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">varus moment at knee (bow-legged) during stance phase&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cause</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Mediolateral dimension of socket too large}}<br></div><div>{{c2::foot too inset}}<br></div><div>{{c3::Abducted socket}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>solution</u></span></div><div>{{c1::socket fit optimized}}<br></div><div>{{c2::outset foot}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div>{{c3::Adduction of the socket}}<br></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(a varus moment at the knee should occur in stance phase but should never be excessive)</span><br></div><img src=""paste-da70eda93cd37c67efc27341ead368fe3fef5a43.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-a04df2b21d3402adcb815c2a6846ce556ab7e32c.jpg""><br></div><div><div>Observed in coronal plane from
front</div>
<div><br></div>
<div><u>Solutions:&nbsp; </u></div>
<div>Outset foot</div>
<div>Align foot toe break to reduce in-toeing at all stance </div>
<div>Add ply socks or replace socket to improve fit (control)&nbsp;</div></div><div><img src=""nihms510487f2a.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transtibial Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Pistoning</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div><u>Solutions:</u></div>
<div>{{c1::improve socket fit}}</div><div>{{c2::improve suspension}}&nbsp;</div></div>"	"<div>Improve socket fit with thicker liner; adding ply socks; adding flexible inner liner; reducing moisture/perspiration; or replacing socket<br></div><img src=""paste-ba552410eea591f695bc819b88d64da43fe8665f.jpg"">"																				
"E<span style=""font-style: italic;"">xcessive varus moment (bow leg) during stance phase/excessive lateral thrust of the socket brim</span>:<div><br></div><div>amputee may complain of pain/pressure on {{c1::proximal}} {{c1::medial}} and {{c2::distal}} {{c3::lateral}} aspect of residual limb</div>"	"<img src=""paste-ecff17bcead5a5a5f56dd867bea21fb18486145a.jpg""><img src=""paste-4fd274b7b2f1f97b8026e78ee5fbb128dbe46204.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Transtibial Amputee Gait Deviations</b></span><br><div><br></div><div>Excessive toe out&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Solutions: </u></div>

shortened stance time, knee may be laterally thrust at initial contact and then
medially thrust at toe off&nbsp;</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lateral bending of trunk (generally to prosthetic side)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>prosthetic causes</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Prosthesis too short}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::High medial wall}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Prosthesis aligned in abduction}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-a857a860f60e3dca36a603ee2039b55285582bb3.jpg""><div><div>High medial wall may cause amputee to lean away to minimize discomfort</div><div>Prosthesis aligned in abduction (may cause wide-based gait)</div></div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Solutions:
</u></div>
<div>Build relief over painful areas</div>
<div>Lengthen pylon</div>
<div>Consider ISCHIAL CONTAINMENT for better purchase on short limb</div></div><div><img src=""nihms510487f2a.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Abducted gait: (Very wide-based gait)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>prosthetic causes</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Prosthesis too long}}</div><div>{{c2::Too much prosthesis abduction}}</div><div>{{c3::High medial socket wall}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Improperly shaped lateral}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<img src=""paste-2b95b37e49cb7f9e8c3dab49a178e38c2bbe2798.jpg""><div><div><u>Solutions:</u></div>
<div>Lower medial brim/shelf</div>
<div>Widen socket medially to capture ischium or adduction roll (muffin top)</div>
<div>Shorten a long prosthesis</div>
<div>PT to reduce abduction contracture</div></div><div><img src=""paste-dc998949c4d4599e4ebdbd8b5708f5df6f4d5abf.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""nihms510487f2a.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Circumducted gait (Prosthesis swings laterally)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>prosthetic causes</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Prosthesis too long}}</div><div>{{c2::Inadequate suspension}}</div><div>{{c3::too much friction in knee}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-6506dbf7b1bc86a97f5cb9a4f20a6272e1348d1d.jpg""><div><div><u>Solutions: </u></div>
<div>Lower medial brim/shelf</div>
<div>Address inadvertently-long prosthetic components </div>
<div>PT to reduce abduction contracture</div></div><div><img src=""paste-cfa4697e8a41a6b299e8e531c92fbf1e65a114e4.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</b></span><div><font color=""#333333""><b><br></b></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Vaulting (Rising on toe of sound foot)&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>prosthetic causes</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Prosthesis too long}}</div><div>{{c2::Socket suspension may be inadequate}}</div><div>{{c3::limitation of knee flexion}}</div></div><div>{{c3::excessive plantar flexion}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">permits amputee to swing prosthesis through with little knee flexion</span><div><img src=""transfemoral-gait-deviations-12-2048.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div><u>Solutions: </u></div>
<div>Address an inadvertently-long prosthesis</div>
<div>Ensure adequate suspension</div>
<div>PT for gait mechanics</div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</b></span><div><font color=""#333333""><b><br></b></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Medial or lateral whips: (aka oscillation of shin)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>prosthetic causes</u></span></div><div>Lateral whips may result from excessive {{c1::internal rotation of prosthetic knee}}</div><div>Medial whips may result from excessive {{c1::external rotation of knee}}</div><div>{{c2::Improper donning of socket}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Socket fit too tightly}}</div><div>{{c3::Badly aligned toe break}}</div></div>"	"<img src=""paste-0b9f15f1ab2da141fef4ba9de39c1c759a30f016.jpg""><div><div><u>Solutions:</u>&nbsp; </div>
<div>Ensure
proper donning alignment of socket on limb</div>
<div>Assess
prosthetic foot alignment</div></div><div><img src=""paste-057c6a934ef8ef88db421ea7b57fff90c79d80dd.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</b></span><div><font color=""#333333""><b><br></b></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Foot rotation at heel strike (foot rotates laterally, sometimes with vibrating motion)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>prosthetic causes</u></span></div><div>{{c1::too hard heel cushion}}</div></div><div>{{c1::too hard plantar flexion bumper}}<br></div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-ce8744e9104283e5604af2c9abbd2e6c053ac7d4.jpg""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-22 at 8.40.35 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</b></span><div><font color=""#333333""><b><br></b></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Foot slap (plantar flexes too rapidly)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>prosthetic causes</u></span></div></div><div>{{c1::Plantar flexion bumper too soft}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div>{{c1::soft heel cusion}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-22 at 8.46.18 PM.png"">"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Uneven heel rise (Prosthetic heel rises markedly and rapidly when knee is flexed at beginning of swing phase)</span><div><br></div><div><u>prosthetic problem</u></div><div>{{c1::Knee joint w/ insufficient friction}}</div><div>{{c2::Extension aid is inadequate}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-5c210b9f723b5403b1d6bf2454cdcb0cd0534d22.jpg""><div><div><u>Solutions:</u></div>
<div>Dial
up knee friction</div>
<div>Upgrade
to K3
(variable cadence) knee</div></div>"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">terminal swing impact (Rapid forward movement of shin piece allows knee to reach maximum force before heel strike)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>prosthetic problem</u></div><div>{{c1::Knee friction insufficient}}</div><div>{{c2::Knee extension aid too strong}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-577967965eb2d6eb36726f6452d25d38bf394e84.jpg"">"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral or Transtibial Amputee</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Uneven step length</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>prosthetic problem</u></div><div>{{c2::Insufficient knee/socket flexion}}</div><div>{{c3::too loose an extension aid}}</div><div>excessive plantar flexion</div><div><br></div><div><u>patient problem</u></div><div>{{c1::Pain or insecurity (transfer weight quickly prosthesis)}}</div><div>{{c1::Hip flexion contracture}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The length of the step taken with the prosthesis differs from that of the sound leg</span><div><img src=""paste-b66b4856b534bb66e6ec0e6618a285815bfd0508.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Exaggerated lordosis</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>prosthetic problem</u></div><div>{{c1::Insufficient socket flexion}}</div><div>{{c2::Insufficient support from anterior socket brim}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">lumbar lordosis is exaggerated when the prosthesis is in stance phase, and the trunk may lean posteriorly</span><div><img src=""paste-080e1112f47832db939ce77da68b21732a3efa16.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div><u>Solutions: </u></div>
<div>Hip
flexion built into socket usually &gt; 5 degrees; more for pre-existing flexion
contractures</div>
<div>PT to
improve hip extension</div></div><div><img src=""nihms510487f2a.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gait Analysis of the Transfemoral Amputee</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">hip hiking</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>prosthetic problem</u></div><div>{{c1::prosthesis too long}}</div><div>{{c1::excessive plantar flexion}}</div><div>{{c1::poor suspension}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-22 at 9.06.20 PM.png"">"																				
<b>Incisional Pain in the Amputee Patient</b><div><u><br></u></div><div><div>Remember that not all residual limb pain is a result of a problem within the amputation site.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>Consider the Ddx</u></div><div>{{c1::poorly fitting prosthesis}}</div><div>{{c2::continued claudication}}</div></div><div>{{c3::radicular pain}}</div><div>{{c4::neuroma}}</div>	can add from the thommen book																				
"<b>PHANTOM LIMB PAIN</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::50}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::85}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of amputees experience some phantom limb pain</span></div><div><br></div><div>considered a significant long-term problem in <u>&lt;</u> {{c2::5}}% of amputees</div><div><br></div><div>If pain persists &gt;{{c3::6}} months, prognosis for spontaneous recovery is poor</div>"	Recent data does not suggest a predisposition for phantom limb pain among traumatic amputees, elderly amputees, or those with pain in the amputated limb before amputation<div><br></div><div>There appears to be no correlation between phantom pain and amount of time after amputation or use of prosthesis.<div><br></div><div><div>Dr. Thommen, if they were insensate from peripheral neuropathy before amutation they are unlikely to experience phantom pain</div></div></div>																				
<b>Insufficient push-off</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>cause</b></div><div>{{c1::Gastroc-soleus weakness}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Achilles tendon rupture}}<br></div><div>{{c2::metatarsalgia}}<br></div><div>{{c2::hallux rigidus}}<b><br></b></div>																					
"<b>Excessive medial femur rotation</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>cause</u></div><div>{{c1::Tight medial hamstrings}}<br></div><div>{{c2::anteverted femoral shaft}}<u><br></u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">weakness of opposite muscle group</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Excessive lateral femur rotation</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>cause</u></div><div>{{c1::Tight lateral hamstrings}}<br></div><div>{{c2::retroverted femoral shaft}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">weakness of opposite muscle group</span><u><br></u></div>"																					
"<div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Transtibial Amputee</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Knee too forcefully and <u>rapidly flexed</u> after heel strike</span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">high pressure&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and/or prolonged discomfort&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">against&nbsp;</span>{{c1::anterodistal tibia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<img src=""paste-13a52220a76a05e4aad4b4068d5815c3ff0ab362.jpg"">"																				
<div>prosthetic knees that can not be used for bilateral AKA's&nbsp;</div><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::Stance-control knee (safety)}}<b>&nbsp;</b></div><div>{{c1::Manual Locking Knee}}<br></div>	the knees won't be able to unlock																				
<b>SOCKETS FOR TRANSRADIAL AMPUTATIONS</b><div><br></div><div>Proximally, the socket extends posteriorly to the {{c1::olecranon}} and anteriorly to the {{c1::elbow crease}}</div>	"The shorter the residual limb, the closer is the trim line to the crease<div><img src=""paste-f2369fd24ca38168477a7281ebcb3f0559699035.jpg""><br><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/51737372/figure/fig13/AS:669692331040771@1536678502171/39-The-standard-components-of-a-BE-prosthesis-The-components-are-a-O-ring-of-the.png""><br></div></div>"																				
<b>Trans-radial Amputation Prostheses Components</b><div><br></div><div><u>amputee with a body-powered prosthesis will also need the following:</u></div><div>{{c4::Harness and control system}}<br></div><div>{{c3::Upper arm cuff/pad}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Elbow hinge}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Socket}}<br></div><div>terminal devices and wrist units<br></div>	"<div><div><img src=""paste-ef5c5a5fb58e6980555d1aa2719f5a8942dd3993.jpg""><br><div><img src=""paste-f2369fd24ca38168477a7281ebcb3f0559699035.jpg""><br></div></div></div>"																				
"<div><strong>Split socket</strong>: (trans-radial)</div><div><br></div><div>consists of a total-contact segment encasing the residual limb&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>that is connected by hinges to a separate&nbsp;{{c1::forearm shell}} to which the TD's are attached</div><div><br></div><div>used in&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">patients who have&nbsp;</span>{{c2::very short residual limbs}}<span style=""font-style: italic;"">&nbsp;</span>or to incorporate {{c3::an elbow-lock mechanism}} in the prosthesis</div>"	"<div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">so</span>&nbsp;that the special elbow hinges can be used to increase available joint&nbsp;ROM<br></div><img src=""paste-189ff91d10e068291f95b453a7f53939bf134354.jpg""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-25 at 3.52.57 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Muenster socket</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">An alternative to the split socket (for short transradial amputees) is the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::self-suspended}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;socket design</span><strong><br></strong></div>"	"<img src=""paste-ed1d375a570a08c9a96654cf2a81e2fcbd2c2098.jpg""><img src=""paste-3e1b17afb253307d5a786c7565f7a4a3e4996591.jpg"">"																				
"<div><strong>Muenster socket&nbsp;</strong></div><div><br></div><div>&nbsp;the sockets high trim lines enclose the olecranon and the epicondyle of the humerus&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>there is some limitation in ROM, that&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">is compensated by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::preflexing}}<span style=""font-style: italic;"">&nbsp;the socket</span></div><div><br></div><div>When this type of suspension is used, a {{c2::figure-9 harness}} can be used for control purposes only</div><div><br></div><div>the reduction in {{c3::force requirements (operate the&nbsp;TD)}} and the ease of use more than compensate for ROM limitation</div>"	"<img src=""paste-ed1d375a570a08c9a96654cf2a81e2fcbd2c2098.jpg""><img src=""paste-3e1b17afb253307d5a786c7565f7a4a3e4996591.jpg"">"																				
<b>ELBOW HINGES</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Flexible elbow hinge:</u></div><div>Used where sufficient {{c1::voluntary pronation and supination}} are available to make it desirable to maintain these functions&nbsp;</div>	"Wrist disarticulations and long transradial amputations are common<div><img src=""paste-45ea131df43efe67b0aa4b63c17b6adad4ec2eae.jpg""><img src=""paste-8862eb719c03f9e279b48b793b52e1e9451518d8.jpg""><br><div><img src=""paste-629dea14f9b03a1b6a6bfb59805440ef0b6a1e34.jpg""></div></div>"																				
<b>ELBOW HINGES</b><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>Rigid elbow hinge:</u></div><div><br></div><div>Used in short transradial amputations when normal elbow flexion is present but there is {{c1::no voluntary pronation-supination}}&nbsp;</div>	"<br><div><img src=""paste-45ea131df43efe67b0aa4b63c17b6adad4ec2eae.jpg""><img src=""paste-8862eb719c03f9e279b48b793b52e1e9451518d8.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-25 at 3.49.01 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Rigid elbow hinge:</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Types:</u></div><div>{{c1::Single axis}}</div><div>{{c2::Polycentric}}</div><div>{{c3::Step-up design}}</div>	"Step-up design: used with split-socket prosthesis, in very short transradial amputation where flexion is limited. By virtue of a gear or double-pivot arrangement, these hinges permit the residual limb to drive the prosthetic forearm through an increased&nbsp;ROM. Disadvantage is that it takes twice the force (energy cost doubles) to provide the same amount of flexion as a single-axis hinge joint.<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-25 at 3.49.01 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-25 at 3.49.56 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<u>transradial amputee</u><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Locking elbow joints</strong>&nbsp;are used only if there is {{c1::significant elbow flexor weakness}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-25 at 3.52.57 PM.png"">"																				
<b>Cuffs and Pads</b><div><br></div><div>used on the upper arm to connect the {{c1::socket}} to the {{c1::harness}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>It also serves as an {{c2::anchor point (for cable-control)}}</div><div><br></div><div>the {{c3::half-cuff}} is used in the majority of <u>short</u> transradial fittings</div><div><br></div><div>the {{c3::triceps pad}} is used with <u>long</u> transradial, wrist disarticulation, and transmetacarpal prostheses</div>	"Except in the Muenster socket, a half-cuff or a triceps pad with an appropriate elbow hinge is used to help furnish socket suspension and stability<div><div><img src=""paste-265082c4c947f7e33b55906dd0eb13be56ea893e.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-603fd55d88c4d73593c94a2ea7facb6abd527698.jpg""><br></div><div>1: leather half-cuff as
used in combination with rigid elbow hinges and a single billet.</div><div>2: hall-cuff with two billets, again
in combination with rigid elbow hinges.&nbsp;</div><div>3: inverted Y-strap made from fabric&nbsp;<br></div></div>"																				
<div><b>{{c1::Figure-8}}&nbsp;aka&nbsp;{{c1::O-ring harness}}</b></div><div><br></div><div>Most commonly used UE amputee harness</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_6.png"">"																				
anterior suspension strap<div><br></div><div>gives additional support for pulling or lifting</div><div><br></div><div>and acts as the attachment point for the {{c1::elbow loading}}&nbsp;strap on a body-powered above-elbow prosthesis</div>	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_6.png""><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Figure-9 harness</strong>:<div><br></div><div>self-suspended transradial socket (e.g., Muenster socket) that requires a harness...</div><div><br></div><div>only for

controlling the {{c1::TD}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Used for long residual limbs with {{c2::suction sockets::equipment}}</div><div><br></div><div>Consists of an {{c3::axilla loop}} and a {{c3::control attachment}} strap</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Pros</span>: It is lighter and provides {{c4::greater freedom (and comfort)}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>by the elimination of the usual front support strap and triceps pad or cuff<br></div><img src=""paste-28e4a06862687a4fea684c57a7725dd9c1761e9c.jpg"">"																				
<div><strong>Chest strap with shoulder saddle&nbsp;</strong></div><div><br></div><div>used if the patient {{c1::cannot tolerate the axilla loop}}</div><div><br></div><div>Also used with those who will {{c2::do heavy lifting}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-282c24f2ebff3387fbb66ffc2b32eed37793fbef.jpg""><img src=""paste-81ffc8ff1d8604aaf4d86f7f17a48e9865ae9716.jpg""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_7.png"">"																				
<strong>single-control cable system</strong>&nbsp;(Bowden cable system)&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>used in the transradial and consists of one cable to transmit body power to operate the&nbsp;{{c2::TD}}</div><div><br></div><div>muscle movements used to operate the terminal device are {{c1::forward humeral flexion}} and {{c1::biscapular abduction}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-a5483fd66d6ca3078a448fc5b7e41da80682b96b.jpg""><br></div>continuous length of flexible housing through which the cable slides<div><br></div><div>fastened by a base plate and retainer to the forearm shell and by a housing crossbar assembly to the cuff of the triceps pad;&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>these housing retainers also serve as reaction points when force is applied to the cable.</div>"																				
"<div><strong>dual-control cable system</strong>&nbsp;(split cable)</div><div><br></div><div>typically used in the transhumeral control cable system as well as in the very short transradial split-socket prosthesis with locking hinge</div><div><br></div><div><u>Consists of one cable with two functions:</u></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""font-style: italic;"">Flex</span>&nbsp;the elbow (when elbow unlocked)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""font-style: italic;"">Operate</span>&nbsp;TD (when elbow locked)}}</div><div><br></div><div>in light of this, {{c2::two fair-lead housings}} are necessary<br></div>"	"<div><a>a cable to control locking and unlocking of the elbow mechanism&nbsp;<strong>(C)</strong>,&nbsp;</a></div><div><a>a cable that will lift the forearm if the elbow unit is unlocked or operate the terminal device if the elbow unit is locked&nbsp;<strong>(D)</strong>.</a></div><div><img src=""F000308f30-07-9781437719369.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>The cable is held in place and guided by separate lengths of housing.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>The pieces of housing are fastened with retainers at points where the cable must be supported or operated through an angle.</div><div><br></div><div><div>Since the system must provide force for elbow flexion and operation of the terminal device, two fair-lead housings are necessary:</div><div><br></div><div>The proximal lead, through which the cable slides when the elbow is flexed</div><div><br></div><div>The distal lead, through which the cable slides when the terminal device is operated</div></div>"																				
"<div><strong>dual-control cable system</strong>&nbsp;(split cable)</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Elbow locking and unlocking</span>&nbsp;are controlled by a second cable, the elbow-lock cable.</div><div><br></div><div><u>action preformed</u></div><div>resulting movement</div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>{{c2::humeral flexion}}&nbsp;and&nbsp;{{c2::biscapular abduction}}</u></div><div>{{c1::flexing the elbow (to desired level)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::operate the terminal device}}<span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div><u>{{c3::Shoulder depression}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span>{{c3::extension}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and&nbsp;</span>{{c3::abduction (down, back, out)}}</u><br></div><div>{{c1::lock the elbow}}<br></div><div>{{c1::unlock the elbow}}</div>"	"<img src=""F000308f30-07-9781437719369.jpg""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-29 at 2.27.07 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>SOCKETS FOR TRANSHUMERAL AMPUTATIONS</b><div><br></div><div>lateral socket wall extends to the {{c1::acromion}} and the medial socket wall is flattened below the {{c1::axilla}}&nbsp;<br></div>	"<div>to help <u>prevent inadvertent socket rotation</u>.<br></div><div><div><br></div><div>As in transradial prostheses, the transhumeral socket is usually of <u>double-wall</u> construction</div><div><br></div><div>with the inner wall providing a snug, total-contact fit and the outer shell providing appropriate length and shape</div></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-030-60746-3_4/MediaObjects/449682_1_En_4_Fig3_HTML.jpg""><br></div>"
