"<b>ELBOW UNITS (transhumeral amputee)</b><div><br></div><div>Elbow-locking systems are divided into two types:</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>1. {{c2::<span style=""font-style: italic;"">External (outside) locking elbow</span>:}}&nbsp;</u></div><div>Used with {{c1::transhumerals (and disarticulations)&nbsp;::same}} when {{c1::extending &lt;4cm from epicondyles::#}}</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>2. {{c2::<span style=""font-style: italic;"">Internal locking elbow</span>:}}&nbsp;</u></div><div>Used with {{c1::transhumeral::same}} when {{c1::extending &gt;4cm proximal from epicondyles::#}}, and shoulder prostheses</div><div><br></div><div>Preferred because of greater {{c3::mechanical durability}} and {{c4::cosmetically appeal}}</div>"	"<div><div>External hinge – AE or BE, bulkier</div></div><div><img src=""paste-e51f6643040cafb58c4b8b9e34fa6d3bf0a594b5.jpg""><br></div><div><div>Internal hinge – trans humeral &gt;
4cm above elbow</div></div><img src=""paste-8f5effe67c3e5a84056c14c3c6ec83f3b955d236.jpg""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-25 at 3.52.22 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">harness designs&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most frequently used for <u>transhumeral</u> prostheses</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">are modifications of the basic&nbsp;</span>{{c1::figure-8}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::chest strap}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;patterns used with transradial prostheses</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-81ffc8ff1d8604aaf4d86f7f17a48e9865ae9716.jpg""><img src=""paste-722fb55866e722377bf34b92f3b1e3b701cca9a5.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-16 at 10.13.23 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-16 at 10.13.05 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Myoelectric Control Systems</b><div><b><br></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>below-elbow amputees</u></span></div><div>{{c1::wrist extensors}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;= open the terminal device</span></div><div>{{c1::wrist flexors}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;= close the terminal device</span></div><div><br></div><div><u>above-elbow amputee</u></div><div>{{c3::biceps muscle}} = flex the elbow and close the terminal device&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::triceps muscle}} = extend the elbow and open the terminal device</div><div><br></div><div>can change back and forth between the terminal device and the elbow control by {{c2::co-contracting (biceps and triceps)}}&nbsp;</div></div>"	"electrical signal produced by voluntary activation of the residual muscles is detected by surface electrodes in the socket<div><img src=""paste-d86babecc3e4507c9ac33392688d6946a1b6f381.jpg""></div>"																				
<b>Myoelectric System</b><div><br></div><div>With short transhumeral or shoulder amputation, {{c1::shoulder girdle muscles}} are used to control elbow and TD function</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Hybrid control}} can reduce the cost, weight, and harnessing of the prosthesis</div><div><br></div><div>{{c3::Electric switches}} can also be incorporated into the harness or socket if myoelectric control is not available</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(34, 34, 34);""><b>Targeted Muscle Reinnervation (TMR)</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(34, 34, 34);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(34, 34, 34);"">reinnervation of the major brachial nerves – musculocutaneous, median, radial (colored green) –&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(34, 34, 34);"">into distinct regions of the pectoralis major muscles of the chest (colored red).&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(34, 34, 34);"">Upon reinnervation, electrodes (colored blue) are used to relay information detected in the chest muscles to the prosthetic arm,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(34, 34, 34);"">which then translates the electrical impulses into movement.</span><br></div><img src=""ProstheticArm.png"">"																				
<b>elbow units</b><div><br></div><div>amputees who have difficulty flexing their prosthetic forearm, may use a {{c1::spring assist}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>passive humeral rotation is accomplished by means of a {{c2::turntable}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c3::friction}} permits control of rotation to maintain the desired plane of elbow operation</div>	"<img src=""B00230_C07286PK_C11381PK-Automatic-Elbow.jpg""><div><span style=""color: rgb(78, 78, 78); background-color: rgb(247, 248, 249);"">Flexion can be locked in 8 distinct positions, with a free swing position, using an anterior actuator that can be operated manually or by means of a harness.</span><br><br><span style=""color: rgb(78, 78, 78); background-color: rgb(247, 248, 249);"">Humeral rotation is available and can be controlled with an adjustable friction screw. The rotation can also be manually locked using a rotatable ring</span><br></div>"																				
"<b>BODY-POWERED VERSUS MYOELECTRIC SYSTEMS</b>&nbsp;<div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u><strong>Body-powered devices</strong>:</u></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Advantages</span>: Less expensive, {{c2::lighter}}, more durable, easier to repair, {{c3::higher sensory feedback}}</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Disadvantages</span>: {{c1::Mechanical appearance}}, difficult to use for some people, dependent on motor strength</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u><strong>Myoelectric devices</strong>:</u></div><div>Advantages: {{c1::Better cosmesis}}, less harnessing, {{c3::stronger grasp force}}</div><div>Disadvantages: More expensive, {{c2::heavier}}, decreased durability, need for daily recharging of batteries</div>"																					
<strong>Preprosthetic training UE amputee</strong><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Forearm rotation}} and {{c1::humeral rotation}} are the motions most seriously affected</div><div><br></div><div>Testing and strengthening muscles in the residual limb may be helpful for future myoelectric control</div>	"<span style=""font-style: italic;"">Preprosthetic training includes:</span><div><br></div><div>residual limb shrinkage, muscle strength and&nbsp;ROM, desensitization, scar mobilization,&nbsp;ADL&nbsp;assessment, and HEP<div><br></div><div><div>Transhumeral amputations: 80% have limitations of humeral rotation</div><div><br></div><div>Transradial amputations: 80% have limitations of forearm rotation</div><div><br></div><div>If bony malformations limit&nbsp;ROM, <u>PT will be of no help</u></div></div></div>"																				
<strong>Vocational issues UE amputee</strong><div><br></div><div>greatest occupational effect on {{c1::skilled / semiskilled}} laborers who are unable to continue their original occupations</div><div><br></div><div>a source of emotional maladjustment and of reduction in earning power</div>	prosthetic team should serve in an <u>advisory capacity</u> on any contemplated change in occupation&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>because the patient may be <u>able to return</u> to his job with the prosthesis</div><div><br></div><div><div>the TD is extremely important to the amputee’s vocational success.</div></div>																				
<b>TRANSRADIAL AMPUTEE TRAINING</b><div><br></div><div>Once the patient has learned basic use of the prosthesis, they begin training purposeful activity</div><div><br></div><div>Before attempting any activity, {{c1::prepositioning}} of the TD is essential&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Prehension}} is the final phase of control training before practice in daily activities is started</div>	Control training may be considered complete when the patient has maximal control of the terminal device in space																				
<b>GLENOHUMERAL JOINT</b><div><br></div><div>Arm abduction is achieved through glenohumeral and {{c1::scapulothoracic}} joint motion</div>																					
<b>GLENOHUMERAL JOINT</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::2}} degrees of <u>glenohumeral</u> motion for every {{c1::1}} degree of <u>scapulothoracic</u> motion during arm abduction</div><div><br></div><div>there is a maximum {{c1::120}} degrees of glenohumeral motion to {{c1::60}} degrees of scapulothoracic motion</div>	"scapulothoracic motion allows the glenoid to rotate and permits glenohumeral abduction without acromial impingement<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_1.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>LABRUM</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Fibrocartilaginous tissue surrounding the glenoid fossa</div><div><br></div><div>Serves as an attachment site for: {{c3::biceps long head}}, {{c1::glenohumeral ligaments}}, and the {{c1::shoulder capsule}}</div><div><br></div><div>Prevents {{c2::anterior}} and {{c2::posterior}} humeral head dislocation</div>	"Approximately <u>30%</u> of the humeral head articulates with the glenoid fossa<div><br><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span></div><div>Deepens the glenoid fossa and increases overall contact of the humeral head with the glenoid by <u>70%</u><br></div><div><img src=""f15-01-9780323549479.jpg""></div><div><img src=""187e61_6a82a1aea3de49fb9b8c2d1d3003d226~mv2_d_2536_1902_s_2.jpeg""><br></div>"																				
<b>GLENOHUMERAL LIGAMENTS</b><div><br></div><div>arise from folds of the {{c1::joint capsule}} and attaches to the {{c1::glenoid}}</div><div><br></div><div>located on the {{c2::anterior}} aspect of the humeral head</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u><strong>Superior</strong>&nbsp;glenohumeral ligament</u></div><div>Prevents translation in the {{c3::inferior}} direction</div><div><br></div><div><u><b>Middle</b> glenohumeral ligament</u></div><div>Prevents {{c3::anterior}} shoulder translation</div><div><br></div><div><u><b>Inferior</b> glenohumeral ligament</u></div><div>primary {{c3::anterior}} ligament stabilizer</div>	"Sup/ middle: provides stability of the shoulder from 0 degrees to 90 degrees of abduction<div>Inf: above 90 degrees</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_9.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>DYNAMIC STABILIZERS (shoulder)</b></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Rotator cuff muscles::category}}: surround the humeral head and help approximate it into glenoid fossa</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Long head of the biceps tendon::m}}, deltoid, and {{c2::teres major::m}}, latissimus dorsi</div><div><br></div><div>as well as {{c1::scapular stabilizers::category}}</div>	<div><u>S.I.T.S.</u>&nbsp;<br></div><div><div>Supraspinatus</div><div>Infraspinatus</div><div>Teres minor</div><div>Subscapularis</div></div><div><br></div><div><div>Scapular stabilizers: (e.g., trapezius, serratus anterior) play a supporting role in stabilizing the&nbsp;GHJ&nbsp;during shoulder range of motion (ROM)</div></div>																				
<div><b>STATIC STABILIZERS (shoulder)</b></div><div><br></div><div>include the glenoid, the {{c1::labrum}}, the {{c1::shoulder capsule}}, and the {{c1::glenohumeral ligaments}}</div>	"<img src=""B9781437709223000101_f01-11-9781437709223.jpg"">"																				
"<strong>coracoclavicular (CC) ligament</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is made up of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::conoid}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::trapezoid}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">connects the coracoid process to the clavicle and anchors the clavicle to the coracoid process, preventing vertical translation of the clavicle</span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_12.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rockwood Classification of&nbsp;</span>AC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Joint (Shoulder) Separations</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>{{c2::Type 1}}</u><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">AC ligament:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sprained}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">CC ligament:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::intact}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_1/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_1_Fig1_HTML.gif""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_13.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-01 at 9.19.34 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rockwood Classification of&nbsp;</span>AC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Joint (Shoulder) Separations</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>{{c2::Type 2}}</u><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">AC ligament:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::complete tear}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">CC ligament:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sprained}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_1/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_1_Fig1_HTML.gif""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_13.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-01 at 9.19.34 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rockwood Classification of&nbsp;</span>AC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Joint (Shoulder) Separations</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>{{c1::Type 3}}</u><br></div><div><u><br></u></div><div>AC ligament: {{c2::complete tear}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>CC ligament: {{c2::ruptured}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_1/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_1_Fig1_HTML.gif""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_13.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-01 at 9.19.34 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rockwood Classification of&nbsp;</span>AC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Joint (Shoulder) Separations</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Type 4</u><br></div><div><u><br></u></div><div>AC and CC ligament: complete rupture</div><div><br></div><div>Clavicle: {{c1::displaced posteriorly (through trapezius)}}</div><div><br></div><div>appearance on physical exam: {{c2::skin tenting}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_1/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_1_Fig1_HTML.gif""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_13.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-01 at 9.19.34 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rockwood Classification of&nbsp;</span>AC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Joint (Shoulder) Separations</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Type 5</u><br></div><div><u><br></u></div><div>AC and CC ligament: complete rupture</div><div><br></div><div>Clavicle: {{c1::displaced superior and posteriorly (100% compared to contra.)::2}}</div><div><br></div><div>physical exam: {{c2::shoulder droop}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_1/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_1_Fig1_HTML.gif""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_13.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-01 at 9.19.34 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rockwood Classification of&nbsp;</span>AC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Joint (Shoulder) Separations</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Type 6</u><br></div><div><u><br></u></div><div>AC and CC ligament: complete rupture</div><div><br></div><div>Clavicle: {{c1::displaced inferior (to coracoid process)}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_1/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_1_Fig1_HTML.gif""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_13.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-01 at 9.19.34 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>PROVOCATIVE TEST FOR&nbsp;AC&nbsp;JOINT IMPINGEMENT</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cross-chest (or scarf)}} test: Passive adduction of the arm across the midline causing joint tenderness</div>	"Cross-chest (horizontal adduction or scarf)<div><img src=""Cross-Body-Adduction-Test-3.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>AC joint injuries</b><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Weighted (10 lb) anterior–posterior (AP) radiographs::image modality}} of the shoulder</div><div><br></div><div>Type III injuries may show a {{c2::25% -100::#-#}}% widening of the&nbsp;CC&nbsp;space.</div><div><br></div><div>Type V injuries may show a widening &gt;{{c2::100}}%.</div>"	"pt is holding a weight in there affected hand<div><img src=""ace9514a6c713dcc601eac85d5f03f_gallery.jpeg""><img src=""paste-6403aef1482c3f1823d79c6d90b9294c00c73ade.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-030-06240-8_1/MediaObjects/476781_1_En_1_Fig4_HTML.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Acute AC Joint Injury, Conservative Treatment&nbsp;</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Types I and II</span>:</u></div><div>Rest, ice, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</div><div>Avoid heavy lifting and contact sports</div><div>Shoulder–girdle complex stabilization and strengthening</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Sling for comfort (for the first 1 to 2 weeks)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Return to play: When the patient is asymptomatic with full&nbsp;ROM</div><div>Type I: {{c2::2}} weeks</div><div>Type II: {{c3::6}} weeks</div>"																					
<b>ACUTE&nbsp;AC&nbsp;JOINT INJURIES</b><div><br></div><div><u>Type III:</u></div><div>{{c1::Surgery (heavy laborers, athletes)::tx}}</div>	<div><b>Treatment is controversial</b>. Conservative or surgical route depends on the patient’s need (occupation or sport) for particular shoulder stability.</div><div><br></div><div>Surgical for those indicated (heavy laborers, athletes)</div><div><br></div><div>Generally, no functional advantage is seen between the two treatment regimens</div>																				
<b>ACUTE&nbsp;AC&nbsp;JOINT INJURIES</b><div><br></div><div><u>Type&nbsp;{{c3::IV, V, and VI}}:</u></div><div>{{c1::ORIF::tx}}</div><div>{{c2::distal clavicular resection::tx}} with {{c2::reconstruction of the&nbsp;CC&nbsp;lig::tx}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>historically it was thought acute injuries were treated with ORIF and chronic injuries were treated with CC ligment reconstruction</div><div><br></div><div>however, new studies have shown no difference in outcomes in types III injuries treated surgically after 6 weeks non-op treatment versus immediate surgery</div><img src=""cc screw pic.jpg"">orif w/ CC screw&nbsp;<img src=""hook plate.jpg"">orif w AC plate<div>CC ligament reconstruction with coracoacromial (CA) ligament (Modified Weaver-Dunn)</div><div>(not as strong)<br><div><img src=""weaverdunn_large.gif""><br></div><div><br></div></div>"																				
<div><b>CHRONIC&nbsp;AC&nbsp;JOINT INJURIES/PAIN</b></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Corticosteroid injection::tx}}</div>	"May require a clavicular resection and&nbsp;CC&nbsp;reconstruction<div><img src=""Screen-Shot-2018-12-04-at-8.34.54-AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen-Shot-2017-09-27-at-18.50.02-e1512076250337.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><img src=""Screen-Shot-2017-11-30-at-21.13.07-e1543933403907.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-18 at 9.32.23 AM.png""><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Needle position: Insert the needle in-plane from lateral to
medial aiming at the lateral margin of the clavicle.</div><div>- The subacromial space is approxi-
mately 4 mm below the capsule, so the needle should be
carefully placed to avoid puncturing the deep capsule and
entering the subacromial space.</div>
<div>Pearls:</div><div>- Direct the needle parallel to the probe, as the joint lies</div>
<div>relatively superficial.</div><div>- Immediately after successful injection, the capsule may
</div>
<div>appear elevated and the joint space wider.</div><div>- A gel standoff technique may be used to allow more room
</div>
<div>for the needle approach.&nbsp;<br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<u>COMPLICATIONS OF&nbsp;AC&nbsp;JOINT INJURIES</u><div>{{c1::clavicular fractures}}</div><div>{{c2::Distal clavicle osteolysis}}</div><div>{{c2::AC&nbsp;joint arthritis}}<br></div>	"<div>Associated clavicular fractures and dislocations</div><div><br></div><div>Distal clavicle osteolysis: Degeneration of the distal clavicle with associated osteopenia and cystic changes</div><div><br></div><div>AC&nbsp;joint arthritis: May get relief from a corticosteroid injection and conservative rehabilitative care</div><div><img src=""10.-AC-Joint-Arthritis-1_-1.jpg""><img src=""ac-joint-oa.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Instability}}:<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;translation of the humeral head with respect to the glenoid fossa</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It may result in subluxation or dislocation</span><div><img src=""360_F_240733258_kDZZaa8vWvXGjtJTg7HF7ilOEGYRwGkX.webp""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"{{c1::Subluxation}}:<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;incomplete separation of the humeral head from the glenoid fossa with immediate reduction</span>"	"<img src=""360_F_240733258_kDZZaa8vWvXGjtJTg7HF7ilOEGYRwGkX.webp"">"																				
"{{c1::Dislocation}}<strong>:&nbsp;</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">complete separation of the humeral head from the glenoid fossa without immediate reduction</span>"	"<img src=""360_F_240733258_kDZZaa8vWvXGjtJTg7HF7ilOEGYRwGkX.webp"">"																				
"<b>DIRECTION OF INSTABILITY</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>Anterior glenohumeral instability:</u></div><div>{{c1::most::frequency}} common&nbsp;</div><div>Often seen in the {{c2::younger population}} preforming frequent {{c2::overhead activities}}</div><div>Mechanism: Arm {{c3::abduction}} and {{c3::external rotation}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Posterior glenohumeral instability:</u></div><div>{{c1::less::frequency}} common&nbsp;</div><div>May be seen following {{c2::a seizure}}</div><div>Mechanism: Landing on a {{c4::forward flexed}} and {{c4::adducted arm}}</div>"	"<img src=""shoulder-dislocation-FI-size-1.jpg""><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">results from trauma, such as shoulder dislocation,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">or repetitive
microtrauma associated with overhead activity,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">and it can
occur without trauma in individuals with generalized ligamentous laxity&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
"<div><div><div><strong>TUBS&nbsp;(<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch04#bid_4_54"">Rockwood et al., 1996</a>)</strong></div><div><strong>T</strong>— {{c1::Traumatic shoulder instability}}</div><div><strong>U</strong>— {{c1::Unidirectional}}</div><div><strong>B</strong>— {{c1::Bankart lesion}}</div><div><strong>S</strong>— {{c1::Surgical management}}</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""B9781437709223000113_f02-01-9781437709223.jpg""><div><img src=""B9781437709223000113_f02-02-9781437709223.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><strong>AMBRI&nbsp;(<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch04#bid_4_54"">Rockwood et al., 1996</a>)</strong></div><div><strong>A</strong>— {{c1::Atraumatic shoulder instability}}</div><div><strong>M</strong>— {{c1::Multidirectional instability}}</div><div><strong>B</strong>— {{c1::Bilateral lesions}}</div><div><strong>R</strong>— {{c1::Rehabilitation management}}</div><div><strong>I</strong>— {{c1::Inferior capsular shift, if surgery}}</div>"	"<img src=""B9781437709223000113_f02-01-9781437709223.jpg""><div><img src=""B9781437709223000113_f02-02-9781437709223.jpg""></div>"																				
<b>{{c1::Bankart lesion}}:</b> <u>{{c4::Labral tear off the anterior glenoid}}</u><div><br></div><div>Most commonly associated with {{c2::anterior instability::clinical sign}}</div><div><br></div><div>May also be associated with an {{c3::avulsion fracture}} of the {{c3::glenoid rim}}</div>	"<div>allows the humeral head to slip anteriorly<br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_14.png"">"																				
<div><b>{{c1::Hill–Sachs lesion}}:</b> {{c2::Compression fracture}} of the {{c3::postero-lateral humeral head}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>caused by abutment against the anterior rim of the glenoid fossa</div><div><br></div><div>Associated with {{c4::anterior dislocations}}</div><div><br></div><div>A lesion that accounts for &gt;{{c5::30}}% of the articular surface may cause instability</div>	"A notch occurs on the posterior lateral aspect of the humeral head<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_15.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>GHJ&nbsp;Instability</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Dead arm syndrome:</u></div><div>Symptoms include {{c1::early shoulder fatigue}}, pain, numbness, and paresthesias</div><div>Shoulder {{c2::slipping in and out of place}} most commonly in the {{c3::throwing (abduction and external rotation)}} position</div>	Typically seen in athletes such as pitchers or volleyball players who require repetitive overhead arm motion																				
"<strong>Laxity exam</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Ask the patient to touch the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::thumb}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;against the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::volar forearm}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Patients with lax tissues are more likely than others to be able to voluntarily dislocate the shoulder (AMBRI)</span></div>"	"<img src=""P-hypermobility-415x233-rd9-esIL.png""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Some patients are double jointed, which is a lay term for capsular laxity</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">can also use shoulder hyper abduction test (gady's)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">this is also part of the beighton score (ellers danlos, hypermobility)</span></div>"																				
<strong>Apprehension test</strong>:<div><br></div><div>A feeling of anterior {{c1::shoulder instability}} with 90-degree shoulder {{c1::abduction}} and {{c1::external rotation}}</div><div><br></div><div>caveat, test is NOT positive if the patient {{c2::experiences&nbsp;pain alone}}</div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div>causing apprehension (fear of dislocation) in the patient<br></div><div><br></div><div>highly accurate: if positive anterior instability is assured&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 10.42.46 PM.png""><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Patient: 1. </span>Lies on table, with arm
hanging off edge. <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">2. </span>Shoulder is
abducted to 90°, elbow flexed to 90°,
and shoulder maximally externally
rotated.
</div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Examiner: </span>Further externally rotates shoulder by applying posteriorly directed force on the distal forearm with one hand and anterior force on the proximal arm.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Positive test: </span>Reproduces the patient’s pain, or gives the patient
the “apprehension” of reproduction of their pain or the feeling
that their shoulder will dislocate or “pop out of the socket.”
</div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Consistent with: </span>Anterior shoulder laxity or instability.&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<strong>Relocation test</strong>:<div><br></div><div>Supine apprehension test with a {{c1::posterior-directed}} force applied to the {{c1::anterior aspect}} of the shoulder</div><div><br></div><div>This force relieves the feeling of apprehension</div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 10.45.59 PM.png""><span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Patient: 1. </span>Lies on table, with half of
arm hanging off edge. <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">2. </span>Shoulder is
abducted to 90°, elbow flexed to 90°,
and shoulder maximally externally
rotated (same as the Surprise test).
</div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Examiner: 1. </span>Stabilize patient’s arm
by holding the wrist. <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">2. </span>With the palm
of the hand, direct a posterior force to
the glenohumeral joint.
</div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Positive test: </span>Pain and/or sense of shoulder instability decreases
or the range of motion increases.
</div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Consistent with: </span>Anterior shoulder laxity or instability&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
{{c1::Anterior drawer}}<strong>&nbsp;</strong>test:<div><br></div><div>Passive anterior displacement of the humeral head on the glenoid confirms {{c2::anterior instability::diagnosis}}</div>	"<div>similar to load and shift, will use the hawkins scale&nbsp;</div><img src=""Anterior-Drawer-of-the-Shoulder-2.jpg""><div><img src=""9781604065237_c005_f016.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Anterior load-and-shift::phys-ex}}<strong>&nbsp;test</strong>:<div><br></div><div>positive test: the {{c2::humeral head}} is {{c2::subluxed over the glenoid rim}} and this reproduces there sx's<br><div><img src=""264DA14D591A52180C.png""><br></div></div>"	"<div><div>Essentially a modified form of the anterior drawer test, also graded on hawkins scale</div><div><br></div><div>Humeral head is loaded against the glenoid and then passively displaced anteriorly</div></div><img src=""Load-and-Shift-2.jpg"">"																				
"{{c1::Jerk::phys-ex}}<strong>&nbsp;</strong>test: assess for&nbsp;{{c2::Posterior GHJ instability}}<strong>&nbsp;</strong><br><div><img src=""paste-2a6639f8cc178aac4e3ad2db452cf6e68714897a.png""><br></div>"	Place the arm in 90 degrees of flexion and maximum internal rotation with the elbow flexed 90 degrees.&nbsp;<div>Adduct the arm across the body in the horizontal plane while pushing the humerus in a posterior direction.&nbsp;</div><div>The patient will jerk away when the arm nears midline to prevent posterior subluxation or dislocation of the humeral head.</div>																				
<div><strong>sulcus sign</strong>: If an indentation develops between the acromion and the humeral head, the test is positive.</div><div><br></div><div>examiner {{c1::pulls down on the patient’s arm}} with one hand&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and {{c1::stabilizes the scapula}} with the other</div><div><br></div><div>This suggests increased {{c3::multidirectional (inferior)}} laxity in the GH joint<br></div>	"<div><font color=""#0000aa"">No tests have evaluated the Sn or Sp of the sulcus sign for inferior instability&nbsp;</font></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_17.png"">"																				
<b>GLENOHUMERAL INSTABILITY</b><div><br></div><div><u>X-ray films views</u></div><div>{{c1::AP}}</div><div>{{c1::scapular-Y}}</div><div>{{c1::axillary lateral}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""scapular y technique_moved.jpg""><div><img src=""C5-FF14-7.gif""><img src=""scapular y.jpg""><br><div><img src=""axillary lateral technique_moved.jpg""><br></div></div>"																				
<b>GLENOHUMERAL INSTABILITY</b><div><br></div><div><u>Other X-ray views:</u></div><div>{{c1::West Point}} view: {{c2::Bankart}} lesions</div><div>{{c1::Stryker notch}} view: {{c2::Hill–Sachs}} lesions</div>	"<div><img src=""westpoint xr technique_moved.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""stryker notch imaging techniques_moved.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>Treatment Traumatic GHJ Instability (TUBS)</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Surgical</span>:</u></div><div><br></div><div>should be considered if rehabilitation fails, and in active individuals, particularly with a history of a {{c2::labral tear}}</div><div><br></div><div>After a {{c1::3rd}} dislocation, the risk for another approaches 100%.&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><b><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Conservative</span>:</b><br></div><div><u>Sling</u> immobilization: Length of time is variable.</div><div>Rehabilitation:&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;and strengthening of the shoulder–girdle complex should follow the brief stage of immobilization.</div><div>Passive range of motion (PROM) with <u>Codman’s pendulum</u> exercises</div><div><u>Isometric</u> exercises early in the recovery course</div>"																				
"<b>TREATMENT POSTERIOR GLENOHUMERAL INSTABILITY</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Conservative</span>:</u></div><div>{{c1::Immobilize}} in {{c1::neutral position}} for roughly 3 weeks</div><div>Strengthening the {{c2::posterior shoulder–scapula::2 categories}}<font color=""#fc0010"" style=""""><b>*</b></font> musculature is imperative, up to 6 months</div><div><br></div><div><u>Surgical:</u></div><div>In the event of a failed rehabilitation program, a posterior {{c3::capsulorrhaphy}}<b><font color=""#fc0010"">^</font></b> is the surgical procedure of choice&nbsp;</div>"	"Rehabilitation generally is adequate for the majority of these patients.<div><br></div><div><b><font color=""#fc0010"">*</font></b>(infraspinatus, posterior deltoid, teres minor, trapezius, serratus anterior)<br></div><div><br></div><div><b><font color=""#fc0010"">^</font></b><a href=""https://player.understand.com/shoulderelbowdoc/en/87527a46-1c59-4576-a311-85e4fb88ed1e/577a1ad8-6324-448b-a817-dc38f55fbc72"">capsulorrhaphy</a>:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(30, 71, 102); background-color: rgb(254, 254, 254);"">surgical procedure that repairs and tightens the shoulder capsule by tightening the ligaments and capsule</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(30, 71, 102); background-color: rgb(254, 254, 254);"">(arthroscope) repaired using a construct of small stitches, which then anchored down to the rim of the glenoid</span><br></div><div><img src=""1-s2.0-S1058274600826300-gr4.jpg""><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-08 at 4.18.45 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(30, 71, 102); background-color: rgb(254, 254, 254);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/13845282/figure/fig1/AS:954447911981056@1604569523171/Medially-based-T-for-the-capsular-shift-1-3-oclock-position-capsular-flap.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(30, 71, 102); background-color: rgb(254, 254, 254);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>TREATMENT MULTIDIRECTIONAL GLENOHUMERAL INSTABILITY (AMBRI)</b><div><br></div><div>&gt;{{c1::80}}% of the patients obtain excellent results with rehabilitation</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Educating}} patients should be a part of the treatment program</div><div><br></div><div>if necessary surgery conservative measures fail, {{c3::inferior capsular shift}} may be indicated</div>	"<div><div>Educating patients to avoid voluntarily dislocating the shoulder and to avoid positions of known instability should be a part of the treatment program</div><div><br></div></div>Surgical treatment may be an option only when conservative measures fail. At that time, an inferior capsular shift may be indicated<div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/366070784/figure/fig1/AS:11431281105474756@1670417067201/llustration-of-open-inferior-capsular-shift-procedure-A-Capsular-incision-is.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Glenoid Labral Tears&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div>may be accompanied by {{c1::rotator cuff}} or {{c1::biceps tendon}} pathology</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Repetitive overhead}} activity or traumas are causative factors</div>	"Tendons (rotator cuff and biceps) insert on the labrum<div><br></div><div>ie overhead sports (baseball, volleyball)<br></div><div><img src=""superior-labral-tear-or-slap-tear.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Glenoid Labral Tears</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u><div><br></div><div>similar to that of {{c3::shoulder instability::pathology}}: {{c1::clicking}}, {{c1::locking}}<b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b>, and pain</div><div><br></div><div><u>PROVOCATIVE TESTS</u></div><div>{{c2::Load-and-shift}} test</div><div>{{c2::O’Brien’s}} test</div></div><div>{{c4::Dynamic shear::my approach: malanga}} test<b><font color=""#fc0006"">^</font></b></div>"	"<div><strong><font color=""#fc0006"">*falacy:</font> in reality clicking is rare and locking is almost unheard of</strong></div><div><b><font color=""#fc0006"">^&nbsp;</font></b><strong>time saver: can do seated anterior apprehenison test in this position</strong></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Phys-ex tests of labral tear are very unreliable</u></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Load-and-shift test</strong>:</div><div>The examiner grasps the humeral head and pushes it into the glenoid while applying an anterior and posterior force. A positive test indicates labrum instability and is displayed by excess translation.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>O’Brien’s test</strong>:</div><div>Used to detect SLAP lesions</div><div>It is performed in two parts: With the arm internally rotated, forward flexed, and adducted about 15 degrees, the examiner applies a downward force to the patient’s pronated arm initially. Then the examiner applies a downward force to the patient’s supinated arm.</div><div>A positive test results in deep shoulder pain that improves when the downward force is applied with hand in supination.</div><div><img src=""cFo7PKZX3rO2DzxFu9QdkQ.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-15 at 7.40.46 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-15 at 7.37.00 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>{{c1::O’Brien’s}} test:</b></div><div><br></div><div>Used to detect {{c2::SLAP lesions}}<b><font color=""#084fff"">*</font></b></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-04 at 11.32.55 AM.png""><br></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><font color=""#084fff""><b>* </b></font>in reality it has higher Sn and Sp for AC joint injury&nbsp;</div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>Active Compression (O’Brien’s) Test
</u></div><div><u><br></u></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Patient: </span>Positions upper limb with
shoulder flexed to 90°, horizontally
adducted to 15°, and maximally inter-nally rotated and elbow fully extended.
</div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Examiner: 1. </span>Apply a downward force to
the distal forearm against maximal
resistance of the patient.&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">2. </span>The above is
<font color=""#fc0006"">repeated with shoulder externally
rotated</font>. (<font color=""#084fff"">releives the pain</font>)</div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Positive test: </span>Pain or audible click at the acromioclavicular joint
or at the glenohumeral joint.
</div><div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Consistent with: </span>Acromioclavicular joint dysfunction if pain in
AC joint, or superior labral anterior posterior (SLAP) pathology
if pain at the glenohumeral joint.&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-04 at 11.34.19 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<strong>Impingement syndrome</strong>:<div><br><div><div>A {{c1::narrowing}} of the {{c1::subacromial space}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>causing compression and inflammation of the {{c1::subacromial bursa}}, {{c2::biceps tendon}}, and {{c2::rotator cuff}}</div></div></div>	"<strong>Most likely the most common cause of shoulder pain</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div>RC most often involving the supraspinatus tendon<strong><br></strong></div><div><img src=""shoulder-impingement-illustration-showing-234236613.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><strong>Impingement syndrome</strong>:<br></div><div><div><br></div><div>most commonly affects the {{c1::supraspinatus}} tendon,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>under the acromion and the greater tuberosity occurs with arm {{c2::abduction}} and {{c2::internal}} rotation</div></div>	"<img src=""shoulder-impingement-illustration-showing-234236613.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Impingement syndrome can lead to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::chronic tendinopathy}} or<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::rotator cuff tear}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""Cuff+Pain-min-640w.jpeg"">"																				
"<strong>Stages of subacromial impingement syndrome (<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch04#bid_4_207"">Neer, 1972</a>)</strong>:<div><br></div><div>Stage 1: {{c1::Edema (hemorrhage) and inflammation::2}} — reversible (age &lt;25)</div><div>Stage 2: {{c2::Fibrosis and tendonitis::2}} (ages 25–40)</div><div>Stage 3:&nbsp;{{c3::AC&nbsp;spur and rotator cuff tear::2}}&nbsp;(age &gt;40)</div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-03 at 2.29.09 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_33/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_33_Fig1_HTML.gif""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rotator cuff tears occur primarily in the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::supraspinatus}}<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;tendon</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">especially at the critical zone of hypovascularity about&nbsp;</span>{{c2::1 cm}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;from the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::insertion site}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">weakened as a result of many factors, including injury and chronic impingement</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Poor blood supply to the tendon also makes it prone to injury</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""shoulder_rotator_cuff_intro01.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div><b>Acromion morphology types:</b></div><div><br></div><div>Type I → {{c1::Flat}}</div><div>Type II → {{c1::Curved}}</div><div>Type III → {{c1::Hooked}}</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_20.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Patients with a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::curved (2)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hooked (3)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;acromion morphology have a higher risk of rotator cuff tears</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_20.png"">"																				
"RC tears&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">rarely affect people younger than&nbsp;</span>{{c1::40}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;years old</span>"																					
<b>provocative&nbsp;impingement tests</b><div>{{c1::Painful arc sign}}<br><div>{{c2::Neer’s impingement sign}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Hawkins’ impingement sign}}</div></div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_21.png""><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_22.png"">"																				
<div><strong>Painful arc sign</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>Abducting the arm, with pain occurring roughly between {{c1::60}} degrees and {{c1::120}} degrees</div><div><br></div><div>pain beyond this angle may be indicative of {{c2::ac joint}} pathology</div>	"<img src=""painful-arc-1024x676.jpg"">"																				
"<b>Impingement/Rotator Cuff tear</b><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Plain films (AP)<div></div></div><div><div>{{c1::Supraspinatus}} Aka&nbsp;{{c1::""shoulder outlet""}}&nbsp;view = Assess {{c2::acromion morphology (1, 2, 3)}}</div></div>"	"(15 degrees caudal tilt for a transcapular “Y” view): i think cucurrulo wrong on this one attempting to show accromion view<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_23.png""><br></div><div><div><div><span style=""font-weight: bold;"">FIGURE 5.13 Outlet view.</span>&nbsp;This projection shows the | same anatomic structures as demonstrated on the Y view of the shoulder girdle. In addition, coracoacromial arch and space occupied by the rotator cuff are well imaged. S<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">houlder&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">outlet</span><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;view. This projection is </span><font color=""#095cff""><b>obtained similarly to the <u>Y view</u></b></font><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""> of the shoulder girdle; however, the central beam is directed toward the superior aspect of the humeral head and is </span><font color=""#095cff""><b>angled approximately 10 to 15 degrees caudad</b></font></div></div><div><a><img src=""C5-FF14-6.gif""></a><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""></span><div><span style=""font-weight: bold;"">FIGURE 5.14 Types of the acromion.</span>&nbsp;On the outlet view of the shoulder, three morphologic types of acromion are well demonstrated. (<span style=""font-weight: bold;"">A</span>) Type I (flat). (<span style=""font-weight: bold;"">B</span>) Type II (curved). (<span style=""font-weight: bold;"">C</span>) Type III (hooked). Recently reported a very rare Type IV (convex undersurface) is not shown here.</div></div><div><a><img src=""C5-FF12-6.gif""></a></div></div><div>per ortho bullets (looks same as a scapular Y lateral view to me)</div><div><img src=""supraspinatous outlet view_moved.jpg""><br></div><div>shoulder outlet&nbsp; (per radiopedia)</div><div><div>The&nbsp;<strong>outlet&nbsp;</strong>or<strong>&nbsp;Neers projection&nbsp;</strong>of the shoulder is a specialized projection demonstrating the coracoacromial arch often utilized in the investigation of shoulder impingement. seen in orthopedic clinics and closely resembles a lateral scapular projection but incorporates a 10-15 degree caudal angulation of the tube.</div><img src=""8a79935ef60436da39a8dd100402ff_big_gallery.jpeg""><br></div><div>impingement&nbsp;</div><div><a><img src=""C5-FF13-6.gif""></a></div>"																				
<b>Chronic Rotator Cuff Tear</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>X-ray Imaging Findings</u></div><div>{{c1::Superior migration}} of the humerus</div><div>{{c2::Flattening}} of the {{c2::greater tuberosity}}</div><div>{{c3::Subacromial sclerosis}}</div><div>{{c4::cysts}} in the greater tuberosity (chronic)&nbsp;</div>	"Impingement: Typically normal<div><img src=""a18cb1_43088c82d75649e5a3e41be8f2d62d57~mv2.png""><br></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs00256-019-03251-8/MediaObjects/256_2019_3251_Fig1_HTML.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""RDI-3-154-g001.gif""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::MRI}}&nbsp;is the gold standard to evaluate the integrity of the <u>rotator cuff</u>, but...<div><br></div><div>an&nbsp;{{c1::MRI&nbsp;arthrogram}} with {{c1::Gadolinium}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;may </span>be indicated in those who are suspected to have a <u>labral tear</u></div>"	"labral tear may not be seen on a routine shoulder&nbsp;MRI<div><img src=""mri-of-torn-rotater-cuff1.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-12 at 8.16.49 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A, </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Normal shoulder magnetic resonance image.
The supraspinatus tendon is uniformly low signal and continuous
</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(arrows)</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">. The space between the humeral head and the acromion </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(a)
</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">is maintained.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">B, </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Chronic rotator cuff tear. The supraspinatus tendon
is completely torn and retracted to the level of the glenohumeral
joint </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(arrow), </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">where it is surrounded by fluid. Note the high-riding
humeral head, close to the acromion. This is due to the atrophy of
the cuff muscles associated with chronic tendon tears.&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""B9781416034278500118_gr21.jpg""><br></div><div><a>MRI with gadolinium identifies disruption of the anterior glenoid labrum (<em>arrow</em>).</a><br></div><div><a><img src=""B9781416034278500118_gr20.jpg""><br></a></div><div><a></a><a>Posterior labral detachment demonstrated on an axial MRI with intra-articular gadolinium (<em>arrow</em>).</a><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Ultrasound (US) RC tear</b>: Full thickness tears may be indicated by&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::discontinuity}} of or {{c2::heterogeneous}} appearing tendon</div>	"<div>and interposition of the subacromial bursa or deltoid into the vacant tendon.</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-18 at 9.48.40 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""8f514fa920dfabf46aed3b65701683_big_gallery.jpg""><br></div><div>NORMAL supraspinatus&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-18 at 9.51.31 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""font-style: italic;""><b>CONSERVATIVE TREATMENT:</b>&nbsp;</span><b>IMPINGEMENT, CHRONIC PARTIAL, AND FULL RC TEARS</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>{{c1::Acute}}&nbsp;</u><u>phase</u><u>&nbsp;(up to 4 weeks)</u></div><div>{{c2::Relative rest}}</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>{{c3::Recovery}}&nbsp;phase (months)</u></div><div>{{c4::Full pain-free&nbsp;ROM}}</div><div>{{c4::Improve stabilizers}}&nbsp;</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>{{c5::Functional}}&nbsp;phase</u></div><div>Perform {{c6::activity-specific}} training</div>"	"<div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Conservative treatment</span>&nbsp;(<span style=""font-style: italic;"">Rehabilitation</span>):</u></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Acute phase (up to 4 weeks)</strong></div><div>-Relative rest: Avoid any activity that aggravates the symptoms.</div><div>-Reduce pain and inflammation.</div><div>-Modalities: US, iontophoresis</div><div>-Reestablish nonpainful and scapulohumeral&nbsp;ROM.</div><div>-Retard muscle atrophy of the entire upper extremity.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Recovery phase (months)</strong></div><div>-Improve upper extremity&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;and proprioception.</div><div>-Full pain-free&nbsp;ROM</div><div>-Improve rotator cuff (supraspinatus) and scapular stabilizers (rhomboids, levator scapulae, trapezius, serratus anterior).</div><div>-Assess single planes of motion in activity-related exercises.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Functional phase</strong></div><div>-Continue strengthening, increasing power and endurance (plyometrics).</div><div>-Perform activity-specific training.</div><div>-Rehabilitation in swimmers focuses on strengthening the rotator cuff muscles and scapular stabilizers, including serratus anterior and lower -trapezius.Corticosteroid injection: Only up to three injections yearly (may weaken the collagen tissue, leading to more microtrauma</div>"																				
<b>RC TEAR SURGICAL TREATMENT: ACUTE, ACUTE ON CHRONIC PARTIAL, AND FULL TEARS</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Indications (RC tear confirmed on MRI)</u></div><div><br></div><div>tears with {{c1::significant loss of function}} or {{c3::intractable pain}}</div><div><br></div><div>partial or full thickness tears with {{c1::preserved function}} that {{c1::fail conservative treatment}}</div><div><br></div><div>patient should be made aware that {{c2::restoration of abduction}} is less predictable than {{c2::relief of pain}}</div>	"<div><font color=""#fc0006"">if they do not have <u>significant loss of function or intractable pain</u>&nbsp;it is okay to do 6 weeks of therapy</font>&nbsp;</div><div>- inject while you wait for MRI, then decide. close follow up to see if they progress</div><div>- Chronic RC tears are always managed with PT first</div><u>Reduction of pain</u> is the primary indication for surgical repair in chronic rotator cuff tears<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-25 at 10.13.51 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Surgical Treatment: Impingement, Chronic Partial, And Full RC tears&nbsp;</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>Partial tears&nbsp;(&lt;40% thickness) Procedure:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Partial anterior {{c1::acromioplasty and coraco-acromial ligament lysis (aCaLL)}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Partial tears&nbsp;(&gt; 40% thickness)&nbsp;Procedure:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Repair rotator cuff tendon}}</div>"	"<img src=""5.-Subacromial-Decompression-and-Acromioplasty-1.png""><div><img src=""paste-92d674829aa4e2eae27c8a55c6cf07c520408d08.jpg""><img src=""paste-7b734a4dc855236b1542ee8926f50f8171d3074c.jpg""><div><div><b><u>Operative (ORTHO BULLETS)</u></b></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">subacromial decompression and rotator cuff debridement alone</strong></div><div>indications</div><div>- select patients with a low-grade partial articular sided rotator cuff tear&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong><br></strong></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong>rotator cuff repair (arthroscopic or mini-open)</strong></span></div><div>indications</div><div>- acute full-thickness tears&nbsp;</div><div>- bursal-sided tears &gt;3 mm (&gt;25%) in depth&nbsp;</div><div>- partial articular-side tears &gt;50% can be treated with tear completion and repair&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/evidence/30335631""><i></i></a>&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>- younger patients with acute, traumatic tears</div><div>- older patients with degenerative tears</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-01 at 11.51.41 AM.png""><br></div></div></div>"																				
"<div><b>Acute rotator cuff tears&nbsp;(<span style=""font-style: italic;"">i.e., athletes/trauma</span>)</b></div><div><br></div><div>Statistics showed that surgical repair within the first {{c1::3}} weeks&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>resulted in {{c2::significantly better::similar/better}} overall function than later reconstruction</div>"	"Once atrophy and <u>fat replacement</u> occurs there is little use in reattachment&nbsp;<div><img src=""paste-22aeea5611842cbb2f0851e4b5bb2990748f9b20.jpg""><br></div><div>3 grades of supraspinatus atrophy associated RC tear&nbsp;<br></div>"																				
<b>Impingement snydrome, Partial, or Full thickness RC tear</b><div><br></div><div>Corticosteroid injection: Only up to {{c1::3}} injections should be preformed yearly&nbsp;</div>	may <u>weaken the collagen</u> tissue, leading to more microtrauma																				
<b>Degenerative Joint Disease of the Shoulder</b><div><br></div><div>Arthritis may occur at the glenohumeral or&nbsp;AC&nbsp;joint.</div><div><br></div><div>may result from: {{c1::post-traumatic lesions}}, {{c1::chronic rotator cuff}} pathology, Lyme disease, and more.</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_24.png"">"																				
<b>Degenerative Joint Disease of the Shoulder</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div><br></div><div>pain and {{c1::limitations&nbsp;on active / passive&nbsp;ROM}}, which lead to impairment of activities of daily living (ADLs)</div><div><br></div><div>Pain more common in {{c2::internal}} rotation of the shoulder but may also be seen with abduction</div>	<div>Manual muscle testing (MMT) may or may not be affected depending on the severity of the disease.</div><div><br></div><div>Pain may be nocturnal and relieved by rest.</div><div><br></div><div>Tenderness felt on palpation on the anterior and posterior aspects of the shoulder.</div>																				
"<b>Degenerative Joint Disease of the Shoulder</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>X-ray Imaging</u><b><br></b></div><div>1. AP&nbsp;view:&nbsp;</div><div>- {{c1::internal rotation}}</div><div>- {{c1::external rotation}}</div><div>2. {{c2::True AP (40 degrees of obliquity)}} aka&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(61, 61, 61);"">Grashey view&nbsp;</span></div><div>3. {{c3::Axillary}} view</div>"	"<div><div><u>Changes seen on x-ray include</u></div><div>Irregular joint surfaces</div><div>Joint space narrowing (cartilage destruction)</div><div>Subacromial sclerosis</div><div>Osteophyte changes</div><div>Flattened glenoid</div><div>Cystic changes in the humeral head</div></div><div><img src=""true ap shoulder techniques_moved.jpg""><img src=""axillary lateral technique_moved.jpg""><br></div><img src=""shoulder image ap er.jpg""><img src=""shoulder imaging ap ir.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Degenerative joint disease of the shoulder</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Conservative Treatment</u></div><div>ROM</div><div>{{c1::RC strengthening}}<u><br></u></div><div>NSAID</div><div>{{c2::GHJ corticosteroid injection}}</div>"	"Goal is to decrease pain and inflammation<div>GHJ injection (injectate onto the articular cartilage of the humeral head)<br></div><div><img src=""430px-GHJ_injection_under_US.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-08 at 4.35.56 PM.png""></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Doppler
can be checked to visualize the suprascapular artery in the
spinoglenoid notch.
</div>
<div>Needle position: directed subcapsular
and contacts the humeral head</div>
<div>drive the needle directly
toward the humeral head. a steeper
approach may be necessary with likely 3.5 or spinal needle</div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""Screenshot-2022-11-30-at-2.27.04-PM.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Precautions status post-TSA </b>(<strong>Total shoulder arthroplasty)</strong></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Stage 1:</u></div><div><div>No {{c1::external rotation}} &gt;{{c1::15}} degrees<br></div><div>{{c2::nonweight bearing (NWB)}} with {{c2::Sling immobilization}}</div></div><div>can do {{c5::isometrics}}</div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>0 to 3 weeks</u><strong>&nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>No {{c3::active&nbsp;ROM}} especially {{c3::abduction}} and {{c3::extension (&gt;0 degrees)}}</div><div>may begin {{c4::PROM (pendulum etc.)}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Stage 1: 3 to 6 weeks</u><br></div><div>may begin {{c4::begin active ROM (including abduction (AAROM (wall walks to AROM))}}</div>	"<img src=""diagram-total-shoulder-arthroplasty.jpg""><div><img src=""Anatomic+reverse+total+shoulder+replacement.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Precautions status post-TSA&nbsp;</b>(<strong>Total shoulder arthroplasty)</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Stage 2: 6 to 12 weeks</u></div><div>Precautions: Discontinue use of {{c1::sling}}</div><div>start {{c1::light weights (&lt;2lbs)}}</div><div>Treatment: may begin {{c2::Isotonic}} exercises</div><div>may now start {{c3::active external rotation::ROM}}</div>	"isotonic = concentric and eccentric<div><img src=""diagram-total-shoulder-arthroplasty.jpg""><div><img src=""Anatomic+reverse+total+shoulder+replacement.png""></div></div>"																				
<b>Precautions status post-TSA&nbsp;</b>(<strong>Total shoulder arthroplasty)</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Stage 3: &gt;12 weeks</u></div><div>Precautions: Previous&nbsp;{{c2::ROM}}&nbsp;precautions cancelled</div><div>Treatment: Start {{c1::progressive resistive exercises}}, active ranging, stretching</div><div>Lifelong restriction against {{c3::lifting &gt; 20lbs}} (as sx's dictate)</div>	"<div><font color=""#fc0006"">Most patients DO NOT regain
full/normal ROM ultimately</font></div><div><img src=""diagram-total-shoulder-arthroplasty.jpg""><div><img src=""Anatomic+reverse+total+shoulder+replacement.png""></div></div>"																				
<strong>Shoulder arthrodesis</strong><div><div><br></div><div><u>Indications</u></div><div>Severe shoulder pain secondary to osteoarthritis (OA)</div><div>Joint infection<br></div><div>{{c1::Mechanical loosening of a shoulder arthroplasty}}</div></div>	"<div>Surgical resection and fusion of the&nbsp;GHJ</div><div><br></div><div>Typical patient is a young heavy laborer with repetitive trauma to the shoulder</div><div><img src=""image-45fad7f3865c41d1d35dc1414630871f94325661.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><div>INTRODUCTION</div><div><span style=""background-color: rgb(224, 234, 251);"">-</span>The goal of shoulder arthrodesis is&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">to provide a stable base</span>&nbsp;for the upper extremity optimizing hand and elbow function</div><div>- it remains an important treatment option in appropriately selected patients</div><div><br></div><div><u>Indications</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">stabilization of paralytic disorders</span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>brachial plexus palsy</div><div>irreparable deltoid and rotator cuff deficiency with arthropathy</div><div>salvage of a failed total shoulder arthroplasty</div><div>reconstruction after tumor resection</div><div>painful ankylosis after chronic infection</div><div>recurrent shoulder instability which has failed previous repair attempts</div><div>paralytic disorders in infancy</div></div>"																				
<strong>Shoulder arthrodesis</strong><div><div><br></div><div><u>Fusion position</u></div><div>{{c1::30}}-degree forward flexion<br></div><div>{{c1::50}}-degree internal rotation</div></div><div>{{c1::50}}-degree abduction<br></div>	"<div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Yunus-Imren/publication/221748114/figure/fig3/AS:667827405074451@1536233869878/Shoulder-movements-of-a-patient-who-underwent-arthrodesis-for-sequela-of-poliomyelitis.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Calcific tendonitis of the supraspinatus tendon</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Symptoms can improve with {{c1::subacromial injection}} and physical therapy</div><div>US-guided percutaneous {{c2::needling}}, {{c2::aspiration}}, and {{c2::saline lavage}} of the lesion has been performed with success</div>"	"Size of the deposit has NO correlation to symptoms<div><br></div><div>Sharp pain in the shoulder with&nbsp;ROM, particularly with shoulder abduction and overhead activities</div><div><br><div>AP&nbsp;x-ray of the shoulder will show calcium deposits, usually at the tendon insertion site</div><div><br><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span></div><div>Surgical treatment is rare and reserved for patients with severe pain and inability to perform&nbsp;ADLs&nbsp;who have failed more conservative treatments<br></div></div><div><img src=""shoulder_calcific_intro01.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""calcific-tendinitis.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>adhesive capsulitis:&nbsp;</b></span>{{c1::Synovial}} tissue of the capsule and bursa become adherent"	"<u>General</u><div>Painful shoulder with restricted glenohumeral motion</div><div>Contracture of the shoulder joint</div><div>Unclear etiology may be autoimmune, trauma, inflammatory.</div><div>More common in women over the age of 40 years</div><div><br></div><div><u>Associated with a variety of conditions:</u></div><div>Intracranial lesions: Cerebral vascular accidents (CVAs), hemorrhage, and brain tumor</div><div>Clinical depression</div><div>Shoulder–hand syndrome</div><div>Parkinson’s disease</div><div>Iatrogenic disorders (prolonged immobilization)</div><div>Cervical disc disease</div><div>Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM)</div><div>Hypothyroidism</div><div><img src=""273d49568cf84c2c99e32fedfa6ce76f.aspx""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Adhesive Capsulitis</b></div><div><br></div><u>STAGES</u><div>{{c1::Painful}} stage: Progressive vague pain lasting roughly 8 months</div><div>{{c1::Stiffening}} stage: Decreasing&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;lasting roughly 8 months</div><div>{{c1::Thawing stage}}: Increasing&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;with decrease of shoulder pain</div>	"<div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/352537203/figure/fig3/AS:1036278531387392@1624079463492/Chart-shows-the-clinical-presentation-of-frozen-shoulder-Icons-with-facial-expressions.png""><br></div><br>"																				
<b>Adhesive Capsulitis Imaging&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Plain films (AP&nbsp;view)</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>typically normal but indicated to rule out underlying {{c1::tumor}}, {{c6::calcium deposit}} or {{c5::severe OA}}</div><div>Indicated in patients whose pain and motion do not improve after {{c2::3}} months of treatment</div><div>Osteopenia may be seen; otherwise normal.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Shoulder&nbsp;MRI:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>demonstrates {{c3::thickened capsule}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Shoulder arthrogram:</u></div><div>will demonstrate {{c4::decreased joint volume}}</div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-02 at 8.22.34 PM.png""><img src=""shoulder-hydrodilatation-left-02.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Adhesive Capsulitis</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>strongly encouraged {{c5::supervised PT (for ROM)}}</div><div>{{c1::Sub-acromial injection}} and {{c1::gleno-humeral injection}} can decrease pain to maximize therapy</div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c2::suprascapular nerve blocks}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::joint capsule
hydrodilation}}, need further study</div><div>{{c3::Manipulation under anesthesia}} may be indicated if there is no substantial progress after {{c3::12}} weeks of conservative treatment</div></div></div></div><div>{{c4::Arthroscopic lysis of adhesions}}—usually reserved for patients with&nbsp;IDDM&nbsp;who do not respond to the above</div>"	"<div><b>Conservative:</b></div><div>PT Restoring&nbsp;PROM&nbsp;and&nbsp;AROM</div><div><div>Home program: Stretches in all ranges of motion</div><div>Modalities: US and electrical stimulation</div></div><div>Corticosteroid injection: Subacromial and glenohumeral. Variable efficacy. <font color=""#fc0006"">""AH SM, injection is critical to do early""</font></div><div><br></div><div><b>Operative (ortho bullets)&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgb(252, 0, 6);"">""</span><span style=""color: rgb(252, 0, 6);"">Maenpa, surgeons unlikely to go to OR for this""</span></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">manipulation under anesthesia (MUA)</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>failure to improve with non-operative modalities</div><div><u>contraindications</u></div><div>controversial if done during freezing/inflammatory phase</div><div>diabetics- 50% failure rate</div><div>following rotator cuff or labral repair</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">arthroscopic or open capsular release</strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>after extensive therapy has failed (3 months)</div><div>arthroscopy will spare subscapularis tendon with the advantage of releasing intra-articular and subacromial adhesions</div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs40122-018-0109-6/MediaObjects/40122_2018_109_Fig1_HTML.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Arthroscopic-Capsular-Release.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"																				
<div><b>BICEPS TENDON RUPTURE</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most common site of rupture is at the {{c1::proximal}} end of the {{c1::long head of the biceps tendon}}</div><div><br></div><div>associated with {{c2::rotator cuff tears}} and a chronic history of {{c2::impingement syndrome}}</div>	"Distal rupture is rare, typically occurring in people performing significant physical activities (e.g., bodybuilders, heavy manual workers).<div><br></div><div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div><div>Seen in adults &gt;40 years old with&nbsp;</div><div>Point tenderness in the bicipital groove</div><div>Positive impingement signs if associated with shoulder impingement syndrome</div><div>Sharp pain, audible snap, ecchymosis, and visible bulge (“Popeye muscle”) in the upper arm with tendon rupture</div></div></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_27.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>{{c2::Yergason’s}}</b><strong>&nbsp;test:&nbsp;</strong>determines the stability of the long head of the biceps tendon in the bicipital groove<div><br></div><div>Pain at the {{c1::anterior}} shoulder with flexion of the elbow to 90 degrees, and resisted {{c1::supination}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_29.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Speed’s test: assess for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Biceps tendonitis}}"	"<img src=""paste-7eb5159321a5811b8ac7a6143d3e4a782044833d.jpg"">"																				
<div><b>{{c1::Ludington’s}}</b><strong>&nbsp;test</strong>: assess for {{c2::Biceps rupture}}</div><div><br></div><div>patient’s hands are resting on top of his/her head, the patient is asked to contract and relax the biceps muscles on each side</div>	"<div><div><div><img src=""f13-02-9780323549479.jpg""></div></div>FIG. 13.2<div><div>Ludington’s test is performed by having the patient clasp both hands onto or behind the head, allowing the interlocking fingers to support the arms. This action permits maximum relaxation of the biceps tendon in its resting position. The patient then alternately contracts and relaxes the biceps while the clinician palpates the tendon and muscle. In a complete tear, contraction is not felt on the affected side.</div></div></div>"																				
"<b>Treatment Long Head Biceps Tendonitis:</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Injection of tendon sheath}}<b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b></div>"	"<div><b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b>controversial due to the potential for tendon rupture<br></div><div>""evidence of degeneration on MRI, probably would hold off""&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Conservative treatment is appropriate for <u>most</u> patients</div><div>ROM&nbsp;and strengthening as tolerated, Modalities</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-29 at 12.00.08 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/281339725/figure/fig5/AS:314920160776197@1452094225875/a-Scheme-and-b-ultrasound-image-of-long-head-of-biceps-tendon-sheath-injection-The.png""><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-29 at 11.59.47 AM.png""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Needle position: Insert the needle from lateral to medial
in-plane&nbsp;</div><div>with the probe targeting the biceps tendon sheath</div><div>between the biceps tendon and the transverse
humeral ligament.&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<b>Treatment Proximal Biceps&nbsp;Rupture:</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Biceps tenodesis}} can be considered in younger, active individuals who require heavy lifting</div><div><br></div><div>Some patients may request reattachment of biceps tendon for cosmetic reasons</div>	"<img src=""biceps-tenodesis-handbook-300x208.jpg"">"																				
<b>Treatment Proximal Biceps&nbsp;Rupture:</b><div><br></div><div>Tendon reattachment (tenodesis) {{c1::is not::is/is not}} indicated in most patients</div>	"<img src=""biceps-tenodesis-handbook-300x208.jpg""><div>only for athletes and high demand workers&nbsp;</div>"																				
"<b>Deltoid Strain and Avulsion</b><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>Anterior deltoid injured during {{c1::acceleration}} phase of throwing</div><div>Posterior deltoid injured during {{c1::deceleration}} phase of throwing<div><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>May injure the origin with Grade {{c2::V}}&nbsp;AC&nbsp;joint separations</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png"">&nbsp;<br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>For strains and contusions, ice and {{c3::immobilize}} acutely</div></div></div>"	"<div>Then perform stretching and progressive strengthening exercises</div><div><br></div><div>For complete rupture or avulsion, treatment is surgical reattachment</div><div><br></div><div>MRI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the shoulder can better assess soft tissue pathology in suspected cases of deltoid rupture</span><br></div>"																				
<strong>Medial scapular winging</strong>: (serratus)<div>{{c3::Bench pressing::etiology}} or {{c3::wearing heavy pack straps::etiology}} can impinge the nerve</div><div>Scapula is {{c1::elevated}} and retracted</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Lateral scapular winging</strong>: (trapezius)&nbsp;</div><div>Nerve injury occurs in the {{c3::posterior triangle of the neck::anatomic location}}</div><div>Scapula is {{c1::depressed}} and protracted</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_30.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Scapular fractures</b></span><div><br></div><div>commonly occur in association with {{c1::other serious (visceral) injuries}}</div><div><br></div><div>diagnosis is often {{c2::missed (on initial exam)}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Fracture sites: Glenoid, glenoid rim, coracoid, scapular neck and body, acromion</div>"	"Associated with other significant injuries such as rib fractures, pulmonary contusions, pneumothorax/hemothorax, splenic lac etc.<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_31.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Scapular fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>{{c1::CT scan}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c2::Closed treatment}} for {{c3::nondisplaced}} fragments</div><div>{{c2::ORIF}} for {{c3::Large displaced}} fragments</div></div><div>{{c4::Arm sling}}&nbsp;</div><div>followed by early&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;exercises as tolerated, usually within {{c4::1 to 2}} weeks after injury<br></div>"	"<div>Plain films:&nbsp;AP, lateral scapular-Y, and axillary views<br></div><div><br></div>Note: Patients with isolated scapular body fractures should be considered for <b>hospital admission</b> due to the risk of <b>pulmonary contusion</b>.<div>could order trauma pack to look for other occult fractures. ord CT C/A/P to look for organ injury<br><div><img src=""paste-e1f8a117605c68ac5341578c9f10bbc68141408e.png""><br><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_31.png""><br></div></div></div>"																				
<b>Clavicle Fracture</b><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>AP&nbsp;plain films of the clavicle with inclusion of&nbsp;AC&nbsp;and&nbsp;SC&nbsp;joints</div><div>{{c1::Chest x-ray}} to evaluate for superimposed {{c1::pneumothorax}} complication<br></div>	"<img src=""5.jpg"">"																				
<div><b>clavicular fractures</b><u><br></u></div><u><div><u><br></u></div>Treatment</u><div>Most are {{c1::treated conservatively}}</div>	"<div>standard sling &gt; figure 8. for compliance with use&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Progressive&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;may be initiated after 3 weeks of immobilization<br></div><div><img src=""paste-4def5bf2f8bae82be83b46fe00fd826036114b3b.jpg""><br></div><div><div><b>TREATMENT distal calvicle</b></div><div><br></div><div>Nonoperative</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sling immobilization with gentle ROM exercises at 2-4 weeks and strengthening at 6-10 weeks</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">stable fractures (Neer Type I, III, IV)</span></div><div>pediatric distal clavicle fractures (skeletally immature)</div><div><br></div><div>Operative</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">open reduction internal fixation</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;absolute</div><div>open or impending open fractures</div><div>subclavian artery or vein injury</div><div>floating shoulder (distal clavicle and scapula neck fractures with &gt; 10mm of displacement)</div><div>symptomatic nonunion</div><div><u>relative</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">unstable fracture patterns (Neer Type IIA, IIB, V)</span></div><div>brachial plexus injury (questionable because 66% have spontaneous return)</div><div>closed head injury</div><div>seizure disorder</div><div>polytrauma patient</div><div><br></div><div><b>TREATMENT Mid clavicle&nbsp;</b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">Nonoperative</span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>&lt; 2cm shortening and displacement</div><div>&lt; 1cm displacement of the superior shoulder suspensory complex&nbsp;</div><div>closed and no neurovascular injury</div><div>low demand patient&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>modalities:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sling,&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">figure-of-8 strap</span></div><div>elevate and extend shoulder to bring distal fragment to the proximal fragment</div><div><br></div><div>outcomes&nbsp;</div><div>figure-of-8 associated with more pain, shortening, and lower compliance than sling</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">no difference in functional or cosmetic outcomes between sling and figure-of-eight braces</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">Operative</span>&nbsp;</div><div><u>indications&nbsp;</u>absolute</div><div>open fractures</div><div>displaced fracture with skin tenting&nbsp;</div><div>subclavian artery or vein injury</div><div>floating shoulder (clavicle and scapular neck fracture)</div><div><br></div><div><u>relative and controversial indications</u></div><div>displaced with<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;&gt; 2cm shortening&nbsp;</span></div><div>bilateral displaced clavicle fractures</div><div>brachial plexus injury (questionable because 66% have spontaneous return)</div><div>closed head injury</div><div>seizure disorder</div><div>polytrauma patient</div></div>"
