<b>clavicular fractures</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><u>surgical indications</u></div><div>{{c1::open clavicle fractures}}</div><div>{{c2::grossly displaced}} fracture with {{c2::skin tenting}}</div><div>fractures with significant {{c3::medialization of shoulder girdle}}</div><div>Displaced lateral clavicle fractures &gt;{{c4::1}} cm at the&nbsp;AC&nbsp;joint are best treated surgically<br></div></div>	"<div><img src=""images..jpg"">Rock wood pin<img src=""lateral_clavicle_orif.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>""more common with distal (type) &gt;&nbsp;middle</div><div><br></div><div><b>TREATMENT distal calvicle</b></div><div><br></div><div>Nonoperative</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sling immobilization with gentle ROM exercises at 2-4 weeks and strengthening at 6-10 weeks</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">stable fractures (Neer Type I, III, IV)</span></div><div>pediatric distal clavicle fractures (skeletally immature)</div><div><br></div><div>Operative</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">open reduction internal fixation</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;absolute</div><div>open or impending open fractures</div><div>subclavian artery or vein injury</div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">floating shoulder</font> (distal clavicle and scapula neck fractures with &gt; 10mm of displacement)</div><div>symptomatic nonunion</div><div><u>relative</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">unstable fracture patterns (Neer Type IIA, IIB, V)</span></div><div>brachial plexus injury (questionable because 66% have spontaneous return)</div><div>closed head injury</div><div>seizure disorder</div><div>polytrauma patient</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""neer_distal_clavicle-145630ebe331246639b.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>TREATMENT Mid clavicle&nbsp;</b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">Nonoperative</span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>&lt; 2cm shortening and displacement</div><div>&lt; 1cm displacement of the superior shoulder suspensory complex&nbsp;</div><div>closed and no neurovascular injury</div><div>low demand patient&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>modalities:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sling,&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">figure-of-8 strap</span></div><div>elevate and extend shoulder to bring distal fragment to the proximal fragment</div><div><br></div><div>outcomes&nbsp;</div><div>figure-of-8 associated with more pain, shortening, and lower compliance than sling</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">no difference in functional or cosmetic outcomes between sling and figure-of-eight braces</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">Operative</span>&nbsp;</div><div><u>indications&nbsp;</u>absolute</div><div>open fractures</div><div>displaced fracture with skin tenting&nbsp;</div><div>subclavian artery or vein injury</div><div>floating shoulder (clavicle and scapular neck fracture)</div><div><br></div><div><u>relative and controversial indications</u></div><div>displaced with<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;&gt; 2cm shortening&nbsp;</span></div><div>bilateral displaced clavicle fractures</div><div>brachial plexus injury (questionable because 66% have spontaneous return)</div><div>closed head injury</div><div>seizure disorder</div><div>polytrauma patient</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>proximal humerus fracture</b></span><div><br></div><div><font color=""#333333"" style="""">Neer</font> classification involves displacement of fractures in 4 different parts</div><div><br></div><div><u>and relationship of 4 anatomic segments</u></div><div>1. {{c1::Greater tuberosity}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Lesser tuberosity}}</div><div>3. {{c1::Humeral head}}</div><div>4. {{c1::Humeral shaft}}</div><div><br></div><div>In order to be considered a, ""part (displaced)""</div><div>a fragment must be angulated by {{c2::45}} degrees or displaced at least {{c2::1}} cm&nbsp;</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_32.png""><div><img src=""NEER-PROXIMAL-HUMERUS-FRACTURE-CLASSIFICATION.jpg""><br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-07 at 1.21.20 PM.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>proximal humerus fracture</b></span><div><br></div><div><u><font color=""#333333"" style="""">Neer</font>&nbsp;Four-Part Classification</u>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>One-part humeral fracture: {{c1::Nondisplaced, impacted fractures::2}}</div>"	"All parts <u>still in alignment</u><div><img src=""type-of-fracture.gif""><br><div><img src=""neer_chart.jpg""><br></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>proximal humerus fracture</b></span><div><font color=""#333333""><b><br></b></font></div><div><font color=""#333333""><b># of fragments (not anatomical segments)<br></b></font><div><br></div><div><u><font color=""#333333"">Neer</font>&nbsp;Four-Part Classification</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Two-part humeral fracture: {{c1::One}} fragment/s are displaced&nbsp;</div><div>Three-part humeral fracture: {{c1::Two}} fragment/s are displaced</div><div>Four-part humeral fracture: {{c1::All}} fragment/s are displaced</div></div>"	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_12/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_12_Fig1_HTML.gif""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">proximal humerus fracture:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">s</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">urgical neck</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the most common location&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_32.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">proximal humerus fracture o</span>ccurs primarily in {{c1::older osteoporotic patients::epidimiology}}&nbsp;"	after a low-energy fall<div><br></div><div>or in young patients that experience a high-energy trauma</div><div><br></div><div>Mechanism: Most commonly from a fall on an outstretched hand, usually from a standing height</div><div><br></div><div>Pain, swelling, and ecchymosis in the upper arm, which is exacerbated with the slightest motion</div><div><br></div><div>Loss of sensation is seen if there is neurologic involvement</div><div><br></div><div>Diminished radial pulse if the fracture compromises the vascular supply</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In a proximal humeral fracture at the surgical neck, the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::supraspinatus::m.}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;causes abduction of the proximal fragment</span>"																					
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>proximal humerus fracture</b></span><br></div><div><br></div><div><u>X-ray&nbsp;Imaging&nbsp;(trauma series)</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::apical oblique}} view<br></div><div>AP&nbsp;view</div><div>scapular Y view</div><div>axillary view</div><div>west point axillary view</div>"	"<div><div>CT scan indications: preoperative planning, humeral head or greater tuberosity position uncertain, intra-articular comminution</div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(122, 122, 122);"">The benefit of the apical oblique image&nbsp;</span><em>(fig. 4)</em><span style=""color: rgb(122, 122, 122);"">&nbsp;is that the Hills-Sach lesions and glenoid fractures are reliably detected</span><br></div><img src=""RadiologyExpert_English_Class_X_shoulder_fig04a_apicOblique_technique-scaled-pdtk0bm48aqs5kv88i53vwdan7a1juhguq0bz3.jpg""><div><a><strong>C,</strong>&nbsp;Radiograph of the left shoulder in the plane of the thorax does not reveal any significant abnormality.&nbsp;</a></div><div><a><strong>D,</strong>&nbsp;In the apical oblique view, note the calcification on the anteroinferior glenoid rim (<em>arrow</em>).</a><br><div><img src=""B9781416034278500118_gr10.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(122, 122, 122);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">proximal humerus fracture</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><u>Conservative&nbsp;Treatment</u></div><div>indication: {{c1::One Part (nondisplaced)}} fractures</div><div>initially {{c2::Sling immobilization}} but progress to early rehabilitation within {{c2::6}} weeks<b><font color=""#0027ff"">*</font></b></div><div>{{c3::Codman’s}} maneveur</div><div>{{c3::AROM}} exercises as early as tolerated</div>"	"<div><div><b>TREATMENT</b></div><div><br></div><div><b>Nonoperative</b></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sling immobilization followed by progressive rehabilitation</strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">most can be treated non-operatively</font> including</div><div>- minimally displaced surgical and anatomic neck fractures</div><div>-&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">greater tuberosity</span>&nbsp;fracture displaced&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&lt; 5mm</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><div>Total healing time is typically 6 to 12 weeks. Early callus formation usually occurs at 4-6 weeks.</div><div><br></div><div><b><font color=""#0027ff"">*</font></b><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Duration of immobilization</span>&nbsp;— optimal timing for beginning rehabilitation remains uncertain.&nbsp;</div><div>Multiple RCT's report no significant harm and possibly improved mobility&nbsp;</div><div>among patients whose initial immobilization is <font color=""#095cff""><u>&lt;</u>&nbsp;2 weeks</font>&nbsp;</div></div><div><br></div><div><b>Operative</b></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">CRPP (closed reduction percutaneous pinning)</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>- 2-part surgical neck fractures</div><div>- 3-part and valgus-impacted&nbsp;</div><div>- 4-part fractures in patients with good bone quality, minimal metaphyseal comminution, and intact medial calcar</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">ORIF</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>- greater tuberosity&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">displaced &gt; 5mm&nbsp;</span></div><div>- displaced 2-part fractures</div><div>- 3, and 4-part fractures in younger patients&nbsp;</div><div>head-splitting fractures in younger patients&nbsp;</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">I</strong><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">ntramedullary nailing</strong></div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;</div><div>- surgical neck fractures or 3-part greater tuberosity fractures in younger patients</div><div>- combined proximal humerus and humeral shaft fractures</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">A</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">rthroplasty</span>&nbsp;</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>- in younger patients (40-65 years old) with complex fracture-dislocations or head-splitting components that may fail fixation&nbsp;</div><div>- low-demand elderly individuals with&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">non-reconstructible</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;tuberosities</span>&nbsp;and poor bone stock</div><div>- older patients with fracture-dislocation</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-07 at 1.21.20 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">proximal humerus fracture</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u><br></div><div><div>{{c1::ORIF::tx}}: {{c2::Greater than one part::type}} (displaced &gt;{{c2::2}} cm)</div></div>"	"<div><b>TREATMENT</b></div><div><br></div><div><b>Nonoperative</b></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sling immobilization followed by progressive rehabilitation</strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>most proximal humerus fractures can be treated nonoperatively including</div><div>- minimally displaced surgical and anatomic neck fractures</div><div>-&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">greater tuberosity</span>&nbsp;fracture displaced&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&lt; 5mm</span></div><div><br></div><div><b>Operative</b></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">CRPP (closed reduction percutaneous pinning)</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>- 2-part surgical neck fractures</div><div>- 3-part and valgus-impacted&nbsp;</div><div>- 4-part fractures in patients with good bone quality, minimal metaphyseal comminution, and intact medial calcar</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">ORIF</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>- greater tuberosity&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">displaced &gt; 5mm&nbsp;</span></div><div>- displaced 2-part fractures</div><div>- 3, and 4-part fractures in younger patients&nbsp;</div><div>head-splitting fractures in younger patients&nbsp;</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">I</strong><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">ntramedullary nailing</strong></div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;</div><div>- surgical neck fractures or 3-part greater tuberosity fractures in younger patients</div><div>- combined proximal humerus and humeral shaft fractures</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">A</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">rthroplasty</span>&nbsp;</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>- in younger patients (40-65 years old) with complex fracture-dislocations or head-splitting components that may fail fixation&nbsp;</div><div>- low-demand elderly individuals with&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">non-reconstructible</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;tuberosities</span>&nbsp;and poor bone stock</div><div>- older patients with fracture-dislocation</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-07 at 1.21.20 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>complications proximal humerus fracture</u>&nbsp;</span><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Brachial plexus}} injuries</div><div>{{c1::Axillary}} nerve and artery injury&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Avascular necrosis (AVN)::complication}}</div>"	"<div>Brachial plexus injuries</div><div>Axillary nerve injury can occur with surgical neck fractures.</div><div>Radial and ulnar nerves may be affected as well.</div><div>Median nerve is the least affected.</div><div>Axillary artery compromise may be evident depending on the site of injury.</div><div>Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the humeral head may occur with anatomic neck fractures secondary to interruption of the humeral circumflex artery</div><div><img src=""Anatomyofproximalhumerus.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Stress fractures of the Humerus&nbsp;aka {{c2::Little Leaguer’s shoulder}}</b><div><br></div><div>occur in the {{c1::epiphyseal growth plate (epiphysiolysis)}} in children</div><div><br></div><div>occur through the {{c1::shaft}} in adults&nbsp;</div>	"<div><img src=""https://journals.sagepub.com/cms/10.1177/0363546516632744/asset/images/large/10.1177_0363546516632744-fig1.jpeg""><br></div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12891-019-2532-1/MediaObjects/12891_2019_2532_Fig1_HTML.png"">"																				
<b>Stress fractures of the Humerus</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div><br></div><div>Symptoms usually resolve with activity restriction of {{c1::8}} weeks in adults&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and {{c1::12}} weeks in adolescents</div>	<div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Insidious onset of shoulder pain aggravated by <b>repetitive overhead throwing</b></div><div>Focal tenderness over the stress fracture</div><div>Discomfort with resistance to shoulder abduction and internal rotation</div><div>Mild weakness may be possible.<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Early plain films may be unremarkable.</div><div>With chronic stress fractures, there may be <b>cortical thickening</b> along the mid-third of the medial cortex.</div><div>In adolescent pitchers, widening of the lateral part of the physis with associated sclerosis or cystic changes may be seen on external rotation&nbsp;AP&nbsp;films.</div>																				
"<b>Elbow Arthrodesis</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Indications</span>:</u></div><div>Arthritis</div><div>Failed surgical procedure</div><div><br></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Fusion position</span>:</u></div><div>Unilateral: Flexion—90 degrees</div><div>Bilateral: Flexion—{{c1::110}} degrees in one arm and {{c1::65}} degrees for the other</div>"	"<img src=""elbow_fusion_intro01.jpg"">"																				
<b>Medial Epicodylitis</b><div><br></div><div>Caused by repetitive {{c1::valgus}} stress to the elbow</div><div><br></div><div>throwing motion of a pitcher, especially in the {{c2::late cocking}} and {{c2::acceleration}} phases&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and swinging motion (backswing and downward follow-through swing just prior to ball impact) of a golfer</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(A) Early cocking phase. (B) Late cocking phase. (C) Acceleration phase. (D) Follow-through.</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_38.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c4::Little Leaguer’s}}&nbsp;elbow aka&nbsp;{{c5::Medial}}&nbsp;epicondyle&nbsp;{{c1::tracktion}}&nbsp;{{c1::apophysitis}}</b><div><br></div><div>Long-term repetitive valgus stress loading to the elbow in children, who have immature bones</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(38, 50, 56);"">strong pull on the tendons and ligaments, player feels pain at the&nbsp;</span>{{c5::medial}}<span style=""color: rgb(38, 50, 56);"">&nbsp;side of the elbow</span><br></div><div><br></div><div>May lead to {{c2::osteochondritis dissecans}} of the {{c3::capitellum}}</div><div><br></div><div>mainstay of treatment: {{c6::conservative}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""medialEpicondApophysitis_a_enIL.jpg""></div><div><img src=""mrime.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div>medial epicondyle edema&nbsp;</div><div>surgery only for avulsion fracture&nbsp;</div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div>OD:&nbsp;</span><b>joint condition in which bone underneath the cartilage of a joint dies due to lack of blood flow</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">This bone and cartilage can then break loose, causing pain and possibly hindering joint motion</span></div><div><img src=""osteochondritis-oats.png""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""little-league-elbow.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Medial Epicondylitis&nbsp;Treatment</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>Conservative:</u></div><div>Short term: Rest, ice,&nbsp;NSAIDs</div><div>{{c3::counterforce brace}} or {{c3::wrist splint (at neutral)}}</div><div>Long term: {{c1::Activity modification (poor throwing/swinging mechanics addressed)}}</div><div>+/- {{c4::common flexor tendon injection (w/ prp etc.)}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Surgical:</u></div><div>{{c2::Surgical pinning}}: reserved for an unstable elbow joint</div>"	"<div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Tenderness just distal to the medial epicondyle over the common flexor tendon origin</div><div>Pain may be reproduced with <b>resisted wrist flexion and pronation.</b></div><div><b>Ulnar neuropathy</b> symptoms may occur secondary to valgus stretch of the nerve.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>X-ray may show physeal widening, and/or avulsion of medial epicondyle.</div><div>ultrasound (<font color=""#0027ff"">tears are readily apparent</font>)</div><div>MRI&nbsp;can show edema in the medial epicondyle apophysis, tears.&nbsp; <font color=""#0027ff"">Rarely needed</font></div><div><font color=""#0027ff""><br></font></div><div><div><u>Operative</u>&nbsp;(<font color=""#0027ff"">surgery not great may be better to try 10x</font>)</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong>open debridement of PT/FCR, reattachment of flexor-pronator group</strong></span>&nbsp;</div><div>-&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">up to 6 months of nonoperative management&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">that fails in a compliant patient</span></div><div><font color=""#5372a6"">-&nbsp;</font>symptoms severe and affecting quality of life w/ clear diagnosis</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-13 at 1.41.40 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Tr trochlea, <i>*</i>&nbsp;joint space, <font color=""#0027ff""><span style=""font-style: italic;"">orange </span>= common
flexor tendons</font>, and <span style=""font-style: italic;"">green </span>= UCL</div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-13 at 1.41.16 PM.png""><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Needle position: inserted parallel to
the transducer from either proximal to distal or distal to
proximal.&nbsp;</div><div>Due to the superficial nature of the tendon, a gel
standoff may be helpful.&nbsp;</div><div>For PNT, insert the needle into the
tendon itself.&nbsp;</div><div>For a peritendinous injection, <font color=""#0027ff"">keep the needle
above or below the tendon.</font></div><div><br></div><div>If performing PNT, intermittently switch to an out-of-plane/short-axis view&nbsp;</div><div>in order to determine the anterior-
posterior/radial-ulnar position of the needle within the
region of tendinosis [<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 255);"">4</span>].&nbsp;</div><div>Repetitively fenestrate the entire
region of tendinosis while injecting local anesthetic, PRP,
or AB.&nbsp;</div><div>Resistance should decrease with increased passes.
Calcifications and enthesophytes should be mechanically
broken up&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""p13_p050_i180.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Cozen’s}} Test</div><div>positive test indicates:<span style=""font-weight: 600;"">&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Lateral epicondylitis of the elbow}}<br></div>
<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-15 at 8.51.25 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Patient:&nbsp;</span>Flexes elbow to ~60° on lap or table and fully extends wrist.</div><div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Examiner:&nbsp;</span>Forcibly flex the extended wrist.</div><div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Positive test:&nbsp;</span>Pain at the lateral epicondyle during resisted extension.</div><div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Consistent with:&nbsp;</span>Lateral epicondylitis of the elbow.<br><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Note:&nbsp;</span>You may use the Clamshell test on page 42 to increase resistance.&nbsp;</div>"																				
{{c2::Mill’s}} test:&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Passive extension of the {{c1::elbow}} with forced wrist {{c1::flexion}} and finally forced {{c3::pronation}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>positive if pain at the lateral epicondyle</div><img src=""Mills-Test-1.jpg"">"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>positive test is consistent with:<span style=""font-weight: 600;"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Medial
epicondylitis of the elbow}}<br></div>
<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-15 at 8.56.48 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><u>Golfer's elbow</u></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Patient: </span>Flexes forearm to
~50° on lap or table and
fully flexes wrist.
</div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Examiner: </span>Forcibly extend
the flexed wrist.
</div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Positive test: </span>Pain at the
medial epicondyle.
</div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Consistent with: </span>Medial
epicondylitis of the elbow.
</div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Note: </span>You may use the Reverse Clamshell test on page 42 to
increase resistance.&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<div><b>Lateral epicondylitis Treatment</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>Conservative:</u></div><div>Relative rest, ice,&nbsp;NSAIDs&nbsp;for 10 to 14 days</div><div>Physical therapy (stretching, strengthening, modalities)</div><div>Correct improper biomechanics and technique<br></div><div>{{c1::wrist splinting &amp; counterforce bands::2}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Corticosteroid injection}} is {{c2::controversial}} in its efficacy</div><div><br></div><div><u>Posttreatment return to play</u></div><div>Decrease {{c3::string tension}}</div><div>Increase {{c3::grip size}}<br></div><div>Switch to {{c3::2-handed backhand}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Surgical:</u></div><div>release of origin or excision and revitalization of pathologic tissue in the {{c4::ECR-B::m.}}&nbsp;</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-19 at 10.55.18 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-19 at 10.55.36 AM.png""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Needle position: The needle should be inserted parallel to
the transducer from either proximal to distal or distal to
proximal.&nbsp;</div><div>Due to the superficial nature of the tendon, use a gel standoff</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>For PNT, insert the needle into the
tendon itself and repetitively fenestrate the entire region of
tendinosis.&nbsp;</div><div>For a peritendinous injection, keep the needle
above or below the tendon&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::Olecranon bursitis}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>&nbsp;</b>aka&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">draftsman’s or miner’s elbow</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#333333""><u>Diagnostic Studies</u></font></div><div>+/- {{c2::aspirate analysis (culture/crystals)}}<br></div><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c2::serial fluid aspiration}} +/- {{c2::empiric abx (infection suspected)}}</div><div>Conservative: Rest,&nbsp;NSAIDs, and {{c3::compressive elbow padding}}</div><div>Surgery: {{c4::bursectomy}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Resist the urge to drain it (prob never do it)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>compressive wrap after draining&nbsp;</div><div>empirical treatment with <b>antibiotics</b> until cx result&nbsp;</div><div><b>serial draining</b> w/out steroid injection (not routinely done)</div><div><b>bursectomy</b> is controversial&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>MECHANISM</u><br></div><div>Repetitive trauma, inflammatory disorder (gout, pseudogout, rheumatoid arthritis [RA])</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-22 at 8.18.49 PM.png""></div><div><img src=""1200px-Bursitis_Elbow_WC.JPG""><br></div>"																				
{{c1::Elbow}} Dislocation: most common type of dislocation in children&nbsp;	"and the second most common type in adults (second only to shoulder dislocation)<div><br></div><div>Young adults 25 to 30 years old are most affected and sports activities account for almost 50% of these injuries</div><div><img src=""paste-52b2099d40b913984c3d4699b923fd90693aa171.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>elbow dislocation</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::posterior::direction}} is the most common, occurring 98% of the time</div><div><br></div><div>Associated injuries include fracture of the {{c2::radial head}}, as well as injury to the {{c3::brachial a.}} and {{c3::median n.}} (neuro-vascular structures)</div>	"<div><u>SYMPTOMS</u></div><div>Inability to bend the elbow following a fall on the outstretched hand</div><div>Pain in the shoulder and wrist</div><div>neurovascular evaluation of the radial artery, and median, ulnar, and radial nerves is <u>most important</u>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Plain&nbsp;AP&nbsp;and lateral radiographs</div><div>CT&nbsp;and&nbsp;MRI&nbsp;scans are seldom necessary</div><div><img src=""Screen-Shot-2016-01-08-at-12.20.35-PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>elbow dislocation</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c2::Reduce dislocation}} as soon as possible after injury</div><div>{{c1::Splint (for 10 days)}}<br></div><div>Initiate&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;exercises,&nbsp;NSAIDs</div>	"<img src=""B9780323033848500135_gr1.jpg""><div>figure 8 strap for added stability&nbsp;<br><div><img src=""B9780323033848500135_gr3.jpg""></div></div>"																				
{{c1::distal biceps tendonitis}}<div><br></div><div><u>presentation</u></div><div>Insidious onset of pain in the antecubital fossa usually after an eccentric overload</div>	"Audible snap with an obvious deformity (“Popeye sign”), swelling, and ecchymosis if an avulsion is suspected<div><img src=""WhatIs1.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""easset_upload_file46193_240428_e.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>distal biceps tendon avulsion</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::Surgical: Reattachment}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>conservative is for low demand/elderly who do not care if they loose function or partial tear / tenoditis&nbsp;</div><img src=""distal-bicep-repair.jpg""><div>Operative</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">surgical repair of tendon to tuberosity&nbsp;</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>young healthy patients who do not want to sacrifice function&nbsp;</div><div>partial tears that do not respond to nonoperative management</div><div><br></div><div>surgical treatment should occur within a few weeks from the date of injury</div><div>further delay may preclude a straightforward, primary repair</div>"																				
<b>{{c1::triceps tendonitis}}</b><div><br></div><div><u>presentation</u><div>Posterior elbow pain with tenderness&nbsp;</div><div>Pain with resistive elbow extension</div></div>	"Sudden loss of extension with a palpable defect in the triceps tendon (avulsion)<div><img src=""WHatIs.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>{{c1::Valgus Extension Overload (VEO)}}<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">&nbsp;aka&nbsp;</span>{{c1::thrower's/pitcher's arm}}</b><br></div><div><br></div><u>General</u><div>Spectrum of overuse elbow injuries caused by repetitive forces during the throwing motion</div><div>Valgus forces cause {{c2::tensile}} stress in the medial elbow and lateral {{c2::shear}} stress in the {{c4::postero-medial}} {{c4::olecranon}}</div><div><br><div><u>Pathology</u></div><div>Olecranon {{c5::osteophytosis}} and {{c5::loose body}} formation occurs secondary to repetitive abutment of olecranon -&gt; olecranon fossa</div></div>"	"<img src=""hhf.jpg""><img src=""mechanism.jpg"">"																				
<div><div><b>{{c1::Valgus extension overload (VEO)}}&nbsp;</b></div></div><div><br></div><u>Clinical Features</u><div>{{c3::Postero-medial::location}} elbow pain</div><div>lack of {{c4::full elbow extension}}</div><div>often associated {{c2::Catching or locking}}&nbsp;<br></div>	"<img src=""hhf.jpg""><img src=""mechanism.jpg"">"																				
"<div><b>Bounce Test:</b> Provocative test for Valgus extension overload (VEO)</div><div><br></div><div>Flex elbow to {{c3::30}} degrees and repeatedly {{c1::extend}} the elbow fully while applying a {{c1::valgus}} stress</div><div><br></div><div>Pain may be elicited, particularly at the {{c2::last 5 - 10 degrees of extension::# ROM}}</div>"	"<img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/266094855/figure/fig2/AS:1094961734914060@1638070629203/Valgus-extension-overload-VEO-test-The-VEO-test-is-accomplished-with-the-elbow-at-a.jpg""><div>Valgus stress test should also be performed at &gt;90 degrees to rule out&nbsp;UCL&nbsp;injury</div><div><br></div><div><b>Physical exam</b></div><div><u>palpation</u></div><div>tender to palpation over posteromedial olecranon</div><div><u>motion</u></div><div>flexion contracture</div><div><u>provocative tests</u></div><div>crepitus due to loose bodies and synovitis in the posterior compartment</div><div>pain with forced elbow extension</div><div>sustained elbow extension - ""arm bar test""</div><div>repeated terminal elbow extension - ""bounce test""</div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Valgus extension overload (</span>VEO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span></b><div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></b></div><div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>AP/lateral x-rays may show a {{c1::loose body}} or {{c1::osteophyte}} formation at the olecranon.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>stop trowing</div><div>strengthening eccentric elbow {{c2::flexor-pronator::2 m groups}}<u><br></u></div><div>evaluation of pitching biomechanics<br></div><div>NSAID's</div><div>Surgical technique includes: {{c3::removal of the loose body/osteophyte}}</div></div>"	"<div>PT focused on strengthening eccentric elbow flexor-pronator to better control rapid elbow extension<br></div><img src=""mri.jpg""><div><font color=""#095cff"">arrow: osteophyte</font></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/340960311/figure/fig1/AS:885154008547330@1588048569845/MRI-image-of-Olecranon-bursitis-on-sagittal-view-Note-Courtesy-of-Dr-Marc-Brown.png""></div><div>normal</div><div><br><div><b>surgery</b></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>persistent symptoms that fail to improve with nonoperative treatment</div><div><u>contraindications</u></div><div>MCL insufficiency is a relative contraindication for olecranon debridement alone</div><div><u>technique</u></div><div>-arthroscopy procedures can include debridement or drilling of chondromalacia, debridement of lateral meniscoid lesion or posterolateral plica, osteophyte excision, loose body excision</div><div>-care must be taken to only remove osteophyte and not normal olecranon as this many result in a loss of bony restraint and increase stress on the MC</div></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Positive test is&nbsp;Consistent with: {{c1::Ulnar collateral ligamentous laxity}}&nbsp;</div></div></div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-21 at 8.26.07 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>"	+ = Pain and/or joint laxity<div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Significant medial elbow pain occurring after the throwing motion</div><div>A pop or click may be heard precipitating the pain.</div><div>Medial pain or instability on valgus stress with the elbow, flexed 20 degrees to 30 degrees if the&nbsp;UCL&nbsp;is torn</div>																				
<b>Medial Colateral Ligament Sprain</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Plain films may reveal {{c1::calcification/spurring}} along the&nbsp;UCL</div><div>{{c2::Valgus stress}} radiographs demonstrate a {{c3::2}}-mm joint space</div>	"<font color=""#095cff"">3-mm</font> joint space suggestive of&nbsp;UCL&nbsp;injury (per ortho bullets)<div><img src=""stress.jpg""><br><div>On US, applying a valgus force during examination may show increased joint space<br></div></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">MR-arthrogram</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;- diagnostic (use of dye)</span><br></div><div><img src=""39B_moved.JPG""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
{{c1::UCL}} {{c1::anterior band reconstruction}} aka Tommy John surgery	"<div><u>rehabilitation</u></div><div>first line</div><u><div><u><br></u></div>Indications</u><div>-&nbsp;high-level throwers that want to continue competitive sports</div><div>- failed nonoperative management in partial tears and willing to undergo extensive rehabilitation</div><div><br></div><div><u>outcomes</u></div><div>90% return to preinjury levels of throwing with newer reconstruction techniques</div><div><img src=""elbow_uclr_intro01.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""ulnar-collateral-ligament-injury.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>positive test is Consistent with:<span style=""font-weight: 600;""> </span>{{c1::Radial collateral ligamentous laxity (LCL)}}&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-25 at 8.05.10 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																					
"<div><b>{{c1::Lateral pivot-shift}}</b><strong>&nbsp;test</strong>: Assesses the&nbsp;{{c2::LCL}}&nbsp;for {{c2::postero}}-{{c2::lateral}} instability</div><div><img src=""9781604060669_c040_f001.jpg""><br></div>"	"O’Driscoll and colleagues (1991) described the posterolateral rotatory instability test. The examination is performed with the patient supine and the shoulder flexed at least 90 degrees. The wrist is supinated and then a valgus moment, combined with an axial compressive force, is applied to the elbow as it is fully extended. This maneuver may reproduce an apprehensive response in a symptomatic patient. Careful palpation of the posterolateral aspect of the elbow during this maneuver is required to appreciate this subtle rotatory subluxation of the radial head.<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">Posterolateral rotatory instability (PLRI) of the elbow was first described in 1991 by O’Driscoll et al. [</span><a href=""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4896886/#CR1"">1</a><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">•] as an injury to the lateral ulnar collateral ligament (LUCL) leading to posterolateral subluxation or dislocation of the radius on the capitellum without disruption of the proximal radioulnar joint. It is most often caused by a traumatic event such as an elbow dislocation or a significant valgus stress combined with an axial load</span><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Median nerve compression at the elbow</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">distal to ligament of struthers&nbsp;</span></div></span>{{c1::lacertus fibrosus}}<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">&nbsp;aka distal&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">bicipital aponeurosis</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">causes compression of the PT</span></div>"	"an aponeurotic structure originating and enveloping the distal biceps tendon as well as the proximal flexor muscle group of the forearm<div><img src=""1-s2.0-S1930043321000856-gr1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Median nerve compression at the elbow</b></span><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>caused by the following structures:</u></span><br></div><div>Ligament of Struthers or supracondylar spur</div><div>Lacertus fibrosus</div><div>Pronator teres muscle</div><div><br></div><div>and... {{c1::Between the two heads of the flexor digitalis superficialis (FDS)}}</div>"	"<img src=""B9781455726721000180_f018-001-9781455726721.jpg""><div><img src=""images-8e6cb9df3240a092ac75e9151ffba303d1e6fbc8.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>cubital tunnel syndrome</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>X-ray to evaluate for {{c1::osteophytes or loose bodies}}</div><div><br></div><div>Consider&nbsp;MRI&nbsp;for soft tissue abnormalities if indicated</div><div>EMG/NCS&nbsp;above and below the elbow</div>																					
<b>cubital tunnel syndrome</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::elbow protection (splinting/pad)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Relative rest,&nbsp;NSAIDs, and technique modification</div><div>Surgical: Ulnar nerve transposition</div>	"<img src=""paste-bab83f4cee3637a86c8f4b312ab4d18ef919ec90.jpg""><img src=""images-ae32f7a8237ae133442685d68a2386038fc6bbb6.jpg"">"																				
<b>{{c1::osteochondrosis of the elbow}}&nbsp;aka&nbsp;{{c2::Panner's::eponym}}&nbsp;disease</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>pathophys</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::aseptic necrosis::pathology}} of the {{c3::Epiphysial plate::location}} in the {{c3::capitellum::location}}</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">Lateral compression injury typically in&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">pre/adolescent</span><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">&nbsp;throwing athletes</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">Panner's disease and osteochondritis dissecans are a spectrum of dz</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">Panner's disease, an osteochondrosis of the capitellum, is a rare disorder that usually affects the dominant extremity in &lt;10 y/o's&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><u>management: reduction of stressful activtiy</u> is usually sufficient&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6d89fb4015c371790aa84016e92e97bb5902aa88.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><img src=""623-epiphyseal-plate-line.jpe"">"																				
<b>osteochondrosis of the elbow aka Panner's disease</b><div><br></div><div>similar to but not the same as {{c1::osteochondritis dissecans::same}} of the capitellum of the elbow&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::OCD::same}} is a {{c2::localized}} {{c2::fragmentation}} of the bone and cartilage of the capitellum</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">Osteochondritis dissecans of the capitellum typically occurs in adolescents and is associated with loose body formation</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">Panner's disease and osteochondritis dissecans likely represent a continuum of disordered endochondral ossification with presentation and prognosis dependent primarily on age at onset.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Osteochondritis Dissecans of Elbow is a localized injury and subsequent separation of articular cartilage and subchondral bone of the capitellum, most commonly seen in gymnasts and pitchers</span><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><div><u>Pathophysiology</u></div><div>theorized to result from repetitive compression-type injury (overhead or upper extremity weight bearing activities) of the immature capitellum causing</div><div>- vascular insufficiency</div><div>- repetitive microtraum</div></div><div><img src=""child_elbow_panners_cause02.jpg""><img src=""osteochondritis-elbow.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>osteochondrosis (panner's) disease elbow</b><div><br></div><div><u>Mechanism continued</u></div><div><br></div><div>Believed to be caused by interference in {{c2::blood supply}} to {{c2::epiphysis}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>leading to {{c1::resorption}} of the {{c1::ossification center}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>initially, followed by repair/replacement</div>	"<div><img src=""endochondral-ossification-growth.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Panners-Disease.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Osteochondrosis (panner's) elbow</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Tenderness and swelling on the {{c1::lateral}} aspect of the elbow<br></div><div>{{c2::Limited extension}} seen on eval of ROM<br></div>	"Usually seen in dominant elbow of young boys<div><img src=""child_elbow_panners_intro01.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""panners_a_enIL.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Osteochondrosis/dritis dissecans of the elbow</b><div><br></div><div><u>Plain film&nbsp;Imaging:</u></div><div>type 1: Intact cartilage, Sclerosis</div><div>type 2: {{c1::patchy areas of lucency::type 2}}&nbsp;</div><div>type 3: {{c2::fragmentation::type 3}}</div>	"type 1: Intact cartilage<br><div>type 2: Cartilage fracture with bony collapse or displacement<br></div><div><img src=""images-7a9c9bfcee9dbd93c9078a0b26cbc2922f391f18.jpg""><br></div><div>type&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">3: loose bodies present in joint</span><br></div><div><img src=""images-fba0d9e76d09d587b41df4fb171fe05592d191d0.jpg""><img src=""images-ce447947b95c996196971775ba6c46897891c772.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div><b>OSTEOCHONDROSIS OF THE ELBOW (PANNER’S DISEASE)</b><br></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::Conservative}}</div></div>	"Conservative: (Immobilization, then gradual&nbsp;ROM)<div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><u>Panner's disease (osteochondrosis of the capitellum)</u></span></div><div>usually&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">benign</span>&nbsp;self-limiting course</div><div>surgery is <b>contraindicated</b> for Panner disease (unlike OCD elbow)</div><div><br></div><div><u>Osteochondirtis dissecans treatment</u></div><div>can be op or non-op</div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>Procedures</u></div><div>microfracture drilling&nbsp;</div><div>fixation of fragment&nbsp;</div><div>arthroscopic debreidment&nbsp;</div><div>OATS procedure</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Special problem associated with humeral shaft fracture is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::radial nerve injury}}"	"<div>TIP: be sure to add in finger extension (EIP) in addition to EE and WE on MMT</div><div>and dorsal arm / hand when testing LT and PP</div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_42.png"">"																				
"Midshaft humeral fracture<div><br></div><div>{{c2::95}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of patients will regain their radial nerve function within&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">During this period of observation patient should wear a splint and work with a therapist</span><div><br></div><div>EMGs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are indicated if radial nerve function does not return</span></div>"																				
<b>Mid-shaft humeral fracture</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>treatment</u><b>&nbsp;</b></div><div>for the vast majority of patient's: {{c1::non-operative::op/non-op}}</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">90% union rate (depending on fracture characteristics)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>non op</b></span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>indicated in&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">vast majority of humeral shaft fractures</span></div><div>criteria for acceptable alignment include:&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/evidence/17088660""><i></i></a>&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&lt; 20° anterior angulation</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&lt; 30° varus/valgus angulation</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&lt; 3 cm shortening</span></div><div><u>absolute contraindications</u></div><div>severe soft tissue injury or bone loss</div><div>vascular injury requiring repair</div><div>brachial plexus injury</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><div><b>Operative</b></div><div><b style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF)</b></div><div><u>absolute indications</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">open fracture</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">vascular injury requiring repair</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">brachial plexus injury&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">ipsilateral forearm fracture (floating elbow)</span>&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/evidence/5909054""><i></i></a>&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1016/humeral-shaft-fractures#926""><i></i>&nbsp;</a></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">compartment syndrome</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">periprosthetic humeral shaft fractures at the tip of the stem</span></div><div><u>relative indications</u></div><div>bilateral humerus fracture</div><div>polytrauma or associated lower extremity fracture (earlier weight bearing)</div><div>pathologic fractures</div><div>burns or soft tissue injury that precludes bracing</div><div>fracture characteristics</div><div>distraction at fracture site&nbsp;</div><div>short oblique or transverse fracture patter</div><div>intraarticular extension<br></div></div>"																				
<b>Mid-shaft humeral fracture</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>non-operative treatment</u><b>&nbsp;</b></div><div>{{c1::coaptation splint}} aka {{c1::sarmiento brace}} followed by {{c2::functional brace}}</div>	"<b>Coaptation Splint &amp; Functional Bracing</b><div><br></div><div><u>coaptation splint</u></div><div>applied until swelling resolves</div><div>adequately applied splint will extend up to axilla and over shoulder</div><div>common deformities include varus and extension</div><div>valgus mold to counter varus displacement</div><div><br></div><div><u>functional bracing</u>&nbsp;<a href=""https://upload.orthobullets.com/topic/1016/images/functional%20brace.jpg""><i></i></a>&nbsp;</div><div>extends from 2.5 cm distal to axilla to 2.5 cm proximal to humeral condyles</div><div><b>sling should not be used</b> to allow for gravity-assisted fracture reduction</div><div>shoulder extension used for more proximal fractures</div><div><b>weekly radiographs</b> for first 3 weeks to ensure maintenance of reduction</div><div>every 3-4 weeks after that</div><div><img src=""paste-1b909008f69ef92d0f52fd2644a39c22870adff3.jpg""><img src=""functional brace.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Distal humerus fracture:</b>&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Classification can be complex (multiple criteria exist)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most useful way to consider them is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::displaced}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::nondisplaced}} (cuccurullo)</div>"	"<div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">AO/OTA Classification of Distal Humerus Fractures</span></div><div><img src=""ota distal humerus.jpg""><br></div><div>a:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Extra-articular (supracondylar fracture)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">b: Intraarticular Single column</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">c: intraarticular Both columns</span></div></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_43.png""><div><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Distal humerus fracture</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::Orthopedic referral}}</div></div>"	"<div>Nondisplaced fractures: can be treated by splinting/casting and early motion</div><div><br></div><div>Displaced fractures: closed reduction with percutaneous pin, ORIF, or total elow arthroplasty</div><div><img src=""distal humerus 1_moved.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>RADIAL HEAD FRACTURE</b><div><b><br></b><div><u>General</u></div><div>commonly associated with {{c1::Dislocations of the elbow}}</div></div>	"<img src=""2_moved.JPG"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Radial head fracture</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>classification</u></span></div><div>Type I: {{c1::Nondisplaced}}</div><div>Type II: Marginal radial head fracture, {{c1::minimal displacement}}</div><div>Type III: {{c1::Comminuted}}</div><div>Type IV: {{c2::associated elbow disslocation}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""screen shot 2012-11-05 at 2.04.26 pm.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b style="""">Radial head fracture</b><b>&nbsp;Treatment</b><div>Orthopedic referral:</div><div><br></div><div><u>Type I (nondisplaced):</u></div><div>{{c1::Short period of immobilization (3–5 days)}}&nbsp;</div>"	"followed by early&nbsp;ROM to prevent contracture&nbsp;<div>do not bear weight&nbsp;<br><div><img src=""21_p015_i140.png""><br></div><div><img src=""21_p015_i080.png""><br></div><div><img src=""21_p015_i100.png""><br></div></div>"																				
<b>Radial head fracture</b><b>&nbsp;Treatment</b><div>Orthopedic referral:</div><div><br></div><div><u>Type II (minimal displacement):</u></div><div>Surgical fixation for fracture &gt;{{c1::2}} mm displacement or {{c1::30}}% radial head involvement</div><div><br></div><div><u>Type III (comminuted fracture):</u></div><div>Surgical fixation</div>	"<u>Procedures</u><div>ORIF</div><div>radial head excision</div><div>radail head arthroplasty</div><div><img src=""21_p350_i100.png""><br></div><div><img src=""21_p220_i100.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Radial head fracture</b><b>&nbsp;Treatment</b><div><br></div><div>Surgical fixation for: {{c1::Type II &amp;&nbsp;&gt;::type}}</div>	"<div><div>Type I:&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold; color: blue;"">Nondisplaced</span></div><div>Type II: Marginal radial head fracture,&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold; color: blue;"">minimal displacement</span></div><div>Type III:&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold; color: blue;"">Comminuted</span></div><div>Type IV: associated elbow disslocation&nbsp;</div></div><div><img src=""21_p350_i100.png""><br></div><img src=""21_p220_i100.png"">"																				
"<div><b>OLECRANON FRACTURE</b><div><br></div></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>{{c1::+/- inability to extend the forearm}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Nondisplaced: {{c2::Conservative (immobilization followed by physical therapy)}}</div><div>Displaced: {{c2::Surgical fixation (<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">displaced fx, abnl extensor mechanism</span>}}</div>"	"<img src=""colton-oblique and transverse..jpg"">"																				
<div><b>Coxa vara</b> occurs when the femoral neck and shaft angle is {{c1::decreased}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>hip abduction is limited, knee assumes a {{c1::valgus}} deformity</div><div><br></div><div>[angle is different in males (125<sup>o</sup>) than in femaes (115–120<sup>o</sup>)]<br></div>	"Coxa valga occurs when the angle is increased. The affected limb is lengthened and the knees assume a varus deformity<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-03 at 3.53.20 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
iliofemoral ligament: function is to limit {{c2::extension}}<div><br></div><div>as well as {{c1::abduction}}, and {{c1::external}} rotation of the hip</div>	"<img src=""Extracapsular-Ligaments-of-the-Hip-Joint.-1.jpg"">"																				
ischio-femoral ligament: function is to limit {{c1::internal rotation}} of the hip	"<img src=""Extracapsular-Ligaments-of-the-Hip-Joint.-1.jpg"">"																				
"pubofemoral ligament:<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;function is to limit hip&nbsp;</span>{{c1::abduction}}"	"<img src=""Extracapsular-Ligaments-of-the-Hip-Joint.-1.jpg"">"																				
ligamentum {{c1::capitis femoris::not teres}} extends from the acetabular notch to the femur&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>ligament is fairly weak and does little to strengthen the hip.</div><div><br></div><div>In 80% of cases, it carries a small artery to the femoral head</div>	"<img src=""hip-joint-opened-crop.jpg"">"																				
"Hip OA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;will limit&nbsp;</span>{{c1::internal rotation::movement}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;first</span>"																					
the (shoulder) load and shift test can be graded with the {{c1::Hawkin's}} scale for {{c3::anterior}} stability<div><br></div><div>caveat, do not confuse {{c2::laxity}} with {{c2::instability}}</div>	"<div>in <b>normal</b> relaxed people, the humeral head can be subluxed over the glenoid rim</div><div><br></div><div><b>positive only if</b> the patient has instability which feels like their symptoms, not pain alone</div><img src=""DalfSIvVwAAGZ2A.jpg"">"																				
Gold standard Dx for shoulder instability: {{c1::MRI arthorgram}}	"<div>best for visualization of labral tear</div><div><br></div><div>can do MRI, but contrast in<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">creases sensitivity and specificity for detecting soft-tissue injuries</span></div><div><br></div><div>ex. GLAD: a sheared off portion of articular cartilage along with the labrum&nbsp;</div><div>presence is a<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;risk factor for failure&nbsp;</span>following arthroscopic stabilization procedures</div><div><img src=""02aff701-a7dd-4f1b-80b3-826dbcefb4f2_glad_lesion..jpg""></div>"																				
treatment of TUBS: {{c1::arthroscopic repair (most often surgical)}}	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">management of first-time dislocators remains controversial, high rate of recurrent instability</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><u>Relative indications</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">first-time</span>&nbsp;traumatic shoulder dislocation with&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">Bankart lesion</span>&nbsp;confirmed by MRI in athlete&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">younger than 25&nbsp;</span>years of age</div><div>high demand athletes, work</div><div>recurrent dislocation/subluxation&nbsp;</div><div>&lt; 20-25% glenoid bone loss</div><div><br></div><div><u>risk factors for re-dislocation are</u><br></div><div>military and overhead and/or contact athletes experience an unacceptably high rate of recurrent instability</div><div>age &lt; 20 (highest risk)</div><div>male</div><div>contact sports</div><div>hyperlaxity</div><div>glenoid bone loss &gt;20-25%</div><div>greater tuberosity fractures</div><div><br></div><div>conservative/rehab</div><div>reduction</div><div>immobilization</div><div>PT</div><div>return to sport 7 - 12 days</div><div><img src=""shoulder-arthoscopic labral repair.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"In order to diagnose AMBRI on physical exam<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">must have at least&nbsp;</span>{{c1::instability in 2 or more planes}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">also can use&nbsp;</span>{{c2::beighton score}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;to increase suspicion</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">anterior, posterior, or inferior</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">sulcus sign</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">apprehension</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">jerk test</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">load and shift</span></div><div><img src=""sulcus sign.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/293025400/figure/fig1/AS:329964101619721@1455680980884/Beighton-score-for-joint-laxity.png""><br></div><div><div>= Beighton's criteria &gt;4/9&nbsp; (ortho bullets)</div><div>able to touch palms to floor while bending at waist (1 point)</div><div>genu recurvatum (2 points)</div><div>elbow hyperextension (2 points)</div><div>MCP hyperextension (2 points)</div><div>thumb abduction to the ipsilateral forearm (2 points)</div></div>"																				
"<b>AMBRI treatment:</b>&nbsp;(rehabilitation 1st line in the vast majority)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::3-6}} month regimen needed&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>strengthening of the {{c2::dynamic stabilizers::broad category}} of the shoulder&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div>{{c3::closed kinetic}} chain exercises&nbsp;are used early in the rehabilitation process</div>"	rotator cuff and periscapular musculature<div><br></div><div>CKC: safely stimulate co-contraction of the scapular and rotator cuff muscles<br></div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">nocturnal&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Shoulder Pain could point toward a diagnosis of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::impingement}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::RC tear}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Patients often report having difficulty sleeping on the affected side</span>"																				
dx of shoulder labral tear/pathology: {{c1::MRI w/&nbsp;intra-articular contrast}}	"<div>Imaging and Treatment = same as&nbsp;GHJ&nbsp;instability</div><div>""T3 MRI now obviates need for contrast""</div><img src=""Shoulder001a.jpg""><img src=""paste-e2443dc5c847fec4ef2fe8cf4a1d53604a7ac565.jpg""><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-30 at 11.24.15 AM.png"">"																				
<u>classification of slap tear</u><div>class 2. {{c1::Labral&nbsp;fraying}} with {{c1::detached biceps}} tendon anchor (41% of cases)</div>	"<div><div><u>classification of slap tear</u><br></div><div>1. Labral and biceps fraying, anchor intact (11% of cases)</div><div>2. Labral fraying with detached biceps tendon anchor (41% of cases)</div><div>3. Bucket handle tear, intact biceps tendon anchor&nbsp;(33% of cases) (Biceps separates from bucket handle tear)</div><div>4. Bucket handle tear with detached biceps tendon anchor (15% of cases) (Biceps remains attached to bucket handle tear</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-30 at 11.23.43 AM.png"">"																				
<div><u>classification of slap tear</u></div><div>3. {{c1::Bucket handle tear}}, with {{c1::intact biceps tendon}} anchor</div>	"<div><u>classification of slap tear</u><br></div><div>1. Labral and biceps fraying, anchor intact (11% of cases)</div><div>2. Labral fraying with detached biceps tendon anchor (41% of cases)</div><div>3. Bucket handle tear, intact biceps tendon anchor&nbsp;(33% of cases) (Biceps separates from bucket handle tear)</div><div>4. Bucket handle tear with detached biceps tendon anchor (15% of cases) (Biceps remains attached to bucket handle tear</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-30 at 11.23.43 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
(SLAP) Labral tear tx: {{c1::Nonoperative::op/non-op}}	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">delayed surgery
does not lead to poorer outcomes, thus 1st line is rehab&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">recommended 3-month period of physical therapy and medications before OR</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">rest from sports, followed by physical therapy and NSAIDs</span></strong></div><div><br></div><div>rehab focusing on <u>scapular dyskinesia</u> and r<u>otator cuff strengthening</u> for all patients</div><div><br></div><div>can do an injection</div><div><img src=""classification illustration_moved.jpg""><br></div>"																				
(SLAP) Labral tear surgical tx: {{c1::arthroscopic debriedment}} +/- {{c1::labral repair (sutures)}}	"<b>Operative</b>&nbsp;<div><div><br></div><div>(PM&amp;R Essentials)</div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Type I: Gentle débridement of labrum back to stable tissue.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Type II: Arthroscopic labral repair with suture anchors.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Type III: Arthroscopic débridement of the bucket-</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">handle fragment with repair of any unstable portions</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">of the labral rim.<br>Type IV: Treatment of the biceps disease with débride</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ment, tenotomy, or tenodesis combined with labral</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">repair or débridement.<br><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Patients older than 40 years have had less successful re</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">sults&nbsp;</span></div></div></div><div><br></div><div>(ortho bullets)<div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">arthroscopic debridement</span></strong><br></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>-Types I, III, and IV tears involving &lt;1/3rd of the biceps tendon,</div><div>- severe symptoms that have failed nonoperative management</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">arthroscopic debridement with&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">repair of the labrum/biceps&nbsp;</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div><font color=""#095cff"">-&nbsp;highly controversial</font></div><div>- Type 2 tears traditionally repaired in overhead athletes</div><div>- return to play rates after SLAP repairs are significantly lower for pitchers compared to non-pitchers&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""f15-04-9781455775774.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""SLAP-tear.jpg""><br></div><div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>"																				
"procedure for shoulder impingement snydrome: {{c1::subacromial injection}}<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">anesthetic can be beneficial in differentiating&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">tendinopathy&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">from&nbsp;</span>{{c2::a rotator cuff tear}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>{{c3::sub-acromial decompressions::general term (surgical tx)}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">: failed a minimum of 4-6 months of nonoperative treatment</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">if
there is continued weakness post injection, one must consider a rotator
cuff tear</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-08 at 4.42.00 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-08 at 4.42.09 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen-Shot-2018-12-04-at-5.26.51-PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""4-Figure2-1.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>

"<div>

of diagnostic accuracy in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::acromioclavicular}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;joint disease&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>

<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">stabilizes the clavicle
and pushes the acromion into the clavicle with the thumb&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""f10-04-9780323549479.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
