"<b>Shoulder Labral Tear</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>associated complication</u></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::paralabral cysts}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;causing compression on the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::suprascapular nerve}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Aspiration of paralabral cysts can be performed with image guidance&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">This has been shown to provide relief in 60% of patients,
although it is usually temporar7</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Failure to address the primary pathologic process may allow recurence of the cyst&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-319-98908-2_28/MediaObjects/395439_1_En_28_Figa_HTML.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>FABERE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(Patrick’s) test</span></b><div><br></div><div>Anterior pain is indicative of {{c1::intra / periarticular hip}} pathology</div><div><br></div><div>Posterior pain is indicative of&nbsp;{{c1::SI&nbsp;joint}}&nbsp;disorder</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_78.png"">"																				
Thomas Test: used to assess {{c1::hip flexion contractures}}	"<div>to a lesser extent tight IT band and quads</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_79.png""></div>"																				
"<b>Thomas Test</b><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>examiner will {{c2::maximally flex the hip and knee}}<br><br></div><div>
with the patient holding the thigh close to his body by pulling on the leg</div>
<div><br></div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Positive test: </span>the patient is&nbsp;{{c1::unable to keep the hip in the neutral
position}},&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div><img src=""1675938320864.jpg""><br></div>and it remains in any degree of <u>flexion</u> or associated <u>lumbosacral lordosis</u>&nbsp; (E and D, respectively)<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_79.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Ober Test:</b>&nbsp;for contraction of the {{c1::tensor fascia lata}} or {{c1::iliotibial band (ITB)}} tightness	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_80.png"">"																				
<b>Ober Test</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>With the patient side lying with the uninvolved leg on the table,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>flex the knee to 90 degrees and then allowed to lower from full abduction</div><div><br></div><div>Positive test: If the {{c1::thigh remains abducted}}</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_80.png"">"																				
<b>Femoral Nerve Stretch Test (Ely’s Test)</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>positive test is consistent with:<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Femoral nerve irritation}} and/or {{c1::upper lumbar radiculopathy}}</div>	"the best test to evaluate lumbar radiculopathy from an upper lumbar disc herniation ie L2, L3, L4<div><br></div><div>in this way seems analagous to the SLR.&nbsp; however, much more rare than L5-S1 radic</div><div><br></div><div>may also be positive in tight IT, rectus, or hip pain&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-05 at 8.54.57 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Femoral Nerve Stretch Test (aka&nbsp;{{c3::Ely’s}}&nbsp;Test)</b><div><br></div><div>With the patient lying {{c1::prone}}, flex the knee &gt;90 degrees and {{c1::extend}} the hip</div><div><br></div><div>positive test: {{c2::Pain in the anterior thigh}}</div>	"Tests for femoral neuropathy and upper lumbar radic<br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-05 at 8.54.57 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>True Leg Length Discrepancy</b><div><br></div><div>measure from the {{c1::anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)}} to the {{c2::medial malleolu}}s</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_82.png"">"																				
"<b>determine if Leg Length Discrepancy&nbsp;is due to femur or tibia</b><div><br></div><div><u>patient supine, flex the knees 90 degrees, feet flat on table</u></div><div><br></div><div>If one knee is <u>higher</u> than the other, that {{c1::tibia}} is longer (C)</div><div><br></div><div>If one knee projects <u>further</u> anteriorly, that {{c1::femur}} is longer (<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch04#fig4_82"">D</a>)&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>True leg length discrepancy has many causes, including fractures crossing the epiphyseal plate in childhood or poliomyelitis<br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_82.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Apparent Leg Length Discrepancy</b><div><br></div><div>Apparent leg length discrepancy may be caused by {{c1::pelvic obliquities}} or {{c1::hip deformity (flexion / adduction)}}</div><div><br></div><div>With the patient supine, measure from the {{c2::umbilicus}} to the {{c2::medial malleoli}} (from a nonfixed to a fixed landmark)</div>	"First, determine that no true leg length discrepancy exists<div><br></div><div>may also be assessed by observing the levelness posterior superior iliac spines<br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_83.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Hamstring Strain</b><div><br></div><div>Injuries typically occur during the {{c2::eccentric}} phase of muscle contraction&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and at the {{c1::myotendinous junction::injury location}}, most commonly in the {{c1::lateral}} hamstrings</div>	"<div>Note that the normal <u>strength ratio of hamstrings to quadriceps is 3:5</u></div><div><br></div><div>The hamstrings are placed under <u>maximal stretch when the hip is forced into flexion and the knee into extension</u></div><div><br></div><div>Predisposing factors associated with this strain include inadequate warm-up, poor flexibility, exercise fatigue, poor conditioning, and muscle imbalance</div><div><br></div><div>A rehab program needs to correct these risk factors as well as core stability deficits</div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#095cff"">Injuries range in severity from Grade I (strain) to Grade III (complete tear)</font></div><div><br></div><div>Most commonly seen in track and gymnastics injuries</div><div><img src=""hamstring-tear.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""1617614177_Hamstring_big_450.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Hamstring Strain</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Provocative test</u></div><div>Pain elicited in the {{c1::ischial}} region with {{c2::resisted knee flexion}}&nbsp;</div>	"and tenderness to palpation<div><img src=""partial-hamstring-tears.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Hip Flexor Strain</b><div><div><br></div><div>Occur due to eccentric overload of psoas muscle or as the athlete tries to {{c1::flex}} the {{c1::fully extended}} hip<br></div></div>	"such as in hurdling or kicking<div><br></div><div>Commonly seen in sprinting as well as in soccer, gymnastics, baseball, and football</div><div><img src=""7948713b-9b41-4879-93b9-2d112f84b155_mq.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Hip Flexor Strain</b><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>AP&nbsp;and {{c1::frog leg lateral}} views are used to exclude {{c2::apophyseal avulsion fracture}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>Injury to the apophyseal plate can occur in adolescent athletes (commonly seen at&nbsp;ASIS, ischial tuberosity,&nbsp;AIIS, lesser trochanter, iliac crest)</div><div><div><a></a></div><div><div><div><img src=""f081-005-9781455743766.jpg""></div></div></div></div><img src=""7aa283633c98bbbaffa2eff118c367_big_gallery.jpeg""><div><h2><span style=""font-weight: normal;"">To obtain the frog-leg lateral view, the patient should be positioned supine on the x-ray table with the hip of interest abducted 45 degrees, the ipsilateral knee flexed 30 to 40 degrees, and the ipsilateral heel resting against the contralateral knee (&nbsp;<a>Fig. 81-5&nbsp;</a>). The cassette is positioned so that the top of the film rests at the ASIS. The crosshairs of the beam are directed at a point midway between the ASIS and the pubic symphysis, with an x-ray tube–to-film distance of approximately 40 inches.</span></h2></div>"																				
"<b>Piriformis syndrome</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div><br></div><div>Pain may present in the {{c1::lateral}} {{c1:: buttock}}, and proximal {{c1::posterior}} {{c1::thigh/hip}}, as well as the general {{c1::SI::anatomic structure}}&nbsp;region</div><div><br></div><div>may be exacerbated by {{c2::walking up stairs::activity}} and activities that require {{c2::internal rotation::movement}}</div><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c3::Sitting on
hard surfaces}} may exacerbate symptoms of nubness and paresthesias, with radiation {{c3::but not into::into/but not into}} the leg&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>situation whereby the piriformis muscle is compressing the sciatic nerve, resulting in a sciatic neuropathy&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div>can be due to poor body mechanics in a chronic condition or an acute injury with forceful hip internal rotation<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">diagnosis is considered when signs of a lumbar radiculopathy elicited by provocative testing are absent,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">neurologic examination is normal, and </span><font color=""#fc0006"">other causes of gluteal and sacroiliac pain are ruled out</font><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>EMG and nerve conduction studies are rarely positive</u>, used to r/o other conditions</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">this <b>diagnosis is controversial</b> and may cuase anywhere from .1-6% of LBP</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-13 at 10.30.39 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div>{{c1::FAIR}} test, if positive is consistent with&nbsp;Piriformis syndrome&nbsp;</div>	"Pain with hip Flexion, Adduction, and Internal Rotation (FAIR) = pain in the buttocks<div><img src=""paste-1e7834580977e8a3ddc47fa715d8c14347d93d6d.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-13 at 10.37.22 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Piriformis Syndrome</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Stretching of the {{c1::external rotator}} hip muscles,&nbsp;NSAIDs, and US are the initial therapies</div><div>{{c2::Corticosteroid injections}} if more conservative measures fail</div>	"US as vastly more accurate than fluoro<div>botox has also been used&nbsp;<br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-13 at 10.44.51 PM.png""><br></div></div>"																				
Liner-Liner<div><br></div><div>primary purpose: {{c1::anti-perspirant}}&nbsp;</div>	"promote skin integrity and hygiene<div><br></div><div>reduce odor, absorb friction and inhibit growth of bacteria</div><div><br></div><div>less than 1 Ply so will not inhibit suspension of gel prosthetic liner</div><div><img src=""knit-rite-liner-liner-stump-sock-with-gel-pin-locking-liner-1SXLRGMD_1024x1024_2x_jpg_large.webp""><br></div>"																				
Urethane liner<div><br></div><div>primary purpose: {{c1::even pressure distribution}}</div>	"<div>Polyurethane liner provides even pressure distribution and a precise, comfortable fit for below-knee fittings</div><div><br></div><div>most advanced off-the-shelf liner with Anatomy Specific Geometry provides anatomical shape and different wall thicknesses&nbsp;</div><div>– thicker in sensitive areas to provide protection, and thinner in other areas to increase flexibility and wearer comfort</div><div><br></div><div>ideal for bony anatomy, scar or skin issues</div><div><br></div><div>may be impregnated with anti-bacterial material</div><div><img src=""6Y512-03-1200x1200.jpg""><br></div>"

"<div><b>Treatment Traumatic GHJ Instability (TUBS) ""early""</b><b><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></b></div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><div style=""font-weight: bold;""><b><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></b></div><u>Conservative</u></span><u>:<br></u><div>{{c1::<u>Sling</u>&nbsp;immobilization}}: Length of time is variable</div><div>{{c2::PROM}} with {{c2::Codman’s pendulum}}&nbsp;exercises<br></div><div>{{c3::<u>Isometric</u>}} exercises early in the recovery course</div>"	"Rehabilitation:&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;and strengthening of the shoulder–girdle complex&nbsp;<div><img src=""paste-cbaa80a7f1bc5f7a649a5089f041090c11936d53.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>{{c1::calcific tendonitis::dx}}</b></div><div><br></div><div>Sharp pain in the shoulder with&nbsp;ROM, particularly with shoulder abduction and overhead activities</div><div><br><div>AP&nbsp;x-ray of the shoulder showing {{c2::peri-articular densities}}&nbsp;</div></div>	"Surgical treatment is rare and reserved for patients with severe pain and inability to perform&nbsp;ADLs&nbsp;who have failed more conservative treatments<div><a href=""https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Fradiopaedia.org%2Farticles%2Fcalcific-tendinitis&amp;psig=AOvVaw05zQ6tMbdMfFD53Rh-2l-j&amp;ust=1682868624346000&amp;source=images&amp;cd=vfe&amp;ved=0CBAQjRxqFwoTCNCq1Ka0z_4CFQAAAAAdAAAAABBZ""><img src=""cfe3d47771ae940e59894b5ac666e2_gallery.jpg""></a></div><div><img src=""2221986.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><u>classification of slap tear</u><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Labral and biceps fraying}}, anchor {{c1::intact}} (11% of cases)</div>	"<div><div><u>classification of slap tear</u><br></div><div>1. Labral and biceps fraying, anchor intact (11% of cases)</div><div>2. Labral fraying with detached biceps tendon anchor (41% of cases)</div><div>3. Bucket handle tear, intact biceps tendon anchor&nbsp;(33% of cases) (Biceps separates from bucket handle tear)</div><div>4. Bucket handle tear with detached biceps tendon anchor (15% of cases) (Biceps remains attached to bucket handle tear</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-30 at 11.23.43 AM.png"">"																				
<div><u>classification of slap tear</u><br></div><div>4. {{c1::Bucket handle tear}} with {{c1::detached biceps tendon}} anchor&nbsp;<br></div>	"<div><div><u>classification of slap tear</u><br></div><div>1. Labral and biceps fraying, anchor intact (11% of cases)</div><div>2. Labral fraying with detached biceps tendon anchor (41% of cases)</div><div>3. Bucket handle tear, intact biceps tendon anchor&nbsp;(33% of cases) (Biceps separates from bucket handle tear)</div><div>4. Bucket handle tear with detached biceps tendon anchor (15% of cases) (Biceps remains attached to bucket handle tear</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-30 at 11.23.43 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::Illiopsoas tendonitis / bursitis}}</b><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);""><u>clinical presentation</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);"">pain at the proximal aspect of the thigh, anterior groin, lower abdomen</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(2, 6, 33);""><u>physical examination</u></span></div><div><font color=""#020621"">pain with&nbsp;</font>{{c2::<font color=""#020621"">resisted hip</font>&nbsp;flexion}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>aka hip flexor tendonitis</div><div><br></div><div>etiology inflammation of the muscle tendon unit and bursa occur with overuse or trauma, causing muscle tightness and imbalance</div><div><br></div><div>may cause anterior snapping hip<br></div><div><br></div><div>Treatment</div><div>- Ice,&nbsp;NSAIDs, stretching, and strengthening</div><div>- Corticosteroid injection if conservative measures fail</div><img src=""52afccc219dcb8fad574e70555b94c702317b01f-1500x1500.jpg""><br>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">proximal Iliotibial band syndrome aka&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<u>external</u> snapping hip syndrome}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS) or iliotibial band friction syndrome is an overuse injury <u>typically referring to
lateral knee pain</u>,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">as a result of impingement of the distal
ITB over the <b>lateral femoral epicondyle</b>.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>Less commonly,
ITBS may refer to hip pain</u> associated with movement of
the ITB across the <b>greater trochanter.&nbsp;</b></span></div><div><img src=""External-Snapping-Hip.webp""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b><br></b></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<strong>External snapping hip syndrome</strong>:<div>May be due to a tight&nbsp;{{c1::ITB}}&nbsp;or gluteus maximus snapping over the {{c1::greater trochanter}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_84.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><strong>Internal snapping hip syndrome</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>May be a result of a tight {{c1::iliopsoas tendon (tendonitis)}} snapping over the {{c1::ilio-pectineal prominence}} of the pelvis</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::acetabular labral tear}} or {{c2::loose body/cartilage injury}} in the hip joint are on the differential as well, although less common&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""62_x110_i040.png""><div><img src=""snapping-hip.png""></div>"																				
"<div><b>proximal&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Iliotibial band syndrome</span></b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Patients may complain of hip snapping or clicking {{c1::with or without::with pain/without pain}} pain</div><div>Tenderness over tensor fascia lata/ITB&nbsp;or gluteus maximus&nbsp;</div><div>Tenderness in anterior groin&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>Provocative Tests</u></div><div>passively {{c2::internally}} and {{c2::externally rotate}} the hip with pt in lateral decubitus</div>"	<div>External snapping hip syndrome: Internally and externally rotate the hip passively while the patient is in the lateral decubitus position.</div><div><br></div><div>Internal snapping hip syndrome: Extend, abduct, and externally rotate the affected hip.</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>snapping hip syndrome&nbsp;</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Relative rest, ice, and&nbsp;NSAIDs</div><div>Rehab focuses on {{c1::correction of biomechanics}}, as well as&nbsp;ROM/stretching</div>"	"<img src=""External-Snapping-Hip.webp"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::Hip adductor strain}}</b><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>Predisposing factors include relative {{c2::weakness/tightness}} of the muscle groups<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Presents as pain in the groin t<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">hat may radiate down
to the&nbsp;</span>{{c3::antero-medial}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;thigh&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>Provacative Tests</u></span></div><div>Pain with resisted {{c4::adduction}} and occasionally with {{c4::hip flexion}}</div>"	"A common injury in sports, groin strain occurs due to resisted forceful abduction of the hip<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">refers to an injury of the hip adductor
muscles at the muscle belly, myotendinous junction, or
tendon</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">It can be an acute or chronic injury</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-06 at 1.51.18 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""pulled-groin-muscle-anatomy-image-credit-bruceblaus-2015-november-10.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<b>hip adductor strain</b><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Radiographs of the hip needed urgently to rule out {{c1::avulsion}} of the {{c1::adductor tubercle}}</div>	"MRI is the optimal study<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-02 at 8.50.28 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-06 at 1.52.27 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Hip ADductor strain</b><div><br></div><div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Rest, ice,&nbsp;NSAIDs, and then advance to stretching and strengthening</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">t/c weight bearing as tolerated with
crutches, discontinue sports</span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Associated&nbsp;</span>{{c2::TP's along the adductor muscle}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;may be treated with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::trigger point injections}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div>{{c1::u/s guided injection (+/- PRP)}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Most athletes who undergo
adductor longus tenotomy return to competitive sports
within 3 months&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><img src=""4-Figure3-1.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-03 at 9.04.47 PM.png""></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-03 at 9.05.10 PM.png""><br><div><br><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Start by placing the probe in the transverse
view over the pubic tubercle.&nbsp;</div><div>Then move the transducer lat-erally until the three layers of adductor muscles appear&nbsp;</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Needle position: Advance the needle under direct ultrasound
visualization so that the needle tip is directed just outside the
desired adductor tendon or to the fascial plane of the obturator
nerve division of interest&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div>"																				
"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS)</b> </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>associated risk factors:</u>&nbsp;</span><div>{{c1::leg length discrepancy}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c2::gait abnormalities}}<br></div><div>{{c3::iliotibial
band tightness}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">as well as:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hip&nbsp;</span>OA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, obesity</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, direct trauma, overuse, herniated lumbar disc, and hemiparesis</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">""</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">associated with a number of conditions that cause altered gait mechanics, muscle imbalance, and reduced flexibility""</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u><br></u></span></div>continuum of disorders including</u>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">gluteus medius and minimus tears,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">gluteus medius and minimus&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">tendinitis, or tendinopathy</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">trochanteric bursitis</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">external snapping</span></div><div><img src=""e3e8d917e4a34f39a64fca70dcccce6c.aspx""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>Greater trochanteric pain syndrome</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">lateral hip pain that can&nbsp;</span>{{c1::radiate down}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lateral thigh}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">worsened by&nbsp;</span>{{c3::external rotation}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c3::abduction}} (joint position)&nbsp;</div><div>Patients reports they are unable to {{c2::lie on the affected side}}</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Symptoms are exacerbated by hip
movements,&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">in particular external rotation and abduction</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Pain may also be provoked by standing, walking, stair
climbing, crossing the legs, running&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_85.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Greater trochanteric pain syndrome</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></b></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>Tenderness over the greater trochanter on palpation or during movement from full extension to flexion</div><div>FABER localizing pain to the lateral hip</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Lateral hip pain may be reproduced with resisted&nbsp;</span>{{c2::hip abduction}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;with the patient in
a&nbsp;</span>{{c2::side-lying}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;position&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Pain can also be elicited with active hip&nbsp;</span>{{c3::internal}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c3::external rotation}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;at 45 degrees of hip flexion&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">evaluation of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::leg length discrepancy}}</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""paste-fa5172c31c22d8f7bc7d69f29cf65d98484f285b.jpg"">"																				
<b>GTPS</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::ITB}}&nbsp;stretching and&nbsp;NSAIDs</div><div>In severe cases, {{c2::DME (a cane)}} may be needed&nbsp;</div><div>Strengthening of the {{c1::hip abductor}} muscles</div><div>{{c3::corticosteroid injection (+/- u/s guidance)}} for resistant cases</div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">therapy is first line&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">For cases unresponsive to noninvasive treatments, cortico-steroid injections</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">some studies have found injections effective in the short term, other studies report incomplete long-term re-lief and symptom recurrence&nbsp;</span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Caution must be exercised with repeated injection</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-03 at 8.54.45 PM.png""></div><div>Needle position: The needle is advanced under ultrasound
guidance into the fluid-filled bursal sac if visualized;&nbsp;</div><div>other-wise, it is placed both superficial and deep to the gluteus
medius tendon,&nbsp;</div><div>in the subtrochanteric or subgluteus medius
bursa, respectively.&nbsp;</div><div>Half of the medication may be injected
into each site to cover both bursae.<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;<br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"{{c1::posterior}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is the most common type of <u>hip</u> dislocation (90%)</span>"	"<img src=""PastedGraphic-1.jpeg"">"																				
<div><b>posterior hip dislocation</b></div><div><br></div><u>complications</u><div>common etiology: {{c3::MVC (knee strikes the dashboard)}}&nbsp;</div><div>the {{c1::sciatic}} nerve may be injured</div><div>AVN&nbsp;may occur in {{c2::10}}% of patients</div>	In this position, the head of the femur is covered posteriorly by the capsule and not by bone<div><br><div>Due to the close proximity of the sciatic nerve to the hip posteriorly</div><div><br></div><div>Note: Anterior hip dislocations may result in femoral nerve compromise</div><div><br></div><div>AVN&nbsp;may occur in 10% to 20% of patients</div></div>																				
<b>posterior hip dislocation</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>hip will be flexed, {{c2::adDucted::aB/aD}}, and {{c2::internally::int/ext}} rotated</div><div>affected leg appears {{c1::shorter}}</div><div>inability to {{c1::aBduct}} the affected hip</div>	"because the dislocated femoral head is higher than the normal side<div><img src=""360_F_82637760_APRlGZJK7aZyGPMlYErCv6GrsqAZQ9vR.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>posterior hip dislocation</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>{{c1::Hip xray}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c2::emergent orthopedic consult}}</div></div></div>	"<div><div><div>CT helps to determine direction of dislocation, loose bodies, and associated fractures</div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">post reduction CT</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">must be performed for all traumatic hip dislocations</span><br></div><div><br></div><div>This is an orthopedic emergency due to potential vascular compromise and sciatic nerve injury</div></div><div><img src=""604ef89c9cc3f8878052e1866d6b4a_gallery.jpg""><br></div><div><div><b>TREATMENT</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Nonoperative</u></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">emergent closed reduction within 12 hours</span>&nbsp;</strong></div><div>indications</div><div>acute anterior and posterior dislocations</div><div>contraindications</div><div>ipsilateral displaced or non-displaced femoral neck fracture</div><div><br></div><div><u>Operative</u></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">open reduction and/or removal of incarcerated fragments</span></strong></div><div>indications</div><div>irreducible dislocation</div><div>radiographic evidence of incarcerated fragment</div><div>delayed presentation</div><div>non-concentric reduction</div><div>should be performed on urgent basis</div></div>"																				
<div><div><b>clavicular fractures</b><u><br></u></div><u><div><u><br></u></div>Conservative Treatment</u><div>immobilization with a {{c1::simple sling}} or {{c1::figure-8 sling}}</div><div>for {{c2::3}} to {{c2::6}} weeks depending on the age</div></div>	"<div>Progressive&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;may be initiated after 3 weeks of immobilization</div><div><img src=""paste-4def5bf2f8bae82be83b46fe00fd826036114b3b.jpg""><br></div><div><div><b>TREATMENT distal calvicle</b></div><div><br></div><div>Nonoperative</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sling immobilization with gentle ROM exercises at 2-4 weeks and strengthening at 6-10 weeks</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">stable fractures (Neer Type I, III, IV)</span></div><div>pediatric distal clavicle fractures (skeletally immature)</div><div><br></div><div>Operative</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">open reduction internal fixation</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;absolute</div><div>open or impending open fractures</div><div>subclavian artery or vein injury</div><div>floating shoulder (distal clavicle and scapula neck fractures with &gt; 10mm of displacement)</div><div>symptomatic nonunion</div><div><u>relative</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">unstable fracture patterns (Neer Type IIA, IIB, V)</span></div><div>brachial plexus injury (questionable because 66% have spontaneous return)</div><div>closed head injury</div><div>seizure disorder</div><div>polytrauma patient</div><div><br></div><div><b>TREATMENT Mid clavicle&nbsp;</b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">Nonoperative</span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>&lt; 2cm shortening and displacement</div><div>&lt; 1cm displacement of the superior shoulder suspensory complex&nbsp;</div><div>closed and no neurovascular injury</div><div>low demand patient&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>modalities:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sling,&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">figure-of-8 strap</span></div><div>elevate and extend shoulder to bring distal fragment to the proximal fragment</div><div><br></div><div>outcomes&nbsp;</div><div>figure-of-8 associated with more pain, shortening, and lower compliance than sling</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">no difference in functional or cosmetic outcomes between sling and figure-of-eight braces</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">Operative</span>&nbsp;</div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;</div><div>absolute</div><div>open fractures</div><div>displaced fracture with skin tenting&nbsp;</div><div>subclavian artery or vein injury</div><div>floating shoulder (clavicle and scapular neck fracture)</div><div>relative and controversial indications</div><div>displaced with<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;&gt; 2cm shortening&nbsp;</span></div><div>bilateral displaced clavicle fractures</div><div>brachial plexus injury (questionable because 66% have spontaneous return)</div><div>closed head injury</div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><table><tbody><tr><th><i>Clinical recommendation</i></th><th><i>Evidence "<div>Patient with a past medical history significant for kidney transplant&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>presents with pain in the groin and anterior thigh,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Short swing and stance phase on the affected side</div><div><br></div><div>next step: {{c1::MRI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of both hips</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is indicated</span></div>"	"MRI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is most sensitive to early changes in AVN</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">low signal intensity on T1 imaging that may appear as rings, wedges, or irregular configurations</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">T2 images may show a double line sign with a high signal intensity zone inside of a low signal intensity margin</span><font color=""#333333""><br></font><div><img src=""d906d6b208679afa5719df877eeca4_gallery.jpeg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
"{{c1::Trendelenburg test}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span>Physical exam maneuver that is more senitive for an L5 motor radic than EHL"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Trendelenburg test. (A) Negative. (B) Positive.</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_81.png"">"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">osteonecrosis (</span>AVN<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) of the hip</span><br></b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Bracing and casting may help in the pediatric AVN, aka {{c3::Legg–Calvé–Perthes disease}}</div><div>Femoral head {{c2::core decompression}} may be used when there is no&nbsp;compromise of the morphology</div><div>Adults may require {{c1::total hip arthroplasty (THA)}} in later stages with femoral head collapse</div>"	"The main objective is to maintain the femoral head within the acetabulum while healing and remodeling occurs<div><img src=""core-decompression-for-avascular-necrosis-of-the-hip.jpg""></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-04 at 8.41.52 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Osteoporosis of the hip</b><div><br></div><div><u>Modifiable risk factors:</u></div><div>{{c1::Alcohol}} and caffeine consumption</div><div>{{c1::Smoking}}</div><div>{{c1::steroids}}&nbsp;</div><div>(Medications: PPI, antipsychotics, benzodiazepines, AED's)</div><div>Malnutrition</div><div>Body weight &lt;90% of ideal</div>	"<div>Nonmodifiable risk factors include age, sex, and race:</div><div>- Approximately 60% of hip fractures occur in patients &gt;75 years of age.</div><div>- Females have higher incidence of hip fracture than males.</div><div>- Among females, there is a 2 to 3:1 higher rate of fracture in European Americans than in African Americans</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-04 at 9.07.02 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Surgery for hip fracture and degeneration</b><div><br></div><div><u>risks of morbidity and mortality:</u></div><div>Venous thrombosis occurs in &gt;50% of unprotected patients; highest PE risk during the {{c1::2nd}} and {{c1::3rd}} week post-op</div><div>incidence of heterotopic ossification is high (&gt;{{c2::50}}%) after THA, although &lt;10% lose&nbsp;ROM</div><div>mortality rate for those who survive a hip fracture is approximately {{c3::40}}% after 2 years</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Postoperatively, complications can include nonunion or&nbsp;</span>{{c4::osteonecrosis (AVN)}}<br></div>"	<div>may want to look up/clarify the mortality???</div><div><br></div>Approximately 50% of patients return to their premorbid level of functioning<div>mortality rate for those who survive a hip fracture is 20% to 30% after 1 year and approximately 40% after 2 years<br></div>																				
<b>Fractures of the femoral neck are classified by Garden classification:</b><div><br></div><div>Stage I: {{c1::Incomplete}}, nondisplaced with occasional {{c1::valgus angulation}}</div>	"<div><b>Fractures of the femoral neck are classified by Garden classification:</b><br></div><div>Stage I: Incomplete, nondisplaced with occasional valgus angulation</div><div>Stage II: Complete, nondisplaced, occasionally unstable</div><div>Stage III: Displaced with the hip joint capsule partially intact</div><div>Stage IV: Displaced with the hip joint capsule completely disrupted</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_88.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Fractures of the femoral neck are classified by Garden classification:</b></div><div>Stage II: {{c1::Complete}}, {{c1::nondisplaced}}, occasionally unstable</div>	"<div><b>Fractures of the femoral neck are classified by Garden classification:</b><br></div><div>Stage I: Incomplete, nondisplaced with occasional valgus angulation</div><div>Stage II: Complete, nondisplaced, occasionally unstable</div><div>Stage III: Displaced with the hip joint capsule partially intact</div><div>Stage IV: Displaced with the hip joint capsule completely disrupted</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_88.png""></div>"																				
<div><b>Fractures of the femoral neck are classified by&nbsp;{{c2::Garden}}&nbsp;classification:</b></div><div>Stage III: {{c1::Displaced}} with the hip joint capsule {{c1::partially intact}}</div>	"<div><b>Fractures of the femoral neck are classified by Garden classification:</b><br></div><div>Stage I: Incomplete, nondisplaced with occasional valgus angulation</div><div>Stage II: Complete, nondisplaced, occasionally unstable</div><div>Stage III: Displaced with the hip joint capsule partially intact</div><div>Stage IV: Displaced with the hip joint capsule completely disrupted</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_88.png""></div>"																				
<div><b>Fractures of the femoral neck are classified by Garden classification:</b></div><div>Stage IV: {{c1::Displaced}} with the hip joint capsule {{c1::completely disrupted}}</div>	"<div><b>Fractures of the femoral neck are classified by Garden classification:</b><br></div><div>Stage I: Incomplete, nondisplaced with occasional valgus angulation</div><div>Stage II: Complete, nondisplaced, occasionally unstable</div><div>Stage III: Displaced with the hip joint capsule partially intact</div><div>Stage IV: Displaced with the hip joint capsule completely disrupted</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_88.png""></div>"																				
<div><b>hip fracture</b><u><br></u></div><u><div><u><br></u></div>Clinical Features</u><div>Common presentation is hip pain, limb {{c1::externally}} rotated, and an apparent {{c1::shortened}} limb&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""f014-001-9780443067181.jpg"">"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Garden femoral neck fracture&nbsp;</span>Stages I and II (Nondisplaced):&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><u>Surgical Treatment (options)</u><div>{{c1::Surgical Pins::category}}</div><div>{{c1::cannulated screw fixation::example}}</div><div>{{c1::sliding hip screw::example}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Conservative (indications)</u></div><div>unfit for surgery</div><div>{{c2::non-ambulatory}}</div><div>{{c2::chronic impacted fracture}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""f014-011-9780443067181.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""31_p090_i020_b13.png""><img src=""31_p050_a_i020_a12.png""><br></div><div><b>Fig.&nbsp;</b>internal fixation of femoral neck fx:&nbsp;</div><div>(a) multiple pins; (b) crossed screw-nails; (c) compression with dynamic screw and plate.</div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_88.png"">"																				
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Garden femoral neck fracture&nbsp;</span>Stages 3 and 4&nbsp;(displaced):&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Surgical&nbsp;Treatment:</u></div><div>{{c1::bipolar/monopolar hemiarthroplasty}} or {{c1::total hip replacement}}</div></div>"	"<div>controversial, sounds like its for the elderly</div><img src=""f34-06.jpg""><img src=""hip-replacement-implants.jpg""><div><div>partial hip replacement, only the head of the femur (thigh bone) is replaced and the new prosthetic head rotates in the natural hip socket</div><div>THA performed when there is cartilage damage on both the femoral head and within the socket</div><div>candidates for partial hip replacement have no underlying hip arthritis and have healthy acetabular cartilage</div><div>This is the case for someone who has fractured the femoral neck</div></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_88.png""><br></div>"																				
Bipolar hemi-arthroplasty differs from monopolar by {{c1::allowing motion at two sites}}<div><br></div><div><div>Theoretically reduces friction and impact</div></div>	"<div><div>Prosthetic innerbearing surface and prosthetic-bearing acetabular surface</div><div>Acetabular erosion and protrusion should theoretically be reduced by reducing motion at the acetabulum</div></div><img src=""f34-06.jpg""><img src=""hip-replacement-implants.jpg""><div><div>partial hip replacement, only the head of the femur (thigh bone) is replaced and the new prosthetic head rotates in the natural hip socket</div><div>THA performed when there is cartilage damage on both the femoral head and within the socket</div><div>candidates for partial hip replacement have no underlying hip arthritis and have healthy acetabular cartilage</div><div>This is the case for someone who has fractured the femoral neck</div></div>"																				
<b>Muscles Active During Gait Cycle</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>all are eccentric except for...</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::iliopsoas}} always</div><div>{{c1::calf m's}} after {{c1::midstance}}</div><div>{{c3::pretibial m's}} during {{c3::swing phase}}&nbsp;</div><div>+/- {{c2::quadriceps}} during {{c2::phase??}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-18 at 6.31.28 PM.png"">"																				
<div><div><b>Femoral Neck Fracture Garden Stages I and II: s/p Surgical Pin</b></div></div><div><br></div><div><u>Postoperative restrictions</u></div><div>{{c1::elderly}} patient may start with WBAT with walking aid the day after surgery</div><div><div>Initial restricted weight bearing is required for the {{c1::young}} patient</div><div>reassessed at {{c2::6}} weeks</div><div>{{c2::Unrestricted}} range-of-motion exercises of the hip joint are allowed</div></div>	"<img src=""31_r001_i080.png"">"																				
<b>Femoral Neck Fracture Garden Stages III and IV: s/p&nbsp;</b>hemiarthroplasty or total hip replacement<div><br></div><div><u>Postop rehabilitation:</u><div>Rehabilitation of {{c1::cemented}} cases by immediate full weight bearing</div><div>Rehabilitation of {{c1::uncemented}} cases may be partial or full weight bearing</div></div>																					
"{{c1::Sepsis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is a cause of dislocation after hip replacement and must be considered</span>"																					
"<b>THA Posterior Approach</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Advantages</u></div><div>Allows for&nbsp;{{c3::extensive exposure of proximal femur/acetabulum}}<b><font color=""#fc0006"">^</font><br></b><div>{{c1::Most::most/least}} commonly-performed THA</div><div>Shorter {{c2::OR time}}</div></div>"	"<div>Splits fascia latae;&nbsp;splits glut max; tenotomy of&nbsp;piriformis &amp; short external rotator muscles,&nbsp;posterior joint capsule split<br></div><div><div>Femoral head dislocated by internally rotating hip</div><div>Lateral recumbent position in OR</div><div>Post-op x-rays (alignment &amp; leg length)&nbsp;later in recovery room</div><div>Careful reconstruction of posterior joint capsule and short external rotators reduces dislocation risk by factor of 8</div><div><u><b><font color=""#fc0006"">^</font></b>exposure for complex bony defects, revisions, pathologic&nbsp;fx, intra-op&nbsp;fx</u></div></div><div><img src=""paste-37afeee9cbf772f7f02429d802a184ac6a08d7af.jpg""><img src=""paste-b519d7f7f392859b411cf90a061c212bc2e5d09f.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>THA Posterior Approach</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>total hip precautions</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Avoid hip&nbsp;</span>{{c1::flexion}}<font color=""#333333"">&nbsp;</font>over {{c1::90 degrees}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Avoid hip&nbsp;</span>{{c1::adduction}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;past&nbsp;</span>{{c1::midline}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">extreme hip&nbsp;</span>{{c1::internal rotation}}<u><br></u></div><div><br></div><div><u>ADL modification</u></div><div>Must {{c2::sleep on back}} with an {{c2::abduction pillow}}</div><div>No {{c2::driving}}</div><div>Avoid {{c2::low chairs/toilets}}</div><div><br></div><div>precautions in place for {{c3::3 months::time}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">must be followed to avoid dislocation</span><div><img src=""230B-f__23063.1635859100.1280.1280.jpg""></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-06 at 9.10.19 AM.png""><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
"<b>THA Anterior Approach</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>total hip precautions</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">avoidance of hip&nbsp;</span>{{c1::extension}} past neutral<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">avoidance of hip&nbsp;</span>{{c1::external rotation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>past neutral</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>ADL modification</u></div><div>Drive in {{c2::2}} weeks</div><div>
<div>Sleep in {{c2::any}} position</div>
<div>Most walk without AD in {{c3::6::same}} weeks&nbsp;<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>Dislocation precautions for {{c3::6::same}} weeks (surgeon specific)<br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">avoidance of hip extension and external rotation (i.e., opposite of posterior&nbsp;</span>THA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;precautions).</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">no hip precuations??? per thommen conflicts with&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""paste-a07f7d3359cddc80371e028668189f3522e3ce60.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>THA Anterior Approach</b><div><br></div><div><u>Advantages</u></div><div>Less likely to cause {{c2::leg length discrepancy}}</div><div>Less likely to cause {{c2::ABductor insufficency}}<b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b><br></div><div>
<div>Dislocation rate at least {{c1::10}}x lower<span style=""color: yellow;"">&nbsp;</span><br></div></div><div><div>{{c3::weight bearing}} much sooner</div></div><div>Shorter {{c3::hospital LOS}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Disadvantages</u></div><div>higher risk of {{c4::lateral femoral cutaneous}}<b><font color=""#fc0006"">^</font></b> neuropathy&nbsp;</div><div>compared to the {{c6::sciatic}} neuropathy of the PA<br></div><div>can not be used for {{c5::revisions}}</div>"	"<div>Specialized traction (Hana – $700K) table with bilateral boots, femoral
bone hook &amp; perineal post allow positioning of either leg<br></div>
<div>Supine position (easier on pts with
heart &amp; lung disease) </div>
<div>True intermuscular incision
(between TFL &amp; sartorius, then rectus femoris &amp; glut med), &amp;
inter-neural interval.&nbsp; Anterior joint
capsule is split&nbsp;</div>
<div>“Muscle-sparing” least likely to disrupt soft tissue
anatomy</div>
<div>Spares short, external rotators
(posterior internal muscle sleeve – piriformis, obturators and gemellae)&nbsp; </div>
<div>Fluoroscopic AP check of leg-length
&amp; alignment in OR </div>
<div>Primary THAs; not revisions,
complex proximal femoral pathology, or prior pelvic or femoral hardware</div>
<div>Shorter hospital LOS (home POD # 1
or 2)</div>
<div>15%-20% of THA surgeries</div><div><b><font color=""#fc0006""><br></font></b></div><div><b><font color=""#fc0006"">^</font></b>risk of femoral neuropathy same across all approaches (0-
2.4%)&nbsp;</div><div><b><font color=""#fc0006"">*</font></b>trendellenberg 0-16% with PA and 4-20% with LA<br></div><div><img src=""paste-13ed457fb7a7325ac82e97ad96bc0a25ac42ae82.jpg""><img src=""01-anterior-hip-table.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div>reverse TSA is indicated over a TSA when there is {{c1::Loss or paralysis of RTC muscles}}</div>	"<div>a pt with R-TSA may never regain external rot/ aBd (Verobej)</div><img src=""diagram-total-shoulder-arthroplasty.jpg""><div><img src=""Anatomic+reverse+total+shoulder+replacement.png""></div>"																				
"<div>absolute contra-indication to both TSA <u>and</u>
reverse TSA: {{c1::Loss or paralysis of both RTC and
deltoids}}</div>"	"<img src=""diagram-total-shoulder-arthroplasty.jpg""><div><img src=""Anatomic+reverse+total+shoulder+replacement.png""></div>"																				
<u>THA absolute contraindication</u><div>infection</div><div>{{c1::osteoperosis}}</div>																					
<u>TKA absolute contraindication</u><div><div>Recent or recurrent&nbsp;knee sepsis</div><div>{{c1::Dysfunction of extensor&nbsp;mechanism}}<br></div></div>																					
"{{c1::Intertrochanteric}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;hip fracture&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is the most common type of hip fracture</span>"	"<div><img src=""1474753935271.jpg""><img src=""1474753936148.jpg""><b><br></b></div><b><div><b><br></b></div>Femoral neck fracture:&nbsp;</b><div>occurs one to two inches from the <font color=""#0d5eff""><b>hip joint</b></font><div>common among older adults and can be related to osteoporosis</div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">usually cuts off the blood supply</font> to the head of the femur</div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Intertrochanteric hip fracture:&nbsp;</b></div><div>occurs three to four inches from the hip joint, <b><font color=""#0027ff"">extra-capsular&nbsp;</font></b></div><div><font color=""#18b712"">does not interrupt the blood supply</font> to the bone&nbsp;</div><div>may be easier to repair</div></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Intertrochanteric hip fractures</b></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>morbidity</u></span></div><div>Highly fragmented fractures may result in significant {{c1::blood loss}}&nbsp;</div><div>Postoperatively, a {{c2::leg length discrepancy}} may result&nbsp;</div>"	"- Moderately high forces are generated in this area, and a strong fixation is required<div><div>- Fractures may be nondisplaced, displaced two-part fractures, or unstable three-part fracture</div></div><div>AO class</div><div><img src=""c537852e-5958-40a9-86f9-db831e52ed68_ao_ota_31a_classification.jpg""><br></div><div>evans class</div><div><img src=""027e4d69-e2da-414e-ac6a-8f9ecabd3404_evans.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_89.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Intertrochanteric hip fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div>Treatment is typically {{c1::Surgical::op/non-op}}</div>"																					
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Intertrochanteric hip fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Surgical&nbsp;</span>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::sliding hip screw (A compression screw or angle nail plate) may be used}}<br></div><div>If the fixation is unstable, {{c2::medial displacement osteotomy}} of the femur may be required</div>"	"angle nail plate = sliding hip screw<br><div><img src=""paste-ef742435ad3a49fbaa0a92d6c7c929de9c8c56e0.jpg""><img src=""paste-b6ab377976c9ad812bae53fabf2deca8e230584a.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""pauwel-osteotomy.png""><br></div><div>One goal of a proximal femoral osteotomy (PFO) is to alter the biomechanics of the hip</div><div>Treatment rationale is aimed at changing the area of contact to a disease-free area of cartilage<br></div><div>1st done for AVN&nbsp;or in peds for subluxation</div><div><img src=""DA7C57FF5.gif""><span style=""color: rgb(127, 126, 126);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""1-s2.0-S1877056812002824-gr17.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""B9781437706956000107_f10-09-9781437706956.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""F000450f045-006b-9780443069918.jpg""><br></div><div>Operative</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">intramedullary hip screw (cephalomedullary nail)&nbsp;</strong></div><div>intramedullary</div><div><b><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">o</span></b><b><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">pen reduction and internal fixation (ORIF)</span></b></div><div>extra medularry techniques</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">sliding hip compression (SHS) screw (</span><font color=""#0027ff"">most common</font><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">proximal femur locking plate</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Intertrochanteric hip fracture</b></span><br><div><br></div><div><u>Post-op Precuations:</u></div><div>Progress from {{c1::partial}} to {{c1::full weight bearing}}</div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Subtrochanteric femur fractures</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Treatment Surgical</u>:</div><div>ORIF&nbsp;will be necessary with several choices of fixation hardware</div><div>most commonly treated with an {{c1::intramedullary (IM) rod}}</div><div>a {{c1::blade plate w/ screws}} may be sufficient in some cases</div>"	"<img src=""1-s2.0-S1877056815001772-gr2.jpg""><br><div><b>TREATMENT</b></div><div><br></div><div>Nonoperative</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">observation with pain management</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>-&nbsp;non-ambulatory patients with medical co-morbidities that would not allow them to tolerate surgery</div><div>- limited role due to strong muscular forces displacing fracture and inability to mobilize patients without surgical intervention</div><div><br></div><div>Operative</div><div><b><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">intramedullary nailing</span>&nbsp;</b>(usually cephalomedullary)&nbsp;</div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>- newer design of intramedullary nails has expanded indications</div><div>- most subtrochanteric fractures treated with IM nail</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">fixed angle plate</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>-&nbsp;surgeon preference</div><div>- associated femoral neck fracture</div><div>- pre-existing femoral shaft deformity</div>"																				
<div><b>femoral-neck stress fractures</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>There are two basic types: {{c1::Compression}} and {{c1::transverse}}</div>	"<div><img src=""image-asset.png""><br></div><img src=""a4e62322-2567-4550-ac29-02d36cdca6f5_compression_diagram.jpg""><img src=""26d9ef14-4063-4442-bb19-f8997f375d32_tension_diagram.jpg""><div><br></div>"																				
<div><b>femoral-neck stress fractures</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Compression-type fractures</u>&nbsp;</div><div>generally occur along the {{c2::inferior}}-{{c2::medial}} neck of the femur</div><div>They are more {{c1::stable::stable/unstable}}</div>	"<div><img src=""image-asset.png""><br></div><img src=""a4e62322-2567-4550-ac29-02d36cdca6f5_compression_diagram.jpg""><img src=""26d9ef14-4063-4442-bb19-f8997f375d32_tension_diagram.jpg""><div><br></div>"																				
<div><b>femoral-neck stress fractures</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Transverse-type fractures</u>&nbsp;</div><div>occur with the fracture along the {{c1::superior}}-{{c1::lateral}} aspect of the femur neck</div><div>These are more {{c2::unstable::stable/unstable}}</div>	"<div><img src=""image-asset.png""><br></div><img src=""a4e62322-2567-4550-ac29-02d36cdca6f5_compression_diagram.jpg""><img src=""26d9ef14-4063-4442-bb19-f8997f375d32_tension_diagram.jpg"">"																				
<b>femoral-neck stress fractures</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>present as {{c1::groin pain}} that worsens {{c2::throughout exercise}}</div><div>often pain at extreme ranges of motion</div>	"<b>PRESENTATION</b><div><br></div><div><u>History</u></div><div>- history of&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">overuse</span>&nbsp;running activities&nbsp;</div><div>- recent increase in training&nbsp;</div><div>- high impact activities&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>Symptoms</u></div><div>-&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">insidious</span>&nbsp;onset of thigh or groin pain, may radiate to knee</div><div>- pain increases with repetitive weight-bearing activities</div><div><font color=""#0027ff"">- may cuase patient to stop running</font></div><div><font color=""#0027ff"">- night pain</font></div><div>- pain improves with cessation of activity</div><div><font color=""#fc0507"">- unlike many injuries that improve after initial 15min of activity</font></div><div><br></div><div><u>Physical exam</u></div><div>- tenderness directly over groin region (62%)</div><div>- pain with extremes of hip motion (79%)</div><div>- antalgic gait</div><div>- provocative tests: straight leg raise, log roll, or axial load</div>"																				
<div><b>femoral neck stress fracture</b></div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>Physical exam</u></div><div>provocative tests: {{c1::intrarticular tests (eg. stinchfeild, log roll, FABER)::phys/ex category}}</div><div>or {{c2::axial load (eg thigh thrust)}}<br></div>	<div>tenderness directly over groin region (62%)</div><div>pain with extremes of hip IR/ER (79%)</div>																				
"<b>femoral neck <u>stress</u> fracture</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>epidimeiology</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">should be suspected in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Endurance athletes}}<u><br></u></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">such as runners, triathletes, and military recruits, are susceptible to proximal femoral stress fractures</span>"																				
<b>femoral neck stress fracture</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Radiographs typically negative at first and in time may show {{c2::periosteal thickening}} or a {{c2::radiolucent line}}</div><div>If plain films are negative, a {{c1::bone scan}} used to be done, may be positive 2 to 8 days after onset of symptoms</div><div>largely supplanted by {{c3::MRI}} which is the study of choice</div>	"<img src=""xr compression side.jpg""><img src=""bne scan stress.jpg""><div><img src=""mri fn stress compression side .jpg""><img src=""8B_moved.JPG""></div>"																				
<b>femoral neck <u>stress</u> fracture</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>non operative treatment</u><b>&nbsp;</b></div><div>{{c1::Compression type &lt;50% width::indication}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>ORIF</u></div><div>{{c1::tension sided (w/ MRI changes)::indication}}</div><div>{{c1::Compression type &gt;50% width::indication}}</div>	"<div><div><b>TREATMENT</b></div></div><div><br></div><div>Nonoperative</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">non-weight bearing and activity restriction</span></strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><u>indications</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">compression side stress fractures + fracture line &lt;50% width</span></div><div>tension side stress changes with no fracture line (MRI)</div><div><br></div><div>Operative</div><div><b style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">cannulated screw fixation</b></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">tension side stress fractures</span>&nbsp;</div><div>compression side stress fractures with fatigue line &gt;50% femoral neck width&nbsp;</div><div>compression side stress fracture with hip effusion</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">open reduction internal fixation&nbsp;</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;</div><div>displaced femoral neck stress fracture</div>"																				
<div><b>Femoral Stress fracture</b>&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp;<br></div><div>if the diagnosis is suspected treat with {{c1::strict NWB}} until it can be confirmed</div>	"<div><div>if non op mgmt is chosen. When there is no pain at rest, then weight bearing to limitation of pain is allowed.<b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div><div><strong>Indications for orthopedic referral</strong></div><div>If a plain radiograph or MRI confirms the presence of a tension-side (ie, superolateral cortex) femoral neck stress fracture, the patient should be referred to an orthopaedic surgeon within <font color=""#fc0507"">24 hour</font>s.&nbsp;</div><div>If the fracture is displaced, <font color=""#fc0507"">immediate referral </font>is needed.&nbsp;</div><div>If there is a compression-side (ie, inferomedial cortex) femoral neck stress fracture, the patient should be evaluated by an orthopedist or sports medicine specialist within <font color=""#fc0507"">72 hours</font>.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Management</strong></div><div>If there is reasonable clinical suspicion for a femoral stress fracture, the patient should be made <font color=""#fc0507"">non-weight-bearing</font> on the affected extremity until the diagnosis is determined.&nbsp;</div><div>Further treatment depends upon the location and type of fracture.&nbsp;</div><div>Fractures at high risk of complications (eg, tension-side femoral neck stress fracture) are generally<font color=""#fc0507""> treated surgically</font>.&nbsp;</div><div>Treatment for the common types of femoral stress fractures amenable to non-surgical management, including basic rehabilitation programs</div></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>TREATMENT</b><br></div></div><div><br></div><div>Nonoperative</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">non-weight bearing and activity restriction</span></strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><u>indications</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">compression side stress fractures + fracture line &lt;50% width</span></div><div>tension side stress changes with no fracture line (MRI)</div><div><br></div><div>Operative</div><div><b style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">cannulated screw fixation</b></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">tension side stress fractures</span>&nbsp;</div><div>compression side stress fractures with fatigue line &gt;50% femoral neck width&nbsp;</div><div>compression side stress fracture with hip effusion</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">open reduction internal fixation&nbsp;</span></strong></div><div><u>indications</u>&nbsp;</div><div>displaced femoral neck stress fracture</div>"																				
"<b>Elbow Dislocation</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Nonoperative: {{c1::closed reduction}} then {{c1::splinting (90° for 5-10 days)}}</div><div>Operative:<strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;</span></strong>{{c2::LCL, +/- MCL}}&nbsp;repair</div>"	"most are non-op<div>op for complex or persistent instability&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Elbow+instability+fall.jpg""><br></div>"

<b>{{c1::Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis}}</b><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>an injury to the {{c2::epiphyseal growth plate}} at the head of the femur causing displacement&nbsp;</div><div>common in obese children aged 11 to 16 years</div><div>may be associated direct hip trauma</div>	"<img src=""left_scfe.jpg"">"																				
<b>Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>presents with groin or hip pain but may also present as thigh or knee pain</div><div>muscle spasms and synovitis occur in the acute phase<br></div><div>often associated with {{c1::antalgic gait::phys-ex}}</div><div>extremity {{c2::externally}} rotates when the hip is flexed</div>	"<img src=""left_scfe.jpg"">"																				
<b>Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Immediate {{c1::nonweight-bearing status}}</div><div>{{c1::percutaneous in situ fixation (Surgical Pin)}} is required</div><div>{{c2::Endocrine}} testing should be done&nbsp;</div>	"<div>consider prophylactic treatment of contralatearal side&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>Endocrine testing should be done to rule out:<div>-Growth hormone deficiency</div><div>-Hyperthyroidism</div><div>-Hypothyroidism</div><div>-Panhypopituitarism</div><div>-Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN&nbsp;syndromes)</div><div><br></div><div>Labs (ortho bullets)</div><div>if patient is &lt;10 years old, pre-pubertal or has short stature or weight below 50th percentile for age.</div><div>TSH, free T4, BUN, serum creatinine</div><div><img src=""scfe4_pinning.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Hip plain radiographs {{c1::AP}} and {{c1::frog-leg lateral}} views</div><div>will help with grading based on {{c2::% of slippage}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_91.png"">"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><b>{{c1::Pubalgia::diagnosis}}: </b>refers to pain in
the groin or lower abdominal area, typically in athletes</div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>multifactorial condition, initially
thought to be due to weakness of the posterior wall of the
<u>inguinal canal</u>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>now considered a, muscular imbalance between {{c2::hip adductors}} and {{c2::rectus abdominus}}&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><font color=""#fc0507"">Questionable Dx at best, (Dr. Howard: reserved for pt's that fail early management)</font></div>These patients have no obvious hernias or symptoms, such as numbness, clicking, a lumps, or dysuria<div><br></div><div>medical causes need to be considered and recognized before it is concluded that the pain is due to a musculoskeletal cause</div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>multidisciplinary approach should be considered given various areas involved (abdomen,
genitourinary system)</div><div><img src=""https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/rg.285075217/asset/images/medium/g08se11c01x.jpeg""><br></div><div><img src=""Athletic-Pubalgia-Sports-Hernia.png""><br></div><div><br></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
Athletic Pubalgia aka {{c1::sports hernia}}&nbsp;	"<div><div>Although a sports hernia may lead to a traditional inguinal hernia, it is a different injury.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Inguinal hernia</strong></div><div>is when abdominal tissue, such as part of the intestine, pushes through an opening in the lower abdominal wall, creating a painful bulge.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Sports hernia</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>is a strain or tear of any soft tissue (muscle, tendon, ligament) in the lower abdomen or groin area.</div></div><div><img src=""femoral-hernia.png""><br></div><img src=""sports-hernia-injury-e1539269632414.jpg"">"																				
"<b>Osteitis Pubis</b><div><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">inflammation of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pubic symphysis}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">caused by repetitive trauma ie. sports involving repetitive&nbsp;</span>{{c3::kicking::activity type}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>overuse of the {{c2::aDductors}}</div></div>"	"<div><img src=""anatomy of ps.jpg""><img src=""superior and inferior ligaments .jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""xpubic-ramus-stress-fracture.jpg.pagespeed.ic_.uabrqQtFOj.jpg""><div><img src=""anteror and posterior.jpg""></div>"																				
<b>Osteitis Pubis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>presents as pain in the {{c1::pubic symphysis::same}} or {{c1::groin pain}}&nbsp;</div><div>may radiate into the thigh</div><div>ambulation may produce a popping&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>Physical Examination</u></div><div>TTP over {{c1::pubic symphysis::same}}&nbsp;</div><div>Pain will be produced on resisted hip {{c2::adduction}}</div><div>Pain can be elicited with {{c3::one-legged hopping}}</div>	"<img src=""xpubic-ramus-stress-fracture.jpg.pagespeed.ic_.uabrqQtFOj.jpg"">"																				
<b>Osteitis Pubis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>xray<b> </b>AP pelvis shows an {{c1::osteolytic}} pubis with bony erosions and often times {{c1::diastasis}} of the symphysis&nbsp;</div>	"<div>degenerative changes within the joint can be see<br></div><img src=""xray op.jpg""><div>MRI<br></div><div>bone marrow edema found early&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""osteitis .jpg""><br></div><div>Bone scan<br></div><div>increased activity in area of pubic symphysis</div><div><img src=""opps1scan.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Osteitis Pubis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Generally rest and&nbsp;NSAIDs&nbsp;are the first-line treatments</div><div>Stretching and strengthening may proceed after reduction in pain<br></div><div>{{c1::Corticosteroid injection}} may be required in persistent cases (controversial)</div><div>{{c2::Surgery for arthrodesis}} may be required in severe cases (not common)</div>	"<div>out of plane?</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-29 at 11.08.17 PM.png""></div><div><img src=""1371-10-9621-1-17-20180124.jpg""></div><div><img src=""CU-Sports-Medicine-Hip-Clinic-Procedures-Osteitis-Pubis-Repair-Inset-1-1024x710.jpg""><br><div><br></div></div>"																				
"<b>Hip Labral Tear</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Physical Examination</u></div><div>1. {{c2::scouring maneuver}}<u><br></u></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>2. {{c1::(FADIR aka FAIR) anterior hip impingement
test}}</div><div>3. as well as tests of {{c3::intra/peri articular pathology::category}}&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>The most reliable test
for FAI and a labral tear is the anterior hip impingement
test</div><div>scouring maneuver, in which the hip
is taken from an abducted and externally rotated position,&nbsp;</div><div>through a flexed and neutral rotation position, and finally
into adduction and internal rotation,&nbsp;</div><div>may produce pain
and possibly a “click”</div><div><br></div><div>Passive hip
extension and external rotation may cause pain if a anterior labral
tear is present. (<u>posterior impingement test</u>)</div><div><br></div><div>Intra articular hip Hip disease can also be provoked <b>FABER test, stinch-feild, Axial loading, and log roll</b></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-30 at 9.25.01 PM.png""><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-06 at 9.10.19 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""log-roll-test-1.jpg""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>Hip Labral Tear</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>typically associated with {{c1::cam FAI}} or {{c1::pincer FAI}} (predisposing condition)</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-30 at 9.31.52 PM.png"">"																				
{{c1::Myositis ossificans}} is the formation of a type of heterotopic ossification within muscle<div><br></div><div>forms from {{c2::intra-muscular hematoma}}</div><div><br></div><div>usually the result of {{c2::repeated trauma}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""13_moved.JPG"">"																				
<div>Q angle&nbsp;is formed by the long axes of the {{c1::femur}} and the {{c1::tibia}} and reflects the natural {{c2::valgus}} attitude of the knee</div>	"<div>Males approximately 13 degrees</div><div>Females approximately 18 degrees</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_94.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(</span>ACL</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>) </b>originates at the posteromedial aspect of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lateral}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;femoral condyle,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">travels <u>inferiorly</u> and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::antero}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">-</span>{{c1::medially}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;through the intercondylar notch, to the medial tibial eminence</span></div>"	"<img src=""anatomy.png"">"																				
ACL primary function is to limit {{c1::anterior tibial translation}}<div><br></div><div>In knee flexion, it draws the femoral condyles {{c2::anterior}}ly</div>	"<div>also prevents posterior translation of the femur and hyperextension of the knee</div><div>limits internal rotation of the femur when the foot is fixed&nbsp;</div><div>ACL&nbsp;tightens with full extension and loosens in flexion.</div><div>Femoral external rotation loosens the&nbsp;ACL, and internal rotation tightens it.</div><img src=""anatomy.png"">"																				
"PCL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;originates from the anterolateral aspect of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::medial}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;femoral condyle, through the intercondylar notch,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and inserts onto the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::posterior}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;aspect of the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::tibial plateau}}</div>"	"<img src=""anatomy.png"">"																				
{{c1::medial}} collateral ligament has an attachment to the meniscus	"<img src=""knee-mcl-420.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">oblique popliteal ligament (</span>OPL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) arises from the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::semimembranosus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;tendon</span>"	"strengthens the fibrous posterior capsule of the knee joint<div>resists knee extension</div><div>attached to the capsule and lateral meniscus</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_98.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">arcuate popliteal ligament complex (</span>APLC<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) provides attachment for the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::posterior horn}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lateral meniscus}}"	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_98.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">posterior bursa (<b>baker's cyst</b>) located between the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::medial head of the gastrocnemius::m.}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::semimembranosus::m.}}"	"<img src=""knee_popcyst_anatomy02.jpg"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>McMurray Test for</b>&nbsp;<b><u>Medial</u> Meniscus</b></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Place a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::valgus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;stress on the knee with the leg&nbsp;</span>{{c1::externally}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;rotated</span>"	"<div>then slowly extend the knee</div><img src=""orthoKneeMcMurrayMedial.jpg"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>McMurray Test for</b>&nbsp;<b><u>Lateral</u>&nbsp;Meniscus</b></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><br></div>Place a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::varus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;stress on the knee with the leg&nbsp;</span>{{c1::internally}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;rotated</span>"	"slowly extend the knee<div><img src=""orthoKneeMcMurrayLateral.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div>{{c1::Apley’s grind}} test<br></div><div><br></div>patient lies prone with the knee flexed to 90 degrees<div><br></div><div>examiner places force downward on the heel, compressing the menisci between the femur and tibia</div>	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_102.png""><br></div>"																				
{{c2::Apley’s distraction}} test<div><br></div><div>positive test is consistent with {{c1::collateral ligamentous (MCL&nbsp;or&nbsp;LCL)}}&nbsp;damage</div><div><br></div><div>patient lies prone with the knee flexed to 90</div><div><br></div><div>Traction force is applied while rotating the tibia internally and externally</div>	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_103.png""><br></div>"
