"<b>Bounce Home Test</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>with patient supine, the examiner flexes the knee while holding the heel</div><div>knee is allowed to {{c1::extend passively}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>causes of decreased knee extension (<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">positive test)&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">include:&nbsp;</span>{{c2::torn meniscus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span>{{c3::loose body}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span>{{c4::intracapsular fluid}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">A positive test occurs when full extension cannot be attained, and rubbery resistance is felt</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_104.png""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(A) Examiner flexes the knee. (B) Examiner lets the knee passively extend (wnl). (C) Positive test occurs when full extension cannot be attained</span><br></div>"																				
<b>Patellofemoral Grind Test</b><div><br></div><div>examiner pushes the {{c1::patella distally}} and then asks the patient to {{c1::contract the quadriceps}} against the resistance<br></div>	"<div>this test evaluates the quality of the patella articulating surfaces</div><div>the patella should glide smoothly cephalad</div><div>positive test will yield pain and crepitation on patella movement</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_105.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Lachman’s Versus Anterior Drawer Test</b><div><br></div><div>in lachman's t<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">he knee is flexed at&nbsp;</span>{{c1::30}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;degrees while in the anterior drawer it is flexed to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::90}} degrees</div><div><br></div><div>false negatives in the anterior drawer test occur becuase the {{c2::hamstrings}} have a {{c2::mechanical advantage}}</div>"	"Lachman’s test may be more difficult for clinicians to perform but tends to be more sensitive<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">positive test occurs when the tibia slides from under the femur with no distinct endpoint.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Some anterior translation is normal. A distinct endpoint should be encountered in a normal exam</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>false - negative's</b>: hemarthrosis, hamstring spasm, torn meniscus, and other structures (i.e., the posterior capsule) can limit forward movement</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_106.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_107.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>{{c1::pivot shift}} test</b>: gold standard phys-ex test for ACL injury becuase it is {{c2::highly specific (98%)}}<div><br></div><div>tibia is {{c4::internally}} rotated while a {{c4::valgus}} stress and axial load is applied<br><div><br></div><div>{{c3::Antero-lateral}} {{c3::subluxation}} of the {{c3::tibial plateu}} indicates a <u>positive test</u><br></div></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-e12ae3794b2dcb6aa0ad6ae76f8451e0d7548e8b.jpg""></div><div>Begin in full knee extension and gently flex the knee to ~ 25 degrees of flexion to relax the fibers of the posterior joint capsule</div><div>5 mm of motion is considered a Grade I tear.</div><img src=""Pivot-Shift-Test-4.webp""><div><img src=""maxresdefault-8baa01faaf2c2d4dd5b990cec1d1b257c6657595.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""kneeassessment_lateralpivotshift_2.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"																				
"<div><div>Positive {{c1::posterior drawer}} test: Torn posterior cruciate ligament</div></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The examiner pushes the tibia away from himself</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_108.png"">"																				
{{c1::Sag Sign}}: purely observational test for the integrity of the&nbsp;PCL<div><br><div>visual comparison made with the contralateral side</div></div>	"<div><div>patient is supine with the hips at 45 degrees and knee flexed to 90 degrees with the foot on the exam table</div></div><img src=""42966tn.jpg""><div><img src=""knee_pcl_intro01.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""751952936-b315eddbc5be1df091fd9d43d9e072d86447de6db20d6bbeed5316f16a03409c-d.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Knee Collateral ligament testing</b></span></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::5}} to {{c1::10}} mm is considered a Grade {{c2::II}} tear</div>"	"<div><div>Knee may be tested in full extension and at approximately 25 degrees of flexion to relax the posterior joint capsules</div><div>- 5 mm of motion is considered a Grade I tear.</div><div>- 5 to 10 mm is considered a Grade II tear.</div><div>- &gt;10 mm is considered a complete interstitial tear.</div><div>Be aware that muscle guarding may cause a false negative</div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(A) Valgus stress test for integrity of the&nbsp;</span>MCL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. (B) Varus stress test for integrity of the&nbsp;</span>LCL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_109.png"">"																				
<b>Meniscal tears</b><div><br></div><div>Medial meniscal injuries are common in {{c1::sports}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Lateral meniscal injuries typically occur during {{c2::squatting}}&nbsp;</div>	caused by shearing forces from loading and rotational forces on the knee<div><br></div><div>M meniscal such as football, basketball, and soccer</div><div><br></div><div>L menicsal Full flexion with rotation is the usual mechanism e.g., wrestling</div>																				
"<div><b>acute meniscal tears</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>often associated with a ""{{c1::pop}}"" after a {{c1::specific inciting incident}}</div><div>Effusions may occur within 24 hours<br></div><div>Patients frequently complain of knee stiffness</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">history will help diagnose a meniscal injury 75% of the
time</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Young patients who experience meniscal tears
will <u>recall the mechanism of injury 80% to 90% of the time</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">in contrast <u>degenerative meniscal tears are not usually
associated with a history of trauma</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;<br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><br></div>Posterior horn tears of the medial meniscus are common and occur with valgus and external rotation<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-09-03 at 9.54.30 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>degenerative meniscal tears</b><div><br></div><div><u>clinical features</u></div><div>do not typically involve {{c1::trauma}}</div><div>{{c2::Impingement}} episodes may be minimal</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">often also report recurrent&nbsp;</span>{{c2::knee swelling}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"They usually occur in patients &gt;40 years old<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">often also report recurrent knee swelling&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""#fc0507"">Howard:</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""> he leans more toward OA than degenerative meniscal tear if there is no distant inciting event that they can recall</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-09-03 at 9.54.30 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">medial meniscus appears&nbsp;</span>{{c1::C}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;shaped and the lateral meniscus appears&nbsp;</span>{{c1::O}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;shaped&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">higher incidence of tears within the medial meniscus&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-31 at 8.44.03 PM.png"">"																				
<b>meniscal tear</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><div><u>ROM&nbsp;is decreased:</u></div><div>{{c1::Effusion}} will limit flexion</div><div>{{c1::Meniscal fragment}} will limit extension</div></div>																					
MRI&nbsp;is the gold standard in diagnosing meniscal tears:<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Sagittal}} views will best show the anterior and posterior meniscal horns</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Coronal}} views are the best views for the meniscal body</div>	"<div>there is a significant false positive rate. ie tears on MRI that are not seen on arthroscopy&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""meniscus.jpg""><br></div><img src=""public.jpg""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-31 at 9.14.01 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Meniscal Tears</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>general</u></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">rest, ice,
and compression, with analgesics</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">weight bearing as tolerated with crutches</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">hinged knee splint with underlying ligamentous injury&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><br></div><div><u>treatment</u></div><div>surgical {{c2::resection}} is often required with injuries to the {{c1::inner two-thirds (white zone)}}</div><div>- generally weight bearing as tolerated in 1 to 2 days</div><div><br></div><div><u>treatment</u><br></div><div>surgical {{c2::repair}} is often required with injuries to the {{c1::outer one-third (red zone)}}&nbsp;<br></div><div>- generally the patient is nonweight bearing for 4 to 6 weeks</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><div>TREATMENT&nbsp;<b style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(essentials)</b><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">In general, only meniscal injuries that are </span><font color=""#fc0507"">persistently symptomatic</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""> should be referred for surgical intervention.&nbsp;</span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">In fact, some meniscal lesions have gradual
resolution of symptoms during a 6-week period and may
have normal function by 3 months</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Types of tears
that may be treated with <u>nonsurgical measures</u> include...&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- partial-thickness longitudinal tears</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- small (</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&lt;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">5 mm) full thickness peripheral tears</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- minor inner rim or degenerative tears&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>TREATMENT <b>(ortho bullets)</b></div><div><br></div><div>Nonoperative</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">rest, NSAIDS, rehabilitation</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>first line treatment for degenerative tears</div><div>""noninferior"" when compared to arthroscopic partial meniscectomy</div><div><br></div><div>Operative</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">partial meniscectomy</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>tears not amenable to repair (complex, degenerative, radial tear patterns)</div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">meniscal repair</span>&nbsp;</strong></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>best candidate for repair is a tear with the following characteristics&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">peripheral</span>&nbsp;in the red-red zone (vascularized region)</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">lower rim width</span>&nbsp;correlates with the ability of a meniscal repair to heal&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-31 at 9.08.06 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-31 at 9.31.11 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">vertical (or longitudinal) can turn into bucket handle&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>Meniscal Tears</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><div>MRI after {{c4::4 weeks}} of the symptoms below, despite initial managment<br></div><div><br></div></div><div><br></div><div><u>non-operative treatment (indications)</u></div><div>1. non {{c1::obstructive}}</div><div>2. not {{c2::persistenty symptomatic (painful)}}&nbsp;</div><div>3. {{c3::degenerative}} tears&nbsp;</div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">1. truly locked knee resulting from a meniscal tear should
be reduced within 24 hours of injury</span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">2. meniscal lesions often have gradual
resolution of symptoms&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">3. conservative is first line in degenerative, may be asymptomatic aka false positives&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""#fc0507"">young/Athletes</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">, may hold them out of sport and obtain MRI at frist visit (howard)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">initially be treated with rest, ice,
and compression, with weight bearing as tolerated</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Patients
may need to use crutches acutely</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A knee splint may be
applied for comfort&nbsp;</span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Analgesics such as acetaminophen or opioids can be used
for pain</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can be used
for pain and inflammation</span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Arthrocentesis can be performed (ideally in the first
24 to 48 hours) when there is a significant effusion&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>UpTo Date</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><div><u>factors that suggest conservative therapy will be successful</u></div><div>●Symptoms develop over 24 to 48 hours after the acute injury (as opposed to immediately after)</div><div>●Swelling is minimal</div><div>●The knee has full range of movement with pain only at or near full flexion</div><div>●Pain with McMurray testing occurs only with deep knee flexion</div></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>terrible triad</b> (also known as O’Donoghue’s triad)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>involves simultaneous injury to:</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::ACL}}</div><div>{{c1::MCL}}</div><div>{{c1::medial meniscus}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""unhappy-triad800.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&gt;50% of&nbsp;</span>ACL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;tears occur with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::meniscal tears}}"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_110.png"">"																				
"<b>ACL tear</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u><br><div>{{c1::Severe effusion}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in the 2 to 12 hours following injury is the most sensitive marker for acute&nbsp;</span>ACL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;injury</span><br></div></div>"	History:<div>- sudden pop and anterior knee pain with posterior lateral joint line pain</div><div>- instability of the knee is common.</div><div>- Early swelling; within 24 hours, a significant effusion will be present.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>On physical exam:</div><div>- An effusion is noted on clinical inspection.</div><div>- Tenderness is variable and associated with meniscal tears and avulsion fracture.</div><div>- The anterior drawer test may be positive or yield a false negative</div><div>- Lachman’s test may be positive but can yield a false negative in approximately 10% of cases</div><div>(examiner dependent / influenced by muscle guardiing)</div>																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>anterior cruciate ligament tears</b></span><br></div><br><div><u>Imaging and Testing</u></div><div>X-rays may show an {{c1::avulsion fracture}}</div><div>{{c2::Arthrocentesis}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::MRI}}&nbsp;</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>of either the tibial insertion of the&nbsp;ACL&nbsp;or the proximal lateral capsular margin of the tibia (Segond’s fracture pathognomonic)<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div>Arthrocentesis can be performed to relieve pressure and pain and will generally <b>return blood or a sanguineous fluid</b>&nbsp;<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">MRI to establish an accurate
diagnosis and the presence of associated injuries&nbsp;<b>may necessitate prompt surgery</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">chondral or
osteochondral fractures, meniscal tears, injured
capsular structures,&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">bone bruises, and other ligamentous injuries</span></div><div><img src=""187e61_beb3a44febab426fa8ad8d2f9308ca4f~mv2.jpg""></div><div><a>MRI Knee - Sagittal T1 - Normal ACL</a></div><div><img src=""acl.jpg""><br></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ACL tear&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>immediate</u> management is typically&nbsp;</span>{{c1::conservative::op/non-op}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Surgical
referral is <u>not necessary in the immediate postinjury period</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">but <u>should be facilitated as soon as it is clear that an individual desires surgery</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">When
associated injuries are present, especially if these cause mechanical symptoms, or in the case of the elite athlete,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">surgical treatment should be considered as soon as
the initial inflammatory phase has passed&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-02 at 9.28.56 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">anterior cruciate ligament tears</b><br></div></div></div></div></div><div><br></div><div><u>Nonoperative management</u><br></div><div>Initially {{c1::partial weight bearing}} with {{c1::knee immobilizer}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::crutches}}</div><div>most perform a post-traumatic {{c2::arthrocentesis}}&nbsp;</div><div>rest, ice, and compression are used while evaluation is ongoing</div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Arthrocentesis can be performed (ideally in the first
24 to 48 hours) for both diagnostic and treatment purposes&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">blood = meniscal / cruciate tear.&nbsp; fat = fracture&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-02 at 9.28.56 PM.png""><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong>physical therapy, lifestyle modifications</strong></span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>low demand patients with decreased laxity</div><div>recreational athlete not participating in cutting/pivoting activities</div></div><div><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong>ACL reconstruction</strong></span></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>must have full motion of knee restored following injury (unless meniscal tear causing mechanical block)</div><div>younger, more active patients (reduces the incidence of meniscal or chondral injury)</div><div>children (activity limitation is not realistic)</div><div>older active patients (age &gt;40 is not a contraindication if high demand athlete)</div><div>partial/single bundle tears with clinical and functional instability</div><div>prior ACL reconstruction failure</div></div></div>"																				
"<div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">anterior cruciate ligament tears</b><br></div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>operative management</u><br></div><div>{{c1::acl reconstruction}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>{{c2::injuries to multiple knee structures (eg, ACL plus meniscus or medial collateral ligament)}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c3::significant knee instability (eg, knee gives out while climbing stairs)}}<br></div><div>{{c4::athletes and high-demand workers (young or wish to return to heavy activity)}}<br></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>most get surgery</u></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">surgical procedure of choice is the arthroscopically assisted autograft&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">by full endoscopic or two-incision techniques,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">with use of either patellar bone–tendon–bone graft or four strands of hamstring tendon graft&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""h9991490_001.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""maxresdefault-8cf5314afe72942658de5870bd0caa8345ba2562.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Test Grading Criteria for Lachman's Maneveur</span><div><br></div><div>Grade {{c2::2}}: 5 to 10 mm translation, likely reflecting {{c1::partial tear}}</div>"	"Grade 1: 3 to 5 mm of translation<div>Grade 2: 5 to 10 mm translation, likely reflecting <u>partial tear</u></div><div>Grade 3: &gt;10 mm translation, likely reflecting <u>complete tear</u></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-03 at 6.50.50 AM.png""><u><br></u></div>"																				
"<b>PCL injury</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u><br></div><div>largely similar to ACL, save for pain and TTP which is felt in the {{c1::Popliteal fossa}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<u>History:</u><div>-initial injury may or may not be associated with a pop.</div><div>-may be minimal swelling initially, increasing over 24 hours.</div><div>-ability to fully extend may be impaired</div><div>-may be able to bear weight without pain.</div><div><br></div><div><u>On physical exam:</u></div><div>-effusion may be present</div><div>-Popliteal tenderness is a common finding in the acute phase</div><div>-Posterior drawer test and sag tests may be positive (quadriceps spasms may cause a false negative</div><div><img src=""PCL-injury-knee.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<u>ACL reconstruction post-op Rehabilitation</u><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::Full Weight
bearing}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span>with {{c1::crutches}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">is usually started immediately</span></div><div>Progress to {{c2::closed chain}} kinetics is then undertaken</div><div>Avoid resistance exercises at {{c3::terminal extension (0-45<sup>0</sup> flexion}} (1st 3 to 6 mo)</div><div>{{c4::Lenox Hill derotation}} orthosis is used to control knee axial rotation as well as&nbsp;AP&nbsp;and medial–lateral control</div><div>Sports-specific exercises may be started in 6 to 12 weeks</div><div>Complete rehabilitation in 6 months to 1 year is the goal with maximum&nbsp;ROM, strength, and agility</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>Partial weight bearing is maintained initially. (per cucurullo) ""outdated""</div><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">closed kinetic chain exercises: mini-squats, steps, and leg press, has allowed quadriceps
strengthening with tolerable shear forces to the graft&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">use of
postoperative functional bracing does not improve outcome
compared with no bracing (per essentials)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Return to play: reviously held consensus is no sooner than 9 months following surgery</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""acl_rehab.jpg""></div><div><a>Comparison of the original&nbsp;<strong>(A)</strong>&nbsp;and current&nbsp;<strong>(B)</strong>&nbsp;Lenox Hill Hill Rerotation Orthosis</a><br></div><div><img src=""F000114f11-11-9781437719369.jpg""><br><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>PCL tear&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>special tests</u></div><div>posterior drawer</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">reverse pivot shift test&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div>sag sign</div><div>{{c1::quadriceps active test}}</div><div>{{c2::dial test}} rules out concomitant {{c3::postero-lateral corner}} injury&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>same set up as posterior drawer</div><div>there must be a sag sign present</div><div>sit on foot, quad fieres, tibia moves anteriorly</div><div>fire hamstring, exagerates posterior sag&nbsp;</div><img src=""Quadriceps-Active-Test-2-1024x576.png""><div>&gt; 10° ER asymmetry at&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">30° &amp; 90°</span>&nbsp;consistent with&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">PLC and PCL</span>&nbsp;injury&nbsp;</div><div>&gt; 10° ER asymmetry at 30° only consistent with isolated PLC injury<div><div><img src=""Dial-Test-6.webp""><br></div></div></div>"																				
"<b>PCL tear</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>nonoperative treatment</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">advocated for those with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::isolated PCL injuries}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<u>&lt;</u> grade II laxity (tear)}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>surgical treatment</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">advocated for those with&nbsp;</span>{{c3::bone
avulsion fractures}}</div><div>{{c4::combined ligament injuries}}</div><div>{{c5::chronic
symptomatic PCL laxity}}</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Initial treatment consists of </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">p</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">rotection, </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">r</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">est, </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">i</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ce, </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">c</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ompression, and </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">e</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">levation (PRICE)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">crutches,</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;extension brace (<b>relative immobilization 4 wks grade3</b>) and&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>avoidance of hamstring exercise, favor KE</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">short-term nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">surgery particularly if this interferes with athletic participation in elite athletes</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">In a high percentage of cases, <b>athletic participation is still possible with PCL insufficiency</b>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">keep in mind that <u>grade III PCL injury</u> almost always is associated with the <u>posterolateral corner injury</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">must be addressed at the time of PCL reconstruction to obtain a good clinical result&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs00402-020-03607-z/MediaObjects/402_2020_3607_Fig2_HTML.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>PCL tear</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>AP X-rays may show a {{c1::tibial avulsion fx}}&nbsp;</div><div>xray {{c2::lateral stress}} view is becoming more popular&nbsp;</div><div>MRI&nbsp;is likley mandatory primarily to {{c3::r/o concomitant PLC injury}}</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><u>only 28% of all PLC injuries are isolated</u></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><u>if missed PLC injury, could be disatrous</u></span></div><div>stress view: flexed to 70 with a posterior directed for to ant tibia, causes displacement&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""pcl injury lateral stress views.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><u><br></u></span></div><div><img src=""pcl grade iii intrasubstance tear sagittal mri.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><u><br></u></span></div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs00402-020-03607-z/MediaObjects/402_2020_3607_Fig2_HTML.png"">"																				
"
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::MCL}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;is the most commonly injured ligament of the
knee&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">True <b>isolated LCL&nbsp;</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>injury</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>&nbsp;is rare</b>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">True straight lateral
instability requires a large vector force ie, a <u>complete
knee dislocation</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>possible damage to neurovascular
structures</u> should be suspected if straight lateral instability is
present&nbsp;<br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-03 at 11.07.27 AM.png"">"																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>Medial and lateral collateral ligament injury<br>
</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>clinical features</u>&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">unique to this pathology is a</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;sensation of,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::""giving way""}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Medial / Lateral knee pain is the most common symptom&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">often accompanied by a sensation
of knee locking</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">may also report an audible pop</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A giving way sensation or a feeling of instability is often reported with high-grade&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Interestingly, grade I and grade II injuries cause more pain than grade III</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">cuased by hamstring compensation or meniscal injury&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">POP, although this is more common with anterior cruciate ligament injuries</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""2366902.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>MCL injury</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>valgus stress testing</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">instability in slight flexion of 30 degrees indicates&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">isolated&nbsp;</span>MCL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;injury (+/-&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">posterior capsule)</span>}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">instability in full extension (</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">0 degrees)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;indicates&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">injury to&nbsp;</span>MCL<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and the PCL (&amp; posterior capsule)</span>}}</div><div>it is critical to also test {{c2::the contralateral side}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>some laxity is normal, we are looking for an asymetry</div><div>pt must relax, tightening the muscles may cause a false -&nbsp;</div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-03 at 11.31.43 AM.png"">"																				
<b>LCL tears</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Isolated&nbsp;LCL&nbsp;injuries are {{c1::rare::epidemiology}}</div><div>must evaluate for {{c2::posterolateral corner instability}}</div><div>tears of the&nbsp;LCL&nbsp;usually are the result of {{c3::knee dislocations}}</div><div>consideration should be made of associated injuries to {{c4::cruciates}}, blood vessels, and {{c4::peroneal nerve}} injury</div>	"A knee dislocation is a potentially devastating injury and is often a surgical emergency.&nbsp;<div>Vascular injury and compartment syndrome are dreaded complications that should not be missed in the workup.&nbsp;</div><div>This is in distinct contrast to patellar dislocations, which generally do not require immediate surgical or vascular intervention.</div><div><img src=""Xray - Lat - knee dislocation (emedicine)_moved.jpg""><img src=""Clinical photo - recurvatum (emedicine)_moved.jpg""><br><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""square_jumbo.jpeg""><br></div></div></div>"																				
"<b>LCL tear</b><div><br></div><div><u>physical eamination</u></div><div>varus stress test (as in MCL injury should be preformed {{c2::at 2 different angles (0 and 30)}})</div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::external rotation recurvatum}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;test (to r/o concomitant damage to the&nbsp;</span>{{c3::posterolateral}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;knee structures)&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><b>varus stress test</b><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">+ 30 degrees alone: damage to the LCL
and arcuate ligament complex</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">+ at 30 and full extension: damage to the LCL but also to the mid 3rd of the capsular ligament, cruciates, IT band, or arcuate ligament
complex&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><b>external rotation recurvatum</b><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Both knees are passively
held in extension by holding the forefoot</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">If the tibia on the affected side
externally rotates more than the normal side, the test result is considered
positive</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">+ test: indicates damage to the posterolateral knee structures&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-03 at 11.56.46 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<b>MCL and LCL</b><div><br></div><div><u>treatment</u></div><div>{{c2::all isolated (any grade)::type}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;MCL injures are treated non-op&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">all grades treated initially w/ PRICE (</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">p</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">rotect, </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">r</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">est, </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">i</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ce, </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">c</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ompression, </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">e</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">levation) + nsaids</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">immobilization can be used in grade II and III injuries w/&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">crutches and a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hinged knee brace (locked
between 20 and 60 degrees)}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>delayed return to play</div>"	"<div>grade II return to play at 2-4 weeks, grade III return to play at 4-8 weeks<br></div><div><br></div><div>most won't have issues, walking in a straight line&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-aeebe0d7b02335413145e2a778969eabcb4afa07.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><b>Operative</b><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">ligament repair vs. reconstruction</span></strong></div><div><u>relative indications</u></div><div><font color=""#095cff"">acute repair</font> in grade III injuries</div><div>-in the setting of <b>multi-ligament knee injury</b></div><div>-displaced distal avulsions with ""stener-type"" lesion</div><div>-<b>entrapment of the torn end</b> in the medial compartment</div><div><font color=""#095cff"">sub-acute repair</font> in grade III injuries</div><div>-<b>continued instability despite nonoperative treatment</b></div><div>-<b>&gt;10 mm medial sided opening</b> in full extension</div>"																				
<div><b>Patellar tendonitis aka jumper's knee<br></b></div><div><br></div><u>General</u><div><br></div><div>often associated with {{c3::microtears::pathophys}} of the patellar tendon</div><div><br></div><div>considered to be an {{c1::overuse syndrome}} associated with high quadriceps loading: jumping, squatting, kneeling, and climbing stairs</div><div><br></div><div>most common site of involvement is the {{c2::inferior pole of the patella}}</div>	"<div><font color=""#095cff"">injury exclusively seen in young athletes (Maenpaa)</font></div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>superior pole</u> of the patella or insertion over the <u>tibial tubercle</u> may also be involved<br></div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">cycle of microtearing, degeneration, and regeneration weakens the
tendon and may lead to <u>tendon rupture</u></span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>training issues</u>: no warm-up,
rapid increase in frequency / intensity&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">biomechanical imbalances,
such as tight hamstrings and excess <u>femoral anteversion</u></span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">histology shows no evidence of
acute inflammation, “<u>patellar
tendinopathy</u> or tendinosis” is a more accurate name</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<div><b>Patellar tendonitis aka jumper's knee<br></b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>present with pain on high impact activity, such as jumping</div><div>pain may {{c1::diminish during the course of the activity session::unique clinical feature}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>Physical Examination</u></div><div>tenderness on palpation over the patellar tendon, inferior, or superior pole of the patella</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">pain typically provoked by&nbsp;</span>{{c2::knee extension against resistance}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""patella+tendinopathy+3.jpg"">"																				
"<b>Patellar tendonitis aka jumper's knee</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>treatment</u></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, ice, and relative rest&nbsp;</span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">as rehabilitation advances, emphasize&nbsp;</span>{{c1::eccentric::exer type}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;strengthening exercises&nbsp;</span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c2::counterforce strap}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Chopat strap}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">eccentric exercise is optimal for rehab of tendinopathies, places <u>maximal tensile load</u> on the muscle and tendon unit&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">injections with PRP, prolotherapy done but with unclear results.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">steroid seems risky (assoc with pupture/not for kids)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">invasive procedures are rarely necessary, patella resuturing for rupture&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""paste-7c6613218041114de216f6b6660ddcabe0fdec37.jpg""><img src=""paste-0aa1711b8000e0ca08e28604339117b13fe2a393.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<b>MCL tear</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Radiographs may reveal an epiphyseal fracture</div><div>MRI&nbsp;is typical to&nbsp;investigate associated injuries (i.e., to the&nbsp;ACL&nbsp;and medial meniscus)</div><div>{{c1::US}} may visualize tear unlike in other knee ligamenouts injuries&nbsp;</div>	"since it is not hidden by bone like the ACL, PCL, and menisci&nbsp;<div>arrows (MCL), mf (meniscofemoral lig) * (meniscus)&nbsp;&nbsp;<div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Michael-Fredericson/publication/46008807/figure/fig9/AS:436696727724043@1481128021457/Ultrasound-image-of-medial-collateral-ligament-reveals-the-superficial-ligament-arrows.png""><br></div></div><div>mcl arrows</div><div><img src=""picture8.png""><br></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/319158414/figure/fig1/AS:654984219742208@1533171815240/Ultrasound-image-of-proximal-MCL-tear-arrow-noting-ligament-tissue-disruption-with.png""><br></div>"																				
{{c1::corticosteroid injection::treatment&nbsp;type}} is not part of the plan for ACL, PCL, collateral ligament, and meniscal injuries	seems reasonable for arthritis and tendonopathy&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>but not in ligaments/fibrocartilage as it worsens healing&nbsp;</div>																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">In the pediatric and
adolescent athlete, have low threshold to order&nbsp;</span>{{c1::MRI}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">may give information about&nbsp;</span>{{c2::physeal}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;injuries that may otherwise
go unnoticed&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"would order for mechanical symptoms, swelling or dislocation&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">Physeal injuries are&nbsp;</span><b>very common in children, making up 15-30% of all bony injuries</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">growth plate</span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">, or physis, is the translucent, cartilaginous disc separating the epiphysis from the metaphysis</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">responsible for longitudinal growth of long bones</span><br></div><div><img src=""Salter-Harris-Physeal-Injury-Classification.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><b>IT band snydrome</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><u>General</u><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::Friction::pathophys}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;has been implicated as the most important factor
in ITBS&nbsp;</span></div></div></div></div><div>{{c2::Inflexibility}} of the&nbsp;ITB&nbsp;and adductor/abductor {{c2::muscle imbalances}} leads to the dysfunction</div>"	"<div>classic overuse injury in runners / cyclists (<font color=""#095cff"">exclusively in the young, Maenpaa</font>)</div><div><br></div><div>can occur at the hip but typically refers to a knee injury&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>ITB&nbsp;slides over the lateral femoral condyle with the knee in flexion and extension<div><img src=""IT-Band-1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>(distal) IT band snydrome</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><u>Clinical Features</u><div>pain over the {{c1::lateral femoral condyle}} and/or {{c1::Gerdy’s tubercle}}, made worse by walking or jogging</div><div>patient adapts by {{c2::externa}}lly rotating the hip, {{c2::interna}}lly rotating the lower leg, and {{c3::pronating}} the foot</div>	"Symptoms improve with running in mild to moderate cases&nbsp;<div><img src=""ITB+1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>IT Band Syndrome</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>special tests</u></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::Noble compression}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;test (provocative)</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div>{{c2::Thomas}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;test&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c2::Ober}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;test&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">1. </span>Place thumb over the ITB&nbsp;over the lateral femoral condyle, passively flex and extend the knee</div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Positive test: </span>Pain occurs as the knee reaches 30° of flexion.
<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Consistent with: </span>Iliotibial band syndrome&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-04 at 9.27.05 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-04 at 9.25.26 PM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<b>IT Band Syndrome</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>treatment</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">RICE, activity below threshold of pain&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::Stretching}} is central to rehabilitation</div><div>Strengthening the {{c2::hip aBductors}} is also important</div><div>{{c4::foam roller}} for associated myofascial pain in the thigh muscles</div><div>{{c5::deep transverse friction}} massage&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Orthotics}} may be helpful to correct foot overpronation</div><div>{{c6::Injection at the lateral femoral condyle}} advocated for&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">persistent pain and
swelling&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"Stretching the&nbsp;ITB, hip flexors, and gluteus maximus is central to rehabilitation<div>Strengthening the hip aBductors, gluteus maximus, and&nbsp;TFL&nbsp;is also important<br></div><div>Injection in resistant cases is often sucessful and curative</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">may be performed at different
locations along the ITB</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Injection into the anatomic pouch
at the lateral femoral epicondyle is relatively simple</span>&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""images-c80fc99c27a1895e63c05e848ed86e6d422b0f3b.jpg""><img src=""paste-c1d7ecdb2a788757bd5b245ac834a458aee3d7da.jpg""><img src=""images-793a4192858aa6615ac10f148b050b4540ebc5a2.jpg""></div><div><img src=""cyraix-23rd-jan-24-320.jpg""><img src=""images-91f10f4ec32b807f5875fbde5f3ca41770ae4b65.jpg""><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-27 at 10.40.51 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-04 at 10.02.20 PM.png""><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Look for hypoechoic
bursal fluid between the hyperechoic femur and overlying dense fibrillar ITB&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div>Needle position: Insert the needle in-plane from either
proximal to distal or distal to proximal, targeting the inflamed
bursa or thickened ITB&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-04 at 10.03.06 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div>The stability of the patella is dependent upon three main characteristics:</div><div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Depth of the intercondylar groove}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Proper contour of the patella}}</div><div>3. {{c2::Adequate muscular control}}</div>	<div>The normal patellar motion is vertical.</div><div><br></div><div>At full extension the applied force of the quadriceps approximating the patella to the condyles is reduced.</div><div><br></div><div>Patellofemoral weight bearing increases with knee flexion:</div><div>-Walking: 0.5 times body weight</div><div>-Ascending or descending stairs: 3.3 times body weight</div><div>-Squatting: 6.0 times body weight</div><div><br></div><div>In hyperextension, there is a tendency for the patella to separate from the femur. The lateral lip of the patellar surface of the femur acts to prevent subluxation.</div>																				
<b>Hip Coxa valga</b> occurs when the femoral neck-shaft angle is {{c1::increased}}<div><br></div><div>the knees assume a {{c1::varus}} deformity</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-03 at 3.53.20 PM.png"">"																				
"<b>patelo-femoral pain syndrome AKA {{c1::runner’s / biker’s knee}}</b><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>#1 most common cause of anterior knee pain</div><div>an overuse injury caused by repeated {{c2::microtrauma::pathophys}}, leading to {{c3::peripatellar synovitis::pathophys}}</div><div>predisposing conditions typically cause {{c4::patellar tracking problems::main predisposing factor}}</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">repetitive overload at the patel­lofemoral joint 2/2&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">poor patellar tracking
in the femoral trochlear groove</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">EMG comparison has shown <b>delayed VMO activation</b> in those patients with patellofemo­ral syndrome</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>pain generators</u> include: the subchon­dral bone, retinacula, capsule, and synovial membrane&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>c</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>hondromalacia</b>, had been associated with
PFPS. However, chondromalacia is
poorly associated with this syn­drome&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""enzo_pierro_19.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>patellofemoral syndrome</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>symptoms</u>&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">diffuse, vague ache of insidious onset at</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;anterior
knee</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">aggravated by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::prolonged sitting (“theater” sign)}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;as well as on&nbsp;</span>{{c2::ascending/descending stairs}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>if pt performs physical activity for leisure ask about {{c3::recent change in equipment or training::2}}</div>
</div>
</div>"	"crepitus, may have an effusion,&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">may also experience pseudolocking</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">greatest force on the patellofemoral joint from squatting, biking, running&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-12 at 11.29.27 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>patellofemoral syndrome</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>physical examination</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">clarke sign</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">TTP of the medial / lateral boarder of the patella</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">observation may reveal&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::high}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">-riding and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::laterally}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;shifted patella (aka&nbsp;</span>{{c2::patella alta}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">evaluation of&nbsp;</span>{{c3::muscle tightness/contracture::general category of special tests}}</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">examination focuses on identification of <b>risk factors that
contribute to malalignment</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">alta more common that baja&nbsp;</span></div><div>Rotation of the patella also indicates evidence of muscle imbalances:</div><div>- internal rotation is given the term squinting&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">patella</span>.</div><div>- external rotation is given the term frog’s eye&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">patella</span>.</div><div>1.) Tight hip flexors = Thomas test&nbsp;</div><div>2.) Tight abductors = Ober test&nbsp;</div><div>3.) Tight hamstrings = straight leg raise test</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-12 at 11.29.27 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;<br></span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<u>Factors that increase Q angle:</u>&nbsp;<div>{{c1::Internal torsion of the femur}} aka {{c1::femoral anteversion}}</div><div>{{c2::lateral insertion}} of the {{c2::patellar tendon}} on the tibia</div><div>{{c3::genu valgum}}</div><div>excessive {{c4::foot pronation}}</div>	"<div><img src=""excessive-femoral-anteversion.png""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-12 at 11.29.27 AM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>patellofemoral pain syndrome</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>treatment</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><div>Activity modification</div><div>adjust {{c1::bike seat/cleats::sport specific equipment consideration}}</div><div>{{c2::Short arc quadriceps}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;activities are used to strengthen the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::VMO}}<br></div><div><div>{{c3::Patellar (KT) taping}} or {{c3::knee sleeve (w/ patella cut out)}}</div></div></div><div>{{c4::foot orthosis}}&nbsp;</div>"	"Reduce the pace of activities that increase patellofemoral stress (climbing, jumping, squatting)<div>saddle too far forward or too low will stress the anterior knee&nbsp;<br></div><div>Short arc quadriceps<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;activities (0 degrees–15 degrees)</span><br></div><div>(KT) taping provides proprioceptive feedback to alter patellar tracking<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div>limited role for injection no concensus on cause (verobej said gel shot??)</div><div>Surgery may involve: Lateral release of the knee capsule and retinaculum, Patellar tendon transfer, Patellectomy</div><div><img src=""images-1eb3e8017d11dbada8b19f58ff53d0961626f7f3.jpg""><img src=""images-04dd06e3e056c56166966d72ad7633d39fa30dcb.jpg""><img src=""images-081851f1f8969a88b17974de7654a4054c25c973.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Chondromalacia patella</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>is essentially a/an {{c1::arthroscopic}} diagnosis</div><div><br></div><div>characterized by {{c2::softening}} of the patellar articular cartilage followed by {{c2::degeneration}}</div>	"diagnosis in which the cartilage appears roughened or fibrillated<div><br></div><div>findings noted in patellofemoral syndrome (PFS) sometimes&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>MRI&nbsp;is only moderately accurate in diagnosing chondromalacia</div><div><img src=""PF-chondromalacia-GIF.gif""><br></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Bruce-Forster/publication/47519822/figure/fig14/AS:486816596926481@1493077529667/Chondromalacia-patellae-grades-II-IV-in-various-patients-A-Axial-fast-spin-echo-proton.png""><br></div><div><div>(A) grade II High signal seen in the patellar cartilage in the lateral patellar facet</div><div>(B) grade III full thickness focal signal intensity change, contour irregularity and thinning of the cartilage</div><div>(C) grade IV extensive full-thickness chondral loss along the medial patellar facet.&nbsp;</div><div>There is also associated marrow oedema and cystic change within the patella</div></div>"																				
presentation of {{c1::chondromalacia patella}} is clinically the same as for patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS)<div><br></div><div>MRI&nbsp;may detect defects in the articular cartilage of the patella, which is the distinguishing characteristic of this disorder</div>	"treatment will follow the treatment already described for&nbsp;PFPS<div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/47519822/figure/fig14/AS:486816596926481@1493077529667/Chondromalacia-patellae-grades-II-IV-in-various-patients-A-Axial-fast-spin-echo-proton.png""></div><div>A) high signal seen in the patellar cartilage (lateral)</div><div>B) full thickness signal intensity</div><div>C) full chondral loss with marrow edema in patella&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><div><img src=""46c4aac8adfdca0ae50d15bf18b130_big_gallery.jpg""></div><div>T2 best sequence to assess cartilage</div><div>abnormal cartilage is usually of high signal compared to normal cartilage</div></div>"																				
Plicae are {{c1::redundant folds}} of the {{c1::synovial lining}} of the knee	"They are common and generally asymptomatic.<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">are embryologic remnant synovial folds</span><br><div><br></div><div>Plica syndrome refers to a pathologic condition in which the plica becomes inflamed.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>It is a diagnosis of exclusion.&nbsp;<br></div></div><div><img src=""Plica.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""640px-Knee_plicae.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>plica band syndrome</b>&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Feature</u>s</div><div>pain {{c1::adjacent to the patella::location}} where careful palpation may detect it</div>	"<div><div>ncrease with prolonged knee flexion or sitting</div><div>made worse by standing and extension</div><div>sensation of buckling if the plica is trapped between the patella and medial condyle</div><div>Snapping with knee extension may occur if the plica is fibrosed</div></div><div><br></div><div>imaging and treatment would follow that of&nbsp;PFPS&nbsp;as previously outlined</div><div>Surgical excision can be done if conservative measures fail</div><div><br></div><img src=""640px-Knee_plicae.jpg"">"																				
"<u style="""">classification of slap tear</u><div style="""">1. {{c1::Labral (and biceps) fraying}}, {{c1::intact}} biceps tendon anchor (11% of cases)</div>"	"<i><div><div><u>classification of slap tear</u><br></div><div>1. Labral and biceps fraying, anchor intact (11% of cases)</div><div>2. Labral fraying with detached biceps tendon anchor (41% of cases)</div><div>3. Bucket handle tear, intact biceps tendon anchor&nbsp;(33% of cases) (Biceps separates from bucket handle tear)</div><div>4. Bucket handle tear with detached biceps tendon anchor (15% of cases) (Biceps remains attached to bucket handle tear</div></div><div><div style=""font-style: normal;""><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-30 at 11.23.43 AM.png""></div></div></i>"																				
"<div style=""""><u style="""">classification of slap tear</u></div><div style="""">4. {{c1::Bucket handle tear}} with {{c1::detached}} biceps tendon anchor (15% of cases)&nbsp;</div>"	"<i><div><div><u>classification of slap tear</u><br></div><div>1. Labral and biceps fraying, anchor intact (11% of cases)</div><div>2. Labral fraying with detached biceps tendon anchor (41% of cases)</div><div>3. Bucket handle tear, intact biceps tendon anchor&nbsp;(33% of cases) (Biceps separates from bucket handle tear)</div><div>4. Bucket handle tear with detached biceps tendon anchor (15% of cases) (Biceps remains attached to bucket handle tear</div></div><div><div style=""font-style: normal;""><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-30 at 11.23.43 AM.png""></div></div></i>"																				
<i><div><b>Severity of&nbsp;TBI:</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Mild&nbsp;TBI:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score {{c1::13}} to {{c1::15}}</div></i>	<i><div><div><b>Severity of&nbsp;TBI:</b><br></div><div>Severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;(coma):&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 3 to 8</div><div>Moderate&nbsp;TBI:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 9 to 12</div><div>Mild&nbsp;TBI:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 13 to 15</div></div></i>																				
<i><div><div><b>Severity of&nbsp;TBI:</b><br></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Severe&nbsp;TBI aka {{c2::coma}}:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score {{c1::3}} to {{c1::8}}</div></div></i>	<i><div><div><b>Severity of&nbsp;TBI:</b><br></div><div>Severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;(coma):&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 3 to 8</div><div>Moderate&nbsp;TBI:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 9 to 12</div><div>Mild&nbsp;TBI:&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;score 13 to 15</div></div></i>																				
"Duration of&nbsp;PTA&nbsp;<u>mild</u>&nbsp;TBI<div><br></div><div>{{c1::0}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<u>&lt;</u> 24hr}}</div>"	"<table><tbody><tr><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">DURATION OF&nbsp;PTA</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">SEVERITY OF&nbsp;TBI</th></tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">0–1 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Mild</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&gt;1 day and &lt;7 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Moderate</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&gt;7 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Severe</td></tr></tbody></table><br>"																				
"Duration of&nbsp;PTA&nbsp;<u>severe</u>&nbsp;TBI<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&gt;&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">7</span>&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;days</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<table><tbody><tr><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">DURATION OF&nbsp;PTA</th><th colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">SEVERITY OF&nbsp;TBI</th></tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">0–1 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Mild</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&gt;1 day and &lt;7 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Moderate</td></tr><tr><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">&gt;7 days</td><td colspan=""1"" rowspan=""1"">Severe</td></tr></tbody></table><br>"																				
<b>Severity of TBI based on LOC</b><div><br></div><div>Mild: {{c1::0}} to {{c2::&lt; 30 min}}</div>	"<img src=""TBI-Classification-System-2.jpg"">"																				
<b>Severity of TBI based on LOC</b><div><br></div><div>Moderate: {{c1::30min}} to {{c2::24 hours}}</div>	"<img src=""TBI-Classification-System-2.jpg"">"																				
<b>Severity of TBI based on LOC</b><div><br></div><div>Severe: {{c1::&gt; 24 hours}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""TBI-Classification-System-2.jpg"">"																				
<b>osteochondritis dissecans</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div><br></div><div>condition thought to be secondary to {{c1::repetitive small stresses::pathophys (general ie, not elbow)}} to {{c4::subchondral bone}} that {{c2::disrupt blood supply}} to that area</div><div><br></div><div>process is essentialy a {{c3::localized area of&nbsp;AVN}}&nbsp;at the end of a long bone</div><div><br></div><div>may progress to formation of {{c5::a loose body}}</div>	"concern is that it will progress to OA but there is no clear evidence to support this<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">arthroscopies found a 60% incidence of cartilage
lesions</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">often associated w/ other injuries (ie ACL or meniscal)&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-16 at 11.53.28 AM.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<b>osteochondritis dissecans</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>areas typically involved include:</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">distal femur</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">distal humerus</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::patella}}<br></div><div>{{c2::talus}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-16 at 11.53.28 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>osteochondritis dissecans</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>walking with the foot&nbsp;rotated&nbsp;{{c1::outward}} may relieve pain</div><div>presence of a loose body may cause {{c2::mechanical symptoms::sx category}}&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c3::tenderness to palpation}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;over the chondral injury&nbsp;</span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ROM is critical&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ligamentous laxity testing to rule
out concomitant injury</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"mechanical symptoms: locking, synovial effusion, and a buckling sensation<br><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ROM may reveal&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">crepitus or clunk or be restricted&nbsp;</span><br><div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-16 at 12.06.02 PM.png""><br></div></div></div>"																				
"<b>osteochondritis dissecans</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>The patient must be {{c1::protected from weight bearing}}<br></div></div><div>surgical candidates are typically: {{c2::grade 3}}, {{c2::grade 4}}, and {{c2::detached fragment}}&nbsp;</div><div>surgeries include:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Microfracture,&nbsp;</span>{{c3::OATS}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">, ACI</span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">post-op rehab includes:&nbsp;</span>{{c4::continuous passive motion::device}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>healing of the defect may occur if the diagnosis is made before the fragment separates<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">MRI is standard of care in evaluating
the morphology of an articular cartilage injury and for ligamentous or meniscal injuries&nbsp;</span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">grade I</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">: </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>cartilage softening</b> and swelling</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">grade II</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">: </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>partial-thickness defect</b> with fissures on the surface that do not reach subchondral bone or exceed 1.5cm</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">grade III</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">: </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>fissuring to subchondral bone</b> in an area with a diameter of more than 1.5cm</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">grade IV</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">: </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>exposed
subchondral bone</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Microfracture, osteochondral auto-graft transfer (i.e., OAT), and autolo-gous chondrocyte implantation (ACI)</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""oats-procedure.jpg""><img src=""paste-81020559affbe78343c872a2ab52f9f45f4ff5d1.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b><br></b></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>popliteus tendonitis</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>{{c1::Lateral}} knee pain typically during {{c2::downhill}} activities and with excessive {{c2::pronation}}</div><div>Point tenderness anterior to the {{c3::LCL}}</div><div>Pain with {{c4::cross-legged}} position</div>	"Treatment<div>- Avoid downhill running until symptoms resolve.</div><div>- Rest, ice, compression,&nbsp;NSAIDs</div><div>- May require arch supports or medial heel wedges</div><div><img src=""350px-Popliteus_injection_site_Albury-Noyes.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Thomas Test:</b> used to assess hip flexion contracture&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>to a lesser extent, it can eval: {{c1::tight IT band}} and {{c1::tight quads}}</div>	"<div>if the thigh rises = hip felxion</div><div>if the shin rises = quadriceps</div><div>leg abducts = ITB&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-ddb853a24b37bdce75ed2535812ad739fe8e1a0a.png""><img src=""paste-f2933e4d101f4bc65f2a39b463ca48c7c298931e.jpg""><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_79.png"">"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><b>chronic exertional compartment syndrome</b>&nbsp;</div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>clinical features</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">pain described as aching, burning, or cramping in a specific
muscle region</span></div><div>pain will typically increase with {{c1:: exercise}}&nbsp;</div><div>neural compression can cause weakness and numbness</div><div><br></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>{{c2::firm compartment}} or {{c2::fascial hernias}} may be palpable</div><div>rarely are distal pulses diminished</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">fascia in the lower leg does not accommodate to the increase
in blood flow and fluid shifts that may occur with heavy exercise&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><br></div>pain associated with this syndrome could also be due to:<div>- Sensory receptor stimulation in fascia or periosteum caused by high pressure</div><div>- Release of biochemical factors caused by reduced blood flow that cant meet metabolic demand&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Lower leg pain may also be caused by tibial stress fractures or periostitis which occur concurrently with&nbsp;CECS</div><div><img src=""Compartment-Syndrome.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>chronic exertional compartment syndrome</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Imaging and Testing</u><br></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::Compartmental tissue pressure measurement}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;is the “gold
standard” for diagnosis</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div><img src=""compartment-syndromes-30-320.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""f67-03-9780323549479.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>chronic exertional compartment syndrome</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Imaging and Testing</u><br></div><div><div><div><div>Compartmental tissue pressure<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;measurement is the “gold standard” for diagnosis</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">devices most commonly used traditionally were the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::slit and wick catheters}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">newer devices, such as the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::transducer-tipped probe}} are more popular now<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div></div></div></div>"	"<div><img src=""compartment-syndromes-30-320.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""f67-03-9780323549479.jpg""></div>"																				
"<b>chronic exertional compartment syndrome</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">initial treatment consists of rest, ice, and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs</span><u><br></u></div><div>at present, the most effective treatment for&nbsp;CECS&nbsp;is {{c1::fasciotomy}}</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Counseling the patient to
avoid running on hard surfaces</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">use orthotics to control
pronation, and wear running shoes with the appropriate amount of cushion and a flared heel</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Surgery is usually reserved for symptoms persisting &gt;&nbsp;<u>6 to 12 weeks</u>, despite conservative therapy</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span><img src=""lower-leg-compartment-syndrome-surgery.jpg""></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>chronic exertional compartment syndrome</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Compartment pressure measurement</u>&nbsp;</div><div>elevated pressures should coincide with {{c2::reproduction of the exact pain syndrome}}</div><div>Pressures are measured {{c1::pre- and postexercise::timing for dx}}</div><div>delay in return to {{c3::preexercise pressure}} is required for a positive test</div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">The following values are</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;commonly used
to diagnose </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">anterior compartment </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">syndrome:</span></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- Pre-exercise pressure </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&gt;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">15 mm Hg</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- 1 minute after exercise </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&gt;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">30 mm Hg</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- 5 minutes after exercise </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&gt;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">20 mm Hg</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>Dr. Howard</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">a delta of 10mm Hg is also a borderline positive value&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19); font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19); font-style: italic;"">It is important that the patient’s symptoms correlate with&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19); font-style: italic;"">the compartment in which there is elevated pressure&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19); font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>MRI&nbsp;has been found useful given compexities for pressure measurement during exercise. r/o other causes&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Alternatively, near-
infrared spectroscopy has been used as well&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>acute compartment syndrome&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>necrosis of muscle and nerve can develop in as little as {{c1::4}} to {{c1::8}} hours</div><div><br></div><div>ACS&nbsp;most commonly occurs in association with {{c2::fractures of the long bones (leg or forearm)}}</div>	<div><div>ACS&nbsp;constitutes a <u>surgical emergency</u></div><div><br></div></div>intracompartmental tissue pressure acutely becomes elevated and obstructs venous outflow<div><br></div><div>If untreated, can develop with secondary muscle paralysis, muscle contractures, and sensory impairment called Volkmann’s ischemic necrosis<br></div>																				
<div><b>acute compartment snydrome</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>nontraumatic causes:</u>&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><div>{{c1::vascular disease}}</div><div>{{c1::thrombosis}}</div></div><div>{{c1::ischemia-reperfusion injury (s/p revascularization procedures)}}</div><div><br></div><div>conditions that decrease serum osmolarity</div><div>certain animal bites</div><div>prolonged limb compression (e.g., following severe drug or alcohol intoxication or poor positioning during surgery).<br></div>	"less frequent, but are <font color=""#fc0006"">more likely to go unnoticed</font><div><font color=""#fc0006""><br></font></div><div>
<div>
<div>
