<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Nontraumatic causes&nbsp; also include&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- hemorrhage into a compartment, as can occur in anticoagulated patients&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- after
diabetic muscle infarction</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- following trauma, soft
tissue injury and swelling [</span></div><div><font color=""#2c99bf"">-&nbsp;</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ischemia and then hyperperfusion caused by prolonged
surgery in the lithotomy position&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>acute compartment syndrome</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div><br></div><div>sx: cacharacteristics are {{c1::pain}}, {{c1::paresthesias}}, and {{c1::paralysis}} (3 Ps)</div><div><br></div><div>phys ex: Remove {{c2::cast or dressing if present}} and&nbsp;extreme pain&nbsp;on {{c2::passive stretching}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>intractable pain and sometimes sensory hypesthesia distal to the involved compartment (usually dorsal foot and median distribution in the hand)<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Of the 6 classic signs (pain, pallor,
pulselessness, paresthesias, paralysis, poikilothermia) pulselessness is rare&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>Pulses are usually completely normal in&nbsp;ACS&nbsp;because the intracompartmental pressure rarely exceeds systolic or mean arterial pressure&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div>strethching the long muscles passing through a compartment (plantar flexion of toes or full extension of fingers will stretch muscles of the forearm or shin)</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-12-16 at 6.10.14 PM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>acute compartment syndrome</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Imaging and Testing</u></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Slit catheter}} technique: inserting a catheter into the compartment and monitoring the pressure via a transducer&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>compartment syndrome = when the {{c2::diastolic}} pressure minus the {{c2::intra-compartmental}} pressure is ≤ {{c3::20}} mmHg</div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Manometric techniques (handheld manometry or needle manometry) are available to measure compartment pressure directly.<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">The differential pressure, calculated as the intra-muscular pressure subtracted from the diastolic blood pressure, determines the treatment course</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">1.) If the differential
pressure is less than 30mm Hg, <u>fasciotomy is indicated</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">2.) if remains above
30mm Hg, safe to observe with <u>serial pressure measurements</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-23 at 11.14.37 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>{{c1::Medial Tibila Stress}}&nbsp;Syndrome aka&nbsp;shin splints</b><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div><br></div><div>repetitive-stress injury that results from chronic traction on the {{c2::periosteal}}–{{c2::fascial}} junction<br></div><div><br></div><div>attachment of the {{c3::soleus}} muscle along the medial tibia may be the most likely site of avulsion</div><div><br></div><div>main predisposing factor is {{c4::hyper-pronation}}</div>	"<div>periosteum may become detached from the bone due to ballistic overload<br></div><div><br></div><div>fibrofatty filling may occur at the site of the defect</div><div><br></div><div>other deep flexors of the foot are involved<br></div><div><br></div><div>common in runners after an increase in training&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-24 at 8.43.42 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>medial tibial stress syndrome&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>gradual onset of pain along the posteromedial border of the tibia</div><div>pain may {{c1::improve}} with exercise&nbsp;</div>	"<div><div>pain worsens&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">after</span>&nbsp;the completion of activity and can last until the next morning</div><div>TTP along the entire length or as little length as 2 to 4 cm</div><div>HPI: repetitive running on hard surfaces, inappropriate warm-up, inappropriate or recent change in footwear</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-24 at 8.43.42 AM.png"">"																				
<b>medial tibial stress syndrome&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>relative rest is first, NSAID's, stretching of the posterior compartemnt&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>when pain is present at rest {{c1::crutch walking}} is indicated</div><div>{{c3::ice massage}} and {{c3::graston}} technique&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::custom orthotic insert (+/- heel wedge)}} or {{c2::arch support shoes}}</div><div>Fasciotomy of the posteromedial fascia may be required in resistant cases (rarely needed)</div>	"Decreasing the volume of the inciting activity or avoidance of the activity entirely should be considered<div><div>Return to activity should be gradual and should occur when the patient is pain free for several days</div><div>A comprehensive history should be obtained, including running mileage, changes in intensity, and footwear<br></div><div>Training should start at 50% of preinjury level for intensity and distance. Soft, level surfaces should be used initially<br></div><div><img src=""images-ddb39b0f4dcb87bae92e63aecc2d7870d69ddd57.jpg""><img src=""images-ac92ad1608f08fd48eb5f5ecd534e47f644b636c.jpg""><img src=""foot-shape-and-shoes.jpg""><br></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Lower Extremity Stress Fractures</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Symptoms</u></div><div>Pain {{c1::worsens}} with increased activity</div><div><br></div><div><u>Physical Examination</u>&nbsp;</div><div>well localized TTP at the fracture site<br></div><div>{{c2::one-legged hop}} test&nbsp;<br></div><div>even {{c3::a tuning fork}} can illicit pain</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>pain may progress to walking and rest, night pain may occur<br></div><div><br></div><div>There may be swelling and redness at the fracture site<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-24 at 9.52.08 PM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lower Extremity Stress Fractures: classic risk factor is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::low bone mineral density}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;commonly seen in&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Female athlete triad}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">female athlete triad (the triad) refers to a constellation of 3 clinical entities:&nbsp;</span><div><b>menstrual dysfunction</b></div><div><b>low energy availability (with or without an eating disorder)</b></div><div><b>decreased bone mineral density (BMD)</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">.</span></div><div><br></div><div>Low bone mineral density (BMD) poses a higher risk for stress fractures. Causes of low&nbsp;BMD&nbsp;include.</div><div>- Females with late onset of menses</div><div>- Individuals with low body weight (&lt;75% ideal body weight)</div><div>- Poor nutrition correlates with lower calcium intake</div><div>- Tobacco and excessive alcohol use</div><div>- Female athlete triad</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Lower Extremity Stress Fractures</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>most common sites include:</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">1. tibia</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">2.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::fibula}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">3.&nbsp;</span>{{c2::metatarsals}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-24 at 9.57.23 PM.png"">"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lower Extremity Stress Fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>{{c1::X-rays}}: the first line diagnostic imaging&nbsp;</div></div>"	"<div>they are highly specific but not that sensitive&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-24 at 10.07.28 PM.png""><br></div><div><br></div>X-rays are the first line diagnostic imaging but are rarely abnormal initially.<div>- Stress fractures may not be seen for 2 to 3 weeks after symptoms develop.</div><div>- Periosteal thickening appears first, followed by cortical lucency.</div><div>- The linear stress fracture appears as a lucency within a thickened area of cortical hyperostosis during healing.</div><div><br></div><div>MRI</div><div>- MRI&nbsp;is the most sensitive and specific, becoming the first choice of test in investigating stress fractures.</div><div>- MRI&nbsp;has comparable sensitivity to bone scan with better specificity.</div><div>- MRI&nbsp;can also visualize the fracture and differentiate between fracture and other lesions.</div><div><br></div><div>Bone scan</div><div>- Bone scans can be used when radiographs are negative and a stress fracture is still highly suspected.</div><div>- Bone scans are very sensitive (close to 100%) but low in specificity.</div><div>- A positive scan will yield focal increased uptake in the third phase.</div><div>- Tumors, osteomyelitis, bony infarct, and bony dysplasia can also cause localized increased uptake.</div><div><br></div><div>CT</div><div>- CT&nbsp;scan can reveal fracture lines not visualized with plain films.</div><div>- CT&nbsp;can also differentiate other lesions that cause increased uptake on bone scan.</div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lower Extremity Stress Fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>MRI is ordered when {{c1::Xray is negative}} and fracture is {{c1::at a suspected high risk site}}&nbsp;</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-24 at 10.07.28 PM.png"">"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lower Extremity Stress Fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>CT is ordered when {{c1::MRI is inconclusive}}</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-24 at 10.07.28 PM.png"">"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lower Extremity Stress Fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><div><u>treatment</u></div></div><div>the most important factor in managment is determining {{c1::high risk versus low risk site}}&nbsp;<br></div>"	"<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Low-risk sites</span></div><div>- Fractures of the second and third metatarsal shafts</div><div>- posteromedial tibial shaft</div><div>- fibula</div><div>- proximal humerus or humeral shaft</div><div>- ribs, sacrum, and pubic rami&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">High-risk sites</span>&nbsp;</div><div>- Pars interarticularis of the lumbar spine&nbsp;</div><div>- Femoral head&nbsp;</div><div>- Femoral neck&nbsp;</div><div>- Patella</div><div>- Anterior cortex of the tibia (ie, tension side)</div><div>- Medial malleolus</div><div>- Talus</div><div>- Tarsal navicular</div><div>- Proximal fourth metatarsal</div><div>- Proximal fifth metatarsal shaft</div><div>- Base of second metatarsal&nbsp;<br></div><div>- Great toe sesamoid</div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lower Extremity Stress Fractures</b><div><br></div><div><u>Orthopedic refferral for:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::high risk site}}</div><div>{{c2::progression on imaging}}</div><div>{{c3::failed rehab}}&nbsp;</div><div>high demand athlete/worker&nbsp;<br></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>surgery has not shown to be beneficial in the literature.&nbsp; However...</div><div><br></div><div>femoral neck fractures (superior aspect) may
require pinning, if they do not heal w/ nonweight bearing</div><div>Midshaft tibial fractures are at risk for non-union. must be immobilized and observed closely; open bone grafting may be done</div><div>Tarsal navicular stress fracture may require ORIF<br></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>Lower Extremity Stress Fracture</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div><div>those without pain on normal ambulation should avoid aggravating the injury (i.e., relative rest)</div></div><div>if there is pain on normal ambulation, the patient should be {{c1::nonweight bearing}} for {{c2::7}} to {{c2::10}} days</div><div>maintain fitness with {{c3::Nonimpact activities (ie. cycling and swimming)}}&nbsp;</div><div>at least {{c4::1}} to {{c4::2}} weeks of pain-free normal ambulation should be achieved before returning to {{c3::impact activity}}</div>	"Stress fractures of the 1st to 4th metatarsal shafts typically will heal with rest alone and do not require immobilization<br><div><br></div><div>In non–weight- bearing subjects, a trial of walking is performed every 2 days</div><div>once walking is pain free, full ambulation with crutches is begun</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">stress fractures at greater risk for delayed healing or nonunion, but which are still frequently managed by primary care physicians (eg, fractures involving tibial plateau or medial malleolus), treatment can include a short period of non-weightbearing and stabilization in a long air splint, knee splint, or hinged brace.</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">If such devices are unavailable, either a controlled ankle movement (CAM) walker or cast boot that extends above the level of the fracture is likely effective. No crutches are required if the patient can ambulate in a splint with little or no pain.</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">The non-weightbearing phase typically extends only as long as the patient experiences significant pain with walking. Once a splint allows the patient to walk with little to no pain, the patient can transition to intermittent or partial use of crutches and then steadily to unassisted ambulation.</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Fibula stress fracture is similar.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Metatarsal stress fractures usually respond well to cessation of the inciting activity (eg, marching, dancing, running) for four to eight weeks</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">In some instances the use of a stiff soled orthopedic shoe or a walking boot may be helpful for patients who continue to have pain despite cessation of the inciting activity. If pain persists with simple walking, a period of unloading (usually a week or two) may be helpful until walking is no longer painful. Unloading can be accomplished by making the patient partial or non-weight-bearing with crutches or other means. For partial weight-bearing, the patient can use the heel of the affected foot. In patients with severe pain, a short-leg cast and non-weight-bearing can be used for a short period (eg, one to two weeks).</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div>Calcium intake should be 1,500 mg daily with 400 to 800&nbsp;IU&nbsp;of vitamin D</div><div><img src=""Aircushionedlegsplint.jpg""><img src=""FNT24-2667R.JPG""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-e963a3088fe7555a6b28711fd52ef4cd859d6738.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Lower Extremity Stress Fracture High Risk Site</b><div><br></div><div><u>Orthoses/DME</u></div><div><u><br></u></div><div><div>midshaft tibial stress fractures and tarsal navicular fractures, require immediate immobilization with a {{c1::bivalved orthotic boot}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Femoral neck fractures on the tension (superior) aspect require strict non–weight-bearing status with {{c2::axillary crutches}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Metatarsal stress fractures can be treated with a {{c3::stiff shoe}} or a {{c3::rigid orthosis}}</div><div><br></div><div>Navicular fractures may require immobilization in a {{c4::short leg cast}}</div></div>	"Fractures with the propensity to progress to nonunion, may require immediate immobilization or strict non–weight-bearing status&nbsp;<br><div><img src=""aircast_airselect_standard_1.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Postoperativeshoe.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-5e418373fa7fad66c25afb92f8607766d014eadb.png""><br></div><div>certain types of navicular would need casting&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Walkingbootbrace.jpg""><br></div><div>per uptodate this could be okay for navicular and acute 5th metaterasal fracture&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">A walking boot or brace is used in the treatment of a number of fractures or soft tissue injuries of the leg.</span><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Energy Expenditure of Different Levels of Amputation (trauma)&nbsp;</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">with respect to <u>vascular unilateral</u> BKA and AKA,</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">energy expenditure of gait is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::multiplied by 2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, as compared with traumatic&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div>T BKA = ~20%</div><div>V BKA = 40%</div><div>T AKA = ~60%</div><div>V AKA = 100%</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-03 at 10.56.09 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Neck and back pain</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Course</u></div><div>Disability and the ability to return to work generally improve in {{c1::1 month}}</div><div>but {{c2::one-third::fraction}} may have persistent discomfort for up to a year after injury</div><div>20% of those reporting limitation in activity</div>	"<div>Neck and back pain are the leading musculoskeletal disorders that contribute to impairment and disability</div><div><br></div><div>Injury to the lumbar region in particular has up to a 15% annual incidence and 84% l<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ifetime prevalence (70% cervical, 15% thoracic)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">natural course is favorable, as symptoms are usually self-limited</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">though resolution is likely, recurrence of symptoms is possible because of structural and pathological functional adaptations</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div><b>Neck and back pain</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Course</u></div><div>approximately {{c1::10}}% of patients with low back pain continue with residual complaints</div>	<div>Due to its morbidity, this subgroup constitutes the 2nd most common reason for primary care physician office visits.</div><div><br></div><div>Proper treatment of these patients depends on an accurate diagnosis, which may be elusive due to the complexity of the structures involved.</div><div><br></div><div>Diagnostic testing may be indicated to further define pathology and to focus care.</div>																				
<div><b>Neck and back pain</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Course</u></div><div>approx {{c1::50}}% resolve in 1-2 weeks</div><div>approx {{c1::90}}% resolve in 6-12 weeks<u><br></u></div><div>approx {{c2::85}}% recur</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-01 at 11.04.45 AM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Neck and Back pain</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Red Flag Symptoms</u></span></div><div>{{c1::gait ataxia/falls (significant neuro decline {numbness, weakness})}}<br></div><div>{{c2::bowel/bladder dysfunction (saddle anesthesia)}}<br></div><div>{{c3::weight loss}}<br></div><div>{{c4::fevers chills}}</div><div>+/- {{c9::morning stiffness (improves w/ exer)::younger pt}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Red Flag HPI</u><br></div><div>{{c5::major fall or trauma}}<br></div><div>{{c6::personal history of cancer}}<br></div><div>{{c7::recent spine procedure/surgery}}<br></div><div>{{c8::immuno supressed/compromised}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-01 at 11.08.14 AM.png""><div><b><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><img src=""gmEQByGsF2TjiZkCJaBojpZEWXHcoCHSjKrtdg4IMLKBPgzbEYF_Xh44Ltuu7LjAIx0rPblwTrtbDlOioLjIKxChRN__svkEAofI7ytYQm6D2HXzpDt.png""></span></b><br></div><div><b><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><br></span></b></div><div><b><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Studies show imaging w/out redflags or radiculopathy does not change outcomes</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Further – 25-65% of asymptomatic people have bulging discs and or spinal stenosis</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">OA poorly correlates with sx’s</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Ask if they would even consider surgery anyway</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Changes of unclear significance: annular tears, modic changes, schmorl's nodes</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Most do not require imaging especially if pain &lt; 4 weeks</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">MRI w/ out con is usually the imaging of choice 1</span><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">st</span><span style=""font-weight: 400;""> line if it is req</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">CT if the pt can not undergo MRI is reasonable alternative</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">X-ray x2 (anterior-posterior and lateral will suffice) (do not get oblique’s or flex/ext)</span></div><br><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><u>Immediate MRI get in acute back pain +</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">1. Cauda equina (weakness not fitting SN. bladder/fecal retention/incontinence, saddle)</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">2. Severe Trauma&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">3. Severe or progressive neruo sx’s (ie weakness)</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">4. Point tenderness, </span><span style=""font-weight: 400; text-decoration-line: underline;"">Fever</span><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">, hemodialysis, IVDU, Epidural, endocarditis, bacteremia&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">6. c/f cancer w/ neuro sx’s</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">7. c/f cancer no neuro sx guided by algorithm&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">8. lower c/f infection guided by algorithm&nbsp;</span></div><br><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><u>Delayed MRI in</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">1. +/- Severe sx fitting a nerve route as out pt (radic)</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">2. + straight leg raise</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">3. +/- Stable sx’s of spnal stenosis as out pt (both in absence of red flags)</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">4. these pts w/ sx’s &gt;4-6wks who are willing and surge candidate = MRI</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><u>immediate X-ray</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">1.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35); font-weight: 400;"">sig compression fx – algorithm&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35); font-weight: 400;"">2. &gt;70y/o w/ acute pain</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35); font-weight: 400;"">3. cancer no neuro sx’s</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35); font-weight: 400;"">“Factors to consider include the patient's age, smoking history, family history, physical examination findings, and any associated concerning symptoms (eg, recent weight loss)”</span></div><br><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><u>Delayed x-ray after trial of tx/therapy</u></span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">1.&nbsp;minor risk factors for cancer (unexplained weight loss or age &gt;50 years)</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">2. if these don’t improve in 4-6 wks and were not previously imaged = image</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">3. risk factors for ankylosing spondylitis (AM stiffness improves w/ exercise, alternating buttock pain,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">4. risk factors for vertebral compression fracture (osteoporosis, glucocorticoid use, sig. trauma, or older&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">5. 4-6wks</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">- if sx’s unchanged and imaged before do not re-image</span></div></b></div>"																				
<b>Neck and Back Pain</b><div><br></div><div><u>Absenteeism</u><br></div><div>Missed work for 6 months = approx {{c1::50}}% return to work</div><div>Missed work for 1 year = approx {{c2::25}}% return to work<br></div><div>Missed work for 2 years = approx {{c3::0}}% return to work<br></div>																					
"<b>Acute Low Back Pain (&lt;4-6 wks)</b>&nbsp;""essential the same as red flags""<div><br></div><div><u>indicatations for immediate imaging (MRI)</u></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Trauma}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Unexplained Weight Loss}}</div><div>{{c3::Neurological Symptoms (severe)}}</div><div>{{c4::Age &gt; 50}}*</div><div>{{c5::Fever}}</div><div>{{c6::Invasive Procedures (ESI, IVDU, Dialysis)}}</div><div>{{c7::Steroid Use (immunocompromised)}}</div><div>{{c8::History of Cancer}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><u>severe Neuro</u><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>&nbsp;symptoms include:</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">new urinary retention or urinary incontinence (from overflow)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">new fecal incontinence</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">saddle anesthesia</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">significant motor deficits&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">(not localized to a single nerve root)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">(not needed immediately in stable spinal stenosis)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><div><u>c/f Infection</u>&nbsp;</div><div>objective fever, TTP of SP's (vertebral osteomyelitis), and Neuro sx's (spinal epidural abscess)</div><div></div><div>Current immunosuppression<br></div><div>Hemodialysis</div><div>IVDU</div><div>invasive epidural/spinal procedure</div><div>Current or recent endocarditis or bacteremia</div></div><div><br></div><div><u>Cancer</u></div><div>any current or recent cancer</div><div>known mets</div><div>wether they have had imaging recently or not</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-02 at 11.08.27 AM.png""><br></div><img src=""ACEP_0517_pg16a.png"">"																				
<div><b>Acute Low back Pain,&nbsp;risk factors for Infection (spinal epidural abscess)</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Presentation</u></div><div>fever, TTP of SP's (vertebral osteomyelitis), and Neuro sx's&nbsp;</div><div></div><div><br></div><div><u>HPI</u></div><div>{{c1::Current immunosuppression}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Hemodialysis}}</div><div>{{c3::invasive procedures (epidural/spinal injection, surgery, IVDU)}}<br></div><div>{{c4::Current or recent endocarditis or bacteremia}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-02 at 11.08.27 AM.png"">"																				
"<div><b>Acute Low back Pain,&nbsp;Neurologic Compromise</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Symptoms warranting imediate imaging</u></div><div><div>{{c1::new urinary dysfunction}}<br></div><div>{{c1::new bowel incontinence}}<br></div><div>{{c2::saddle anesthesia}}<br></div><div>{{c3::severe motor deficit}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;that is&nbsp;</span>{{c3::not atributable to a single nerve root}}</div></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">(not needed immediately in stable spinal stenosis or radiculopathy)</span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-02 at 11.08.27 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Lower Back Pain</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Indications for delayed MRI</u></div><div>
<div>{{c2::severe sx's/phys-ex fitting a single nerve route}}&nbsp;<b></b></div>
<div>{{c3::stable sx’s/phys-ex of spinal
stenosis}}&nbsp;<br></div><div><b></b></div>
<div>and even non-specific axial LBP who {{c1::trialed PT &gt;4-6wks}} and who are {{c1::willing to undergo ESI/surgery}}<b></b></div></div>"	the caveat is that severe weakness from radic that effects ADL's probably should have stat imaging and expedited referral to NSY<div><br></div><div>axial LBP in actual clinical practice may get MRI and ESI after failing therapy for 6 weeks, although evidence for this is low&nbsp;</div>																				
<b>C3–C7 Vertebrae</b><div><br></div><div><u>unique characteristic</u><br><div>cervical uncinate processes: raised margins along the {{c1::lateral}} aspect of the superior vertebral body&nbsp;</div><div>caused by {{c2::disc degeneration}}</div></div>	"<img src=""Uncovertebral-joints.png"">"																				
uncinate processes aka {{c1::joints of Luschka}}	"<img src=""Uncovertebral-joints.png"">"																				
C3, C4, C5, C6: {{c1::Bifid::unique characteristic}} spinous processes	"C1 and C2 are rings<div>C7: <u>Non</u>bifid spinous process</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_140.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Lumbosacral Transitional Vertebrae</b><div><br></div><div>importance of identifying this entity is for {{c1::correctly identifying the level of pathology}}<br></div>	"<div>notably when planning for an interventional spinal procedure or surgery</div><div><br></div><div><div><b>Nomenclature:</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Sacralization:</u>&nbsp;anomalous partial or complete fusion of the L5 vertebra to the sacrum.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Incidence: Approximately 1% complete, approximately 6% incomplete</div><div><br></div><div><u>Lumbarization:</u>&nbsp;partial or complete nonunion of the S1 segment of the sacrum.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>This forms an additional lumbar segment (“L6” vertebra) and leaves four remaining fused sacral segments. Incidence approximately 4%.</div></div><div><img src=""APM-15-103-f2.jpg""><br></div><div><span style=""background-color: rgb(245, 245, 245);"">(A) If the lowest ribs are interpreted as 12th ribs (white arrows), the lumbar spinal configuration might be identified as (sacralization) <font color=""#fc0006"">WRONG</font>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""background-color: rgb(245, 245, 245);"">(B) By counting inferiorly from C1, the lowest ribs are confirmed as 13th ribs and the lowest incomplete-fused vertebra as S1 (lumbarization).</span><br></div>"																				
"<div><div><strong>Sacral Vertebrae</strong></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">A triangular-shaped bone consisting of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;fused vertebrae</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div><strong>Coccygeal Vertebrae</strong></div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::3-4::#-#}} fused segments</div></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_145.png"">"																				
<b>Facet Joint Orientation</b><div><br></div><div><u>Cervical:</u></div><div>Atlanto-axial (AA) and atlanto-occipital (AO) joints have no true facet joints due to their atypical anatomy.</div><div>C3–C7 facets are positioned in the {{c1::frontal (coronal)}} plane</div><div><br></div><div><u>Thoracic facets</u>&nbsp;</div><div>are positioned in the {{c1::frontal (coronal)}} plane</div><div><br></div><div><u>Lumbar facets</u>&nbsp;</div><div>are positioned in the {{c1::sagittal}}&nbsp;</div>	"lumbar begins saggital plane in the upper lumbar region and progress to the frontal plane at L5–S1<div><img src=""Thoracic+Spine.Physio.Auckland.mrsphysio.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Facet Innervation</b><div><br></div><div>Each facet joint is innervated by {{c1::two::#}} {{c1::medial branch}} nerves from the {{c2::dorsal rami}} of the spinal nerve&nbsp;</div>"	"The pattern of innervation differs depending on the spinal region.<div><img src=""MBB-Diagram-Copy.jpg""><br></div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">L4-L5</font><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">&nbsp;</span><font color=""#fc0006"">facet</font><span style=""color: var(--wp--preset--color--vivid-red)  !important;""> in red</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">. </span><font color=""#14980c"">L3 and L4</font><font color=""#002444"">&nbsp;</font><span style=""color: var(--wp--preset--color--vivid-green-cyan)  !important;"">originating branches in green&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">going to innervate that joint.</span><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-02 at 5.36.32 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);""><br></span></div><div>C4-C5 facet is innervated by the C4 and C 5 dorsal rami&nbsp;</div>"																				
<div><b>Facet Innervation</b></div><div><br></div><div>facets in the thoracic and lumbar spines are innervated by...</div><div><br></div><div>Example: the L4–L5 facet joint is innervated by the {{c1::L3}} and {{c1::L4}} medial branches</div>	"<div>medial branches from the one above and&nbsp; 2 levels above&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""MBB-Diagram-Copy.jpg""><br></div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">L4-L5</font><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">&nbsp;</span><font color=""#fc0006"">facet</font><span style=""color: var(--wp--preset--color--vivid-red)  !important;"">&nbsp;in red</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">.&nbsp;</span><font color=""#14980c"">L3 and L4</font><font color=""#002444"">&nbsp;</font><span style=""color: var(--wp--preset--color--vivid-green-cyan)  !important;"">originating branches in green&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">going to innervate that joint.</span><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-02 at 5.36.32 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);""><br></span></div><div>C4-C5 facet is innervated by the C4 and C 5 dorsal rami&nbsp;</div>"																				
<b>Facet Innervation</b><div><br></div><div>Facet joints in the cervical spine are innervated by...&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Example: the C4–C5 facet is innervated by the {{c1::C4}} and {{c1::C5}} medial branches</div>	"<div>medial branches from both of the spinal levels of that facet joint<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-02 at 5.36.32 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);""><br></span></div><div>C4-C5 facet is innervated by the C4 and C5 dorsal rami&nbsp;</div><div><div><img src=""MBB-Diagram-Copy.jpg""><br></div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">L4-L5</font><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">&nbsp;</span><font color=""#fc0006"">facet</font><span style=""color: var(--wp--preset--color--vivid-red)  !important;"">&nbsp;in red</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">.&nbsp;</span><font color=""#14980c"">L3 and L4</font><font color=""#002444"">&nbsp;</font><span style=""color: var(--wp--preset--color--vivid-green-cyan)  !important;"">originating branches in green&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 36, 68);"">going to innervate that joint.</span></div></div>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">intervertebral disc i</span>nnervation</b><div><br></div><div>receives innervation from the {{c1::sinuvertebral nerve}} and {{c2::gray ramus communicans}}</div><div><br></div><div>both innervations are from the {{c3::ventral}} rami&nbsp;</div>"	"the above refers to the outer 1/3 of the disc (annulus fibrosis)<div><br></div><div>the nucleus pulposus does <u>NOT have innervation</u><br></div><div><img src=""jkma-2021-64-3-185f2.gif""><u><br></u></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/351044697/figure/fig2/AS:1015269812088834@1619070594766/The-sinuvertebral-nerve-innervates-the-disc-In-a-healthy-adult-disc-the-nerve-endings.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Dorsal Spinal Rami</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>innervate</u></div><div>some skin, dorsal spinal ligaments</div><div>{{c1::ZP joints}}</div><div>{{c1::extensor back musculature}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-02 at 6.36.56 PM.png"">"																				
position assosicated with highest disc pressure changes: {{c1::forward flexion}}	"<div><div>Relative change in pressure (or load) in the 3rd lumbar disc in various positions</div></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_150.png""><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Note</span>: Neutral erect posture is considered 100% in the figures; other postures and activities are calculated in relationship to this.</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Source</span>: From Nachemson AL. The lumbar spine: an orthopaedic challenge. Spine. 1976;1:59–71</div>"																				
"<b>Aging Effects on the Disc</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>decreases in the following:</u></div><div>{{c1::Nuclear water content}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Ratio of chondroitin:keratin}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c3::Proteoglycan molecular weight}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-03 at 1.24.17 PM.png"">"																				
<strong>Ligamentum flavum</strong>:<div><br></div><div>Function: Maintains {{c1::constant disc tension}} and assists in straightening the column after flexion</div>	"Elastic ligament that connects adjacent vertebral arches longitudinally, attaching laminae to laminae<div><img src=""Ligament-Injuries-1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>{{c1::Interspinous}}</b><strong>&nbsp;and&nbsp;</strong><b>{{c1::supraspinous}}</b><strong>&nbsp;ligaments</strong><div><br></div><div>Run from spinous process to spinous process</div><div><br></div><div>Function: Weakly resist both spinal {{c2::separation}} and {{c2::flexion}}</div>	"supraspinous ligament runs from C7 to L3:<div><img src=""Ligament-Injuries-1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>{{c1::Intertransverse}}</b><strong>&nbsp;ligaments</strong>:<div><br></div><div>Connect&nbsp;TP&nbsp;to&nbsp;TP</div><div><br></div><div>Function: Resist lateral flexion of the spine</div>	"<img src=""3746-ligaments_labeled.jpg"">"																				
<b>Surface Anatomy</b>&nbsp;<strong>Landmarks</strong><div><br></div><div><u>Cervical Region</u></div><div>{{c1::C7}}: Vertebral prominens (largest cervical SP, not bifid)</div><div><br></div><div><u>Thoracic Region</u></div><div>{{c2::T3}}: Spine of the scapula</div><div>{{c3::T8}}: Inferior angle of the scapula</div><div><br></div><div><u>Lumbar Region</u></div><div>{{c4::L4}}: Iliac crests</div><div>{{c5::S2}}: Posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS)</div>	"<img src=""8e1153d802a254b35d9d0db4d2eb3dbe.jpg""><div><img src=""211-1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Intrinsic Back Muscles</b><div><br></div><div><u>Superficial layer:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Splenius capitis and cervices}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Intermediate layer aka Erector spinae:</u></div><div>{{c1::Iliocostalis: Lumborum, thoracis, cervices}}</div><div>{{c1::Longissimus: Thoracis, cervicis, capitis}}</div><div>{{c1::Spinalis: Thoracis, cervicis, capitis}}<div></div></div><div><br></div><div><u>Deep layer aka {{c2::Transverso-spinal}} muscles:</u><div>{{c3::Multifidus}}</div><div>{{c3::Rotators}}</div></div><div>{{c3::Semispinalis: Thoracis, cervicis, capitis}}<br></div>	"lateral to medial convention (also superficial to deep)<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_152.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Atlanto-occipital joint and&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Atlanto-axial joint make up&nbsp;</span>{{c1::50}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of flexion/extension and rotation movement of the cervical spine&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">remaining motion is distributed over the C3-C7 cervical segments</span>"																				
"<div><b style="""">Internal snapping hip syndrome</b><u><br></u></div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>Provocative Tests:</u></div><div>{{c1::Flex}}, {{c1::abduct}}, and {{c1::externally rotate}} the affected hip<br></div>"	"<div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><b><font color=""#0b6aff"">Essentially the opposite of Scouring Maneveur</font></b></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">External snapping hip syndrome:&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Internally and externally rotate the hip passively while the patient is in the lateral decubitus position</span><br></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><b>palpate the tendon</b></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><b>First: Flex, aBduct, externally rotate&nbsp;</b></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><b>followed by: Extend, and internally rotate</b></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-16 at 10.09.01 AM.png""><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-16 at 10.08.43 AM.png""><br></div><div><br></div>"																				
"<strong>The Degenerative Cascade: Spondylosis</strong><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch04#bid_4_37"">Kirkaldy–Willis and Burton (1992)</a>&nbsp;presented a functional degenerative classification of the three-joint complex.&nbsp;</div><div>It is initiated by a rotational strain or compressive force to the spine during lumbar flexion.</div><div><br></div><div><u>cascade consists of three phases:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>(a) {{c1::dysfunction}}</div><div>(b) {{c2::instability}}</div><div>(c) {{c3::stabilization}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_153.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-04 at 3.04.03 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>Herniated Disc</b></div><div><br></div><u>General</u><div><u><br></u><div>HNP is a disc injury in which the {{c1::nuclear pulposus}} migrates through the {{c1::annular fibers}}</div><div><br></div><div>may also initiate the release of enzyme {{c2::phospholipase A2}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>most commonly happens at {{c3::30}} to {{c3::40}} years of age</div></div><div><br></div><div>the most common location is {{c4::L4}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">–</span>{{c4::L5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c4::L5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">–</span>{{c4::S1}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;discs followed by the&nbsp;</span>{{c5::C5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">–</span>{{c5::C6}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;disc</span></div>"	"phospholipase A2 is the most common cause of chemical radiculitis (per Bobby)<div><br></div><div>it activates inflammatory mediators, such as leukotrienes, prostaglandins, platelet-activating factors, bradykinins, and cytokines<br></div><div><br></div><div>Fortunately, approximately three-fourths of these injuries will resolve with conservative care in 6 months to 1 year<br></div><div><img src=""annular-tear-2.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Disc classifications. (A)&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Bulging disc}}<br>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Disc classifications. (A) Bulging disc. (B) Prolapsed disc. (C) Extruded disc. (D) Sequestered disc.</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_154.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-04 at 3.19.31 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Disc classifications. (B)&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Prolapsed disc}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Disc classifications. (A) Bulging disc. (B) Prolapsed disc. (C) Extruded disc. (D) Sequestered disc.</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_154.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-04 at 3.19.31 PM.png""></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Disc classifications. (C)&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Extruded disc}}</div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Disc classifications. (A) Bulging disc. (B) Prolapsed disc. (C) Extruded disc. "Bulging Disc:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">No&nbsp;</span>{{c1::annulus defect}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">. Disc convexity is&nbsp;</span>{{c2::beyond vertebral margins}}"	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_154.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Prolapsed disc:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Nuclear material protrudes into&nbsp;</span>{{c1::an annulus defect}}"	"<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_154.png""><br></div>"

"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Sequestered disc:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Nuclear fragment is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::free in the canal}}"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_154.png"">"																				
"

<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Approximately&nbsp;</span>{{c1::one third::fraction}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;of&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">asymptomatic&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">subjects have substantial lumbar degenerative abnormalities on MRI</span></div>
</div>
</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Lumbar degenerative disease is probably entirely asymp- tomatic in the majority of cases.</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Because of factors not well understood, such as leakage of inflammatory factors from the disc,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">a chronic pain syndrome may develop in some patients, possibly from repetitive sensitization of nociceptive fibers in the anulus fibrosus&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Patients
with myofascial or soft tissue etiology of back pain&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">report pain worsened with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::static}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::prolonged physical activity}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">improvement may be associated with rest and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::modalities (<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">heat, cold, and pressure)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>"	"improvement with modalities<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;including heat, cold, and pressure = makes you think its more superficial</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">or at least they have concomitant myofascial pain&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
"<b>Lumbar Spondylosis / Disc Disorders&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>plain film Xrays</u></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::Antero-posterior}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lateral}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;radiographs&nbsp;</span></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c2::Oblique}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;views are helpful
to identify&nbsp;</span>{{c3::spondylolysis}}</div><div>{{c4::Flexion-extension}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;films are necessary to identify&nbsp;</span>{{c5::dynamic instability}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">up todate rec only ap and lateral ??</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">dynamic instability and can assist in the selection of appropriate surgical candidates for fusion</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Significant degenerative instability usually does not occur before the age of 50 years&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""images-21e760428149eac5fd4a0355ee5b8bb22dc93133.jpg""><img src=""Spondylolysis_x_ray_.docx.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""4-Figure3-1-a907aa91710a0a4e4ac1ffba1d2e8866932e0ad8.png""><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Lumbar Spondylosis / Disc Disorders&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>X-ray findings:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Decreased disc height::common OA}}</div><div>{{c1::vertebral osteophytosis::common OA}}</div><div>{{c1::sclerosis::common OA}}</div><div>{{c2::foraminal narrowing::unique spine}}</div><div>{{c2::facet arthrosis::unique spine}}</div><div>

<div>
<div><div>{{c1::Discography}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">: only technique that correlates structural abnormalities of the disc with a patient’s pain response&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><img src=""discogram1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>Discography</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::Reproduction}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;of painful symptoms with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::intradiscal injection of contrast}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">aids in the ""localization"" of specific disc levels as pain generators&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">separates painful disc degeneration from painless degeneration&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(8, 8, 8);"">dye moves into cracks in the disc, which can then be seen on a&nbsp;</span>CT<span style=""color: rgb(8, 8, 8);"">&nbsp;scan</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(8, 8, 8);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(8, 8, 8);"">However, disks that show signs of wear and tear don't always cause symptoms, so use is controversial</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(8, 8, 8);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(8, 8, 8);"">may be used to select pt's for fusion, d</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">isc arthroplasty, discectomy (</span><font color=""#fc0006"">again also controversiol for disc/axial pain</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">)&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""discogram1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Disc herniation locations</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Central:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">typicaly present with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::axial spinal pain}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;+/-&nbsp;</span>{{c1::radicular symptoms}}</div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Possible multiroot involvement if the cauda equina is affected or myelopathy if the spinal cord is involved</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_155.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Disc herniation locations</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Posterolateral:</u></span><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">eg. L4–L5 herniation can impinge the L</span>{{c1::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;nerve root</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""illustration cervical v 3s.jpg"">"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Disc herniation locations</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Lateral:</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">example, a far lateral L4–L5 herniation can impinge the L</span>{{c1::4}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;nerve root</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div>"	"<img src=""illustration cervical v 3s.jpg"">"																				
"During a s<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">traight leg raise test, sciatic nerve tension at 30–70 degrees of hip flexion,</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#333333"">Positive if pain radiates posterior thigh and below the knee<br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Dorsiflexion of ankle may produce the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Lasegue’s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;sign</span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">meant to rule out a false positive due to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::tight hamstrings}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><u>AKA Braggard Sign</u></div><div>Elevate the leg as in SLR to the point of pain provocation.&nbsp;</div><div>Drop the leg to a nonpainful range, and dorsiflex the ipsilateral ankle</div><div>Meant to differentiate neural tension from tight hamstrings<br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_159.png"">"																				
"<strong>Bowstring Test</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">after a positive&nbsp;</span>SLR<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is elicited,&nbsp;</span>{{c2::sligthly flex the knee (or decrease the angle of hip elevation)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::decrease the radicular pain}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Then&nbsp;</span>{{c1::add pressure}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::popliteal fossa}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to reproduce symptoms</span><strong><br></strong></div>"	"<div>positive in 71% of pt's with known lumbar disc disease, (i guess strengthens suspicion)</div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_160.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Internal disc disruption:</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;degradation of the internal architecture of the disc&nbsp;</span>without<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::gross herniation}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is associated with annular fissures and nuclear tissue disorganization</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The degradation of nuclear material can lead to radial fissures and erosion of the annulus</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">causing chemical and mechanical stimulation of nociceptive fibers</span></div><div><img src=""20190521020431_disc-herniation-vancouver-disc-center-of-america.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""internal-disc-disruption.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Internal disc disruption</b></span><br><div><br></div><div>Etiology: {{c1::Endplate fractures}} due to excessive loads </div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_167.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Grades of radial fissures in internal disc disruption</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Grade 0:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::No annular disruption}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_166.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Grades of radial fissures in internal disc disruption</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Grade 1:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Inner&nbsp;</span>{{c1::one-third::fraction}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;annular disruption</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_166.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Grades of radial fissures in internal disc disruption</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Grade 2:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Inner&nbsp;</span>{{c1::two-thirds::fraction}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;annular disruption</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_166.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Grades of radial fissures in internal disc disruption</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Grade 3:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Outer&nbsp;</span>{{c1::one-third}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;annular disruption ±&nbsp;</span>{{c2::circumferential spreading}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_166.png"">"																				
"<b>Lumbar Spondylosis / discogenic pain</b><div><br></div><div><u>conservative treatment</u></div><div>Stretching focused on {{c1::hamstring flexibility}}<br></div><div>Strengthening focused on {{c2::core strengthening}} exercises</div><div>Mackenzie program is an {{c3::extension-biased}} program designed to centralize extremity pain</div><div>{{c4::Lumbar bracing/corset}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">not thought to be beneficial unless there is significant spondylolisthesis</span><br></div>"	"1) Relative rest: Strict bedrest is NOT recommended.<div>2) Patient education:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">self-limited and typically
resolve within 4 to 6 weeks&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">3)&nbsp;</span><u>Medications:</u></div><div>NSAIDs, oral steroids, TCA's, SNRIs, muscle relaxants, opioids&nbsp;</div><div>4) <u>Modalities:</u></div><div>Thermal therapies (heat, cold), electric stimulation, ultrasound, TPDN</div><div>5) <u>Rehabilitation:</u></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">muscle stabilization program uses static
and dynamic postural exercises to improve&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">pelvic tilting to control degree of lumbar lordosis in pain-free ROM&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">education about proper body
mechanics during activities of daily living, and work</span></div><div><font color=""#0d1113"">core stability of&nbsp;</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">the lumbo-pelvic-hip complex to prevent buckling and to return to equilibrium after perturbation&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-03 at 10.12.49 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-03 at 10.13.05 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>Lumbar Spondylosis / discogenic pain</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div><br></div><div>xray imaging,&nbsp;MRI,&nbsp;CT, discogram</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Radial fissures}} are best demonstrated on postdiscogram&nbsp;CT</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::high-intensity zone (HIZ)}} in the annulus may be seen on T2-weighted&nbsp;MRI&nbsp;images.</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">(HIZ)&nbsp;</span><b>represents a fissure in the posterior annulus</b><br></div><div><img src=""Painful-Disc-MRI.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""my01038_im04647_mcdc7_discogram_resultsthu_jpg.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""my01038_im04646_mcdc7_discogram_injectthu_jpg.jpg""><br></div><div><a href=""https://scoliosisjournal.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13013-018-0168-9""><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs13013-018-0168-9/MediaObjects/13013_2018_168_Fig1_HTML.png""><img src=""paste-9e6ac450ddf53f589c493cdab97bdcfe6e66e442.jpg""><span style=""background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); color: rgb(241, 243, 244);"">685 × 429</span></a><br></div>"																				
"<b>Lumbar Spondylosis / discogenic pain</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>invasive treatments:</u></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::T<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ransforaminal</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;epidural steroid injection</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c2::Minimally invasive intradiscal therapies}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c3::Spinal Surgery (fusion /stabilization)}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Theoretically, medication delivery to the anterior
epidural space could decrease inflammatory processes in degenerative discs&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">However, there is only good evidence for epidural steroid
injections for radicular pain</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">There is only fair evidence for&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">epidural steroid injections</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;for&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">axial
pain&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Minimally invasive intradiscal therapies (e.g., chemo-nucleolysis, percutaneous disc decompression {discectomy/nucleoplasty})&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">have been used since the 1970s with various clinical successes&nbsp;</span></div><div>Intradiscal electrothermography (IDET) annuloplasty has not been shown to be an effective treatment</div><div>basivertebral nerve ablation&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Spinal procedures including fusion stabilization may be considered for patients with unremitting pain&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Some insurance companies declared lumbar
spine fusion not medically necessary for degenerative disc disease</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Most insurances require prior authorization and consider approval only when intensive extensive conservative measures failed</span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">posterior fusion procedures
with or without pedicle screw instrumentation,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">anterior interbody fusion&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">removal of disc or artificial disc</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span><img src=""h9991582_001.jpg""></div><div><img src=""paste-832995344e85cc4e3f167dd0cabd5c20e71925c5.jpg""><img src=""paste-e79c463734a60ebb83585c6630d10b9c373cde91.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><img src=""https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/d795f4ba-589b-4ad0-9f95-d91b01134da1/os12048-fig-0002-m.png""><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(28, 29, 30);"">(A) ALIF interbody device with integral fixation. (B) ALIF implant with anterior plate fixation. (C) ALIF implant with posterior instrumentation.</span><br></div><div><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/spine/deformities/spondylolisthesis/spondylolisthesis-type-5/posterior-fusion-of-l5-s1""><img src=""55c_p015_i220.png""></a><span style=""color: rgb(28, 29, 30);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>L1 radiculopathy</b><div><br></div><div><u>sensory</u></div><div>{{c1::groin}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-3021e99fd641a7060d10c58dce9fc3dbeff4e55b.jpg""><br></div><img src=""lumbar-2.jpg"">"																				
<b>L2 Radiculopathy&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>sensory</u></div><div>{{c1::upper antero-meial thigh}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-3021e99fd641a7060d10c58dce9fc3dbeff4e55b.jpg""><br></div><img src=""lumbar-2.jpg"">"																				
<b>L3 Radiculopathy&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>sensory</u></div><div>{{c1::anterior lower thigh}}</div>	"<div><img src=""image31.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 8.04.26 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>L4 Radiculopathy</b><div><br></div><div><u>sensory</u></div><div>{{c1::anterior thigh/knee}} and {{c1::medial leg}}</div>	"<div><img src=""image31.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 8.04.26 AM.png""></div>"																				
<b>L5 Radiculopathy</b><div><br></div><div><u>sensory</u></div><div>{{c1::antero-lateral thigh}}</div><div>{{c1::lateral calf}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::foot dorsum (1st or 2nd toe)}}</div>	"<div><img src=""image31.png""><img src=""https://o.quizlet.com/awD04F.wM2FFvbUFT9r-Vw.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 8.04.26 AM.png""></div>"																				
<b>S1 Radiculopathy</b><div><br></div><div><u>sensory</u></div><div>{{c1::posterior thigh}}</div><div>{{c1::posterior calf}}</div><div>{{c1::lateral}} or {{c1::plantar foot}}</div>	"<div><img src=""image31.png""><img src=""https://o.quizlet.com/awD04F.wM2FFvbUFT9r-Vw.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 8.04.26 AM.png""></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">patients&nbsp;</span>{{c1::can::can / can not}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;have radiculopathy without visible disc herniations or
nerve root compression&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>2 possibile causes of radicular pain</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">1) mechanical compression</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">2) inflammation&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><br></div>chemical radiculitis from annular tears<div>diabetes etc.</div><div>bobby power point&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">lumbar radiculopathy is often caused
by a herniated disc, this is not invariably the case.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Many pathologic processes, such as bone encroachment,
tumors, and metabolic disorders (e.g., diabetes)&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::20}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">% of asymptomatic pt's in the 20 to 39 year olds will have</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;disc herniation on MRI</span></div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">There is a high incidence of abnormal findings in asymptomatic people,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">37.5% in the 60- to 80-year age group</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">In fact, in one study, only 36% of asymptomatic individuals
had normal discs at all levels&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>Indications for NCS/EMG in Racidulopathy</b><div>{{c1::MRI equivocal}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">persistent unexplained symptoms with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::true weakness}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::r/o mimickers}}</div><div>{{c3::Physical Examination is unreliable}}</div>"	"if there is uncertainty about the Dx: entrapment mono neuropathy, peripheral neuropathy, or plexopathy<br><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">EMG can help to distinguish pain-related reduced muscular effort from true neurogenic weakness (ie. faking it)</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>as well as...</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">localize the specific spinal nerve root that is damaged and correlate with imaging</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">distinguish between old and new axon loss&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">EMG provides objective evidence of denervation when there is no motor deficit on PE</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><div>- this is particularly useful in patients with past surgery and residual pain.</div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">advantage over imaging techniques is high specificity, ie rarely will NCS/EMG be abnormal in asymptomatic individuals&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- herniated discs are usualy asymptomatic so A HNP on imaging may not be the true cause</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 8.45.33 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<b>Radiculopathy&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>indication for urgent imaging</u></div><div>{{c1::c/f high risk etiology}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::severe intractable pain}}</div><div>{{c3::significant weakness}}&nbsp;</div>	"otherwise can be diagnosed clinically and managed conservatively<div>can get delayed imaging if there is no improvment and the pt wishes for ESI or surgery&nbsp;</div><div><u>close follow up to ensure weakness in non-progressive</u></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 8.45.33 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 1.31.10 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 1.26.50 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-09 at 1.28.25 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Vertebral Traction</b>:<div><br></div><div>Cervical region: 20 degrees to 30 degrees of flexion with {{c1::25}} lb. of resistance</div><div>Lumbar region: May require increased force or a split table to overcome friction</div><div><br></div><div><u>Indications:</u></div><div>Radicular pain (most widely accepted)</div><div>{{c2::Paraspinal muscle spasm}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Contraindications:</u></div><div>{{c3::Ligamentous instability}}</div><div>{{c4::Radiculopathy of uncertain etiology}}</div><div>{{c5::Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)}}<br></div>	"also contraindicated in Acute injury, Vertebrobasilar arteriosclerotic disease, Spinal infections (Pott’s disease)<br><div><img src=""paste-c1c358117576b1ff6363d5cab34693de505e1b14.jpg""><img src=""paste-25a5d5510f876901f74eb9c307386087eb8c1d4e.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Nonoperative treatment allows resolution of radiculopathy in up to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::90}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">% of cases&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">optimum treatment of compressive cervical radiculopathy is the subject of continued debate, and initial management may vary significantly among practitioners. There is sparse evidence that any treatment improves upon the natural history of the condition</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">clinical symptoms are self-limited in most cases.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Thus, immediate diagnostic testing is not necessary for patients with suspected radiculopathy&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">who are neurologically intact and at low risk for neoplastic, infectious, or inflammatory etiologies</span></div></div></div></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<b>Radiculopathy</b><div><br></div><div><u>treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Epidural steroid injections (</span>ESIs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Chymopapain injections}}<br></div><div><div>{{c3::Surgical intervention}}</div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">steroid injections are beneficial in <u>acute radiculopathy</u> in patients with or without disc herniation</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">study results in <u>chronic radiculopathy</u> are less convincing&nbsp;</span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">scientific literature shows that the effects of ESI are <u>relatively short-lived</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">the intervention is beneficial because it <u>limits opiate use and&nbsp;</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>referral for surgery</u></span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>Surgery is appropriate under 2 conditions</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">1) emergency basis with a central disc herniation with bowel / bladder
dysfunction or bilateral lower extremity
weakness</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">2) patient continues to have
pain that limits function after an adequate trial of nonoperative treatment</span></div>
<div><br></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A Cochrane review on surgery versus conservative care concluded that&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">in selected
patients, surgery can provide faster relief</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">but there is no convincing evidence of a difference in long-term out-comes</span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">for cases of disc herniation, simple facetectomy, laminectomy
and discectomy suffice</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Fusion should be avoided in these instances</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">unless there is spinal instability with radiculopathy or if the surgical
procedure will result in spinal instability</span></div><div><img src=""11550tn.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/295840513/figure/fig1/AS:571653999599616@1513304342778/Artists-representation-of-en-bloc-facetectomy-A-transverse-cut-1-across-the-pars-is.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<div><b>Chymopapain injections</b>:</div><div><br></div><div>Mechanism: {{c1::Dissolves}} {{c2::subligamentous disc herniations}} contained by the&nbsp;PLL</div><div><br></div><div>Complication/side effects: Anaphylactic reaction, chronic pain, poor efficacy</div>	"<div>again, no evidence that minimally invasive intradiscal therapies out preform&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">standard microdiscectomy&nbsp;</span></div><img src=""full-jns_1975_42_4_0384.fig003.jpg"">"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><font color=""#0d1113""><b>Imaging in Radiculopathy</b>&nbsp;</font></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">it is “normal”
to have some disc abnormality even at times with neural compression on imaging</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">to be meaningful,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::MRI must clearly
correlate with the clinical findings}}</div>
</div>
</div>"																					
"<b>Facet Arthropathy</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>usually pain is located {{c1::para-midline (more often than axial (disc))}}</div><div>Neck or back pain exacerbated with {{c2::rotation}} and {{c2::extension}}</div><div>In the Lumbar spine the pain may {{c3::refer into the buttock}}</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">pt may experience difficulty with prolonged&nbsp;</span>{{c4::walking}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div>No neurologic abnormalities</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">In the lumbar spine, these joints may refer pain
into the buttock or posterior thigh but rarely below the
knee&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">prolonged erect posture ex stair climbing, twist-ing, standing, and prone lying</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">facet problems are common with underlying disc disease so may have those sx's as well</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""FRmXS-IX0AEv0Oc.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>Lumbar Spondylosis / discogenic</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>clinical features</u></div><div>constant, deep, aching {{c1::axial::location}} discomfort</div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">pain exacerbated with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::lumbar flexion}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">, mechanical stresses, and&nbsp;</span>{{c3::Valsalva maneuver}}</div><div>absent neurologic involvement<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;<br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Symptoms are typically exacerbated during bending,
twisting, stooping, and forward flexion in patients with primary discogenic pain</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">valsalva: lifting,&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">coughing, sneezing&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Paramidline is more common in facet and SI joint pain</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<div>
<div>
