<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>Radiculopathy&nbsp;</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b><br></b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>clinical features</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">pain exacerbated by prolonged&nbsp;</span>{{c1::standing}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"as well as&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">sitting, coughing, and sneezing&nbsp;</span><div><font color=""#0d1113""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#0d1113"">-&nbsp;</font>Extension-biased programs may be used for postero-lateral&nbsp;HNP</div><div>- Neutral or flexion-biased program may be used for far-lateral&nbsp;HNP</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Various methods, which include flexion and ex-
tension exercises (often called a lumbosacral stabilization
program), have been tried&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">gold standard in diagnosing facet pain is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::double diagnostic medial branch blocks}}"	No imaging study is specific for facet-mediated pain<div>Degenerative changes may be noted but are not diagnostic&nbsp;</div><div>as they do not typically corelate well with pain</div><div>MRI&nbsp;may show hypertrophy of the capsule and facets.</div>																				
"<b>facet arthropathy</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::facet joint injections}}<br></div><div>{{c2::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">dorsal rami medial branch radiofrequency </span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ablation</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>RFA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;only if diagnostic blocks are positive</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Surgery is rare in primary and isolated facet arthropathies&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""images-6137223d74262a618707df46f1c4df17e9e12285.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-10 at 9.14.03 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"SI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;joint has a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::synovial}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;joint anteriorly and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::syndesmosis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;joint posteriorly</span>"	"<img src=""transverse view SI joint.jpg""><div><img src=""VA-508-SiJointCapsuleAnatomy.png""><br><div><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">Syndesmosis: Some of the long bones in the body such as the radius and ulna in the forearm are joined by a syndesmosis (along the interosseous membrane). Syndemoses are slightly moveable (amphiarthrodial).&nbsp;</span><b>The distal tibiofibular joint</b><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">&nbsp;is another example</span><br></div></div>"																				
"SI&nbsp;joint is innervated by the<div>{{c3::lateral branches::same}}&nbsp;of the&nbsp;{{c1::L4 - L5::#roots}} {{c2::dorsal ramus}}<div>and {{c3::lateral branches::same}} of the {{c1::S1–S3 (S4)::#roots}} {{c2::dorsal rami}}<br></div></div>"	"<img src=""9-2.jpg""><div><img src=""urncambridge.orgidbinary9907020160511091658487-083488941fig1_9.jpeg""><br></div>"																				
<b>SIJ dysfunction</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Location: aka {{c3::Fortin Finger}} Test&nbsp;</div><div>Acute or gradual lumbar and buttock pain</div><div>may refer to the {{c1::thigh}}, {{c1::leg}}, or {{c1::groin}}&nbsp;</div><div>increased discomfort with {{c2::positional changes}}</div>	"<div>Less common than disc or facet issues&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>Clinical exam has significant false-positive rates and variable sensitivity rates<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">The most common symptoms are..&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">buttock pain (94%)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">lower lumbar pain (72%)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">lower extremity pain (50%)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Pain in the distal leg and pain in the foot were also reported,
as was low abdominal pain and groin pain&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Dr. Dove: more common in woman, tall athletes, pregnancy&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<b>Fortin test&nbsp;</b><br><br>The subject is asked to point to the region of pain with one finger<div><br></div><div>Positive: pointed immediately {{c1::infero}}-{{c1::medial}} to the {{c2::PSIS}} within 1 cm&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>patient consistently pointed to the same area over at least two trials</div>	"<div><br></div><img src=""800px-PSIS_03_posterior_view.png""><div><img src=""SI_joint_intro01.jpg""><br></div>"																				
If {{c1::3}} or more <u>SIJ provocation tests</u> are present in the setting of {{c2::transitional}} pain<div><br></div><div>the patient will be considered for trial of sacroiliac belt or diagnostic sacroiliac injection</div>	"sitting to standing or supine to sitting&nbsp;<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-07-28 at 8.14.20 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<u>SIJ dysfunction tests of motion</u><div>{{c1::Gillet’s test}}&nbsp;<u><br></u><div>{{c2::standing /seated flexion test}}&nbsp;</div></div>	"aka&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-weight: 600; background-color: rgb(202, 230, 236);"">NONPROVOCATIVE&nbsp;</span>SI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-weight: 600; background-color: rgb(202, 230, 236);"">&nbsp;JOINT TESTS</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Monitor&nbsp;</span>PSIS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;motion when the patient raises the leg to 90 degrees.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The&nbsp;</span>PSIS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on raised leg should rotate down. Restriction of this motion is considered abnorma</span><font color=""#333333""><b><br></b></font><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_186.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-weight: 600; background-color: rgb(202, 230, 236);""><br></span></div><div><div>Monitor the&nbsp;PSIS&nbsp;of the seated patient as he or she bends forward.&nbsp;</div><div>Asymmetric cephalad motion of the&nbsp;PSIS&nbsp;indicates a sacroiliac dysfunction.&nbsp;</div><div>Use the standing flexion test to distinguish the side of the dysfunction.</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_187.png""><br></div></div><div><br></div></div>"																				
In general, physical exam tests for SIJ dysfunction are divided into tests of {{c1::motion}} or provocation	aka non provocative&nbsp;																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Provocative SIJ test</u>&nbsp;</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Patrick’s (</span>FABERE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) test</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Thigh Thrust test&nbsp;</span><font color=""#333333""><br></font><div>{{c1::Distraction}}<br><div><div>{{c2::Gaenslen’s test}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></div></div></div><div>{{c3::Compression}}<br></div><div>{{c4::Yeoman’s test}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_182.png""><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_183.png""><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_184.png""><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_185.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>SI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;joint pain</span></b><br><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging/Diagnostics</u></div><div>X-ray, bone scan,&nbsp;CT,&nbsp;MRI</div><div>these studies may reveal {{c1::alternative pathologies}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Diagnostic&nbsp;SI&nbsp;joint intra-articular injection (block)}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">considered by some the “gold standard” for diagnosis&nbsp;</span></div>"	"With the exception of sacroiliitis, <font color=""#fc1307"">imaging is unreliable</font> in diagnosing&nbsp;SI&nbsp;joint dysfunction<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">MRI can reveal soft
tissue disease and marrow changes in <u>sacroiliitis</u> with erosions&nbsp;</span></div><div>Osteoarthritis</div><div>Spondyloarthropathies</div><div>Pregnancy</div><div>Trauma</div><div>Pyogenic sacroiliitis<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">However, numerous investigators have shown
anesthetic leakage from the joint space after injection</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">American Pain Society
guidelines suggest that there is only fair to poor evidence for
sacroiliac joint blocks to diagnose SIJD</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Recent evidence suggests that extracapsular structures, the
dense ligamentous network comprising the sacroiliac joint
complex</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">may be a principal cause of persistent pain</span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_199.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<b>SI joint Dysfunction</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Conservative</span>: Relative rest, medications, topicals, correct imbalances, rehabilitation programs&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Manipulation (chiro / osteopathic)}}</div><div>{{c1::SI&nbsp;joint belt}}<br></div><div>{{c2::SI&nbsp;joint&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">intra-articular steroid injection</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c2::Radiofrequency neurotomy}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c3::fusion of
the sacroiliac joint}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"IA steroid injection:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">two thirds of patients with sacroiliac joint dysfunction may attain significant pain relief&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">evidence for injections is poor&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">multisite, multidepth lateral
branch blocks are physiologically effective at a rate of 70%</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">making this a valuable technique&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Surgery is very rarely performed for sacroiliac joint dysfunction&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""paste-d2940780a29219488e6e1093cc8aea9547567b5d.jpg""><img src=""images-ef613c31438031d7691cc7317f9ed150a0fa52f9.jpg""><img src=""images-0813863086baa381b4bca21c2d43b4021686816f.jpg""><img src=""paste-af8da9b689f28835155fa0afd7fe588c4923021d.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_199.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">If a plain radiograph or MRI confirms the presence of a femoral neck stress fracture</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">then,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::consult ortho::next step}}</div>"	"<strong>Indications for orthopedic referral</strong><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>tension-side</u> (ie, superolateral cortex) femoral neck stress fracture, referred to an orthopaedic surgeon </span><font color=""#fc0507"">within 24 hours.&nbsp;</font></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">If the fracture is<u> displaced</u>,</span><font color=""#fc0507""> immediate</font><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""> referral is needed.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">If there is a <u>compression-side </u>(ie, inferomedial cortex) femoral neck stress fracture, the patient should be evaluated </span><font color=""#fc0507"">within 72 hours.&nbsp;</font></div>"																				
"SCI/TBI HO usualy occurs at&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold; color: blue;"">2 months</span>&nbsp;post injury&nbsp;<br><div style=""""><br></div><div style=""""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">When occurs after 1 year, is usually associated with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">some oter pathology (acute fracture,&nbsp;</span>DVT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, or pressure injury)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div style=""""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div style=""""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Usually has a more&nbsp;</span>{{c1::benign}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;course</span></div>"	"<i><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The 1 to 3 months status post-injury is most common; peak at 2 months</span></i>"																				
"{{c1::spondylolysis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">is a fracture of the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::pars interarticularis}}"	"<div>it can lead to spondylolisthesis</div><img src=""lumbar_spondylolysis_cause02.jpg""><div><img src=""spondylolisthesis.jpg""></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">spondylosis is a fracture of the pars interarticularis</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">which is located at the junction of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pedicle}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lamina}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">superior articular process (</span>SAP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_170.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>spondylolysis</b></span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font></div><div><u>Etiology</u><font color=""#333333""><br></font><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">defect most commonly seen in&nbsp;</span>{{c2::children/adolescents::epidimiology}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;at the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::L5}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;vertebral level</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">result of repetitive&nbsp;</span>{{c3::hyper-extension}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c3::rotational}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;forces&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(e.g., sports such as gymnastics, football, wrestling, swimming) in young athletes</span><br></div><div><br></div>if <u>bilateral</u> it may progress to&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">spondylolisthesis (unilateral will not, as neural arch is intact)</span><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">progression is common but prognostic factors are lacking, making it
difficult to predict which patients are at risk&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<div><b>Spondylolisthesis</b></div><div><br></div><u>Clinical Features</u><div>Low back pain exacerbated with motion and {{c1::hamstring}} tightness</div><div>{{c2::Radicular}} symptoms may occur with marked slippage&nbsp;</div>	"resulting in central or foraminal stenosis<div><img src=""nerve-root_im-0023005-01.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Spondylolisthesis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">If spinal nerve root impingement occurs, it will most likely effect the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::L5::#}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;nerve</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">typically&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">will effect the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::exiting::<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">exiting/traversing</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;nerve</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Because spondylolisthesis </span><font color=""#fc0507"">most commonly involves the L5-S1 level</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""> (<b>vast majority</b>), the L5 nerve is most often affected by this problem&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""#0b6aff"">Unlike disc bulge which hits the traversing nerve</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">, a spondy will effect the exiting nerve&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""nerve-root_im-0023005-01.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Spondylolysis</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>{{c1::Localized}} back pain exacerbated by {{c2::hyper-extension}} and relieved with {{c2::flexion}}</div><div>unlike in&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">spondylolisthesis, the&nbsp;</span>{{c3::Neurologic exam}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;will be normal</span></div>"	"<u>ie. standing, lying prone</u><div><br></div><div>in reality, it is <b>not possible to distinguish</b> between this syndrome and other cuases of back pain</div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>One exception</b> is a child who presents with acute back pain, in whom reactive changes
to the bone marrow are found&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""#fc0507"">Ultimately, in patients with established spondylolysis/spondylolisthesis, it is difficult to attribute pain to these abnormalities</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">-Less than 5% of children diagnosed with
spondylolysis or spondylolisthesis have back pain&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">-the incidence of back pain in those with
spondylolysis or spondylolisthesis is similar to the
general population</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">-those with and without back pain have nearly an identical incidence of spondylolysis</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">-Furthermore, the degree
of spondylolytic spondylolisthesis is not associated with the
prevalence of back pain</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">-no study has linked progression of spondylolisthesis with pain symptoms</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">-Disability
because of back pain is no more prevalent in the population
with spondylolysis and spondylolisthesis than in the general public&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
{{c1::spondylolisthesis}}<br><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>Slippage of a vertebral body with respect to the vertebral body below it&nbsp;</div><div>Occurrence is two to four times greater in {{c2::males::gender}}</div>	"It may be an anterior translation (anterolisthesis) or posterior translation (retrolisthesis)&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">or laterally, called laterolisthesis<br></span><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_172.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
"<b>Etiologies of Spondylolisthesis</b><div><br></div><div><div><div><div>
<div>{{c1::Dysplastic}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;spondylolisthesis: results from a&nbsp;</span>{{c2::congenital abnormality}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;of one or more facet joints</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 12.58.26 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Wirbelgleiten-Klassifikation-Witse-en.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Etiologies of Spondylolisthesis</b><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Type&nbsp;</span>{{c2::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Isthmic}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::spondylolytic}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;spondylolisthesis: results from&nbsp;</span>{{c3::bilateral pars defects (bilateral spondylolysis)}}</div></div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 12.58.26 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Wirbelgleiten-Klassifikation-Witse-en.jpg""></div>"																				
"<b>Etiologies of Spondylolisthesis</b><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Type&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Degenerative}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;spondylolisthesis:&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">results from arthrosis/subluxation of the&nbsp;</span>{{c3::facet joints}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c3::intervertebral discs}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">most common at&nbsp;</span>{{c4::L4}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">-</span>{{c4::L5}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;and with advancing age</span></div></div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 12.58.26 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Wirbelgleiten-Klassifikation-Witse-en.jpg""></div>"																				
"<b>Etiologies of Spondylolisthesis</b><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Type&nbsp;</span>{{c1::4}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Traumatic}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;spondylolisthesis&nbsp;</span></div></div>"	"<div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">results from fractures of posterior elements <u>other than the pars</u>, such as facet joints, laminae, or pedicles</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 12.58.26 PM.png""><div><img src=""Wirbelgleiten-Klassifikation-Witse-en.jpg""></div>"																				
"<b>Etiologies of Spondylolisthesis</b><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Type&nbsp;</span>{{c2::5}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Pathologic}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;spondylolisthesis&nbsp;</span></div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">results from pathologic changes in posterior elements due to malignant neo- plasm, infection, or primary bone disease</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 12.58.26 PM.png""><div><img src=""Wirbelgleiten-Klassifikation-Witse-en.jpg""></div></div>"																				
"<b>Etiologies of Spondylolisthesis</b><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Type 6:</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Post-surgical}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;spondylolisthesis&nbsp;</span></div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 12.58.26 PM.png"">"																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Isthmic spondylolisthesis is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::male::gender}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;predominant,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">whereas
degenerative spondylolisthesis is more common in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::females::gender}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Meyerding grading of slippage</b> (spondylolisthesis)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Grade 1:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::1%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">–</span>{{c1::25%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;slippage</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_173.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Meyerding grading of slippage</b>&nbsp;(spondylolisthesis)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Grade 2:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::26%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">–</span>{{c1::50%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;slippage</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_173.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Meyerding grading of slippage</b>&nbsp;(spondylolisthesis)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Grade 3:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::51%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">–</span>{{c1::75%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;slippage</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_173.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Meyerding grading of slippage</b>&nbsp;(spondylolisthesis)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Grade 4:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::76%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">–</span>{{c1::100%}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;slippage</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_173.png"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Meyerding grading of slippage</b> (spondylolisthesis)</span><br></div><div><br></div>{{c1::Spondyloptosis::name}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&gt;100% slippage aka grade 5</span>"	"<img src=""48a9f104b155c5122baef8a5d7169a_gallery.jpeg"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>spondylolisthesis</b>&nbsp;+/-&nbsp;</span><b style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">spondylolysis</b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>physical examination</u></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">forward flexion may reveal&nbsp;</span>{{c1::palpable step-off}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div><div>{{c2::stork}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;test (provocative maneveur)&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Detection of spondylolisthesis on <b>physical examination is
difficult</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">in the rare cases of grade III or greater slips, “step-off” of the spinous processes can be seen or
palpated</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">In grade I and
II spondylolisthesis, the step-off has <u>never been shown to be a reliable</u> finding</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>Neurologic deficits and +SLR are rarely found</u> in cases of spondylolytic spondylolisthesis</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 1.30.20 PM.png""></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<div><b>Spondylolysis (pediatrics)</b></div><div><br></div><u>Imaging</u><div>X-rays: {{c1::Oblique}} views may demonstrate a pars defect represented by the calssic {{c2::collar}} on the {{c2::Scotty dog}}</div><div>If x-rays are negative, {{c3::bone scan}} can be considered</div><div>If both of the above are negative, a {{c4::single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)}} scan can be performed</div><div>{{c5::High-resolution&nbsp;MRI}} is the actual test of choice in clinical setting (not board answers)</div>	"<b>Bone scans</b>&nbsp;<div>- may be positive at 5 to 7 days and last up to 18 months</div><div>- Can help to differentiate between acute and chronic fractures (chronic will not show uptake)</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>SPECT</b>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- improves the localizing ability of
bone scintigraphy</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- creates a series of
slices through the target structure, permitting spatial
separation of overlapping bone&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""Spondylolysis__Oblique__View.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 2.08.46 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A, </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">focal lesion at the right side of lumbar spine - SPECT/
CT confirmed bilateral spondylolysis with increased activity.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">B, </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Fused SPECT/CT shows a spondylolysis with focal increased activity in the right
L3 pars.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">C, </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Fused SPECT/CT shows a spondylolysis with focal increased activity in the left L4 pars.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">D, </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Three-dimensional CT image shows deficiency of posterior spinous processes that led to
development of the bilateral spondylolysis.&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 2.13.15 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<div><b>Spondylolysis (pediatric)&nbsp;</b></div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Relative rest (ie. avoidance of high impact exercises/activities until pain free or for 90 days)</div><div>PT and gradual return to play</div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c2::Rigid antilordotic bracing (for 3 to 6 months often for 23 hours a day)}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;""not advocated for by most""</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div>neurosurgery or ortho referreal in {{c1::&gt; grade 1 spondylolisthesis::grade}} or any sign of {{c1::neurological injury}}</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">nonoperative treatment of spondylolysis, children and young
adults return to a pain-free in unrestricted activities 84% of the time</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">sx control HEP</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">, icing, warm baths or showers, OTC analgesics</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">, and topical capsacin&nbsp;</span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">adults with spondylolysis, with or without spondylolisthesis, are treated the same as other nonspecific back pain&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""paste-5a6b716ede01698cb829770a70aec64d45871101.jpg""><br><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 2.13.15 PM.png"">"																				
<b>Spondylolisthesis</b><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>X-rays, {{c1::Flexion and extension}} views may demonstrate signs of segmental instability</div><div>some advocate {{c2::CT}}&nbsp;as the test of choice&nbsp;</div><div>however, {{c2::MRI}} likely remains the gold standard</div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Because of its ability to clearly visualize bone, <b>CT is considered superior to MRI</b> by some&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">for
identifying spondylolysis (<u>and other small fx's</u>)&nbsp;</span></div><div><font color=""#fc0507"">MRI sensitivity likely in the mid 90's and can actually show the neuro-foramina&nbsp;</font></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""#0d1113"">MRI with fat saturation technique can identify subtle bone
marrow </font><b style=""""><font color=""#0b6aff"">edema (acuity)</font></b><font color=""#0d1113""> of early stress injury to the pars interarticularis&nbsp;</font></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Axial T2 MRI
demonstrating increased fluid in the facet joints is also sensitive for early detection of spondylolisthesis&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 2.44.13 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Spondylolysis defects of L5 as seen on parasagittal (</span><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">) and axial (</span><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">B</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">) CT scans. </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(arrows)</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- Note the lack
of complete vertebral ring on axial view&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 2.45.18 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">MRI of spondylolytic spondylolisthesis.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Discontinuity of the vertebral ring is demonstrated </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(arrows) </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">on the axial T2 image </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(left)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">discontinuity of the pars is seen </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(arrow) </span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">on the parasagittal T1 image </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(right)</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- Compare the elongated, horizontally oriented neuroforamina at L5-S1&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 2.46.22 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">MRI of degenerative spondylolisthesis at L4-L5 </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(left)</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Increased T2 signal is demonstrated in axial view of the L4-L5 facet
joints </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(right)</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">.&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>Spondylolisthesis</b><div><br></div><div><div><u>Radiographic&nbsp;{{c3::instability}}</u>:</div><div>Translation &gt;{{c1::3.5}} mm (cervical) and &gt;{{c1::5}} mm (thoracic or lumbar)</div><div>Rotational motion of two adjacent vertebrae &gt;{{c2::11}} degrees in the C-spine and {{c2::15}} degrees in the lumbar spine</div></div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_174.png""><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_175.png"">"																				
"<b>Spodylolisthesis Treatment</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Conservative</u></span>:</div><div>Indicated in {{c1::Grade 1}}, {{c1::Grade 2}}, and {{c1::asymptomatic Grade 3}}</div><div>Relative rest, eliminate aggravating activities</div><div>Rehabilitation program: Focus on spinal stabilization exercises in a flexion-biased position and hamstring flexibility</div><div>{{c2::Thoracolumbosacral orthosis (TLSO) bracing}} is used if increased pain occurs despite decreased activity&nbsp;</div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c3::spinal injections}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"Grade 2 and 3 are <font color=""#fc0507"">restricted from contact sports</font><div><br></div><div><b>Invasive procedures</b></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- For radicular pain, epidural injections may be used if the site of nerve
root compression lies within the spinal canal</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- selective nerve root blocks may be used if compression lies
within the transforaminal space</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- For axial pain, facet injections may be used if the facet joints themselves are thought
to be the source of pain.&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-09 at 2.55.30 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Fluoroscopic injection of pars interarticularis defect,
with contrast material filling the pseudojoint capsule&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>"																				
"<b>Spodylolisthesis Treatment</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><u>Surgical Indication</u>:</div><div>Indicated in {{c1::symptomatic Grade 3}}, {{c1::Grade 4}} and {{c1::Grade 5}}</div><div>as well as {{c2::unstable spondylolistheses}} and {{c2::progressive neurologic deficit}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div></div>"	"<div>Spinal procedure intervention typically includes bilateral posterolateral fusion with or without decompression<br></div><div><br></div><div>reoperation is common, so must have severe sx's, failed conservative mgmt, and correlate with imaging</div><div><br></div><div>despite this,&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Surgical outcomes are generally favorable&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
<div><strong>Sports hernia: (pathophysiology)</strong></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::a strain or tear}} of {{c1::any soft tissue}} in the lower abdomen or groin area</div>	"<div>strain or tear of any soft tissue (muscle, tendon, ligament) in the lower abdomen or groin area<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-11 at 7.48.12 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::Apophyseal}}<span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">&nbsp;injuries</span></b><br><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">injuries in a&nbsp;</span>{{c2::growing}}<span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c2::adolescent}}<span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">&nbsp;(epidemiology) athletes, that cause inflammation at the site of a major&nbsp;</span>{{c3::tendinous insertion}}<br></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">Conservative therapy is usually effective</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(42, 42, 42);"">severity can range from pain (apophysistis) to avulsion fracture&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><img src=""Apophysitis-and-osteochondrosis.png""><span style=""color: rgb(42, 42, 42);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""11B-Run5VpvzZ1lyhwGk_HQ.png""><span style=""color: rgb(42, 42, 42);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""bone_anatomy_knee.jpg""><br></div><br>"																				
the Q-angle is formed from<div><br></div><div>line of the femur: {{c1::ASIS}} to the {{c1::mid patella::same}}</div><div>line of the tibia: {{c1::mid patella::same}} to the {{c1::tibial tubercle}}</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_94.png"">"																				
<b>Athletic Pubalgia aka Sports Hernia</b><div><br></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>{{c1::resisted rectus abdominus flexion}}</div><div>{{c2::resisted hip aDduction}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-17 at 10.24.56 AM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-17 at 10.24.46 AM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>spinal stenosis</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>degenerative changes result in disc space narrowing followed by:</u>&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::vertebral body osteophytosis}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::facet joint arthropathy}}<br></div><div>{{c1::ligamentum flavum hypertrophy}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""lumbar-spinal-stenosis.jpeg"">"																				
<div><b>Central spinal stenosis</b></div><div><br></div><div>Decreased size of the central spinal canal typically secondary to spondylotic changes</div><div><br></div><div>rarely in some patients it can be cuased by {{c1::epidural lipomatosis}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>in addition too: osteophytosis, facet and ligamentum flavum hypertrophy</div>	"can also occur due to other conditions including <u>disc herniation</u> or <u>degenerative spondylolistheses</u><div><u><br></u></div><div><em><b>Epidural lipomatosis</b>:</em><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">&nbsp;is a rare disorder in which an abnormal amount of fat is deposited on or outside the lining of the spine</span><u><br></u></div><div><img src=""1-s2.0-S2210261220311573-gr1.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>spinal stenosis</b></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Neurologic sequelae may begin when the central canal is &lt;</span>{{c1::12}}mm<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(relative stenosis) to &lt;</span>{{c1::10}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">mm (absolute stenosis)</span>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b><font color=""#0b6aff"">10-13</font> is considered relative&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><div>A significant portion of the general population may have anatomic
spinal stenosis without symptoms</div><div><br></div><div>Studies indicate 25% of asymptomatic people older than
40 have significant narrowing of the lumbar spinal
canal</div><div><br></div><div>Stenosis causes symptoms only when there is
sufficient impingement on neural structures</div><div><br></div><div>Therefore, spinal stenosis is considered significant
only if it results in symptomatic pain and compromised
function</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>{{c4::Lateral recess::same}}&nbsp;stenosis:</b><div><br></div><div><u>subdivided into three areas of entrapment:</u></div><div>{{c4::Lateral recess::same}} (Entrance zone): {{c1::descending nerve root::entrapment}}</div><div>{{c5::Pars Region}} (Mid zone): {{c2::DRG::entrapment}}</div><div>{{c6::Intervertebral foramen}} (Exit zone): {{c3::spinal nerve::entrapment}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-21 at 9.34.54 PM.png""><div><img src=""1393-1.jpg""><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-981-16-9547-6_11/MediaObjects/480772_1_En_11_Fig3_HTML.png""><br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-21 at 9.35.44 PM.png""><br></div></div>"																				
<b>Central Spinal Stenosis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>pain in the {{c1::buttock}}, {{c1::thigh}}, or {{c1::leg}}</div><div>symptoms typically exacerbate with {{c2::standing}} and {{c2::walking}}</div><div>symptoms improved with {{c3::sitting}} and {{c3::bending forward (lying, walking uphill/shopping)}}</div>	"neurogenic claudication symptoms are position dependent<div>- exacerbated with lumbar extension</div><div>- improved with lumbar flexion&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div>1.) common to appear 50's - 60's&nbsp;</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>2.) Leg pain is often greater
than back pain (back pain predates leg pain)</div><div>3.) leg pain can be <u>unilateral or bilateral</u> and
<u>monoradicular or polyradicular</u>&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<b>Spinal Stenosis</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Conservative: Rehabilitation program focused on a {{c1::flexion-biased}} spinal stabilization program</div><div>aquatic therapy</div><div>{{c2::ESIs}}</div><div>{{c3::Surgical decompression}}&nbsp;</div>	"ESI's are typically TFESI (most effective)<div>interlaminar may be tried if initial injections is not effective or if ligamentum flavum is felt to be etiology&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>No strict indications for surgery</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">surgical therapy for patients who do not have an adequate clinical response to conservative therapy</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">who are functionally disabled by their symptoms, or have a progressive neurologic deficit</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">decompression alone preffered over fusion&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">surgery seems to be better than non-op</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">although, benefits will wane over time and the groups become similar&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Scoliosis can be considered either&nbsp;</span>{{c1::functional}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c1::structural}}"	"<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">Structural scoliosis is when the patient's spine actually has a physical curve.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">Functional scoliosis is when the spine appears to be curved,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">but the apparent curvature is actually the result of an irregularity elsewhere in the body (e.g. different leg lengths).</span></div><div><img src=""scoliosis+1.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div>"																				
{{c1::Functional}} Scoliosis: spinal rotiation occurs due to malpositioning or unilateral paraspinal muscle pull	"This may be associated with back pain and muscle spasm.<div><br></div><div>In this type of curve, there is no significant vertebral body rotation, and scoliosis is reversible</div><div><img src=""scoliosis+1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Physical Evaluation of Scoliosis</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::ADAMS TEST (FORWARD BENDING TEST)::eponym}}</div>	"The child bends forward with legs straight at the knees and hands together as if trying to touch the toes.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>The spine should be viewed from occiput down and sacrum up</div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/236599695/figure/fig1/AS:392803407417348@1470663038624/The-Adams-forward-bend-test-performed-by-left-a-patient-without-scoliosis-and-right.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>The Cobb angle</b>&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">One line is drawn along the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::superior endplate}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the vertebra,&nbsp;</span>that is {{c1::tilted the most at the top}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and along the {{c1::inferior endplate}} of the vertebra, that is&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::tilted the most at the bottom}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig10_12.png"">"																				
<b>Scoliosis</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>most common clinical presentation is typically {{c1::asymptomatic}}</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Correlation with discomfort is unclear</u>, but low back pain is usually the initial symptom.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is related to curve severity and usually begins at the&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;at the convexity</span><br><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Symptomatic patients may present with back pain, postural imbalance, symptoms of spinal stenosis (neurogenic claudication, radiculopathy)</span><br></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Curves under 30 degrees have less than a 5 percent risk of progression</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Outcome for patients with AIS (adolescent idiopathic) is generally favorable, whether they are treated with observation, bracing, or surgery</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">They have a slightly increased risk of back pain and degenerative disc changes compared with patients without AIS</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">the curve puts more pressure on the fascets and narrows the neuro foramina (may get&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">ESI's and fusions)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">they may be serially monitored with xray&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-22 at 8.51.28 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Scoliosis</b><br><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u>&nbsp;</div><div>x-rays on a {{c1::36}}-inch {{c1::digital cassette}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;that can&nbsp;</span>{{c2::portray the entire spine}}</div>"	"the need for follow-up scoliosis survey films will depend on skeletal maturity, patient age, and degree of curvature<div><br></div><div><b>Uptodate</b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>Adults</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">offer lifetime annual/biennial radiographs and clinical follow-up to allow for assessment of any progression of deformity or changes in quality of life</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>Adolescents</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Follow-up with the orthopedic surgeon typically is scheduled for one to two years after the onset of skeletal maturity, regardless of treatment</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">The frequency and duration of subsequent orthopedic follow-up depends upon the magnitude of the curve at skeletal maturity and patient preference</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Cobbanglemeasurement.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">diagnosis of scoliosis is confirmed by a Cobb angle of &gt;</span>{{c1::10}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;degrees of lateral curvature</span>"	"<img src=""Cobbanglemeasurement.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Measurement of vertebral rotation in scoliosis uses the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pedicle method}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Vertebral body is divided into six segments and grades from&nbsp;</span>{{c2::0}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::4+}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are assigned</span></div>"	"<img src=""1-s2.0-S0169260705001999-gr1.jpg""><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_176.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Scoliosis</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><u>Treatment</u><div>Observation: {{c1::&lt;20}} degrees</div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-22 at 8.35.09 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>Lightweight pull-string corset-like lumbar brace</div><div>orthotist can help by providing a thoracolumbar prefabricated brace</div><div>Turmeric 1500 mg daily</div><div>Long-acting nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/naproxen-drug-information?search=scoliosis&amp;topicRef=91910&amp;source=see_link"">naproxen</a></div><div><a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/acetaminophen-paracetamol-drug-information?search=scoliosis&amp;topicRef=91910&amp;source=see_link"">acetaminophen</a>, 1000 mg up to three times daily</div><div>Thirty minutes of low-impact aerobic exercise daily</div><div></div><div>If overweight, a weight loss diet; if underweight, encourage weight gain.</div><div></div>Rollator&nbsp;</div>"																				
<div><b>Scoliosis</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><u>Treatment</u><div>Bracing: {{c1::20-40}} degrees</div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-22 at 8.35.09 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>Lightweight pull-string corset-like lumbar brace</div><div>orthotist can help by providing a thoracolumbar prefabricated brace</div><div>Turmeric 1500 mg daily</div><div>Long-acting nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/naproxen-drug-information?search=scoliosis&amp;topicRef=91910&amp;source=see_link"">naproxen</a></div><div><a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/acetaminophen-paracetamol-drug-information?search=scoliosis&amp;topicRef=91910&amp;source=see_link"">acetaminophen</a>, 1000 mg up to three times daily</div><div>Thirty minutes of low-impact aerobic exercise daily</div><div></div><div>If overweight, a weight loss diet; if underweight, encourage weight gain.</div><div></div>Rollator&nbsp;</div>"																				
<div><b>Scoliosis</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><u>Treatment</u><div>Surgery: {{c1::&gt;40}} degrees</div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-22 at 8.35.09 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>Lightweight pull-string corset-like lumbar brace</div><div>orthotist can help by providing a thoracolumbar prefabricated brace</div><div>Turmeric 1500 mg daily</div><div>Long-acting nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/naproxen-drug-information?search=scoliosis&amp;topicRef=91910&amp;source=see_link"">naproxen</a></div><div><a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/acetaminophen-paracetamol-drug-information?search=scoliosis&amp;topicRef=91910&amp;source=see_link"">acetaminophen</a>, 1000 mg up to three times daily</div><div>Thirty minutes of low-impact aerobic exercise daily</div><div></div><div>If overweight, a weight loss diet; if underweight, encourage weight gain.</div><div></div>Rollator&nbsp;</div>"																				
<div><b>Scoliosis</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>Bracing</u>:</div><div>primarily used to {{c1::prevent worsening (does not correct)}}&nbsp;</div><div>Worn {{c2::23}} hours a day until {{c3::spinal growth}} is completed</div><div>Patients should be evaluated at {{c4::2}} to {{c4::3}} year intervals for life after the brace is discontinued</div>	<div>Weaning off can begin when radiographs display signs of maturity and curves are stable</div>																				
"<b>Scoliosis</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Types of bracing</u></span><br></div><div>{{c1::Milwaukee brace}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">High thoracic curves (apex at T8)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></span></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Low-profile&nbsp;</span>TLSO}}:&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lower thoracic, thoracolumbar, and lumbar curves (apex below T8)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<div>there are now soft braces and ones that can be worn at night only to increase conpliance</div><img src=""paste-fd4a5d1fe4fd22c763fcf9386d2c57c7e9496ce6.jpg""><img src=""paste-c22474392d343fb8c4d38178fd052ddaa403df37.jpg""><div><img src=""bioengineering-08-00002-g002-550.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>Scoliosis</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Surgical&nbsp;indications:</u></div><div>Relentless progression</div><div>Neurological Dysfunction</div><div>&gt;50 degrees in the {{c1::skeletally mature::pt factor}} patient&nbsp;</div><div>&lt;35 degrees in {{c2::neuromuscular diseases (loss of pulmonary function)}}</div>	&gt;40-degree curvature in the skeletally immature																				
"<b>{{c1::Scheuermann}}<span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">&nbsp;disease aka juvenile kyphosis</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">An adolescent disorder of the vertebral endplates and apophysis resulting in an increased thoracic kyphosis</span><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">usually involves&nbsp;</span>{{c2::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;sequential vertebrae and is generally &gt;</span>{{c2::45}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;degrees</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">Scheuermann disease, juvenile kyphosis, or juvenile discogenic disease</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">a condition of hyperkyphosis that involves the vertebral bodies and discs of the spine</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">identified by anterior wedging of greater than or equal to 5 degrees in 3 or more adjacent vertebral bodies</span></div><div><img src=""MRI__with__measurements.gif""><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>Scheuermann kyphosis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><u>Etiology</u></div><div>Failure of endochondral ossification</div><div>{{c1::Intervertebral disc herniation}}</div><div>{{c2::Anterior wedging of the vertebral bodies}}</div><div>Fixed thoracolumbar kyphosis</div><div>Recent literature also notes an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern Clinical Features</div></div>	"<u>clinical features</u><div><div>More common in adolescent males.</div><div>Can present with a progressive, nonpainful thoracic kyphosis.</div><div>The thoracic kyphosis remains fixed and does not correct with hyperextension.</div><div>Back pain may occur in young athletes due to localized stress injury to the vertebral growth plates.</div></div><div><img src=""scheuermanns_a_enIL.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Schmorl’s node}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: herniation of disc material through the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::vertebral endplate}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;into the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::spongiosa}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of the vertebral body</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and vertebral wedging ~5</span><sup style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">o</sup><div>associated with scheurman kyphosis<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_178.png""><br></div></div>"																				
<div><b>Scheuermann kyphosis<br></b></div><div><br></div><u>Treatment</u><div>Rehabilitation program: Focus on thoracic extension and abdominal strengthening exercises</div><div>Bracing may be used for kyphosis ≤{{c1::74::same}} degrees for a length of time dependent on skeletal maturity</div><div>Surgical correction may be indicated if kyphosis is &gt;{{c1::75::same}} degrees&nbsp;</div>	"or &gt;65 degrees in the skeletally mature<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">extension-type orthosis</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;(Jewitt type - with high chest pad)</span></b><br></div><div><img src=""paste-d4e873abf6d6f200ee8eaa8e2d4d9d5f7930ee61.jpg""><b><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></b></div>"																				
"vertebral compression fractures are most commonly&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">occur at the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::thoracolumbar junction}}"	"lower thoracic (essesntials)<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">due to the transition between the fixed rigid thoracic and the highly mobile lumbar vertebra</span><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_180.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>vertebral compression fracture</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><u>Etiology</u></div><div>{{c1::Trauma}}</div><div>{{c1::Osteoporosis/osteopenia}}</div><div>{{c2::Neoplasm}}</div><div>Medication related (corticosteroids)</div></div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_180.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>compression fracture</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Sudden onset of constant thoracolumbar pain</div><div>Exacerbated with {{c1::Valsalva maneuvers}}, turning in bed, flexion, or incidental trauma (ie. stepping off a curb)</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_180.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>compression fracture</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>{{c1::kyphotic deformity::observation}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::tenderness to percussion over SP::provocation}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_180.png"">"																				
compression fracture&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>grade 1: {{c1::20}}-{{c1::25}}% height loss</div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-23 at 10.25.02 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div>compression fracture&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>grade 2: {{c1::25}}-{{c1::40}}% height loss</div></div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-23 at 10.25.02 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div>compression fracture&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>grade 3: {{c1::&gt;40}}% height loss</div></div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-08-23 at 10.25.02 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>three-column model for evaluating thoracolumbar fractures</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Anterior Contents</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Anterior longitudinal ligament}}</div><div>{{c1::Anterior two-thirds of the vertebral body}}</div><div>{{c1::annulus fibrosis}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""22bf108ea84f15036e0257c75cc6a7da.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>three-column model for evaluating thoracolumbar fractures</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Middle Contents</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Posterior longitudinal ligament}}</div><div>{{c1::Posterior one-third of the vertebral body}}</div><div>{{c1::posterior annulus fibrosis}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""22bf108ea84f15036e0257c75cc6a7da.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>three-column model for evaluating thoracolumbar fractures</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Posterior Contents</u></span></div><div>{{c1::Posterior ligaments: Ligamentum flavum, supraspinous and infraspinous ligament::braod category}}</div><div>{{c1::Posterior elements: Pedicles, facets, spinous process::braod category}}</div>"	"<img src=""22bf108ea84f15036e0257c75cc6a7da.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>three-column model for evaluating thoracolumbar fractures</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div><u>instability defined by:</u></div><div>{{c1::injury to middle column}}</div></div><div>{{c1::injury to 2 contigous columns}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_179.png"">"																				
<div><b>compression fracture&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>conservative managment indications</u>&nbsp;</div><div>No neurologic compromise&nbsp;</div><div>No {{c1::unstable 3-column fracture pattern}}</div><div>Indicated for fractures causing &lt;{{c2::25}}% decrease of vertebral height</div>	"<div>Nonoperative =&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong>activity as tolerated +/- thoracolumbosacral orthosis</strong></span>&nbsp;(Ortho Bullets)</div><div><br></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>-&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">neurologically intact</span></div><div>- mechanically stable fracture pattern (3 column)</div><div>- posterior ligament complex preserved</div><div>- progressive kyphosis &lt; 30° (controversial)</div><div>- vertebral body has lost &lt; 50% of body height (controversial)</div><div><font color=""#fc0507"">- intractable long term pain</font> (acute or subacute fx refractroy to opioids --&gt; kyphoplasty) (Uptodate)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>thoracolumbar orthosis</u></div><div>recent evidence shows<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;no clear advantage of TLSO on outcomes</span></div><div>if it provides symptomatic relief, may be beneficial for patient</div><div>bracing may not be suitable for those with associated abdominal or chest injuries</div><div><img src=""db9b52a67cb84ab19009c537ead24cac.jpeg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>compression fracture&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>conservative managment</u>:</div><div>Activity as tolerated&nbsp;</div><div>Rehabilitation program: Focus on hyperextension exercises<br></div><div>Medications for pain control: may need tramadol, buprenorphine, or opioids&nbsp;</div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">intranasal c</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">alcitonin</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">, advocated early in treatment&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div>{{c2::Bracing (elastic binder custom TLSO)}} controversial&nbsp;</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Calcitonin is not effective immediately; therefore, initiating it with acetaminophen, ibuprofen, or naproxen is best</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Custom-molded&nbsp;</span>TLSO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">/Jewett brace</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div><b>compression fracture&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>work up</u>:</div><div>X-rays, CT</div><div>{{c1::MRI}} or {{c1::bone scan}}</div><div>Labwork for {{c2::metabolic d/o}} or {{c2::malignancy}}</div><div>{{c3::DEXA}} on a non urgent basis&nbsp;</div>	"MRI to determine acuity or retropulsion into the cord<div><br></div><div><u>Labs</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">CBC, CMP, (calcium, phosphorous, albumin, total protein, creatinine, liver enzymes including alkaline phosphatase, electrolytes)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">25-hydroxyvitamin D</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">in men, a serum testosterone level</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">ESR, CRP, SPEP/UPEP</span></div>"																				
<div><b>compression fracture&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>invasive treatment</u>:</div><div>{{c1::vertebroplasty}}</div><div>{{c1::kyphoplasty}}</div><div>Surgery&nbsp;</div><div></div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Surgery</b>: fx causing &gt;50% height loss, instability, and late kyphotic deformity leading to neurologic compromise</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Interventional</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">For those who are not satisfied with the level of symptomatic relief, are unable to perform ALD's, or are not tolerating opioids (constipation, confusion, urinary retention), we suggest vertebral augmentation rather than continued medical management&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">incapacitating pain from acute and subacute vertebral compression fractures who are unable to taper parenteral or transition to oral opioids within seven days of admission or have intolerable sedation, constipation, or delirium from this therapy, we suggest vertebral augmentation rather than continued medical management (</span><a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/grade/6?title=Grade%202C&amp;topicKey=ENDO/7775"">Grade 2C</a><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">). This is typically performed during the initial hospitalization??</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><u>vertebroplasty</u>,&nbsp;</span>bone cement is injected into fractured vertebrae to stabilize the spine and relieve pain<div><img src=""paste-4c36e75269078935eab7ed98b18e9bdfad4bd141.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>Kyphoplasty</u> relies on the use of a balloon tamponade system that can have technical difficulties and greater cost</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">but it may partially restore vertebral height</span><br></div><div><img src=""kyphoplasty.png""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>vertebral body burst fracture:</b><div><br></div><div>Compression fractures of the vertebral body involving the {{c1::anterior and middle columns}} of the spine</div>	"2/2 significant trauma, typically from a fall or MVA<div>- more dangerous than compression fractures (SC injury)<br><div>- Most commonly seen in the thoracolumbar region</div><div><br></div><div>Treatment is based on if it is stable or unstable:</div><div><br></div><div><u>Stable:</u></div><div>-&nbsp;Neurologically intact. Posterior column remains intact.</div><div>- &lt;50% collapse of anterior vertebral body height</div><div><br></div><div><u>Unstable:</u></div><div>- Neurologic deficits present</div><div>- &gt;50% loss of anterior vertebral body height</div><div>- Central canal compromise &gt;30%</div><div>- Posterior element injury</div></div><div><img src=""db9b52a67cb84ab19009c537ead24cac.jpeg""><br></div>"																				
<b>vertebral body burst fracture&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment Stable</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>Typically treated {{c1::nonoperatively}} with {{c1::bracing (4 to 6 months)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Follow-up radiographs}} performed {{c2::standing}} to evaluate for kyphosis</div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment Unstable</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>Surgical decompression and fusion to treat or avoid neurologic compromise</div>	"from a significant trauma, typically from a fall from a height or MVC<div>- more severe than a compression fx as bone can damage the spinal cord<br><div>- Most commonly seen in the thoracolumbar region</div><div><br></div><div>Treatment is based on if it is stable or unstable:</div><div><br></div><div><u>Stable:</u></div><div>-&nbsp;Neurologically intact. Posterior column remains intact.</div><div>- &lt;50% collapse of anterior vertebral body height</div><div><br></div><div><u>Unstable:</u></div><div>- Neurologic deficits present</div><div>- &gt;50% loss of anterior vertebral body height</div><div>- Central canal compromise &gt;30%</div><div>- Posterior element injury</div></div><div><img src=""the-different-types-of-spinal-fractures-including-compression-wedge-and-burst.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>Meniscal Tears</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">obtain ortho referral imideiately for&nbsp;</span>{{c3::locked knee (can not fully extend)}}<br><div><br></div><div><u>operative treatment (indications)</u></div><div>1.&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">notable&nbsp;</span>{{c1::mechanical symptoms}},&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">despite the initial management</span></div></div><div>2. {{c2::recurrent effusions}},&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">despite the initial management&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">3.&nbsp;</span>{{c4::large complex tear seen on MRI::objective}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>MRI</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">should be obtained with notable mechanical symptoms or recurrent effusions&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">that persist for </span><font color=""#fc0507"">three to four</font><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""> weeks despite the initial managemen</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Consultation with an orthopedic surgeon</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">needed if the MRI demonstrates a large or complex meniscal tear</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">patient continues to develop joint effusions, locking of the knee, or other disabling symptoms&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">after </span><font color=""#fc0507"">four to six weeks</font><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""> of conservative management</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><div>The following factors suggest surgery will be required:</div><div>●A severe twisting injury occurred and activity could not be resumed thereafter</div><div>●The knee is locked or motion is severely restricted</div><div>●Pain develops with McMurray testing involving minimal knee flexion</div><div>●An associated anterior cruciate ligament tear exists (see&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/anterior-cruciate-ligament-injury?search=knee%20meniscal%20tear&amp;topicRef=186&amp;source=see_link"">""Anterior cruciate ligament injury""</a>)</div><div>●There is little improvement in symptoms after three to six weeks despite proper conservative treatment</div></div>"																				
<b>ACL tear</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>indications for MRI (clinical presentation)</u></div><div>{{c1::unable to bear wieght}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::unstable (giving out)}}</div><div>{{c3::+ lachman's}} or {{c3::joint effusion}} (physical exam)</div><div><br></div><div>(otherwise trial of PT and RICE before obtaining imaging)</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-09-10 at 2.35.09 PM.png"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Classification of Cancer Rehabilitation</b></span><br></div><br><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>divided into four categories</u>:&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c1::preventative}}<br></div><div>{{c2::restorative}}<br></div><div>{{c3::supportive}}<br></div><div>{{c4::palliative}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-10 at 9.24.48 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>most common cancer rehabilitation problems</b></span><div><br></div><div>35% {{c1::General weakness (fatigue)}}</div><div>30% {{c2::ADL deficits}}</div><div>30% {{c3::Pain}}</div><div>25% {{c4::Difficulty with ambulation}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Other problems include</u>:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">speech, swallowing, respiratory,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">neurologic impairments, skin problems,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">nutritional deficiencies, lymphedema, skeletal disease, and psychological disorders&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(</span><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch09#bid_9_53"">Lehman et al., 1978</a><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::immobility}}-<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">related complications are pertinent in the cancer rehab patient&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">secondary to longer time periods of illness, treatment, and recovery</span></div>"	<b>Immobility May Predispose Patients to the Following Body System Issues</b>:<div><br></div><div><u>Musculoskeletal</u>:</div><div>-Muscle atrophy</div><div>-Decreased endurance</div><div>-Joint contractures</div><div><br></div><div><u>Vascular</u>:</div><div>-Orthostatic intolerance</div><div>-Deep venous thrombosis (DVT)</div><div>-Pulmonary embolism (PE)</div><div><br></div><div><u>Metabolic</u>:</div><div>-Protein loss</div><div>-Impaired glucose tolerance</div><div>-Hypercalcemia</div><div><br></div><div><u>Skin</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>Pressure ulcers</div><div><br></div><div><u>Gastrointestinal (GI)/genitourinary (GU)</u>:</div><div>-Dysphagia</div><div>-Difficulty voiding</div><div>-Constipation</div><div><br></div><div><u>Neuro</u>: Compressive neuropathies</div><div><br></div><div><u>Psychological</u>:</div><div>-Sleep disturbance</div><div>-Depression</div><div><br></div><div><u>Respiratory</u>: Pneumonia</div>
