"<b>Cancer Rehabilitation Intervention</b><div><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;&nbsp;high index of suspicion for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::swallowing disorders}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;should be maintained</span><br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_ufig1.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp; high index of suspicion should be maintained for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::metastatic involvement (of the extremities and spine)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	<u>Swallowing Issues</u><div><br></div><div>- Swallowing disorders may result from a variety of reasons in patients with cancer.</div><div>can be associated with cognitive impairment,&nbsp;CNS&nbsp;involvement, and radiation treatment,&nbsp;</div><div>and appear in patients with generalized deconditioning secondary to bed rest.</div><div><br></div><div>-When aspiration is suspected, a dysphagia evaluation is performed.&nbsp;</div><div>If silent aspiration is suspected, a videofluoroscopic swallow study (VFSS) is necessary.</div><div><br></div><div>-Calorie counts should also be performed to ensure adequate nutrition.&nbsp;</div><div>A gastrostomy may be required for long-term nutritional management in some patients.</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Extremities with possible tumor involvement&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">should be&nbsp;</span>{{c1::nonweight bearing}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ROM}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;withheld until a workup is completed</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Complaints of bony pain or discomfort warrant further investigation prior to initiating a skilled rehabilitation program</span>"																				
"<b>Primary (non-mets) Brain Tumors in Adults&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Gliomas}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;comprise approximately 60% of all primary&nbsp;</span>CNS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;tumors</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">originate in the glial cells of the central nervous system (CNS).&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gliomas can be divided into 3 main types: astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas, and ependymomas</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">median survival of patients with glioma has improved over the past few years but is still only 15 months</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""glialcellsillustration-5a94d585642dca00362568c4.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b>Primary (non-mets) Brain Tumors in Adults</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::Cerebellar astrocytoma}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the most common primary&nbsp;</span>CNS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;solid tumor in <u>young</u> adults</span><b><br></b></div>"																					
<b>SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS OF BRAIN TUMORS</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Headache (most common)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::&nbsp;Weakness (most common focal sign)}}</div><div>{{c3::Seizures (first presenting sign)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Contrast&nbsp;MRI}} is the best diagnostic test</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-10 at 10.28.40 PM.png"">"																				
"<b>BRAIN METASTASIS</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>commonly originate from primary tumor (most to least)</u></span>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Lung cancer::same}}, followed by {{c1::melanoma}}, in men</div><div>{{c1::Lung cancer::same}}, followed by {{c1::breast tumors}}, in women<br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-10 at 10.28.40 PM.png"">"																				
{{c1::Astrocytomas}} are the most common glioma in adults	"<img src=""glialcellsillustration-5a94d585642dca00362568c4.jpg"">"																				
{{c1::GLIOBLASTOMA}} is the most common MALIGNANT primary CNS tumor in adults	"GLIOBLASTOMA MULTIFORME (GBM, “Glioblastoma”, alternate term for grade IV [high-grade astrocytoma)<div><img src=""review-204334ac28101c06380488b5d3565339a5b00f97.webp""><br></div>"																				
"<b>PRIMARY BRAIN TUMORS IN CHILDREN</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Brain tumors (25%) are only 2nd to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::leukemia}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(33%) as the most prevalent malignancy in childhood</span><b><br></b></div>"																					
"{{c1::Cerebellar astrocytoma}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the most common posterior fossa tumor in childhood and has a&nbsp;</span>{{c2::the best::good/poor}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;prognosis</span>"																					
"{{c1::Medulloblastoma}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the 2nd most common posterior fossa tumor in childhood&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and it is the most prevalent brain tumor in children less than 7 years of age</span>"																				
"{{c1::Brainstem gliomas}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the 3rd most frequent posterior fossa tumor in children</span>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Brain metastasis occurs in approximately&nbsp;</span>{{c1::25}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of patients with cancer</span>"																					
<b>MEDICAL TREATMENT OF BRAIN TUMORS</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Dexamethasone}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Antiepileptic}} medications<br></div><div>{{c3::Neurosurgical evaluation (to consider resection of single or a couple of metastases when indicated)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Whole brain radiation}} versus {{c4::Stereotactic radiosurgery}} therapy</div><div>{{c5::Chemotherapy}}&nbsp;<br></div>	<div>Dexamethasone intravenous (IV) or orally to decrease brain edema and symptoms</div><div><br></div><div>Antiepileptic medications to control or prevent seizures</div><div><br></div><div>Neurosurgical evaluation to consider resection of single or a couple of metastases when indicated</div><div><br></div><div>Whole brain radiation therapy (x-ray tomography [XRT])</div><div><br></div><div>Stereotactic radiosurgery (radiation therapy), which gives high doses of radiation to a limited field,&nbsp;</div><div>increases response rates to isolated metastasis, and spares radiation injury to the rest of the brain.</div><div><br></div><div>Chemotherapy&nbsp;</div>																				
"<strong style="""">Nongliomas</strong><div><b><br></b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>prevalent examples include</u>:&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">medulloblastomas</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::meningiomas}}<br></div><div>{{c1::medullpituitary adenomas}}<br></div><div>{{c1::primary CNS lymphomas}}<br></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Gliomas can be divided into 3 main types: astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas, and ependymomas</span><br></div><img src=""review-204334ac28101c06380488b5d3565339a5b00f97.webp"">"																				
<b>Spinal Cord Tumors</b><div><br></div><div>majority of&nbsp;tumors affecting the spinal cord are {{c1::extra}}dural (95%) and arise from {{c1::metastasis}} in the vertebral body</div>	Spinal cord tumors&nbsp;are rare																				
<b>Spinal Cord Tumors</b><div><br></div><div>Approximately 70% of&nbsp;metastatic spinal tumors affect the {{c1::thoracic::c/t/l}} cord</div>																					
"RADIATION SIDE EFFECTS IN SPINAL CORD TUMOR TREATMENT<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most common</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;form of radiation damage is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::induced transient myelopathy}}<br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Radiation myelopathy of</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;the spinal cord is divided into transient myelopathy and delayed radiation myelopathy</span>"																				
"<strong>induced transient myelopathy</strong><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">develops&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3 (to 4) months}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after treatment&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and spontaneously resolves over 3 to 6 months</span>"																				
<strong>induced transient myelopathy</strong><div><br></div><div>transient&nbsp;demyelination of the {{c1::posterior columns}} and {{c1::lateral spinothalamic tract}}</div><div><br></div><div>patients may report&nbsp;symmetric, {{c2::electric shock-like paresthesias}} or {{c2::numbness}}&nbsp;</div>	radiating to the extremities																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Delayed radiation myelopathy</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::irreversible::prognosis}}"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Delayed radiation myelopathy</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">symptoms do not begin until&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::12}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months after completing radiation treatment</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Most cases occur within 30 months</span>"																				
<b>Delayed radiation myelopathy</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Symptoms begin with&nbsp;lower extremity {{c2::paresthesias}} followed by {{c1::bowel dysfunction}} and {{c1::weakness}}</div>																					
<b>Peripheral Nervous System Involvement in Cancer</b><div><br></div><div><u>Peripheral neuropathy can&nbsp;occur due to</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::tumor infiltration}}</div><div>{{c2::paraneoplastic syndromes}}</div><div>toxicity from the chemotherapy</div>																					
<b>Peripheral Nervous System Involvement in Cancer</b><div><br></div><div><u>Peripheral polyneuropathy has&nbsp;been associated with</u></div><div>{{c1::lung cancer}}</div><div>{{c2::multiple myeloma (MM)}}</div><div>breast cancer&nbsp;</div><div>colon cancer</div>	Polyneuropathy is associated&nbsp;with inflammation and degeneration and can be demyelinating and axonal in nature																				
"<b>Peripheral Nervous System Involvement in Cancer</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Subacute motor neuropathy</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;usually occurs with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lymphoma::cancer type}}<br></div>"	"<div>rare, acquired, motor neuropathy characterized by progressive asymmetric weakness without sensory problems.<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div>considered immune-mediated motor neuropathy.<br></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Anterior horn cells degenerate, resulting in weakness</span><div><font color=""#333333""><br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">However, stabilization occurs with gradual improvement</span></div></div>"																				
"CHEMOTHERAPY SIDE EFFECTS TO PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Vincristine may cause distal axonal degeneration, severe neuropathic pain, and, in rare cases,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::quadriparesis}}<br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">motor involvement which can lead to quadriparesis</span>"																				
"CHEMOTHERAPY SIDE EFFECTS TO PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM<div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Cisplatin, bortezomib, and vincristine may also cause&nbsp;</span>{{c1::autonomic::rare type}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;neuropathies</span><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">resulting in fluctuating blood pressure or heart rate</span>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Radiation may cause peripheral nerve damage due to effects on the nerve itself&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::involvement of the surrounding connective tissue (and vascular supply)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Symptoms include muscle atrophy, hyperesthesia, paresthesias, decreased strength, and decreased&nbsp;</span>ROM"																				
"{{c1::Brachial plexopathy}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is an uncommon nerve injury,</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">but can occur as a result of radiation treatment or through direct tumor extension, or paraneoplastic syndrome</span></div>"	tumor cells can infiltrate the nerve sheath alone, and standar MRI will be negative&nbsp;																				
"<b>TUMOR EXTENSION vs&nbsp;</b><b>RADIATION SIDE EFFECTS TO PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM</b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In&nbsp;</span>{{c1::direct tumor extension}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span>{{c2::pain}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the initial symptom</span></div>"																					
"<b>TUMOR EXTENSION vs&nbsp;</b><b>RADIATION SIDE EFFECTS&nbsp;</b><b>TO PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM</b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In&nbsp;</span>{{c1::postradiation plexopathy}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span>{{c2::numbness / paresthesias}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the initial symptom</span></div>"																					
{{c1::Cognitive}} side effects of radiation are probably dose related<div><br></div><div>{{c2::Young children}} are at higher risk than {{c2::adults}} are,&nbsp;</div>	as myelin is developing rapidly; therefore, they are susceptible to&nbsp;CNS&nbsp;insult.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>It usually presents slowly, in delayed fashion, and can be difficult to distinguish from tumor recurrence.</div><div><br></div><div>Cognitive effects are estimated in approximately <b>34%</b> of patients after radiation therapy, <u>especially if combined with chemotherapy</u></div>																				
<b>Orthopedic Complications of Radiation</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Fibrosis / contractures}} can develop</div><div>Postradiation {{c2::osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis [AVN])}} is uncommon&nbsp;</div>	The patient should be maintained on a prophylactic stretching program before treatment&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>and continued therapeutic stretching after radiation treatment</div><div><br></div><div>Post Radiation AVN is uncommon but <b>may lead to pathologic fractures</b><br></div>																				
"{{c1::Carcinomatous myopathy}}:<br><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">syndrome seen in metastatic disease that is consistent with muscle necrosis and presents with proximal muscle weakness</span></div>"																					
"<b>{{c1::Carcinomatous neuropathy}}:</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">presents with distal motor and sensory loss, proximal muscle weakness, decreased reflexes and sensation.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It most often occurs with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::lung}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cancer</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Type&nbsp;</span>{{c3::II}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;muscle atrophy is present as well as a distal peripheral polyneuropathy</span></div>"																					
"<strong>Upper extremity lymphedema</strong><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">most common after breast cancer, may occur with&nbsp;</span>{{c3::head}} and {{c3::neck}} cancer</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Found in patients who have had a full nodal dissection, as well as&nbsp;</span>{{c1::radiation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;therapy,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and less commonly with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::sentinel node}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;directed biopsies</span></div>"	<div>Breast cancer patients experience upper extremity swelling and a sense of arm fullness.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Usually develops over an extended period of time, postmastectomy or lumpectomy&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>with full node dissection&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>in up to one-third of women but only 5% after sentinel node biopsy.</div>																				
<div><strong>Lower extremity lymphedema</strong></div><div><br></div><div><u>associated with</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::uterine}} disorders</div><div>{{c1::prostate}} cancer</div><div>lymphoma</div><div>{{c2::melanoma}}</div>	<div>Found in melanoma patients who had a nodal dissection</div><div><br></div><div>Prostate cancer patients with whole pelvic radiation or surgery</div>																				
<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><b><br></b><div>{{c1::Acute, transient, and mild}}: Occurs a few days postoperatively</div></div>	<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><b><br></b><div>-&nbsp;Acute, transient, and mild: Occurs a few days postoperatively</div><div>-&nbsp;Acute and painful: Occurs 4 to 6 weeks postoperatively resulting from acute phlebitis or lymphangitis</div><div>-&nbsp;Erysipeloid form: Results from minor trauma. Superimposed on chronic edema.</div><div>-&nbsp;Insidious and painless: No erythema. Happens years after first treatment. Most common form</div></div>																				
<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Acute and painful}}: Occurs 4 to 6 weeks postoperatively resulting from acute {{c2::phlebitis}} or {{c2::lymphangitis}}</div></div>	<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><b><br></b><div>-&nbsp;Acute, transient, and mild: Occurs a few days postoperatively</div><div>-&nbsp;Acute and painful: Occurs 4 to 6 weeks postoperatively resulting from acute phlebitis or lymphangitis</div><div>-&nbsp;Erysipeloid form: Results from minor trauma. Superimposed on chronic edema.</div><div>-&nbsp;Insidious and painless: No erythema. Happens years after first treatment. Most common form</div></div>																				
<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Erysipeloid form}}: Results from {{c2::minor trauma}}. Superimposed on chronic edema.</div></div>	<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><b><br></b><div>-&nbsp;Acute, transient, and mild: Occurs a few days postoperatively</div><div>-&nbsp;Acute and painful: Occurs 4 to 6 weeks postoperatively resulting from acute phlebitis or lymphangitis</div><div>-&nbsp;Erysipeloid form: Results from minor trauma. Superimposed on chronic edema.</div><div>-&nbsp;Insidious and painless: No erythema. Happens years after first treatment. Most common form</div></div>																				
<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><br><div>{{c1::Insidious and painless}}: No erythema. Happens years after first treatment.&nbsp;</div></div>	<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><b><br></b><div>-&nbsp;Acute, transient, and mild: Occurs a few days postoperatively</div><div>-&nbsp;Acute and painful: Occurs 4 to 6 weeks postoperatively resulting from acute phlebitis or lymphangitis</div><div>-&nbsp;Erysipeloid form: Results from minor trauma. Superimposed on chronic edema.</div><div>-&nbsp;Insidious and painless: No erythema. Happens years after first treatment. Most common form</div></div>																				
<b>Lymphedema Presentation in Cancer</b><div><div><br></div><div>Most common form is {{c1::Insidious and painless}}</div></div>	Happens years after first treatment<div>&nbsp;</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Insidious and painless cancer lymphedema occurs</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::years}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;after first treatment</span>"																					
<b>Stages of Lymphedema</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Stage 0</u>: {{c1::Damage to lymphatic vessels, but No edema}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div><u>(latent)</u><br></div><div><br></div>Lymphedema is present but not clinically evident.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Symptoms may include a sensation of heaviness of the limb</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-24 at 4.09.44 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Stages of Lymphedema</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Stage 1</u>: Edema is {{c1::reversible}} and {{c1::Non-pitting}} on exam</div>	"<u>Stage 1&nbsp;(spontaneously reversible)</u><div><u><br></u></div><div>Edema usually upon awaking in the morning.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Limb size is normal or almost normal.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Swelling may be reversible.<u><br></u></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-24 at 4.09.44 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""LymphedemastageIAB.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Stages of Lymphedema</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Stage 2</u>: Edema is {{c1::irreversible}} and {{c1::Pitting}} on exam. {{c2::Fibrosis}} starts to develop.</div>	"<u>(spontaneously irreversible)</u><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-24 at 4.09.44 PM.png""><u><br></u></div><div><img src=""LymphedemastageIIAB.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Stages of Lymphedema</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Stage 3</u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: edema is irreversible, and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::hard}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on exam,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::fibrotic tissue}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;develops</span><b><br></b></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(lymphostatic elephantiasis)</span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-24 at 4.09.44 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""LymphedemastageIIIABC.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Lymphedema is categorized by its severity when compared to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::a healthy extremity}}"																					
<b>Lymphedema Grading</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Grade 1&nbsp;(Mild)</u>:</div><div>Pitting edema that can be {{c1::reversed by elevation}}&nbsp;</div><div>Present in {{c2::distal arm or leg}}</div><div>Difference in circumference {{c3::&lt;4 cm}}</div>																					
<b>Lymphedema Grading</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><u><strong>Grade 2</strong>&nbsp;(Moderate)</u>:</div><div>{{c3::Nonpitting::pit/non-pit}}, brawny edema {{c3::not reversible::reversible/not reversible}} with elevation of the extremity</div><div>Infection: {{c1::None to occasional}}</div><div>Difference in circumference is &gt;{{c2::4}} cm but &lt;{{c2::6}} cm</div></div>	<div>skin becomes hardened secondary to the development of fibrotic tissue due to chronic excess protein</div><div>in the interstitial spaces and deposition of adipose tissue.</div><div>Edema moderate, reversible with effort</div><div>Involves entire limb or corresponding quadrant of the trunk</div>																				
<b>Lymphedema Grading</b><div><br></div><div><div><u>Grade 3a&nbsp;(Severe)</u>:</div><div>Edema is present in one limb and {{c3::associated trunk quadrant}}<br></div><div>Pressure does {{c4::not produce::does/does not}} pitting&nbsp;</div><div>Edema {{c5::minimally reversible or not reversible::reversible/not reversible}}</div><div>Infection common but usually fewer than {{c2::4}} times per year<br></div><div>difference in&nbsp;circumference is &gt;{{c1::6}} cm</div></div>	Swelling of the&nbsp;involved extremity described as lymphostatic elephantiasis.<div><br></div><div>Cartilage like&nbsp;</div>																				
<b>Lymphedema Grading</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Grade 3b&nbsp;(Massive edema)</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>Same symptoms as stage 3a except that {{c1::2 or more extremities are affected}}</div>																					
<b>Lymphedema Grading</b><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Grade 4&nbsp;(Gigantic): Elephantiasis</u>:</div><div>Edema is severe&nbsp;and irreversible&nbsp;</div><div>Edema may involve {{c1::face and head}}</div><div>Infection frequent, {{c2::more&nbsp;than 4}}&nbsp;times per year</div>	<div>Due to almost&nbsp;complete obstruction of the lymphatic channels</div><div><br></div><div>Impossible for ultrasound testing to even detect a pulse.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Focus is on&nbsp;management, containment of infections</div>																				
<b>Lymphedema Diagnosis</b><div><br></div><div>Diagnosis is based&nbsp;on the patient’s history and a physical examination,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Limb circumference}}, water&nbsp;displacement, bioelectrical impedance, and optoelectronic perometry are used to measure limb differences</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Lymphoscintigraphy}} is the&nbsp;imaging standard of care for identifying lymphatic system abnormalities</div><div><br></div><div>Some genes have&nbsp;been identified that are associated with hereditary syndrome</div>	Other causes of edema should be ruled out, (malignancy,&nbsp;DVT, infections, and venous insufficiency)																				
<div>when evaluating patients in lymphadema clinic,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>other causes of unilateral edema should be ruled out,&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::malignancy}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::DVT}}</div><div>{{c3::infections}}</div><div>{{c4::venous insufficiency}}</div>	"<u>Localized edema DDx</u><div><br></div><div><div>dependent edema (paralysis)</div><div>lymphedema<br></div><div><a href=""https://www.dynamed.com/condition/venous-insufficiency"" style=""vertical-align: super;"">chronic venous insufficiency</a>&nbsp;(bilateral edema may appear assymetric if the degree of venous insuff diff)</div><div><a href=""https://www.dynamed.com/condition/deep-vein-thrombosis-dvt"" style=""vertical-align: super;"">deep venous thrombosis (DVT)</a></div><div><a href=""https://www.dynamed.com/condition/cellulitis"">cellulitis</a></div><div><span style=""vertical-align: super;"">local MSK trauma&nbsp;</span><sup>(gastrocnemius tear or&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.dynamed.com/condition/popliteal-cyst"">popliteal cyst</a>)</sup></div><div><span style=""vertical-align: super;"">iliac vein compression (such as in May-Thurner syndrome) or obstruction</span></div><div>reflex sympathetic dystrophy&nbsp;</div><div><a href=""https://www.dynamed.com/management/acute-compartment-syndrome-emergency-management"">compartment syndrom</a>e</div><div>Cancer (a pelvic mass could obstruct the system)</div></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Work up</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">compression ultrasonography (CUS) with Doppler should be obtained.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">CUS: venous insufficency versus pelvic outflow obstruct</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">would get CT of the pelvis to see if a mass cuased outflow obs&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
"<b>Lymphedema Treatment</b><div><br></div><div><u>prevention</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">avoid&nbsp;</span>{{c1::constricting the limb}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">avoid&nbsp;</span>{{c1::skin injury (meticulous hygiene (infection)}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">avoidance of extreme heat exposure</span><br></div><div><font color=""#333333"">maintain&nbsp;</font>{{c2::healthy weight}}<font color=""#333333"">&nbsp;</font></div>"																					
"<b>Lymphedema Treatment</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::elevation}}<br></div><div>{{c1::short stretch compresion bandages}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c2::manual lymph drainage}}<b><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">followed by&nbsp;</span>{{c2::custom compression garments}}</div><div>{{c3::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">intermittent pneumatic</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;compression pump</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">If a pneumatic</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or graded compression pump is used, it must be used for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;hours daily&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">followed by placement of a compression garment to prevent reaccumulation of fluid.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">This must be done&nbsp;</span>{{c2::daily}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;for the remainder of the patient’s life</span></div>"																					
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">intermittent pneumatic</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;compression pump &amp; decongestive therapy&nbsp;</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>cuations/contraindications</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">patients with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::CHF}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;should be monitored closely</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Caution should be</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;taken in the presence of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::residual tumor}}</div><div>Pumping should be&nbsp;discontinued if edema increases {{c3::above the pump’s sleeve}}</div><div>Pumps should not&nbsp;be used in the presence of {{c4::infection}} or {{c4::thormbus}}</div><div>Pumps are contraindicated&nbsp;in pt Hx of {{c5::bilateral mastectomy (truncal edema)}}&nbsp;</div>"	No true absolute contraindications exist																				
should not consider OT manual therapy or IPC (NOT list of cuations)<div><br></div><div><u>patient factors</u></div><div>{{c1::allodynia}}</div><div>{{c2::unwilling to use compression garments}}</div>	too painful to have massage<div><br></div><div>releasing the edema is pointless if they do not compress afterward</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">When&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">more than</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;one lymphedematous area</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is involved,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">there is no place for fluid resolution and other areas may become edematous</span></div>"																					
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Lymphadema Treatment</b>&nbsp;</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Following mastectomy,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>immediate</u></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>&nbsp;postoperative therapies</u></span></div><div>{{c1::hand pumping}}<br></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">hand, elbow, and shoulder (</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">40<sup>o</sup> of flexion and abduction)</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>ROM}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;exercises</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">as well as&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">positioning techniques, postural exercises,</span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">are safe to do right away</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>Active assistive exercises can be initiated when the surgical drains have been removed</span>"																				
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">CANCERS WITH A</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;PREDILECTION TO METASTASIZE TO BONE</span></b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::prostate}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::breast}}</div><div>{{c1::kidney (bladder cuccurullo)}}</div><div>{{c1::thyroid}}</div><div>{{c1::lung}}<br></div>"	"PB-KTL<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-24 at 8.21.51 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Bone Metastasis</b></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>most consistent</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;symptom is pain that is most severe&nbsp;</span>{{c1::at night}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span>{{c2::upon weight bearing}}"																					
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Bone Metastasis</b></span></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In patients with spinal involvement, pain may be worse&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lying down}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and improves with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sitting}}</div>"																					
"{{c1::proximal femur}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the most common site of pathological fractures</span>"	Metastatic bone disease&nbsp;causes pain, pathological fractures, neurologic injury, and functional disability<div><br></div><div>Pathologic fractures occur in 10% to 30% of patients with bone lesions.</div><div><br></div><div>The risk of&nbsp;pathologic fracture is correlated with the extent of the lesion, the type of destruction, and the anatomic location.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Lesions in higher stress areas such as the lesser trochanter are often associated with subsequent pathologic fracture.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>A high risk of fracture is associated with highly anaplastic and rapidly growing vascular lesions, which are usually osteolytic.</div>																				
<div>Skeletal metastases are&nbsp;rarely {{c1::solitary}}</div>	<div>metastasis usually involves the axial skeleton, proximal femur, and humerus</div><div><br></div><div>70% of spinal&nbsp;metastases occur in the thoracic spine</div><div><br></div><div>95% are extradural&nbsp;in origin and involve the vertebral body anterior to the spinal canal</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">If the clinician suspects metastatic involvement,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the patient should be&nbsp;</span>{{c1::placed nonweight bearing}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;until a full evaluation and workup is completed</span></div>"																					
"<b>Diagnosis of Metastatic Bone Disease</b><div><u><br></u></div><div><u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Complaints of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::Non-spinal}}</u><b><font color=""#fc0507"">*</font></b><u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pain in a patient with&nbsp;</span>{{c2::known history of cancer}}</u><b><font color=""#fc0507"">*</font></b></div><div>{{c1::plain film x-rays}}<br></div><div>{{c1::cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">whole body skeletal evaluation (bone scan, FDG-(</span>PET<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) scans)</span>}}<br></div><div>+/- {{c3::biopsy}}<b><font color=""#fc0507"">^&nbsp;</font></b></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">1. radiographs of the affected area are recommended for initial evaluation</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">2. If there is no apparent lesion on radiograph, but the clinical suspicion is high then (CT) or (MRI)</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">3. i</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">nitiation of analgesic therapy is indicated before the etiology is determined while further testing is planned</span><br></div><div><b style=""""><font color=""#fc0507"">*</font></b><font color=""#232323"">&nbsp;</font><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">cancer patients presenting with significant back pain, spinal MRI is indicated, even in the absence of neuro signs</span></div><div><b style=""""><font color=""#fc0507"">*</font></b><font color=""#232323""> patients with NO hx of cancer or a distant history are more complex&nbsp;</font></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-25 at 8.01.00 PM.png""><br><div><b><font color=""#fc0507"">^&nbsp;</font></b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">need for biopsy depends on...</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">whether surgery will be performed,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">whether clinical diagnosis using imaging evaluation is sufficient</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">whether pathological diagnosis is required to confirm metastasis</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">For patients with no history of cancer, biopsy of skeletal abnormality may be necessary for pathologic diagnosis.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">For patients whose cancer is in remission, documentation of a pathologic diagnosis may be necessary especially if this is the first evidence of recurrence or disease progression.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">For patients with known history of stage IV malignancy or who are found to have other visceral metastasis on staging or restaging evaluation, clinical diagnosis with one or more imaging modalities may be sufficient to make a presumptive diagnosis of bone metastasis.</span><br><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-25 at 8.03.03 PM.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<div><b>Diagnosis of Metastatic Bone Disease</b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>Evaluation of a patient with <u>no, or a remote, history of cancer</u> is more complex</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">1. diagnostics must include&nbsp;</span>{{c1::contrast-enhanced CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis (tailored for visceral organ evaluation)::broad category}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">2. plus a&nbsp;</span>{{c2::whole body skeletal evaluation (bone scan or FDG-PET/CT)::broad category}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">1. to search for the primary site</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">2. used for comprehensive staging evaluation</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">In general, diagnostic evaluation should precede biopsy of suspicious bone lesions,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">particularly if a pathologic or impending pathologic fracture is present or suspected</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"																				
<div>{{c2::bone scan}}<strong>:&nbsp;</strong>an important tool for detecting cancer that has metastasized</div><div><br></div><div>highly sensitive but not highly specific for tumor involvement&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div>can be falsely positive in the setting of {{c3::prior trauma / degenerative joint disease}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>False negatives occur in the setting of bone destruction without {{c1::ongoing repair or bone metabolism}}</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Tc-99m skeletal scintigraphy</b>, generally referred to as a ""bone scan,""</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>most widely used</u> method to detect bone metastases</span><font color=""#232323""><br></font><div><div><b><font color=""#fc0507"">*</font></b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">less sensitive for detecting tumors with little to no osteoblastic activity (such as multiple myeloma)&nbsp;</span></div><div><b><font color=""#fc0507"">*</font></b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">and for aggressive lesions with rapid bone destruction because ithey have less osteoblastic activity resulting in new bone formation</span><br><img src=""Bonescanskeltlmetastases.jpg""></div><br></div></div>"																				
"{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">FDG-</span>PET}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;scans are more sensitive (able to pick up disease better)&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and more specific (what they pick up is more likely to really be cancer) than bone scans</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">A major benefit of FDG-PET over bone scan is its ability to screen for distant metastases at sites other than bone</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">For some malignancies (ie, lung and breast cancer), FDG-PET is more specific than bone scans for detection of bone metastases,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">although it is possibly less sensitive (especially for osteoblastic foci) and clearly more expensive</span><font color=""#232323""><br></font><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-25 at 8.01.00 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
<b><sup>18</sup>F NaF&nbsp;PET&nbsp;scan</b> imaging provides the physician with physiologic information of the bone<div><br></div><div>When the&nbsp;scan shows areas of increased uptake of&nbsp;<sup>18</sup>F NaF in the skeleton,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>it reflects sites of increased {{c1::blood flow (and bone remodeling)}}</div>	An additional type of&nbsp;PET&nbsp;scan is also utilized in clinical practice. It is&nbsp;FDG&nbsp;PET&nbsp;scan, and this scan shows areas of increased uptake of&nbsp;FDG&nbsp;in the skeleton. This reflects your body’s use of radioactive glucose (FDG). This is because cancer cells take in glucose faster than normal tissue. Recent literature shows the&nbsp;<sup>18</sup>F NaF&nbsp;PET&nbsp;scan to be superior to&nbsp;FDG&nbsp;for identifying boney metastases																				
<b>FDG-PET&nbsp;scan</b><div><br></div><div>This reflects your body’s use of {{c1::radioactive glucose (FDG)}}&nbsp;</div>	This is because cancer cells take in glucose faster than normal tissue																				
Recent literature shows the {{c1::<sup>18</sup>F NaF&nbsp;PET}}&nbsp;scan to be superior to&nbsp;FDG-PET&nbsp;for identifying boney metastases	"""per cucurrulo"" although Up to Date shows FDG as the standard<div><br></div><div><h3 style=""display: inline !important;""><a href=""https://www.cedars-sinai.org/programs/imaging-center/clinical-trials/nopr-registry/18f-sodium-fluoride-pet-bone-scan.html"">18F Sodium Fluoride (NaF) PET</a></h3><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.cedars-sinai.org/programs/imaging-center/clinical-trials/nopr-registry/18f-sodium-fluoride-pet-bone-scan.html""><h3><a href=""https://www.cedars-sinai.org/programs/imaging-center/clinical-trials/nopr-registry/18f-sodium-fluoride-pet-bone-scan.html"" style=""font-size: 20px;""></a></h3><h3 style=""display: inline !important;""><strong style=""color: black; font-size: 20px;"">Differences Between FDG-PET and 18F NaF PET</strong></h3></a><div><br></div><div><u>FDG</u>:</div><div>- Glucose based</div><div>- Visualizes soft tissue, i.e. visceral tumors and metastases</div><div>- Good for lytic and trabecular osseous metastases</div><div><br></div><div><u>18F NaF PET</u>:</div><div>- Fluorine based</div><div>- Visualizes osseous tumors and bony metastases better than 99mTc MDP (aka bone scan)</div><div>- Reduced radiation exposure compared to FDG</div><div>- Higher resolution compared to 99mTc MDP bone scan</div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&gt;90% of upper extremity metastases involve the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::humerus}}"																					
<b>Bone Metastasis in the Upper Extremity</b><div><br></div><div><u>majority of symptomatic lesions are from</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Breast cancer}}</div><div>{{c2::MM}}</div><div>{{c3::Renal cancer}}</div>																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Most metastases of the lower extremity involve the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hip}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::femur}}"																					
<b>Bone Metastasis in the Lower Extremity</b><div><br></div><div><u>majority of symptomatic lesions are from</u>:</div><div>Hip: {{c1::prostate}} CA</div><div>Femur: {{c2::Breast}} CA</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-26 at 8.54.46 PM.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the spine is considered stable when&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">only&nbsp;</span>one column is involved}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;unless&nbsp;</span>{{c2::it is the middle column}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the spine is considered unstable when two or more columns are involved or the middle column is involved</span><img src=""9780826134578_fig9_9.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">spine is also considered unstable if &gt;</span>{{c1::20}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;degrees of angulation are present</span>"																					
"<b>Treatment of Bone Metastases</b><div><br></div><div><u>treatment may consist of</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::immobilization (splinting, bracing, orthoses)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::analgesics}}</div><div>{{c1::bone resorption inhibitors (IV bisphosphonates or denosumab)}}<br></div><div>{{c3::radiation (in addition to systemic therapy ie&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Chemotherapy and hormone therapy)</span>}}<br></div><div>{{c4::local procedures (nerve blocks, vertebroplasty)}}<br></div><div>{{c2::surgical intervention (If unstable lesion or refractory pain (rarely in stable lesion)}}</div>"	"<div><div>systemic therapy ie.chemotherapy, are not associated with immediate pain relief</div><div></div><div>thus, palliative local therapy (eg, radiation therapy) is often considered prior to or concurrent with systemic anticancer therapies</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-26 at 9.09.12 PM.png"">"																				
<b>General Indications for Surgical Treatment of Metastatic Bone Disease</b><div><br></div><div>1.<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Intractable pain}}*</div><div>2. {{c2::Impending pathological fracture}}</div><div>3. {{c2::Pathological fracture has occurred}}</div><div>4. {{c3::spine metastases (causing mechanical instability or epidural spinal cord compression)}}</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">*1. for highly selected patients with advanced cancer who present with a bone lesion as the only focus of cancer beyond the primary site,</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">en bloc resection of the metastasis may optimize local tumor control, provide durable pain relief, and possibly prolong patient survival.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">However, curative resection is rare for bone metastasis, except for selected patients with isolated spine or sternal involvement</span></div><div><font color=""#232323""><br></font></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">For patients with an impending or pathologic fracture of a long bone, the goals are: pain, morbidity, and function&nbsp;</span></div><div><br></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">2.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Prophylactic fixation of an impending pathologic fracture may be considered for patients&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">with a high risk for pathologic fracture as assessed by Mirels criteria</span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">3. If a pathologic fracture of a long bone is present, it is often best treated with internal fixation and instrumentation.&nbsp;</span></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">For patients with long bone or spinal metastases, postoperative radiation therapy is generally given after surgical stabilization&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">to promote remineralization and bone healing, alleviate pain, improve functional status,&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Lytic lesion criteria for instability</b>&nbsp;</span><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>(A)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Cortical destruction exceeds 1.3 cm in the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::femoral neck}}</div><div><strong>(B)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Cortical destruction exceeds 2.5 to 3 cm&nbsp;</span>{{c1::elsewhere in the femur}}</div><div><strong>(C)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Lytic lesion exceeds 60% of the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::total bone width (diameter)}}</div><div><strong>(D)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Lytic lesion exceeds 30% to 50% involvement of the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::cortex}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-11-26 at 9.39.27 PM.png""><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig9_10.png""><br></div>"																				
Second-order neurons in the spinal cord are {{c2::wide dynamic range (WDR)::same}} neurons and nociceptive-specific (NS) neurons.<div><br></div><div>{{c2::WDR::same}}: Mostly in laminae {{c1::III}}–{{c1::V}} and receive input from low threshold A-β, nociceptive A-δ, and C fibers&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Responses from&nbsp;WDR&nbsp;are graded, reflecting the type of stimulus fiber.</div>	"NS: I and II only respond to noxious stimuli<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig11_1.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Clinical diagnostic criteria&nbsp;</span><b>of CRPS</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;—&nbsp;The {{c1::Budapest}} consensus criteria (Up to Date)</div><div><br></div><div>the patient must report at least 1 <u>symptom</u> in {{c2::3}} of the following 4 categories<br></div><div><br></div><div>the patient must display at least 1 <u>sign</u> at the time of evaluation in {{c2::2}} of the following 4 categories<br></div>"	<div>●Continuing pain, which is disproportionate to any inciting event.</div><div></div><div><br></div><div>●For the clinical diagnosis of CRPS, the patient must report at least one symptom in three of the following four categories (the more stringent research criteria require at least one symptom in all four categories):</div><div></div><div>•Sensory: Reports of hyperesthesia and/or allodynia</div><div></div><div>•Vasomotor: Reports of temperature asymmetry and/or skin color changes and/or skin color asymmetry</div><div></div><div>•Sudomotor/edema: Reports of edema and/or sweating changes and/or sweating asymmetry</div><div></div><div>•Motor/trophic: Reports of decreased range of motion and/or motor dysfunction (weakness, tremor, dystonia) and/or trophic changes (hair, nail, skin)</div><div></div><div><br></div><div>●For the clinical diagnosis of CRPS, the patient must display at least one sign at the time of evaluation in two of the four following categories (the more stringent research criteria require at least one sign in three of the four categories):</div><div></div><div>•Sensory: Evidence of hyperalgesia (to pinprick) and/or allodynia (to light touch and/or temperature sensation and/or deep somatic pressure and/or joint movement)</div><div></div><div>•Vasomotor: Evidence of temperature asymmetry (&gt;1°C) and/or skin color changes and/or asymmetry</div><div></div><div>•Sudomotor/edema: Evidence of edema and/or sweating changes and/or sweating asymmetry</div><div></div><div>•Motor/trophic: Evidence of decreased range of motion and/or motor dysfunction (weakness, tremor, dystonia) and/or trophic changes (hair, nail, skin)</div><div></div><div><br></div><div>●There is no other diagnosis that better explains the signs and symptoms.</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS)&nbsp;</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">a disorder of the extremities characterized by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::regional}}<font color=""#232323"">&nbsp;pain</font><b style=""""><font color=""#fc0507"">^^</font></b><font color=""#232323""> that is disproportionate in time or degree to the trauma or lesion.&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></div><div><font color=""#232323""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#232323"">abnormal sensory, motor, sudomotor (sweat), vasomotor, and/or trophic(skin) findings.&nbsp;</font></div><div><font color=""#232323""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#232323"">The syndrome shows variable progression over time.</font></div>"	"<b><font color=""#fc0507"">^^</font></b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Regional: pain is not restricted to a specific nerve territory or dermatome and usually has a distal predominance</span>"																				
<b>CRPS diagnostic testing</b><div><br></div><div>a clinical diagnosis that does not require tests, but used with atypical features and to r/o other causes</div><div><br></div><div><div>{{c1::Bone scintigraphy}}&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Plain film radiography}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Autonomic testing}}&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div>	"Bone scintigraphy - can support the diagnosis if there is increased (ipsilateral &gt;1.32 compared with contralateral) radiotracer uptake&nbsp;<div><br><div>Plain radiographs - often demonstrate patchy osteoporosis, but the sensitivity of this finding for CRPS is very low&nbsp;<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>Autonomic tests - resting sweat output (RSO), the resting skin temperature (RST), and the quantitative sudomotor axon reflex test (QSART).&nbsp;</div><div>2°C difference for the affected versus unaffected side was supportive of the diagnosis of CRPS&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Other tests and interventions</span>&nbsp;</div><div>There is no clear role for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography (CT)</div><div>nor is there any role for the response to <u>sympatholysis</u> to confirm the diagnosis of CRPS<br></div>"																				
<u>Extensor Compartments of the Wrist</u>&nbsp;<div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>First compartment</strong>:</div><div>{{c1::Abductor pollicis longus (APL—“All peanut lovers”)}}</div><div>{{c1::Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB—“Eat peanut butter”)}}</div>	"<img src=""7ebab1467e1d372167fc4984e7cb10_gallery.jpeg""><div><img src=""wrist_compartments1500.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<u>Extensor Compartments of the Wrist</u><div><u><br></u><div><strong>Second compartment</strong>:</div><div>{{c1::ECR-L}}</div><div>{{c1::ECR-B}}</div></div>	"<img src=""7ebab1467e1d372167fc4984e7cb10_gallery.jpeg""><div><img src=""wrist_compartments1500.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<u>Extensor Compartments of the Wrist</u><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Third compartment</strong>:</div><div>{{c1::EPL}}</div>	"<img src=""7ebab1467e1d372167fc4984e7cb10_gallery.jpeg""><div><img src=""wrist_compartments1500.jpg""></div>"																				
<u>Extensor Compartments of the Wrist</u><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Fourth compartment</strong>:</div><div>{{c1::EDC}}</div><div>{{c1::Extensor indices proprius (EIP)}}</div>	"<img src=""7ebab1467e1d372167fc4984e7cb10_gallery.jpeg""><div><img src=""wrist_compartments1500.jpg""></div>"																				
<u>Extensor Compartments of the Wrist</u>&nbsp;<div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Fifth compartment</strong>:</div><div>{{c1::EDM}}</div>	"<img src=""7ebab1467e1d372167fc4984e7cb10_gallery.jpeg""><div><img src=""wrist_compartments1500.jpg""></div>"																				
<u>Extensor Compartments of the Wrist</u><div><u><br></u><div><strong>Sixth compartment</strong>:</div><div>{{c1::ECU}}</div></div>	"<img src=""7ebab1467e1d372167fc4984e7cb10_gallery.jpeg""><div><img src=""wrist_compartments1500.jpg""></div>"

<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Primary osteoarthritis in the wrist is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::rare::<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">common/</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">rare</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>"	"more likely&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Secondary osteoarthritis resulting from post-traumatic
conditions,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">as can be seen after distal radius fractures, carpal fractures, and carpal instability&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>

<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">carpal instability: disruption of
the interosseous ligament between the scaphoid and lunate&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">other rare cuases include rheum or&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">idiopathic
osteonecrosis of the lunate (Kienböck disease) and the
scaphoid (Preiser disease)&nbsp;</span></div>

<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">wrist OA rates are significantly lower than
the rates of thumb basal joint osteoarthritis (30%), distal
interphalangeal joint arthritis (</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">28%-35%)&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-04 at 10.49.46 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>non union (fracture)</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-04 at 10.50.07 AM.png""><br></div><div>SL dissociation&nbsp;</div>

<div>
<div><div>{{c1::Watson::physical exam}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;test evaluates for&nbsp;</span>{{c2::scapho-lunate instability (ligament rupture)}}</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<img src=""urncambridge.orgidbinary20220412103228452-0533978110885929579670fig4_7.png"">"																				
<b>wrist OA&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>treatment</u><div>analgesics, HEP</div><div>{{c2::wrist cock up splint (or custom splints)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::radiocarpal joint injection::procedure}}</div></div><div>surgery&nbsp;</div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">wrist splint with a volar metal stabilizing bar
(<u>cock-up splint</u>) can be a small inconvenience;&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">however,
by virtue of immobilizing the wrist, it can provide great
symptom relief during daily activities.&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Surgical procedures for osteoarthritis can be divided into
motion-sparing procedures and fusions (arthrodesis)&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Motion-sparing procedures include proximal row carpec-
tomy, total wrist arthroplasty, and limited intercarpal fusions
with scaphoid excision.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screenshot-2022-11-30-at-2.25.53-PM.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-12 at 4.00.35 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""mus-arthrocentesis-wrist.gif""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Heberden’s nodules involve the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">distal interphalangeal (</span>DIP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}} joint<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""h9991469_003-bf8dc2244554e0efde74d6a0ffcb20e809c4bfd5.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Bouchard’s nodules involve the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">proximal interphalangeal (</span>PIP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;joint</span>"	"<img src=""h9991469_003-bf8dc2244554e0efde74d6a0ffcb20e809c4bfd5.jpg"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::Swan neck deformity}}:</b><div>{{c4::lax volar plate}} and {{c4::imbalance of forces}} about the DIP joint&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">with a&nbsp;</span>{{c3::dorsal}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;migration of the&nbsp;</span>{{c3::lateral bands}}<br></div><div>clinically appears as {{c2::Flexion}} at the&nbsp;DIP&nbsp;joint</div>"	"<div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">[caused by a derangement in the&nbsp;</span>extensor mechanism&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(aka t</span>riangular ligament)<font color=""#0d1113"">] cuccurrolo&nbsp;</font><br></div><div><font color=""#0d1113"">""conflict, seems like this could cause boutenier""&nbsp;</font></div></div><div><br></div><div>Caused by shortening and contracture of the intrinsic muscles of the hand</div><div><img src=""Swan-neck-deformity-300x174.png""><br></div><div><img src=""swan+neck+2.jpg""></div><div><b><u>PATHOANATOMY</u></b></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><b><u>lax volar plate</u></b></span>&nbsp;</div><div>allows hyperextension of PIP</div><div>- trauma</div><div>- generalized ligament laxity</div><div>- rheumatoid arthritis</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><b><u>imbalance of forces on the PIP joint</u></b></span>&nbsp;</div><div>PIP extension forces that is greater than the PIP flexion force</div><div>-&nbsp;mallet injury</div><div>- FDS rupture</div><div>- intrinsic contracture</div><div>- MCP joint volar subluxation (RA)</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-04 at 11.27.49 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><b>{{c1::Boutonnière deformity}}:</b><br></div><div><div>Caused by tearing of the {{c2::extensor hood}} aka {{c2::central slip}}</div><div>clinicaly appears as {{c3::Hyperextension}} of the&nbsp;DIP&nbsp;joint</div></div>	"<div>Hyperextension at the&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joint</div><div>Flexion at the&nbsp;PIP&nbsp;joint</div><div>Hyperextension of the&nbsp;DIP&nbsp;joint</div><div><img src=""67-central-slip.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""central-slip-9-1.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Anatomy-of-the-Extensor-Apparatus-of-the-Hand.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-04 at 11.27.49 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>1st CMC joint arthritis treatment&nbsp;</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::(short) thumb spica splint}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>{{c2::CMC joint injection}}<br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">operative&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-7271438523c667db4d27e7dc2611d2abd13907a1.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-04 at 11.44.30 AM.png""><b><u><br></u></b></div><b><u>Operative</u></b><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong><strong><strong><br></strong></strong></strong></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong><strong><strong>CMC arthroscopic debridement</strong></strong></strong></strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">indications</span></div><div>early stages of disease</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong><br></strong></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong>1st metacarpal&nbsp;<strong><strong>osteotomy</strong></strong>&nbsp;</strong></strong></div><div>indications</div><div>- early Stage I-II disease</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong><br></strong></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><strong>trapeziectomy +/- ligament reconstruction&nbsp;</strong></strong></div><div>indications</div><div>- Stage I-IV disease</div><div>multiple techniques with none showing clear benefit over the others</div><div><b><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></b></div><div><b><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">CMC arthrodesis</span>&nbsp;</b></div><div>indications</div><div>- Stage II-III disease in&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">young male heavy laborers</span>&nbsp;</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">CMC denervation</strong></div><div>indications</div><div>- Stage I-IV disease</div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></strong></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">CMC prosthetic arthroplasty</strong></div><div>indications</div><div>- not recommended</div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><b>de Quervain tenosynovitis&nbsp;</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>treatment</u></span></div><div>{{c1::1st dorsal compartment injection (1st line)}}<br></div><div>{{c2::thumb spica splint}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;aka&nbsp;</span>{{c2::long opponens orthosis}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;+/- NSAID's</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">surgery&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">It is essential that corticosteroid enter the compartment of
both the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
for the injection to be effective.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">with the success of
injections, surgery is reserved for those whose injection therapy
fails</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Surgery involves <b>release of the extensor retinaculum</b>, and both open and endoscopic techniques can be used.</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-04 at 12.07.25 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;<br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-04 at 11.59.04 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">de Quervain tenosynovitis</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>general</u></span></div><div>Repetitive or direct trauma to the sheath of the&nbsp;{{c1::EPB}}&nbsp;and&nbsp;{{c1::APL}}&nbsp;tendons, causing inflammation</div>"	"<img src=""C73-FF1.gif"">"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">de Quervain tenosynovitis&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Pain and tenderness on the {{c1::radial}} side of the wrist associated with movement</div><div>Edema and crepitus may also be present<div><br></div><div><u>Physical Examination</u></div><div>{{c2::Finkelstein’s}} test&nbsp;</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">The Eichhoff test is sometimes
erroneously called the Finkelstein test</span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_50.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;<br></span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<div><b>Ganglion Cyst</b></div><div><br></div><u>General</u><div>{{c1::Synovial}} fluid-filled cystic structure that arises from the {{c1::synovial sheath of the joint space::similar/same}}**</div>	"**<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">The ganglion is a benign, <b>mucin-filled cyst</b> found in
relation to a joint, ligament, or tendon. It is typically filled
from the joint through a tortuous duct or “stalk” that func-
tions as a valve directing the flow of fluid. The mucin itself
contains high concentrations of hyaluronic acid as well as
glucosamine, albumin, and globulin [</span><span style=""color: rgb(44, 153, 191);"">1</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">]. When it is used to
describe ganglia, the term </span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>synovial cyst </u></span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>is actually a mis-
nomer</u> because ganglion cysts do not contain synovial fluid
and are not true cysts lined by epithelium but rather by flat
cells. The etiology of ganglia remains a mystery, although
many think that ligamentous degeneration or trauma plays
an important role&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_51.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<b>ganglion cyst&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Small smooth mass on the dorsal or volar aspect of the wrist&nbsp;</div><div>occurs on the dorsal aspect in 60% of cases</div><div>Pain may occur with {{c1::ranging the wrist (or slight pressure)}}</div>	"<div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">The combination of clinical presentation, transillumination, ultrasonography, and MRI&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">are generally sufficient to distinguish between a benign ganglion cyst&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">and other potentially neoplastic soft tissue masses.&nbsp;</span></div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">However, the presence of <u>certain clinical features</u> such as&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">rapid growth,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">pain at rest,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">functional impairment,</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">atypical location (eg, proximal or distal to the wrist rather than overlying the wrist)&nbsp;</span></div><div><font color=""#fc0006"">should prompt consideration for a surgical biopsy</font><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><u>work up</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">- ultrasound should show well demarcated thick wall</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">- xray to r/o bone tumor&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">- MRI for soft tissue tumor&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(53, 53, 53); font-weight: 700;"">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(53, 53, 53); font-weight: 700;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Tenosynovial giant cell tumor</span>&nbsp;—&nbsp;A tenosynovial giant cell tumor is a firm, fixed swelling that generally develops on the flexor surfaces of the tendons of the hands. It can be distinguished from ganglion cysts in that it is a fixed, enlarging mass that does not transilluminate (<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/image?imageKey=RHEUM%2F101782&amp;topicKey=RHEUM%2F7761&amp;search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;rank=1%7E150&amp;source=see_link"">picture 3</a>).</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Epidermoid cysts</span>&nbsp;—&nbsp;Epidermoid cysts, also called epidermal cysts or epidermal inclusion cysts, are small, hard, pearl-like cysts or nodules, often with a central punctum, that is freely mobile on palpation. They tend to disappear spontaneously over time. The most common locations are the volar aspect of the distal phalanx of the index or middle finger or are within the interdigital webs. They are rarely larger than 1 centimeter and do&nbsp;<strong>not</strong>&nbsp;transilluminate. (See&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/overview-of-benign-lesions-of-the-skin?sectionName=Epidermoid%20cyst&amp;search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;topicRef=7761&amp;anchor=H1101420445&amp;source=see_link#H1101420445"">""Overview of benign lesions of the skin"", section on 'Epidermoid cyst'</a>.)</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Lipoma</span>&nbsp;—&nbsp;Lipomas of the hand and wrist may present as a soft, painless slow-growing mobile nodule. Unlike ganglion cysts, lipomas do not transilluminate. (See&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/overview-of-benign-lesions-of-the-skin?sectionName=Lipoma&amp;search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;topicRef=7761&amp;anchor=H17&amp;source=see_link#H17"">""Overview of benign lesions of the skin"", section on 'Lipoma'</a>.)</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Infectious tenosynovitis</span>&nbsp;—&nbsp;Infectious tenosynovitis can occur in any joint, but occurs most frequently in the hands and wrist. Infectious tenosynovitis is characterized by diffuse swelling and tenderness that tracks along the tendon in a longitudinal fashion, and should be suspected in the setting of a preceding puncture or bite wound. Infection of the hand requires immediate surgical consultation for possible exploration and drainage. (See&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/infectious-tenosynovitis?search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;topicRef=7761&amp;source=see_link"">""Infectious tenosynovitis""</a>.)</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Rheumatoid nodules</span>&nbsp;—&nbsp;Rheumatoid nodules are firm, nontender, flesh-colored, subcutaneous lesions that occur in approximately 20 percent of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid nodules may be fixed or movable and when present on the hand or wrist, are usually on the extensor surface. (See&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/rheumatoid-nodules?search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;topicRef=7761&amp;source=see_link"">""Rheumatoid nodules""</a>.)</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Tendinous xanthoma</span>&nbsp;—&nbsp;These pinkish, yellow papules may be the first evidence of hyperlipidemia. Usually asymptomatic and bilateral, they may occur abruptly (eruptive xanthomas) over pressure points and extensor surfaces or gradually over Achilles, patellar, and digital extensor tendons. Often, the patient pays no attention to them; the clinician may be the first to realize their significance. (See&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/hypertriglyceridemia-in-adults-management?search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;topicRef=7761&amp;source=see_link"">""Hypertriglyceridemia in adults: Management""</a>.)</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Tophus</span>&nbsp;—&nbsp;Uric acid deposits can produce firm subcutaneous nodules in patients with gout. They typically originate at the joint margin and may be yellow with overlying erythema when close to the surface. Although tophi can occur at any site, they can be observed in the hands and wrist (<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/image?imageKey=SURG%2F74050&amp;topicKey=RHEUM%2F7761&amp;search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;rank=1%7E150&amp;source=see_link"">picture 4</a>). Tophi from chronic tophaceous gout are typically not painful or tender. (See&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/clinical-manifestations-and-diagnosis-of-gout?search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;topicRef=7761&amp;source=see_link"">""Clinical manifestations and diagnosis of gout""</a>.)</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Synovial sarcoma</span>&nbsp;—&nbsp;A synovial sarcoma is a rare cause of a soft tissue mass around a joint. It can arise at any age and anatomic area but tends to favor the distal extremities in young adults. Larger size of the tumor (&gt;5 cm) is associated with a greater risk for metastases and local recurrence. Synovial sarcoma is a translocation-associated soft tissue malignancy. The translocation t(X;18) has been identified in synovial sarcoma only, and its sensitivity and specificity have been both established. In certain difficult cases, the detection of this fusion event (by RT-PCR or cytogenetic studies) has been instrumental to the correct diagnosis [<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/ganglion-cysts-of-the-wrist-and-hand/abstract/15"">15</a>]. (See&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.uptodate.com/contents/clinical-presentation-histopathology-diagnostic-evaluation-and-staging-of-soft-tissue-sarcoma?search=ganglion%20cyst&amp;topicRef=7761&amp;source=see_link"">""Clinical presentation, histopathology, diagnostic evaluation, and staging of soft tissue sarcoma""</a>.)</div></div></div>"																				
<b>ganglion cyst&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><u>Treatment</u><div>{{c1::Immobilization}}</div><div>{{c2::Aspiration of the cyst (90% recurrence)}}</div><div>{{c2::Surgical removal if needed (10% recurrence)}}</div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A cock-up wrist
splint is prescribed for carpometacarpal and dorsal and volar wrist ganglia,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">whereas a radial gutter splint is prescribed
for ganglia associated with de Quervain tenosynovitis.&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"
