<div><b>{{c1::Kienböck’s disease}}:</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><u>General</u><br></div><div><br></div><div>Idiopathic loss of blood supply to the {{c3::lunate}} bone, which causes&nbsp;AVN&nbsp;(osteonecrosis) of the bone</div><div><br></div><div>Thought to be caused by {{c2::vascular impairment}} and/or {{c2::repeated trauma (repeated stress or fracture)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Bone collapse results in degenerative changes at the wrist.</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_52.png"">"																				
<b>Kienböck’s disease (lunate osteonecrosis)</b><div><br></div><div><u>RISK FACTORS (anatomic)</u></div><div>{{c1::Poor vascular supply to the area}}</div><div>{{c2::Short ulnar variance (found in 20% of nl wrists)}}</div>	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">dominant hand of men in the age
group of 20 to 40 years&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Many of these patients are manual
laborers who report a history of a major or repetitive minor
injury.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Associations w/ corticosteroid use, cerebral palsy, systemic lupus erythematosus, sickle cell disease, gout, and strep infection&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><img src=""817990"">"																				
<b>Kienböck’s disease (lunate osteonecrosis)</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>{{c1::Ulnar}}-sided pain, stiffness, and swelling over the {{c1::dorsal}} aspect of the wrist directly over the lunate</div><div><br></div><div><u>Physical Examination</u></div><div>{{c2::decreased ROM (flexion and extension)}}</div><div>Reduced grip strength (due to pain)<br></div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Presenting symptoms include chronic wrist pain, decreased
range of motion, and weakness [</span><span style=""color: rgb(44, 153, 191);"">5</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">].&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">The pain is usually deep
within the wrist, although the patient often points to the
dorsum of the wrist,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">aggravated by activity.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Some
patients complain of a pressure-like pain that may awaken
them.&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""wrist_kienbocks_disease_intro01.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>Kienböck’s disease</b><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>{{c1::Plain films: May see a compression fracture, flattening, or sclerosis}}</div><div>{{c1::Bone scan: Increased uptake of the lunate}}</div><div>{{c1::MRI: Increased signal intensity on T2, decreased on T1}}</div>	"<div>MRI replaced bone scan</div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-02-05 at 1.45.17 PM.png"">"																				
<b>Kienböck’s disease</b><div><br></div><div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::Orthopedic referral}}</div></div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Without surgery,
progressive radiographic collapse and radiographic arthritis
almost invariably occur</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Many clinicians prefer to begin with symptomatic treatment.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Depending on the situation, this may involve a splint
and activity modification or a short arm cast.</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;<br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Rehabilitaiton does not play a major role.</span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>scaphoid fractures</b></span><div><br></div><div>{{c2::one-third::fraction}} develop osteonecrosis of the bone secondary to its blood supply</div><div><br></div><div>the {{c1::middle (waist)}} and {{c1::proximal}} portion of the bone have a large nonunion rate&nbsp;</div>"	"<div>The majority of the blood supply is to the distal one-third of the bone</div><div><img src=""scaphoid-fracture.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>scaphoid fractures</b></span><div><br></div><div>the most common location is the {{c1::waist}} fracture</div>"	"<div>Waist (65%)<br></div><div>Tubercle (2%)</div><div>Distal pole (10%)</div><div>Proximal pole (15%)</div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_53.png"">"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">scaphoid fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Swelling and tenderness in the areas of the {{c1::anatomical snuff box}}</div><div>worsened with&nbsp;ROM, especially in {{c2::extension}} and {{c2::radial deviation}}</div><div>Tenderness to palpation over the {{c3::tuberosity of the scaphoid}}<br></div>"	"tuberosity of the scaphoid<div><img src=""volarpain.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">scaphoid fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u><br></u></b></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Plain films: Posterior-anterior (PA) and oblique view of the wrist in {{c1::ulnar deviation}}</div><div>{{c2::Repeat in 2 weeks}} if no fracture is seen initially</div>"	"<div>Repeat films at 4 to 6 weeks if still symptomatic.</div><div><br></div><div>CT scan can be done if there is a question of fracture.</div><div><br></div><div>Bone scan can be positive as early as 24 hours after injury.</div><div><br></div><div>MRI most sensitive for fracture and AVN</div><div><img src=""xray.jpg""><img src=""scaphoidview.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">scaphoid fractures</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><font color=""#333333"">FOSH and TTP over snuff box</font></div><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><u>Initital Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::thumb spica cast (for 10 to 14 days and repeat the radiographs)}}</div>"	"A fracture may or may not be visualized on initial x-ray imaging.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Therefore, <font color=""#fc0507"">a patient with tenderness in the area of the anatomical snuff box has a fracture until proven otherwise</font>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>cast them and repeat imaging in 2-3 weeks</div><div><br><div>The location of the fracture (10% proximal pole, 70% waist, 20% distal pole), stability of fracture, and the timing of injury will dictate treatment.<br></div><div><br></div><div><div><u>On average</u></div><div>Distal pole fractures take 8 weeks to heal.</div><div>Waist (middle portion) fractures (most common) take 3 months to heal.</div><div>Proximal pole fractures take 4 months or longer to heal.</div></div></div><div><img src=""OrthoWristThumbSpicaCast.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>scaphoid fracture</b><div><br></div><div><div><u>Conservative treatment</u></div><div>immobilization of the wrist in a {{c2::long thumb spica cast}} for {{c1::6}} weeks with the wrist in a neutral position</div><div>then, change to a {{c2::short thumb spica cast}} if the plain films show proper healing</div><div><br></div><div>If poor healing occurs at this time, surgical stabilization may be indicated</div></div>	"<div><u>On average</u></div><div>Distal pole fractures take 8 weeks to heal.</div><div>Waist (middle portion) fractures (most common) take 3 months to heal.</div><div>Proximal pole fractures take 4 months or longer to heal.</div><div><img src=""thumb.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>scaphoid fracture</b><div><br></div><div><div><div><u>surgical treatment:</u></div><div>Fractures of the {{c1::proximal pole}}</div><div>{{c2::displaced (&gt;1 mm)}} fractures&nbsp;</div><div>fractures with {{c3::delayed presentation (&lt;2–3 weeks to diagnose)}}&nbsp;</div></div></div>	"<div><div>should be referred to orthopedics due to the high risk of&nbsp;AVN.</div><div><br></div></div><div><div>and non-displaced waist fracturesto allow decreased time to union, faster return to work/sport (ortho bullet)</div></div><div><img src=""screw.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>fractures of the hook of the hamate</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>etiology</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">direct trauma to the hamate bone on the palmar surface of the wrist/hand</span></div><div>{{c2::axial loading}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;through the 4th or 5th metacarpal</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">avulsion from shear forces from adjacent/attached tendons during forceful&nbsp;</span>{{c1::twisting}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;motion of the wrist</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">sports activities commonly related to this injury mechanism include&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">racquet-related sports, baseball, and golf; with injurious forces occurring at end swing</span></div><div><img src=""07b_Figure_32.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hamate Fractures&nbsp;</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Ulnar and palmar wrist pain with {{c1::racquet swing::sport}}&nbsp;</div><div>may lead to accompanying {{c2::neuropathic sx's (paresthesias or weakness in ulnar distributions)::category}}</div><div>Provocative maneuver: resisted {{c3::finger flexion}} with the wrist held in ulnar deviation&nbsp;</div></div>"	<div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>X-rays with&nbsp;PA, lateral, carpal tunnel, and 45 degrees supinated oblique views</div><div>CT may be needed for fractures at the base of the hook</div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Nondisplaced body fractures: 4 to 6 weeks short arm cast</div><div>Displaced body fractures require surgical referral</div><div>Acute hook fractures: 50% heal after prolonged casting (6 weeks to 4 months).</div><div>Most acute hook fractures should have adequate vascular supply to heal if immobilized within the first week.</div><div>Cast should maintain slight wrist flexion and slight&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;flexion to reduce shear forces from fourth and fifth digit flexor tendons.</div><div>Injuries older than 2 weeks may require excision.</div><div>Persistent numbness of ulnar digits requires electrodiagnostic evaluation</div>																				
<b>trapezium fractures</b><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Body and trapeziometacarpal fractures present as tenderness of the dorsal wrist {{c1::proximal}} to the thumb&nbsp;CMC&nbsp;joint</div><div>Trapezial ridge fractures present as a tender point {{c1::distal}} to the scaphoid tuberosity.</div>	<div><u>General</u></div><div>Isolated fractures are rare.</div><div>May occur when the <b>base of the thumb metacarpal is forced by axial load i</b>nto the trapezium</div><div>Can occur also as an avulsion fracture.<div><br></div><div><u>TYPES</u></div><div>Body</div><div>Trapeziometacarpal</div><div>Trapezial ridge</div></div><div>Clinical Features</div><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>X-rays with&nbsp;PA, lateral, oblique, carpal tunnel,&nbsp;</div><div><b>Bett’s views</b> (thumb extended and abducted, wrist slightly pronated, beam centered on the scaphotrapeziotrapezium area)</div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Nondisplaced body, proximal trapezial ridge fractures, and trapeziometacarpal fractures require a <b>short arm thumb spica cast for 4 weeks</b>.</div><div>Displaced body and distal trapezial ridge fractures require surgical referral.</div>																				
{{c1::Colles’}} fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with <b>dorsal</b> displacement and angulation<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Smith’s}} fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with <b>volar</b> displacement and angulation</div>	"<div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Acute pain, swelling at the wrist, usually after a fall on an outstretched arm</div><div><br></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>AP&nbsp;and lateral plain films of the wrist and hand</div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Orthopedic referral for closed reduction depending on the location, degree of displacement, and reproducibility</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_55.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Dupuytren’s contracture</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>thickening and contraction of the palmar fascia due to {{c1::fibrous proliferation::patho phys}}</div><div>genetic component primarily in people of Northern European descent ""Viking disease""</div><div>Commonly associated with DM, {{c2::alcoholism}}, {{c3::epileptics (AED’s)}}, and pulmonary tuberculosis (TB)</div><div>Typically seen in men &gt;40 years old</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_62.png"">"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Dupuytren’s contracture</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>{{c1::Painless::painful/painless}} nodules in the distal palmar crease</div><div>involved finger is drawn into flexion as the nodules thicken and contract.</div><div>Flexion is commonly seen at the&nbsp;{{c2::MCP}}&nbsp;joint involving the {{c2::fourth digit}} finger&nbsp;</div>"	"These nodules are initially nontender and may become tender as the disease progresses<div><img src=""dupuytrens_1280.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Dupuytren’s contracture</b><div><font color=""#333333""><b><br></b></font><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::rehabilitative techniques}} are of little to no value<br></div><div>{{c2::collagenase injections}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Surgical release}} if severe and affects function</div></div>"	"<font color=""#fc0507"">rehabilitation treatments <u>alone</u> are of no use</font><div><b>No benefit: US, splinting, massage, continuous traction, PT, corticosteroid injections</b><br><div>any rehab efforts are use pre/post operatively&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div><u>diagnosis</u> is clinical</div><div>no tests are indicated&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""ROH-Birmingham_Xiapex-Injection_Mark-Brewster_03.11.2017-8-e1536096847706-1160x766.jpg"">&nbsp;</div></div></div>"																				
{{c1::stenosing tenosynovitis}} aka <b>trigger finger</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>repetitive trauma causes an inflammatory process to the {{c2::flexor tendon sheath}} of the digits</div><div>a nodule forms, resulting in abnormal gliding through the {{c3::A1}} pulley system</div><div>commonly associated with: repetitive trauma,&nbsp;{{c4::DM}},&nbsp;RA, gout</div><div>Seen in persons &gt;40 years old</div>	"<div>as the digit flexes, the nodule passes under the pulley system and gets caught on the narrow annular sheath<br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_63.png"">"																				
<b>trigger finger</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>painful {{c1::catching / locking}} with finger flexion and/or extension</div><div>nodule may be {{c2::tender to palpation}} on exam</div>	"most often the thumb or ring finger&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600; color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Differential Diagnosis
</span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Dupuytren disease<br>
Ganglion of the tendon sheath (retinacular cyst)<br>
Tumor of the tendon sheath (giant cell tumor or space-occupying&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">lesion, such as an amyloidosis)&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Rheumatoid arthritis&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-02 at 9.33.54 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>trigger finger</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">1st line</span>: {{c1::Corticosteroid injection}}, {{c1::immobilization by splinting}},&nbsp;and NSAIDs</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Surgical</span>: Surgical release if {{c2::conservative treatment fails}}</div>"	"<div><u>non-invasive</u></div>supervised therapy is not typically indicated<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Noninvasive measures generally involve splinting of the
</span><font color=""#fc0006"">metacarpophalangeal joint</font><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""> at 10 to 15 degrees of flexion&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">with the <u>proximal interphalangeal and distal interphalangeal
joints free</u>, for up to 6 weeks continuously&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">also helps with continued work etc.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>procedures</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">post injection would use a splint and rec rest for 1 week</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">can perform multiple injections per year&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">may inject even if no locking on exam, if the story fits&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><u>surgery</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">refractory cases with multiple recurrence each year</span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Individuals
with diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, multiple joint involvement, and younger age at onset are more likely to require
surgery&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""paste-e97e828bcd7f982f046de464c360977c49f3982a.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>blocking one of MCP &gt; DIP &gt; PIP any of which will help&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""hq720.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-02 at 9.53.43 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-02 at 9.51.16 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Digital&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Ligamenus Injury (</b></span>PIP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and&nbsp;</span>DIP joints)<br></div><div><br></div><u>General</u><div>Involve the {{c1::Collaterals}} and {{c1::volar plate}}</div><div>Injury may result in a partial tear (sprain) or complete dislocation</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><b>Volar plate:</b>&nbsp;</span>A thick ligament on the underside of the middle finger joint<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">- It keeps the finger from hyperextending back.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">- Hyperextension with dorsal dislocation, which is usually reducible</span><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""#202124""><br></font><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><b>Collateral ligaments:</b>&nbsp;2 ligaments, 1 on each side of the joint.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">- They prevent the finger from hyperextending sideways.</span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">-&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Valgus or varus stress with the finger in an extended position</span></div><div><img src=""volar-plate-04.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Digital&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Ligamenus</b>&nbsp;(</span>PIP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and&nbsp;</span>DIP joints)<div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>History of trauma to the finger with an immediate {{c1::obvious deformity}}</div><div>{{c2::Local tenderness to palpation}} over the involved area with swelling of the joint</div><div>{{c3::assess the stability}} of the joint on exam</div>"	"assess the stability of the joint by applying a stress to the medial and lateral aspect<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_64.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Digital Ligamenus Injury</b>&nbsp;(</span>PIP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and&nbsp;</span>DIP joints)<div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Reduce the joint by stabilizing the proximal end and applying a distal traction.</div><div>{{c1::Buddy splinting}} of the finger should be done for approximately {{c2::2 weeks}}</div><div>{{c3::Surgical}}: Complex lesions</div></div>"	"<div>may immobilize with a splint for a few days followed by buddy taping</div><div>3 weeks for a sprain</div><div>6 weeks for a complete tear</div><div>followed by ROM and +/- PT</div><div><img src=""volar-plate-avulsion-injury-2641107-1-640x294.webp"">&nbsp;</div><img src=""1-84a0fe71f927e35e2bf0977837183c5b80a5154c.jpg"">"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Digital&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Ligamenus Injury </b>(</span>PIP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and&nbsp;</span>DIP joints)<div><br></div><div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>AP&nbsp;and lateral Xray views</div></div><div>to rule out {{c1::fracture}} and&nbsp;</div><div>ensure proper {{c1::reduction}} of the joint</div>"	"<div>MRI: indicated if equivocal physical exam findings</div><div><img src=""mri collateral lig.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>1st digit UCL sprain aka&nbsp;{{c1::skier's thumb}}&nbsp;</b><br><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>Mechanism of injury is a forceful {{c2::radial}} deviation of the proximal phalanx at the&nbsp;{{c1::MCP::same}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Stener’s}} lesion: entrapment of the adductor aponeurosis between the ruptured ligament and {{c1::MCP::same}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>can also arise from chronic laxity aka game keepr's thumb</div><div>stenr's occurs in complete tears and impairs healing&nbsp;</div><img src=""skiers-thumb-graphic1.jpg""><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Martin-Langer-5/publication/281712189_Steners_lesion_Thumb_ulnar_collateral_ligament/data/55f56a1a08ae7a10cf8a00e2/Stener-s-lesion-Thumb-ulnar-collateral-ligament.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>1st digit UCL sprain aka skier's thumb</b><div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>{{c1::Instability}} of the&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joint</div><div>Prior to stress examination of the joint, {{c2::x-ray}} should be performed</div></div>	<div>likely swelling, brusing, and pain&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>XRAY should be obtained to rule out non-displaced avulsion fracture.																				
"<b>1st digit UCL sprain aka skier's thumb</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u style="""">physical examination</u></div><div>position the joint in approximately {{c1::30}} degrees of {{c1::flexion}}</div><div>a {{c2::radial}} deviation force is then applied distally to stress the&nbsp;UCL<b><br></b></div><div>{{c3::Palpation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;of MCP identify Stener’s lesion</span><br></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">To avoid a false interpretation, the examiner must prevent
MCP rotation by grasping the thumb proximal to the joint.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">If
there is more than 30 degrees of laxity (or 15 degrees more
laxity than on the noninjured side), rupture of the proper
collateral ligament is likely.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">The thumb is then positioned in
extension for repeated valgus stress testing.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">If valgus laxity
is less than 30 degrees (or 15 degrees less than on the non-
injured side), the accessory collateral ligament is intact.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">If
valgus laxity is greater than 30 degrees (or 15 degrees more
than on the noninjured side), the accessory collateral ligament is also ruptured&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-16 at 8.15.09 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>Skier's thumb&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A plain radiograph is essential to rule out an avul-
sion fracture&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div>+/- {{c1::Stress radiograph}} should be done comparing both hands</div><div>radial deviation &gt;{{c2::40}} degrees in extension and &gt;20 degrees in flexion on plain films</div><div>If radiographs are equivocal, one can obtain&nbsp;MRI&nbsp;although it is not needed,</div><div>{{c3::US}} for evaluation is accurate in full thickness tear&nbsp;</div></div>"	"<div>Surgical referral should be considered above these stress thresholds of deviation<br></div><img src=""840761.png"">"																				
<b>Skier's thumb&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Grade 1: {{c1::taping}} during activity&nbsp;</div><div>Grade 2: {{c1::thumb spica cast}} for 4 to 6 weeks, followed by splinting&nbsp;</div><div>Grade 3: {{c1::operative}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>the cast may extend beyond the wrist for greater stability</div><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">grade 2 Injuries involving nondisplaced
or small avulsion fractures can also be managed nonsurgically&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- but may require
a longer course of immobilization&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>Return to play or full activity when thumb is painless, with firm end point on radial deviation stress and at least 80% recovery of&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;and pinch strength</div><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>Stener’s lesion,&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Grade II injuries resulting in severe instability, displaced fractures, or intra-articular
fragments are also surgical candidates&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><br></div><div><u>Grade I injury</u>: Pain and no increased motion</div><div><u>Grade II injury</u>: Increased opening with pain on stressing</div><div><u>Grade III injury</u>: No pain, continued motion while stressing</div>
</div>
</div></div><div><img src=""OrthoWristThumbSpicaCast.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>flexor/extensor tendon injuries (hand)</b><div><br></div><div><u>imaging</u>&nbsp;</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::AP and lateral plain radiographs}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Ultrasonography}} is an alternative to magnetic resonance imaging&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""Xray - lateral_moved.jpg""><div>dislocation, avulsion fracture, foreign body retention, air in the soft tissues&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""IMG-0001-00001_1__big_gallery.jpeg""><br></div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs43055-019-0110-z/MediaObjects/43055_2019_110_Fig3_HTML.png""><br></div><div><img src=""1012070192-d33f4af48559656e7591d28a39ea6f302ec78463953a195f709f77d1dbe6d5d5-d_840.jpg""><br></div>"																				
management of extensor tendon injuries depends largely on the {{c1::zone of injury}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-17 at 10.18.40 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-17 at 10.21.37 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>extensor tendon injuries</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>treatment</u></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>conservative {{c1::splinting}} can be attempted
for {{c2::closed}} {{c3::zone I}} and {{c3::zone II}} extensor tendon injuries&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>treatment protocols for extensor tendon injuries vary by
zone, mechanism, and time elapsed since the injury</div><div><br></div><div>If the
disruption of the extensor mechanism is due to a laceration,
crush injury, burn, or <b>bite</b>, surgical referral is warranted.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Open injuries</b> require surgery (if repair is not immediate, antibiotics initiated, irrigated, skin suturing)</div><div>laceration <b>&gt; 50% of tendon width</b> in all zones (ortho bullets)??</div><div><br></div>
</div>
</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-17 at 10.18.40 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-17 at 10.21.37 AM.png""></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Mallet finger:</b> (Zone 1 and Zone 2 extensor tendon injury managed similarly)</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::stack splint::specific name}} with the DIP&nbsp;in {{c2::full extension}} for 6 (to 8) weeks&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>followed by {{c3::ROM}} with {{c3::night splinting}} for additional 2 (to 4) weeks<br></div><div>Surgical repair reserved for poor healing or if an avulsed fragment involves greater than {{c4::1/3::fraction}} of the joint<br></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>- splint should be worn continuously, except during hygiene&nbsp;</div><div>- Maintaining the&nbsp;DIP&nbsp;in extension at all times is essential<br></div><div>- Weekly visits to assess full finger flexion should be done<br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>- If no extensor lag is identified, initiate PROM 10
repetitions hourly&nbsp;</div><div>- then 2 more weeks of splint at night and during exercise</div><div>- after 8 weeks discontinue / wean from splint and exercises progress to active extension&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_68.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-17 at 10.57.38 AM.png""><br></div><div><br></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"{{c1::Mallet finger}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Rupture of the extensor tendon at its insertion (aka&nbsp;</span>Zone 1<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;extensor tendon injury)</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_67.png"">"																				
"Mallet finger<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Rupture of the extensor tendon at its insertion (aka&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Zone 1}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;extensor tendon injury)</span>"	"<img src=""extensor tendons.jpg"">"																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Zone III extensor tendon injuries can result in a {{c1::boutonnière}} deformity&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>If the lateral
bands slip volarly,&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><br></div>injury at the insertion (DIP and volar plate laxity cuases the swan neck)<div><img src=""CentralSlipExtensorTendon-sm.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Zone III extensor tendon injury</b>&nbsp;aka boutonnière deformity<div><br></div><div>the {{c1::Elson's::eponym}} test is a physical examination maneveur used to assess the integrity of the {{c2::central slip}}</div>	"<div><b>The Elson’s</b> test essentially isolates the central band/slip of the extensor tendon complex [1].</div><div>1. Position the patient’s PIP in 90-degrees flexion. This normally keeps the central band taut and the lateral bands loose.</div><div>2. Ask the patient to extend the PIP, while the provider applies a counterforce at the middle phalanx.</div><div>3. <u>NORMAL</u> Elson’s test: Results in active extension of the PIP joint and a floppy DIP.</div><div>4. <font color=""#fc0507"">ABNORMAL</font> Elson’s test: Results in no active extension of the PIP joint and a slightly extended, taut DIP.</div><div><img src=""Elson-Test-2.webp""><br></div><div><img src=""Elson-Test-1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">Zone III extensor tendon injury (Boutonnière Deformity)&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 600;""><br></span></div><div><u>treatment</u><span style=""font-weight: 600;"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::initially treated with splinting::general}}&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>"	"initially treated with <u>4 to 6 weeks</u> of splinting of the PIP joint in extension with MCP and wrist joints free<div><br></div><div>Open injuries, Displaced avulsion fractures, axial and lateral instability of the PIP,&nbsp;</div><div>and failed nonoperative treatment are indications for surgical intervention&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-17 at 11.24.25 AM.png""><img src=""extensor tendons.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Zone V, VI, and VII extensor tendon injury</b><div><br></div><div><u>treatment</u>&nbsp;</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::dorsal dynamic extension splint::uniqueDME/orthosis}}&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-17 at 11.27.20 AM.png""><img src=""extensor tendons.jpg""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-17 at 11.30.14 AM.png""><br><div><br><div><br></div></div></div>"																				
"<b>Flexor Tendon Injury</b><div><br></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>perform maneuver to isolate the action of both the&nbsp;{{c2::FDP}} and the {{c2::FDS}}&nbsp;<br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>if exam is limited because of pain, {{c1::tenodesis}} can be employed to determine whether the tendon is intact&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_66.png""><div><b>A) Testing of the&nbsp;FDP</b>&nbsp;</div><div>Flex the&nbsp;DIP&nbsp;while the&nbsp;PIP&nbsp;joint is held in extension.</div><div>examiner places a finger on the middle phalanx&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><b>B) Testing flexion of the&nbsp;FDS</b></div><div>It is important to eliminate the action of the&nbsp;FDP&nbsp;because the&nbsp;FDP&nbsp;can perform many of the same actions as the&nbsp;FDS</div><div>Hold the&nbsp;DIP&nbsp;of the noninvolved digits in extension.&nbsp;</div><div>Then ask the patient to flex the unrestrained digit,&nbsp;</div>"																				
"{{c1::Jersey finger}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon (FDP) at its insertion (Zone&nbsp;</span>{{c2::I}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;injury)</span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-18 at 10.56.22 AM.png""><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>Zone I</b> is from the tendon insertion
at the base of the distal phalanx to the midportion of the
middle phalanx.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Zone II</b> extends from
the midportion of the middle phalanx to the distal palmar
crease.&nbsp;</div><div>- This zone is known as <font color=""#fc0507"">no man’s land</font> because of the
poor functional results after tendon repair.&nbsp;</div><div>- Tendon
injury in this zone usually involves both FDP and FDS&nbsp;</div><div><b>Zone III</b> is located from the distal palmar crease to the distal portion of the transverse carpal ligament.&nbsp;</div><div>- This zone in-
cludes the intrinsic hand muscles and vascular arches.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Zone
IV</b> overlies the transverse carpal ligament in the area of the
carpal tunnel.&nbsp;</div><div>- In this zone, injuries usually involve multiple
FDP and FDS tendons.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Zone V</b> extends from the wrist
crease to the level of the musculotendinous junction of the
flexor tendons.&nbsp;</div><div>- Injuries in this region most often result from
self-inflicted laceration (suicide attempts).&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
In regard to digital flexor tendon injury, zone {{c1::2}} has the worst prognosis&nbsp;	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-18 at 10.56.22 AM.png""><div><div><div><div><div><b>Zone I</b>&nbsp;is from the tendon insertion at the base of the distal phalanx to the midportion of the middle phalanx.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Zone II</b>&nbsp;extends from the midportion of the middle phalanx to the distal palmar crease.&nbsp;</div><div>- This zone is known as&nbsp;<font color=""#fc0507"">no man’s land</font>&nbsp;because of the poor functional results after tendon repair.&nbsp;</div><div>- Tendon injury in this zone usually involves both <u>FDP and FDS</u>&nbsp;</div><div><b>Zone III</b>&nbsp;is located from the distal palmar crease to the distal portion of the transverse carpal ligament.&nbsp;</div><div>- This zone in- cludes the intrinsic hand muscles and vascular arches.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Zone IV</b>&nbsp;overlies the transverse carpal ligament in the area of the carpal tunnel.&nbsp;</div><div>- In this zone, injuries usually involve multiple FDP and FDS tendons.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Zone V</b>&nbsp;extends from the wrist crease to the level of the musculotendinous junction of the flexor tendons.&nbsp;</div><div>- Injuries in this region most often result from self-inflicted laceration (suicide attempts).&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Jersey finger: Mechanism of injury is a rupture of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon}}"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_65.png"">"																				
"<b>Flexor Tendon Injury</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::Early orthopedic referral for surgical repair}}</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Postoperative rehabilitation}}&nbsp;</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Dorsal dynamic protection splint::DME/orthosis}}&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>Surgical intervention is almost always required for flexor
tendon injuries.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Optimally, surgical
correction of the flexor tendon injury occurs within the first
12 to 24 hours.&nbsp;</div><div>Delayed primary repair is performed in the
first 10 days.&nbsp;</div><div>If repair is not performed within 4 weeks, the tendon usually is retracted repair
difficult&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Immediately postoperatively, the hand is placed in a protective dorsal splint with 20 to 30 degrees of wrist flexion.&nbsp;</div><div>All metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints are placed in 20 to
50 degrees of flexion, depending on zone.&nbsp;</div><div>A dorsal
hood extends to the fingertip level, allowing PIP joint and
DIP joint extension to 0 degrees.&nbsp;</div><div>All of the fingers are held
in flexion by dynamic traction applied by rubber bands attachmed to the fingernails</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-18 at 11.14.01 AM.png"">&nbsp;<br></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>{{c1::Bennett’s}}</b><strong>&nbsp;fracture</strong>: Oblique fracture-subluxation at the base of the thumb metacarpal<div><br></div><div>Intra-articular fracture with a palmar ulnar fragment (ortho bullet)</div>	"<img src=""life in fast lane..jpg""><div><img src=""Rolando-Bennet-fractures-compared-2.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>{{c1::Rolando’s}}</b><strong>&nbsp;fracture</strong>: Fracture at the base of the thumb metacarpal that may be classified as a T, Y, or comminuted configuration	"<img src=""cow701_moved.jpg""><br><div><img src=""Rolando-Bennet-fractures-compared-2.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Boxer’s fracture refers to a f</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">racture of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::metacarpal neck/shaft}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_69.png"">"																				
ANKLE SPRAIN GRADING<div><br></div><div><u>Grade 1 (Mild)</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Partial tear of the&nbsp;ATFL::pathophys}}</div>	"<div>CFL&nbsp;and&nbsp;PTFL&nbsp;are intact</div><div>Mild swelling with point tenderness at the lateral aspect of the ankle</div><div>Anterior drawer: Negative<br></div><div>Talar tilt: Negative</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-19 at 5.56.22 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
ANKLE SPRAIN GRADING<div><br></div><div><u>Grade 1 (Mild)</u>:</div><div>{{c1::No instability::phys-ex}}</div>																					
ANKLE SPRAIN GRADING<div><br></div><div><u>Grade 2 (Moderate)</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Complete tear of the&nbsp;ATFL &amp; Partial tear of the&nbsp;CFL}}</div>	"Diffuse swelling and ecchymosis<div><div>Stress tests</div><div>Anterior drawer: Positive</div><div>Large anterior shift of the ankle or palpable clunk</div><div>Talar tilt: Negative</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-19 at 5.56.22 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
ANKLE SPRAIN GRADING<div><br></div><div><u>Grade 2 (Moderate)</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Anterior drawer: Positive::phys-ex}}<br></div>																					
ANKLE SPRAIN GRADING<div><br></div><div><u>Grade 3 (Severe)</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Complete tear of the&nbsp;ATFL&nbsp;and&nbsp;CFL}}</div>	"<div>Stress tests</div><div>Anterior drawer: Positive</div><div>Talar tilt: Positive</div><div>Inverting the talus on the tibia looking for a clinical asymmetry in comparison</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-19 at 5.56.22 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
ANKLE SPRAIN GRADING<div><br></div><div><u>Grade 3 (Severe)</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Anterior drawer: Positive &amp; Talar tilt: Positive::phys-ex}}</div>																					
ANKLE SPRAIN GRADING<div><br></div><div><u>Dislocation</u></div><div>{{c1::Complete tear of the&nbsp;ATFL,&nbsp;CFL, and&nbsp;PTFL}}<br></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-19 at 5.56.22 AM.png"">"																				
<b>ankle sprain</b><div>&nbsp;<div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>inspect&nbsp;</div><div>palpate</div><div>ROM</div><div>{{c1::anterior drawer}}</div><div>{{c1::talar tilt}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::eversion test}}</div><div>{{c2::external rotation test}} aka Kleiger's test&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::squeeze test}}&nbsp; &nbsp;</div></div><div>assess for {{c3::peroneal}} nerve or tendon injury&nbsp;</div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div>Palpation should include the med/lat ligaments, syndesmotic area,&nbsp;</div><div>maleoli, base of the fifth metatarsal, navicular (ottowa)</div><div><br></div><div>1. and 2. anterior drawer and talar tilt are tests of laxity, (compared to other side)&nbsp;</div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><br></div><div>3. eversion test is positive if there is pain&nbsp;</div><div>- deltoid injury if medial pain is elicted</div><div>- syndesmosis injury if anterior pain&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>4. external rotation test separates the ankle mortise and elicits ant. pain&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>4. squeeze test is positive if there is pain over the syndesmosis<br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-19 at 6.13.45 AM.png""><img src=""1262-3.jpg""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<b>ankle sprain</b><div><br></div><div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>X-rays with&nbsp;AP, lateral, and mortise views (ottowa ankle rules)</div><div>+/- {{c1::Stress views}} are optional&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::US}} may demonstrate tear of the&nbsp;ATFL&nbsp;and&nbsp;CFL<br></div><div></div>{{c2::MRI}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;if pain persists for 6-8 weeks following sprain</span><br></div>"	"<div><div>MRI eval for: osteochondral injury, syndesmotic injury, peroneal tendon injury</div><div><br></div><div>ottowa ankle reduced imaging by 30% while missing no fractures&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""lateral_ankle_stress_view_mod.jpg""><br></div><div>Anterior drawer may show a &gt;5 mm displacement.</div><div>Talar tilt may show a 5-degree to 10-degree difference as compared to the contralateral extremity.</div></div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Yannick-De-Brucker/publication/289518819/figure/fig8/AS:399015737872391@1472144173350/Normal-values-at-standard-X-ray-views-AP-Mortise-and-lateralof-the-ankle-References.png"">"																				
"<b>ankle sprain</b><div><br></div><div><u> treatment</u>&nbsp;<br><div>NSAIDS, ice, compression, modalities, supervised PT&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::crutches}} for 2-3 days (if ambulatory pain)</div></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c2::walking boot}} for 2 weeks (if severe)</div><div>followed by {{c2::ankle lace up brace}} for 4 more weeks then just during exercise&nbsp;</div><div><div><div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c3::Surgery}} is rare for ankle sprains&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>Grade II and grade III sprains
may require longer use of assistive devices</div><div><br></div><div>resting dorsiflexion limits stretch on the injured anterior talo-fibular ligament and minimizes resultant joint effusion</div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><br></div><div>prolonged immobilization (more
than 4 weeks) is less effective than early functional treatment&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">even grade 3 is not </span>treated surgically unless they result
in chronic instability, although surgical outcomes seem good&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""paste-a0a67830026dbbd0db9b347b41a07abd53915a69.jpg""><img src=""paste-a6f2fe2490124814b98d2f6ed68483d4597a30f2.jpg""><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><br></div><div><u>Rehab</u></div><div>AROM as soon as tolerated (write the alphabet)&nbsp;<br></div><div>concentric and eccentric exercises with
tubing when the patient tolerates pain-free weight bearing</div><div>Double-leg toe raises should progress to single-leg toe raises</div><div>proprioceptive and balance training dimproves recovery and reduces recurrence of injury&nbsp;<br></div><div>sport specific training&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>ankle sprain</b><div><br></div><div><div>Grade 3:</div><div>Controversial: Conservative versus surgical</div><div><br></div><div><u>Indications for surgery</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::bony avulsions}}</div><div>{{c2::severe ligamentous damage on both sides of the ankle}}</div><div>{{c3::severe recurrent injuries}}</div></div><div>failed conserative management&nbsp;</div><div>certain types of syndesmotic injuries (ie + stress films w/ out fx)</div>	"<div>Six-month trial of rehabilitation and bracing</div><div>Ligament repair, tenodesis of the peroneus brevis</div><div>if patient is a high-performance athlete, and conservative treatment fails (i.e., patient has persistent critical instability),&nbsp;</div><div>then surgical reconstruction of torn ligaments may be considered as early as 3 months postinjury.</div><div><img src=""foot_and_ankle_internal_brace_repair_0-large.png""><img src=""ankle.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""brostrom-repair.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""WJO-6-161-g003.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<strong>Peroneal Tendon Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>repetitive forceful eversion causing {{c1::tenosynovitis}}&nbsp;</div><div>sudden dorsiflexion of the ankle can cause a {{c2::subluxation or dislocation}}&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>	"Tenosynovitis: <b>inflammation or degeneration of the synovium</b> within the tendon sheath<div>dislocation is commonly a skiing injury</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_120.png""><br></div>"																				
<strong>Peroneal Tendon Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Painful swelling in the lateral {{c1::retromalleolar}} area&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::inability to evert the foot}} if a dislocation or rupture is suspected</div><div>{{c3::popping}} sensation in the lateral aspect of the ankle</div>	"<img src=""peronealtears_1280.jpg"">"																				
<strong>Peroneal Tendon Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>pain with resisted {{c1::dorsiflexion}} and {{c1::eversion}}</div>	"<img src=""3b3e5d_edb225b7207c49bf8d186a270e6b8ae7~mv2.png"">"																				
"<div><div><strong>Peroneal Tendon Injury</strong></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span><br></div><div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Tenosynovitis: {{c1::Same treatment as for a lateral ankle sprain}}</div><div>Rupture/subluxation/dislocation → {{c2::orthopedic evaluation}}</div></div>"	<div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>None needed initially.&nbsp;MRI&nbsp;if indicated.</div><div>US may help visualize peroneal tendon subluxation over the lateral malleolus when the ankle is dorsiflexed and everted</div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Rupture/subluxation/dislocation</u>&nbsp;</div><div>4 to 6 weeks of immobilization in a plantar-flexed position</div></div>																				
"<strong>Tibialis Posterior Tendon Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Insidious onset of {{c1::postero-medial}} {{c1::ankle&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">(and hindfoot)</span>}} pain increased by activity (push-off)</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- may be caused by trauma,
degeneration, or inflammatory arthritides</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- most commonly seen in woman the sixth to seventh decades of life&nbsp;</span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">- most
common cause of acquired flatfoot in the adult&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">As the insufficiency progresses, pronation
increases, leading to pain over the dorsolateral aspect of the
midfoot&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""tibialis-posterior-tendinopathy800-800x426.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<strong>Tibialis Posterior Tendon Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>Medial hind foot swelling and TTP<br></div><div>Weakness with inversion and plantar flexion</div><div>classic “{{c1::too many toes}}” sign is seen with a tibialis posterior tendon rupture</div>	"When viewing the patient’s feet from behind, more toes are visible on the affected side secondary to collapse of the medial longitudinal arch.<div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">elements of the deformity: valgus hindfoot (calcaneovalgus), midfoot
abduction, and forefoot pronation&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">difficulty performing a one-sided toe-stand
while holding on to the clinician’s hands. The heel fails to
invert into a varus position</span></div><div><img src=""forefoot abduction.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;<br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<strong>Tibialis Posterior Tendon Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Acute</span>: {{c1::Same as lateral ankle sprains}}</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Conservative</span>: Rehabilitation, {{c3::custom orthotics (to address pronation)}}</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Surgical</span>: {{c2::Tendon transfer}}, excising the accessory navicular</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Custom orthotic devices with longitudinal arch support and medial heel lift shoe
inserts,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">University of California Biomechanics Laboratory
(UCBL) inserts</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Unfortunately, there is no
proof that any orthotic device can halt progression of the disorder</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Complete tendon disruption, in the absence of bone
collapse (stage II)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">treated with flexor digitorum longus transfer with medial
sliding calcaneal osteotomy.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">worsening deformity and lateral hindfoot pain (stage III)</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Subtalar or triple arthrodesis
may be indicated&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">imaging is not needed&nbsp;<br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ultrasound can be done, MRI is the gold standard</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-20 at 9.08.51 AM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<strong>Tibialis Posterior Tendon Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">when viewing the patient’s feet&nbsp;</span>{{c1::from behind}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, more toes are visible on the affected side&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">secondary to collapse of the medial longitudinal arch</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_123.png"">"																				
<strong>Achilles Tendon Disorders</strong><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>Inflammation and degeneration causing a series of microtears or breakdown in the collagen fibers</div><div>Inadequate {{c1::vascularization}} 2 to 6 cm proximal to the insertion of the tendon</div><div>Sudden push-off with the foot in the extension position (e.g., landing from a jump)</div><div>Training errors: Sharp increase in volume or intensity</div><div>Change in footwear</div><div>Anatomic causes: Hyperpronation, {{c2::tight hamstrings and heel cords (Achilles tendons)}}, pes cavus, and genu varum</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_124.png"">"																				
<strong>Achilles Tendon Disorders</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div>Thompson’s test: {{c1::Squeezing the calf}} should elicit plantar flexion of the foot with an intact Achilles tendon&nbsp;</div>	"<div>Squeezing the calf should elicit plantar flexion of the foot with an intact Achilles tendon (i.e.,&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">negative</span>&nbsp;Thompson’s test).</div><div>In an Achilles tendon rupture, the foot is unable to plantar flex secondary to the tendon separation (i.e.,&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">positive</span>&nbsp;Thompson’s test).</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-20 at 11.53.33 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Achilles Tendon Disorders</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">non weight bearing with crutches and a CAM boot / short leg splint in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">plantar flexion (</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">10-15<sup>o</sup>)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;(rupture)</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div>Relative rest, ice, anti-inflammatory medications, physical therapy&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::counter force brace}} or {{c2::heel lift}}</div><div>topical {{c3::nitroglycerin}}</div><div>do not {{c3::inject steroids}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<b>Ortho referral for full&nbsp;</b><strong>Achilles tendon rupture</strong>:<div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Conservative</u></span>:&nbsp;</div><div>nonweight bearing using crutches and cast/CAM&nbsp;boot in a plantar-flexed position for a period of 8 to 12 weeks.&nbsp;</div><div>The dorsiflexion is increased gradually so that by the end of 12 weeks, the patient is in a neutral position.&nbsp;</div><div>Activity level and weight bearing status are increased gradually (heel lifts may be used).</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Surgical</u></span>:&nbsp;</div><div>Tendon repair. Patient is placed in a cast for 2 weeks and then put in a plantar flexion dial lock brace for 4 to 6 weeks,&nbsp;</div><div>which is slowly brought to neutral. Activity level is increased gradually (heel lifts may be used).&nbsp;</div><div>Surgical repair is usually reserved for active individuals.</div><div><img src=""images-8e65a384a60be55036483e0dc7d43792ceac3072.jpg""><img src=""paste-dd26a4d0c6fb3979a242cf4557e85046e6e0d645.jpg""><img src=""pt-exercises-for-achilles-tendonitis-5202656_final-a2c745a0e3f6429bb68a6fe068b757a3.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div><div><strong>Flexus Hallucis Longus (Fhl) Injury</strong></div></div><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>Also known as {{c1::dancer’s}} tendonitis</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">mechanism: repetitive push-off maneuvers causing inflammation of the synovium</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">pain in the groove of the sustentaculum tali and behind the lateral malleolus to its insertion</span><br></div>"	"<u>Clinical Features</u><div>Tenderness along the tendon at the posteromedial aspect of the great toe</div><div>Decreased ability to flex the great toe</div><div>Increased pain with active plantar flexion and passive dorsiflexion</div><div><img src=""photo-fhl-tendonitis-300x300.jpg""><br></div>"																				
Retrocalcaneal bursitis can be often accompanied by {{c1::insertional achilles tendinitis}} and {{c2::Haglund deformity}}																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Retrocalcaneal bursitis is a commonly caused by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::high heel shoes (improper foot wear)}}"	"Repetitive pressure and shearing forces from an object (e.g., high heels or shoes)<div>or footwear with a hard heel counter eg ice hockey</div><div><br></div><div>causing thickening and inflammation of the bursae, Achilles tendon, and enlargement of the posterior calcaneal region</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Haglund’s deformity</strong>&nbsp;aka (“pump bump”)</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_127.png""><br></div>"																				
<div><strong>Haglund Syndrome /</strong>&nbsp;<b>retrocalcaneal bursitis</b><br></div><br><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Tenderness in the posterior ankle at the {{c1::Achilles insertion}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Soft tissue swelling}} can be palpated on exam</div>	Similar type of pain can result from insertional Achilles tendonitis or&nbsp;																				
"<strong>Haglund Syndrome /</strong>&nbsp;<b>retrocalcaneal bursitis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>physical examination</u></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>A positive {{c1::two-finger squeeze}} test result</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	pain elicited by application of pressure both medially and laterally with two fingers&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>just superior and anterior to the Achilles insertion&nbsp;</div>																				
"<strong>Haglund Syndrome /</strong>&nbsp;<b>retrocalcaneal bursitis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Imaging</u><b>&nbsp;</b>""not required""</div><div>retrocalcaneal bursa: {{c1::us}}</div><div>Haglund Syndrome: {{c1::xray (no diagnostic criteria established)}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-b8573640366788e8ac94adc8769773ab19ec9b45.jpg""><br></div><img src=""WJO-2-13-g028.jpg"">"																				
"<b>Retrocalcaneal Bursitis (haglund deformity)</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::alter footwear}}</div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>aspirated and inject with 2-mL of corticosteroid&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div>Surgical excision of the bursae if conservative measures fail</div>"	"manage the same as achillies tendonitis<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>A portion of the heel
counter can be cut away and replaced with a soft leather
insert&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>to cause less friction at the site where the heel counter meets the skin&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>injection is unlikely to harm the tendon&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
Posterior ankle impingement syndrome is cuased by the {{c1::Os Trigonum}}<div><br></div><div>pain is reproduced on exam by {{c2::passive plantar flexion}}</div>	"<img src=""Picture1_gallery.jpeg""><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">Pathology of the os trigonum-talar process is the most common cause of this syndrome,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">but it also may result from flexor hallucis longus tenosynovitis, ankle osteochondritis, subtalar joint disease, and fracture</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(33, 33, 33);"">pain with push off and plantar flexion&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
<div><strong>Tibiofibular Syndesmosis Injury</strong></div><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>Also known as a {{c1::high ankle sprain}}</div><div>Hyperdorsiflexion and forceful {{c2::eversion}} of the ankle</div><div>Direct blow to the foot with the ankle held in external rotation</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_128.png"">"																				
<strong>Tibiofibular Syndesmosis Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Imaging</u></div><div>Plain films with&nbsp;AP, lateral, oblique, and mortise views</div><div>Xray Rule out {{c1::widening between (distal tibia / fibula)}} and a {{c2::Maisonneuve fracture}}</div><div>MRI,&nbsp;CT. if xrays are equivocal but suspicion remains high&nbsp;<br></div>	"<div><b>findings</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>decreased&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">tibiofibular overlap</span></u>&nbsp;</div><div>normal &gt;6 mm on AP view</div><div>normal &gt;1 mm on mortise view</div><div><br></div><div><u>increased&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">medial clear space</span></u>&nbsp;</div><div>normal less than or equal to 4 mm</div><div><br></div><div><u>increased&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">tibiofibular clear space</span></u>&nbsp;</div><div>normal &lt;6 mm on both AP and mortise views</div><img src=""tibia-fibula overlap.jpg""><img src=""high fibula fracture.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Maisonneuve fracture</b>:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Rupture of the anterior tibiofibular ligament extending through the interosseous membrane,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">which often results in a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::proximal fibula fracture}}</div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_129.png"">"																				
"<strong>Tibiofibular Syndesmosis Injury</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Conservative: {{c1::sprain}}&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Surgical</span>: {{c1::diastasis}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><b>TREATMENT</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Nonoperative</u></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">non-weight-bearing CAM boot or cast for 2 to 3 weeks</strong></div><div><br></div><div>indications</div><div>syndesmotic sprain without diastasis or ankle instability</div><div>delayed weight-bearing until pain free</div><div>physical therapy program using a brace that limits external rotation</div><div>typically display a&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">notoriously prolonged and highly variable</span>&nbsp;recovery period</div><div>recovery may extend to twice that of standard ankle sprain</div><div><br></div><div><u>Operative&nbsp;</u></div><div><strong style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">syndesmosis screw fixation</strong></div><div><br></div><div>indications</div><div>syndesmotic sprain (without fracture) with instability on stress radiographs</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">syndesmotic sprain refractory</span>&nbsp;to conservative treatment</div><div><img src=""malreduced syndesmosis.jpg""><img src=""arthrex tight rope.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<strong>Tibiofibular Syndesmosis Injury</strong><br><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>pain and swelling on the {{c1::anterior ankle}} just {{c1::above the joint}}</div>																					
<strong>Sinus Tarsi Syndrome</strong><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><div><u>General</u></div><div>results from a&nbsp;{{c1::Talocalcaneal ligament}} sprain</div></div>	<div><u>Mechanism of Injury</u></div><div>Excessive foot pronation causing adduction of the talus</div><div>History of arthritis:&nbsp;RA, gout, and seronegative spondyloarthropathies</div><div>History of prior ankle injury: Inversion sprain or fracture of the tibia, calcaneal, or talus</div>																				
<strong>Sinus Tarsi Syndrome</strong><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Pain on the {{c1::antero-lateral}} aspect of the foot and ankle</div>	"Diagnosis: Resolution of symptoms with injection of local anesthetic into the sinus tarsi<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_130.png""><br></div>"																				
hyperactivity of the&nbsp;{{c1::Tibialis Anterior}}&nbsp;often contributes to equinovarus deformities	"along with achillies shortening&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>TA contributes to the inversion (varus) and supination portion of the deformity&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Congenital-Talipes-Equinovarus-Clubfoot-8.jpg""><br></div></div>"																				
<strong>Tibialis Anterior Spasticity</strong><br><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Surgical: {{c1::SPLATT procedure}}</div><div>often done along with {{c2::Achilles tendon lengthening}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Conservative</u></span></div><div>ROM, stretching, casting, bracing, chemoneurolysis, neurotoxin injections (botulinum toxin)</div><div><br></div><div><div><b>SPlit Anterior Tibial Tendon Transfer (SPLATT)</b></div><div><br></div><div>Technique: The&nbsp;TA&nbsp;tendon is split, and a portion of the tendon is transferred to the lateral foot.&nbsp;</div><div>Half remains attached to its site of origin,lateral half of the tendon is tunneled into the third cuneiform and cuboid bones</div></div><div><br></div><div>This provides an eversion force to counteract the dynamic varus deformity to provide a flat base for weight bearing<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""chp0020_pl020-001ac-9780323448086.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>plantar fascitis</b>&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div><u>General&nbsp;</u></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">an&nbsp;</span>overuse<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;injury resulting from repetitive microtears&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div>increased {{c2::tension}} on the plantar fascia leads to ""chronic inflammation""</div><div>etiologies include: {{c1::pes cavus (high arch)}}, {{c1::pes planus (flat foot)}}, obesity, tight Achilles tendon, and bone spurs</div><div>{{c3::heel spurs}} are not felt to be the definitive cuase</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">research has demonstrated the relative absence of
inflammatory cells in the injured tissue,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">suggesting more of
a degenerative process&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">caused by an increase in training or professions that stand alot&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">only 50% of patients with plantar heel pain had a heel spur
and 10% of patients with a heel spurs were symptomatic&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_132.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<b>plantar fasciitis</b><br><div><br></div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Tenderness over the {{c1::medial}} aspect of the {{c1::heel}}</div><div>Pain can be elicited by {{c2::hyperextension}} of the {{c2::great toe(s)}} with palpation along the plantar fascia</div><div>Pain is worse {{c3::in the morning}} or {{c3::at the start of weight-bearing activities}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c4::Tight Achilles tendon}} is frequently associated with plantar fasciitis<br></div>	"<div><u>commonly pain may radiate prox into calf</u> from arch collapse Tib post, tight gastroc etc. (Dr. Ham)</div><div><br></div>pain and TTP at the origin of the plantar fascia (medial calcaneal tubercle) and along the plantar arch (can be entire length)<div><br></div><div><div>pain worse at the beginning of standing, walking after prolonged sitting and decreases during activity</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-23 at 8.45.28 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>plantar fasciitis</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Modalities,&nbsp;NSAIDs, Achilles tendon and plantar fascia stretching</div><div>{{c1::Orthotics (new shoes, heel pads, cushion, and lift)}}</div><div>{{c1::roll tennis ball (golf ball, ice massage)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Nighttime dorsiflexion splints}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Injections}} in refractory cases&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::work accommadations (seated tasks,&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">“stress mats”)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>Surgical: Plantar fascia release (rarely indicated)</div>"	"Conservative: 90% to 95% effective and should be done for at least 6 months prior to considering surgery<div><br></div><div>rehabilitaiton includes strengthneing foot intrinsics and a protocol for return to walking/running&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div><div><u>Injections:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Do not inject anesthetic/corticosteroid into the subcutaneous tissue or fascial layer.&nbsp;</div><div>Stay out of the superficial fat pad to avoid fat necrosis.</div></div></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><br></div><div>Needle position: Enter the skin from either the medial heel,&nbsp;</div><div>in-plane with the transducer, and guide it <b>to the
plantar fascia</b>.&nbsp;</div><div>guide it to areas of calcification, hypoechogenicity, or thickening.</div><div>active ankle dorsiflexion may best visualize the plantar fascia margins&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-23 at 9.07.07 AM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-23 at 9.07.25 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Morton’s neuroma</b></span><br></div><div><br></div><u>General</u><div><br></div><div>Irritation and degeneration of the distal interdigital nerves in the toes</div><div><br></div><div>with eventual enlargement due to {{c1::perineural fibrosis}}</div><div><br></div><div>most commonly effected is the {{c2::3rd
plantar intermetatarsal}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;nerve&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">accumulation of collagenous material within the sheath of Schwann and usually the result of repetitive trauma&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">risk factors similar to plantar fascitis:&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">flatfoot (pes planus); anterior splay foot; high-arch foot (pes cavus);&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">ill-fitting shoes</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-24 at 5.09.26 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Morton’s neuroma</b></span><br></div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Sharp shooting forefoot pain that can {{c1::radiate to the affected digits}}</div><div>{{c2::Dysesthesias}} and {{c2::numbness}} are common</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">symptoms typically radiate distally, involving the opposing plantar sides of the third and fourth
toes&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_133.png""></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Morton’s neuroma</b><br></div><div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Physical Exam</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>apply {{c1::dorsal and plantar pressure to the interdigit web space with one hand}}&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>apply {{c2::lateral and medial foot compression to squeeze the metatarsal heads together}}</div></div></div>"	"<div>Isolated pain on the plantar aspect of the web space is consistent with Morton’s neuroma.</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A Mulder sign is present when symptoms are reproduced and a palpable and sometimes audible click is detected&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-24 at 5.20.53 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>"																				
"<b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Morton’s neuroma</b><div><b style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></b></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>{{c1::Shoe modifications (wide toe box, low heel height)}}</div><div>{{c2::Accommodative padding (Metatarsal pads (aka neuroma pads)}}</div><div>{{c3::Corticosteroid injection}} may be diagnostic and therapeutic</div><div>Surgical: Excision if indicated</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">off-the-shelf arch supports, more individualized therapies such as custom foot orthoses&nbsp;</span></div><div>Masses greater than 5 mm are
more likely to be symptomatic (positive scan)<br></div><div><div><div><img src=""ultra-sound-img.png""><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Place the probe transversely over the
MTP joints.&nbsp;</div><div>Visualize the neuroma and center it on the screen&nbsp;</div>
<div>Markings: Identify small arteries.
</div>
<div>Needle position: Enter the skin out-of-plane&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-24 at 5.33.01 PM.png"">&nbsp;<br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Arrowhead </span>indicates needle tip&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<b>{{c1::Hallux rigidus}}:</b><div><br></div><div>Degenerative joint disease of the first&nbsp;MTP&nbsp;joint leading to pain and stiffness&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Pain and swelling with decreased&nbsp;</span>ROM and<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Antalgic gait pattern</span><br></div>"																					
"<b>Hallux Rigidus&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u>&nbsp;</div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">orthoses to limit
stresses at the MTP joint (carbon fiber inserts)&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Consult prosthetist for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::steel shank}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;and possibly a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::rocker-bottom}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c2::Intra-articular ultrasound-guided injection of steroid}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;may provide short-term relief</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">surgery&nbsp;<br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	arthroplasty has not lived up to expectations<div>fusion has better outcomes&nbsp;</div>																				
<b>{{c1::MTP&nbsp;sprain}}: Also known as {{c2::turf toe}}</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>General</u></div><div><u><br></u></div><div>occurs from a {{c3::hyper-extension}} mechanism<b>&nbsp;<br></b><div><br></div><div>Acute injury to the ligaments and capsule (plantar complex) of the first&nbsp;MTP&nbsp;joint</div></div>	"<div><img src=""c4a6eb6cdd934a8d8ee0406ef1753925.aspx""><img src=""b01b8a3c0e9a46748d936d8aa342242e.aspx""><br></div><div><div>The MTP joint is surrounded by important structures that hold it in place and prevent it from dislocating.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Together these structures are referred to as the plantar complex.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Plantar plate.</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>This thick, fibrous tissue under the MTP joint prevents the big toe from bending too far upward (dorsiflexion).</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Collateral ligaments.</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>Located on each side of the big toe, collateral ligaments connect the phalanx bone to the metatarsal</div><div>prevent the toe from going too far side to side.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Flexor hallucis brevis.</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>This tendon runs under the first metatarsal bone and attaches to the proximal phalanx.&nbsp;</div><div>It provides strength and stability to the big toe during push-off motions.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Sesamoids.</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>These two small bones are enveloped in the flexor hallucis tendon and help it to move more easily.&nbsp;</div><div>the sesamoids provide stability to the MTP joint by helping to bear weight placed on the forefoot.</div></div><div><br></div><div>Chronic sprains may lead to hallux rigidus</div>"																				
<b>Turf Toe&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Physical Examination</u></div><div><div>inspection (swelling and ecchymosis, alignment of MTP joint)</div><div>active and passive range of motion</div><div>inability to {{c1::hyperextend}} the joint without significant symptoms</div><div>assess for {{c2::varus/valgus}} instability</div></div>	<div><strong>X-rays.</strong></div><div>Although the plantar complex is made up of different soft tissues,&nbsp;</div><div>X-rays to make sure there bony pull-off fractures or movement of the two small sesamoid bones.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans.</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>An MRI scan may be useful in Grade 2 and 3 injuries or when abnormalities are noted on the X-rays.</div>
