<b>Turf Toe&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u>&nbsp;<div>rest, ice, NSAID's</div></div><div>{{c1::taping (big toe to the smaller toe)}} or {{c1::toe spacers}}&nbsp;</div><div>a {{c2::graphite insert}} or {{c2::stiff soled shoe}}</div><div>{{c3::walking boot}} or {{c3::short leg cast}} for more severe injuries&nbsp;</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-8794fcb535fe1a283c4b294598d42162f5f8fc07.jpg""><img src=""paste-b815ccbc757b42bfeb1d495fd4f15b37f4658be2.jpg""><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></strong></div><div><strong><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">surgical repair&nbsp;</span></strong><div><br></div><div><u>indications</u> (usually Grade III injuries)</div><div>- failed conservative treatment</div><div>- retraction of sesamoids</div><div>- fracture of sesamoids with diastasis</div><div>- traumatic bunions</div><div>-&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">loose fragments in the joint</span></div><div><font color=""#5372a6"">-&nbsp;</font>hallux toe deformity</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Grade 1.</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>The plantar complex has been stretched,&nbsp;</div><div>causing pinpoint tenderness and slight swelling.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Grade 2.</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>A partial tearing of the plantar complex&nbsp;</div><div>causes more widespread tenderness, moderate swelling, and bruising.&nbsp;</div><div>Movement of the toe is limited and painful.</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Grade 3.</strong>&nbsp;</div><div>The plantar complex is completely torn,&nbsp;</div><div>causing severe tenderness, severe swelling, and bruising.&nbsp;</div><div>It is difficult and painful to move the big toe</div></div>"																				
<b>{{c2::Hallux valgus}} aka {{c3::Bunnion}}</b><div><br></div><div>Lateral deviation of the first toe &gt; normal angle of {{c1::15}} degrees&nbsp;</div><div>between the tarsus and metatarsus seen on standing AP radiograph</div><div>painful prominence of the medial aspect of the&nbsp;MTP&nbsp;joint (bunion)</div>	"
<div>
<div>
<div>intrinsic causes are
essentially genetic and are related to hypermobility of the
first ray (hallux metatarsal) at its articulation with the medial cuneiform Ligamentous laxity can lead to this deformity as well
as to variations in the shape of the metatarsal head (i.e., a
rounder head is less stable than flat&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div>extrinsic cause is inappropriate, noncon-
forming footwear, with abnormal valgus forces creating
deformity</div><div>notable in women who
wear high-heeled shoes with narrow toe boxes.</div><div>ratio of
hallux valgus between women and men has been reported
to be 15:1&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""ima measurements_moved.jpg""><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-30 at 1.36.30 PM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>"																				
<b>Hallux Valgus</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>clinical features</u></div><div>Lateral deviation of the first toe</div><div>prominent medial eminence with pain at the {{c1::1st MTP&nbsp;joint}}</div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>commonly, there will be pain that is worse when constrictive shoes are worn&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and relieved by walking barefoot
or with open-toed shoes&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>if there is associted arthritis, will have pain throughout ROM&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen-Shot-2021-08-04-at-20.59.22-1024x557.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>Hallux Valgus</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>treatment</u>&nbsp;</div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>education about {{c1::proper footwear}}</div><div>various {{c2::orthoses}} are available and are of varying efficacy</div><div>{{c3::pumice stone}} after daily showers may be reccommended for the bunnionette&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<u>proper footwear</u>: shoes with low heels, well-cushioned soles, extra depth, and broad toe boxes<div><br></div><div><div><u>orthoses</u></div><div>sponge wedges to be placed in the first web space</div><div>more formal braces that attempt to pull the hallux into a neutral position</div><div>custom-molded orthotic appliances to resist foot pronation and to support the arch</div></div><div><br></div><div><u>procedures</u></div><div>injections are not reccommended&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>surgery</u></div><div>""not likely to completely satisfy the patient, tried after conservative methods fail""<br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>soft tissue procedure</div><div>proximal metatarsal osteotomy</div><div>MTP arthrodesis</div><div><img src=""paste-83e0e0c31b4bb88723995da1de90138319bf0d9d.jpg""><img src=""paste-6607b394fd09a7fee255b7bc3ebc237f56b2b288.jpg""></div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/333091393/figure/fig1/AS:758508244979714@1557853866409/Orthosis-for-treatment-of-hallux-valgus-A-Toe-spreader-B-Valgus-splint-and-C.jpg""><br></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
<div><div><b>Hammer toe</b></div></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>deformity of the lesser toes in which there is {{c1::flexion}} of the&nbsp;{{c1::PIP}}&nbsp;joint</div><div>and passive extension of&nbsp;{{c2::MTP}}&nbsp;with the {{c2::DIP}}&nbsp;joint usually not affected</div><div>Caused by {{c3::chronic, tight shoe wear}} but may be seen after trauma</div><div>a {{c5::long 2nd Ray}} and {{c5::Hallux Valgus}}, also contribute&nbsp;<br><div>typically {{c4::only a few::all / a few}} toes are affected</div></div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Contributing factors include long-term wear of poorly
fitting shoes, especially those with tight, narrow toe boxes.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Crowding and overlapping from hallux valgus are other
causes.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A long second ray with subsequent buckling of the
toe may also lead to the deformity. Other predisposing fac-
tors are diabetes, connective tissue disease, and trauma</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">In contrast
to clawing, which tends to involve all toes, hammer toe de-
formity usually affects only one or two toes [</span><span style=""color: rgb(44, 153, 191);"">2</span><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">]. Hammer
toes are classified as either flexible (passively correctable)
or rigid (not passively correctable<br>&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_134.png""></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>Hammer toe</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>clinical features</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Pain is present in the toe and patient has difficulty wearing footwear</span><b><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">on exam assess wheter the deformity is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::flexible or rigid}}</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Flexor digitorum longus contracture is
assessed with the ankle in dorsiflexion and plantar flexion.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Correction of the deformity on plantar flexion signifies a
flexible hammer toe.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Dorsiflexion, in turn, accentuates the
deformity&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Hammer toe</b></span><br><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>home exercise program of passive manual stretching<br></div><div>Shoes with {{c1::high toe boxes}}.&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Orthoses: Padding, such as toe crest pads or custom or premade&nbsp;</span>{{c2::hammer toe regulators}}<br></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Shoes should be 1/2 inch longer than the longest toe<br></div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">A soft insole can
also be used, which is useful for pressure relief</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Ulcer and callus management
may be necessary, educated about
monitoring their skin for breakdown</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Patients
with calluses on the PIP joint may benefit from digital caps
or silicone cushions.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">Surgery when conservative
treatment fails. Cosmesis alone is not a good indication&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><img src=""f82b645f-26c2-4ba1-852f-051701cf6e3e.0bd7655ad4534b11aea50c41ba4b2117.jpeg""><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
<div><div><b>Claw toe</b></div></div><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>Characterized by {{c1::extension}} of&nbsp;the MTP joint</div><div>and {{c1::flexion}} of the&nbsp;PIP and DIP joints&nbsp;</div><div>usually the result of incompetence of the {{c2::foot intrinsic muscles}}</div><div>secondary to {{c2::neurologic disorders}} affecting the strength of these structures&nbsp;</div>	"<div>(i.e., diabetes, alcoholism, peripheral neuropathies, Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease, and spinal cord tumors).</div><div>synovitis is the most common cuase</div><div>typically involves multiple toes, often bilateral</div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_135.png"">"																				
<b>Claw toe</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>Shoes with soft insoles and {{c1::high toe boxes}}</div><div>{{c2::claw toe Splints}} are available</div><div>Surgical correction may be necessary if conservative treatment fails</div>	"<div>overall identical to hammer toe&nbsp;</div><img src=""paste-821ff6062de282fb27a183a1e94c7ba92e2a94cb.jpg""><img src=""paste-033354b9e471d08d2c2a9fd41d648c21f197601f.jpg""><div><img src=""https://img.medscapestatic.com/pi/meds/ckb/18/31518tn.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><div><b>Mallet toe</b></div></div><div><br></div><div><u>General</u></div><div>{{c1::Flexion}} deformity at the&nbsp;{{c1::DIP}}&nbsp;joint</div><div>usually the result of {{c2::jamming}} type injury, {{c2::wearing tight shoes}} or congenital&nbsp;</div>	"normal alignment at the&nbsp;PIP&nbsp;and&nbsp;MTP&nbsp;joints<div>contracture (or spasm) of FDL because of pressure of toe against the end of shoe</div><div>&gt; 70% of patients have a longer digit<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_136.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<b>Mallet Toe</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u></div><div>calluses should be trimmed</div><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::Moleskin}}<span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;may be applied to painful corns&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div>wear shoes with soft insoles and high toe boxes</div><div>{{c2::silicone mallet toe sleeves::orthosis}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">crest pads or mallet toe regula-
tors,</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(13, 17, 19);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div><div><u>surgery</u> for fixed contracture, uleration, worsening deformity</div><div>Surgical treatment includes flexor tenotomy.&nbsp;</div><div>If the deformity is fixed, condylectomy is required<br></div><div><img src=""61DBrXC2wJL._AC_UF1000,1000_QL80_.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<div><div><b>Isolated Lisfranc joint injury</b></div></div><br><div><u>Clinical Features</u></div><div>Vague foot or ankle pain with swelling localized to the {{c1::dorsum}} of the foot</div><div>This injury is easily missed and often misdiagnosed as a {{c2::lateral ankle sprain}}</div><div>Pain may be reproduced by {{c3::stabilizing the hind foot}} and {{c3::rotating the forefoot}}</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Spectrum of midfoot injuries, from sprains to fracture/dislocations at the tarsometatarsal (</span>TMT<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">) joint</span><div>Low-energy trauma: Caused by a direct impact to the joint or by axial loading of the midfoot and rotating it (athletes)</div><div>High-energy trauma: Less common. Due to direct, high-impact trauma (e.g.,&nbsp;MVA) with greater damage produced<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_137.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<b>Lisfranc joint injury</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>imaging</u></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Diagnosis is confirmed by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::plain radiographs}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;which may show&nbsp;</span>{{c1::widening between the 1st and 2nd ray}}</div>"	"<div>CT for subtle bone injuries or preop planning&nbsp;</div><div>MRI could reveal a purely ligamentous injury</div><img src=""4b6959ae-8ac9-4a0f-be6a-8241e59a7ab3_screen_shot_2024-01-31_at_12.37.43_pm.jpg"">"																				
<b>Lisfranc joint injury</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u>Conservative&nbsp;Treatment</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>indicated for {{c1::Nondisplaced joint}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::Nonweight bearing}} and {{c2::immobilization (6 to 8 weeks)}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div>sounds like most are actually op</div>with continued support thereafter<div>certain non-displaced injuries that are stable with weight bearing</div><div>nonoperative candidates<div><div><img src=""mechanism illustration_moved.jpg""><br></div></div></div>"																				
<b>Lisfranc joint injury</b><div><br></div><div><u>Surgical&nbsp;Treatment</u>:</div><div>indicated for {{c2::displaced fracture dislocation}} injury</div><div>Stabilization with {{c1::percutaenous pin}} and {{c1::delayed ORIF}}</div>	"<img src=""lisfranc_fluoro_crpp..jpg"">"																				
<div>Fractures at the base of the fifth metatarsal can be classified by zone:</div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Zone 1</strong>: Pseudo-Jones fracture—{{c1::avulsion fracture of the tuberosity}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-437767ae811df7e08d0d316ccc77e8e550a70662.jpg""><img src=""paste-7326c7b03123be70e607af6ae633515ed479d593.jpg""><img src=""images-adebe01c50a6c3eba9625cb1f25a06530945f777.jpg"">"																				
Fractures at the base of the fifth metatarsal can be classified by zone:<div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Zone 2</strong>: Jones’ fracture occurs at the {{c1::metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction}}</div>	"<div>Risk of nonunion<br></div><img src=""paste-437767ae811df7e08d0d316ccc77e8e550a70662.jpg""><img src=""paste-7326c7b03123be70e607af6ae633515ed479d593.jpg""><img src=""images-adebe01c50a6c3eba9625cb1f25a06530945f777.jpg"">"																				
Fractures at the base of the fifth metatarsal can be classified by zone:<div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Zone 3</strong>: {{c1::Diaphyseal stress}} fractures typically result from repetitive loading</div>	"<div>Risk of nonunion<br></div><img src=""paste-437767ae811df7e08d0d316ccc77e8e550a70662.jpg""><img src=""paste-7326c7b03123be70e607af6ae633515ed479d593.jpg""><img src=""images-adebe01c50a6c3eba9625cb1f25a06530945f777.jpg"">"																				
<b>{{c1::Dancer’s fracture}}: </b>Distal shaft fracture of the fifth metatarsal																					
<strong>Nutcracker fracture</strong>: {{c1::Cuboid fracture}}																					
<b>{{c1::March fracture}}:</b> Metatarsal stress fracture																					
<b>Jones’ fracture:</b><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u><br></div><div>{{c1::Nonweight-bearing with short leg cast for 6-8 weeks}}</div>	"ORIF&nbsp;if nonunion occurs<div><img src=""5th mt stress fx.jpg""><br></div><div><div><b>Operative&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">intramedullary screw fixation</span><span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;</span></b></div><div><br></div><div><u>indications</u></div><div>zone 1 fractures with rotational displacement or skin tenting</div><div>zone 2 (Jones fracture) in elite or competitive athletes&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>zone 3 fractures in athletic individuals, cavovarus alignment, or with sclerosis/nonunion&nbsp;</div></div>"																				
"<div><b>Contraindications for Needle Aspirations and Injections (ie. corticosteroids)</b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span><br></div></div><div><u>Absolute</u><br></div><div>{{c1::Anesthetic or Corticosteroid allergy}}<br></div><div>{{c2::Cellulitis}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Septic Joint}}</div><div>{{c4::Cancer}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c5::s/p total joint arhtroplasty}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Relative</u></div><div>{{c6::Coagulopathy}}</div><div>{{c6::Lymphedema, severe}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c6::Skin disorders, ex. overlying psoriatic plaques}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c7::No prior imaging (monoarticular arthritis of unknown etiology)}}</div><div>{{c7::Uncontrolled diabetes (A1c &gt; 9)}}</div><div>{{c7::Directly prior to a surgical implant}}<br></div><div>{{c8::Osteochondral fracture or cartilage injury (impedes healing)}}</div><div>{{c8::Osteoperosis of adjacent bone, severe}}<br></div><div>{{c9::Immunocompromised patient}}<br></div>"																					
<b>Possible Side Effects of Corticosteroids (oral or injection)</b><div><br></div><div><u>Local:</u></div><div>{{c1::Infection}}</div><div>{{c2::Subcutaneous fat atrophy}}</div><div>{{c3::Skin depigmentation}}</div><div>{{c4::Tendon rupture}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Systemic:</u></div><div>{{c5::Impaired glucose tolerance}}</div>	<div>Skin flushing</div><div>Menstrual irregularity (high doses)</div><div>Osteoporosis (prolonged use)</div><div>Psychosis (high doses)</div><div>Steroid arthropathy</div><div>Adrenal suppression</div><div>Immunosuppression (high, chronic doses)</div><div>Avascular necrosis</div>																				
"{{c1::Triamcinolone::corticosteroid}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is more likely to cause tissue atrophy than methylprednisolone when injecting superficial structures</span>"																					
"<div><b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hyaluronan or hyaluronic acid (</span>HA</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>)</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">a large, linear&nbsp;</span>{{c1::glycosaminoglycan}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;that is a major component of the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::synovial}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::cartilage}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;extracellular matrix.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is important for joint lubrication, tissue hydration, and protein homeostasis</span><br></div>"																					
"<b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Hyaluronan or hyaluronic acid (</span>HA</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>)</b></span><div><br></div><div><u>Benefits</u>&nbsp;</div><div>enhanced {{c1::endogenous&nbsp;HA&nbsp;synthesis}}&nbsp;by synovial cells</div><div>{{c2::proteoglycan synthesis}} by chondrocytes</div><div>{{c3::analgesic effects (and anti-inflammatory effects)}}&nbsp;</div>"	"Several formulations of hyaluronan and high molecular weight hyaluronan have been&nbsp;FDA-approved&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>to treat symptomatic&nbsp;OA&nbsp;of the knees that has failed more conservative measures</div><div><br></div><div>Use caution with patients with allergy to products from birds such as feathers, eggs, or poultry.</div><div><br></div><div>Side effects are the same as with any type of injection.</div><div><br></div><div>Duration of pain relief can last as long as 6 months</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">rare complication is an </span><font color=""#fc0507"">acute postinjection flare</font><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">, termed <b>pseudoseptic reaction</b></span><br></div>"																				
<b>Waddell’s signs: </b>detects non-organic back pain&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Demonstration of more than {{c1::3}} signs may be cause for suspicion</div><div><br></div><div>{{c2::Distraction}}</div><div>{{c3::Over-reaction}}</div><div>{{c4::regionalization}}</div><div>{{c5::simulation}}</div><div>{{c6::tenderness}}</div>	"<div>These signs can be remembered with the acronym&nbsp;<b>DO&nbsp;ReST</b></div><div><br></div><div>Be aware that an organic component is not excluded with positive Waddell’s signs</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-03-30 at 3.54.44 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Heel cushion-relief/excavation}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><br><div><img src=""61XSBH9+eYL._AC_SL1200_.jpg""><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">A soft pad with excavation under the painful part of the heel (e.g., a calcaneal spur)</span><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>A
calcaneal bar is recommended for cases in which the foot
is too sensitive to tolerate a pad inside the shoe&nbsp;</div><div>and the
heel pain is associated with a chronic condition.&nbsp;</div><div>The same can be accomplished with a shoe that has a
spring for the heel set on the anterior calcaneus&nbsp;</div><div>The application of a rocker bottom shoe can also
be used to help initiate heel strike anterior and the&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"{{c1::Metatarsal pads}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: used for&nbsp;</span>{{c2::forefoot (metatarsal}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;pain)</span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 8.58.00 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Dome-shaped pads glued to the inner sole with the apex under the metatarsal shafts.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It relieves pressure from the metatarsal heads by transferring the load to the metatarsal shafts</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">may aslo use metatarsal bar or rocker bottom</span></div>"																				
"<strong>Internal heel wedges</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Can be applied medially for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::pes planus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;or laterally for&nbsp;</span>{{c2::medial compartment oa}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br><div><img src=""51-FxheVE1S.jpg""><br></div>"																					
"{{c1::Toe crest}}: typically for hammer toes<div><img src=""Dr-Foot-Silicone-Gel-Toe-Crest-Ring-Sleeve-Pad-Cushion-Hammer-Claw-Mallet-Toes-Toe-Straightener_621cdc33-c4d5-4530-.png""><br></div>"	Used to relieve pressure at the distal end and plantar surface of the toes&nbsp;																				
"<div><b>{{c1::University of California Biomechanics Lab (UCBL) orthosis}}:&nbsp;</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Custom-molded orthosis used to control</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::flexible calcaneal deformities (rearfoot valgus or varus)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::excessive pronation ""flat foot""}}</div><div>{{c4::transverse plane deformities of the midtarsal joints (forefoot abduction or adduction) ""in-toeing and out-toeing""}}</div>"	"<img src=""d973f5_b57a8fc8d60b415986c323db89026985~mv2.jpg""><div><div>It encompasses the heel and hindfoot and holds the midfoot with high medial and lateral trim lines.</div><div>It provides effective longitudinal arch support and realigns a flexible flat foot.</div><div>It allows for subtalar supination, holds the calcaneus in place, and prevents subtalar pronation.<br></div><div><img src=""in-toeing-children.jpg""><img src=""7ef49-rearfoot2bvalgus.png""><br></div></div>"																				
<div>{{c2::Rocker bar}}: This is a convex strip placed across the sole just posterior to the metatarsal heads. It is longer than the metatarsal bar.</div><div><br></div><div>It can be used to relieve metatarsal pain (by relieving pressure), quicken the gait cycle (by assisting rollover during stance),&nbsp;</div><div>or assist {{c1::dorsiflexion (decrease demand on weak plantar flexors (push off))}}</div><div><br></div><div>also been recommended for use in cases of plantar fasciitis, neuropathic ulceration, and trauma to the midfoot or metatarsal region.</div>	"<div>improves push off</div><img src=""shoes-20-320.jpg"">"																				
"<strong>Heel extension</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">: Can project anteriorly either medially aka (</span>{{c1::Thomas}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;heel) to provide support to the medial longitudinal arch</span>"	"<img src=""https://o.quizlet.com/OupKVWaPnODNkLMV1Tudow.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Biomechanical application of force and counterforce principle</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">in all orthotic devices,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;points of pressure are needed&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_ufig6_2.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c2::Posterior Leaf Spring (PLS)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:</span></b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Most flexible plastic&nbsp;</span>AFO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;with a very thin plastic band behind the ankle&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">allowing the patient to overpower the brace during the push-off/plantar flexion phase,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">yet allowing dorsiflexion assist and positioning of the foot during the swing phase.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">This design is typically used for&nbsp;</span>{{c1::flaccid foot drop}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 10.21.01 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 10.30.35 PM.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::Semirigid}}</b><strong>&nbsp;plastic&nbsp;AFO</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Trim line is just behind the malleoli and provides increased&nbsp;</span>{{c2::ML}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;stability of the ankle and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::dorsiflexion}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;positioning of the foot.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Less motion is allowed with this brace design, and the patient cannot&nbsp;</span>{{c3::easily propel during push-off}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">This design is most commonly used for patients who have a&nbsp;</span>{{c4::foot drop}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;with some&nbsp;</span>{{c5::extensor tone}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and/or&nbsp;</span>{{c5::ML<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;instability of the ankle</span>}}</div>"	"<div>or heavier person&nbsp;</div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 10.31.58 PM.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::Rigid (solid)}}</b><strong>&nbsp;plastic&nbsp;AFO</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Trim line at the malleoli or anterior to the malleoli with no motion allowed at the tibiotalar or subtalar joint.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Commonly used for patients with the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::highest levels of spasticity/tone}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or when&nbsp;</span>{{c3::complete immobilization of the ankle (post op/charcot)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is necessary</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The standard solid plastic&nbsp;</span>AFO<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;would typically have a foot plate extending through the metatarsal heads (three-fourth-length foot plate),&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">but if the toes are spastic and claw into a flex position a full foot plate should be used.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Inhibitory foot plate designs are used, which put the toes into extension to help reduce tone throughout the entire limb.&nbsp;</span></div><div><img src=""https://o.quizlet.com/y.2uDz2pN0my5FeivIDQaw.png""><img src=""1-s2.0-S0958259222000219-gr1.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""1-s2.0-S0958259222000219-gr7.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Solid AFOs set at {{c1::90}} degrees are commonly used for foot
drop&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Less obvious but equally important is ’the ability of
the solid AFO to treat conditions affecting the knee.&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Again,
remember that plantar flexion creates knee extension and dorsiflexion creates knee flexion at heel strike</span>.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>The AFO can be
fixed in a few degrees of plantar flexion to provide stability
at the knee during the stance phase of gait.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Genu recurvatum can also be treated with a solid AFO. The more rigid
the AFO, the greater the flexion moment at the knee at heel
strike??</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>Hinged Plastic AFOs</b></div><div><br></div><div>allow full or partial ankle motion, which can permit
a {{c5::more natural gait}}.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>They should be considered when {{c1::complete restriction of ankle motion is not required}}.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>hinging an AFO adds&nbsp;{{c3::mediolateral stability}}.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>consider prescribing for {{c2::children}} with {{c2::spasticity}}
with a {{c4::tendency toward inversion}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>or for a patient with
multiplanar ankle and subtalar flaccidity accompanying a
foot drop with a history of {{c4::twisting the ankle}}</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div>single midline posterior pin/spring mechanism&nbsp;functions like the more traditional medial and lateral dual posterior spring assist mechanism&nbsp;<br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 10.51.06 PM.png""><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 800;"">Plastic Ankle-Foot Orthoses Varus-Valgus Control&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div><div><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>An equinovarus (or inversion) deformity is controlled
by applying forces medially at the {{c1::metatarsal head}} area and
{{c1::calcaneus}}.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>The next force is applied more proximally along
the lateral aspect of the {{c2::distal fibula}} using a padded lateral {{c3::flange}}.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>This helps prevent inversion at the subtalar and
ankle joints.&nbsp;</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"A more proximal medial tibial force is applied to provide stabilization of the leg portion of the plastic AFO by providing an opposing force to the fibular area&nbsp;<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 11.05.43 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 11.09.50 PM.png"">"																				
"<div><div><div><div><div><b>carbon fiber
AFOs</b></div><div><br></div><div>advantages of
carbon fiber AFOs are lighter weight, lower profile footplate,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and the ability to provide some {{c1::propulsion}} to substitute for {{c1::weak plantar flexors}}.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Unlike custom plastic AFOs, most carbon fiber AFOs are
{{c2::prefabricated}}</div><div><br></div><div><div>The disadvantages include poor mediolateral control and the lack of adjustability.&nbsp;</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>&nbsp;therefore the patient can have a trial walk with the brace before fit and delivery&nbsp;<br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 11.16.56 PM.png"">"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700; font-style: italic;"">Patellar Tendon Bearing Ankle-Foot Orthoses</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700; font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Most of the
weight bearing is distributed throughout the {{c2::soft tissues}} of
the leg</div><div><br></div><div>A custom-molded PTB AFO can reduce weight
bearing in the affected foot by up to {{c1::50}}%&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>often prescribed for diabetic ulcerations
of the foot, tibial fractures,&nbsp;</div><div>relief of the weight-bearing
surface in painful heel conditions, such as calcaneal fractures, postoperative ankle fusions, and AVN</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-27 at 11.24.56 PM.png"">"																				
"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""font-weight: 700; font-style: italic;"">Charcot Relief Orthotic Walker Boot</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 700; font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>fully padded on the inside with total contact of
the foot, ankle, and leg.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>has a {{c1::rocker bottom}}
and rubber sole for indoor and outdoor ambulation.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>CROW Boot is indicated temporarily
for {{c2::wound healing}}, but may be needed permanently for
{{c3::Charcot joint}}&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: 700; font-style: italic;""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<img src=""crow-walker-black.jpg"">"																				
"<strong>Single channel ankle joints,&nbsp;</strong><b><font color=""#0b6aff"">posterior pin</font></b><div><br></div><div><u>function</u></div><div>{{c1::limits plantar flexion}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>indication</u></div><div>{{c2::plantar spastictiy}}</div><div>{{c3::painful anke ROM}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 6.51.39 AM.png""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 6.52.09 AM.png"">"																				
"<div><strong>Single channel ankle joints, <font color=""#0b6aff"">posterior</font></strong><font color=""#0b6aff"">&nbsp;<b>spring</b></font>&nbsp;(Klenzak joint)</div><div><br></div><div><u>function</u></div><div>{{c1::assists dorsiflexion}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>indication</u></div><div>{{c2::flaccid foot drop}}</div><div>{{c3::knee hyper-extension}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 6.51.39 AM.png""></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.06.49 AM.png""><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 6.52.09 AM.png"">"																				
"<div><strong>Single channel ankle joints,</strong>&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0b6aff"">anterior pin</font></b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>function</u></div><div>{{c1::limits dorsiflexion}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>indication</u>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::weak gastroc (aids push-off)}}</div><div>{{c2::weak knee extensors}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 6.51.39 AM.png""></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.10.06 AM.png""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 6.52.09 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::Dual channel}}</b><strong>&nbsp;ankle joints</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;have both posterior and anterior channels.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The posterior channel functions exactly the same as a single channel joint described earlier.&nbsp;</span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The anterior channel provides the additional option of an adjustable steel pin to block the forward progression of the tibia at midstance (dorsiflexion stop),&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">or to lock the joint in a fixed position. This can be useful when the quadriceps muscle is weak or when there is Charcot joint deformity at the ankle</span></div>"																				
<b>PLASTIC VERSUS METAL&nbsp;AFO</b><div><br></div><div>Plastic&nbsp;AFOs&nbsp;benefits: lightweight, intimate fit, cosmetic appeal, lack of attachment to the shoe</div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>metal&nbsp;AFO&nbsp;should be considered</u></div><div>{{c1::risk of skin breakdown}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::insensate foot (due to peripheral neuropathy or peripheral nerve injury)}}&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::fluctuating edema (not able to be managed with compression stockings)}}</div><div>{{c4::obesity}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.16.42 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>Knee–Ankle–Foot Orthoses</b><div><br></div><div><u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">A&nbsp;</span>{{c1::free motion}}<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;knee joint</span></u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">provides unlimited flexion but usually has a stop to prevent&nbsp;</span>{{c2::hyperextension}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Used for patients with genu recurvatum but with enough strength to control the knee in stance and ambulation</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.28.21 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>Knee–Ankle–Foot Orthoses</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>{{c1::posterior offset}}<span style=""font-style: italic;"">&nbsp;knee joint</span></u>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>patient’s weight line falls anterior to the joint, {{c2::stabilizing the knee}} during the early stance phase.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>It is free to flex during the swing phase and allows sitting without the need to manipulate the lock.</div><div><br></div><div>good option for an obese patient with {{c3::quadriceps}} weakness but still some {{c3::hip extensor}} strength&nbsp;<br></div>"	"<div>It should not be used in patients with knee or hip flexion contractures, or with a plantar flexion stop at the ankle.<br></div><div>The patient must be careful when walking on a ramp as the knee may flex inadvertently.<br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.30.03 AM.png"">"																				
"<div><b>Knee–Ankle–Foot Orthoses</b><br></div><div><br></div><u>{{c1::Ratchet}}</u><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>&nbsp;knee joints</u>:</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;are usually used to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::stretch out knee flexion contractures}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The rachet joint locks every 7 degrees to 10 degrees from 90 degrees of flexion to full extension</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">becoming the most popular lock&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.36.14 AM.png""><br></div></div>"																				
"<b>Knee–Ankle–Foot Orthoses</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u>{{c1::bail lock}} knee joint</u></div><div><br></div><div>engages when the knee is {{c2::fully extended}};&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>there is a semicircular lever (bail) attached posteriorly that simultaneously unlocks the ML joints with an upward pull</div><div><br></div><div>(either manually or by backing up to sit down on a chair)</div>"	"<div>Disadvantages: The bail is bulky and can be accidentally released if it hits a rigid object.<br></div><div><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.40.21 AM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.42.12 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>Knee–Ankle–Foot Orthoses</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">adjustable knee lock joint (aka&nbsp;</span>{{c1::dial lock}}<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">)</span></u><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">has a serrated adjustable knee joint that permits locking in almost any degree of flexion</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">It is useful in patients with a&nbsp;</span>{{c2::knee flexion contracture}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;that is diminishing with treatment</span><b><br></b></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 7.45.36 AM.png"">"																				
"<b>Knee–Ankle–Foot Orthoses</b><br><div><strong><br></strong></div><div>{{c1::polycentric}} knee joint:<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;provides unlimited knee flexion and extension but has significant added weight and requires maintenance</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>uses a double-axis system to
simulate the movements of the femur
and tibia at the knee joint<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Although this
concept is theoretically sound,&nbsp;</div><div>the polycentric knee joint
has not proved to be advantageous over the straight set
knee joint, and it is less commonly used.&nbsp;</div><div>It also adds bulk
to the orthosis. It is most frequently used in sport knee
orthoses.&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 9.32.08 AM.png""><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"																				
"<b>Knee–Ankle–Foot Orthoses</b><div><br><div>{{c1::Drop lock}}<span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;knee joints</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;have rings that drop over the joints in extension.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">activated either by gravity or with assistance from the patient</span></div></div>"	"drop down and can allow ex 30 degrees of knee flexion for descending stairs&nbsp;<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 9.38.21 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>SCOTT-CRAIG LONG LEG BRACE</b><div><br></div><div><u>Components</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Sole plate (extending to the metatarsal heads, crossbar for ML stabilization)}}</div><div>Ankle joint set at {{c2::10}} degrees of dorsiflexion</div><div>{{c4::Anterior}} rigid tibial band (patellar tendon strap)</div><div>{{c3::Offset}} knee joint with {{c3::bail lock}}</div><div>Proximal {{c4::posterior}} thigh band</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_14.png"">"																				
<b>{{c2::SCOTT-CRAIG}}&nbsp;LONG LEG BRACE</b><div><br></div><div>Bilateral&nbsp;KAFOs&nbsp;designed for standing and ambulation in adults with paraplegia</div><div><br></div><div>Provides patient who has a complete neurological level at {{c1::L1}} or lower with a more functional gait</div><div><br></div><div>Paraplegic patients can ambulate using a {{c3::swing-to or swing-through}} gait pattern</div>	"It eliminates unnecessary hardware to reduce weight and facilitate donning/doffing (eliminates the lower thigh and calf band).<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-04-28 at 11.30.03 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Unsupported&nbsp;</span>{{c1::standing}}&nbsp;is possible with <u>Scott-Craig orthoses</u></div><div><br></div><div>With the ankles and knees locked,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>hip stabilization can be achieved by leaning the trunk backward so that the&nbsp;COG&nbsp;of the trunk rests posterior to the hip joint,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>resulting in tightening of the anterior hip capsule and the {{c2::“Y” ligament (iliofemoral ligament, ligament of Bigelow)}}</div><div><br></div><div>usually strong/stable enough to provide hip-pelvic stability when using a&nbsp;KAFO&nbsp;without pelvic bands.</div>"	"<div><img src=""https://o.quizlet.com/zxJPKr8NKUwnlxUQoAbp1g.jpg""><br></div><img src=""31-38.jpg"">"																				
Rigid AFO with anterior shell blocks ankle motion in all 3 planes&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>and also reduces {{c1::knee flexion}} in stance phase&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""1-s2.0-S0958259222000219-gr7.jpg"">"																				
<b>Hip–Knee–Ankle–Foot Orthosis</b><div><br></div><div>A hip joint and pelvic band attached to the lateral upright of a&nbsp;KAFO&nbsp;convert it to a hip–knee–ankle–foot orthosis (HKAFO).</div><div><br></div><div>Indication: essentialy any {{c1::hip weakness (Complete paralysis of the leg)}}</div>	"<div>Hip flexion/extension instability</div><div>Hip adduction/abduction weakness</div><div>Hip internal rotation/external rotation instability</div><div>Complete paralysis of the leg</div><div><img src=""Orlando-HKAFO_6045.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>{{c4::reciprocal gait orthosis&nbsp;(RGO)}}&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div>used for upper lumbar paralysis in which active {{c1::hip flexion}} is preserved</div><div><br></div><div>hip joints are coupled together with cables (or to the pivoting pelvic band [IRGO]),&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>As a step is initiated and hip flexion takes place on one side,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>the cable coupling induces {{c2::hip extension}} on the opposite side, producing a reciprocal walking pattern</div><div><br></div><div>Forward stepping is achieved by active hip flexion, and {{c3::lower abdominal muscles (and/or trunk extension)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Using two crutches and an&nbsp;RGO, paraplegics can ambulate with a {{c5::four-point}} gait</div>	"A&nbsp;RGO&nbsp;consists of:&nbsp;<div>bilateral&nbsp;HKAFOs</div><div>offset knee joints with drop locks</div><div>posterior plastic&nbsp;AFOs, thigh pieces, custom-molded pelvic girdle</div><div>hip joints, and a thoracic extension with Velcro straps in addition to the control mechanism</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_15.png""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Adding a&nbsp;</span>{{c1::footplate}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to a knee immobilizer decreases the rotational instability of the knee</span>"																					
<b>{{c1::Patten-Bottom}} Orthosis:</b><div><br></div><div>Uses uprights with no ankle joint that terminate in a floor pad distal to the shoe so the foot is freely suspended in midair</div><div><br></div><div>A {{c2::shoe lift}} is needed on the opposite side to equalize leg length</div>	"<img src=""31157927600_13f9f0d708.jpg"">"																				
<b>Rationales for Efficacy of Tone-Reducing Orthoses</b><div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Inhibition of reflexes}}</div><div>2. {{c2::Pressure over muscle insertions}}</div><div>3. {{c3::Active and static prolonged stretch}}</div><div>4. {{c4::Orthokinetics}}</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_18.png"">"																				
<b>Complications Associated With Static Orthosis Use</b><div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Skin breakdown}}</div><div>2. {{c2::Contractures}}</div><div>3. {{c1::Infection}}</div>																					
"<div><div>Basic {{c1::opponens}} splint</div></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_20.png"">"	Primarily used to immobilize the thumb and first&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joint to promote tissue healing and/or protection&nbsp;<div>or for positioning of the weak thumb in opposition to other fingers to facilitate three-jaw chuck pinch</div><div><br></div><div>Hand–thumb orthoses consist of a dorsal and a palmar bar encircling the hand,&nbsp;</div><div>with a thumb abduction bar and C-bar to stabilize the thumb.</div>																				
"<div><div>{{c1::Long opponens}} splint&nbsp;</div></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_21.png"">"	"Similar to short opponens orthosis but crosses the wrist.&nbsp;<div>Stabilizes first&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;while forearm bar maintains wrist in extension and prevents radial and ulnar-deviation deformities.</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Examples</span>: Long opponens splints (<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch06#fig6_21"">Figure 6–21</a>) and thumb spica splints</div>"																				
<b>OPPONENS ORTHOSIS WITH LUMBRICAL BAR</b><div><br></div><div>Hand–finger orthosis (HFO) that prevents&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joint hyper-{{c1::extension}} but allows full&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;{{c1::flexion}}</div><div><br></div><div>Prevents {{c2::claw hand}} deformity (in addition to the benefits already mentioned for opponens orthoses)</div>	"<img src=""maxresdefault-1bf00d2d227a262064ca7b37c43f08833714722b.jpg"">"																				
<b>OPPONENS ORTHOSIS WITH FINGER EXTENSION ASSIST ASSEMBLY</b><div><br></div><div>Similar to basic opponens orthoses but adds outriggers that assist&nbsp;{{c1::PIP}}&nbsp;and&nbsp;{{c1::DIP}}&nbsp;joint extension</div><div><br></div><div>Used for interphalangeal (IP) {{c2::flexion contracture}}, boutonnière deformity, or postsurgical release of {{c3::Dupuytren’s contracture}}</div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-04 at 8.18.25 PM.png""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Splint for an intraarticular fracture,
such as a hand-based PIP
extension splint with an outrigger,&nbsp;</div><div>which gives constant longitudinal
traction although the joint is
gently moved&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Finger-extension-assist-orthosis2.jpg""><img src=""UM2.2_image.jpg""></div></div></div></div></div></div>"																				
<b>FINGER STABILIZERS/STATIC FINGER ORTHOSES</b><div><br></div><div>IP&nbsp;orthoses (DIP,&nbsp;PIP, and&nbsp;DIP&nbsp;+&nbsp;PIP&nbsp;gutter splints, static finger splints, aluminum and foam splints)</div><div><br></div><div>Finger orthoses are used to restrict motions at the&nbsp;PIP&nbsp;and&nbsp;DIP.</div><div><br></div><div>Generally,&nbsp;IP&nbsp;maintained in {{c1::full extension}} to keep the collateral ligaments stretched and to prevent&nbsp;IP&nbsp;flexion contracture&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Used to promote healing (e.g., phalanx fracture,&nbsp;PIP/DIP&nbsp;dislocation) and to provide {{c2::prolonged finger stretch}} (e.g., burns and contractures</div>																					
<b>RING ORTHOSES</b><div><br></div><div>Swan neck ring splint: {{c1::Flexes}} the&nbsp;{{c2::PIP}}&nbsp;joint&nbsp;</div>	"<div>A</div><div>(Prevents PIP hyperextension) but allows full&nbsp;IP&nbsp;flexion through a three-point pressure system&nbsp;</div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_22.png""><div><img src=""images-95bafea7c72b0b8dd6fc8857b8302abe9f0d804c.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>RING ORTHOSES</b><div><br></div><div>Boutonnière ring splint: Immobilizes the&nbsp;{{c1::PIP}} joint&nbsp;in {{c1::extension}}&nbsp;</div>	"<div><img src=""images-d94c340a00b2b6c042364442575b49014f08c3df.jpg""><br></div><div>and prevents flexion through a three-point pressure system<br></div><img src=""https://connect.springerpub.com/binary/sgrworks/aba676ea1d3c18f6/d004351112575dd4201c0458c49c0f89d82e9ea93f257121bf219bd31af8b79d/9780826134578_fig6_22.png"">"																				
"<div><div>{{c1::Ulnar-deviation correction}} splint</div></div><img src=""https://connect.springerpub.com/binary/sgrworks/62aa8486e3a434b6/7755c51d8119f565662fd518167ca2a0ccaff0efc61546708be5e75191c068bc/9780826134578_fig6_23.png""><img src=""radial-image-2.jpg"">"																					
<b>MCP&nbsp;ULNAR-DEVIATION RESTRICTION ORTHOSIS&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div>Used to limit ulnar deviation of the&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;with unrestricted (if possible)&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;flex/extension&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>in {{c1::rheumatoid / arthritic}} patients with ulnar deviation at the&nbsp;MCP</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_23.png"">"																				
<b>THUMB {{c1::CARPOMETACARPAL STABILIZERS (THUMB POSTS)::2}}</b><div><br></div><div>similar to opponens othosis but lower profile&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Thumb orthosis that stabilizes the first carpometacarpal (CMC) and&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joints in neutral position&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>to protect the thumb from inadvertent motion</div>	"<div>THUMB CARPOMETACARPAL STABILIZERS/THUMB POSTS<br></div><img src=""2b0956d4-8c2a-4723-b2fa-aac0c10b21b2.__CR0,0,970,600_PT0_SX970_V1___.jpg"">"																				
"<b>C-bar<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;splint</span></b><div><br></div><div>Hand-finger orthosis that consists of a rigid C-shaped splint held firmly in the thumb and index finger&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Function: Increases or maintains the {{c1::thenar web space}}</div><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>Uses:</u></div><div>{{c3::Burns}}</div><div>postsurgical {{c4::revision of scar}}</div><div><div>prevents {{c2::web-space contractures}}</div></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_24.png"">"																				
"{{c1::C-bar splint (thenar web spacer)}}<br><div><img src=""3-s2.0-B9780323483230000159-f015-009-9780323483230.jpg""><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Uses: Burns, postsurgical revision of scar, webspace contracture</span>"																				
<b>Wrist–Hand–Finger Orthoses</b><div><br></div><div><u>RESTING HAND SPLINTS</u></div><div><br></div><div>Static wrist–hand–finger orthosis (WHFO) used to immobilize the wrist, fingers, and thumb</div><div><br></div><div>Wrist in {{c3::neutral (to slight extension)}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>digits in a/an {{c1::intrinsic plus position}} (MCPs&nbsp;{{c2::flexed}} to {{c2::70–90}} degrees, IPs in {{c2::full extension}})&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>thumb&nbsp;CMC&nbsp;in {{c4::palmar abduction}}, and thumb&nbsp;MCP/IP&nbsp;in full extension</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-05 at 9.15.30 AM.png"">"																				
<div><u>{{c1::RESTING HAND}}&nbsp;SPLINTS</u><br></div><div><br></div><div>aka Static {{c2::wrist–hand–finger orthosis (WHFO)}} used to immobilize the wrist, fingers, and thumb</div><div><br></div><div>minimizing future {{c3::joint capsule contractures}}</div><div><br></div><div>Provides functional thumb position for {{c4::opposition}} and {{c5::three-jaw chuck pinch}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-05 at 9.15.30 AM.png""><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>muscle tone, orthotic
devices should be designed to prevent deformities and to
help adjust muscle tone.&nbsp;</div><div>Resting and positioning orthotic
devices are also necessary to help prevent complications,&nbsp;</div><div>such as distal edema, joint subluxation, and contracture
formation.&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<b>VOLAR WRIST–HAND ORTHOSIS (WRIST COCK-UP SPLINT)</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u><br></u></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Uses</span>:</u></div><div>carpal tunnel syndrome<br></div><div>resting wrist and hand in following {{c1::injuries (arthritis, wrist sprain/contusion, flexor/extensor tendinitis)}}</div>"	"<div>Wrist–hand orthosis (WHO) extending from distal two-thirds of forearm to just proximal to&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joint&nbsp;</div><div>to allow full&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;flexion while maintaining the functional position of the wrist and hand</div><div><br></div><div>postsurgical wrist extensor tendon repair, wrist fusion, skin grafting, contracture prevention,</div><div>reduce spasticity, prevent ulnar/radial deviation of the wrist/hand (e.g.,&nbsp;RA), TFCC tear&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""terafoam_wrist_cock-up_brace-edit_3.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>DORSAL WRIST-HAND ORTHOSES</b><div><br></div><div>Provide the same functions of the volar&nbsp;WHO (cock-up splint)&nbsp;with greater {{c1::stabilization (because of rigid dorsal hand section)}}</div><div><br></div><div>More difficult to fabricate and fit than the volar&nbsp;WHO</div>	"<strong>Dorsal Blocking Orthosis for management of post-operative flexor tendon and peripheral nerve rehabilitation</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">dorsally placed immobilization orthosis designed to protect the sutured/repaired flexor tendons and/or nerves in a tension free position.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Other names for this splint include Extension Block Splint, Dorsal shell, and Dorsal Protective splint.</span></div><div><img src=""Dorsal-cock-up-orthosis-Orfit-Eco_B_HR-e1524833282936.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><div>most common pathologies of the wrist that benefit from this orthosis include: <u>(similar to volar splint)</u></div><div>-Fractures</div><div>-Nerve compressions (Carpal tunnel syndrome)</div><div>-Wrist sprains</div><div>-Post-surgical conditions</div><div>-Spasticity</div><div>Some distinct advantages of the dorsal design are that it leaves the <b>volar palm free for sensory input,</b>&nbsp;</div><div>and it acts as a strong lever to help lift a spastic flexed wrist into a more functional and beneficial position.&nbsp;</div><div>The dorsal design allows for <font color=""#0b6aff"">functional activities to be performed easily</font> without the interference of the orthosis</div></div>"																				
"<div><b>Finger / Thumb Mobilization Orthoses</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div>primarily used for finger / thumb {{c1::contractures}}</div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><font color=""#0b6aff""><b>Dynamic:</b></font> Provides an elastic force to
help regain
joint motion&nbsp;</div></div></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-08 at 7.45.22 AM.png""><br></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><br></div><div><b><font color=""#0b6aff"">Serial static</font></b>: periodically
changed to alter the joint angle</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-08 at 7.47.00 AM.png"">&nbsp;</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div></div><br><div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><b>IP&nbsp;extension-mobilization orthosis</b></span><b>&nbsp;passively extend the&nbsp;PIP&nbsp;joints.</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Uses</u></span>:&nbsp;</div><div>Finger&nbsp;IP&nbsp;flexion contracture, boutonnière deformity, and postsurgical release of Dupuytren’s contracture</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Examples</u></span>:&nbsp;</div><div>Dynamic&nbsp;IP&nbsp;extension splints, reverse finger-knuckle benders, Capener splints, spring coil assist, eggshell finger extension casts, buddy splints</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><b><span style=""font-style: italic;"">IP&nbsp;flexion-mobilization orthoses</span>&nbsp;passively flex&nbsp;PIP&nbsp;joints.</b></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Use</span>:&nbsp;</u></div><div>Finger&nbsp;IP&nbsp;extension contracture</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Examples</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Dynamic&nbsp;IP&nbsp;flexion splints, finger-knuckle benders, fingernail hook orthoses, buddy splints</div></div>"																				
"<b>MCP&nbsp;Mobilization Orthoses,&nbsp;</b><span style=""font-style: italic;"">extension-mobilization orthoses</span>: (Extends&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joints)<div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Uses</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Extend&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joints in&nbsp;MCP{{c1::-flexion contractures}}, ie burns</div><div>s/p ORIF of metacarpal fracture / tendon surgeries&nbsp;</div><div>as well as patients with {{c2::weak finger extension (e.g., radial nerve or brachial plexus lesion)}}</div>"	"<div>for radial nerve palsy</div><img src=""Distal-radial-nerve-orthosis-with-springs-on-all-fingers-e1622707908724.jpg""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-08 at 7.54.56 AM.png""></div><div>post op tendon surgery&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Extensor-tendon-mobilization-orthosis-with-Orfitube-e1622707964328.jpg""><br><div><br><div><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Examples</span>:&nbsp;</div><div>Reverse&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;knuckle benders</div><div>dynamic&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;extension splints with dorsal outrigger</div><div>MCP&nbsp;extension assists, radial nerve splints<br></div></div></div>"																				
"<b>MCP&nbsp;Mobilization Orthoses,&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;flexion mobilization orthoses: (Flex&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joints)</b><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Uses</span>:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Flex&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joints in&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;collateral ligament contractures, extensor tendon shortening,&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::median/ulnar lesion (claw hand)}},&nbsp;</div><div>postcapsulotomy, post-ORIF&nbsp;of metacarpal fracture</div><div>{{c2::flexor tendon (or surgery)}} injury</div>"	"<span style=""font-style: italic;"">Examples</span>:&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;knuckle benders, dynamic&nbsp;MCP-flexion splints with volar outrigger and fingernail hooks,&nbsp;MCP-flexion assists<div><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>Dynamic motion-
blocking
</b></div>
</div>
<div>
<div>Allows certain motions but blocks
others.&nbsp;</div><div>It uses a passive, elastic
line of pull in the desired
direction, but permits active
motion in the opposite direction</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-08 at 8.05.01 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""1-s2.0-S1569186114000199-gr2.jpg""><img src=""images-fa7665bda0b93430841a7416785b1c792856fa97.jpg""><br></div><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Unlike the serial <b>static splint</b>, the
orthosis is not remolded to
increase joint motion
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div>The MERiT static progressive
component3 (available
commercially) decreases the static
line length as it is turned, thereby
increasing the range of joint
motion
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div>Most commonly used splint for regaining joint motion<br>
Some patients may tolerate static progressive over dynamic orthosis,
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Differ from serial splints by using
nonelastic components, such as
static lines, hinges, screws, and
turnbuckles to place a force on a
joint to induce progressive change
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div>possibly due to the joint position constant while the tissue
accommodates gently and gradually to the tension, without the influence
of gravity or motion</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-08 at 8.09.32 AM.png""></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"																				
"<div><b>WIRE WRIST-EXTENSION ASSIST ORTHOSIS (OPPENHEIMER SPLINT)</b></div><div><br></div><div>Prefabricated from spring steel wire and padded steel bands to assist wrist extension by tensing the steel wire,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>thus aiding finger flexion through tenodesis effect</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Used in patients with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::radial neuropathy}}<br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(54, 43, 54);"">provides dynamic wrist, finger and thumb extension to open the hand while allowing active flexion</span><div><img src=""2011_11_04_16_41_44__14_nc44590a_W11.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(54, 43, 54);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>WRIST-DRIVEN PREHENSION ORTHOSIS (TENODESIS ORTHOSIS, FLEXOR HINGE SPLINT)</b><div><br></div><div>Used in {{c1::C6}} complete tetraplegia to provide prehension through tenodesis action and maintain flexibility of the hand</div><div><br></div><div>Wrist extensors should be {{c2::3+}} or better to use body-powered tenodesis</div><div><br></div><div><u>Disadvantages</u></div><div>PIP and DIP&nbsp;joints of the fingers 2 and 3 and the&nbsp;CMC&nbsp;and&nbsp;MCP&nbsp;joints of the thumb are immobilized</div><div>May interfere with {{c3::manual wheelchair propulsion}}</div><div>Rarely accepted by C7 and C8 tetraplegics who prefer to use residual motor power or utensil holders</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig6_25.png"">"																				
"<b>{{c1::Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago (RIC)}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;tenodesis splint</span></b><div><br></div><div>Made of low-temperature thermoplastics in three separate pieces (wristlet, short opponens, and dorsal plate over index / middle finger)</div><div><br></div><div>Easily and quickly fabricated; made as a training and evaluation splint for patients; lightweight</div><div><br></div><div>Uses a cord/string running from the wrist piece, across the palm and up between the index and ring fingers.&nbsp;</div>"	"
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>The Rehabilitation Institute of
Chicago tenodesis splint, which
assists the patient with a C6 level
of spinal cord injury to achieve a
functional pinch<br></div></div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Active extension of the wrist
produces controlled passive
flexion of the fingers against a
static thumb post through a
tenodesis action</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_26.png"">&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"																				
"<b>Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago (RIC)<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;tenodesis splint</span></b><div><br></div><div>Made of low-temperature thermoplastics in three separate pieces (wristlet, short opponens, and dorsal plate over index / middle finger)</div><div><br></div><div>Easily and quickly fabricated; made as a {{c1::training / evaluation}} splint for patients; (lightweight)</div><div><br></div><div>Uses a {{c2::cord/string}} running from the wrist piece, across the palm and up between the index and ring fingers</div><div><br></div><div>The string is lax when the wrist is flexed and tightens with wrist extension,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>bringing the fingers close to the immobilized thumb, accomplishing three-jaw chuck prehension</div>"	"<div>RIC Splint&nbsp;</div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-11 at 6.21.57 AM.png""><div>Conventional Tenodesis Splint&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-05-11 at 6.21.47 AM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b>Balanced forearm orthosis</b></div><div><br></div><div>Shoulder–elbow–wrist–hand orthosis (SEWHO) that consists of a forearm trough and a mount&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Allows patients with weak shoulder and elbow muscles to move the arm horizontally&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and flex the elbow to {{c1::bring the hand to the mouth}}&nbsp;</div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></div><div><span style=""font-style: italic;""><u>Requirements</u></span>:</div><div>Some residual muscle strength of biceps and pectoralis (MMT at least grade {{c2::2}})&nbsp;</div><div>eg. AIS grade C{{c3::5}} tetraplegic</div><div>Adequate trunk stability and balance</div><div>Adequate endurance in a sitting position</div><div>Preserved&nbsp;ROM&nbsp;of the shoulder and elbow joints</div>"	"<div>(e.g., patients with spinal cord injury, Guillain–Barré syndrome, polio, muscular dystrophy, and brachial plexus injury)<br></div><div>Other uses: May be used in spastic patients to allow self-feeding by dampening muscle tone through a friction device<br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_27.png"">"																				
<b>Elbow Orthoses</b><div><br></div><div>eg. Dynamic elbow splints, static progressive elbow splints, turnbuckle elbow splints</div><div><br></div><div>generaly used for {{c1::contractures}} and {{c1::fracture}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>not used in {{c2::spastic muscles (further increase tone)}}</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-style: italic;"">Static progressive elbow extension orthosis</span><br></div><img src=""Static-Progressive-Orthoses-101-4.jpg""><div><div>Once fabricated, a static progressive orthosis will allow the wearer to make&nbsp;<strong>small incremental changes</strong>&nbsp;in PROM</div><div>Patients get the instruction to constantly adjust and readjust the tension on their stiff joints.</div><div>Static progressive orthoses are typically worn <u>3 to 4 times per day for 30 minutes</u> at a time to reap the benefits&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>Non-elastic components</strong></div><div>Static progressive orthoses use a non-elastic component that places tension on a stiff joint to hold it at its maximum tolerable length.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>The importance of the maximal tolerable length</strong></div><div>In general, the orthotic design maintains the shortened tissue at its maximal tolerable length</div><div>The longer the tissue is held at its maximum tolerable length, the more it increases in length.&nbsp;</div><div>A successful application of a static progressive splint can be measured by gains of <u>5-10 degrees of PROM each week</u>.</div></div>"																				
"<b>Tone Reducing Orthoses</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Antispasticity ball}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;splint</span></div><div>{{c1::Hand-cone}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;splint</span><br></div>"	"<div><strong>(A)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Antispasticity “ball” splint.&nbsp;</span><strong>(B)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Hand-cone splint.</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_28.png"">"																				
<b>Tone Reducing Orthoses</b><div><br></div><div>Typically worn {{c1::2 hours}} on and {{c1::2 hours}} off throughout the day</div><div><br></div><div><u>Functions</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>Flexor tone reduction</div><div>prevent {{c2::skin breakdown/maceration (of palm by fingernails)}}</div><div>increase {{c3::passive range of motion (serial static splinting)}}</div>	"<div><strong>(A)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Antispasticity “ball” splint.&nbsp;</span><strong>(B)</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;Hand-cone splint.</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig6_28.png""><div><div>Can be either hand-based orthoses or forearm-based&nbsp;WHFOs&nbsp;</div><div>Can be volar based, dorsal based, or circumferential</div><div><br></div><div><u>Rationales of efficacy</u>:</div><div>Reflex-inhibiting positioning:&nbsp;<strong>Neurodevelopmental technique</strong>&nbsp;(NDT/Bobath) approach</div><div>Firm pressure into volar surface (palm): Rood (sensorimotor) approach</div><div><br></div><div><u>Dorsal-based splints (<b>e.g., Snook</b>)</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>Facilitation of muscle contraction by direct contact.&nbsp;</div><div>It is theorized that stimulation of extensor surface might balance muscle tone and/or avoid increased flexor tone</div></div>"																				
"{{c1::Hunner’s}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;ulcers, patches of broken skin on the bladder wall, are present in 10% of interstitial cystitis patients</span>"																					
<strong>Interstitial cystitis (</strong>Diagnosis of exclusion)<div><strong><br></strong></div><div><div>Diagnosis:&nbsp;</div><div>cystoscopy</div><div>hydrodistention</div><div>{{c1::potassium sensitivity}} test</div><div>urodynamics evaluation</div></div>	Potassium sensitivity test: K+ and water are placed into the bladder at one time.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Test is positive if the patient experiences more pain/urgency with K+ and water than with water alone</div>																				
<b>2011 American Urological Association interstitial cystitis treatment guidelines</b><div><br></div><div><u>First line:</u>&nbsp;</div><div>Patient education, diet modification, stress management</div><div><br></div><div><u>Second line</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::PT}}</div><div>{{c1::oral medications (amitriptyline, cimetidine, hydroxyzine, pentosan polysulfate)}}</div><div>{{c1::bladder instillations (DMSO, heparin, lidocaine)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Third line: Treatment of Hunner’s ulcers (laser, fulguration, triamcinolone injection), hydrodistention (low pressure, short duration)</div><div>Fourth line: Neuromodulation (sacral or pudendal nerve)</div><div>Fifth line: Cyclosporine A, Botulinum toxin</div><div>Sixth line: Surgical intervention (urinary diversion, augmentation, cystectomy)</div>																					
<div><strong>Irritable bowel syndrome</strong>:</div><div><br></div><div>Symptom-based diagnosis of abdominal pain or discomfort for {{c1::6}} months&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>and at least three {{c1::3}} per month for the last {{c1::3}} months without other diagnostic cause</div>	<u>Symptoms</u>:&nbsp;<div>Chronic abdominal pain, discomfort, bloating, urgency to move bowels, tenesmus, alteration of bowel habits (diarrhea-predominant [irritable bowel syndrome;&nbsp;IBS-D], constipation-dominant [IBS-C], or both [IBS-M]), or improvement of pain with bowel movement.&nbsp;</div><div>Onset likely to occur after an infection (IBS-PI), stressful life event, or maturity onset.</div><div><br></div><div><u>Comorbidities</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>HA, fibromyalgia, depression, or chronic fatigue syndrome</div><div><br></div><div><u>Treatment</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>Diet modification, psychotherapy, probiotics, oral medications (fiber supplements, laxatives), antidiarrheals (loperamide), antispasmodics (hyoscine, cimetropium, pinaverium), antidepressants (TCAs,&nbsp;SSRIs), or lubiprostone (Amitiza)</div>																				
<strong>Neuropathic pelvic pain</strong><div><br></div><div>refers to pain 2/2 {{c1::a specific peripheral sensory nerve}}&nbsp;</div>	"Anatomy: llioinguinal nerve (T12–L1), iliohypogastric (T12–L1), genitofemoral (L1–L2), lateral femoral cutaneous (L2–L3), obturator (L2–L4)<div><img src=""nervesaffected.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Modic Type I&nbsp;</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">the trabeculae are fractured in many places, the trabeculae are shorter and broader, and the “scaffolding” pattern is unstructured and uneven.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The marrow is substituted by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::serum}}</div>"	"<img src=""Modic-Picture.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Modic Type II</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">trabeculae are also fractured in many places but are shorter and broader and the “scaffolding” pattern is unstructured and uneven</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">changes the marrow is substituted by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::visceral fat}}</div>"	"<img src=""Modic-Picture.jpg"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><b>Modic Type III&nbsp;</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">rare, and it is essentially&nbsp;</span>{{c1::bone scar tissue}}</div>"	"<img src=""Modic-Picture.jpg""><div><br></div>"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Modic Type I:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Bright}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on T2,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::dark}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on T1</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""Modic-classification.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Modic Type II:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Bright}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on T2 and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Bright}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;T1</span>"	"<img src=""Modic-classification.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Modic type III:&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Dark}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on T2 and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Dark}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;on&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">T1</span>"	"<img src=""Modic-classification.png"">"																				
<b>Potential Spinal Injection Complications</b><div><br></div><div>Infection: 1% to 2% of spinal injections</div><div>Cardiovascular: {{c1::dysrhythmias}}</div><div>Neurological: Trauma to the spinal cord or nerve roots is a rare but serious complication</div><div>Embolic infarction of the spinal cord and brain can potentially occur with intravascular injection of {{c2::particulate steroid medications}}</div><div>Respiratory: Oversedation, spinal anesthesia</div><div>Urological: Urinary retention</div><div>{{c3::Dural puncture: &lt;0.5%. Postdural&nbsp;HA}} is a relatively benign condition</div>	Common adverse effects: Injection site pain, temporarily increased radicular pain and paresthesias without morbidity, acute anxiety, lightheadedness, diaphoresis, flushing, nausea, hypotension, and nerve injury.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Less common potential events could include vasovagal syncope and dural puncture.</div>																				
<div><b>Local anesthetic toxicity symptoms</b></div><div><br></div><div><u>Early</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Perioral and tongue paresthesias}}</div><div>{{c2::dizziness (orthostasis)}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Late</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>{{c3::Muscle twitching}}</div><div>drowsiness, CNS&nbsp;depression,&nbsp;</div><div>respiratory depression</div><div>tonic–clonic seizures,&nbsp;</div><div>bradycardia, hypotension, cardiac arrhythmia (conduction block), cardiac arrest</div>																					
"<b>Local anesthetic toxicity&nbsp;</b><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>management</u>:&nbsp;</span></div><div>ACLS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;protocols</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">cardiac arrhythmia treatment</span></div><div>{{c1::lipid emulsion}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;therapy</span></div>"																					
<b>Transforaminal approach</b>:<div><br></div><div>Places medication near the anterior epidural space and closer to the inflamed spinal nerve root</div><div><br></div><div>the infrapedicular or&nbsp;“{{c1::safe triangle}}”<strong> </strong>approach,&nbsp;</div>	"in which the target endpoint for the spinal needle is inferior to the 6 o’clock position&nbsp;<div>of the pedicle in the upper third of the neuroforamen&nbsp;in lumbar&nbsp;TF-ESIs<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig11_4.png""><br></div></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_196.png""><br></div>"
