<div><b>the borders of the safe triangle include</b></div><div><br></div><div>Superior border: {{c1::inferior pedicle}}</div><div>Lateral border: {{c1::Lateral edge of the vertebral body}}</div><div>Hypotenuse: {{c1::Spinal nerve root}}</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig11_4.png"">"																				
<b>IL&nbsp;approach:</b><div><br></div><div>A midline or paramedian approach when the patient is placed in a prone position</div><div><br></div><div>Using an&nbsp;AP&nbsp;view, an 18- or 20-gauge Tuohy or Crawford needle connected to a {{c1::loss of resistance (LOR) syringe}}</div><div><br></div><div>A midline&nbsp;IL&nbsp;approach will advance the needle through the supraspinous ligament → interspinous ligament → ligamentum flavum<br></div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig11_6.png""><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_197.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Caudal approach</b>:<div><br></div><div>After the sacral hiatus is identified under fluoroscopy, the needle is advanced through the sacral hiatus</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>The needle should not be advanced higher than the S{{c1::3}} level</div><div><br></div><div>Has the least risk for dural puncture, but the medication is diffused to the greatest degree</div>	"as the dural sac typically ends at the S2 level<div><br></div><div><div>High injectate volumes are used to treat pathologic lesions superiorly up to the L4–L5 or L5–S1 levels.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>As a result, its use and efficacy is limited.</div></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_198.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Diagnostic Medial Branch Blocks</b><div><br></div><div>A positive response is considered when there is &gt;{{c1::80}}% pain relief postprocedure.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Performing {{c2::2 (an initial and a confirmatory)}} diagnostic&nbsp;MBB&nbsp;is recommended,&nbsp;</div>	as studies have shown a high false-positive rate of &gt;50% when only a single diagnostic block is performed																				
"<b>Facet Joint Radiofrequency Ablation</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>ablating the medial branch nerves that innervate the facet, After two positive diagnostic medial branch blocks,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>the&nbsp;RF&nbsp;probe is placed {{c1::parallel::orientation}} to the medial branches that innervate the symptomatic facet joint.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">place the cannulae at the base of the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::transverse processes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::superior articular processes}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_195.png"">"																				
<strong>Intradiscal electrothermal therapy (IDET)</strong>:<div><br></div><div>blunt-tipped thermal catheter is threaded through an introducer cannula into the {{c1::nucleus}},&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>thermocoagulation across {{c1::annular fissures}} has been proposed to ablate disc nociceptors,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>remodel collagen fibers, and denature inflammatory mediators</div>	"The current literature does not show significant efficacy of&nbsp;IDET&nbsp;over placebo<div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_200.png""><br></div>"																				
"<strong>Percutaneous disc decompression</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">device is threaded through an introducer cannula into the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::nucleus pulposus}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">The&nbsp;</span>{{c1::removal of material}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;has been proposed to reduce intradiscal pressure, to unweight internal disc nociceptors or the spinal nerve roots&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(e.g., Nucleoplasty, Nucleotome, DeKompressor,&nbsp;</span>LASE<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">):</span></div>"	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_201.png"">"																				
<div><strong>Spinal cord stimulator (SCS)</strong>:&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Modulates pain signals in the spinal cord primarily through the {{c1::gate control theory::MOA}}</div><div><br></div><div>implantation should be considered only after a {{c2::successful SCS&nbsp;trial}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>electrodes are placed over the area of the {{c3::dorsal columns}} into the epidural space</div>	"<img src=""9780826134578_fig4_202.png"">"																				
<b>Epidural Lysis of Adhesions (Epidural Adhesiolysis)</b><div><br></div><div>indicated for spinal pain with or without radicular pain due to adhesions corroborated by diagnostic imaging.</div><div><br></div><div>performed by placing a semirigid catheter into the epidural space via a caudal, interlaminar, or transforaminal approach</div><div><br></div><div>It delivers {{c1::medications}} to the region of the adhesions {{c1::breakdown}} epidural fibrosis</div>	<div>Contraindications include infection, coagulopathy, and presence of arachnoiditis.</div><div><br></div><div>There is a paucity of literature and limited evidence showing efficacy in treating postsurgery syndrome.</div>																				
<b>Vertebral Augmentation</b><div><br></div><div>Goal is to provide pain relief from vertebral body compression fractures,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>for people who have minimal to no pain relief from {{c1::4}} to {{c1::6}} weeks of conservative treatments</div><div><br></div><div>This procedure is performed by placing {{c2::polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA)}} cement into the fracture site</div>	"<div>The most common etiology of a fracture is osteoporosis.&nbsp;</div><div>Other causes: metastatic disease, multiple myeloma, expanding hemangiomas, Paget’s disease, and painful (acute) Schmorl nodes.</div><div><u>Kyphoplasty</u>&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig4_203.png""><br></div>"																				
"{{c1::Vertebro}}<strong>plasty</strong><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">:&nbsp;</span><div><br></div><div>PMMA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is injected directly into the vertebral body through an introducer cannula.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Its primary focus is pain relief</span></div>"	"<img src=""Vertebroplasty-Kyphoplasty.png"">"																				
"{{c1::Kypho}}<strong>plasty<font color=""#333333"">:</font></strong><div><br></div><div>PMMA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is placed indirectly into the vertebral body through a balloon tamp/introducer cannula.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Its focus is pain relief and restoration of vertebral body height</span></div>"	"<img src=""Vertebroplasty-Kyphoplasty.png"">"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">stellate ganglion is comprised of the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">lower cervical sympathetic&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ganglia</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">upper thoracic&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">sympathetic&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ganglia</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">and is located anterolateral to the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::C7}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;vertebral body</span></div>"	"<img src=""stellateanatomy.png"">"																				
<div>stellate ganglion receives {{c1::parasympathetic}} input and transmits {{c1::sympathetic}} output&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>to the head, neck, heart, and upper extremities</div>	"<img src=""256_Figure_1.jpg"">"																				
"<b>stellate ganglion block</b><div><br></div><div>Injection target area and clinical landmark is the {{c1::Chassaignac tubercle (carotid tubercle)}} of the C6 vertebral body</div><div><br></div><div>Anomalous intrathoracic pathways known as&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">Kuntz’s nerves</span>&nbsp;can {{c2::bypass}} the stellate ganglion</div>"	"<div>resulting in incomplete sympathetic blockade<br></div><img src=""EKcas9kXsAMzaWD.jpg"">"																				
<b>stellate ganglion block</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><div><u>indications</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Chronic facial and/or cervicobrachial}} pain syndromes&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::CRPS&nbsp;type I or II}}<br></div><div>{{c3::vascular and sympathetically mediated&nbsp;HAs}}&nbsp;</div></div>	"(*Note: Stellate ganglion blocks can potentially exacerbate a migraine&nbsp;HA&nbsp;in certain situations),&nbsp;<div>vascular insufficiency/vaso-occlusive diseases (e.g.,Raynaud’s syndrome),&nbsp;</div><div>neuropathic pain syndrome, postherpetic neuralgia,&nbsp;</div><div>trigeminal neuralgia, neuropathic orofacial pain, phantom limb pain, or hyperhidrosis</div><div><img src=""rapm-2019-June-44-6-669-F1.large.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"<b>stellate ganglion block</b><div><strong><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></strong></div><div><u style="""">Complications</u>&nbsp;(even with a successful injection):</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Horner’s syndrome}}</div><div>{{c2::Hoarseness}}&nbsp;<br></div><div>{{c3::Paralysis}}</div>"	"Horner's (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, enophthalmos)<div>Hoarseness (local anesthetic spread to recurrent laryngeal nerve leading to vocal cord paralysis)<br></div><div><div>Paralysis: From brachial plexus block and epidural/subdural/intrathecal, or intravascular injection</div></div><div><div><br></div><div>Dyspnea (local anesthetic spread to phrenic nerve leading to hemidiaphragm)<br></div><div><br></div><div>Intravascular/intrathecal injection of local anesthetic potentially leading to serious complications such as seizures and cardiac arrhythmias</div><div><br></div><div>Organ injury, such as pneumothorax, esophageal perforation, vascular injuries (carotid, vertebral arteries)</div><div>Infection: Meningitis/epidural infection, cellulitis</div><div>Hematoma formation</div></div><div><img src=""17507-stellgate-ganglion-block.jpg""><br></div>"																				
"LUMBAR SYMPATHETIC BLOCKS<div><br></div><div>Sympathetically mediated pain in the lower abdominal/pelvic regions or the lower extremities can be mediated by sympathetic blockade.</div><div><strong><span style=""font-style: italic;""><br></span></strong></div><div><u>Indications</u>:</div><div>{{c1::Lower abdominal/pelvic genitourinary pain syndromes}}</div><div>{{c2::Lower extremity pain (PVD,&nbsp;CRPS&nbsp;type I or II)}}<br></div><div>{{c3::Hyperhidrosis}}</div>"	"<div><strong><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Complications</span></strong>:</div><div>Vasodilation, increased temperature, reduction of edema</div><div>Genitofemoral neuralgia with chemical neurolysis &gt; neuralgia with&nbsp;RF&nbsp;lesioning</div><div>Intravascular or subarachnoid injection</div>"																				
<b>CELIAC PLEXUS BLOCKS</b><div><br></div><div>Often indicated for controlling pain arising from the {{c1::epigastric viscera}}</div><div><br></div><div>in particular from {{c1::upper abdominal neoplasms (ie. pancreatic cancer)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Receives sympathetic fibers from the {{c2::greater, lesser, and least splanchnic nerves}}</div><div><br></div><div>Receives parasympathetic fibers from the {{c2::vagus nerve}}</div>	"<div><img src=""fig2-11.jpg""><br></div><img src=""1-s2.0-S0378603X17300724-gr1.jpg"">"																				
"<b>CELIAC PLEXUS BLOCKS</b><br><div><br></div><div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Indications</span>:</u></div><div>{{c1::Sympathetically mediated thoracic, chest wall, upper abdominal viscera pain::general}}</div></div><div><br></div><div><div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">complications</span>:</u></div><div>Similar to a stellate ganglion block; may result in an ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome,&nbsp;</div><div>pneumothorax, infection, or temporary intercostal neuritis</div></div>"	"hyperhidrosis;&nbsp;<div>intractable cardiac arrhythmia;&nbsp;<div>Prinzmetal’s angina; acute (occlusion) or chronic vascular (Raynaud’s) diseases;&nbsp;</div><div>upper extremity&nbsp;CRPS;&nbsp;</div><div>postthoracotomy pain;&nbsp;</div><div>acute herpes zoster; postherpetic neuralgia;&nbsp;</div><div>postmastectomy&nbsp;</div><div>phantom breast pain</div></div><div><img src=""Celiac_Plexus_Block.gif""><br></div>"																				
<b>SUPERIOR HYPOGASTRIC PLEXUS BLOCK</b><div><br></div><div>treatment for {{c1::chronic pelvic pain::general}} from {{c1::pelvic cancers (gynecologic, colorectal, or genitourinary)}}<div><br></div><div><div>the hypogastric plexus is located at the lower one-third of the {{c2::L5}} vertebral body, anterolateral border bilaterally</div></div></div>	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-030-87266-3_55/MediaObjects/500036_1_En_55_Fig1_HTML.png""><br></div><div>L4 and L5 spinous processes are identified and needle insertion sites are 5 to 7 cm lateral to the midline at the level of L4–L5 interspace.</div><div><br></div><div>With the bevel of the needle directed medially, two 7- to 9-inch, 22-gauge needles are inserted under fluoroscopic guidance so that the needle tips lie anterolateral to the L5–S1 intervertebral space.</div><div><br></div><div>In the&nbsp;AP&nbsp;view, the spread of contrast should be confined to the midline region.</div><div><br></div><div>In the lateral view, a smooth posterior contour corresponding to the anterior psoas fascia indicates needle is at the proper depth.</div><div><br></div><div>Diagnostic block with anesthetics and neurolytic block with phenol or alcohol</div><div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-030-87266-3_55/MediaObjects/500036_1_En_55_Fig2_HTML.png""><br></div>"																				
<b>Spinal Cord Stimulation (SCS)</b><div><br></div><div><u>indications</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Failed back surgery syndrome (FBSS)}}</div><div>{{c2::CRPS}}</div><div>{{c3::arachnoiditis}}</div>	"<div>discogenic pain refractory to conservative and surgical interventions<br></div><div><br></div>painful peripheral neuropathy, refractory angina pectoris, nonoperable ischemic limb pain, and migraine&nbsp;HA<div><img src=""Spinal-Cord-Stimulator_VU_3053102-cropped-1.jpg""><br></div>"																				
<b>Spinal cord stimulator&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div><u>Electrode insertion levels</u>:</div><div>Should be at least {{c1::2}} spine segments below target level&nbsp;</div>	"so that at least 3 inches of the lead body lies within the epidural space to maximize electrode stability<div><br></div><div>Cervical electrode placement: Below T1–T2 vertebral body level</div><div><br></div><div>Lower part of the body: T12–L1 or L1–L2</div><div><br></div><div>Upper extremity: T2–T3 or T3–T4</div><div><img src=""spinal-cord-stimulator.jpeg""><br></div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Blastic lesions typically occur in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::prostate}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;cancer (90%)</span>"	"<div><strong>Lytic lesions</strong>&nbsp;(<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch09#fig9_10"">Figure 9–10</a>) are generally considered to be more prone to fracture than blastic lesions. Lytic lesions typically occur in the following tumors:</div><div>Myeloma</div><div>Lung</div><div>Kidney</div><div>Thyroid</div><div>Malignant lymphomas</div><div>Breast</div>"																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Metastatic breast cancer can present as&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lytic or blastic}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;bone lesions.&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Approximately 60% of breast cancer bone lesions are blastic</span>"																				
{{c1::Osteosarcomas}}:<div><br></div><div>most common primary malignant bone tumor in children</div><div><br></div><div>Occur in adolescence and commonly involve the knee and proximal humerus</div>																					
"<b>WHO&nbsp;Analgesic Ladder for Cancer Pain</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Patients not on any analgesic therapy with mild/moderate pain</span><br><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Step 1&nbsp;</span>{{c1::nonopioid analgesics}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><br></div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(acetaminophen, acetylsalicylic acid [</span>ASA<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">], nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs [</span>NSAIDs<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">])</span><br></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig9_11.png"">"																				
<div><b>WHO&nbsp;Analgesic Ladder for Cancer Pain</b><br></div><br><div><div>Step 2 {{c1::opioid analgesic (“weak opioid”)}} should be added&nbsp;</div></div>	"<div>(codeine, hydrocodone, oxycodone). Included in this step is tramadol,&nbsp;</div><div>which is a centrally acting nonopioid analgesic with low affinity for mu-opioid receptors.&nbsp;</div><div>Also inhibits reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. Max dose 400 mg/day<br></div><div><img src=""9780826134578_fig9_11.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>WHO&nbsp;Analgesic Ladder for Cancer Pain&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Step 3&nbsp;</span>{{c1::strong opioid}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;when pain is severe&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><b><br></b></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(morphine, oxycodone, methadone, levorphanol, hydromorphone, fentanyl).</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Morphine is the agent of choice.&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Its dose should be maximized before other agents are added.</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><img src=""9780826134578_fig9_11.png"">"																				
"<div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Of the&nbsp;</span>NSAIDS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">,&nbsp;</span>{{c1::ketorolac}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;is the agent that has the least incidence of thrombocytopenia</span><b><br></b></div>"																					
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Breakthrough pain is treated with “rescue doses.”&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Use of short-acting, immediate release preparations is recommended (oxycodone, morphine, hydromorphone).&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Calculated as&nbsp;</span>{{c1::10}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::15}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% of the total daily opioid dose</span></div>"																					
Currently, there are no guidelines dictating how soon a feeding tube should be placed&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>or the optimal location of tube placement (gastrostomy vs. jejunostomy)</div><div><br></div><div><u>distal tube placement is preferred</u><br></div><div>pt's with {{c1::GERD}}</div><div>recurrent {{c1::pneumonia}}</div><div>possible {{c1::aspiration}}</div>	"<div>Direct gastrostomy or jejunostomy has a decreased risk of aspiration and&nbsp;GERD-related problems;&nbsp;</div><div>they are preferred when there is a potentially prolonged length of time of nonoral nutrition (<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_37"">Grahm et al., 1989</a>).</div><div><br></div><div>These direct routes should be in place for at least 30 days to decrease the complications associated with removal.</div><div><br></div><div>Percutaneous tube placement has the added advantages of lower surgical risks and the ability to start tube feeds within 24 hours of placement,&nbsp;</div><div>whereas more surgically placed tubes have mechanical parts that can more easily be inserted (during mealtimes only) and removed&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Enteral routes that allow for bolus feeding are advantageous because they more closely approximate natural feeding,&nbsp;</div><div>making daily routines and therapies more manageable, especially in patients likely to go home.</div>"																				
A high level of gastric residue was the most common feeding intolerance found in&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients<div><br></div><div>the delivery of {{c1::erythromycin}} by nasogastric tube may control&nbsp;GI&nbsp;disorders</div><div><br></div><div>although {{c1::metoclopramide}} increases gastroesophageal sphincter tone and can aid in&nbsp;GERD,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>it should be avoided due to its ability to cause sedation and extrapyramidal side effects</div>																					
<b>Parenteral Feeding</b><div><br></div><div>Intravenously delivered nutrition, usually through a central venous line, or, in limited circumstances, a peripheral line</div><div><br></div><div>Parenteral feeding can be either supplemental or primary (total parenteral nutrition).</div><div><br></div><div>utilized when a/an {{c1::segment of&nbsp;GI&nbsp;tract is nonfunctional}}&nbsp;or in any condition with a/an {{c2::increased metabolic demand}}</div>	<div>Because parenteral feeding products bypass essential&nbsp;GI&nbsp;metabolism,&nbsp;</div><div>they are made of a constitution of nutrients that must be in an elemental form.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Optimal proportions of elements within a parenteral solution vary widely and should frequently be reassessed</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>Risks of parenteral feeding include central/peripheral line complications (infection, clot formation, edema).&nbsp;</div><div>Central lines have an added risk of pneumothorax during catheter insertion.&nbsp;</div><div><b>Electrolyte and metabolic abnormalities are common</b>&nbsp;with parenteral feeding and should be closely monitored</div>																				
<b>Hypothalamic Pituitary Dysfunction</b><div><br></div><div>Some studies show rates as high as {{c1::50}}% in TBI (increased {{c2::growth hormone}} release is the most common).<br></div>	<div>Two-thirds of severe&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;mortalities with structural abnormalities occur in the hypothalamic pituitary region.</div><div><br></div><div>Originally thought to be a rare condition,</div><div><br></div><div>recent evidence suggests that a much higher percentage of&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients have anterior pituitary dysfunction.<br></div>																				
"<b>Hypothalamic Pituitary Dysfunction</b><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_28"">Ghigo et al. (2005)</a>&nbsp;have suggested an algorithm for the evaluation and treatment of people who have sustained a&nbsp;TBI</div><div><br></div><div>Recommend that all patients undergo endocrine function evaluation at {{c1::3 months}} and at {{c1::1-year}} postinjury regardless of injury severity</div><div><br></div><div><u>Recommended screening</u>:&nbsp;</div><div>{{c2::follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)}}<br></div><div>{{c2::luteinizing hormone (LH)}}</div><div>{{c2::AM&nbsp;cortisol / urinary free cortisol}}</div><div>{{c2::insulin growth factor (IGF)}}<br></div><div>{{c2::testosterone, estradiol}}</div><div>{{c2::prolactin}}</div>"	"<div>Based on the screening studies, more involved provocative testing may be ordered and possible hormone replacement<br></div><img src=""StatePearls_Pituitary_ElSayed_2016_Kathi.jpg"">"																				
<b>SIADH</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><u>treatment</u></div><div>Fluid restriction to approximately {{c1::1.0}} L/d</div>	(800 mL–1.2 L/d; either alone or with a loop diuretic)<div><br></div><div>Careful daily monitoring of weight changes and serum Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;until sodium level &gt;135 mmol/L.</div><div><br></div><div>Hypertonic saline (e.g., 3% NaCl solution)—200 to 300 mL should be infused&nbsp;IV&nbsp;over 3 to 4 hours in patients with severe symptoms&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>(Chronic&nbsp;SIADH&nbsp;may be treated with demeclocycline) salt tabs, urena, loops, and vaptans&nbsp;</div>																				
<b>Cerebral Salt Wasting Syndrome</b><div><br></div><div>It may be a more common cause of hyponatremia in&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;patients than&nbsp;SIADH.</div><div><br></div><div>CSW&nbsp;is thought to occur because of direct neural effect on {{c1::renal tubular function}}</div>	"<div><u><span style=""font-style: italic;"">Hallmark</span>&nbsp;of&nbsp;CSW:</u></div><div><u><br></u></div><div>In&nbsp;CSW, hyponatremia is not dilutional (as in&nbsp;SIADH)—CSW&nbsp;patients are, in fact, volume depleted.<u><br></u></div><div><br></div><div>Decreased blood volume (↓ extracellular volume = hypovolemia) secondary to sodium loss (in urine)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>→ this triggers ↑ in&nbsp;ADH&nbsp;secretion that is appropriate rather than inappropriate (differentiating this condition from&nbsp;SIADH).</div>"																				
<b>Cerebral Salt Wasting Syndrome&nbsp;</b><div><u><br></u></div><div><u>TREATMENT</u></div><div>{{c1::Hydration/fluid replacement}} + {{c1::electrolyte (Na<sup>+</sup>) correction}}</div>	<div>It is important to differentiate&nbsp;CSW&nbsp;from&nbsp;SIADH, and to recognize that there is water depletion in this condition,&nbsp;</div><div>as treating it with fluid restriction (adequate treatment for&nbsp;SIADH) may further reduce the extracellular fluid with disastrous results to the patient.</div>																				
<b>Diabetes Insipidus&nbsp;</b><div><br></div><div>It may occur in severe head injuries; it is often associated with fractures of the skull.</div><div><br></div><div>A fracture in or near the {{c1::sella turcica}} may tear the stalk of the pituitary gland,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>with resulting&nbsp;DI&nbsp;(due to disruption of&nbsp;ADH&nbsp;secretion from post pituitary) in addition to other clinical syndromes</div><div><br></div><div>Spontaneous remissions of traumatic&nbsp;DI&nbsp;may occur even after {{c2::6}} months,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>presumably because of regeneration of disrupted axons within the pituitary stalk</div>	<div>represents a deficiency of&nbsp;ADH&nbsp;(vasopressin).</div><div><br></div><div>In contrast to&nbsp;SIADH&nbsp;or&nbsp;CSW, hypernatremia can result due to excessive volume depletion.</div>																				
"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Most mild&nbsp;</span>TBI<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;(concussion) patients have a good recovery&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">usually within&nbsp;</span>{{c1::1::#}} to {{c1::3::#}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>{{c1::months::time period}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;postinjury&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">symptoms clearing within the first few weeks or months</span>"																				
<b>Second Impact Syndrome</b><div><br></div><div>Results from a person sustaining {{c1::a 2nd brain injury}} before {{c2::symptoms of a prior concussion have cleared}}</div>	Immediately following the second head injury, patients become dazed,&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>and within 15 seconds to several minutes can rapidly decompensate</div><div><br></div><div>—collapse, pupil dilation, loss of eye tracking, respiratory failure, semicomatose state</div>																				
"<b>Second Impact Syndrome</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Current research suggests an impairment in the brain’s&nbsp;</span>{{c1::vascular autoregulation}}</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">leading to engorgement and increased&nbsp;</span>ICP<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;that results in herniation&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">(either of the medial temporal lobe through the tentorium or the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum)</span></div>"																				
"<b>Second Impact Syndrome</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Incidence of second impact syndrome is unknown and likely underreported,&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">but studies suggest morbidity and mortality rates close to 100% and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::50}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">% respectively</span><b><br></b></div>"																					
"The American Congress of Rehabilitation (<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_31"">Giacino et al., 1995</a>)&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>defined<b> Concussion (mild&nbsp;TBI)</b> as a traumatically induced physiologic disruption of brain function&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>with at least one of four manifestations</u></div><div>Any {{c1::loss of consciousness (LOC)}}</div><div>Any {{c2::loss of memory for events (immediately before or after the injury)}}</div><div>Any {{c3::alteration in mental status at the time of the accident}}</div><div>{{c4::Focal neurologic deficits}} that may or may not be transient</div>"	"The injury&nbsp;<strong>does not exceed</strong>&nbsp;the following severity criteria:<div>- LOC&nbsp;of 30 minutes</div><div>- PTA&nbsp;of 24 hours</div><div>- Initial&nbsp;GCS&nbsp;of 13</div><div><br></div><div>Usually, mild&nbsp;TBI&nbsp;has no findings of structural injury on routine neuroimaging (CT/MRI).</div><div><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/258062264/figure/tbl2/AS:601655573753873@1520457275912/Criteria-for-distinguishing-mild-TBI-from-moderate-to-severe-cases-17.png""><br></div>"																				
"<div><b><u>In the&nbsp;<span style=""font-style: italic;"">International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Edition (ICD-10)</span>&nbsp;(<a href=""https://connect.springerpub.com/content/book/978-0-8261-3457-8/chapter/ch02#bid_2_78"">1992</a>) criteria</u></b>,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><b>post-concussion syndrome (PCS) includes</b>:</div><div><br></div><div>A history of head trauma with {{c1::loss of consciousness}} preceding symptom onset by a maximum of {{c2::4 weeks}}</div><div><br></div><div>There must be symptoms in at least {{c3::3}} or more of the following categories:</div><div>- Headaches</div><div>- Noise intolerance</div><div>- Dizziness</div><div>- Malaise</div><div>- Fatigue</div><div>- Light intolerance</div><div>- Irritability</div><div>- Anxiety</div><div>- Depression</div><div>- Emotional lability</div><div>- Subjective concentration, memory, or intellectual difficulties without neuropsychological evidence of impairment</div><div>- Reduced alcohol tolerance</div><div>- Preoccupation with the previously mentioned symptoms</div>"																					
"<div>{{c1::Persistent}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span>PCS<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;has been used to describe symptoms lasting over&nbsp;</span>{{c2::3}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::6}}<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;months</span><br></div>"																					
Concussions {{c1::are no longer::are/are not}} categorized on severity scales	<div>Classification systems were cast aside in 2013 and are now based on clinical judgment alone.&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div>Severity is now gauged using a symptom severity scale,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>such as Sport Concussion Assessment Tool, Fifth Edition (SCAT5) or Acute Concussion Evaluation (ACE).&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>SCAT5&nbsp;is a standardized tool developed by the Concussion in Sport group, used to evaluate concussive injury in athletes 13 years of age and older.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>The&nbsp;ACE&nbsp;is an initial assessment tool for concussion that can be utilized by the general public.</div>																				
<div><b>Concussion Categorization</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>Severity is now gauged using a symptom severity scale,&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>such as {{c1::Sport Concussion Assessment Tool [Fifth Edition (SCAT5)]}} or {{c2::Acute Concussion Evaluation (ACE)}}</div>	<div>SCAT5&nbsp;is a standardized tool developed by the Concussion in Sport group, used to evaluate concussive injury in athletes 13 years of age and older.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>The&nbsp;ACE&nbsp;is an initial assessment tool for concussion that can be utilized by the general public.</div>																				
<b>Concussion Categorization</b><div><br></div><div>A consensus statement following the International Sports Concussion Conference in Zurich&nbsp;<br></div><div><div><br></div><div>developed a symptom checklist composed of four different domains.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><u>The four domains are</u>:<br></div><div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Somatic}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>2. {{c2::Cognitive}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>3. {{c3::Affective}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>4. {{c4::Sleep changes}}&nbsp;</div></div>	The clinician generates a total score of severity and counts the domains in which the person has symptoms.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>1. Somatic (headache, dizziness, visual disturbances, nausea, and the like)</div><div><br></div><div>2. Cognitive (confusion,&nbsp;LOC, inability to concentrate, and memory problems)</div><div><br></div><div>3. Affective (emotional lability, anxiety, sadness, and irritability)</div><div><br></div><div>4. Sleep changes (trouble falling asleep, or sleeping more or less than usual)</div><div><br></div><div>The combination of symptoms reported by the patient and a neurological exam,&nbsp;</div><div>in which the doctor evaluates the patient’s vital signs, visual performance, balance, memory, and cognitive functioning,&nbsp;</div><div>guides how the concussion is managed.</div><div><br></div><div>Treatment for concussions includes physical and cognitive rest for 48 hours,&nbsp;</div><div>followed by a gradual return to activities, learning, or work in addition to a graded aerobic exercise regimen under clinical supervision</div>																				
<b>Concussion Return to Play (RTP)</b><div><br></div><div>Return-to-play (RTP) criteria in sports have been similarly controversial.</div><div><br></div><div>In 2016, the Fifth International Conference on Concussion in Sport released its most recent Consensus Statement on Concussion in Sport.</div><div><br></div><div>It explicitly recommends no {{c1::RTP&nbsp;on the day of a concussive injury (regardless of the severity)}}</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">Graduated Return to Play Protocol From the Fifth International Conference on Concussion in Sports, 2016</span><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-10 at 9.06.29 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div>"																				
<b>Concussion Return to Play (RTP)</b><div><br></div><div>Concussion management and&nbsp;RTP&nbsp;guidelines begin with physical and cognitive rest until {{c1::the acute symptoms resolve}}</div><div><br></div><div>usually {{c2::24}}–{{c2::48}} hours, followed by a stepwise graded program of exertion prior to medical clearance and&nbsp;RTP.</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-10 at 9.06.29 PM.png"">"																				
<b>Concussion Return to Play (RTP)</b><div><br></div><div>In the Graduated Return to Play Protocol, the athlete can only proceed to the next level if {{c1::asymptomatic at the current level}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-10 at 9.06.29 PM.png"">"																				
<b>Concussion Return to Play (RTP)</b><div><br></div><div>Generally, each step should take at least {{c1::24 hours}}, thereby resulting in at least {{c1::1 week}} to proceed through the full rehabilitation protocol.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>If any post concussion symptoms occur, the athlete is to {{c2::drop back to the previous asymptomatic level}}&nbsp;</div>	"and try to progress again after another 24-hour period of rest has passed<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-10 at 9.06.29 PM.png""><br></div>"																				
"<b>Concussion Return to Play (RTP)</b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">following rest from acute symptoms (24-48h)</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><u>Graduated Return to Play Protocol From the Fifth International Conference on Concussion in Sports, 2016</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">1.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::symptom limited activity (ADL's)}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">2.&nbsp;</span>{{c2::light aerobic exercise}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">3.&nbsp;</span>{{c3::sport specific exercise (drills running)}}</div><div><font color=""#333333"">4.&nbsp;</font>{{c4::resistance training / non-contact drills (drills passing)}}</div><div><font color=""#333333"">5.&nbsp;</font>{{c5::full contact practice (nml. training)}}</div><div><font color=""#333333"">6.&nbsp;</font>{{c6::return to play}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2024-06-10 at 9.06.29 PM.png"">"																				
<b>Benefits of Pulmonary Rehab</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>improvement in {{c2::exercise tolerance}}, symptom-limited oxygen consumption, work output, mechanical efficiency</div><div><br></div><div>Exercise increases (AVO<sub>2</sub>) difference by increasing {{c1::oxygen extraction from arterial circulation}}</div>	<div>Reduction in dyspnea and respiratory rate (RR) at rest and at various levels of activity</div><div><br></div><div>Improvement in general quality of life, decreased anxiety and depression, as well as improvement in the capacity to perform&nbsp;ADLs</div><div><br></div><div>Improvement in ambulation capacity</div><div><br></div><div>Decreased hospitalization rates/reduced healthcare resource utilization</div><div><br></div><div>Focus on conditioning peripheral musculature in order to improve efficiency and reduce stress on the heart and lungs</div>																				
What is the <u>definition</u> of cerebral palsy (CP)?	CP is a group of disorders of the development of <u>movement</u> and <u>posture</u>, causing activity limitations that are attributed to a non-progressive disturbance that has occurred in the developing fetal or infant brain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What is the <u>incidence</u> of CP in school-aged children?	CP affects approximately 3 per 1,000 school-aged children.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What is the <u>live birth</u> incidence of CP for term infants?	The live birth incidence of CP is about 2/1,000 for term infants.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What is the incidence of CP in preterm infants less than 28 weeks gestation?	The incidence of CP is 82/1,000 live births in preterm infants &lt;28 weeks gestation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What is the incidence of CP in infants of 32 to 36 weeks of gestation?	The incidence of CP decreases to 6.8/1,000 live births for those of 32 to 36 weeks of gestation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What are some risk factors for cerebral palsy?	"Risk factors for CP include<span style=""color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">&nbsp;infection (</span>prenatal, perinatal, and postnatal)<span style=""color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">, stroke, toxins, neonatal encephalopathy, complications of prematurity, intrauterine growth restriction, maternal conditions, and trauma.</span>"																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What is the greatest risk factor for CP?	Prematurity&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What is the best predictor of CP in <u>term</u> infants?	Neonatal encephalopathy&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
How is CP classified by movement type?	1.spastic (70%–85%)<br>2.dyskinetic<br>3.hypotonic<br>4.ataxic<br>5.mixed																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
How is CP classified by anatomic distribution?	CP can be classified by anatomic distribution into hemiparesis, diparesis, and quadriparesis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What does the Gross Motor Function Classification System describe?	It describes mobility function based on age, with levels from 1 to 5, detailing capabilities from walking without limitations to severely limited self-mobility.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What are some key items to look for in the diagnosis of CP?	Key diagnostic items include:<br><ul><li><u>persistence</u> of primitive reflexes after 6 months</li><li>asymmetry</li><li>obligatory responses</li><li>early handedness</li><li>failure to use the involved hand or early rolling.</li></ul>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What <u>percentage</u> of CP patients have abnormal neuroimaging findings?	&gt; 80% of CP patients have abnormal neuroimaging.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What are common neuroimaging findings in CP?	Common findings include periventricular leukomalacia (PVL), focal cortical infarcts, basal ganglia and thalamic lesions, brain malformations, and generalized encephalomalacia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
Which imaging modality is more likely to show abnormalities in CP?	MRI is more likely to show abnormalities compared with CT.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What are common associated disorders in CP?	Associated disorders include:<br><br>sensory impairments, hearing, visual, cognitive, psychological, oromotor, nutritional, genitourinary, respiratory, bone mineral density, and dental impairments.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What percentage of CP patients experience pain?	Pain is experienced by 50% to 75% of CP patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What gastrointestinal disorders are common in CP?	Gastrointestinal disorders in CP include:<br><br>abdominal pain, constipation, <u>gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD),</u> and swallowing disorders, affecting 90% of patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What is the prevalence of seizures in CP?	15-55%&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What musculoskeletal disorders are associated with CP?	Musculoskeletal disorders in CP include:<br><br>hip dysplasia, dislocation, scoliosis, low bone mineral density, spasticity, and contractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What types of gait impairments are seen in CP?	Gait impairments in CP can include <u>scissoring, intoeing, crouch gait, stiff knee, and toe gait</u>.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What treatments are included in the management of CP?	therapy and medical management of spasticity, such as oral medications, chemical neurolysis, and intrathecal baclofen.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What therapy approaches are not recommended for CP?	Neurodevelopmental treatment (NDT) and sensory integration therapy (SIT) are not recommended approaches for CP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What might therapy for CP include?	Therapy for CP may include <b>stretching, strengthening, tone management, and functional training.</b>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What surgical options are available for managing spasticity in CP?	Surgical management includes selective dorsal rhizotomy, which involves sectioning of<b> L2 to S1 </b>sensory nerve rootlets.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What are potential negative effects of selective dorsal rhizotomy?	Negative effects can include hypotonia, bladder dysfunction (usually transient), weakness, and spinal deformity including spondylolysis/listhesis and hip dislocation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What other orthopedic interventions are used in CP treatment?	Other interventions include serial casting, muscle–tendon lengthening and transfers, and osteotomy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What indicates a good prognosis for ambulation in CP?	Good prognosis for ambulation is indicated if there is independent sitting by age 2 years, reciprocal crawl at 1½ to 2½ years, and supine to prone by 18 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What indicates a poor prognosis for ambulation in CP?	A poor prognosis for ambulation can generally be expected if there is the presence of three or more primitive reflexes at 18 to 24 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
How does life expectancy relate to mobility in CP?	Life expectancy is reduced with <u>immobility </u>and <u>inability to self-feed</u>.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Introduction
What is the incidence of congenital brachial plexus palsy (CBPP) in the United States?	CBPP occurs in 1 to 2 out of 1,000 live births in the United States.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What are the risk factors for CBPP?<br><br><i>CBPP - congenital brachial plexus palsy&nbsp;</i>	<b>Shoulder dystocia - Only established risk factor&nbsp;<br><br></b>also - risk factors for CBPP include a multiparous mother and increased birth weight<br><b><br></b>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
How does Erb’s palsy present clinically?	Erb’s palsy presents with shoulder internal rotation and adduction, elbow extension and pronation, and wrist flexion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What are the main features of a C8, T1 lesion in CBPP?<br><br><i>CBPP - congenital brachial plexus palsy&nbsp;</i>	Main features include Horner’s syndrome and isolated hand paralysis, more often seen in complete brachial plexus palsy C5–T1.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What is the rate of spontaneous recovery in congenital brachial plexus palsy?<br><br>	seen 50-90% of the time&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What associated injuries can occur with congenital brachial plexus palsy ?	Associated injuries can include facial palsy, cephalohematoma, clavicle or humerus fracture, torticollis, cervical spine injury, diaphragmatic injury, and Horner’s syndrome (with lower plexus injury).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
How is congenital brachial plexus palsy diagnosed?	Diagnosis is often made at birth with weakness noted in the affected arm.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What should be included in the physical examination for congenital brachial plexus palsy?	Physical exam should include a detailed neurologic examination focusing on stimulated motor and sensory responses as well as reflexes, noting any deficits. ROM should also be assessed both actively and passively.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What imaging should be conducted for congenital brachial plexus palsy?	Neuroimaging such as <u><b>MRI</b></u> should be conducted to rule out fractures and neuromas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What are the goals of treatment for congenital brachial plexus palsy?	Goals of treatment are to normalize limb function, optimize nerve regeneration, and allow elbow flexion and shoulder stabilization.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What is important in limb positioning for congenital brachial plexus palsy treatment?	Limb positioning is important to increase awareness, range of motion, splinting, and developmental training.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
When is surgery indicated in congenital brachial plexus palsy treatment?	Surgery is indicated if antigravity strength is not present at the elbow at <u>6 months.</u> Early surgical intervention is recommended between age 3 and 9 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What orthopedic interventions may be used in congenital brachial plexus palsy?	Orthopedically, tendon releases/transfers and early pinning may be used to avoid shoulder stretch and gentle ROM should be considered to manage pain due to traumatic neuritis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What are the neurosurgical options for congenital brachial plexus palsy?	Neurosurgical options include <u>neurolysis</u> of scar and fibrotic tissue, end-to-end <u>anastomosis</u>, <u>nerve transfer</u> of the sural or great auricular nerves, and end-to-side <u>neurorrhaphy</u>.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What is a <u>good prognosticator</u> for normal function in congenital brachial plexus palsy?	Recovery by 3 months is a good prognosticator for normal function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What may indicate a poor prognosis in congenital brachial plexus palsy?	Limited elbow flexion at 6 months may be predictive of poor prognosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What complications may occur with congenital brachial plexus palsy?	Complications may include muscle atrophy, contracture, developmental concerns, glenoid dysplasia with posterior subluxation, issues of cosmesis, and pain, which may be indicated by biting the limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Congenital_Brachial_Plexus_Palsy
What percentage of all spinal cord injuries (SCIs) occur in children under 15 years?	10% of all SCIs occur in children under the age of 15 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
How does the risk of SCI in children under 9 years differ between genders?	In children under 9 years of age, boys are <u><b>four times</b></u> more likely to be affected compared with girls.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
Are there racial differences in SCI risk in children over 15 years?	Yes, racial differences exist, with an overall <u><b>increased risk</b></u> for African Americans and Hispanic Americans.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
What are the most common causes of pediatric SCI?	The most common causes of pediatric SCI are <u>motor vehicle accidents</u> (MVAs), <u>falls</u> (under 10 years), and <u>sports</u> (15 to 16 years).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
Which spinal levels are most commonly affected in pediatric SCI?	C5–C8 level injuries are most common in pediatric SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
Why are pediatric patients prone to higher cervical injuries?	Pediatric patients are prone to higher cervical injuries due to their relatively large head size and more mobile developing spine, favoring stretch injury to ligaments without bony fracture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
What percentage of children under 10 years with SCI had occiput-C1 injury?	<u><b>50%</b></u> of children under 10 years with SCI had occiput-C1 injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
What is SCIWORA?	SCIWORA refers to spinal cord injury <u>without</u> radiographic abnormality, where 50% were neurologically intact.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
How does management of SCI differ between children and adults?	Management differs, particularly in areas like <u>deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis</u>, which is <b>not clear </b>in children.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
How might mobility change for younger children with high lumbar or thoracic SCI as they reach adolescence?	Younger children with high lumbar or thoracic SCI may be ambulatory with bracing but become more wheelchair dependent at adolescence as it is more energy-efficient.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
What orthopedic conditions are children with SCI at risk for?	"Children with SCI are at risk for conditions like <span style=""color: rgb(170, 0, 127);""><b>scoliosis and hip subluxation or dislocation</b></span>, not typically seen in skeletally mature adults with SCI."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
How prevalent is scoliosis in pediatric SCI cases before reaching skeletal maturity?	&nbsp;Scoliosis occurs in <u><b>almost all cases</b></u> of pediatric SCI that have not reached skeletal maturity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
What percentage of pediatric SCI cases with scoliosis require surgical management?	<u><b>Two thirds</b></u> of pediatric SCI cases with scoliosis require surgical management.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
What role do thoracolumbosacral orthoses (TLSOs) play in managing scoliosis in children with SCI?	Although compliance is low, TLSOs have been shown to decrease the curvature progression rate in children, thus delaying the need for surgery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Special_Considerations_Pediatric_SCI
What is spina bifida?	Spina bifida is a type of neural tube defect (NTD) where there is failure of neural tube closure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
When does neural tube closure begin and proceed?	Neural tube closure begins mid-cervical and proceeds caudally and rostrally by day 27.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is the risk of having a child with an neural tube defect?	The risk of having a child with NTD is 0.1% to 0.2%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is the<b><u> recurrence rate </u></b>of neural tube defect if one child already has an NTD?	The recurrence rate is 2% to 5%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is the recurrence rate of NTD if two or more children already have an NTD?	The recurrence rate <u><b>increases to 10% to 15%</b></u>.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
Which population has the highest rates of NTDs?	Hispanic population.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What are some environmental risk factors for NTDs?	Environmental risk factors include <u>hyperthermia</u> within the first 28 days from <u>maternal fever, hot tubs, or sauna use</u>.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What are some occupational risk factors for NTDs?	Occupational risk factors include solvent exposure, health care workers, and agriculture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What are some maternal risk factors for NTDs?	Maternal risk factors include obesity, diabetes, and medication use such as valproic acid, antiretrovirals, isotretinoin, and methotrexate.<br><br><br><br>Notes:&nbsp;<br>Antiretrovirals- Dolutegravir (integrase strand transfer inhibitors)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is the most common nutritional risk factor for NTDs?	The most common nutritional risk factor is <b>folate (B9)</b> deficiency.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What are the AAP guidelines for folate supplementation?	Folate 0.4 mg/day for women of childbearing years and 0.4 mg/day prior to conception and through the first trimester in cases of a previous child with spina bifida or a high-risk pregnancy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
How is spina bifida often diagnosed?	Diagnosis is often suspected based on prenatal screening with <u><b>elevation of α-fetoprotein, splaying of pedicles, lemon and banana sign on high-resolution US, and amniocentesis.</b></u>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is spina bifida occulta?	Spina bifida occulta is a bony defect without herniation of neural elements, found incidentally in 5% to 36% of adults.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What may be associated with spina bifida occulta?	It may be associated with tethered cord and bowel/bladder issues, and may have hair patch, dimple, sinus, or nevus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is meningocele?	Meningocele involves a bony defect with herniation of meninges but not neural tissue, found in less than 10% of cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is meningocele associated with?	Examination of meningocele is generally normal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is meningomyelocele?	Meningomyelocele involves herniation of meninges and neural elements, often associated with Chiari type 2 malformation and hydrocephalus in most cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is the most common location for meningomyelocele?	75% of meningomyelocele cases are lumbosacral.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What is caudal regression?	Caudal regression is characterized by the absence of the sacrum and parts of the lumbar spine, associated with maternal diabetes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What complications are associated with caudal regression?	Complications can include syrinx, anorectal stenosis, renal, cardiac, and external genital malformations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What are the potential sensory and motor deficits depending on spinal level involvement?	there will be different sensory and motor deficits that may be present, often asymmetric.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What are common issues at the<u> thoracic spinal level</u> relative to spina bifida?	At the thoracic level, the upper extremities are spared except when T1 is involved. Kyphoscoliosis from weak trunk occurs in 80% to 100% of the cases, and lower extremity contractures may develop from position and wheelchair mobility.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What deficits and complications are associated with L1 to L3 involvement relative for ?	With L1 to L3 involvement, hip flexor and abductor tone is present, which predisposes to early hip dislocation and scoliosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What might a child with L1 to L3 involvement require for ambulation?	A child with L1 to L3 involvement may ambulate with bracing (HKAFO and RGO) and an assistive device (AD) but may stop due to high energy cost.<br><br><br>e.g<br>HKAFO - Hip Knee Ankle Foot orthosis<br>RGO - Reciprocating Gait Orthosis&nbsp;<br>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What typically results from an L4 to L5 lesion?	An L4 to L5 lesion typically results in late hip dislocation. <br>1. L4 lesions predispose to a calcaneovarus foot<br>2. L5 predisposes to a calcaneus foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What does management of spinal defects typically include?	Management can include closure in the first 24 to 48 hours of life; however, in utero repair has been reported.<u> Rehabilitative management</u> includes the use of bracing, wheelchair fitting, seating, and standers as part of developmental training, mobility, and deformity prevention.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What are potential complications to address in spinal defect management?	Potential complications include:<br>-obesity<br>-latex allergy and potential cross-reactivity to kiwi, banana, avocado, and chestnuts<br>-cognitive function and learning problems especially in higher level lesions<br>-shunt malfunction<br>-tethered cord<br>-diastematomyelia<br>-syringomyelia<br>-neurogenic bowel<br>-neurogenic bladder.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
How often should bladder studies be completed for a <u>child</u> with spinal defects?	<b>Baseline US, urodynamics, and VCUG should be completed as a newborn.</b><br><br><br><br>notes:&nbsp;<br>US repeated every 3 months <u>during the first year</u>, twice in the <u>second year</u>, and<u> yearly thereafter</u>. <br><br>Urodynamic studies and VCUG should be repeated at 3 months, at 1 year, once at 2 or 3 years of age, and then every 2 years or sooner if there is a change in bladder function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
How is bladder capacity determined?	"In the first year of life: <span style=""color: rgb(170, 0, 127);""><b>weight in kg × 7 to 10 mL<br></b></span>Age 1 to 12 years: <span style=""color: rgb(170, 0, 127);"">(age + 2) × 30 mL<br></span>Teens/Adults: <span style=""color: rgb(170, 0, 127);"">400 mL</span>"																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What treatments are available for neurogenic bladder?	"Treatments for neurogenic bladder include<b> <span style=""color: rgb(170, 0, 127);"">intermittent catheterization</span> (IC),</b> with <b>self-catheterization possible</b> by age 5 if adequate hand use and cognition are present. Additional treatments include oral medication, botulinum toxin injections, vesicostomy, and surgical bladder augmentation."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Spina_Bifida
What can cause neuromuscular disorders?	Neuromuscular disorders can be caused by an abnormality of any component of the lower motor neuron (anterior horn cell, peripheral nerve, neuromuscular junction [NMJ], or muscle).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Pediatric_Neuromuscular_Disorders
What systemic effects are frequently associated with neuromuscular disorders?	They are frequently associated with systemic effects, as pathologic changes may affect skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscles, the brain, and mitochondria in multiple organs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Pediatric_Neuromuscular_Disorders
What is the most common etiology of neuromuscular disorders?	The most common etiology of neuromuscular disorders is genetic, but it may be progressive, acquired, or hereditary.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Pediatric_Neuromuscular_Disorders
What is crucial when evaluating a patient for a neuromuscular disorder?	It is crucial to obtain a detailed family history and, if possible, to obtain a diagnostic evaluation of the affected relatives.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Pediatric_Neuromuscular_Disorders
What should the diagnostic evaluation of a child with a suspected neuromuscular disorder include?	Diagnostic evaluation should include comprehensive past medical history, detailed family history, and meticulous physical examination.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Pediatric_Neuromuscular_Disorders
What considerations should be made regarding additional laboratory and genetic data in neuromuscular disorders?	Request for additional laboratory and genetic data that may be costly and not readily available must be considered following ascertainment of developmentally appropriate assessment and history.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Pediatric_Neuromuscular_Disorders
What is the most common reason for referral for possible neuromuscular disorder in infants?	Most common reason for referral is if the infant appears floppy&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Pediatric_Neuromuscular_Disorders
What is Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA)?	SMA comprises a group of autosomal recessive disorders caused by the <b>degeneration of anterior horn cells</b> of brain stem motor nuclei and is characterized by muscle weakness.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What are the subtypes of SMA?	The subtypes are:<br>SMA type I (acute infantile or Werdnig-Hoffmann)<br>SMA type II (chronic infantile)<br>SMA type III (chronic juvenile)<br>SMA type IV (adult onset)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
When does SMA type I typically onset?	SMA type I onset is from birth to 6 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What is characteristic of SMA type I?	SMA type I presents severe, progressive muscle weakness, flaccid or reduced muscle tone, and children with this type do not attain sitting without support.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What does diagnostic workup for SMA type I include?	<table><tbody><tr><td><div><div>Diagnostic workup includes a normal creatine kinase (CK) level, nerve conduction study (NCS)/EMG showing decreased amplitude, and a muscle biopsy revealing large group atrophy and clusters of large fibers.</div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What are the prognosis and treatment options for SMA type I?	<table><tbody><tr><td><div><div>Treatment is supportive and prognosis is poor, with death occurring in the vast majority within the first 3 years of life.</div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
When does SMA type II typically onset?	SMA type II onset is between 6 and 18 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What are the features and prognosis of SMA type II?	SMA type II is characterized by developmental motor delay, tremor in fingers, and sitting attainment but not independent ambulation. Life span varies from 2 years to the third decade of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
When does SMA type III typically onset?	SMA type III onset is after 18 months of age.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What is characteristic of SMA type III?	SMA type III is characterized by slowly progressive proximal weakness, and children can stand and walk but may struggle with stairs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
When does SMA type IV typically onset?	SMA type IV onset is after the age of 20 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What are the features of SMA type IV?	SMA type IV is characterized by slowly progressive proximal weakness and has a normal life expectancy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What is Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS)?	GBS is a primarily demyelinating neuropathy and the most common cause of acute motor paralysis in children, characterized as an autoimmune-mediated disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What are the clinical features of GBS?	GBS manifests as an acute monophasic, afebrile, postinfectious illness with ascending weakness and areflexia, sometimes accompanied by pain and dysesthesias.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What are common triggers of GBS?	Triggers include Epstein–Barr virus (EBV), cytomegalovirus (CMV), enteroviruses, hepatitis A and B, varicella, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Campylobacter jejuni.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What is Miller Fisher syndrome?	A variant of GBS characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia, often linked to infection with C. jejuni.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What are recovery outcomes for children with GBS?	Recovery outcomes are generally more favorable in children than in adults, with a recurrence rate of 5%–12% which is relatively uncommon.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What is the most effective form of therapy for GBS in children?	Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is generally considered the most effective therapy for GBS in children.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What alternative treatment may be used for GBS and how does it compare to IVIG?	Plasmapheresis may decrease the severity and shorten the duration of GBS, with results similar to IVIG but possibly fewer side effects.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What are the critical aspects to monitor in GBS patients?	Care should be taken to monitor respiratory and cardiac function, especially in the acute, progressive stage of the disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What is the most concerning aspect of GBS in childhood?	Respiratory compromise is the most concerning and life-threatening aspect of GBS in childhood.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What differential diagnoses should be considered for GBS in children?	Differential diagnoses include botulism, myasthenia gravis, infectious processes (like Lyme disease or HIV), peripheral neuropathies, and NJ disorders such as tick paralysis and hypercalcemia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Anterior_Horn_Disorders
What is Hereditary Motor Sensory Neuropathy (HMSN)?	HMSN is an <b>inherited</b> disorder of both motor and sensory peripheral nerves characterized by progressive neuromuscular impairments.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
How do motor and sensory signs develop in HMSN?<br><br>*Hereditary Motor Sensory Neuropathy (HMSN)	Motor signs tend to develop before sensory signs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
What are the early clinical features of HMSN?<br><br>*Hereditary Motor Sensory Neuropathy (HMSN)	Early clinical features include weakness and atrophy first in the intrinsic foot muscles followed by ankle and toe dorsiflexors, resulting in high-arched feet, hammertoes, and difficulty with heel walking.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
When does HMSN typically onset?<br><br>*Hereditary Motor Sensory Neuropathy (HMSN)	The onset of HMSN is usually in the first or second decade of life.
