RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
What are the seven subtypes of HMSN?	The subtypes include HMSN types 1A and IB, type 2, type 3, type 4, type 5, type 6, and type 7, with associations to various conditions like CMT, Déjerine-Sottas disease, and Refsum disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
What is the most common form of CMT1?<br><br>*Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT)	The most common form of CMT1, known as CMT1A, is associated with a duplication within chromosome 17p11.2.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
What genetic association is found with CMT1B and Déjerine-Sottas disease?	CMT1B and some cases of Déjerine-Sottas disease are associated with mutations in the <b>myelin protein zero (MPZ) gene on chromosome 1.</b>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
How do MPZ mutations affect phenotypes?	MPZ mutations are associated with multiple, overlapping phenotypes including CMT1B, Déjerine-Sottas disease, and the axonal CMT2 phenotype.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
What are the inheritance patterns of HMSN disorders?	CMT1 and CMT2 are inherited dominantly as the demyelinating and axonal forms, respectively, while Déjerine-Sottas is a severe form with onset in infancy and CMT4 includes various demyelinating autosomal recessive forms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
What complications arise from foot deformities in CMT?	Common foot deformities in CMT can lead to discomfort, impaired ambulation, and disability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
How can ankle weakness and instability from CMT be treated?	Ankle weakness and instability can be treated with orthoses or shoe modifications. Moderate activity is recommended, and overexertion should be avoided.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Hereditary_Motor_Sensory_Neuropathy
What percentage of neonates born to mothers with myasthenia gravis develop transient neonatal myasthenia?	Transient neonatal myasthenia occurs in 10% to 30% of neonates born to mothers with myasthenia gravis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Neuromuscular
When do signs of transient neonatal myasthenia typically become apparent?	Signs are most commonly apparent by the third day of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Neuromuscular
What is the major cause of transient neonatal myasthenia?	The major cause is the transplacental transfer of <b>circulating acetylcholine (ACh) antibodies from mother to fetus.</b>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Neuromuscular
What is the prognosis for transient neonatal myasthenia if treated and monitored?	If treated and monitored, it is a self-limiting condition in the vast majority of cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Neuromuscular
What is congenital or infantile myasthenia?	Congenital or infantile myasthenia occurs in infants of non-myasthenic mothers and may have an autosomal recessive inheritance, usually without antibodies to the ACh receptor.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Neuromuscular
How does juvenile myasthenia gravis compare to adult myasthenia gravis?	How does juvenile myasthenia gravis compare to adult myasthenia gravis?																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Neuromuscular
What special considerations are there in treating juvenile myasthenia gravis?	Considerations include postponement of corticosteroid therapy due to potential growth retardation and avoidance of thymectomy due to the risks of induced immunodeficiency.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Neuromuscular
What are typical clinical presentations of juvenile myasthenia gravis?	It particularly affects adolescent girls and presents with weakness of facial and mastication muscles, and can affect swallowing, speech, respiration, as well as the neck, trunk, and limb muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Neuromuscular
What is Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD)?	FSHD is a slowly progressive dystrophic myopathy with predominant asymmetric involvement of facial and shoulder girdle musculature.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
What is the inheritance pattern of FSHD?	FSHD has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern with 10% to 30% caused by sporadic mutation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
At what age does FSHD usually present?	Presentation is usually before age 20 years, and diagnosis is confirmed in over 90% by molecular genetic testing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
What are the clinical features of FSHD?	Clinical features include:<br>1.facial weakness<br>2.expressionless appearance<br>3.difficulty with eye closure<br>4.involvement of scapular stabilizers and shoulder muscles<br>5.mild nonprogressive scoliosis<br>6.mild restrictive lung disease in 50% of patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
What is Coates syndrome?	Coates syndrome is a rapidly progressive form of early onset FSHD characterized by sensorineural hearing deficit and progressive exudative telangiectasia of the retina.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
Coates syndrome is a rapidly progressive form of early onset FSHD characterized by sensorineural hearing deficit and progressive exudative telangiectasia of the retina.	EMD is characterized by weakness, contractures, and cardiac conduction abnormalities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
What are the subtypes of Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy?	There are two subtypes: EMD-1 and EMD-2, with EMD-1 being X-linked recessive and EMD-2 linked to chromosome 1q21.2 with variable inheritance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
What are the clinical features of EMD-1?	EMD-1 typically presents in the second decade of life with elbow flexion contractures as a hallmark, and progressive cardiac disease that may lead to complications like arrhythmia or cardiomyopathy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
What are the clinical features of EMD-2?	EMD-2 is characterized by scapuloperoneal and facial distribution of weakness, with contractures being rare in this form.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
What are congenital myopathies?	Congenital myopathies are heterogeneous disorders usually presenting with infantile hypotonia due to genetic defects, causing primary myopathies without structural abnormalities of the central nervous system or peripheral nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Myopathies
What is Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA)?	JIA is the most common rheumatic disease of childhood, affecting bone and joints and can lead to overgrowth, undergrowth, or aberrant growth.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What are possible anomalies related to JIA?	Possible anomalies include micrognathia, leg length discrepancy, and hip dysplasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What are the diagnostic criteria for JIA?	Diagnosis should occur before age 16 years, persist for at least 6 weeks, and be a diagnosis of exclusion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What are indicators of poor outcomes in JIA?	Indicators include greater severity at onset, symmetrical disease, early wrist and hip involvement, serologic evidence of rheumatoid factor (RF), persistent active disease, and early radiographic changes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What are the seven subtypes of JIA?	The subtypes are systemic arthritis, oligoarthritis, RF-negative polyarthritis, RF-positive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, enthesitis-related arthritis, and undifferentiated arthritis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What are the main goals of rehabilitation for children with JIA?	Goals include preventing joint damage, achieving normal growth and development, and maintaining and improving function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What are common treatments for JIA?	Treatments include resting the joint, splinting, range of motion exercises, modalities, and adaptive equipment. NSAIDs and intra-articular steroid joint injections are first-line treatments.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
Why is ultrasound contraindicated in children with JIA?	US is contraindicated in children with open growth plates.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What are second-line treatments for JIA?	Second-line treatments include TNF inhibitors (etanercept and adalimumab) and T-cell blockers (abatacept) for TNF inhibitor nonresponders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What percentage of children with JIA may achieve remission with NSAIDs and methotrexate?	Up to 75% of children may achieve <b>remission with NSAIDs and methotrexate.</b>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What special considerations are needed for managing JIA?	Special considerations include more frequent cervical spine involvement, common TMJ and wrist involvement, shoulder joint issues in polyarticular and psoriatic arthritis, hip flexion contractures, common knee involvement with quadriceps weakness, and leg length discrepancy leading to pelvic asymmetry and scoliosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Juvenile_Idiopathic_Arthritis
What do electrodiagnostic studies include?	Electrodiagnostic studies include nerve conduction studies (NCSs or NCVs) and EMGs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
Electrodiagnostic studies include nerve conduction studies (NCSs or NCVs) and EMGs.	Other less commonly performed electrodiagnostic tests include somatosensory evoked potentials, brain stem auditory evoked potentials or responses, single-fiber EMG (SFEMG), repetitive stimulation studies, and sympathetic skin response.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
How are NCS and EMG usually performed and reported?	NCS and EMG are usually performed <b>together</b> and reported as <b>one comprehensive report</b>.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
What kind of information does the NCS/EMG test provide?	<table><tbody><tr><td>This test provides physiologic information about nerves and muscles in real time.<br></td></tr></tbody></table>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
What type of function information does NCS/EMG provide?	It gives information about muscle and nerve function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
How does the information provided by NCS/EMG compare to that provided by most radiologic studies?	Unlike most radiologic studies, which give a static picture of anatomy and do not directly assess function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
What are the indications for electrodiagnostic testing?	Indications for electrodiagnostic testing include numbness, tingling/paresthesias, pain, weakness, atrophy, depressed deep tendon reflexes, and/or fatigue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
How can EMG/NCS serve in a patient’s clinical picture?	EMG/NCS can serve as an important part of a patient’s clinical picture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
What are the uses of electrodiagnostic tests?	Electrodiagnostic tests are used to establish a correct diagnosis, localize a lesion, determine the treatment when a diagnosis is already known, and provide information about the prognosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
How should NCS/EMG be considered in relation to a history and physical examination?	How should NCS/EMG be considered in relation to a history and physical examination?																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Introduction
What is the sweep speed for NCS?	Sweep speed is the horizontal axis on the recording in units of time (milliseconds [ms]).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Initial_Setting_NCS
What is the gain for NCS?	Gain is the vertical axis on the graph in units of voltage (millivolts [mV] for motor studies or microvolts [μV] for sensory studies).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Initial_Setting_NCS
What are the motor settings for sweep and gain?	Motor settings: sweep—2 ms/division, gain—5 mV/division																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Initial_Setting_NCS
What are the sensory settings for sweep and gain?	Sensory settings: sweep—2 ms/division, gain—20 μV/division																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Initial_Setting_NCS
What is the sweep speed setting for EMG?	Sweep speed: 10 ms/division																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Initial_Settings_EMG
What is the low-frequency filter setting for EMG?	Low-frequency filter: 10 to 30 Hz																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Initial_Settings_EMG
What is the high-frequency filter setting for EMG?	High-frequency filter: 10,000 to 20,000 Hz																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Initial_Settings_EMG
What is the amplifier sensitivity setting for EMG?	Amplifier sensitivity: 50 to 100 μV																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Initial_Settings_EMG
What is NCS?	NCS is the recording of an electrical response of a nerve that is stimulated at one or more sites along its course.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
How is the nerve stimulated in NCS?	The nerve is stimulated electrically using a probe.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
Where is the response recorded in motor studies?	The response is recorded over the muscle that the nerve supplies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
Where is the response recorded in sensory studies?	The response is recorded over the dermatome that the nerve supplies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What is the action potential (AP) in NCS?	The action potential (AP) is the summative response of many individual axons or muscle fibers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What is the response called for motor nerves?	For motor nerves, this response is called a compound motor action potential (CMAP).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What does CMAP represent?	CMAP represents the summative response of motor units (MUs) that are firing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
In what units are CMAPs usually recorded?	CMAPs are usually recorded in millivolts (mV).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What is the response called for sensory nerves?	For sensory nerves, the response is called a sensory nerve action potential (SNAP).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What does SNAP represent?	SNAP represents the summation of individual sensory nerve fibers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
In what units are SNAPs usually recorded?	SNAPs are usually recorded in microvolts (μV).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What are late responses in NCS?	Late responses include F waves and H-reflexes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What does orthodromic refer to?	Orthodromic refers to conduction in the same direction as occurs physiologically.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What does antidromic refer to?	Antidromic refers to conduction in the opposite direction to the physiological direction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What is latency in the context of AP?	Latency is the time it takes from stimulation to the beginning of the CMAP or SNAP (the distal speed of transmission).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
On what is the latency of a sensory nerve dependent?	The latency of a sensory nerve is dependent on the conduction speed of the fastest fibers and the distance it travels.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What additional factor affects the latency of a motor nerve?	The latency of a motor nerve includes the time it takes for the AP to synapse at the neuromuscular junction (NMJ) and the speed of conduction of the electrical potential through the muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
Why is the latency of a sensory nerve directly related to conduction velocity (CV)?	Since there is no myoneural junction of sensory nerves, the latency of a sensory nerve is directly related to the conduction velocity (CV).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What is required for latency measurement to be meaningful?	Latency measurement requires standardized and accurately recorded distance or else the results are meaningless.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What does conduction velocity reflect?	Conduction velocity reflects how fast the nerve AP is propagating.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
How is velocity measured in sensory studies?	In sensory studies, the velocity is measured directly from the time it takes the AP to travel the measured distance (distance/latency).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
How is velocity calculated in motor nerves?	In a motor nerve, two different sites have to be stimulated to calculate the velocity (velocity = change in distance/change in time) and account for the myoneural junction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What speeds up NCV in myelinated nerves?	The presence of a myelin covering speeds up NCV via a process known as saltatory conduction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
How much faster do myelinated nerves conduct impulses compared to unmyelinated nerves?	Myelinated nerves conduct impulses approximately 50 times faster than unmyelinated nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
On what is CV primarily dependent in myelinated nerves?	In myelinated nerves, the CV is primarily dependent on the integrity of the myelin covering.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What does slowing or latency prolongation usually imply?	Slowing or latency prolongation usually implies demyelination.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
With what does amplitude correlate?	Amplitude correlates with axonal integrity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
What could decreased amplitude indicate?	It is the job of the electromyographer to diagnose and communicate the type of injury that exists, the severity, and the location.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Intro_NCS
Who proposed a classification of nerve injuries in 1943?	<b>Seddon</b> proposed a classification of nerve injuries in 1943.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is neurapraxia?	Neurapraxia is defined as conduction block. This type of nerve injury occurs in the peripheral nerve with minor contusion or compression. There is preservation of the axon; only the myelin is affected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What happens in neurapraxia?	In neurapraxia, there is an area of demyelination that is so severe that the <b>AP cannot propagate</b> (saltatory conduction cannot occur).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is the transmission of AP like in neurapraxia?	The transmission of AP is interrupted for a brief period, but recovery is usually complete in days to weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is axonotmesis?	Axonotmesis is a more significant injury: breakdown of axon with accompanying Wallerian degeneration distal to the lesion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is preserved in axonotmesis?	There is preservation of some of the supporting connective tissue stroma (Schwann cells and endoneurial tubes).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
How can axon regeneration occur in axonotmesis?	Regeneration of axons (through collateral sprouting or axonal growth) can occur with good functional recovery, depending on the amount of axonal loss and the distance from the injury to the muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is neurotmesis?	Neurotmesis is a severe injury with complete severance of the nerve and its supporting structures; extensive avulsing or crushing injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What structures are disrupted in neurotmesis?	The myelin, axon, perineurium, and epineurium are all disrupted.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is the expected recovery in neurotmesis?	Spontaneous recovery is not expected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
How can injury to the myelin be characterized?	Injury to the myelin can be focal (local), uniform (throughout the nerve), or segmental (affecting some parts of the nerve but not others).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is uniform demyelination?	Uniform demyelination is the slowing of CV along the entire nerve (e.g., Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is segmental demyelination?	Segmental demyelination is an uneven degree of demyelination in different areas along the course of the nerve; may have variable slowing (temporal dispersion).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is focal nerve slowing?	Focal nerve slowing is a localized area of demyelination causing nerve slowing; decreased CV is noted across the lesion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What is conduction block?	Conduction block is severe focal demyelination that prevents propagation of the AP through the area.&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
How does conduction block present?	Clinically, conduction block presents as weakness.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
will amplitude decrease or increase if the nerve is stimulated proximal to the lesion?	There will be more than 20% amplitude decrement when the nerve is stimulated proximal to the lesion. The distal CMAP amplitude remains intact.&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What happens in axonal injuries?	Axonal injuries will lead to Wallerian degeneration distal to the lesion. Low-amplitude CMAPs will be noted with both proximal and distal stimulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
What are the EMG findings in axonal injuries?	On EMG, abnormal spontaneous<b> potentials (fibrillations [fibs] and positive sharp waves [PSWs]) are seen.</b> The MU recruitment will be decreased (increased firing frequency of existing MUs)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Types_Nerve_Injuries
With reinnervation, how would Motor units findings present on EMG?	With reinnervation, MUs may become polyphasic with high amplitude and long duration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies
What is the H-reflex (Hoffmann reflex)?	The H-reflex (Hoffmann reflex) is a true reflex and is the electrical equivalent of the monosynaptic or oligosynaptic stretch reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
For what condition is the H-reflex a sensitive but nonspecific tool?	The H-reflex is a sensitive but nonspecific tool for possible S1 radiculopathy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
When is the H-reflex particularly useful?	The H-reflex is particularly useful when clinical, radiologic, and electrophysiologic signs of motor root involvement are <b>lacking</b>.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
How is the H-reflex usually elicited?	The H-reflex is usually elicited by submaximally stimulating the tibial nerve in the popliteal fossa.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What kind of stimuli are used to elicit the H-reflex?	Slow (less than 1 pulse/s), long-duration (0.5–1 ms) stimuli with gradually increasing stimulation strength are used to elicit the H-reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
Through which nerve fibers does the H-reflex stimulus travel?	The stimulus travels along the most excitable 1a afferent nerve fibers, through the dorsal root ganglion (DRG).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What pathway does the H-reflex follow after the DRG?	It gets transmitted across the central synapse to the anterior horn cell, which then sends it down along the alpha motor axon to the muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What does the H-reflex measure?	The H-reflex measures the time it takes for the o<b>rthodromic sensory response to get to the spinal cord proximally</b> and the <b>orthodromic motor response to reach the muscle distally</b>.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What are the generally acceptable results for the H-reflex?	A generally acceptable result would be a motor response usually between 0.5 and 5 mV in amplitude and a latency of 28 to 30 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
Why are H-reflex studies usually performed bilaterally?	H-reflex studies are usually performed bilaterally because asymmetry of responses is an important criterion for abnormality.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What can an abnormal latency greater than 0.5 to 1.0 ms suggest in patients under 60 years?	An abnormal latency greater than 0.5 to 1.0 ms (as compared with the other side) or H-reflex absence in patients under 60 years may suggest a lesion along the H-reflex pathway (afferent and/or efferent fibers).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What may cause an abnormal H-reflex latency or absence?	This may be due to an S1 radiculopathy or any other source of slowing along this pathway.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What is the standard formula for calculating the H-reflex?	The standard formula for calculating the H-reflex is 9.14 + 0.46 (leg length in cm from the medial malleolus to the popliteal fossa) + 0.1 (age).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What adjustment is made to the H-reflex calculation for patients older than 60 years?	For a patient older than 60 years, 1.8 ms will be added to the total calculated value.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::H_Reflex
What is the F wave or F response?	F wave or F response is a small-amplitude, variable-latency late motor response that occurs following the activation of motor nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
Why is it called the F wave?	It derives its name from the word “foot” because it was first recorded from the intrinsic foot muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
Does the F wave represent a true reflex?	Unlike the H-reflex, the F wave does not represent a true reflex because there is no synapse from an afferent impulse to a motor nerve.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
How are potentials evoked in F waves?	Depolarizing peripheral nerves with external stimuli evokes potentials propagating both proximally and distally.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
What results from the electrical stimulation of a peripheral nerve?	Electrical stimulation of a peripheral nerve results in an orthodromic CMAP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
What activates a small percentage of anterior horn motor neurons?	<b>The proximally (antidromically) propagating potential</b> activates a small percentage of anterior horn motor neurons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
What generates an orthodromic motor response (the F wave)?	The activation of a small percentage of anterior horn motor neurons generates an orthodromic motor response (the F wave) along the same axon.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
Where is the F wave picked up by the recording electrode?	The F wave activates a few muscle fibers picked up by the recording electrode.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
From where can F waves be obtained?	F waves can be obtained from any muscle by a supramaximal stimulus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
Why must multiple stimulations be used to obtain the shortest latency in F waves?	Because of their variability (as opposed to H-reflexes), multiple stimulations must be used to obtain the shortest latency.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
In what conditions may F waves be useful?	F waves may be useful in the evaluation of <b>peripheral neuropathies</b> with predominantly proximal involvement, such as Guillain-Barré syndrome and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
Why is the value of the F wave limited in evaluating focal nerve lesions?	The value of the F wave in evaluating focal nerve lesions, such as radiculopathy or peripheral nerve entrapment, is extremely limited largely due to the variability of F-wave responses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
Why are F waves generally not seen in nerves with severely reduced CMAP amplitude?	F waves are generally not seen in nerves where the CMAP amplitude is severely reduced, such as severe axonal loss, since the F-wave amplitude is only 1% to 5% of the amplitude of the CMAP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
What is the normal latency of F wave in the upper limb?	Normal latency of F wave in the upper limb is 28 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
What is the normal latency of F wave in the lower limb?	Normal latency of F wave in the lower limb is 56 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
What is the acceptable side-to-side difference for F wave latency in the upper limbs?	Side-to-side difference for F wave latency in the upper limbs should be &lt;2.0 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
What is the acceptable side-to-side difference for F wave latency in the lower limbs?	Side-to-side difference for F wave latency in the lower limbs should be &lt;4.0 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::F_Waves
What is the blink reflex?	The blink reflex is the electrophysiologic correlate of the corneal reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What is the sensory afferent limb of the blink reflex?	The sensory afferent limb of the reflex is the supraorbital nerve, a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
Where are the intervening synapses of the blink reflex located?	The intervening synapses are in the pons and medulla.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What is the motor efferent limb of the blink reflex?	The motor efferent limb is the facial nerve (CN VII), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What happens when one side of the supraorbital branch of the trigeminal nerve is stimulated?	Stimulation of one side of the supraorbital branch of the trigeminal nerve elicits a motor response (eye blink) bilaterally through the facial nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
&nbsp;What can be detected by abnormalities along the reflex arc?	Abnormalities anywhere along the reflex arc (central or peripheral) can be detected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What causes the early response (R1) in the blink reflex?	The early response (R1) is due to a disynaptic reflex arc from the ipsilateral sensory nucleus of V to the ipsilateral facial nerve.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What causes the late response (R2) in the blink reflex?	The late response (R2) is due to multiple interneurons connecting the ipsilateral sensory nucleus of V to the ipsilateral spinal motor nucleus of V and then to the bilateral facial nuclei.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
Where are recording electrodes placed for the blink reflex?	Recording electrodes are placed below and slightly lateral to the pupils bilaterally.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
Where are reference electrodes placed for the blink reflex?	Reference electrodes are placed just lateral to the lateral canthus bilaterally.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
Where can the ground electrode be placed for the blink reflex?	The ground can be placed on the chin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
Where is the stimulator placed for the blink reflex?	The stimulator is placed over the medial supraorbital ridge of the eyebrow.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What should be the sweep speed for the blink reflex?	The sweep speed should be 5 or 10 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What should be the initial sensitivity for the blink reflex?	The initial sensitivity should be 100 or 200 μV.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What is the normal latency for the R1 response in the blink reflex?	Normal latency for the R1 response is &lt;13 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What is the normal latency for the ipsilateral R2 response in the blink reflex?	Normal latency for the ipsilateral R2 is &lt;41 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What is the normal latency for the contralateral R2 response in the blink reflex?	Normal latency for the contralateral R2 is 44 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What is the acceptable normal bilateral variation for the R1 response?	Acceptable normal bilateral variation for R1 is &lt;1.2 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What is the acceptable normal bilateral variation for the ipsilateral R2 response?	Acceptable normal bilateral variation for ipsilateral R2 is &lt;5 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What is the acceptable normal bilateral variation for the contralateral R2 response?	Acceptable normal bilateral variation for contralateral R2 is &lt;7 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Blink_Reflex
What does EMG testing involve?	EMG testing involves evaluation of the electrical activity of skeletal or voluntary muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
How do muscles contract and produce movement?	Muscles contract and produce movement through the orderly recruitment of motor units (MUs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What is defined as a motor unit (MU)?	An MU is defined as <b>one anterior horn cell, its axon, the NMJ, and all the muscle fibers</b> (ranging from five to hundreds), innervated by that motor neuron.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What is the fundamental structure assessed in EMG testing?	The MU is the fundamental structure assessed in EMG testing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What does EMG require a thorough knowledge of?	EMG requires a thorough knowledge of the anatomy of the muscle being tested in order to place the needle electrode in the appropriate muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What are monopolar needles?	Monopolar needles are 22-G to 30-G Teflon-coated stainless steel needles with an exposed tip of 0.15 to 0.2 mm².																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What do monopolar needles require as a reference lead?	They require a surface electrode or a second needle as a reference lead.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What serves as a ground for monopolar needles?	Another surface electrode serves as a ground.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
How does a monopolar needle record voltage changes?	A monopolar needle records the voltage changes between the tip of the electrode and the reference.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
Why does a monopolar needle register larger amplitude and increased polyphasicity?	Since it picks up from a full 360° field around the needle, it registers larger amplitude and has increased polyphasicity compared to the concentric needle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
Why is the monopolar needle less uncomfortable?	The smaller diameter and the Teflon coat make the monopolar needle less uncomfortable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What advantage does the monopolar needle have over the concentric needle?	Its cost advantage has led to its preferential clinical use.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What are concentric needles?	Concentric needles are 24-G to 26-G stainless steel needles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What comprises a concentric needle?	The needle comprises a reference (cannula) electrode with a bare inner wire in the center of the shaft that is the recording electrode.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
How does the concentric needle register voltage changes?	The concentric needle can register the voltage changes between the wire and the shaft.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What shape does the pointed tip of the concentric needle have?	The pointed tip of the needle has an oval (beveled) shape.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
Where is the exposed active recording electrode located on the concentric needle?	The exposed active recording electrode is on the beveled portion of the cannula.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
From what field does the concentric needle pick up?	The concentric needle picks up from a 180° field.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
Why does the concentric needle register smaller amplitude?	It registers smaller amplitude since it has a smaller recording area.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What serves as the ground for concentric needles?	A separate surface electrode serves as the ground.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Monopolar_vs_Concentric_Needles
What is the effect of cooling on Na+ channels?	Cooling is thought to prolong the opening of Na+ channels.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Temp_Age_Effect_NCS
How does decreasing the temperature of a limb affect SNAPs and CMAPs?	Decreasing the temperature of a limb affects SNAPs and CMAPs by prolonging latency, decreasing CV, and increasing amplitude and duration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Temp_Age_Effect_NCS
By how much does CV decrease per 1°C decrease in temperature?	CV decreases 2.4 m/s per 1°C decrease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Temp_Age_Effect_NCS
CV decreases 2.4 m/s per 1°C decrease.	The best approach is to warm the limb prior to the NCS (32° in the upper limbs and 30° in the lower limbs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Temp_Age_Effect_NCS
How do SNAP and CMAP amplitudes change with age?	As patients age, SNAP and CMAP amplitudes decrease and latencies increase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Temp_Age_Effect_NCS
What percentage of adult motor NCS values do newborns have, and why?	Motor NCSs for newborns are 50% of adult values since myelination is incomplete.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Temp_Age_Effect_NCS
By what age are normal adult motor NCS values attained?	Normal adult values are attained by age 5 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Temp_Age_Effect_NCS
How does NCS change after age 60 years?	After age 60 years, there is a progressive decline of 1 to 2 m/s per decade in the NCS of the fastest motor fibers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Temp_Age_Effect_NCS
What are the four components of the EMG evaluation?	The four components of the EMG evaluation are insertional activity, activity at rest, MU analysis, and recruitment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What is insertional activity?	Insertional activity refers to the brief electrical activity associated with the needle entering the sarcolemma, causing muscle fiber injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
How is the sound of insertional activity described?	The associated sound of insertional activity should be crisp.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
How long does normal insertional activity last?	Normal insertional activity only lasts a few hundred milliseconds and is due to muscle depolarization.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What causes increased insertional activity?	Increased insertional activity occurs due to denervation or cell membrane irritability and lasts &gt;300 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What happens if positive deflection waveforms are sustained and fire regularly?	If these positive deflection waveforms are sustained and fire regularly, they are considered abnormal spontaneous potentials.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What causes decreased insertional activity?	Decreased insertional activity occurs when the needle is placed into atrophied muscle, fat, or edema and lasts &lt;300 ms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What should be done after inserting a needle into normal muscle at rest?	After insertion of the needle into normal muscle at rest, there should be electrical silence.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
Where should a needle be placed to observe normal muscle at rest?	A needle should be inserted into a muscle at three to four different depths and in three to four different directions (examining three or four electrically discrete areas of muscle) for insertional activity and activity at rest.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
How many discrete areas of muscle should the needle examine?	The needle should examine about 12 to 16 discrete areas of the muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What should be done if end plate activity is observed?	The needle should be moved out of the end plate as the clinician cannot get reliable information about the muscle.<br>																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What are the two waveforms that may occur in end plate activity?	The two waveforms that may occur are miniature end plate potentials (MEPPs) and end plate potentials (EPPs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What are MEPPs?	MEPPs represent spontaneous release of single quantum of acetylcholine (ACh) at the presynaptic terminal that manifests as end plate noise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
"What are EPPs or ""end plate spikes""?"	"EPPs or ""end plate spikes"" represent single muscle fiber depolarizations at the presynaptic terminal with resultant release of large amounts of ACh."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
Can MEPPs and EPPs be present together?	MEPPs and EPPs may or may not be present together.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What usually represents pathology in abnormal spontaneous activity?	Abnormal spontaneous activity usually represents pathology (injury or denervation).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
When can fibrillations (fibs) and positive sharp waves (PSWs) be seen in abnormal spontaneous activity?	Fibrillations and positive sharp waves can be seen in abnormal spontaneous activity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Needle_EMG_Examination
What is the most objective evidence of acute denervation?	The presence of spontaneous activity on needle EMG is the most objective evidence of acute denervation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
How soon can fibrillations and PSWs be seen in paraspinal muscles after injury?	Fibrillations and PSWs can be seen in the paraspinal muscles within 5 to 7 days of initial injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
When do findings in peripheral muscles occur after injury?	Findings in peripheral muscles occur within 3 to 6 weeks after injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
How many muscles should be tested to diagnose radiculopathy?	The corresponding paraspinal muscle and two peripheral muscles innervated by different peripheral nerves, but the same nerve root, should have positive findings.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What happens to motor units (MUs) with axon loss?	What happens to motor units (MUs) with axon loss?																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What may disappear with reinnervation?	With reinnervation, the abnormal spontaneous activity may disappear.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What is the most common entrapment neuropathy?	Median neuropathy at the wrist, known as carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), is the most common entrapment neuropathy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What are the etiologies of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS)?	The etiologies of CTS are multifactorial with varying contributions of local and systemic factors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What is the initial presentation of CTS usually due to?	What is the initial presentation of CTS usually due to?																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
Can demyelination affect motor fibers early on in CTS?	Yes, demyelination may also affect the motor fibers early on in CTS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
How may CTS progress if untreated?	CTS may progress to axonal loss of both sensory and motor fibers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What are the symptoms of CTS?	Symptoms of CTS include numbness, tingling, and pain along the median nerve distribution (palmar surface of the first 3½ digits).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
When are CTS symptoms often worst or most prevalent?	Symptoms may be worst or most prevalent at night and may wake the patient from sleep.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What symptoms may occur as CTS progresses and median motor fibers become involved?	Weakness of grip strength (inability to open jars or dropping objects) may occur as symptoms progress and median motor fibers become involved.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
Which hand is usually affected first in bilateral CTS?	The dominant hand is usually affected first in bilateral CTS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What does physical examination for CTS involve?	Physical examination for CTS involves sensory tests (pinprick, 2-point discrimination, and/or Semmes-Weinstein pressure monofilaments) and motor tests/inspection for abductor pollicis brevis (APB) atrophy and weakness.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What is the sensitivity of electrodiagnostic studies in confirming the diagnosis of CTS?	Electrodiagnostic studies have an 85%–90% sensitivity in confirming the diagnosis of CTS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What must be kept in mind about the relationship between abnormal studies and CTS?	It must be kept in mind that not all those with abnormal studies have CTS, and not all those with CTS have abnormal studies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What does the classic evaluation of CTS include?	Classic evaluation of CTS includes motor and sensory nerve conduction studies (NCS) of the median nerve and its comparison with the ulnar nerve (ipsilaterally) and median nerve (contralaterally).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What may a needle study help assess in CTS?	A needle study may help assess for axonal damage or reinnervation and rule out radiculopathy or other nerve lesions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
How are antidromic SNAPs recorded for CTS?	Antidromic SNAPs are recorded with the active electrode over the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint of the second or third digit, stimulating the mid-palm (7 cm from electrode) and across the carpal tunnel (14 cm from electrode).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What is important to change in recordings for CTS to affect the velocity?	It is important to change the distance in recordings depending on the size of the patient’s hand.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
On what does the electrodiagnostic analysis of CTS depend?	The electrodiagnostic analysis of CTS depends upon evidence of median nerve slowing, conduction block, or axon loss in the carpal tunnel.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What are commonly used criteria for CTS in electrodiagnostic analysis?	Commonly used criteria for CTS include prolonged absolute motor or sensory latency, sensory slowing across the carpal tunnel, as well as amplitude changes that would indicate axonal loss or a conduction block.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What sensory changes may indicate CTS?	Sensory changes that may indicate CTS include conduction velocity (CV) &lt;44 m/s (median nerve across the carpal tunnel) and latency of &gt;0.5 ms compared with the ipsilateral ulnar nerve.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What amplitude changes may indicate motor involvement in CTS?	Amplitude changes indicating motor involvement in CTS include an amplitude of the median response across the carpal tunnel &lt;50% of the distal amplitude or the contralateral amplitude.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What latency changes may indicate motor involvement in CTS?	Motor latency changes that may indicate CTS include latency of &gt;4.2 ms at a distance of 8 cm from the active electrode, and latency of &gt;1 ms greater than the ipsilateral ulnar motor nerve latency.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
Which muscle should be included in the EMG test for CTS?	The EMG test for CTS should include the abductor pollicis brevis (APB) muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What should be tested if the APB muscle is abnormal in CTS?	If the APB is abnormal, more proximal median as well as non-median innervated muscles should be tested to rule out a more proximal median neuropathy, peripheral neuropathy, plexopathy, radiculopathy, or a lesion of the anterior horn cell.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What is a possible source of confusion in median nerve electrodiagnostic studies?	A possible source of confusion is a Martin-Gruber anastomosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What is Martin-Gruber anastomosis?	Martin-Gruber anastomosis is a relatively common anastomosis where ulnar fibers (destined for ulnar innervated muscles) travel with the median nerve.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What are the three classic electrodiagnostic findings for Martin-Gruber anastomosis?	The three classic electrodiagnostic findings are: <br>1. The median CMAP has a positive (downward) initial deflection after median nerve stimulation at the elbow that is not seen with wrist stimulation. <br><br>2. The CMAP amplitude of median nerve stimulation at the elbow will be larger compared with wrist stimulation. <br>3. The amplitude is increased because at the elbow the ulnar nerve fibers traveling with the median nerve are stimulated and added to the median CMAP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Specific_Disorders
What is peripheral neuropathy?	Peripheral neuropathy is a generalized dysfunction of the peripheral nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
Which segments of the nerves are usually more affected in peripheral neuropathy?	The distal segments of the nerves are usually more affected than the proximal segments.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
How does peripheral neuropathy typically occur?	Peripheral neuropathies typically occur in a “stocking and glove” distribution, affecting the feet and hands with numbness, pain, or paresthesias.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What are electrodiagnostic studies used to determine in peripheral neuropathy?	Electrodiagnostic studies (NCS/EMG) are used to determine the presence of peripheral neuropathy and can help to identify its characteristics and severity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
How is peripheral neuropathy classified?	Peripheral neuropathy is classified based on the types of fibers involved (sensory or motor), the primary pathology affecting the component of the nerve (axonal or demyelinating), and its extent (segmental or uniform).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What must be tested in electrodiagnostic testing to differentiate between single entrapment neuropathy and a generalized process?	Both sensory and motor nerves must be tested in at least three extremities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What is required to diagnose a peripheral neuropathy?	Relevant findings must be found in at least three extremities to be diagnosed as a peripheral neuropathy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
Why might early changes in peripheral neuropathy not be seen in the upper extremity?	Early in the progression of peripheral neuropathy, changes may not be seen in the upper extremity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What might be reduced in sensory NCS for peripheral neuropathy?	Sensory NCS: SNAPs may be reduced.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What happens to SNAP if the neuropathy is axonal?	If axonal, amplitude of SNAP will be reduced or unobtainable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What happens to SNAP if the neuropathy is demyelinating?	If demyelinating, SNAP can have an increased latency and/or decreased CV; demyelination may result in loss of SNAP through conduction block (neurapraxia).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What might be affected or unobtainable in motor NCS if the neuropathy is axonal?	If axonal, amplitude of CMAP may be affected or unobtainable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What changes might be seen in CMAP if the neuropathy is demyelinating?	If demyelinating, CMAP may have increased distal latency or slowing of CV. Conduction block may also cause decreased CMAP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
How is uniform demyelination assessed?	Uniform demyelination is assessed by the location of slowing CV. If uniform, all fibers are slowed, resulting in uniform slowing of CV, prolonged latencies, and normal duration and amplitude NCS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
How is segmental demyelination assessed?	Segmental demyelination is assessed by the location of slowing CV. If segmental, some fibers will travel slower than others, and the CMAP will be dispersed, with a longer duration and lower amplitude (temporal dispersion).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What do late responses (F waves and H-reflexes) assess in peripheral neuropathy?	Late responses assess both the proximal and distal segments of a peripheral nerve and therefore may also be affected. However, findings are nonspecific.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What should be tested in EMG to assess for axonal neuropathy and rule out additional pathology?	Test proximal and distal muscles to assess for axonal neuropathy and rule out additional or concomitant pathology.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What are the usual findings in EMG for peripheral neuropathy?	Findings are usually negative in peripheral neuropathy except in a few cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What might affected muscles demonstrate in axonal motor neuropathy?	Affected muscles (usually distal) may demonstrate spontaneous activity (fibs and PSW).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
How can the duration of an axonal lesion be assessed in EMG?	The duration of the disease can be assessed by evaluating chronic changes in MUAPs (increased duration, polyphasicity, or large amplitude reveals reinnervation and reorganization).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What might be seen in chronic neurogenic disorders in EMG?	Chronic neurogenic disorders may show CRDs (complex repetitive discharges).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What are the possible causes of peripheral neuropathy?	There are many causes for peripheral neuropathy, including genetic and acquired disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
How are these disorders further classified?	These disorders are further typified based on separate classifications of peripheral neuropathy that can be derived using electrodiagnostic studies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Peripheral_Neuropathy
What may motor neuron diseases affect?	Motor neuron diseases may affect both the upper motor neurons (UMNs) and lower motor neurons (LMNs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What specific areas do motor neuron diseases affect?	These disorders specifically affect the motor cortex, corticospinal tracts, and/or anterior horn cells.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What are the clinical signs of LMN lesions?	Clinical signs of LMN lesions include atrophy, flaccidity, hyporeflexia, and fasciculations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What are the clinical signs of UMN lesions?	UMN signs include weakness, spasticity, hyperreflexia, and upgoing plantar reflex (positive Babinski sign).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
Are there usually any sensory changes in motor neuron diseases?	There are usually no sensory changes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What aspect of the disorder can be assessed with EMG testing?	With EMG testing, only the LMN aspect of the disorder can be assessed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What are the electrodiagnostic findings for SNAP in motor neuron diseases?	SNAP has normal amplitude and conduction velocities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What are the electrodiagnostic findings for CMAP in motor neuron diseases?	CMAP conduction velocities are normal or mildly decreased. The amplitude of the CMAP may be decreased due to axonal loss if significant atrophy is present.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
