What are the EMG findings in motor neuron diseases?	EMG findings (in at least three limbs or two limbs and bulbar muscles) include abnormal spontaneous potentials (fibs and PSW), fasciculations, and CRDs. Decreased recruitment with increased firing frequency may be noted. Large-amplitude, long-duration polyphasic potentials may be noted if reinnervation has occurred.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What are examples of LMN motor neuron diseases?	LMN: Poliomyelitis/post-polio syndrome (PPS) and spinal muscular atrophy (SMA).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What is an example of a disease that affects both UMN and LMN?	UMN and LMN: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What is an example of a disease that affects only UMN?	UMN: Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What characterizes ALS?	ALS is characterized by degeneration of anterior horn cell.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What signs are usually present in ALS?	UMN and LMN signs are usually present.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What is the clinical presentation of ALS?	Clinical presentation includes asymmetric atrophy, weakness and fasciculations, dysphagia, and dysarthria. Pseudobulbar signs may be noted. Bowel and bladder are typically spared.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What are the EMG findings in ALS?	EMG findings include abnormal spontaneous potentials (fibs and PSWs). MUAPs demonstrate decreased recruitment with increased MUAP duration and amplitude.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What characterizes PPS?	PPS is characterized by the loss of anterior horn cell decades (typically 30 years) after polio.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What is the hypothesized cause of PPS?	This disorder is hypothesized to be due to burnout of MUs from increased metabolic demand or normal axon loss with aging.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What are the Halstead-Ross criteria for PPS?	Halstead-Ross criteria include the onset of two or more of the following: fatigue, arthralgia, myalgia, and cold intolerance with history of previous stable polio diagnosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
How does PPS resemble in electrodiagnostic findings?	Electrodiagnostically, PPS may resemble poliomyelitis, so clinical findings must be considered.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What do NCSs show in PPS?	NCSs show normal SNAPs and abnormal CMAP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
&nbsp;What does EMG show in PPS?	EMG shows increased amplitude and duration of MUAPs with decreased recruitment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::Motor_Neuron_Diseases
What is an important tool in the diagnosis of myopathies?	Electrodiagnostic testing is an important tool in the diagnosis of myopathies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What does EMG testing help to do in myopathies?	EMG testing helps to make a diagnosis, determine the extent of a disease, prognosticate, and guide further studies, such as muscle biopsies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
Why is only one side of the body generally tested on EMG?	Generally, only one side of the body is tested on EMG, leaving the muscles on the other side preserved for muscle biopsy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What is important to rule out when performing EMG studies?	It is important to rule out other diseases by performing at least one sensory and one motor nerve study in addition to the EMG study.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What are the typical NCS findings in myopathies?	NCS is usually normal since myopathies typically affect proximal muscles initially.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
Why might NCS be abnormal as myopathy progresses?	As the disease progresses, distal muscles may become involved and the motor NCS may be abnormal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What are the typical SNAP findings in myopathies?	SNAP: Normal (sensory fibers are not affected).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What are the typical CMAP findings in myopathies?	CMAP: Amplitudes may be reduced due to muscle fiber atrophy; distal latency and CV are normal as the myelin is not affected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What are the typical EMG findings in myopathies?	EMG: MUs will usually show early recruitment, polyphasia (due to the variability in muscle fiber diameter), and small-amplitude (due to muscle fiber dropout) and short-duration potentials.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What abnormal potentials can be seen in myopathies?	Fib potentials and PSWs as well as myotonic discharges can be seen.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What may be observed in long-standing myopathies at rest?	In long-standing myopathies, there may be little activity at rest due to loss of muscle fiber.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What is common in many myopathies regarding insertional activity?	Increased insertional activity is also common in many myopathies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
Which muscles typically show more positive EMG findings in myopathies?	Typically, the proximal lower extremity muscles will show more positive EMG findings.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
Why is it important to sample a sufficient number of muscles in myopathies?	It is important to sample a sufficient number of muscles to differentiate between a myopathy and a focal injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
How should muscles be sampled in myopathies?	Muscles should be sampled based on weakness as seen in the clinical examination.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
Why might extremely weak muscles (&lt;2/5 in manual testing) not provide a good signal?	Muscles that are extremely weak (&lt;2/5 in manual testing) can be too deteriorated to provide a good signal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
What are the EMG findings in steroid myopathy?	In steroid myopathy, EMG testing would be normal, as it predominantly affects the type II muscle fibers (EMG tests primarily the type I fibers).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::EMG_Findings_Myopathies
How is the NMJ divided?	The NMJ is divided into the presynaptic terminal, the synaptic cleft, and a postsynaptic muscle end plate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What does neuromuscular transmission involve?	Neuromuscular transmission involves (a) presynaptic terminal depolarization and ACh release, (b) ACh binding and ion channel opening, and (c) postsynaptic membrane depolarization and muscle AP generation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What do disorders of the NMJ hinder?	Disorders of the NMJ hinder the production, release, or uptake of ACh at the NMJ.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What is the most well-known postsynaptic NMJ disorder?	The most well-known postsynaptic disorder is myasthenia gravis (MG).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What are examples of presynaptic abnormalities in NMJ disorders?	Presynaptic abnormalities include Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) and botulism.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What are useful electrodiagnostic tests for evaluating NMJ disorders?	A repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) study and SFEMG are useful electrodiagnostic tests when trying to evaluate for NMJ disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
How are routine sensory and motor conduction studies in NMJ disorders?	Routine sensory and motor conduction studies will usually be normal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What might be observed in profound weakness, such as in myasthenic crisis?	Only in profound weakness, as in myasthenic crisis, borderline or slightly decreased CMAP amplitudes will be observed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What may routine EMG examination demonstrate in NMJ disorders?	Routine EMG examination may demonstrate unstable MUAPs, where moment-to-moment variations in amplitude and configuration may be seen.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
How is RNS performed after routine NCS?	RNS after routine NCS is performed by delivering trains of supramaximal stimuli to a peripheral nerve while recording CMAPs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What does RNS deplete in diseased NMJs?	This depletes stores of releasable ACh from diseased NMJs, producing a progressive amplitude decrement from the first to the fifth waveform in patients with disorders of the NMJ.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What is considered an abnormal decrement in RNS at low rates?	When RNS is performed at low rates (2–5 Hz), a decrement of &gt;10% is considered abnormal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
Which muscles are usually more affected in NMJ disorders?	Although the proximal muscles are usually more affected than the distal muscles, the proximal muscles are more difficult to test.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What is postactivation facilitation?	Postactivation facilitation occurs when there is recovery of the CMAP amplitudes on repeat slow RNS following a 10-second isometric contraction or rapid RNS (20–50 Hz) studies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What causes postactivation facilitation?	This is due to calcium facilitation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
In which conditions is postactivation facilitation present?	Although present to a lesser degree in MG and botulism, it is a hallmark finding in LEMS where increments as high as 500% may be observed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What should be considered if initial studies are unrevealing but suspicion for an NMJ disorder is high?	Consider testing more proximal muscles (e.g., spinal accessory and facial nerves) and/or proceeding to SFEMG of at least one symptomatic muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What is the most sensitive test for NMJ disorders?	SFEMG is the most sensitive test for NMJ disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What are findings consistent with NMJ disorders?	Findings consistent with, but not specific for, NMJ disorders include increased jitter.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What is jitter?	Jitter refers to time variations between interpotential discharges of two different muscle fibers of the same MU.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What is the most extreme abnormality of jitter?	The most extreme abnormality of jitter is failed transmission, or blocking.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
How does jitter and blocking change in MG with increased firing rate?	In MG, jitter and blocking increase with increased firing rate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
How does jitter and blocking change in LEMS and botulism with increased firing rate?	In LEMS and botulism, jitter and blocking decrease with increased firing rate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
What are the prerequisites for performing a reliable RNS study?	Prerequisites for performing a reliable RNS study include immobilization of the limb and recording electrode, supramaximal stimulation, optimization of limb temperature (warming the limb), and withholding of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors 12 to 24 hours prior to testing (if not medically contraindicated).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
Which nerves can be easily tested for RNS?	Distal nerves that can be easily tested for RNS are the median and ulnar nerves, with recording electrodes at APB and ADM, respectively.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
Which nerve is commonly utilized if proximal studies are indicated?	If proximal studies are indicated, spinal accessory nerve with the recording electrode on the upper trapezius muscle is commonly utilized.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
How can ocular MG be tested in RNS?	In patients suspected of having ocular MG, facial RNS recording at orbicularis oris can be performed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
Congenital or Infantile myasthenia patients are missing what antibodies?	Missing antibodies to Ach receptor&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
What is the first line pharmacological therapy for JIA?	NSAIDs and Intra articular steroid joint injections																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies RehabReadyTags::Electrodiagnostic_Studies::NMJ_Disorders
how is FSHD it diagnosed?	Molecular genetic testing																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
Why would we postpone corticosteroid therapy in juvenile myasthenia gravis?	potential growth retardation																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
Why would we avoid thymectomy procedure in juvenile myasthenia gravis?	Increased risk of inducing immunodeficiency																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
Would level of activity (Mild, Moderate, Advanced) should be recommended in a patient with charcot marie tooth?	Moderate activity																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
What should be the patient be advised to avoid in charcot marie tooth?	Overexertion																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
What is the most common <i>movement type category</i> in cerebral palsy&nbsp;	Spastic&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
Persistence of primitive reflexes in an infant at&nbsp;<i>what age</i>&nbsp;is considered a red flag for CP&nbsp;	after 6 months of age																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
Periventricular leukomalacia is a common imaging finding in what pediatric disorder	Cerebral palsy&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
Immobility is a factor that affects what in a patient with cerebral palsy?	Life expectancy																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
An infant shortly after birth presents with internal rotation of the shoulder, adduction, with the elbow extended. What should you assess for?	Erb Palsy																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
Front 	Back																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam
What is mental status based on in a neurologic examination?	Mental status is based on numerous aspects of cognitive functioning including orientation, attention, concentration, memory, etc.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What indicates basic cognition in a mental status evaluation?	Orientation is necessary for basic cognition and is based on person, place, time, and situation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What does attention measure in a mental status evaluation?	Attention is the ability to address situations without distraction and can be tested with serial 7s (asking patient to count backwards from 100 in sevens. Ex: 100, 93, 86...etc)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What does concentration evaluate in a mental status assessment?	Ability to pay attention for a longer period of time.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What are the three components of memory?	learning, retention, and recall.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
"How can you test a patient&#x27;s ability to recall in a mental status examination?"	Ask the patient to repeat three objects initially and recall them after 5 minutes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
How can recent and remote memory be tested?	Asking questions pertaining to the past 24 hours and major events over the patient’s lifetime.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
How is mood determined in a mental status assessment?	By asking, &quot;How are you feeling?&quot; or &quot;Are you feeling sad or depressed?&quot;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What does insight refer to in a mental status evaluation?	"Patient&#x27;s ability to understand awareness of impairment, need for treatment, and attribution of symptoms."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
How is judgment assessed in a mental status evaluation?	Assessing ability to solve everyday problems.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What are the key aspects analyzed when evaluating speech and language in a mental status assessment?	Rate, articulation, fluency, naming, word comprehension, repetition, writing, and reading.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What are considered higher cognitive functions in a mental status examination?	Higher cognitive functions include calculation, abstract thinking, and drawing a clock.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What is the Mini Mental Status Examination used for?	Screening tool for cognitive function																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
What indicates a normal score on Mini Mental Status Examination?	A score of 24 or greater out of 30 is normal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Mental_status
How can the olfactory nerve (CN1) be tested?	The olfactory nerve can be tested by using aromatic nonirritating products to evaluate the sense of smell.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What is examined when testing the optic nerve (CN2)?	visual fields and acuity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
Which cranial nerves are involved in eye movement?	oculomotor (CN3), trochlear (CN4), and abducens (CN6).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What functions are controlled by the oculomotor nerve?	Pupillary constriction, opening the eye, and controlling all muscles of eye movement except for the lateral rectus (CN6) and superior oblique (CN4).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
Which muscle is innervated by the abducens nerve?	Lateral rectus muscle - allows for lateral deviation of the eye																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What muscle does the trochlear nerve innervate?	Superior oblique muscle - downward and inward movement of the eye.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What motor and sensory functions does the trigeminal nerve (CN5) provide?	The trigeminal nerve provides motor innervation to the temporalis and masseter muscles (jaw clenching and lateral movement) and sensory innervation to the face divided into three divisions: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What are the functions of the facial nerve (CN7)?	Motor innervation to the facial muscles for facial expressions, closing the eye, and closing the mouth. It also allows for the taste of salty, sweet, sour, and bitter substances on the anterior two thirds of the tongue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What are the actions of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN8)?	hearing (cochlear division) and balance (vestibular division).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What does the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN9) provide?	Motor innervation to the pharynx and sensory innervation to the posterior portions of the eardrum and ear canal, the pharynx, and the posterior tongue (including taste).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What are the functions of the vagus nerve (CN10)?	Motor innervation to the soft palate (elevation), pharynx, and larynx. Sensory innervation to the pharynx and larynx (gag reflex).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What does the spinal accessory nerve (CN11) control?	Motor innervation to the sternocleidomastoid and upper portion of the trapezius muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What function does the hypoglossal nerve (CN12) serve?	Pure motor innervation to the muscles of the tongue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Cranial
What is muscle tone?	Resistance to muscle stretch through passive elongation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_tone
What is the characteristic of muscle tone when it is flaccid?	Absence of resistance to muscle stretch.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_tone
What clinical indication is observed with lower motor neuron involvement?	LMN symptoms can be observed in Guillain-Barré syndrome, acute phase of stroke, and spinal cord injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_tone
What defines spasticity in muscle tone?	Increased resistance to muscle stretch that is velocity dependent.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_tone
What does upper motor neuron involvement indicate clinically?	UMN symptoms is seen in multiple sclerosis, chronic phase of stroke, and spinal cord injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_tone
How is spasticity measured?	Modified Ashworth Scale.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_tone
What is rigidity in terms of muscle tone?	Increased resistance to muscle stretch that is independent of velocity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_tone
What is a clinical indication of basal ganglia involvement?	Parkinsonism (tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_tone
What does a Grade 0 in muscle strength grading indicate?	No muscular contraction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_Grading
What does a Grade 1 in muscle strength grading indicate?	Trace contraction that is visible or palpable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_Grading
What does a Grade 2 in muscle strength grading indicate?	Full active range of motion with gravity eliminated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_Grading
What does a Grade 3 in muscle strength grading indicate?	Full active range of motion against gravity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_Grading
What does a Grade 4 in muscle strength grading indicate?	Full active range of motion against gravity with minimal to moderate resistance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_Grading
What does a Grade 5 in muscle strength grading indicate?	Full active range of motion against gravity with maximal resistance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_Grading
How are muscle stretch reflexes tested?	Tapping the tendon with a reflex hammer to elicit muscle contraction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
Which reflexes are included in the upper extremity reflex tests?	Biceps reflex (C5, C6); brachioradialis reflex (C5, C6); and triceps reflex (C6, C7).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
Which reflexes are included in the lower extremity reflex tests?	Patella or knee-jerk reflex (L2–L4); medial hamstrings L5–S1 tibial portion of the sciatic nerve; Achilles or ankle-jerk reflex (S1); and plantar reflex (L5, S1).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
What method can be used to optimize the response during reflex testing?	 Jendrassik maneuver (Distract the patient by asking him or her to interlock flexed fingers).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
What does a reflex grade of 0 indicate?	No response.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
What does a reflex grade of 1+ indicate?	Diminished response—hypoactive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
What does a reflex grade of 2+ indicate?	Normal response.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
What does a reflex grade of 3+ indicate?	Brisk response—hyperactive without clonus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
What does a reflex grade of 4+ indicate?	Hyperactive with clonus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Muscle_strength_Reflex
What should sensory testing include?	Superficial and deep sensation. Compare dermatome distributions on each side with the patient’s eyes closed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is light touch tested during sensory testing?	Using a cotton tip applicator.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is pain assessed during sensory testing?	Using a safety pin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is temperature assessed during sensory testing?	Using two different test tubes of hot and cold liquids.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is joint position or proprioception tested?	Joint position or proprioception is tested by moving the patient’s finger or toe holding the digit on the medial and lateral margins and testing the ability to distinguish between the upward and downward movements.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is vibration sense tested during sensory testing?	Using a 128-Hz or 256-Hz tuning fork over a bony prominence and asking the patient when the stimulus ends.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is point localization performed during sensory testing?	Lightly touching the patient and asking for identification of the area.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is two-point discrimination assessed?	Asking patient to distinguish between one point and two points of stimulus on the fingertips or palm.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is stereognosis tested?	Stereognosis is tested by placing a common object in the patient’s hand for identification.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
How is graphesthesia assessed during sensory testing?	Assessed by drawing a number or letter on the patient’s palm for identification.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Sensory_testing
What can coordination, stance, and gait assessment reveal?	Cerebellar involvement through clumsy movements, ataxia, and impaired balance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Coordination_stance_gait
What tests are used to assess coordination?	Finger-to-nose test and heel-to-shin test																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Coordination_stance_gait
How is rapid alternating movement tested?	Asking patient to perform quick, synchronous muscle movements that involve switching between opposing actions																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Coordination_stance_gait
What is the pronator drift test?	Asks the patient to keep arm held up with eyes closed; if there is a downward drift, it indicates a positive sign.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Coordination_stance_gait
What does the Romberg test assess?	Balance. Asking patient to stand with feet together and close the eyes; swaying indicates a positive sign and lack of position sense.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Coordination_stance_gait
What observations are made during a gait assessment?	Observe the individual walk down hallway, do a tandem walk, walk on the heels/toes, hop on each foot, and perform shallow knee bend during a gait assessment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam RehabReadyTags::Neurologic_Exam::Coordination_stance_gait
What are the two primary components of the normal gait cycle?	The normal gait cycle has two primary components: stance phase and swing phase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Cycle
What percentage of the gait cycle does the stance phase represent?	Stance phase makes up 60% of the typical gait pattern.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Cycle
What percentage of the gait cycle does the swing phase represent?	Swing phase makes up 40% of the typical gait pattern.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Cycle
How is a step defined in the context of gait?	A step is defined as the time measured from an event in one foot to the same event occurring in the contralateral foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Cycle
How is a stride defined in the context of gait?	A stride is defined as the time measured from an event in one foot to the same event occurring in the same foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Cycle
What is the effect of pelvic rotation in the horizontal plane on gait?	Pelvic Rotation in the Horizontal Plane – The pelvis rotates 4° to each side, which occurs maximally during double support, elevating the nadir of the COG pathway curve by about 3/8”.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Six_determinants_Gait
What role does pelvic tilt in the frontal plane play in gait?	Pelvic Tilt in the Frontal Plane – The pelvis drops 5° on the side of the swinging leg controlled by the hip abductors, shaving 3/16” from the apex of the COG pathway curve.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Six_determinants_Gait
How does knee flexion affect the center of gravity during gait?	Knee Flexion (KF) – Lowers the apex of the COG by 7/16” at mid-stance (10°–15°).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Six_determinants_Gait
What is the contribution of knee and ankle motion to gait?	Knee and Ankle Motion – Rotation over the calcaneus in early stance with rotation over the metatarsal heads in late stance combined with KF in late stance produces a smooth sinusoidal pathway for the COG.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Six_determinants_Gait
How does lateral pelvic displacement influence gait?	Lateral Pelvic Displacement – Normal anatomic valgus at the knee and varus at the hip decreases lateral sway, reducing total horizontal excursion from about 6” to &lt;2”.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Six_determinants_Gait
What is the function of ankle dorsiflexors during unimpaired gait?	Ankle Dorsiflexors – These muscles (primarily the tibialis anterior, but also the extensor digitorum longus and the extensor hallucis longus) eccentrically contract to smoothly lower the foot from heel strike to foot flat. They also concentrically contract during the swing phase to dorsiflex the ankle and effectively shorten the swinging limb in order to clear the ground.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Muscle_Activity_Unimpaired_Gait
How do the ankle plantar flexors function during unimpaired gait?	Ankle Plantar Flexors – The triceps surae act eccentrically during mid-stance to control ankle dorsiflexion caused by the body’s forward momentum. At push-off, they act concentrically to lift the heel and toes off the ground.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Muscle_Activity_Unimpaired_Gait
What role do the hip abductors play in unimpaired gait?	Hip Abductors – The gluteus medius and minimus contract eccentrically during stance phase to limit pelvic tilt of the swing phase leg. Maximum contraction occurs after heel strike.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Muscle_Activity_Unimpaired_Gait
How do the hip flexors contribute to unimpaired gait?	Hip Flexors – The hip flexors (primarily the iliopsoas) contract eccentrically after midstance phase to slow truncal extension caused by the ground reactive force (GRF) passing behind the hip. The tensor fasciae latae, pectineus, sartorius, and iliopsoas contract concentrically to flex the hip and shorten the limb for effective ground clearance during swing phase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Muscle_Activity_Unimpaired_Gait
What is the role of hip extensors during unimpaired gait?	Hip Extensors – The gluteus maximus and hamstrings start to eccentrically contract just before heel strike to maintain hip stability and slow down the forward momentum of the trunk, since the GRF is anterior to the hip at this stage. They become essentially inactive after foot flat, once the GRF passes posterior to the hip.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Muscle_Activity_Unimpaired_Gait
How do the hamstrings function during the swing phase of gait?	The hamstrings may weakly contract during the swing phase to flex the knee for ground clearance. The hamstrings have a double peak of activity prior to and after heel strike. The first peak occurs during swing phase when there is an open kinetic chain (foot not in contact with ground). This activation decelerates the forward swing of the leg by eccentrically contracting during hip extension and flexing at the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Muscle_Activity_Unimpaired_Gait
What is the role of knee extensors in gait?	Knee Extensors – The quadriceps act primarily to absorb shock as they eccentrically contract during heel strike to keep the knees stable. They are also active just before toe-off to help initiate the forward swing of the limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Muscle_Activity_Unimpaired_Gait
How do the gastrocnemius and soleus function during standing?	Standing – The gastrocnemius-soleus complex (primarily the soleus) is the only muscle normally active during quiet standing. Ligaments and bony articulations maintain the stability of the other joints. The COG is located ~2” anterior to S2.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Muscle_Activity_Unimpaired_Gait
What is Antalgic Gait and how is it treated?	Antalgic Gait – To reduce pain, there is avoidance of weight bearing (WB) on the affected limb. The examiner may note a decrease in the stance phase, a reduced step length on the unaffected side, and a prolonged period of double support.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
How is Gastrocnemius Gait characterized and treated?	Gastrocnemius Gait – Weak plantar flexors during terminal stance and toe-off prevent adequate heel lift. To limit the drop in the COG that occurs without heel lift during terminal stance, the step length of the contralateral leg is shortened. Treatment: A solid or semisolid ankle–foot orthosis (AFO) with a full-length footplate simulates plantar flexion during terminal stance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
What is Trendelenburg Gait and how can it be managed?	Gluteus Medius–Minimus (Trendelenburg) Gait – In an uncompensated Trendelenburg gait, there is contralateral pelvic drop secondary to the inability of the hip abductors to stabilize the pelvis during stance. In a compensated Trendelenburg gait, weak abductors are compensated by a lateral lurch over the affected side to reduce the stress on the weak muscles. Treatment: A cane used in the contralateral hand widens the base of support and decreases the hip abductor strength needed to keep the pelvis level.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
How does Gluteus Maximus (Extensor Lurch) Gait manifest and what is its treatment?	Gluteus Maximus (Extensor Lurch) Gait – This may be seen following injury to the inferior gluteal nerve or a subtrochanteric hip fracture. Weakened hip extensors are unable to decelerate the forward momentum of the body (hip flexion moment) at heel strike. To compensate, the subject adopts a prominent posterior lean and locks the hip joint in extension against the iliofemoral ligament, which keeps the body’s COG behind the hip. Treatment: Two crutches or canes are used for a three-point gait.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
What characterizes Quadriceps (Back Knee) Gait and its management?	Quadriceps (Back Knee) Gait – With weakness or inhibition of the quadriceps (e.g., distal femoral fracture), measures will be adopted to prevent buckling of the knee. One compensation is the use of the hand(s) to force the knee into extension. Another compensatory technique is external rotation of the leg at initial contact and early stance to bring the medial collateral ligament anteriorly to prevent knee buckling. Treatment: A knee brace may be used to provide knee stability at heel strike. Also, the use of a rolling walker promotes trunk flexion to bring COG in front of the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
What is Tibialis Anterior Gait and how is it treated?	Tibialis Anterior Gait – Pretibial muscle weakness that is at least anti-gravity (≥3/5 grade) may cause foot slap after heel strike. If the muscles are &lt;3/5 grade, foot slap is generally not heard because a steppage gait is more likely. The hip and knee are hyperflexed in a steppage gait to clear the foot during swing phase, which may otherwise drag. Treatment: A standard posterior leaf spring orthosis (PLSO), which allows plantar flexion and assists in dorsiflexion. An AFO is often used both to prevent foot slap and to allow clearance of the foot during swing phase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
What characterizes Hemiplegic Gait and how is it treated?	Hemiplegic Gait – Persons with extensor synergies will typically ambulate independently. The typical extensor synergy pattern has a predilection for knee extension, ankle plantar flexion, and inversion. Therefore, extensor tone effectively makes the plegic limb longer than the nonplegic side. A circumduction gait compensates via exaggerated hip abduction to allow for toe clearance and ends with toe strike. Despite the circumduction, there is a decreased step length and swing phase on the plegic side. Gait speed will be reduced in order to maintain an acceptable rate of energy expenditure. Treatment: A solid AFO or a hinged AFO with a posterior stop to decrease effective limb length may be helpful. A small degree of plantar flexion, however, should be maintained to promote knee stability when there is quadriceps weakness. With genu recurvatum, providing additional plantar flexion at the ankle via the addition of a heel lift, and/or cutting the footplate just proximal to the metatarsal heads, moves the COG posteriorly at the knee level, reducing the knee extension moment compared to the untreated state.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
What defines Parkinsonian Gait and its interventions?	Parkinsonian Gait – The classic triad of Parkinson’s disease is tremor, bradykinesia, and instability, with at least the last two affecting gait. While standing, the knees, trunk, and neck are typically flexed and the body appears stiff. When there is ambulation, there is a characteristic shuffling gait with short quickening steps, as if the patient were racing after the COG (festination). Turns are made “en bloc.” Decreased arm swing further compromises balance. Treatment: Heel lifts and assistive devices may help reduce the tendency to fall backward. Walkers with added weight may provide additional stability. Physical therapy to address postural issues can be helpful.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
How is Spastic Paraplegia or Diplegia/Crouched Gait characterized and managed?	Spastic Paraplegia or Diplegia/Crouched Gait – Often seen in persons with cerebral palsy. While standing, the hip and knees are flexed and internally rotated and the foot is held in equinovarus. With ambulation, the increased adductor tone at the thighs causes the knees to scissor in front of each other with each step. Hip adduction causes short step lengths, making the feet seem like they are sticking to the floor. Balance may be impaired as a result of a narrowing base of support. To compensate for this, there is a tendency to lean forward and toward the supporting side. The upper extremities tend to be semiflexed with elbows held out to the sides. Diagnostic nerve blocks may help establish whether or not a contracture is present. Treatment: AFOs can be used to address equinovarus. Botulinum toxin injection therapy may be helpful for addressing adductor scissoring and equinovarus. Use of an assistive device (e.g., a walker) may provide additional stability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Deviations_Prescriptions
What should the cane length be adjusted to?	Cane length should be from the bottom of the shoe’s heel to the upper border of the greater trochanter with the user standing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
What should be the arm flexion angle when holding a cane?	The shoulders should be level and the arm holding the cane should be flexed ~20° to 30° at the elbow, to provide proper push-off.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
How much body weight can a cane unload off the affected lower limb?	A cane can unload up to 20% of body weight off the affected lower limb, depending on cane design and the user’s level of training.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
Where should a cane be held in relation to neuromuscular weakness or joint pathology?	In general, a cane should be held in the hand opposite to the lower limb with neuromuscular weakness or joint pathology. It is advanced together with the affected limb in a three-point gait pattern.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
What is the general rule for ascending and descending stairs with a cane?	Stairs are usually ascended with the stronger lower limb first, then the cane and affected limb. The affected lower limb and cane proceed down first during stair descent.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
How do forearm crutches differ from axillary crutches?	Forearm Crutches (Lofstrand, Canadian) provide less trunk support than axillary crutches but may be indicated if pressure in the axilla is contraindicated. A single forearm crutch can relieve up to 40% to 50% of body weight off a lower limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
How should axillary crutches be fitted?	Axillary Crutch – Length is 1” to 2” plus the distance from the anterior axillary fold to a point on the ground 6” lateral to the bottom of the heel while standing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
What are the advantages of using forearm crutches over axillary crutches?	Forearm Crutches are less supportive of the trunk but useful when axillary pressure is to be avoided. They require good trunk control as they primarily assist in balance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
What is the primary function of a basic walker?	Walkers provide a wider base of support and a generally safer gait than canes or crutches. They allow up to 100% WB relief from an affected lower limb, depending on how they are used.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
When are rolling walkers indicated?	Rolling walkers are indicated for persons who lack the coordination or strength in the upper limbs to lift and advance a standard walker.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
What specific needs do platform walkers address?	Platform walkers are used in a variety of situations including distal upper extremity joint deformities, grip weakness, and flexion contractures of the elbow. They allow WB at the elbow, bypassing the hand, wrist, and part of the forearm.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids RehabReadyTags::Gait_GaitAids::Gait_Aids
What is included in a comprehensive wheelchair and seating evaluation?	Assessment of the medical history, cognition/communication, special sensory skills (vision and hearing), motor and sensory function, skin integrity, current seating/mobility device(s), wheelchair skills, home environment/barriers, method(s) of available transportation, and level of community function (e.g., employment or school).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What does a mat evaluation for a wheel chair entail?	Supine and sitting evaluations																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What does a mat evaluation help determine in a wheelchair assessment?	Postural deformities (e.g., joint contractures, pelvic obliquities, spinal kyphosis, or scoliosis), trunk/postural control, and pertinent range of motion findings																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are typical measurements included in a wheelchair evaluation?	Important patient measurements include hip/trunk/shoulder width, knee-to-seat depth, knee-to-heel length, shoulder height, and axilla height.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What is the benefit of a wheel chair with a folding chair? 	They are easier to transport																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are some drawbacks of a wheel chair with a folding frame? 	They are heavier, less durable, and require more energy to propel																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
Why are rigid frame wheel chairs not particularly useful for ambulatory persons?	Because they do not typically come with swing-away footrests, making it difficult to perform sit-to-stand transfers																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
How does decreasing the weight of a manual wheel chair affect the rolling resistance?	It decreases the rolling resistance																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
Which axle position is advantageous for users with poor trunk control, amputees, and reclining/posterior tilt wheelchairs?	Posterior placement																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are some drawbacks to a wheelchair axle placed in the posterior position?	It increases the turning radius, rolling resistance, and the difficulty in doing wheelies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits of a wheelchair axle placed in the anterior position?	Decreases rolling resistance and improves maneuvarability (decreased turning radius and easier wheelies)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What is a drawback of a wheelchair axle placed in the anterior position?	It increases the risk of tipping over backward																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the differences between molded plastic (Mag) and wire-spoked wheelchair wheels?	Mag wheels are slightly heavier but more durable than spoked wheels. Spoked wheels are preferred in most sports chairs, but require more maintenance and are less safe for some individuals whose fingers may get caught in the spokes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What is the benefit of pneumatic (air-filled inner tube) tires?	Offers comfortable ride on uneven terrain																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the drawbacks to pneumatic (air-filled inner tube) tires?	They are more susceptible to going flat and have a higher resistance to propulsion																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits of rubber tires?	They are easier to propel and require less maintenance, especially if the wheelchair is mostly used indoors																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
"How does increasing camber affect a wheelchair&#x27;s performance?"	Increasing camber decreases turning radius, improves side-to-side and forward stability, decreases rolling resistance at high speeds, and protects user hands during sports																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are some disadvantages to increasing camber on a wheelchair?	Difficulty in tight spaces due to increased overall wheelchair width, increased tire/wheel-bearing wear, and decreased rear stability																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits and drawbacks of small-diameter handrims (sports wheelchairs)? 	It increases the distance with each stroke, but require greater force																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits and drawbacks of pegged handrims (&quot;quad knobs&quot;) on wheelchairs?	They improve ease of use for tetraplegics and users with hand deformities, but increase risk of trauma during attempts to stop and may reduce accessibility																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits of small (&lt;=5&quot; diameter) narrow casters?	They are good for smooth, level surfaces and are less likely to shimmy. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the disadvantages of small (&lt;=5&quot; diameter) narrow casters?	They are more likely to get caught in sidewalk cracks and elevator thresholds																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits of large (&gt;=6&quot; diameter) wide casters?	They are better in roughter, outdoor terrain																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the disadvantages of large (&gt;=6&quot; diameter) wide casters?	They have increased rolling resistance on smooth surfaces and are more likely to shimmy																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the different types of cushions for wheelchairs?	Foam cushions, Gel/Foam combo cushions, and Air-filled villous cushions																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits to foam cushions for wheelchairs?	They are lightweight and inexpensive																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the disadvantages to foam cushions for wheelchairs?	They are not washable and dissipate heat poorly; do not offer adequate pressure relief																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
Who are foam cushions appropriate for?	Ambulatory persons or users who are able to perform pressure relief independently with intact sensation																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits to gel/foam combo cushions for wheelchairs?	They provide good postural stability, are durable and easy to maintain and clean, and dissipate heat well																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the disadvantages to gel/foam combo cushions for wheelchairs?	They are expensive and heavy, and the contouring can interfere with transfers																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
Which type of wheelchair cushion provides the best pressure relief?	Air-filled villous cushions																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits of air-filled villous cushions for wheelchairs?	They are lightweight, good at heat dissipation, and easy to clean and transport																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the disadvantages of air-filled villous cushions for wheelchairs?	They are expensive and poor at providing postural stability																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
For which persons are Recline/Tilt-in-Space wheelchairs necessary for?	Persons who lack ability to otherwise achieve adequate pressure relief and for person with orthostatic instability																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
Reclined positioning in a Recline/Tilt-in-Space wheelchair may be beneficial for which people?	Reclined positioning may also be beneficial for spasticity/spasm management and perform- ing activities such as bladder catheterization or lower body dressing without having to transfer out of the wheelchair																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What is a &quot;Hemichair&quot; and who might benefit from it?	A &quot;Hemichair&quot; is a wheelchair option for some users with hemiplegia - the seat height is lowered ≈2” and a footrest is removed to allow the user to employ the neurologically intact foot for propul- sion and steering.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
How is a wheelchair adapted for lower limb amputees?	The rear axle is moved posteriorly about 2 inches to compensate for the rearward displacement of the patient’s center of gravity; the turning radius is increased; a leg rest can be replaced by a residual limb support on the involved side.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What is a power-assisted wheelchair?	This is a manual wheelchair that operates by combining the force of the user and electrical power from a motor on the wheel of the chair.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
Who might require a power-assisted wheelchar?	It is indicated for users who are able to propel a manual wheelchair, but have poor endurance, shoulder issues, or difficulty propelling on uneven surfaces.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the benefits of a standing wheelchair?	The standing position provides pressure relief and weight bearing, may improve bowel/bladder function, and increases some accessibility (e.g., reaching cabinets). Standing wheelchairs may also provide a psychological benefit for users.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Manual_Wheelchairs
What are the indications for using scooters as power mobility devices?	They are for  persons who can ambulate and transfer but have poor endurance or poor tolerance for prolonged manual wheelchair use.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Power_Mobility_Devices
What are the user requirements for operating a scooter?	Users must have good sitting balance, intact cognitive and visuo-perceptual skills, good hand-eye coordination, and adequate function of at least one upper limb to operate the controls.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Power_Mobility_Devices
What caution should be taken with scooters?	Some models of scooters tip over fairly easily, especially at high speeds. They are not generally recommended for persons with progressive diseases such as multiple sclerosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Power_Mobility_Devices
What are the indications for using power wheelchairs?	Power wheelchairs are for users with physical limitations incompatible with manual wheelchair propulsion (e.g., users with C1-to-C4-level SCI and many with C5-to-C6-level SCI) and for those with strength or endurance deficits (e.g., severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD] and cardiac failure) who may not otherwise be candidates for a power scooter.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Power_Mobility_Devices
What are the user requirements for operating a power wheelchair?	Users must have at least one reliably reproducible movement to access the control system, adequate cognitive and visuo-perceptual function, proper judgment, and motivation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs RehabReadyTags::Wheelchairs::Power_Mobility_Devices
What are the key components of a modality prescription?	Diagnosis, impairments/disabilities, precautions, modality and settings (e.g., intensity and temperature range), area to be treated, frequency of treatment, duration of treatment, goals/objectives of treatment, and reevaluation date.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Essential_Points
What is the primary effect of heat therapy?	Causes vasodilation which increases blood flow to the treated area.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the physiological benefits of applying heat therapy?	Increased tissue metabolism, reduced muscle tension, and relief from pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
How does heat therapy affect connective tissue?	Increases the elasticity of connective tissues, reducing stiffness and improving mobility.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What precautions should be taken when applying heat therapy?	Monitoring to avoid burns, especially in patients with impaired sensation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What is the primary use of cryotherapy in treatment?	Reduce swelling, inflammation, and pain in the treated areas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
How does cryotherapy achieve its effects?	Vasoconstriction - reduces blood flow to the area, decreasing inflammation and edema.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the immediate effects of applying cryotherapy?	Numbing effect in the treated area, reduced nerve transmission speeds, and decreased tissue metabolism.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the indications for using cryotherapy over heat therapy?	Acute injuries, where reducing inflammation and swelling is a priority.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What precautions should be considered with cryotherapy?	"Avoiding frostbite and being cautious with patients who have conditions like Raynaud&#x27;s phenomenon or cold hypersensitivity."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What is the primary purpose of traction in therapy?	Alleviate compression on spinal nerves and reduce pain, especially in conditions like herniated discs or osteoarthritis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
How does traction assist in physical therapy?	Decompressing spinal segments, which can relieve pain and facilitate movement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the indications for the use of traction?	Conditions involving spinal nerve root impingement, such as herniated discs or spinal stenosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What precautions should be taken when using traction?	"Avoiding excessive force which could lead to injury and ensuring the patient&#x27;s comfort and safety during the procedure."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What is TENS and what does it primarily target?	Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) primarily targets nerve pathways to modulate pain signals sent to the brain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
How does TENS relieve pain?	TENS relieves pain through the gate control theory of pain, where electrical stimulation of nerves may block the transmission of pain signals to the brain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the typical settings used in TENS therapy?	Typical settings include adjustments for intensity, frequency, and pulse width to suit patient comfort and treatment objectives.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the indications for using TENS?	Chronic pain conditions like low back pain, arthritis, and after surgeries for pain management.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What precautions should be considered when using TENS?	Precautions include avoiding placement of electrodes near the heart, eyes, and on irritated or broken skin, and not using in patients with pacemakers or other electronic implants.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the classic Western massage techniques?	Effleurage (stroking), petrissage (kneading), tapotement (percussion), and Swedish massage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What is the purpose of deep friction massage?	To break up adhesions seen in chronic muscle injuries.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What does myofascial release aim to do?	Release soft tissue entrapped in tight fascia through prolonged application of light pressure in specific directions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the Eastern techniques of massage mentioned?	Acupressure and Shiatsu massage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the absolute contraindications to massage?	Malignancy, DVT, atherosclerotic plaques, and infected tissues.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the relative contraindications to massage?	Incompletely healed scar tissue, anticoagulation, calcified soft tissues, and skin grafts.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What is phonophoresis?	A technique where topical medications like steroids and anesthetics are mixed with an acoustic coupling medium and driven into tissue by ultrasound.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are the common uses of phonophoresis?	Osteoarthritis, bursitis, capsulitis, tendonitis, strains, contractures, scar tissue, and neuromas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What is iontophoresis?	A technique that uses electrical currents to drive medications across biological membranes directly into symptomatic areas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What is the theoretical benefit of iontophoresis?	To deliver medications directly to the affected area, potentially avoiding side effects associated with systemic medications.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Modalities RehabReadyTags::Modalities::Selected_Modalities
What are Type I muscle fibers known as?	"""Slow-twitch,"" highly fatigue-resistant, appear dark due to their rich vascular supply."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
What staining characteristics do Type I muscle fibers have?	They appear light on myosin ATPase (at pH 9.4) or periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) staining.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
What are Type II fibers described as?	&quot;white meat&quot; but are dark histologically with myosin ATPase or PAS staining.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
Do all fibers in a motor unit have the same type?	Yes, all fibers in a given motor unit are of the same type.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
According to the Henneman size principle, how are motor units recruited?	Smaller motor units are recruited first, and progressively larger units are then sequentially recruited.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
EMG predominantly records what type of fiber activity?	EMG predominantly records Type I fiber activity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
What type of fiber does Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES) recruit?	FES preferentially recruits Type II fibers but may turn Type IIs into Type Is after long-term use.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
Which muscle fiber atrophies with steroid use?	Steroids predominately cause Type IIb fiber atrophy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
How do muscle fiber types change with aging?	Both Type I and Type II fibers decrease with aging.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Muscle_Fiber_Characteristics
What type of strength training generates tension without visible joint motion/change in muscle length?	Isometric strengthening.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What is the most efficient condition for isometric exercise?	Most efficient when the exertion occurs at the resting length of the muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
In what situations might isometric exercise be particularly useful?	Useful when joint motion is contraindicated, or in the setting of pain or inflammation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
Why should isometric exercise be avoided in the elderly and those with hypertension?	It should be avoided due to its tendency to elevate blood pressure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What characterizes isotonic strengthening?	Constant external resistance but variable speed of movement. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
Give examples of isotonic strengthening exercises.	Free weights, weight machines, calisthenics, and TheraBand exercises.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What defines isokinetic strengthening?	Relatively constant angular joint speed but variable external resistance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
