What equipment is necessary for isokinetic strengthening?	Special equipment such as Cybex and Biodex. If the user pushes harder, the speed of the manipulated<br>piece of equipment will not increase, but the resistance supplied by the machine will. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What advantage does isokinetic exercise offer in rehabilitation?	Maximizes resistance throughout the length–tension curve of the exercised muscles and is beneficial in the early phases of rehabilitation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What characterizes concentric contractions?	Concentric contractions are characterized by active muscle shortening.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
How are eccentric contractions characterized?	Eccentric contractions are characterized by active muscle lengthening.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
Which type of muscle contractions generate the most force?	Fast eccentric contractions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What is a plyometric movement?	Brief, explosive maneuver consisting of an eccentric contraction followed by a concentric contraction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What is the aim of plyometric training?	Increase power.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What does the DeLorme axiom propose about strength and endurance training?	High-resistance, low-repetition exercises build strength, while low-resistance, high-repetition exercises improve endurance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
How is a progressive resistive exercise session structured according to the DeLorme method?	Ten reps of an exercise are performed in sets of 50%, 75%, and 100% of the 10 repetition maximum.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
How are the sets ordered in the Oxford technique?	In the Oxford technique, 10 reps at 100% of the 10 repetition maximum are performed first, followed by sets of 75% and 50%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What did DeLateur BJ demonstrate about strength and endurance gains?	Strength and endurance gains are equivalent for both types of exercise as long as muscles are exercised to fatigue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
Which method achieves strength results more efficiently?	High-resistance, low-rep exercise achieves strength results more efficiently (i.e., fewer reps, less time).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What did Moritani and de Vries find about early gains in strength training?	Early gains in strength training were mostly due to neural factors such as improved coordination of muscle firing, not muscle hypertrophy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What does the first set of the DAPRE method involve?	10 reps at 50% of 6 repetition maximum.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What is the second set in the DAPRE method?	The second set is 6 reps at 75% of 6 repetition maximum.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What does the third set of the DAPRE method entail?	The third set is as many reps as possible at 6 repetition maximum.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
How is the weight for the fourth set of DAPRE determined?	The weight for the fourth set depends on the number of reps completed during the third set: the weight remains the same if 5-7 reps were performed, is decreased for fewer reps, and increased for more reps.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
How are adjustments made to the working weight in DAPRE?	Adjustments to the working weight for the next training session are made based on the performance of the third set.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Strength_Training
What does regular aerobic exercise increase and decrease?	Increases max oxygen consumption (VO2max) and decreases resting blood pressure (BP).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
How does strength training affect VO2max or resting BP?	Strength training does not have an effect on VO2max or resting BP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
What cardiovascular adaptations/benefits does aerobic exercise provide?	Aerobic exercise increases stroke volume, cardiac output during maximum exertion, work capacity, and HDL levels; decreases resting heart rate, heart rate response to submaximal workloads, myocardial O2 consumption at rest and during submaximal activities, LDL, and triglyceride levels.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
Does maximum heart rate change with aerobic exercise?	Maximum heart rate does not change with aerobic exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
What recent findings have been reported about aerobic exercise and muscle mass?	Recent reports suggest that aerobic exercise can mitigate muscle mass loss and even have hypertrophic/anabolic effects.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
What benefits do diabetic patients gain from aerobic exercise?	Reduced obesity and insulin requirements from aerobic exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
What additional improvements might be observed from regular aerobic exercise?	Improvements in mood, sleep, immune function, and bone density																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
What signifies the anaerobic threshold during exercise?	The anaerobic threshold signifies the onset of metabolic acidosis during exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
How can the anaerobic threshold be determined noninvasively?	Assessment of expired gases during exercise testing, specifically pulmonary ventilation (VE) and carbon dioxide production (Vco2).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
What does the anaerobic threshold signify in terms of physical exertion?	Peak work rate or O2 consumption at which energy demands exceed the circulatory ability to sustain aerobic metabolism.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Aerobic_Exercise
What is the recommended duration and frequency for moderate intensity exercise?	At least 30 minutes per day on at least 5 days per week, totaling at least 150 minutes per week.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::ACSM_Guidelines
What is the recommended duration and frequency for vigorous intensity exercise?	At least 20 minutes per day on at least 3 days per week, totaling at least 75 minutes per week.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::ACSM_Guidelines
What type of additional exercises are recommended, and how often?	Resistance exercises are recommended 2 to 3 days per week and range of motion exercises at least 2 days per week.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::ACSM_Guidelines
What should a preexercise evaluation by a physician include?	History of exercise patterns, motivations/barriers to exercise, risks/benefits of exercise, preferred activities, social support, scheduling, physical limitations, medical history, medications, symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain, and risk factors like DM, HTN, smoking, hyperlipidemia, obesity, and family history of heart disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
What special attention should be given during a preexercise evaluation?	Physical limitations, current and past medical problems, medications, exercise-induced symptoms, and a thorough review of heart disease risk factors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
What do the 2015 ACSM recommendations emphasize?	The 2015 ACSM recommendations seek to reduce unnecessary barriers to adopting and maintaining a structured exercise program or regular physical activity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
What are the components of an exercise prescription?	Mode, intensity, duration, frequency, and progression (overload).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
"How is &#x27;mode&#x27; defined in exercise prescriptions?"	Particular form or type of exercise, chosen based on desired outcomes and preferences for long-term enjoyment and sustainability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
"How is &#x27;intensity&#x27; calculated in exercise prescriptions?"	Calculated based on heart rate and rate of perceived exertion, often using the Borg Scale of Perceived Exertion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
What does a Borg score of 9, 13, and 17 represent?	A score of 9 is &quot;very light&quot; like walking slowly, 13 is &quot;somewhat hard&quot; like moderate intensity exercise, and 17 is &quot;very hard&quot; like pushing oneself near limits.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
What is the goal Borg score for a moderate intensity exercise program?	A goal Borg score for moderate intensity is typically 12 to 14.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
"What does &#x27;duration&#x27; refer to in an exercise prescription?"	Length of an exercise session, which can be continuous or intermittently accumulated during a day.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
"What does &#x27;frequency&#x27; refer to in an exercise prescription?"	Number of exercise sessions per day and per week.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
"What is &#x27;progression&#x27; or &#x27;overload&#x27; in an exercise prescription?"	Increase in activity level during exercise training that stimulates adaptation over time, which may involve changes in frequency, intensity, and/or duration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise RehabReadyTags::Therapeutic_Exercise::Exercise_Prescription
What ancient text is considered to be the foundational doctrinal text of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) describing acupuncture?	"Huangdi Neijing (""The Yellow Emperor’s Classic of Internal Medicine"")."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What does TCM theory suggest about the cause of disease and pain?	Disease and pain are thought to occur when the flow of qi through meridians is disturbed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What does a meridian refer to?	A meridian corresponds to an organ that extends peripherally 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
How does acupuncture propose to restore health according to TCM?	By using needles to stimulate points along the meridians, restoring proper qi flow.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What historical event in 1929 impacted the practice of acupuncture in China?	The Kuomintang officially outlawed the practice of acupuncture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
How did the Communist government influence acupuncture in China in 1949?	They promoted its resurgence to provide low-cost basic health care to the population.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
"What was the impact of James Reston&#x27;s 1971 New York Times column on acupuncture in the West?"	he experienced success with accupuncture postoperatively which led to a surge of interest in acupuncture in the United States and Western countries.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What were the findings of the 1997 NIH consensus conference regarding acupuncture?	Acupuncture was found effective for postoperative and chemotherapy-related nausea and vomiting, and dental pain, among other conditions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
List some conditions that the WHO identified in 2003 as effectively treatable by acupuncture.	Headache, dental pain, temporomandibular joint dysfunction, neck pain, low back pain, and rheumatoid arthritis, among others.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What are the implications of Western influence on acupuncture during the Qing dynasty?	Western influence led to the decline of acupuncture as it was removed from the medical academy syllabus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
Is there scientific evidence supporting the existence of qi or meridians?	There is an absence of evidence to support the existence of qi or the meridians.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What physiological effects are observed when acupuncture points are stimulated?	Physiological effects include the release of neurotransmitters, endorphins, enkephalins, nerve growth factor, and endogenous cannabinoids.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
How might mechanical movements or electrical stimulation of acupuncture needles influence treatment effects?	Mechanical movements or electrical stimulation of the acupuncture needle may potentiate these effects.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
From what might acupuncture derive some benefit regarding pain relief?	Acupuncture likely derives some benefit from the proximity of acupuncture points to local nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
How does acupuncture potentially reduce pain according to the gate control theory?	Pain messaging may be reduced via acupuncture-induced action potentials traveling in sensory afferents to depress dorsal horn activity, compatible with the gate control theory of Melzack and Wall.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What correlation did Melzack and Wall report regarding acupuncture points?	Melzack and Wall reported a high correlation between acupuncture points and myofascial trigger points, which they felt could be explained by the same underlying neural mechanisms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What have functional MRI studies shown about brain activity during acupuncture?	Functional MRI studies have revealed that parts of the brain are activated and deactivated during needling.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What is a major methodological challenge in modern clinical acupuncture research?	A major challenge is identifying an ideal placebo control, given that &quot;sham&quot; acupuncture can elicit responses not significantly different from treatment at accepted acupuncture points.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What recent innovation has been used as a placebo in acupuncture research?	More recently, non-penetrating acupuncture needles that retract back into the handle of the acupuncture needle after an initial skin prick have been utilized as placebos.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What issue is associated with the placebo devices used in acupuncture studies?	These devices are not standardized, and each has been found to have its own limitations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Brief_History
What materials are most modern acupuncture needles made of?	Most modern acupuncture needles are made of stainless steel.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
What is the typical gauge range of acupuncture needles?	"Acupuncture needles are typically available in #30 to #40 gauge."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
How are the gauges of acupuncture needles often described?	The gauges are often described to be approximately the thickness of a single human hair.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
What are some needling techniques that offer stronger stimulation?	Techniques include needle rotation, vibration, pecking, and electroacupuncture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
What are the most commonly reported adverse reactions to acupuncture?	"The most common adverse reactions are bleeding and needling pain. Other reactions include bruising and drowsiness.		"																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
How can the risk of presyncope and syncope during acupuncture be mitigated?	The risk can be mitigated by flat positioning, close monitoring during an initial visit, and post-procedural observation until full recovery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
What is the most frequently reported serious complication of acupuncture?	The most serious complication frequently reported is pneumothorax.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
What organization has established guidelines for physicians to practice medical acupuncture in the U.S.?	The American Board of Medical Acupuncture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
How is licensing for the practice of acupuncture determined in the U.S.?	Licensing guidelines are determined by each specific state.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Needle_Technique
What benefit does acupuncture offer for migraine headache prophylaxis?	Studies have suggested a benefit of acupuncture in migraine headache prophylaxis over no acupuncture, with an effect similar to some prophylactic drugs but with fewer adverse effects.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
"What have multiple studies demonstrated about acupuncture&#x27;s effect on migraine headaches?"	Multiple studies have shown a therapeutic effect of acupuncture over sham acupuncture in the treatment of migraine headaches.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What alternative acupuncture technique may be considered for managing migraine headaches?	Auricular acupuncture may be a consideration in the management of migraine headaches.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
"Is there sufficient data supporting acupuncture&#x27;s effectiveness for tension headaches?"	There is less available data regarding the effectiveness of acupuncture for tension headaches and other types of headaches.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
How is acupuncture reported to be useful for neck pain?	Acupuncture has been reported to be useful for the treatment of neck pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What is the state of the data quality on acupuncture for neck pain?	High-quality data informing the literature on acupuncture for neck pain are limited.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What did a review by Fu, Li, and Wu conclude about acupuncture for neck pain?	The review noted that pooled data supported a quantitatively significant benefit of acupuncture over sham acupuncture for short-term pain relief, but qualitative review of the trial data limited the support of this conclusion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What recent trends are noted in the data quality for acupuncture treating neck pain?	More recent high-quality data are lacking.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What improvements have been observed with acupuncture in carpal tunnel syndrome?	Acupuncture has been shown to be associated with improved sensory and motor nerve conduction study parameters and decreased hyperactivity in the contralateral sensorimotor cortex on functional MRI in patients with CTS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
How effective is acupuncture in alleviating symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome?	Acupuncture has been reported to alleviate CTS symptoms, with effects similar to steroid injection therapy and night splinting.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What did the 2017 systematic review by Dimitrova, Murchison, and Oken conclude about acupuncture?	The majority of trials meeting review criteria showed a benefit of acupuncture over control in CTS, diabetic neuropathy, and Bell’s palsy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
How is acupuncture used in the context of low back pain?	Acupuncture is widely used by patients with LBP and reported improvements include decreased pain, sleep disturbance, psychological distress, disability, and use of analgesics.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What does a systematic review by Liu et al. conclude about acupuncture for acute low back pain?	The review concluded that there is inconsistent evidence that acupuncture relieves pain better than sham acupuncture for acute LBP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
"What does the same review say about acupuncture&#x27;s effectiveness on chronic low back pain?"	For chronic LBP, the review noted that acupuncture improves pain on short-term follow-up versus sham acupuncture, but does not marginally improve function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What overall benefit does acupuncture provide for chronic low back pain according to the review?	There is consistent evidence of a short-term, clinically relevant benefit of acupuncture for pain and function in comparison to no treatment or when added to other treatment for chronic LBP.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What role has acupuncture been reported to serve in treating osteoarthritis (OA)?	Acupuncture has been reported to be an adjunctive therapy option for OA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What were the findings of the review by Manyanga et al. regarding acupuncture for OA?	The review concluded that acupuncture provides significant improvements in pain intensity, functional mobility, and health-related quality of life for OA patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
According to subgroup analyses, when is acupuncture most effective for reducing OA pain?	Acupuncture is most effective for reducing OA pain when administered for more than 4 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What alternative does acupuncture provide for OA patients according to reviewers?	The reviewers concluded that acupuncture is an alternative for traditional analgesics in patients with OA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What were the findings of the 2014 RCT by Hinman et al. regarding acupuncture for chronic knee pain?	The RCT reported that neither laser nor needle acupuncture improved pain or function in patients older than 50 years with moderate or severe chronic knee pain versus sham acupuncture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What benefits were noted in the Hinman et al. study compared to the no-acupuncture group?	Benefits versus the no-acupuncture group were noted in the study.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What criticisms have been published regarding the Hinman et al. RCT?	Some criticisms of the methodology of the Hinman et al. RCT have been published in the literature.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
How has acupuncture been reported to affect rheumatoid arthritis (RA) symptoms?	Acupuncture has been reported to improve RA symptoms such as pain, joint mobility/morning stiffness, fatigue, depression, and insomnia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What does the review by Macfarlane et al. say about the quality of evidence for acupuncture in RA?	The review noted a lack of high-quality evidence to support the efficacy of acupuncture in RA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
In what situations might acupuncture be useful for postoperative pain?	Acupuncture may be useful in predictable situations involving acute pain, such as dental procedures and postoperative pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What effect does electroacupuncture have before lower abdominal surgery?	Electroacupuncture before lower abdominal surgery has been reported to reduce postoperative analgesic requirements and decrease the side effects of systemic opioids.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
How is acupuncture used in the management of cancer-related pain?	Acupuncture is increasingly being employed as a complementary intervention in the management of cancer-related pain due to the adverse effects of pharmaceutical analgesics.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
"What did the review by Hu et al. conclude about acupuncture&#x27;s effectiveness for cancer-related pain?"	The review concluded that acupuncture alone does not have superior analgesic effects compared to conventional drug therapy for cancer-related pain, but when combined with drug therapy, it results in better outcomes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
How has acupuncture been used to treat stroke patients?	Acupuncture has been used to treat stroke patients for many years in Asian countries, theorized to encourage muscle relaxation and improve muscle movement and function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What did the 2015 meta-analysis by Lim et al. find about acupuncture for poststroke spasticity?	The meta-analysis noted that acupuncture could be effective in treating poststroke spasticity, but many studies had low methodological quality.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
"What did the 2016 Cochrane review note about acupuncture&#x27;s benefits for stroke patients?"	The Cochrane review noted benefits of acupuncture versus no acupuncture for cognition, depression, pain, swallowing function, and specific neurological impairments but no benefit versus sham acupuncture in motor function and quality of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
What is the overall interpretation of the available data on acupuncture for stroke treatment?	The available data were interpreted to be of insufficient quality to allow conclusions regarding the routine use of acupuncture for stroke treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture RehabReadyTags::Acupuncture::Clinical_Applications
How many people undergo amputation of a limb each year in the United States?	An estimated 185,000 people undergo amputation of an upper or lower limb each year in the United States.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
How many people were living with the loss of a limb in the United States in 2005?	It was estimated that 1.6 million people were living with the loss of a limb in 2005.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What is the projected number of people living with limb loss in the United States by 2050?	The number of people living with limb loss is expected to increase to 3.6 million by 2050.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What percentage of amputations are due to dysvascular disease?	Dysvascular disease accounts for 54% of amputation cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What percentage of dysvascular disease-related amputations are in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM)?	Two thirds of amputations due to dysvascular disease have a diagnosis of DM.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What percentage of amputation cases are due to trauma?	Trauma accounts for 45% of amputation cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What percentage of amputation cases are due to cancer?	Cancer accounts for less than 2% of amputation cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What does major amputation refer to?	Major amputation refers to an amputation above the ankle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What factors determine the level of major amputation?	The level of major amputation is determined by the extent of disease, the potential for healing, and the rehabilitation potential of the patient.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What is the goal of determining the level for major amputation?	The goal is to preserve limb length while ensuring complete removal of all affected tissues.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What tests and findings are used to evaluate for ischemia in amputation cases?	Physical exam findings and objective tests such as ankle-brachial index (ABI), arterial Doppler, angiography, skin perfusion pressure, and presence of pressure ulcers are used to evaluate for ischemia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What is associated with a ~100% healing rate in amputation cases?	Palpation of a pulse proximal to the level of amputation is associated with a ~100% healing rate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What does primary amputation refer to?	Primary amputation refers to an amputation without the attempt at limb salvage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
What does secondary amputation refer to?	Secondary amputation refers to amputation following an attempt at limb salvage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Epidemiology_Etiology_Levels
According to the Lower Extremity Assessment Project (LEAP), what is difficult to predict in cases of lower extremity trauma?	According to LEAP, there is no good measure to predict limb salvage versus amputation in the setting of limb-threatening lower extremity trauma.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is the preferred shape and retention feature for a transhumeral (TH) residual limb?	Preferred shape is cylindrical with retention of the deltoid tuberosity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is the ideal residual limb length for a transhumeral (TH) amputation?	Generally, the longer the better, up to 90% of normal length.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is the ideal shape for a transradial (TR) residual limb?	The ideal shape follows the contours of the natural limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What are the benefits of longer transradial (TR) appendages?	Longer appendages provide better lever arms, more pronation/supination, and are optimal for body-powered prostheses and heavy labor.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
How does retention of the brachioradialis affect a transradial (TR) residual limb?	Retention of the brachioradialis improves elbow flexion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is optimal for externally powered prostheses in transradial (TR) amputations?	Medium-length limbs are optimal for externally powered prostheses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is the ideal shape for a transfemoral (TF) residual limb?	The ideal shape is conical.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
How do longer residual limbs benefit transfemoral (TF) amputees?	Longer residual limbs improve seating balance and tolerance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is key for shorter transfemoral (TF) residual limbs?	Maintaining the greater trochanter and its attachment to the hip abductors is key.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What surgical technique provides increased stability in adduction for transfemoral (TF) amputees?	Myodesis surgical technique provides increased stability in adduction, and increased hip flexion and extension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
When might myoplasty be preferable in transfemoral (TF) amputation?	Myoplasty may be preferable in severely dysvascular patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is required to avoid excess distal bulk in transfemoral (TF) amputations?	Muscle mass tapering is required to avoid excess distal bulk, which may affect prosthesis fit.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is the most common amputation level and its functional significance?	Transtibial (TT) is the most common amputation and is the most proximal level at which near-normal function is available.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is the ideal shape and length for a transtibial (TT) residual limb?	Ideal shape and length is a cylindrical appendage about one third the original tibial length, with retention of the patellar tendon attachment to the tibial tuberosity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
How should the fibula and tibia lengths compare in a transtibial (TT) residual limb?	The fibula should be shorter than the tibia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What challenges might arise with longer limbs in transtibial (TT) amputations with vascular disease?	Longer limbs may not have adequate circulatory supply, and fitting of the below-knee socket may be problematic.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is the ideal length from the medial tibial plateau to the bony end in a transtibial (TT) amputation?	The ideal length recommended is 5” to 7”.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What should be done for wound care post-amputation?	Keep limb clean and protected, debride any non-viable tissue, and monitor for signs of infection especially in patients with fever or excessive residual limb pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is commonly used for edema control in postamputation care?	Elastic wraps, most commonly Ace bandages using a figure-of-eight wrapping technique, should begin immediately after surgery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
How often should elastic wraps be reapplied for postamputation care?	Elastic wraps should ideally be rewrapped four times a day (qid) and taught to the patient.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What alternative is available to elastic wraps for edema control?	Elastic socks are an alternative to wraps; they are not expensive and easy to apply.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What are the benefits of rigid dressings in postamputation care?	Rigid dressings are protective, allow for weight bearing to desensitize the limb, and include both immediate postoperative-fitting prostheses and removable rigid dressings for wound inspection and desensitization.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
When should scar mobilization massage be instituted post-amputation?	Scar mobilization massage should be instituted as soon as tolerated to help prevent adherence of the scar to underlying soft tissues and bone.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
When can scar mobilization massage be performed more aggressively?	Once the sutures are removed, massage can be performed more aggressively.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What common contractures develop with above-knee amputations (AKAs)?	Above-knee amputations commonly develop hip flexion (HF), hip abduction, and hip external rotation contractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What contracture is common with below-knee amputations (BKAs)?	Below-knee amputations commonly develop knee flexion (KF) contractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
How can contractures be prevented in postamputation care?	Prevent contractures with a firm mattress, prone lying for 15 minutes three times a day (tid), promoting knee extension while resting, and consider a posterior splint for higher-risk patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What exercises are key in preprosthetic and prosthetic training?	Hip active range of motion (AROM) and strengthening exercises are key.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is a good test to determine cardiovascular tolerance for prosthesis use?	Ambulation (hopping) with a walker (without a prosthesis) is a good test to determine cardiovascular tolerance for prosthesis use.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
How should prosthetic gait training begin?	Prosthetic gait training should begin with parallel bars and progress to walkers or canes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
Why should crutches be avoided in prosthetic gait training?	Crutches should be avoided since they promote poor gait patterns.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
When is the preparatory prosthesis fitted and definitive prosthesis usually created?	The preparatory prosthesis is fitted while the residual limb is still molding, and the definitive prosthesis is usually created at 3 to 6 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Lower_Extremity_Amputation
What is the function of the socket in a prosthesis?	The socket connects the residual limb to the rest of the prosthesis and plays an important role in the transfer of body weight to the ground.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What materials are used for soft inserts in prosthetic sockets?	Soft inserts made of polyethylene foam or silicone gel provide extra protection.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
For what conditions are soft inserts particularly used in prosthetic sockets?	Soft inserts are used for cases of peripheral vascular disease (PVD) or extensive scarring.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
How do soft inserts affect the fit between the limb and the prosthesis?	The inserts reduce the intimacy of contact between the limb and prosthesis, which is important for proprioception.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What is the purpose of a soft foam distal end in a prosthetic socket?	A soft foam distal end discourages verrucous hyperplasia formation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What areas does the patellar tendon-bearing socket use for weight distribution?	The patellar tendon-bearing socket uses the patellar tendon and soft tissues as partial weight-bearing surfaces to distribute weight over &quot;pressure-tolerant areas.&quot;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
How does the total surface–bearing socket distribute pressure?	The total surface-bearing socket distributes pressure across the entire residual limb surface, including bony areas sensitive to increased pressure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What additional options are available for socket designs?	Additional socket options include the rigid external frame with a flexible inner socket.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
How can socks and silicone liners be used in prosthetic socket management?	Addition of socks may be used if fluctuating edema is present as well as silicone liners to protect skin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What functions does an elastic sleeve serve in TT suspension?	An elastic sleeve can serve as a primary or secondary suspension via longitudinal tension, negative pressure during swing phase, and friction between the residual limb and socket.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
When is an elastic sleeve particularly beneficial in prosthetic suspension?	It can provide additional security for short residual limbs, when mediolateral knee stability is questionable or when hyperextension control is required.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What is a silicone locking liner and how is it secured?	A flexible, molded silicone liner is rolled directly onto the residual limb and secured to the socket with a pin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What are the benefits of a silicone locking liner?	This provides optimal suspension, proprioception, and increased range of motion in flexion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What are the requirements for using a silicone locking liner effectively?	It requires stable limb volumes and good hand dexterity for donning/doffing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What does supracondylar and supracondylar-suprapatellar suspension involve?	Includes a brim suspension as an extension of the socket over the medial and lateral femoral condyles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What benefits does supracondylar suspension provide?	It provides increased mediolateral knee stability and may be useful for short residual limbs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What additional stability options are available for very active patients in TT suspension?	A supracondylar cuff with fork strap and waist belt suspension provides additional stability for very active patients, for example, manual laborers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What comprises an elevated vacuum suspension system?	Consists of a gel liner, suspension sleeve, and air evacuation pump, which creates a negative pressure and seal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What benefits does elevated vacuum suspension provide?	Maintains limb volume throughout the day, improves prosthetic control and proprioception, and avoids loosening within the socket and shear forces causing skin breakdown.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What should the prosthetic foot simulate?	The prosthetic foot should serve as a simulation of the original foot-and-ankle joint and musculature.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What are the key functions of a prosthetic foot?	To provide normal energy-efficient gait, shock absorption, and sufficient weight-bearing base of support.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What are the characteristics of Solid Ankle Cushioned Heel Foot (SACH)?	SACH feet are light, durable, inexpensive, and stable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What function does the soft heel of a SACH foot simulate?	The soft heel simulates plantar flexion (PF) during heel strike and provides good shock absorption.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
Who most commonly uses SACH feet?	It is most commonly used for children and most adult TT amputees or ankle disarticulations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
How do Single-Axis Foot prostheses compare to SACH feet?	Single-Axis Foot prostheses are heavier but less durable than SACH feet and are available for exo- and endoskeletal prostheses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
For whom are Single-Axis Feet most commonly used?	They are most commonly used for TF amputees, especially when knee stability is desired.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What movement is allowed by a Single-Axis Foot?	Only sagittal axis movement is allowed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What motion does a multiaxis foot allow?	The multiaxis foot provides significant ankle motion and improved balance and coordination by allowing plantarflexion/dorsiflexion, inversion/eversion, and rotation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What are the benefits of a multiaxis foot?	It provides good shock absorption and is good for uneven ground.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What are the disadvantages of a multiaxis foot?	The multiaxis foot is heavy and costly, and needs relatively frequent adjustments or repairs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
What was the former name for DER feet like Seattle Light and Carbon Copy II?	These feet were formerly called “energy-storing feet.”																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
Have DER feet demonstrated a reduction in energy cost during level walking compared to the SACH foot?	No, they have not demonstrated a reduction in the energy cost or rate of energy expenditure during level walking compared with the SACH foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
At what conditions might DER feet be more efficient?	They may be more efficient than other feet at higher speeds.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
Why are DER feet beneficial for geriatric amputees?	Geriatric amputees benefit from the light weight of these feet.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TT_Prosthetics
How are TF sockets typically fitted and why?	TF sockets are often fitted in slight (5°) flexion and adduction to stretch the hip extensors and abductors, providing a mechanical advantage including knee stability at heel contact.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What should a TF socket allow for in terms of pressures and integrity?	The socket should allow stabilizing pressures on the skeletal structures while allowing for neurovascular integrity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How should forces be distributed in a TF socket design?	Forces should be distributed over the largest area possible.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is the quadrilateral design in socket design?	This ischial–gluteal weight-bearing, narrow anteroposterior design has four sides and four corners, which allow weight bearing through the ischium and gluteal muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the advantages and disadvantages of the quadrilateral socket design?	It is easy to make and fit and most successful for long, firm residual limbs but less stable for shorter residual limbs and less comfortable in a seated position.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is the Ischial Containment Design in socket design?	A “bony lock” incorporates the ischial tuberosity, pubic ramus, and greater trochanter. The posterior rim provides weight bearing through the medial ischium and ischial ramus and is contoured for the ischial tuberosity and gluteal muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What improvements does the Ischial Containment Design offer?	These features improve stability, particularly for shorter and fleshy residual limbs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How does the Ischial Containment Design compare in energy cost of ambulation?	The narrow mediolateral design provides a more efficient energy cost of ambulation than the narrow anteroposterior design at high speeds.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What does suction suspension utilize in TF prosthetics?	Suction utilizes a one-way valve and liner with concentric rings to maintain prosthetic attachment during swing phase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the benefits of suction suspension for TF amputees?	It is lightweight, provides appropriate suspension and proprioceptive feedback, and is indicated in active amputees with good balance and well-shaped and unfluctuating residual limbs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How can suction suspension be provided?	This can be provided using a silicone seal-in liner or via a skin suction suspension, pulling the residual limb into the socket with a pull sock or a donning sleeve through a hole in the bottom of the socket.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What does the Silicone Seal-in Liner with Pin-Locking or Lanyard Strap offer?	Offers a secure suspension using a gel liner rolled onto the residual limb with either a pin or cord attached to the bottom as the interface between the residual limb and socket.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is the function of a Lanyard Strap in TF suspension?	The lanyard is attached to the distal end of the insert (generally silicone) and fed through the bottom of the socket.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is a Silesian Belt or Bandage, and where does it attach?	A Silesian Belt or Bandage is a belt that attaches from the socket at the greater trochanter and wraps around the opposite iliac crest. It aids in rotational control and is adjustable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What issues may arise with the use of a Silesian Belt or Bandage?	Skin breakdown and chafing may be seen in obese patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is Total Elastic Suspension (Belt) and its benefits?	Total Elastic Suspension wraps around the proximal prosthesis and waist, enhancing rotational control. It is more comfortable than a Silesian belt.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the limitations of Total Elastic Suspension (Belt)?	It retains body heat and has limited durability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is a Pelvic Band-and-Belt Suspension?	A rigid belt is connected to a metal hip joint on the lateral side of the socket.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is the indication for using a Pelvic Band-and-Belt Suspension?	It is indicated for improving rotational and mediolateral pelvic stability in obese patients with especially weak abductors and short or poorly shaped residual limbs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the disadvantages of using a Pelvic Band-and-Belt Suspension?	It is heavy and bulky and tends to interfere with sitting.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What does the Single-Axis Manual Locking Knee provide?	This design provides the ultimate stability but the gait is awkward and energy consuming, as the knee remains locked for standing and ambulation and unlocked while seated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the characteristics of the Single-Axis Manual Locking Knee?	It is a durable and inexpensive knee with a fixed cadence to avoid an asymmetric swing phase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
For whom is the Single-Axis Manual Locking Knee commonly used?	It is indicated for level surface ambulation and commonly used in geriatric and debilitated patients with poor hip control.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What does the Stance Phase Control Knee provide?	Provides knee flexion (KF) control during weight bearing and constant friction during swing phase, which provides increased stability and allows for ambulation on uneven surfaces and prevents buckling.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is noted during the swing phase with the Stance Phase Control Knee?	A delayed swing phase is noted, as full unloading is needed to flex the knee. The constant friction during swing phase is set for one general walking speed or fixed cadence.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What design features does the Polycentric knee have?	This typically has a four-bar linkage design, and a shifting center of rotation provides a moment of force into extension at heel strike.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How does the Polycentric knee enhance stability?	The center of rotation moves proximally and posteriorly to the anatomic knees and provides increased stability during the stance phase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the advantages and disadvantages of the Polycentric knee?	Cosmesis is excellent, especially during sitting, but polycentrics are heavy and costly but quite durable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
For whom is the Polycentric knee indicated?	It is indicated for knee disarticulations and long TF amputees.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How does the Swing and Stance Phase Control Hydraulic Knee Unit work?	This design uses a piston in a fluid-filled cylinder, which provides variable resistance during swing phase, allowing the patient to vary the cadence.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the characteristics of a Swing and Stance Phase Control Hydraulic Knee Unit?	It provides a smooth and natural gait, but is heavy, costly, and requires higher maintenance. Available in single-axis and polycentric models.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What does a Microprocessor-Controlled Hydraulic Knee Joint do?	Microprocessors gather information on the gait cycle and electronically adjust the resistance of the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the benefits of using a Microprocessor-Controlled Hydraulic Knee Joint?	Provides high level of resistance in stance phase, permitting weight bearing on the prosthesis during flexion, yielding low-energy expenditure and improved gait symmetry on stairs, inclines, and uneven terrain; appropriate for K3 or K4 amputees.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the disadvantages of a Microprocessor-Controlled Hydraulic Knee Joint?	Disadvantages include having to recharge the battery every night, increased cost, and high maintenance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What must a provider assess when creating a prescription for a lower limb prosthesis?	The provider must assess a patient’s current and potential functional abilities as well as intended use of the prosthesis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What components are included in the prescription of a lower limb prosthesis?	Components of the prescription include socket, interface, suspension, pylon, and foot/ankle type.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is Functional Level 0 (K0) in prosthetic use?	The patient lacks the ability to transfer or ambulate safely, and the use of a prosthesis would not enhance mobility or quality of life. No prosthesis is provided.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What describes Functional Level 1 (K1) in prosthetic use?	The patient is able/capable of transferring and ambulating on level surfaces at a fixed cadence—a household ambulator. Recommended: single-axis, constant friction knee and single-axis or SACH foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is expected of a patient at Functional Level 2 (K2)?	The patient is able/capable of ambulating community distances and traverse small environmental barriers such as uneven surfaces, curbs, stairs—a community ambulator. Prosthesis components should be alignable and foot can be multiaxial or flexible.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What defines Functional Level 3 (K3) in prosthetic use?	The patient is able/capable of ambulating community distances with variable cadence and traversing most environmental barriers and uneven terrain—an unlimited community ambulator. Prosthesis will include consideration of fluid and pneumatic control knees with an energy-storing or dynamic response foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What defines Functional Level 4 (K4) in prosthetic use?	The patient’s capabilities exceed everyday requirements for basic ambulation including high level of impact, stress, and energy—includes athletes, active adults, and children.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What prosthetic components might be considered for Functional Level 4 (K4)?	A hydraulic knee and specialized feet (running, waterproof, adjustable heel height) may be considered as well as a backup suspension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How prevalent is pain among amputees according to one national survey?	In one national survey, approximately 95% of amputees reported one or more types of pain related to amputation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What percentages of amputees reported experiencing phantom pain, residual limb pain, and back pain?	80% reported phantom pain, 68% residual limb pain, and 62% back pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How can poorly controlled pre- and postoperative pain affect amputees?	Poorly controlled pre- and postoperative pain may increase the risk of chronic amputation pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What maintains phantom limb sensation and pain?	Phantom limb sensation, phantom limb pain, and generalized limb pain are maintained by afferent, central, and efferent dysfunction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How is phantom limb pain characterized?	Phantom limb pain can be sharp, burning, stabbing, tingling, shooting, electric, or cramping.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What are the treatment options for phantom limb pain?	Treatment options include desensitization (e.g., massaging and tapping), neuropathic pain agents, topical anesthetics, modalities (e.g., TENS units, mirror therapy), and injections into neuromas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is Choke Syndrome in amputees?	Choke Syndrome involves distal limb edema and painful verrucous hyperplasia due to proximal limb pressure and a lack of total contact with the prosthesis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What is usually present with Choke Syndrome?	An underlying vascular disorder is usually present.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
How is Choke Syndrome treated?	Treatment involves adding a distal pad to the socket, correcting the suspension, removing proximal pressure, and/or refitting the socket.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TF_Prosthetics
What does Figure 7.12 show about amputation levels?	The relationship between amputation level(s) and energy cost and speed is shown in Figure 7.12.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What can cause excessive trunk extension/lumbar lordosis during the stance phase?	A poorly shaped posterior wall may cause patients to forward rotate their pelvis for pressure relief, with compensatory trunk extension. Other causes include insufficient initial socket flexion, HF contracture, and weak hip extensors or abdominal muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What might cause foot slap in a TF locked-knee prosthesis?	Foot slap may be noted if the foot is posteriorly placed or if socket flexion is excessive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What are the causes of knee buckling/instability?	Causes include knee axis too anterior, insufficient PF, failure to limit DF, weak hip extensors, hard heel, large HF contracture, and posteriorly placed foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
How is stability achieved in the presence of potential knee buckling?	Stability is achieved with a plantar-flexed or anteriorly placed foot, or a soft heel (i.e., SACH).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What causes lateral bending in amputees?	Lateral bending generally occurs to the prosthetic side. Causes include a prosthesis that is too short, insufficient lateral wall, abducted socket, abduction contracture, and poor amputee balance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What might cause vaulting of the nonprosthetic limb?	Vaulting of the nonprosthetic limb may be due to a prosthesis that is too long, too much knee friction, or poor suspension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What is a whip in the context of a TF prosthesis, and what might cause it?	A whip is an abrupt rotation of the heel occurring at the end of stance phase as the knee of a TF prosthesis is flexed to begin swing. Causes include improper rotatory alignment of the knee axis, a knee axis not parallel to the floor, flabby muscles about the femur with the prosthesis rotating freely within the underlying soft tissue, or a socket that is too tight.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What is the difference between a medial and lateral whip?	If the heel moves medially during initial flexion, it is a medial whip; if it moves laterally, it is a lateral whip.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What causes an abducted gait in amputees?	Causes include a prosthesis that is too long, an abduction contracture, or a medial socket wall encroaching the groin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What causes a circumducted gait in amputees?	Causes include a prosthesis that is too long, too much knee friction making it difficult to bend the knee during swing-through, or an abduction contracture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What causes excessive heel rise in amputees?	Causes include insufficient knee friction or excessive knee flexion (KF) moment (i.e., posterior foot or insufficient plantar flexion (PF) at heel strike).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What causes foot drag in amputees?	Causes include inadequate suspension, a prosthesis that is too long, insufficient hip flexion (HF) or knee flexion (KF), or weak PF of the nonprosthetic limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What causes terminal swing impact in amputees?	Insufficient knee friction may cause the amputee to deliberately and forcibly extend the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Prosthetic_Gait_Palsy
What are the most common causes of upper extremity amputations?	Upper extremity amputations are most commonly due to traumatic injuries followed by malignancies and dysvascular disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
What percentage of newborn congenital defects are upper limb deficiencies?	Approximately 58.5% of newborn congenital defects are upper limb deficiencies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
What is the most common type of upper limb deficiency in newborns?	The most common type is the left transverse terminal radial limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
What skills must an upper extremity orthosis be able to perform?	The upper extremity orthosis must be able to perform gross and fine motor skills needed by the amputee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
How do unilateral amputees typically manage activities of daily living (ADLs)?	Unilateral amputees typically learn to perform most ADLs with their intact hand.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
How do bilateral amputees typically manage activities of daily living (ADLs)?	Bilateral amputees often use their feet for many ADLs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
Who should be prescribed functional upper extremity prostheses?
