Functional upper extremity prostheses should be prescribed for highly motivated patients with realistic expectations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
What preparation is required before prosthetic fitting for an upper extremity amputation?	Residual limb shaping with bandages may be required for 1 to 2 months before prosthetic fitting to ensure precise fit and appropriate alignment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
What is the purpose of careful residual limb shaping before prosthetic fitting?	To protect bony prominences, avoid compression of peripheral nerves, and allow for sensory feedback for appropriate function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
What is the impact of delaying prosthetic fitting after unilateral amputation?	If fitting is not performed within a 3-to-6-month window after unilateral amputation, long-term prosthesis use is infrequently seen.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::Upper_Extremity_Amputation
At what levels can a TR amputation be performed?	A TR amputation can be performed at three levels: long (55%–90% residual limb), short (35%–55%), and very short (&lt;35%).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TR_Prosthetics
What advantages do longer residual limbs provide in TR amputations?	Longer residual limbs allow for improved cosmesis and functionally provide a greater lever arm and more pronation/supination.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TR_Prosthetics
What type of prostheses are typically prescribed for manual laborers with a TR amputation?	Body-powered prostheses with hooks or hands are typically prescribed for manual laborers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TR_Prosthetics
What weight can typically be lifted with body-powered prostheses in TR amputations?	Lifting up to 20 to 30 lb. can be expected with body-powered prostheses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TR_Prosthetics
What type of prostheses is more appropriate for relatively sedentary amputees with a TR amputation?	Myoelectric prostheses are typically more appropriate for relatively sedentary amputees.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TR_Prosthetics
What is the preference for residual limb length in TH amputations?	Longer residual limbs (up to 90% of original/expected length) are preferred.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How does function compare in TH amputation versus TR amputation?	Function is usually much poorer than with a TR amputation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What are key components for TH prostheses?	Key differences for TH prostheses include the need for an elbow unit and different harnessing and control systems.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What is the typical lifting capacity with TH prostheses?	Lifting between 10 and 15 lb. can be expected (more with a shoulder saddle).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How are length estimates calculated for bilateral TH amputees?	Length estimates for bilateral TH amputees are 19% of patient height for the upper arm and 21% for the forearm component.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What are terminal devices (TDs) in upper extremity prostheses?	Terminal devices (TDs) are the most important functional part of the upper extremity prosthesis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How are terminal devices classified?	They are classified as active or passive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What do passive TDs provide?	Passive TDs provide cosmesis and minimal function (e.g., ball handling or child mitt for crawling).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What are the types of active TDs?	Active TDs are broken into hooks and artificial hands.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How do hooks function in active TDs?	Hooks may have prehensors with thumb- and finger-like components.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How does the proximal limb/prosthesis function with a TD?	The proximal limb/prosthesis essentially functions to position the TD in space.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What is the most common and practical type of TD?	Body-powered voluntary opening split hooks are the most common and practical TDs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How is the TD controlled in body-powered voluntary opening split hooks?	In these devices, the TD is closed at rest. Prehensile force is predetermined by the number of rubber bands in place.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What force is required to provide pinch force in body-powered TDs?	Each rubber band requires 5 lb. of force to provide 1 lb. of pinch force.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How many bands can be used in body-powered TDs?	Up to 10 bands can be used.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What is the typical pinch force for a nonamputee male?	Typical nonamputee male pinch force is 15 to 20 lb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How do voluntary closing TDs function?	Voluntary closing TDs provide better control of closing pressure, but active effort is required to maintain closure of the TD, or items may be dropped.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How do myoelectric hands compare to body-powered TDs?	Myoelectric hands offer spherical/palmar grasp with grip forces higher than body-powered TDs. They can have a lifelike appearance but are relatively fragile.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What controllers are used with myoelectric hands?	Two-site two-function controllers use different muscles to open and close the TD, while one-site two-function controllers use weak versus strong contractions of the same muscle to operate the TD.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What does the prosthetic wrist unit provide and how is it held in place?	The prosthetic wrist unit provides orientation of the TD in space and is held in place by a friction or mechanical lock.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What are the characteristics of the most common wrist unit, the friction wrist?	The friction wrist allows passive pronation/supination but can slip when holding heavy objects.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What do bilateral amputees require in terms of wrist units?	Bilateral amputees require at least one mechanical spring-assisted flexion wrist for access to the body midline.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How is the elbow unit selected for upper limb prostheses?	The elbow unit is selected based on the level of amputation and residual function; pronation and supination decrease as the amputation site becomes more proximal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
"How does the TH prosthetic elbow&#x27;s alternator lock function?"	Most TH prosthetic elbows have an alternator lock, which alternately locks and unlocks with the same movement. Body movements will flex or extend the elbow when unlocked, and the same cable operates the TD when locked.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What does the traditional suspension system employ?	The traditional suspension employs straps and cables, with a double-walled socket for optimal fit. The outer wall is rigid and connects to other components; the inner wall must fit precisely with the residual limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What is the preference for TH amputees in terms of socket type?	The suction socket provides self-suspension without straps and is preferred for the TH amputee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What does the Munster supracondylar socket provide?	It provides self-suspension for a very short TR or elbow disarticulation by encasing the humeral condyles and can be used for externally powered prostheses. Proper fit of the Munster socket limits full elbow extension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How does the body harness function?	The body harness uses cables to allow body motion and effort to operate prosthetic components.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What does the figure-of-8 harness configuration do?	It holds the socket firmly in place, usually with an elbow hinge and half-arm cuff or triceps pad, generally for a short TR or more proximal amputation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What is the difference between the figure-of-8 and figure-of-9 harness configurations?	The figure-of-9 requires a self-suspending socket but is more comfortable than the figure-of-8, generally for a long TR or wrist disarticulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What does the shoulder saddle with chest strap provide?	It frees the opposite shoulder and relieves pressure caused by the axillary loop of the figure-of-8. Heavy loads are better tolerated, but donning is difficult and cosmesis is inferior.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What movement is provided by Glenohumeral (GH) Forward Flexion in body-powered prosthesis control?	This natural movement provides substantial power and reach, allowing for activation of the TD or flexion of an elbow joint.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What does Biscapular Abduction enable in body-powered prosthesis control?	This movement permits activation of a TD, but must stay relatively stationary. The forces generated are relatively weak and sufficient for fine motor activities located at the midline.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How does GH Depression, Extension, Abduction function in body-powered prosthesis control?	This movement locks or unlocks an elbow, but may be unnatural for some users and difficult to master.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What does Scapular Elevation achieve in body-powered prosthesis control?	This locks or unlocks the elbow and is easy to master. It requires a waist belt.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
What does Chest Expansion/Scapular Adduction do in body-powered prosthesis control?	This locks or unlocks the elbow. It is an awkward motion, but does not interfere with TD operations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics RehabReadyTags::Amputation_Prosthetics::TH_Prosthetics
How is concussion classified in relation to traumatic brain injury (TBI)?	Concussion is a subset of TBI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
How is concussion defined?	As a complex pathophysiological process affecting the brain, induced by biomechanical forces.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What can cause a concussion?	A direct or indirect force transmitted to the brain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What is the onset type and duration of neurological impairments caused by a concussion?	Rapid-onset and short-lived neurological impairments.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What are the typical neuropathological changes in a concussion?	Usually due to a functional rather than a structural injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What leads to complex cellular dysfunction in a concussion?	Neurotransmitters released after the injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What is the biochemical pathway that leads to exacerbatation of concussion symptoms?	Glutamate release, efflux of potassium, influx of calcium, hyperglycolysis, release of free radicals and enzymes, damage to cytoskeletons, inflammatory damage, glucose utilization, energy crisis, mitochondrial failure, lactate production, increased membrane permeability, apoptosis, necrosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What are the types of concussion symptoms?	Somatic, cognitive, sleep-related, and emotional.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What is the most common symptom of a concussion?	Headache.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
How often does loss of consciousness occur in concussions?	In less than 10% of cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What are more common symptoms than loss of consciousness in concussions?	Confusion and amnesia (retrograde and/or anterograde).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Definition_Pathophys
What should happen to athletes after recognizing signs of concussion on the field?	Athletes should be medically evaluated on-site by a health care provider and removed from the game.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
What should be done after serious medical conditions have been ruled out in a suspected concussion case?	Sideline evaluation with the Sport Concussion Assessment Tool 5th edition (SCAT5) should be performed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
What type of monitoring is recommended after a concussion diagnosis on the field?	Serial monitoring for deterioration should be performed over the initial few hours.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
Can a player with a diagnosed concussion return to play the same day?	No, a player with a diagnosed concussion should not be allowed to return to play the same day.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
What details should be gathered about the injury during a concussion assessment?	How it occurred, immediate symptoms and evolution, presence of LOC or amnesia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
What should be used to guide the current symptom description in a concussion assessment?	The 22-item Post-Concussion Symptom Scale. Do NOT use concussion grading scales.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
What assessments are included in the physical exam for a concussion?	Neurological exam, Balance Error Scoring System (BESS), visuomotor exam, and if needed, brief neurocognitive testing with SCAT5.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
What does the BESS test involve?	Balance assessment with eyes closed, on firm and soft surfaces, in three stances—feet together, tandem, and on only the nondominant foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
What are the components of the visuomotor exam in concussion assessment?	Nystagmus, saccades, convergence, vestibular–ocular reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
Why are head CT and MRI usually limited in concussion cases?	They are usually negative and their use is limited to cases with high suspicion for structural intracerebral injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
What conditions might prompt the use of a head CT or MRI in concussion cases?	High suspicion for structural intracerebral injury, including intracranial hemorrhage, prolonged LOC, post-traumatic amnesia, persistently altered mental status, focal neurologic deficit, evidence of skull fracture, or signs of clinical deterioration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Assessment
When should an athlete be allowed to return to play after a sport-related concussion?	No athlete should be allowed to return to play until assessed for the presence of concussion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What is the risk associated with returning to play too soon after a concussion?	Risk of reinjury is high, leading to worsened symptoms and prolonged recovery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What term is advised against using to describe repeated concussions before recovery?	Second Impact Syndrome (SIS).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What should the goal of concussion recovery focus on?	Return to play, sports, work, and daily life activities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What is the first step in managing a concussion?	Educate and provide reassurance about recovery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What has previous guidance on complete rest after a concussion been found to cause?	Prolonged symptoms and unnecessary anxiety.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What kind of activities might be allowed for children and young adults during concussion recovery?	Use of computers and video games to test reactions, limited if it causes exacerbation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
How should physical activities be approached in concussion management?	Limit to non-contact nature; allow some form of activity as tolerated by symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
How should cognitive activity be managed in concussion recovery?	Limit to what can be tolerated; avoid removing students from school unless symptoms are significant.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What guides the process for returning athletes to sports after a concussion?	The Graduated Return to Play Protocol, progressing through six stages, each lasting at least 24 hours.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
When should pharmacological treatment be considered in concussion management?	Limited to ongoing symptoms beyond the usual course; melatonin and pain relief with acetaminophen or ibuprofen as needed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
Over what time frame do symptoms normally improve after a concussion?	Days to weeks, and it is essential to provide reassurance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What denotes the term &quot;persistent symptoms&quot; in concussion cases?	Symptoms persisting beyond 10-14 days in adults and 4 weeks in children, indicating a failure of normal clinical recovery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What are common risk factors for prolonged symptoms after a concussion?	Presence of migrainous symptoms, fogginess, or amnesia; younger age, female, prone to overexertion, history of multiple concussions, psychiatric disturbances, or learning disability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What is the post-concussion syndrome, and how should it be approached?	It is a nonspecific wastebasket psychiatric diagnosis often used for symptoms lasting over 3 months after a concussion and should never be used.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What is important for optimal management of complex concussion cases?	A multidisciplinary team approach consisting of a physiatrist, vestibular therapist, and neuropsychologist, with possible consultations from neurology and other specialties.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Concussion RehabReadyTags::Concussion::Management_Treatment
What emotional descriptions are used for pain?	Sickening, nauseating; often associated with anxiety when moderate or severe.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What are the physiological responses when pain is acute?	Behavioral arousal or stress response, increased blood pressure, tachycardia, increased pupil size, increased plasma cortisol levels.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is a nociceptor?	A receptor preferentially sensitive to a noxious stimulus or to a stimulus that would become noxious if prolonged.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is allodynia?	Pain due to a stimulus that does not normally provoke pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is dysesthesia?	An unpleasant abnormal sensation, whether spontaneous or evoked.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
How is hyperalgesia defined?	An increased response to a stimulus that is normally painful.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is hyperesthesia?	Increased sensitivity to stimulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is hyperpathia?	A painful syndrome characterized by an abnormally painful reaction to a stimulus, especially a repetitive stimulus, and an increased threshold.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is hypoalgesia?	Diminished pain in response to a normally painful stimulus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is hypoesthesia?	Decreased sensitivity to stimulation, excluding the special senses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is neuralgia?	Pain in the distribution of a nerve or nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is neuropathic pain?	Pain initiated or caused by a primary lesion or dysfunction in the nervous system.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is neuropathy?	A disturbance of function or pathologic change in a nerve.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is paresthesia?	An abnormal sensation, whether spontaneous or evoked.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What distinguishes superficial from deep somatic pain?	Superficial is localized and sharp from skin or subcutaneous tissues, deep arises from joints or muscles and is dull and aching.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
What is visceral pain?	Pain due to pathology involving an internal organ, often described as dull and diffuse, associated with autonomic symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
How does the type of pain vary with the underlying disorder?	Musculoskeletal pain = nociceptive, neurological pain from CNS or PNS = neuropathic, and pain from disorders like cancer or chronic lower back pain = mixed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Terminology
Where are the cell bodies of primary afferent neurons located?	In the dorsal root ganglia, located in the vertebral foramina at each spinal cord level.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Pathophys
What is the structure of the axon in primary afferent neurons?	Each neuron contains a single axon that bifurcates to the periphery and to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Pathophys
Where does the primary afferent neuron synapse in the spinal cord?	In the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Pathophys
With which neuron does the primary afferent neuron synapse in the dorsal horn?	A second-order neuron.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Pathophys
Where does the axon of the second-order neuron ascend after crossing the midline?	Through the contralateral spinothalamic tract to the thalamus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Pathophys
Where do the neurons synapse after reaching the thalamus?	In the thalamic nuclei with third-order neurons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Pathophys
To where do third-order neurons transmit the signal after the thalamus?	To the internal capsule and corona radiata, and then to the postcentral gyrus of the brain cortex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Pathophys
What are examples of red flags in pain assessment that warrant emergent treatment?	Progressive numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder incontinence, and saddle anesthesia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Examination
How many pairs of spinal nerves are given off by the spinal cord, and what are their categories?	8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral, and 1 coccygeal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
What surrounds the spinal cord and nerves, and what does it contain?	They are surrounded by a sac called the dura mater, which contains the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
Why is it important to understand the dermatomal distributions of each nerve root?	It aids in obtaining history and during examination and treatment of spinal conditions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
What is the rule of thumb for nerve root exits in the cervical spine?	In the cervical spine, a nerve root comes out above its corresponding vertebral body.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
Where does the C7 nerve root exit?	At the C6/C7 level.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
Where does the C8 nerve root exit?	At the C7/T1 level.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
How does the direction of disc herniation affect which nerve root is impacted?	Posterolateral disc herniations typically spare the root at that level and affect the root exiting at the level below.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
How do far lateral disc herniations affect nerve roots?	They can affect the nerve root at that level as it exits via the lateral recesses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
Why are the majority of disc herniations posterolateral?	Posterior longitudinal ligment is narrow and weaker compared to anterior longitudinal ligment + natural curvature of lumbar spine (lordosis) directs pressure towards posterior sides of disc																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Anatomy
What is often the first-line imaging obtained for low back pain?	X-rays.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
What pathologies can X-rays demonstrate?	Spondylitic changes, instability, compression fractures, intervertebral disc degeneration, lytic/blasticlesions, pathologic findings in spine diseases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
What imaging modalities are usually ordered next if further radiographic evaluation is warranted?	CT and MRI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
When is MRI often ordered and what does it evaluate?	MRI is often ordered unless contraindicated, to evaluate soft tissue pathology (e.g., disc disease) and to better evaluate bony pathology (e.g., assessing acuity of fracture).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
What are the main MRI types used in spinal imaging?	T1, T2, sagittal short T1 inversion recovery (STIR), and T1 with fat suppression.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
How do water, fat, bone cortex, stones, and ligaments appear on different MRI types?	Water and pathology: white on T2, dark on T1. Fat: white on T1 and T2. Bone cortex, stones, and ligaments: dark on every type. Contusions are white.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
What is the typical distribution of radiculopathic pain and what can cause it?	Radiculopathic pain typically follows a dermatomal/myotomal distribution and can stem from irritation from disc fragments, bone, and others.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
What are the most common nerve roots involved in the cervical spine?	C6 and C7.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
What are the most commonly involved levels in the lumbar spine for radiculopathy?	L5 and S1.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
What physical exams aid in the accurate diagnosis of radiculopathic pain?	Tests for root irritation such as cervical loading/distraction and straight leg raising.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Imaging
What underlying mechanisms may contribute to CRPS I?	Changes in the peripheral and central somatosensory, autonomic, and motor processing systems, pathologic interaction of sympathetic and afferent systems, neurogenic inflammation, and autoimmunity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
What are the clinical features of CRPS?	Disproportionate extremity pain, swelling, autonomic (sympathetic) and motor symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
Which extremities are more commonly affected by CRPS?	It is slightly more common in the upper extremities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
What defines CRPS I?	Known trauma to an area without specific nerve injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
What defines CRPS II?	Known injury to a nerve.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
What are some causes of CRPS?	Trauma, underlying neurologic pathology, musculoskeletal disorders, and malignancy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
What characterizes the acute stage of CRPS?	Usually a warm phase lasting 2 to 3 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
What characterizes the dystrophic phase of CRPS?	Vasomotor instability for several months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
What characterizes the atrophic phase of CRPS?	Usually a cold extremity with atrophic changes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Complex_Regional_Pain_Syndrome
Are there any diagnostic tests that are sufficiently sensitive and specific for diagnosing CRPS?	No single diagnostic test has proven sensitive and specific enough to diagnose CRPS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What might X-ray imaging show in CRPS patients?	Osteoporosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
How useful is the triple-phase bone scan in diagnosing CRPS?	It has been useful, especially when it shows diffuse increased activity in the delayed third phase, including juxta-articular accentuation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What can skin thermography reveal in CRPS?	Temperature disparities between limbs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What does QSART stand for and what does it measure?	Quantitative Sudomotor Axon Reflex Testing, measures sudomotor function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
Are nerve conduction velocity (NCV) and EMG usually normal in CRPS patients?	Yes, they are usually normal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What is the Budapest Criteria?	The most widely used diagnostic criteria for CRPS, officially adopted by the IASP in 2012.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What must be met according to the Budapest Criteria for diagnosing CRPS?	Continuing pain disproportionate to any inciting event, at least one symptom in three of the four categories, at least one sign in two of the categories, and no other diagnosis that better explains the signs and symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What are the sensory requirements under the Budapest Criteria?	Reports of hyperesthesia and/or allodynia; evidence of hyperalgesia to pinprick and/or allodynia to light touch/deep somatic pressure/joint movement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What are the vasomotor requirements under the Budapest Criteria?	Reports and evidence of temperature asymmetry, skin color changes, and/or skin color asymmetry.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What are the sudomotor/edema requirements under the Budapest Criteria?	Reports and evidence of edema and/or sweating changes and/or sweating asymmetry.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What are the motor/trophic requirements under the Budapest Criteria?	Reports and evidence of decreased range of motion, motor dysfunction (weakness, tremor, dystonia), and/or trophic changes (hair, nail, skin).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Diagnosis_Workup_CRPS
What is the mainstay of treatment for CRPS?	Early restoration of function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Treatment_Medications_CRPS
What should be initiated early in the treatment of CRPS?	Physical therapy (PT)/occupational therapy (OT) program focusing on the affected limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Treatment_Medications_CRPS
What are sympathetic blocks used for in CRPS treatment?	They are used for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Treatment_Medications_CRPS
Which sympathetic block is good for upper extremity CRPS?	Stellate ganglion block.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Treatment_Medications_CRPS
Which sympathetic block is good for lower extremity CRPS?	Lumbar sympathetic block.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Treatment_Medications_CRPS
What are the methods for performing sympathectomy in CRPS treatment?	Interventionally (radiofrequency [RF] and cryoablation) or surgically.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Treatment_Medications_CRPS
How can dorsal column stimulation help in CRPS treatment?	It can be a tremendous help with upper and lower extremity CRPS, especially with an appropriate diagnosis and patient screening to improve outcomes of neuromodulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Treatment_Medications_CRPS
What typically characterizes the onset of pain in spinal stenosis?	Pain typically has a more insidious onset, worsening after arising in the morning and after walking a certain distance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What causes morning pain in spinal stenosis?	The pain is said to be due to the additive compression by engorged epidural veins overnight.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What is neurogenic claudication in spinal stenosis?	Pain worsening when walking down a hill versus up the hill, different from vascular claudication which is pain worsening when walking up a hill.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
How is spinal stenosis related to degenerative disc disease?	Spinal stenosis and degenerative disc disease are not mutually exclusive and often stenosis results from disc herniation/bulges coupled with spondylitic changes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What supports the axial spine and forms the sacroiliac (SI) joints?	The sacrum, which articulates with the iliac wings.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What can cause dysfunction in the sacroiliac joint?	Imbalance or dysfunction can result from repeated lifting and bending, causing a shift on the anteroposterior axis and stress on myofascial attachments.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What are common areas of pain in SI joint pathologies?	The ipsilateral hip and greater trochanter regions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What tests are used to evaluate sacroiliac joint dysfunction?	Provocation maneuvers such as Faber and Gaenslen tests, though their sensitivity and specificity vary.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What is the typical initial treatment for spinal stenosis and SI joint pain?	A short period of rest, initiation of physical therapy (PT) such as &quot;Back School&quot; and McKenzie treatment programs, along with NSAIDs and COX-2 inhibitors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What additional treatment may be given for severe cases of spinal stenosis or SI joint pain?	A tapering dose of oral steroids may be given, depending on the severity of clinical presentation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Neck_LowBack_Pain
What do epidural injections involve?	The introduction of local anesthetics, opioids, or steroids, mainly performed via an interlaminar technique or a transforaminal approach.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What is the interlaminar technique in epidural injections?	It involves traversing the supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum, with a &quot;sudden loss of resistance&quot; indicating entry to the epidural space.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are the indications for cervical/lumbar epidural nerve blocks?	Cervical/lumbar radiculopathy, cervical/lumbar spondylosis, post-laminectomy syndrome, vertebral compression fractures, diabetic polyneuropathy, phantom limb pain, chemotherapy-related neuropathy/plexopathy, cancer pain, and as a diagnostic procedure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are the contraindications for epidural injections?	Local infection, patient on anticoagulants, coagulopathy, and sepsis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What complications can arise from epidural injections?	Dural puncture, intravenous needle placement, epidural hematoma, infection, urinary retention and incontinence, and direct trauma to spinal cord/nerve roots.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What does a dural puncture during an epidural injection potentially cause?	CSF loss or introduction of air (pneumocephalus), responsible for significant postprocedure headaches.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What is the risk associated with epidural hematoma in epidural injections?	Usually self-limiting, but in the setting of anticoagulation, it may cause cord compression, cauda equina syndrome, paralysis, apnea, and death.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What is the proper technique for a caudal epidural steroid injection (ESI)?	The patient is positioned in a lateral or prone position, and the needle is placed over the sacrococcygeal membrane at a 60° angle to the coronal plane, perpendicular to other planes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What typically happens when the sacrococcygeal membrane is pierced during a caudal ESI?	There is usually a loss of resistance as the membrane is pierced.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are general indications for a caudal epidural nerve block?	General indications and contraindications mimic those of the lumbar/cervical approaches where anatomically relevant.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
Why might a caudal injection be preferred in certain cases?	Preferred in cases like prior lumbar surgery which can distort anatomy, or in patients on anticoagulation or coagulopathic therapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are the contraindications for a caudal epidural nerve block?	Infection, sepsis, pilonidal cysts, and congenital anomalies of the dural sac and contents.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are potential complications of a caudal epidural nerve block?	Dural puncture, needle misplacement, hematoma/ecchymosis, infection, and urinary retention/incontinence.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are common sources of chronic neck and low back pain?	The cervical and lumbar facet (zygapophyseal) joints.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What type of joints are the facet joints?	Diarthrodial, made up of the inferior and superior articular processes of adjoining vertebrae.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
How are facet joints innervated?	Dually innervated by the medial branch nerves of each level comprising the joint.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
How is the L4/L5 facet joint innervated?	By the medial branches of L4 and L5 nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What mixture is injected during a facet joint injection?	A mixture of dye, local anesthetic, and steroid.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
When is a definitive diagnosis of facet syndrome made?	With pain relief following the injection of local anesthetic into the facet joint.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are the contraindications for facet joint injections or medial branch blocks?	Medication allergies, systemic or local infection, or coagulopathies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are common complications of facet joint injections?	Transient increase in pain, dural penetration, spinal anesthesia, capsule rupture, infection, and vertebral artery puncture (in cervical facets).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
How are transforaminal ESIs used based on physical exam and radiologic findings?	They target specific nerve roots that are identified as the source of pain, especially when pressure on such a nerve may result in autoimmune responses and facilitate inflammation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What is involved in a selective nerve root block or transforaminal ESI?	Placing a mixture of local anesthetic and steroid in the superior region of the neural foramen where the postganglionic nerve root exits.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are the two main approaches for transforaminal ESIs?	The &quot;safe triangle&quot; approach and Kambin’s triangle approach.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What is the &quot;safe triangle&quot; approach?	This approach utilizes a subpedicular method under the inferior surface of the pedicle to locate the superolateral spinal nerve related to the patient’s symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What risks are associated with the &quot;safe triangle&quot; approach?	The Adamkiewicz artery (AKA artery) runs through this area, and injections here run the risk of damaging the vessel wall or injecting into the artery itself.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
"What is Kambin&#x27;s triangle?"	A right-angled triangle over the dorsolateral disc defined by Kambin in 1972 for endoscopic intervertebral discectomy, believed to protect epidural and neurological structures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are indications for using SNRB/TFESI?	Effective after discectomy in patients with recurrent radiculopathy without disc herniation, in cases of disc herniations, and when facet joint hypertrophy or cysts irritate the nerve root.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are common complications of SNRB/TFESI?	Bleeding, infection, allergic reactions, intravascular injection, spinal cord infarcts, direct trauma to the nerve root, spinal anesthesia, and respiratory arrest during cervical procedures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
What are SI joint injections indicated for?	Sacroiliitis or chronic SI joint arthropathy, serving both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
How is the SI joint visualized for injections?	Under fluoroscopic guidance to ensure accurate placement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
Where is the needle introduced for an SI joint injection?	At the junction of the posterior one third and the middle one third of the joint line.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine::Spinal_Intervention
Why is the lower portion of the SI joint easier to inject?	The posterior iliac spine obstructs the superior portion of the joint, making the lower portion more accessible.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What is done to confirm needle placement in the SI joint space?	A small amount of contrast is injected to perform an arthrogram.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What happens once the arthrogram is satisfactory in an SI joint injection?	The medication, usually a mixture of anesthetic and steroid, is injected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What is the purpose of radiofrequency ablation?	To deliver a current via a needle to cause neurolysis of nerves near the lesion created by the electrode.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What are the general indications for radiofrequency ablation?	Failed conservative treatments, transient relief from medial branch blocks, and no indication for surgical intervention.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What are the contraindications for radiofrequency ablation?	Coagulopathy, platelet dysfunction, and severe cardiopulmonary disease for cervical and thoracic procedures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What are the complications of radiofrequency ablation?	Local soreness, sensorimotor deficits, vascular trauma, pneumothorax, entry into subarachnoid space, diaphragmatic paralysis and hoarseness, puncture of abdominal viscera, or direct trauma to disks, cord, and nerve roots.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What is the purpose of vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty?	To treat pain and spinal instability surrounding acute vertebral compression fractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What are the indications for vertebroplasty?	Refractory pain from vertebral compression fractures aged 2 weeks to 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What are the contraindications for vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty?	Discitis, sepsis, osteomyelitis, significant spinal canal compromise, fractures older than 2 years, &gt;75% collapse of vertebral body, fractures above T5, and traumatic compression fractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What is the difference between vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty?	Vertebroplasty focuses on pain relief by injecting cement, while kyphoplasty also aims to restore vertebral height and stability using balloons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What is the purpose of spinal cord stimulators?	To treat chronic intractable pain by stimulating the dorsal column of the spinal cord.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What are the indications for spinal cord stimulators?	Failed neck/back surgery, peripheral neuropathy, post-herpetic neuralgia, CRPS, epidural fibrosis/arachnoiditis, radiculopathy, phantom limb pain, and ischemic pain from peripheral vascular disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
How is neuromodulation being used in recent applications?	For peripheral stimulation in subcutaneous tissue with promising results, particularly for occipital neuralgia and recalcitrant trigeminal neuralgia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What is the purpose of intrathecal pumps?	Intrathecal pumps are used in the management of chronic pain and spasticity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
How is the intrathecal pump initially set up during the trial phase?	A catheter is inserted intrathecally and connected to an external pump.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What happens if the trial with the intrathecal pump is successful?	A permanent catheter is placed intrathecally, tunneled through subcutaneous tissue to an internal pump, usually situated in a pocket in the anterior abdomen.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
How does the intrathecal pump adjust medication delivery?	The pump can be adjusted to deliver different amounts of medication directly to the spinal fluid.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What is the advantage of intrathecal infusion?	It bypasses the blood-brain barrier, allowing a more directed effect on brain and spinal neuroreceptors with less medication.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What medications are commonly used in intrathecal pumps?	Preservative-free morphine and baclofen for spasticity management are the two most common medications used in these pumps.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pain_Medicine
What are the common causes and classifications of AC injuries?	AC injuries often occur with falls on an adducted shoulder and are classified according to the Rockwood criteria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What characterizes a Type I AC joint injury?	A Type I (Rockwood classification) injury is a nondisplaced sprain of the AC ligament, showing local tenderness without anatomic deformity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How are Type I or Type II AC joint injuries treated?	Treatment includes nonoperative measures such as an arm sling, ice, analgesics, and progressive ROM exercises. An unstable Type II injury may require arm sling use for 2 to 4 weeks. Sports activities can resume when full painless ROM and baseline deltoid strength are achieved.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the treatment for Type III to VI AC joint lesions?	These lesions involve rupture of the AC and CC ligaments with varying clavicle displacements, requiring orthopedic consultation for potential ORIF or conservative management with sling-and-swathe immobilization and long-term therapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What suggests AC Joint Osteoarthritis (ACJ OA) and how is it treated?	ACJ OA, common especially in the elderly, is suggested by ACJ tenderness and pain with cross-body adduction. Treatment may include analgesics, PT, injections, and possibly surgery. Radiologic and US evaluations confirm the diagnosis. Fluoroscopic or US-guided injections are preferred due to the inaccuracy of traditional techniques such as injection.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the causes and symptoms of shoulder impingement syndrome?	Commonly caused by factors like acromion shape, repetitive overhead activities, and age, this syndrome can lead to rotator cuff tendinitis, bursitis, tendinosis, and tears. Symptoms include pain, especially at night, and limited shoulder flexion and abduction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What does a positive Hawkin’s test indicate?	"A positive Hawkin&#x27;s test, involving flexing the elbow and abducting the shoulder to 90° followed by internal rotation, indicates pain in the subacromial region, suggesting shoulder impingement."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
Describe the Neer’s test and its implications.	"In Neer&#x27;s test, the examiner passively flexes the patient’s shoulder to 180° while internally rotating the arm. Pain in the subacromial area indicates a positive test for impingement."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is indicated by a painful arc during the drop arm test?	A painful arc, present from about 70° to 110° of active arm abduction, may indicate rotator cuff pathology. Severe pain or inability to lower the arm in the drop arm test suggests a severe or complete rotator cuff tear.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is the empty can test performed and what does it assess?	The empty can test involves elevating the arm to 90° of abduction, internally rotating it, and angling it in the scapular plane. Downward pressure against resistance is applied. Pain or weakness indicates rotator cuff pathology.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the initial steps for treating a painful rotator cuff?	Rest the shoulder until pain and swelling subside, use ice and NSAIDs, and avoid overhead activities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What physical therapy techniques are used for rotator cuff pathology?	Gentle stretching to preserve ROM and isometric strengthening exercises are initiated, progressing until strength and ROM are restored.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What imaging is recommended if conservative measures for rotator cuff pathology fail?	Diagnostic US and/or MRI of the shoulder should be ordered, depending on imaging availability and the type of injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What can be done if conservative measures and physical therapy fail to relieve rotator cuff pain?	A steroid injection into the subacromial space may relieve pain and improve motion, with US-guided injection being an option.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What does evolving medical practice suggest about US-guided injections for the shoulder?	Evolving practice includes the use of US guidance for shoulder injections to ensure accurate medication placement, especially after initial blind injections fail for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
When is surgery considered for rotator cuff pathology?	Surgery is considered if there is a failure of conservative treatment/steroid injections, prolonged symptoms, large tears, nocturnal pain, history of trauma, and limitations of ADLs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What procedures might be included in surgery for rotator cuff pathology?	Surgery may involve rotator cuff repair, acromioplasty (acromial shaving), and tendon debridement, with recovery taking 4 to 6 months to regain full strength.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
Which shoulder dislocation is more common and what are its complications?	Anterior shoulder dislocations are more common than posterior, with complications including axillary nerve injury, recurrent dislocations, and rotator cuff tears.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are Bankart and Hill-Sachs lesions?	A Bankart lesion is an avulsion of the anteroinferior glenoid labrum from the rim, primarily causing recurrent dislocations. A Hill-Sachs lesion is a compression fracture of the humeral head against the anterior glenoid rim.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What technique is used for the acute reduction of an anterior shoulder dislocation?	The modified Stimson technique, where the patient lies prone with a weight on the affected arm hanging over the table side, achieving reduction in 15 to 20 minutes as shoulder muscles relax.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What post-reduction treatment options are available for shoulder dislocations?	Options include bracing in external rotation, icing, and sling immobilization for 1 to 3 weeks. Passive abduction and external rotation are limited, and gentle pendular exercises are encouraged. Maintenance of elbow, wrist, and hand ROM is important.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is rehabilitation approached after initial treatment for shoulder dislocation?	Once the capsule has healed, shoulder ROM and strengthening are progressively increased, with ongoing debates about the optimal type and timing of surgery for shoulder instability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is Adhesive Capsulitis and who is commonly affected?	Adhesive Capsulitis is a syndrome characterized by a progressive painful loss of passive and active glenohumeral ROM, occurring more commonly in females and typically seen between the ages of 40 and 60.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What conditions are associated with Adhesive Capsulitis?	It can be the end result of conditions causing prolonged immobility such as bursitis and rotator cuff tendinitis, and is also linked with DM, thyroid dysfunction, and autoimmune diseases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the treatment options for Adhesive Capsulitis?	Treatment includes aggressive ROM, NSAIDs, heat modalities, intra-articular steroid injections (well studied, improve short-term outcomes), brisement, manipulation under anesthesia, and suprascapular nerve blocks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the effectiveness of intra-articular steroid injections in treating Adhesive Capsulitis?	Intra-articular steroid injections are well studied and appear to improve short-term outcomes for Adhesive Capsulitis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the expected recovery period for Adhesive Capsulitis?	Recovery from Adhesive Capsulitis may take several months to beyond a year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What causes Bicipital Tendinitis and what other conditions may coexist with it?	Bicipital Tendinitis, often associated with overhead activities or sports, frequently coexists with shoulder impingement syndrome, rotator cuff tears, or labral pathology like SLAP (Superior Labral tear from Anterior to Posterior) lesions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is the stability of the bicipital tendon assessed?	By palpating the bicipital groove and rotating the shoulder internally and externally. Instability may show as subluxation of the tendon medially over the lesser tuberosity with a possible clunk or snap.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is Speed’s test and what does it indicate?	Speed’s test involves elevating the arm to 90° with an extended elbow and palm upward, then resisting forward arm flexion. Pain in the bicipital groove indicates a positive test.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the treatments for Bicipital Tendinitis?	Treatments include NSAIDs, activity modification, a progressive exercise program with modalities like heat and post-activity icing, and possibly local corticosteroid injections guided by ultrasound for accuracy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What causes Scapular Winging and how is it elicited?	Medial winging is caused by serratus anterior weakness (long thoracic nerve) and is tested by having the patient push against a wall. Lateral winging, caused by trapezius muscle weakness (CN XI), is elicited by shoulder abduction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the treatment options for Scapular Winging?	Most cases resolve with a rehabilitation and strengthening program, although traumatic and refractory cases may require surgical correction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
"What is Golfer&#x27;s Elbow and its initial treatment?"	"Golfer&#x27;s Elbow is an overuse syndrome affecting the tendinous origin of the flexor–pronator mass and the medial collateral ligament (MCL) of the elbow. Initial treatment includes rest, ice, compression, elevation (RICE), and NSAIDs."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
"What exercises are important after the initial treatment for Golfer&#x27;s Elbow?"	Once pain and inflammation subside, strengthening exercises for the wrist flexors/extensors, wrist radial deviators, forearm pronators/supinators, and elbow flexors/extensors are started.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
"How can a tennis elbow counterforce strap be used in Golfer&#x27;s Elbow treatment?"	"A tennis elbow counterforce strap may be helpful in managing Golfer&#x27;s Elbow."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
"What care should be taken when considering steroid injections for Golfer&#x27;s Elbow?"	Injection of local steroids into the area of maximum tenderness can be considered, taking care not to injure the ulnar nerve.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is Tennis Elbow and what causes the pain according to studies?	Tennis Elbow is an extensor tendinopathy affecting the extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB), with problems often arising from the common extensor tendon shared by the ECRB and extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
"How is Cozen&#x27;s Test performed for Tennis Elbow and what does it indicate?"	Cozen’s Test involves stabilizing the patient’s elbow, palpating the lateral epicondyle, then the patient pronates the forearm, radially deviates, and extends the wrist against resistance. A positive test reproduces pain near the lateral epicondyle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What initial treatments are recommended for Tennis Elbow?	Initial treatments include relative rest, NSAIDs, and heat or cold modalities. Wrist extensor stretching and strengthening should be initiated when tolerated. Conservative measures are usually effective, but recurrences are common.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What can be used to support the elbow in cases of Tennis Elbow?	A tennis elbow strap worn circumferentially around the forearm just distal to the elbow and a wrist splint may help rest the common wrist extensor tendons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How can tennis equipment be modified to reduce Tennis Elbow symptoms?	Modifications to the racquet include using a larger grip and head and reducing string tension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What advanced treatments are available if conservative measures for Tennis Elbow fail?	Treatments such as platelet-rich plasma (PRP) or autologous whole blood injections may be more effective than corticosteroids injections for those who have failed conservative treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the guidelines for injections in treating Tennis Elbow? (Include max dosage)	No more than three steroid injections should be given, with intervals of 5 days to 1 week.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What surgical options are considered if conservative treatments for Tennis Elbow fail?	Surgical options may include fasciotomy or fixing the conjoined tendon if non-surgical measures fail.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is De Quervain’s Disease and which tendons are affected?	De Quervain’s Disease is a tenosynovitis of the first dorsal compartment of the hand, affecting the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is Finkelstein’s test and what does a positive result indicate?	Finkelstein’s test is positive when pain is elicited in the radial wrist while the wrist is forced into ulnar deviation with the thumb enclosed in a fist, indicating De Quervain’s Disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the initial treatments for De Quervain’s Disease?	Treatment includes activity modification, NSAIDs, and a program of stretching and strengthening.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is a thumb spica splint used in treating De Quervain’s Disease?	A thumb spica splint holds the wrist in neutral and the first MCP immobilized, while the IP joint is free, helping to rest the tendons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the benefits of local corticosteroid injections for De Quervain’s Disease?	Local corticosteroid injections into the compartment reduce acute pain and inflammation. US-guided injections can improve accuracy and decrease the risk of intratendinous injections.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
When is surgical decompression considered for De Quervain’s Disease?	Surgical decompression may be considered curative in severe, refractory cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What commonly causes a Scaphoid Fracture and what is the first sign?	A Scaphoid Fracture is often caused by a fall on an outstretched hand, with initial signs including snuffbox tenderness.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What should be done if initial plain films of a suspected Scaphoid Fracture are negative?	The wrist should be immobilized and films repeated in approximately 2 weeks, as some fractures may not initially be visible.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What imaging can be considered if repeat films of a Scaphoid Fracture are still negative?	If clinical suspicion persists, CT or MRI can be considered.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
Why is there a high incidence of nonunion and avascular necrosis (AVN) in Scaphoid Fractures?	The main blood supply enters from the distal pole, leading to high incidences of nonunion and avascular necrosis, especially in waist and proximal pole fractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What treatments are recommended for nondisplaced Scaphoid Fractures?	A long arm thumb spica cast should be used, with isometric muscle contractions performed to counter atrophy.
