RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
When should Scaphoid Fractures be referred for surgical evaluation?	Displaced fractures or nondisplaced fractures with persistent nonunion should be referred for surgical evaluation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the symptoms and risk factors of Trigger Finger ((Digital Stenosing Tenosynovitis) and who are particularly at risk?	Trigger Finger (Digital Stenosing Tenosynovitis) involves a tendinous knot that gets stuck in the finger pulley system during extension, often seen in patients with diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the treatments for Trigger Finger?	Treatments include NSAIDs, steroid injections to reduce inflammation and pain, and a volar static hand splint that immobilizes the MCP but allows full IP flexion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
When is surgery considered necessary for Trigger Finger?	Surgery may be necessary to release tendons in fingers that are locked in flexion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome and what are its causes?	Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome was classically described as trochanteric bursitis, but MRI and arthroscopy have shown it can also be due to gluteus medius or minimus tendinosis or tears, and snapping hip syndrome.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are common symptoms and signs of Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome?	Symptoms include pain during walking, running, climbing stairs, sitting, and lying on the involved side. Examination may reveal point tenderness over the greater trochanter, pain-limited hip abductor strength, and lateral hip pain with the FABER (Flexion ABduction External Rotation) test.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the initial conservative treatments for Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome?	Treatments include NSAIDs, an ITB stretching program, and hip abductor/extensor strengthening exercises.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What advanced treatments are available if conservative measures for Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome fail?	Steroid injections into the bursas as identified on imaging can relieve symptoms, with musculoskeletal US aiding in both diagnosis and therapy, especially for accurately targeting certain bursas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the causes and symptoms of ITB Syndrome?	ITB Syndrome may be caused by overtraining or running on uneven surfaces, manifesting as lateral knee pain when the ITB slides over the lateral femoral condyle during 20° to 30° of knee flexion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are predisposing factors and diagnostic tests for ITB Syndrome?	Factors include genu varum, tibial varum, varus hindfoot, and foot pronation. Ober’s test, which checks for ITB or TFL tightness, may be positive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the treatment options for ITB Syndrome?	Treatment should focus on stretching the ITB, hip flexors, and gluteus maximus, strengthening the adductors and hip abductors, and using modalities like ice, US, and phonophoresis. Correcting foot pronation and avoiding uneven surfaces are recommended.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is Sacroiliac Joint Pain characterized and where can it be referred?	SIJ pain is a common but often underestimated source of chronic low back pain, typically localized to the buttocks but can also refer to the lumbar region, groin, abdomen, lower limb, or foot.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What challenges are associated with diagnosing Sacroiliac Joint Pain?	Due to its varied symptoms, no single examination or historical feature can reliably pinpoint SIJ or iliolumbar pain, often requiring multiple provocative exams or diagnostic nerve blocks for confirmation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are common diagnostic tests and treatment approaches for Sacroiliac Joint Pain?	Patrick’s test (FABER test) is commonly used to elicit SIJ pain. Treatment may start conservatively with PT and NSAIDs, with referral for diagnostic or therapeutic interventions considered after conservative management fails or for refractory pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is Pes Anserine Bursitis and what mnemonic is associated with it?	Pes Anserine Bursitis involves inflammation under the Sartorius, Gracilis, and SemiTendinosis tendons. The mnemonic &quot;Say Grace Before Tea&quot; helps remember these tendons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the symptoms of Pes Anserine Bursitis?	Symptoms include pain and tenderness at the insertion of the medial hamstrings at the medial proximal tibia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What treatments are recommended for Pes Anserine Bursitis?	Treatment should emphasize stretching the medial hamstrings, improving knee biomechanics, and athletes may wear protective knee padding.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What should be considered when using steroid injections for Pes Anserine Bursitis?	Steroid injections can be very effective, but US guidance is recommended as unguided injections rarely infiltrate the pes anserine bursa properly.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
Where does the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) attach and what is its function?	The ACL attaches superiorly and posteriorly from its anterior medial tibial attachment to the medial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle, preventing excessive anterior translation of the tibia, abnormal ER of the tibia on the femur, and knee hyperextension. It maintains joint stability during deceleration in athletes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the most common mechanism of ACL injury?	The most common mechanism is ER of the femur on a fixed tibia with a valgus load, often due to excessive pivoting or cutting, hyperextension, hyperflexion, or lateral trauma to the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are common symptoms and accompanying injuries of an ACL tear?	A “pop” is often heard or felt at the time of injury, followed by immediate swelling due to hemarthrosis and a sense of instability. The MCL and medial meniscus are also commonly injured, known as the terrible triad or O’Donoghue’s triad.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is the Lachman test performed and what does it assess?	The Lachman test, performed at 20° to 30° of knee flexion, assesses the posterolateral fibers of the ACL. Some laxity may be normal; comparison with the contralateral leg is recommended. It has higher sensitivity than the anterior drawer test (99% vs. 54%).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the pivot shift (Macintosh) test and what does it indicate?	Performed in the lateral decubitus position with the affected knee extended and the tibia internally rotated, valgus stress is applied as the knee is flexed. A “clunk” felt at 30° of knee flexion indicates an ACL injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is an ACL injury confirmed?	An MRI confirms the diagnosis of an ACL injury and may identify other concomitant injuries.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What should nonoperative rehabilitation of an ACL injury focus on?	Nonoperative rehabilitation should concentrate on proprioceptive training and strengthening of the hamstrings to prevent anterior subluxation of the tibia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What types of support and modifications are recommended in nonoperative ACL rehabilitation?	Bracing should limit terminal extension and rotation, and activity modification, such as avoiding cutting and pivoting sports, is crucial to prevent further injury to intra-articular structures like the menisci.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is the need for operative treatment for an ACL injury determined?	The decision for operative treatment depends on the amount of damage, degree of laxity, and is also patient-specific, with younger, more active patients more likely to require surgery compared to older, sedentary ones.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What does post-operative rehabilitation for an ACL injury typically involve?	Post-op rehab can last 6 to 9 months and typically includes weight bearing as tolerated (WBAT) with an extension brace immediately after surgery. The focus remains on strengthening the hamstrings and proprioceptive training.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the rehabilitation goals within the first 6 weeks post-ACL surgery?	The goals are to regain range of motion, possibly assisted by continuous passive motion (CPM) machines, and to enhance patellar mobility.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What should be the focus of ACL rehab between weeks 6 and 10 post-surgery?	The focus should be on progressively increasing intensity and resistance between weeks 6 and 10, with the aim of having essentially no limitation in strengthening by week 10.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
Why is the prevention of ACL injuries considered crucial, particularly among young female athletes?	Prevention is vital because young female athletes, especially in sports like soccer and basketball, are at a higher risk of ACL injuries. Proprioceptive and neuromuscular control training programs can significantly reduce this risk and are recommended for high-risk athletes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the origin and attachment of the PCL, and what does it prevent?	The PCL arises from the posterior intercondylar tibia and extends to attach to the medial femoral condyle, preventing abnormal IR and posterior translation of the tibia, which aids knee flexion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are common causes of PCL injury?	PCL injury typically occurs from a motor vehicle accident when the tibia strikes the dashboard or from high valgus stress or falling on a flexed knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are common findings and tests used to assess PCL integrity?	Common findings include tenderness in the popliteal region. The integrity of the PCL can be tested by the posterior drawer test and the sag test, assessing for posterior displacement of the tibial tuberosity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What additional test can be performed to assess for concomitant injuries with PCL damage?	A varus stress can be applied to an extended knee to assess for concomitant injuries to the PCL and posterolateral corner of the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the preferred imaging for PCL injuries and how are they treated?	MRI is preferred, though less sensitive for PCL than ACL pathology; arthroscopy is more accurate. Mild PCL sprains may only require quadriceps strengthening, while severe injuries might need arthroscopic repair.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the menisci and their function in the knee?	The menisci are fibrocartilaginous structures that increase contact area between the femur and tibia and act as shock absorbers for the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What causes meniscal injuries and what are common symptoms?	Injuries typically result from excessive rotational stresses, such as twisting a flexed knee. Symptoms include knee locking, popping, clicking, joint line tenderness, and loss of full knee flexion or extension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How is a meniscal tear diagnosed? Name 3 tests	McMurray’s test, Apley’s grind test, and the Thessaly test are used for diagnosis. MRI confirms the diagnosis, and arthroscopy is the gold standard for identifying tears.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What treatments are available for meniscal injuries?	Non-surgical treatment includes RICE, NSAIDs, hamstring and ITB stretching, and progressive resistive exercises. Surgical options focus on preserving cartilage, with total meniscectomy no longer considered acceptable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are postoperative care and restrictions following meniscal surgery?	Following partial meniscectomy, patients can bear weight as tolerated once pain-free. After meniscal repair, full weight bearing may be delayed for up to 6 weeks. Post-op therapy focuses on ROM exercises, stretching, and strengthening, with deep squatting discouraged.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the postulated etiology of Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome?	The etiology is thought to be a combination of overuse, muscular imbalance (e.g., hip abductor and external rotator weakness), and biomechanical problems (e.g., pes planus or pes cavus, increased Q angle).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What symptoms are associated with Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome?	Anterior knee pain that occurs with activity and worsens with prolonged sitting or descending stairs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the acute management strategies for Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome?	Acute management includes relative rest, ice, and NSAIDs, and avoiding prolonged sitting.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the mainstay of rehabilitation for Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome?	Rehabilitation focuses on addressing biomechanical deficits through quadriceps strengthening, and stretching the quadriceps, hamstrings, ITB, and gastroc-soleus complex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What exercises were classically used for Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome and what is their current status?	Classically, short arc terminal knee extension (0°–30°) exercises were utilized to strengthen the vastus medialis oblique (VMO), but the idea of VMO selectivity is now controversial. Currently, short arc (0°–45°) closed kinetic chain leg press exercises are recommended to strengthen all quad heads.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What types of exercises should be avoided in Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome rehabilitation?	Full arc and open kinetic chain exercises should be avoided to reduce symptom aggravation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How can taping and orthotics aid in managing Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome?	Taping the patella using the McConnell technique may improve pain during exercise. Orthotics can correct foot issues like pes planus or pronation, and soft braces with patellar cutouts may offer symptomatic relief.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What modalities are occasionally useful and generally not recommended in Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome rehabilitation?	Electrical stimulation and biofeedback can be useful occasionally, while prolonged physical therapy with modalities such as ultrasound is generally not helpful or cost-effective.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
When is surgery considered for Patellofemeral Pain Syndrome?	Surgery is rarely necessary and is reserved for cases of recalcitant instability or symptomatic malalignment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What does &quot;shin splint&quot; refer to and what are its risk factors?	Shin splint refers to exercise-induced tibial pain without evidence of fracture on x-ray, often representing periostitis of the posteromedial tibial border. Risk factors include increased exercise intensity, inadequate footwear, hard surface training, or poor biomechanics.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the symptoms and treatment of shin splints?	Symptoms include local pain and tenderness along the distal third of the tibia, often relieved by rest and not aggravated by passive stretch. Treatment includes rest, NSAIDs, ultrasound, preactivity icing, and correction of aggravating factors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What causes tibial stress fractures and how do they present?	Causes are similar to those of shin splints. Pain is initially exercise-induced, progressing to pain with weight-bearing or even at rest. Point tenderness is noted along the distal or middle third of the tibia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How are tibial stress fractures (TSF) diagnosed and treated?	X-rays may initially be negative but can show a fracture after several weeks. Bone scans are more sensitive. Treatment includes relative rest, NSAIDs, TENS, and possibly a bone graft for recalcitrant cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is chronic compartment syndrome of the leg, and what are its symptoms?	It occurs after a specific period of exercise and can cause pain, paresthesias, numbness, and weakness. Diagnosis is supported by elevated compartment pressures after exercise. Resting pressures &gt;30 mmHg, 15-second postexercise pressures &gt;60 mmHg, or 2-minute postexercise pressures &gt;20mm Hg are all suggestive of chronic com- partment syndrome. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What initial treatments are recommended for chronic compartment syndrome?	Initial conservative treatments include NSAIDs, proper footwear, and correction of training errors. If symptoms persist, surgical fasciotomy may be necessary.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are contributing factors and symptoms of Achilles tendinitis?	Contributing factors include overuse, overpronation, heel varus deformity, and poor flexibility. Symptoms include pain, swelling in the tendon, pain on palpation, a palpable nodule, and inability to stand on tiptoe.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the recommended treatment approach for Achilles tendinitis?	Treatments start with the PRICE (Protection Rest Ice Compression Elevation) principle and may include modalities like ultrasound and plantar flexor strengthening. Downhill exercises are emphasized, while uphill running is discouraged.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the guidelines regarding heel lifts and steroid injections for Achilles tendinitis?	Heel lifts can provide early relief but may cause heel cord shortening if used long-term. Steroid injections are generally not recommended due to the risk of tendon rupture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are treatment considerations for severe or chronic Achilles tendinitis?	For severe or chronic cases, recovery can take up to 24 months. Novel treatments like PRP are being studied. Surgical intervention may be considered for young, active individuals, while casting is an option for older, sedentary persons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What usually causes lateral ankle sprains and which ligaments are involved?	Lateral ankle sprains are usually due to inversion of a plantar flexed foot, typically involving the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) first, followed by the calcaneofibular ligament (CFL), and then the posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What tests are used to assess ligament stability in ankle sprains?	The anterior drawer test assesses primarily the ATFL (displacement ≥5 mm is considered positive), and the talar tilt test checks the CFL by providing an inversion stress on the talus (&gt;10° difference in inversion compared to the unaffected side is positive).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
When are X-rays necessary for ankle sprains?	X-rays are necessary to check the tibiofibular syndesmosis in severe sprains, which may require surgical consultation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What injuries occur with medial ankle ligament sprains and what should be ruled out?	Injuries to the medial (deltoid) ankle ligament are less common and often due to an eversion injury. A proximal fibula fracture (Maisonneuve fracture) should be ruled out.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the three phases of rehabilitation for ankle sprains?	Phase I (1-3 days): RICE principle, avoid treatments that increase swelling. Phase II (days to weeks): Restore ROM, strengthen ankle stabilizers, and Achilles tendon. Phase II (weeks +)I: Reestablish motor coordination and endurance training.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What should be avoided in the initial 24 hours of treating an ankle sprain?	Avoid hot showers, alcohol, methyl salicylate counterirritants (e.g., Bengay), and other treatments that may increase swelling.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What activities are emphasized in Phase III of ankle sprain rehabilitation?	Proprioceptive exercises and endurance training, such as using a balance board, running curves (figure-of-8), and zigzag running are emphasized.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the return to play guidelines for ankle sprains?	Grade I (no laxity and minimal ligamentous tear): 0 to 5 days, Grade II (mild to moderate laxity and functional loss): 7 to 14 days, Grade III (complete ligamentous disruption and cannot bear weight): 21 to 35 days, and syndesmosis injury: 21 to 56 days																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What has recent literature demonstrated about ankle sprain rehabilitation?	Recent literature suggests that an early and accelerated rehabilitation program results in better short-term outcomes for grades I and II lateral ankle sprains.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
Who commonly experiences plantar fasciitis and what causes it?	Plantar fasciitis is commonly seen in athletes and in persons whose jobs require much standing or walking. It is caused by repetitive microtrauma to the plantar fascia, leading to inflammation and pain in the acute phase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is plantar fasciopathy and what biomechanical issue is often at fault?	In chronic conditions, the fascia is less commonly inflamed and becomes degenerative, termed plantar fasciopathy. Biomechanical issues, such as an overpronated foot increasing tension on the fascia, are often at fault.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the classic symptoms of plantar fasciitis?	The classic symptoms include medial heel pain and pain across the entire area of the plantar fascia, especially noted with the first few steps in the morning or at the beginning of an activity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the key component of treatment for plantar fasciitis?	The key component of treatment is a home exercise program that includes routine, daily stretching of the plantar fascia and Achilles tendon, which has proven superior to other treatment modalities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What activities and footwear are recommended for someone with plantar fasciitis?	Patients should be on relative rest from walking, running, and jumping, and consider activities like swimming or cycling. Proper footwear includes well-cushioned soles, possibly an extra-deep heel pad/cup insert, and avoiding high heels.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What types of foot supports are recommended for plantar fasciitis?	Soft medial arch supports are generally preferable to rigid orthotics, which can exacerbate symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
How can inflammation be managed in plantar fasciitis?	NSAIDs and ice may help decrease inflammation. For resistant cases, splints that provide a gentle constant stretch at night may be useful.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What should patients do once plantar fasciitis pain resolves?	Once the pain resolves, patients should gradually return to increased levels of activity while continuing their stretching program.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What is the expected improvement timeline with conservative measures for plantar fasciitis?	The majority of cases will improve with conservative measures within 6 to 12 weeks, if faithfully followed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the options for persistent cases of plantar fasciitis?	In rare, persistent cases, a local corticosteroid injection may be considered. Surgical intervention, involving a release of the involved fascia, is a last resort but necessary only in very rare cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Treatment_Selected_MSK_Conditions
What are the most important initial components of the history and physical examination in sports medicine?	Questions about personal and family history of cardiovascular disease are crucial, along with a thorough history of neurologic or musculoskeletal problems.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What should be emphasized during the physical examination for young athletes and why?	Cardiac auscultation with provocative maneuvers should be emphasized to screen for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a common cause of sudden death in young male athletes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What is the current stance on using ECG in the Pre-Participation Examination (PPE) screen?	The use of ECG in the PPE screen remains controversial, with opinions varying on its necessity for young, asymptomatic individuals without significant history or symptoms. For most young, asymptomatic persons, screening tests such as ECG, treadmill stress test- ing, and lab tests are not indicated in the absence of symptoms or a sig- nificant history of risk factors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What are the recommendations for exercise stress testing in older asymptomatic persons?	The American College of Sports Medicine recommends exercise stress testing for men ≥45 years and women ≥55 years without cardiopulmonary risk factors or known metabolic disease before starting a vigorous exercise program.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
Can most older persons begin a moderate aerobic and resistance training program without stress testing?	Yes, most older persons can begin a moderate aerobic and resistance training program without stress testing, provided they slowly and gradually increase their level of activity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What are some contraindications to sports participation?	Conditions include active myocarditis or pericarditis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, uncontrolled severe hypertension, suspected coronary artery disease (CAD), long QT interval syndrome, recent concussion, poorly controlled convulsive disorder, cervical spine instability, sickle cell disease, unresolved splenomegaly in mononucleosis, and non-compliance in eating disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What types of sports are contraindicated for individuals with poorly controlled convulsive disorders?	Sports such as archery, riflery, swimming, weight lifting, strength training, or sports involving heights are contraindicated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What specific guidance is given for individuals with sickle cell disease regarding sports participation?	Individuals with sickle cell disease should avoid high exertion, contact, or collision sports.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What should be ensured before allowing participation in sports for individuals with transient quadriplegia or cervical spine issues?	Stability of the cervical spine must be assured before allowing participation in any contact or collision sports.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What are the conditions for sports participation concerning individuals with eating disorders?	Athletes with eating disorders should not participate if they are not compliant with treatment or follow-up, or if there is evidence of diminished performance or potential injury due to the disorder.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What are the most important initial components of the history and physical examination in sports medicine?	Questions about personal and family history of cardiovascular disease are crucial, along with a thorough history of neurologic or musculoskeletal problems.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Sports_Exercise
What is the lifetime risk of hip fractures in industrialized countries for females and males?	The lifetime risk of hip fractures in industrialized countries is 18% for females and 6% for males.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What are the primary risk factors for hip fractures?	Osteoporosis and falls are the primary risk factors for hip fractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What are the mortality and morbidity rates following hip fractures?	20% of individuals are not alive by 1 year after a hip fracture and 33% by 2 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What percentage of hip fracture survivors end up in institutionalized care within a year?	Nearly one of three survivors ends up in institutionalized care within a year after the fracture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What is the recovery status of survivors regarding their preoperative activity status?	As many as two of three survivors never regain their preoperative activity status.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
When is surgery usually indicated for hip fractures?	Surgery is usually indicated for most hip fractures, unless medically contraindicated or in nonambulatory patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What type of surgical fixation is typical for stable, nondisplaced femoral neck fractures?	Screw fixations are typical for stable, nondisplaced femoral neck fractures. Ambulation with WBAT and an appro- priate assistive device may be started during the first few days post-op.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What is the treatment protocol for unstable, displaced femoral neck fractures?	Bipolar endoprostheses may be used for unstable, displaced fractures when satisfactory reduction cannot be achieved, especially in patients over 65 years old or those with preexisting articular pathology like osteoarthritis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What type of fixation is used for intertrochanteric fractures and what does it allow?	Sliding hip screw fixation is used for stable intertrochanteric fractures, allowing for early weight-bearing as tolerated (WBAT) and dynamic compression of the fracture during weight-bearing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What are common complications seen during rehabilitation after hip fracture?	Complications include atelectasis, pneumonia, anemia, fracture nonunion, avascular necrosis (AVN), surgical site infection, component loosening, leg length discrepancy, heterotopic ossification (HO), deep vein thrombosis, constipation, and skin breakdown.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_HipFracture
What are the indications for total hip arthroplasty (THA)?	Indications include unstable hip fractures, osteoarthritis (OA), osteonecrosis, inflammatory arthritis, post-traumatic arthritis, malignancy, hemoglobinopathies, and hip dysplasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What are the commonly used surgical approaches for THA?	The most commonly used surgical approaches are the anterolateral and the posterior approaches.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
How is the anterolateral approach for THA performed?	The anterolateral approach utilizes the plane between the tensor fascia latae and gluteus medius, often requiring neutralization of the abductor mechanism via trochanteric ostomy or partial detachment of the anterior gluteus minimus and medius.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
How is the posterior approach for THA performed?	The posterior approach involves splitting the gluteus maximus and staying posterior to the gluteus medius and minimus, dividing the hip capsule, and detaching external rotators such as the piriformis and gemelli.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What are the benefits and requirements of biologically fixed or “cementless” implants in THA?	They provide a more durable bioprosthetic interface but require a longer period of protective weight-bearing (touchdown to partial weight-bearing for ≥2 to 3 months) for osseous integration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What are the characteristics of cement-fixed implants in THA?	Cement-fixed implants are cheaper, may offer immediate weight-bearing as tolerated, but the cement can deteriorate, leading to component loosening and potential need for revision.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What are the post-operative precautions for a posterior THA?	Patients may be out of bed to chair with assistance on post-op day 1, use a triangular hip abduction pillow for 6 to 12 weeks, and follow hip precautions to minimize dislocation risk for up to 12 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What are the movement restrictions after a posterior THA?	Patients are allowed flexion up to 90°, passive abduction, and gentle internal rotation; active abduction, hyperextension, and external rotation are allowed; adduction past midline and internal rotation while flexed are prohibited.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What are some key post-operative considerations for THA patients?	Considerations include DVT prophylaxis, monitoring for anemia and infection, pain control, and managing patient concerns about leg length discrepancies through physical therapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What factors can adversely affect outcomes after THA?	Being younger, male, obese, and highly active may adversely affect outcomes following THA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What are the indications for total knee arthroplasty (TKA)?	The indications for TKA include osteoarthritis (OA) and inflammatory arthritis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What are the differences between cemented and cementless fixation in TKA?	Cemented fixation may allow immediate weight-bearing as tolerated (WBAT), whereas cementless fixation may require several months of restricted weight-bearing for complete stability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What is a key factor in eventual prosthetic failure in TKA?	Polyethylene liner wear is a key factor in eventual prosthetic failure, as microscopic wear debris can trigger an inflammatory response leading to osteolysis and component loosening.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What is an important rehabilitation goal for TKA patients?	Regaining knee range of motion (ROM), specifically 0°–90° before discharge, is an important rehabilitation goal for TKA patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What is controversial in the rehabilitation after TKA?	The use of Continuous Passive Motion (CPM) machines is controversial; some believe it may decrease the length of inpatient stay and improve ROM at 1 year post-op, but most studies do not show long-term benefits in ROM or functional outcomes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What is regenerative medicine and its role in orthopedics and sports medicine?	Regenerative medicine is a rapidly growing field within musculoskeletal and sports medicine, focusing on treatments like prolotherapy, PRP (platelet-rich plasma), and stem cells to facilitate and stimulate healing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What is prolotherapy and its common indications?	Prolotherapy involves injecting an irritant solution, typically hyperosmolar dextrose, to treat chronic painful musculoskeletal conditions like low back pain, tendinopathies, and osteoarthritis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What is PRP and what does it contain that aids healing?	PRP (Platelet-Rich Plasma) involves injecting concentrated platelets from autologous blood, containing growth factors important for cell proliferation, differentiation, and neovascularization.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
How might PRP enhance the healing process?	PRP contains cell adhesion molecules and chemotactic properties that aid in the recruitment of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) and fibroblasts, thus potentially enhancing healing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What is the source and potential of MSCs in regenerative medicine?	MSCs (Mesenchymal Stem Cells) are pluripotent and can differentiate into various adult cell types like bone, cartilage, and fat. They are commonly harvested from the bone marrow of the iliac crest, which yields a significant number of bone-forming MSCs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
What conditions are being treated with MSCs and what is the current status of their efficacy?	Treatments using MSCs include conditions like osteoarthritis, rotator cuff tears, and meniscal tears, with their efficacy still under investigation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho::Rehabilitation_After_Joint_Replacement
p93-96																					RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho
p112-113																					RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::MSK_Sports_Ortho
What is the frequency range of ultrasound (US) and its application in medicine?	Ultrasound (US) operates above the human audible limit of 20 kilohertz (KHz) and is used extensively for imaging in musculoskeletal (MSK) and peripheral nervous system disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Introduction
What are the advantages of using US in musculoskeletal imaging?	Advantages of US include point-of-service availability, lower costs, increased safety versus other imaging modalities, and the ability to view targeted anatomy and neighboring structures in real time, including vascular flow and internal organ movement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Introduction
Are there any contraindications for using US in musculoskeletal imaging?	There are no true contraindications for using ultrasound in musculoskeletal imaging.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Introduction
What are some limitations of using MSK ultrasound?	Limitations include an inability to evaluate bone or structures within bony encasements due to acoustic impedance, challenges in imaging patients with large body habitus, and the quality of the study being highly operator dependent.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Introduction
What are the safety considerations associated with ultrasound?	Ultrasound has an excellent safety record as it does not utilize radiation. However, improper use can raise tissue temperatures and produce cavitation in body fluids. The long-term effects of these phenomena are still unknown.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Introduction
What safety principles does the FDA recommend for ultrasound usage?	The FDA recommends following the As Low As Reasonably Achievable (ALARA) principles to minimize potential risks when utilizing ultrasound.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Introduction
What frequency range do US machines typically operate in, and what type of images do they produce?	Ultrasound machines transmit and receive ultrasonic waves typically between 2 to 15 megahertz (MHz) to produce two-dimensional (2D) images.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Machine_Basics
How does the ultrasound machine produce images?	The CPU sends an electrical current to the transducer probe, which vibrates piezoelectric crystals to produce acoustic waves. These waves travel through a water-based gel on the skin into tissues, are reflected back, and converted into an image by the CPU.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Machine_Basics
What is B mode on an ultrasound machine?	B mode, or brightness mode, is a black-and-white 2D image mode typically used for musculoskeletal ultrasound.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Machine_Basics
How do transducer frequencies affect ultrasound imaging?	Higher transducer frequencies increase resolution and are better for superficial structures, while lower frequencies penetrate deeper but with less resolution.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Machine_Basics
What are the basic types of transducer probes used in MSK medicine and their frequency ranges?	Curvilinear probes average 4 to 9 MHz, linear probes average 5 to 12 MHz, and compact linear probes average 7 to 15 MHz.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Machine_Basics
What factors affect the quality of an ultrasound image?	Acoustic impedance (the amount of resistance a sound wave encounters as it passes through tissue), scattering (when the energy originally transmitted hits a surface and the waves are retransmitted in different directions), refraction (when a sound wave deviates from its original direction due to acoustic impedance), and attenuation (conversion of sound to heat, which is not reflected back to the transducer) affect the quality by altering how the sound wave signal returns to the transducer.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Machine_Basics
What is acoustic impedance and how does it affect ultrasound imaging?	Acoustic impedance is the resistance a sound wave encounters as it passes through tissue; higher impedance between tissues results in more energy reflected back, creating a brighter image.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Machine_Basics
How do the Gain, Depth, Frequency, and Focus knobs affect ultrasound imaging?	Gain controls image brightness, Depth adjusts the field of view depth, Frequency alters the probe frequency for depth and resolution balance, and Focus can target the US wave to a specific area of interest.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Machine_Basics
What is the longitudinal axis in MSK US?	The longitudinal axis, also known as the long axis, is a sagittal view in MSK US.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What is the transverse axis in MSK US?	The transverse axis, also known as the short axis, is a cross-sectional view in MSK US.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What does in-plane needle guidance mean in MSK US?	In-plane needle guidance refers to the needle entering the skin in long axis to the probe, traversing the plane of the transducer, allowing visualization of the entire needle shaft and tip within the tissue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What does out-of-plane needle guidance mean in MSK US?	Out-of-plane needle guidance means the needle is perpendicular to the transducer, appearing as a bright dot within the tissue, providing a cross-sectional view of the needle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What does echogenicity refer to in MSK US?	Echogenicity refers to a structure’s ability to produce echoes, or reflections of the acoustic waves transmitted by the transducer.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
How are anechoic structures displayed in MSK US?	Anechoic structures produce no echoes and appear black on ultrasound images.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
How are hypoechoic structures displayed in MSK US?	Hypoechoic structures produce weaker echoes and appear darker than other structures on ultrasound images.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
How are hyperechoic structures displayed in MSK US?	Hyperechoic structures produce stronger echoes and appear brighter than other structures on ultrasound images.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What is the difference between homogeneous and heterogeneous structures in MSK US?	Homogeneous structures have a uniform echo pattern, whereas heterogeneous structures show an uneven pattern of echoes of varying echodensities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What does isoechoic mean in MSK US?	Isoechoic describes a tissue that produces an echo of the same strength as another tissue, often the surrounding tissue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What are some common artifacts in MSK US and their implications?	Common artifacts include anisotropy, shadowing, enhancement, and reverberation, each affecting image interpretation by altering how sound waves reflect, absorb, or enhance across different tissues or interfaces.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What is anisotropy and how does it affect MSK US imaging?	Anisotropy is a property that causes reflection changes due to slight shifts in the direction of an acoustic wave, impacting the image greatly. It is considered an artifact. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What does shadowing describe in MSK US?	Shadowing occurs when ultrasound waves are partially or totally reflected or absorbed by an object, causing deep structures to appear hypoechoic or anechoic. It is considered an artifact. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What is enhancement in MSK US?	Enhancement is an increase in brightness of structures deep to other structures that transmit sound easily, often adjusted by image processing to compensate for natural attenuation at deeper levels. It is considered an artifact. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
What is reverberation in MSK US?	Reverberation occurs when ultrasound waves hit highly reflective surfaces parallel to each other, causing multiple echoes that are interpreted as deeper structures, seen with structures like a hollow bore needle parallel to the transducer.  It is considered an artifact. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::US_Nomenclature_CommonArtifacts
How does skin appear on ultrasound?	Skin presents as a thin, uniform hyperechoic layer.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
What are the ultrasound characteristics of fat?	Fat is hypoechoic with echogenic septa representing connective tissue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
How do blood vessels appear on ultrasound and how can veins and arteries be distinguished?	Blood vessels are anechoic with a tubular structure. Veins collapse with pressure from the transducer, while arteries do not collapse as easily.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
What are the ultrasound characteristics of synovium and hyaline cartilage?	Synovium is generally hypoechoic. Hyaline cartilage appears hypoechoic to anechoic over the hyperechoic bony cortex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
How do ligaments appear on ultrasound?	Ligaments are hyperechoic, homogeneous bands.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
What are the appearances of tendons in longitudinal and transverse views on ultrasound?	In longitudinal view, tendons have a dense, fibrillar hyperechoic appearance. In transverse view, tendons appear hypoechoic.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
What is anisotropy and how can it affect the ultrasound imaging of tendons?	Anisotropy is a property of tendons causing artifactually hypoechoic appearances due to angle of insonation, which may lead to inappropriate diagnosis of tendinosis or tendon tear.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
How do muscles appear on ultrasound in longitudinal and transverse views?	In longitudinal view, muscle appears as a hypoechoic, irregularly striated tissue with thin hyperechoic lines of fascia. In transverse view, it appears as a hypoechoic mass with hyperechoic speckles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
What is the appearance of nerves on ultrasound?	Nerves show a fascicular “railroad track” pattern in longitudinal view and a “honeycomb” appearance in transverse view, with hyperechoic epineurium and fascicles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
How does bone appear on ultrasound?	Bone appears as a bright echogenic line with acoustic shadowing, showing no visible structures deep to the bone.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Normal_Tissue_Types
What are the ultrasound characteristics of joint effusions in bone and joint disorders?	Joint effusions are anechoic and compressible, making ultrasound sensitive in their detection.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
What may heterogeneous-appearing fluid in a joint indicate, and what might be required?	Heterogeneous-appearing fluid may indicate an infection, for which aspiration may be indicated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
How does synovitis appear on ultrasound?	Synovitis appears as noncompressible, echogenic tissue within a joint.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
What bone and joint abnormalities can be detected by ultrasound?	Erosions and gouty tophi can be seen on ultrasound.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
How do inflamed bursae appear on ultrasound?	Inflamed bursae may contain simple anechoic fluid or complex heterogeneous fluid.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
What are the ultrasound findings in nerve injury?	Affected nerves may show regional swelling, hypoechogenicity, and loss of the typical fascicular pattern.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
How does tendinosis appear on ultrasound?	Tendinosis appears as tendon enlargement with hypoechogenicity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
What are the ultrasound features of partial-thickness tendon tears?	Partial-thickness tears present with regions of anechogenicity and loss of the normal fibrillar pattern of tendons.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
How do high-grade, partial-thickness tendon tears appear on ultrasound?	High-grade, partial-thickness tearing manifests as tendon thinning.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
What does a full-thickness tendon tear look like on ultrasound?	Full-thickness tears manifest as gaps in the tendon.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
How does tenosynovitis appear on ultrasound?	Tenosynovitis may appear either as anechoic with displaceable fluid surrounding the tendon or as heterogeneous fluid with mixed echogenicity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
What are the ultrasound signs of low-grade and high-grade muscle injuries?	"Low-grade muscle strains exhibit subtle regions of hypoechogenicity with reduced echotexture, looking ""washed out,"" while high-grade injuries show evidence of fiber disruption and heterogeneous fluid."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Diagnostic_Applications
What is the common approach for accessing the Glenohumeral (GH) Joint with ultrasound?	The GH joint is best accessed from the posterior approach, with the patient seated or in the lateral decubitus position, hand resting on the opposite shoulder. The needle is introduced lateral to medial in the axial plane, targeting between the posterior aspect of the humeral head and posterior labrum.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Therapeutic_Applications
How is the Elbow Joint accessed for ultrasound-guided procedures?	The elbow is accessed by positioning the patient seated or supine with the elbow flexed, arm across the chest. The needle is introduced superiorly, passing the triceps tendon to enter the joint space through the posterior fat pad.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Therapeutic_Applications
What is the approach for accessing the Hip Joint using ultrasound?	For the hip joint, the patient is supine and accessed anterolaterally. The probe aligns along the long axis of the femoral neck, and the needle is introduced from an inferior approach, entering near the subcapital femur and lateral to the neurovascular bundle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Therapeutic_Applications
Describe the approach for accessing the Knee Joint with ultrasound.	For knee joints with effusions, access is typically with the patient supine, knee slightly flexed. The needle is directed into the bursa after moving the probe medially or laterally from the quadriceps tendon. Without effusions, the medial patellofemoral area is targeted, with the needle introduced inferiorly or superiorly to the probe after turning it 90° along the joint line.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Therapeutic_Applications
How is the Ankle Joint accessed using ultrasound?	With the patient lying supine, the anterior tibiotalar joint is visualized in the sagittal plane. After identifying the dorsalis pedis artery and extensor tendons to avoid them, the needle is introduced into the joint in the sagittal plane via an inferior approach.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound RehabReadyTags::Ultrasound::Therapeutic_Applications
What does the broadened scope of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) guidelines for cardiac rehabilitation (CR) include?	Exercise programs, education, risk factor modification for secondary prevention, and psychosocial counseling.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Introduction_Benefits
When is CR indicated?	After acute myocardial infarction (MI), coronary revascularization, cardiac transplantation, and in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) or chronic stable angina.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Introduction_Benefits
What improvements are associated with CR?	CR improves max oxygen consumption (VO2 max), peripheral O2 extraction, ST depression, exercise tolerance, subjective sense of well-being, and return-to-work rates.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Introduction_Benefits
What reductions are associated with CR?	CR lowers blood pressure (BP), resting heart rate (HR), and myocardial O2 demand.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Introduction_Benefits
How does CR affect glycemic control and lipoprotein levels?	CR improves glycemic control and causes favorable lipoprotein changes, reducing triglyceride (TG) and elevating high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Introduction_Benefits
What long-term effects does CR have on muscle fibers and capillaries?	Long-term CR increases the quantity of mitochondrial enzymes in &quot;slow twitch&quot; muscle fibers and leads to the development of new capillaries in muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Introduction_Benefits
What have angiographic studies shown about intensive physical exercise and a low-fat diet?	Reduced atherosclerotic lesions in stable angina patients over 1 year without lipid-lowering agents.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Introduction_Benefits
What percentage of Americans experience a second or potentially fatal coronary event each year?	More than 30% have a second or potentially fatal event.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Epidemiology
By how much can CR participation reduce mortality compared to nonparticipation?	Mortality reduction with CR participation is over 50% versus nonparticipation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Epidemiology
By what percentage can CR reduce the likelihood of hospital readmissions for all causes?	25%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Epidemiology
What percentage of eligible patients participate in a CR program?	Fewer than 20% 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Epidemiology
What is the utilization rate for eligible Medicare beneficiaries in CR programs?	12%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Epidemiology
Which groups are less likely to receive CR?	Women, the very elderly, minorities, and patients with multiple comorbidities are even less likely to receive CR.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Epidemiology
What factors may contribute to low participation in CR programs?	Geographic factors and a failure of physicians to refer appropriate candidates.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Epidemiology
When can the inpatient training phase (Phase I) of CR begin?	From days 2-4 of hospitalization																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
How long does the inpatient training phase (Phase I) of CR typically last?	It typically lasts 1 to 2 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
Which disciplines are typically involved in Phase I of CR?	Physical therapy, occupational therapy, social work, nutrition, and psychology.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
How is CR generally performed during Phase I?	CR is generally performed with telemetry during this phase.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What are the goals of Phase I of CR?	Goals include prevention of the sequelae of immobilization, education regarding risk factor modification, independent self-care activities, and household distance ambulation on level surfaces.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What type of testing is often done in uncomplicated patients prior to discharge during Phase I?	Protocol-limited submaximal stress testing																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What is the purpose of the submaximal stress testing done during Phase I of CR?	It serves as a guideline for outpatient ADLs and simple household activities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
When does the outpatient training phase (Phase II) of CR start?	2 to 4 weeks after discharge.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
How long does the outpatient training phase (Phase II) of CR typically last?	It typically lasts 8 to 12 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What are the goals of Phase II of CR?	Goals include increasing cardiac volume and gradually returning to normal activity levels.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
When is a functional exercise tolerance (stress) test typically done during Phase II?	6 to 8 weeks following the cardiac event.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What is the purpose of the stress test during Phase II of CR?	The stress test guides the exercise prescription and helps guide return to work and sexual activity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
Who supervises Phase II of CR? 	Trained therapists																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
Does Phase II of CR typically require telemetry monitoring?	No																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What is the maintenance phase (Phase III) of CR?	The maintenance phase is ideally a lifelong program of home- or gym-based exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What is the aim of Phase III of CR?	Maintaining or adding onto benefits obtained during phases I and II.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What are some absolute contraindications for functional stress testing?	Recent change in resting EKG, serious cardiac arrhythmias, unstable angina, acute or worsening left ventricular dysfunction, uncontrolled hypertension, systemic illness, severe aortic stenosis, or severe physical disability precluding treadmill or arm ergometry use.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What are some relative contraindications for functional stress testing?	Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, electrolyte abnormalities, moderate valvular disease, or significant arterial or pulmonary hypertension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
How are the contraindications for exercise stress testing related to CR?	The contraindications for exercise stress testing are similar to the contraindications for CR in general.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Phases_CR
What should the exercise prescription address?	The exercise prescription should address the type, intensity, content, duration, and frequency of exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What types of exercises should be emphasized in CR?	Isotonic, aerobic, and rhythmic exercises involving large muscle groups should be emphasized.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
In which patients are isometrics and resistive exercise contraindicated?	Patients with CHF, severe valvular disease, uncontrolled arrhythmias, or peak exercise capacity &lt;5 METs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is a MET (metabolic equivalent of task)?	A MET is a ratio of the energy expenditure of an activity relative to the resting metabolic rate (3.5 mL O2 uptake/kg/min or about 1 kcal/kg/hr).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is an example of a 5-MET activity?	A 5-MET activity uses 5 times the energy expended at rest.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
At what age is maximum MET capacity usually achieved?	Maximum MET capacity is usually achieved between the ages of 15 and 30 years and progressively decreases with age.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is the typical maximum MET capacity for healthy but nonathletic middle-aged men and young men?	Healthy but nonathletic middle-aged men: 10 METs, Young men: 12 METs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What can distance runners average in METs?	Distance runners can average 18 to 24 METs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
How many phases should the exercise content include?	The exercise content should include three phases: warm-up, conditioning or training, and low-intensity cooldown.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
How long should the warm-up phase last and what should it consist of?	The warm-up phase should last 5 to 10 minutes and consist of flexible movements and stretching that gradually increase HR to target range.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is the purpose of the subtle increase in oxygen demand during the warm-up phase?	The subtle increase in oxygen demand reduces the risk of exercise-related cardiovascular complications.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
How long should the conditioning or training phase last?	The conditioning or training phase should minimally last 20 minutes, up to the recommended 30 to 45 minutes of aerobic activity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
How long should the low-intensity cooldown phase last?	The low-intensity cooldown phase should last 5 to 10 minutes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What complications can occur if the cooldown phase is omitted?	Hypotension, angina, and ventricular arrhythmias due to decreased coronary blood flow secondary to reduced venous return, during a state when myocardial oxygen consumption remains elevated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
How can exercise intensity be determined?	"Exercise intensity can be determined by calculating a ""target"" HR using methods such as the AHA method (70% to 85% of the maximum attained by stress testing) or using 70% to 85% of (220 - age) for young, healthy adults not undergoing formal exercise stress testing."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is the Karvonen formula for calculating target HR?	The Karvonen formula is Target heart rate = ((HRmax - HRrest) × % desired intensity) + HRrest.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What should the desired intensity for CR be for more deconditioned patients?	For more deconditioned patients, the exercise program should begin at the lower end of the spectrum (40%-60%) and increase as fitness improves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
How can HRmax be estimated?	"HRmax can be estimated by subtracting the patient&#x27;s age from 220."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
