What is the usual desired intensity for CR?	Desired intensity for CR is between 40% and 85%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is Borg’s Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale particularly useful for?	Borg’s RPE Scale is particularly useful for cardiac transplant patients since denervation of the orthotopic heart makes HR parameters unreliable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
How is the traditional Borg RPE scale scored?	The traditional Borg RPE scale is scored from 6 to 20.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What does a score of 13 on the Borg RPE scale correspond to?	A score of 13 is rated as “somewhat hard” and corresponds with exercise intensity sufficient to provide training benefits but still allows conversation during exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What does a score of 12 to 13 on the Borg RPE scale correspond to?	A score of 12 to 13 corresponds to about 60% of max HR.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What does a score of 15 on the Borg RPE scale correspond to?	A score of 15 corresponds to 85% of max HR.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What does the Borg scale encourage?	The Borg scale encourages independence in exercise (i.e., phase III CR) as external monitoring devices are weaned off.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is recommended for patients on beta-blockers?	For patients on beta-blockers, training at 85% of symptom-limited HR or 70% to 90% of the maximum workload determined by exercise testing is recommended.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is the usual exercise duration and frequency in a CR program?	The usual exercise duration/frequency is 20 to 30 minutes three times a week for 12 weeks or more when training at 70% of the maximum HR.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What may be helpful for more severely deconditioned individuals?	Shorter durations of training on a daily basis may also be helpful for more severely deconditioned individuals.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is Class A according to the AHA risk stratification?	Class A individuals are apparently healthy and have no evidence of cardiovascular risk with exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is Class B according to the AHA risk stratification?	Class B individuals have established coronary heart disease that is clinically stable and have a low risk of cardiovascular complications with vigorous exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is Class C according to the AHA risk stratification?	Class C individuals are at moderate risk of complications during exercise due to history of multiple MIs or arrest, the New York Heart Association (NYHA) class III or IV CHF, &lt;6 METs exercise capacity, or significant ischemia on exercise test.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What is Class D according to the AHA risk stratification?	Class D individuals have unstable cardiac disease and require restriction of activity; exercise is contraindicated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
Which classes of individuals are typically referred to CR?	Patients referred to CR are typically in classes B or C.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Exercise_Prescription
What are the typical criteria for safe resumption of sexual activity after a cardiac event?	A stable, asymptomatic patient and tolerance of exercise at 5 to 7 METs without abnormal EKG, BP, or HR changes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Postcardiac_Event_Sexual_Counseling
How long is the time required for safe resumption of sexual activity after a cardiac event?	The time required is variable but is usually about 6 weeks after the event, for sex with established partners in familiar positions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Postcardiac_Event_Sexual_Counseling
What is a useful clinical test for determining safe resumption of sexual activity after a cardiac event?	A two-flight stair climbing test: walking for 10 minutes at 3 mi/hr (~3.3 METs), then climbing two flights of stairs without stopping.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Postcardiac_Event_Sexual_Counseling
What sexual activities are associated with sudden death in a cardiac patient?	Illicit affairs and sex after heavy meals and alcohol intake.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Postcardiac_Event_Sexual_Counseling
What are typical sternal precautions following sternotomy?	No pushing, pulling, or lifting objects heavier than 5 to 10 lb. for 6 to 8 weeks. A “side-rolling” maneuver for getting out of bed is typically taught, and manual wheelchair propulsion is usually prohibited during this time as well.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Miscellaneous
What should be done if any of the following cardiac symptoms develop in persons with CAD in nonacute inpatient settings: HR decreases &gt;20% of baseline; HR increases &gt;50% of baseline; SBP increases to 240 mmHg; SBP decreases ≥30 mmHg from baseline or to &lt;90 mmHg; or DBP increases to 120 mmHg?	Activity should be terminated																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Miscellaneous
What is emphasized in CR/exercise for the elderly?	Greater emphasis on warm-up activities (flexibility and ROM exercises, which help prepare the musculoskeletal and cardiovascular systems for exercise) and cooldown activities to gradually decrease the peripheral vasodilation that can lead to hypotension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Miscellaneous
Why are longer rest periods required in the elderly during CR/exercise?	Because of the slower return of exercise HR to resting HR.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Miscellaneous
What are the effects of aging on skin blood perfusion and heat dissipation during exercise?	Aging is associated with a decrease in skin blood perfusion, lowering the efficiency to sweat and regulate heat dissipation during exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Miscellaneous
What should be considered for the elderly in hot/humid environments during exercise?	A lower intensity exercise should be considered.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Miscellaneous
What is the NYHA classification for CHF and angina?	I: &gt;7 METs tolerated asymptomatically, without functional limitation. II: &lt;6 METs tolerated, but higher levels of activities cause symptoms. III: Asymptomatic at rest and with most ADLs; &gt;4 METs not tolerated. IV: Symptomatic at rest and with minimal physical activities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cardiac_Rehab::Miscellaneous
What is pulmonary rehabilitation (PR)?	Pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) is a multidisciplinary program that aims to alleviate symptoms, optimize function, and promote adaptation to chronic lung disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Introduction
In which condition has PR been shown to improve dyspnea, exercise capacity, and health-related quality of life?	In chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), PR has been shown to improve dyspnea, exercise capacity, and health-related quality of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Introduction
What does PR reduce in COPD patients?	PR reduces health care utilization in COPD patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Introduction
How can respiratory disorders generally be characterized when considering PR?	Respiratory disorders can be generally characterized as ventilatory restrictive disorders (CO2 retention) or obstructive disorders (oxygen impairment).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Introduction
What specific measurement helps distinguish between ventilatory and obstructive disorders?	Forced expiratory volume in one second/forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC) helps distinguish between ventilatory and obstructive disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Introduction
What are ventilatory disorders generally caused by?	Ventilatory disorders are generally caused by neuromuscular or skeletal disorders (e.g., myopathy, motor neuron disease, myelopathy, multiple sclerosis [MS], and chest wall deformity).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
How are ventilatory disorders characterized?	Ventilatory disorders are characterized by a decrease in vital capacity (VC), residual volume (RV), functional residual capacity (FRC), and total lung capacity (TLC).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What are key clinical monitoring tools for ventilatory disorders?	Key clinical monitoring tools include spirometry (for VC and max insufflation capacity), cough flow meters, and noninvasive CO2 monitoring.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What is insufflation?	Insufflation is the forced inhalation of volumes greater than that which can be inhaled naturally using the muscles of respiration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What is glossopharyngeal breathing?	Glossopharyngeal breathing is a technique that can be used to maximize insufflation and should be taught as a life-saving backup measure in the event of mechanical ventilation failure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
How can respiratory muscles be aided in ventilatory disorders?	Respiratory muscles can be aided by devices such as mouthpiece or nasal intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) and intermittent abdominal pressure ventilation (IAPV).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
How much can intermittent abdominal pressure ventilation (IAPV) augment tidal volume (TV)?	Intermittent abdominal pressure ventilation (IAPV) can augment tidal volume (TV) by 250 to 1,200 mL.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What is the significance of peak cough flow (PCF) &lt;160 L/min?	Peak cough flow (PCF) &lt;160 L/min (~2.7 L/s) has been associated with failure to close a tracheostomy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What does a PCF &lt;270 (4.5 L/s) indicate?	A PCF &lt;270 (4.5 L/s) indicates a high risk of ineffective cough in acute respiratory disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
In which patients have these PCF values been shown to be clinically useful?	These PCF values have been shown to be clinically useful in patients who are healthy or have neuromuscular disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What interventions are warranted when VC is &lt;1,000 to 1,500 mL or PCF &lt;4.5 L/s?	When VC is &lt;1,000 to 1,500 mL or PCF &lt;4.5 L/s, interventions to assist cough are warranted.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What is manually assisted cough (MAC) and how is it performed?	Manually assisted cough (MAC), for example, “quad cough,” can be provided by a caregiver via an abdominal thrust, with or without patient assist, and with or without insufflation prior to the MAC.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What commercial devices may benefit patients needing cough assistance?	Commercial insufflator–exsufflator devices (e.g., CoughAssist, Respironics) may be beneficial.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What is a less ideal alternative to assist cough and must be used with caution?	Invasive suctioning is a less ideal alternative and must be used with caution.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
How can cough be produced in patients with paralyzed abdominal muscles due to an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion?	Cough can be produced by functional electrical stimulation (FES) in patients with paralyzed abdominal muscles due to an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What are additional methods to mobilize secretions?	Additional methods to mobilize secretions include positive expiratory pressure mask therapy and autogenic drainage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What does autogenic drainage involve?	Autogenic drainage involves specific breathing maneuvers aimed at expelling secretions independently.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What treatments are probably overutilized in patients with ventilatory disorders?	Intubation, tracheostomy, and supplemental oxygen therapy are probably overutilized in patients with ventilatory disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What treatments are probably underutilized in patients with ventilatory disorders?	Noninvasive assisted ventilation and assisted cough are probably underutilized in patients with ventilatory disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Ventilatory_Disorders
What are examples of obstructive disorders (intrinsic disorders)?	Examples of obstructive disorders include COPD, asthmatic bronchitis, and cystic fibrosis (CF).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
How are obstructive disorders characterized?	Obstructive disorders are characterized by a decrease in VC and forced expiratory volume (FEV), and an increase in RV, FRC, and TLC.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What should a PR program for intrinsic disorders include?	A PR program for intrinsic disorders should be comprehensive to include nutritional management, pharmacologic management, appropriate supplemental O2 use, breathing method education, airway secretion management techniques, and an exercise program.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
Which types of exercises are recommended for patients with COPD?	Lower limb strengthening exercises and ambulation/endurance programs are recommended for patients with COPD.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
How can psychological interventions help patients with obstructive disorders?	Psychological interventions such as relaxation therapy may help with adjustment and coping.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
When may supplemental home O2 be indicated?	Supplemental home O2 may be indicated when PO2 is consistently &lt;55 to 60 mmHg.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What are the Medicare guidelines for coverage of home O2?	Medicare guidelines for coverage of home O2 generally require documentation of resting, sleep, or exercise PO2 &lt;55 mmHg or SaO2 &lt;88% on room air.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
Under what conditions may patients with PO2 of 56% to 59% or SaO2 of 89% be eligible for supplemental home O2?	Patients with PO2 of 56% to 59% or SaO2 of 89% may be eligible with concomitant congestive heart failure (CHF), pulmonary HTN, or other criteria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What are the benefits of long-term O2 therapy in COPD?	Long-term O2 therapy has been shown to improve survival and quality of life in COPD.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What are the surgical options for patients with obstructive disorders?	Surgical options include lung volume reduction surgery and organ transplant.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
Who are candidates for lung volume reduction surgery?	Candidates for lung volume reduction surgery have advanced emphysema and have had inadequate clinical improvement following a trial of PR.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
How much of the lungs is typically removed in lung volume reduction surgery?	Typically, 20% to 30% of one or both lungs is removed in lung volume reduction surgery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What are the benefits of lung volume reduction surgery?	Lung volume reduction surgery has been shown to reduce hyperinflation and improve FEV1, forced vital capacity (FVC), and quality of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
In which conditions is lung transplant an option?	Lung transplant is an option in conditions such as CF, pulmonary HTN, COPD, and pulmonary fibrosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What are the absolute contraindications for lung transplant?	Absolute contraindications for lung transplant include ongoing tobacco/substance abuse, active HIV infection, and current/recent malignancy (other than nonmelanoma skin cancer).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What are some relative contraindications for lung transplant?	Relative contraindications include a history of older malignancy, psychiatric diagnoses, obesity, and correctable coronary artery disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What is the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) used for in lung transplant candidates?	The 6-minute walk test (6MWT) is used to assess candidates for lung transplant, both as a measure of urgency and predicting survival.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What is a commonly used minimum 6MWT score for lung transplant candidates?	A minimum 6MWT score of 600 feet is commonly used to screen out candidates who are not expected to survive surgery and tolerate postoperative rehabilitation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Pulmonary_Rehab::Obstructive_Disorders
What is the most common agent causing burn injuries?	Heat																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Introduction
What other agents besides heat can cause burn injuries?	Cold, chemicals, electricity, and radiation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Introduction
Which gender constitutes the majority of patients admitted to acute burn centers in the United States?	Males																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Introduction
Among which age group are burns a leading cause of accidental death?	Younger children 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Introduction
What can severe burn injuries lead to?	Severe burn injuries can lead to a hypermetabolic state, increased hormone production, and muscle wasting.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Introduction
What are predictors of mortality in burn injuries?	Older age (&gt;60 years of age), higher total body surface area (TBSA) affected, and the involvement of inhalation injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Introduction
What layer(s) of the skin do first-degree burns affect?	First-degree burns affect the epidermis only.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
How are first-degree burns characterized?	They are characterized by red, painful areas without blisters or open areas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What is the treatment for first-degree burns?	Treatment options include soaking in cool water (effective only when performed within the first 2 minutes of injury) and over-the-counter analgesics.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
Why is ice application contraindicated for first-degree burns?	Because it may compound the thermal injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
How long does healing take for first-degree burns?	Healing occurs spontaneously over ~3 to 7 days.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
How are partial thickness burns further subdivided? 	Superficial and deep burns																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What layers of the skin do superficial partial-thickness burns affect?	The epidermis and the uper third of the dermis																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
How are superficial partial-thickness burns characterized?	They are characterized by serous fluid-filled blisters and mild-to-moderate exudate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What remains intact in superficial partial-thickness burns?	The basal layer remains intact and there is no neurovascular damage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
How long does healing take for superficial partial-thickness burns?	Healing occurs within ~7 to 14 days.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What is the risk of scarring in superficial partial-thickness burns?	The risk of scarring is low, but some pigmentation changes may be seen.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What layers of the skin do deep partial-thickness burns affect?	Epidermis and most of the dermis, with neurovascular damage present																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
How are deep partial-thickness burns characterized?	They are characterized by moderate-to-severe exudate, but fewer blisters than superficial partial-thickness burns.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
How long does healing take for deep partial-thickness burns?	Deep partial-thickness burns may heal in ~14 to 21 days.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What is the risk of scarring in deep partial-thickness burns?	There is an increased risk of scarring.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What are the surgical intervention options for deep partial-thickness burns?	Early burn wound excision and tissue coverage/skin grafting																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What layers of the skin do full-thickness (third-degree) burns involve?	Epidermis and full dermal layer, with possible fat, muscle, or bone involvement as well.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What covers the burned area in full-thickness burns if skin grafting is not performed?	Eschar eventually covers the burned area if skin grafting is not performed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What does eschar require in full-thickness burns?	Eschar requires debridement, followed by skin grafting.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Degree_Severity
What are the goals of rehabilitation for burn patients?	Preventing/minimizing contractures with positioning/splinting, scar management, pain control, psychosocial well-being, and functional restoration (e.g., activities of daily living, social reintegration, and return to work).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
How do burn patients tend to position their joints?	Position of greatest comfort which is often with joints in a flexed position																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
Which burns are at greatest risk for developing contractures?	Burns on the flexor surfaces of a joint/limb are at greatest risk for developing contractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
How can contracture development be limited in burn patients?	Positioning joints in extension and abduction, as well as early mobilization																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
How can dependent edema be avoided in burn patients?	By ensuring that all of the extremities spend sufficient time in elevated positions																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
When might elevating the head and chest be important in burn patients?	To decrease swelling of the upper airway and optimize respiration																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What can facilitate proper positioning for burn patients?	Specialty hospital beds																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What is the ideal material for a splint in burn rehabilitation?	A low-temperature thermoplastic (due to its light weight and moldability/remoldability)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
How are thermoplastic splints prepared and used?	Thermoplastic splints can be softened in hot water and placed directly on the skin to conform to the contour of the extremity in the desired position.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
A splinting program must be used in conjunction with what?	Mobilization																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What is hypertrophic scarring?	A scar that is present at ≥3 months after burn injury with at least 2-mm thickness.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
When are hypertrophic scars more likely to occur?	Hypertrophic scars are more likely to occur if wounds take &gt;2 to 3 weeks to heal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
When is maturation of hypertrophic scars usually seen?	~1.5 years after injury																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What is the risk associated with hypertrophic scars?	Increased risk of contracture development.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What may be worn to prevent or treat hypertrophic scarring?	Compression garments																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What is believed to be the mechanism of action of compression garments?	Compression garments are believed to reduce scar formation by reducing blood flow into the capillaries responsible for the scar formation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
How might the silicone material in compression garments influence wound healing?	Influenes collagen remodeling in the wound, softening and flattening the wound.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
How long should compression garments be worn daily for burn injury?	23 out of 24 hours per day																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What local treatment may help reduce scarring?	Local steroid injections																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
Why is nutritional management critical in patients with significant burn injury?	Because patients with &gt;30% TBSA burns are at high risk for loss of lean body mass and bone mineral density.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What is the daily caloric goal for burn patients?	25 kcal/kg of body weight, plus 40 kcal for each 1% TBSA affected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
What supplements are commonly added to the diet of burn patients?	Supplements commonly added to the diet include vitamin C, vitamin A, zinc, copper, and manganese.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
How does optimizing nutrition benefit burn patients?	Optimizing nutrition has been shown to accelerate wound healing, decrease infection rates, and decrease length of hospital stay.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Rehab_Goals
How can burn injuries alter drug pharmacokinetics?	Burn injuries can alter drug pharmacokinetics by increasing the effective distribution volume.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
What remains the mainstay of treatment for pain relief in burn injury?	Opioids																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
What condition might patients with high TBSA burns have an increased risk of developing?	Increased insulin resistance																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
What should be closely monitored in patients with large burns and patients older than 60 years old?	Blood sugars																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
How can insulin administration benefit burn patients?	Insulin administration may decrease healing time by decreasing protein catabolism and increasing muscle protein synthesis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
What effect has administration of the synthetic testosterone oxandrolone been shown to have?	Administration of oxandrolone has been shown to increase lean body mass and improve overall outcomes, including wound healing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
How can beta-blockers help burn patients?	Beta-blockers may help by reducing the catecholamine and stress responses to burn injury, mitigating protein and lean body mass loss, and reducing the risk for post-traumatic stress disorder.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
What risks are elevated following burn injury, particularly with high TBSA injuries?	Venous thromboembolism (VTE) risks are elevated																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
What do the data generally suggest regarding VTE prophylaxis in burn patients?	Burn patients with higher levels of VTE risk (e.g., &gt;40% TBSA burns and need for ICU level care) would benefit from early and aggressive chemoprophylaxis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Pharmacotherapy
What are other significant complications following burn injury?	Contractures, infections, peripheral neuropathy, multiple mononeuropathies, bony osteophyte formation, heterotopic ossification, spinal deformity, joint subluxation/dislocation, and pressure ulcers																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Complications
What is the most common site of heterotopic ossification in burn injury patients?	Posterior elbow of the affected limb																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Complications
What spinal deformities can occur as complications of burn injuries?	Spinal deformities that can occur as complications of burn injuries include scoliosis and kyphosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Complications
Where are pressure ulcers particularly common in burn injury patients?	Heel and sacral regions																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Burn_Rehab::Complications
What is the most widely used tool for assessing and describing physical function in the oncology setting?	The Karnofsky Performance Scale (KPS).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Functional_Assessment_Tools
What type of scale is the Karnofsky Performance Scale (KPS)?	It is a clinician-rated, 11-point ordinal scale.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Functional_Assessment_Tools
For what purposes can the Karnofsky Performance Scale (KPS) be used in the oncology setting?	It can be used to help assess the need for treatment, chemotherapy dose adjustments, the need and intensity of rehabilitation services, the need for supportive care, or the need for palliative care.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Functional_Assessment_Tools
Other than the KPS what is another commonly used tool for assessing physical function in oncology patients?	The Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Scale of Performance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Functional_Assessment_Tools
How many points does the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Scale of Performance have?	It is a 6-point ordinal scale.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Functional_Assessment_Tools
How does the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Scale of Performance compare to the Karnofsky Performance Scale (KPS)?	It is simpler to administer but less descriptive than the KPS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Functional_Assessment_Tools
What is the most commonly diagnosed brain tumor?	metastatic, usually arising from tumors of the breast, lung, and melanoma.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
How are primary brain tumors classified?	cellular origin and histologic grade.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What are the most common primary brain tumors?	malignant gliomas, which are derived from astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and ependymal cells.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What is the most common type of glioma and its prognosis?	Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is the most common type of glioma and carries the worst prognosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What are the most common benign brain tumors?	Meningiomas, which arise from the meninges covering the brain and spinal cord, are the most common benign brain tumors, making up 20% of primary brain tumors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What are the clinical presentations of brain tumors?	Clinical presentations of brain tumors include headache, nausea, vomiting, cognitive dysfunction, and seizures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What treatments are available for brain tumors?	Treatment of brain tumors can involve surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What challenges do brain tumor patients face compared to stroke or traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients?	Brain tumor patients face progressive disease course and complications during cancer treatment, including side effects of radiation therapy, chemotherapy, steroids, and antiseizure medications.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What residual deficits might brain tumor patients experience from their disease and treatment?	gait abnormality, hemiparesis, cognitive/speech deficits, and dysphagia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What can cause cognitive dysfunction in brain tumor patients?	Cognitive dysfunction can result from the tumor, surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and medications such as seizure prophylaxis and is considered a negative prognostic indicator.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What percentage of all central nervous system (CNS) tumors are primary spinal cord tumors?	Primary tumors account for 2% to 4% of all CNS tumors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
How are spinal cord tumors classified by location?	Tumors are classified by location: intramedullary, intradural, extramedullary, and extradural.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What are the most common intramedullary tumors?	ependymomas and astrocytomas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What are the most common intradural extramedullary tumors?	schwannomas, meningiomas, and gliomas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What are leptomeningeal metastases?	Leptomeningeal metastases are diffuse metastases that surround the spinal cord and brain, presenting with polyradicular involvement with pain, weakness, paresthesias, and areflexia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
Where are extradural tumors usually located, and what is their typical origin?	Extradural tumors are usually located in the vertebral body and are typically metastatic.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What types of tumors most commonly metastasize to the spine? (6)	breast, lung, prostate, colon, thyroid, and kidney tumors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
How common are primary malignant tumors of the spine?	Primary malignant tumors of the spine are very rare.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What percentage of cancer patients experience cancer-related spinal cord compression?	5%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What is the most common presenting symptom of cancer-related spinal cord compression?	back pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What neurologic deficits warrant urgent evaluation and treatment in cancer-related spinal cord compression?	Neurologic deficits such as weakness, sensory loss, and sphincter dysfunction warrant urgent evaluation and treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
Where is pain from spinal metastases and pathological fractures most common, and when is it worse?	Pain from spinal metastases and pathological fractures is most common in the thoracic spine and is worse at night and when lying down.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What does the finding of a spine or spinal cord lesion warrant?	The finding of a spine or spinal cord lesion warrants further evaluation of the whole spine and brain, as lesions can be non-congruous.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What is the initial treatment for patients with neurologic deficits from spinal cord compression?	Treatment usually begins with high-dose corticosteroids for patients with neurologic deficits.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What treatments are used to treat cord compression from metastatic disease?	Radiation, decompressive surgery, or both are used to treat cord compression from metastatic disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::CNS_Spine_Tumors
What causes paraneoplastic syndromes?	Paraneoplastic syndromes occur when the immune system produces antibodies against tumor cells and proteins and cross-reacts with healthy tissue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Paraneoplastic_Syndromes
With which cancers are paraneoplastic syndromes most commonly associated?	lung, breast, hematologic, and gynecologic cancers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Paraneoplastic_Syndromes
What should suspicion of a paraneoplastic syndrome trigger?	primary malignancy if none has already been identified.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Paraneoplastic_Syndromes
Which systems are often affected by paraneoplastic syndromes?	central and/or peripheral neurological systems.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Paraneoplastic_Syndromes
How is the neurologic deterioration in paraneoplastic syndromes characterized?	often rapid, occurring over days to weeks, and is faster than typical noncancer-related pathologies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Paraneoplastic_Syndromes
What are examples of neurological paraneoplastic syndromes?	Examples of neurological paraneoplastic syndromes include limbic encephalitis (CNS), cranial nerve pathologies, Lambert-Eaton syndrome (neuromuscular junction [NMJ]), and myasthenia gravis (NMJ).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Paraneoplastic_Syndromes
What does the workup for paraneoplastic syndromes include?	The workup includes serology for onconeural antibodies, imaging, nerve conduction study/electrodiagnostic study (NCS/EMG), and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) studies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Paraneoplastic_Syndromes
What are the treatment options for paraneoplastic syndromes?	Treatment options include IV Ig, steroids, and immunosuppressants.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Paraneoplastic_Syndromes
What is chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN)?	Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) is a common and often debilitating side effect of cancer treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Induced_Peripheral_Neuropathy
What factors increase the risk of developing CIPN?	Risk increases with dose, duration, and intensity of chemotherapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Induced_Peripheral_Neuropathy
How can the clinical presentation of CIPN vary?	The clinical presentation can vary depending on the chemotherapy agent.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Induced_Peripheral_Neuropathy
Which parts of the nervous system can be affected by CIPN?	The dorsal root ganglion, nerve terminals of primary sensory neurons, and motor and/or autonomic systems can be affected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Induced_Peripheral_Neuropathy
What do nerve conduction studies most often show in CIPN?	decreased or absent sensory nerve action potentials.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Induced_Peripheral_Neuropathy
What medications can be used to treat symptoms of paresthesias in CIPN?	Duloxetine, nortriptyline, gabapentin, and pregabalin can be used for symptoms of paresthesias.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Induced_Peripheral_Neuropathy
What therapies are recommended when there are functional deficits in CIPN?	Physical and occupational therapy is recommended when there are functional deficits.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Induced_Peripheral_Neuropathy
What might need to be considered if the manifestations of CIPN become severe?	alteration of the chemotherapy itself (dose, duration, or agent) may need to be considered.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Induced_Peripheral_Neuropathy
What can result in brachial plexopathy in proximity to the brachial plexus, for example, breast cancer?	XRT for malignancies occurring in proximity to the brachial plexus can result in brachial plexopathy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
When do most cases of XRT-induced brachial plexopathy occur?	Most cases occur within 3 years of XRT.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
What is the typical presentation of XRT-induced brachial plexopathy?	upper limb weakness, usually painless, in the distribution of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, affecting the shoulder.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
How can the weakness progress in XRT-induced brachial plexopathy?	The weakness can progress to affect the whole upper limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
What concurrent condition may be present with XRT-induced brachial plexopathy?	There may be concurrent lymphedema.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
What is the treatment for XRT-induced brachial plexopathy?	Treatment is largely supportive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
Which part of the brachial plexus does neoplastic brachial plexopathy typically affect?	lower trunk.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
What are the symptoms of neoplastic brachial plexopathy?	acute pain and sensory loss.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
What diagnostic tools can help differentiate between neoplastic and XRT-induced plexopathy?	MRI and NCS/EMG can help differentiate between neoplastic and XRT-induced plexopathy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
What is consistent with XRT-induced plexopathy on EMG?	Myokymic discharges on EMG are consistent with XRT-induced plexopathy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
How is neoplastic brachial plexopathy best managed?	Neoplastic brachial plexopathy is best managed by treating the underlying malignancy with XRT and chemotherapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Plexopathy
What are bony metastases typically a complication of?	Bony metastases are typically a complication of advanced cancer.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
Where are bony metastases most commonly seen?	Bony metastases are seen most commonly in the axial skeleton, followed by the femur, humerus, skull, ribs, and pelvis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
What must be ruled out in patients with a known history of cancer presenting with bone pain?	Metastatic disease																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
How should suspicious bony metastases on x-rays be confirmed?	Suspicious bony metastases on x-rays should be confirmed by bone scan.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
What is the best evaluation tool for spinal metastases?	Spinal metastases are best evaluated by MRI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
What are the more common complications of bony metastases?	The more common complications include pain, hypercalcemia, spinal cord compression, and pathologic fractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
What are the medical therapies for bony metastatic disease?	Medical therapies include chemotherapy, hormone therapy, bisphosphonates (e.g., zoledronic acid), and RANK ligand inhibitors (e.g., denosumab).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
What complications do bisphosphonates use have?	Complications include nephrotoxicity, hypocalcemia, osteonecrosis of the jaw, and atypical fractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
What exercises should patients with bony metastatic lesions perform during rehabilitation?	Patients should only perform active range of motion exercises with the involved limb and avoid resistive exercises.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
What treatments are highly effective in treating pain and neurological deficits from bony metastases?	Radiation and surgical stabilization are highly effective in treating pain and neurological deficits.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Bony_metastases
"What activates the body&#x27;s coagulation and inflammatory pathways in radiation fibrosis syndrome (RFS)?"	Radiation activates the body’s coagulation and inflammatory pathways.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What does increased vascular permeability and abnormal accumulation of thrombin and fibrin lead to?	It leads to progressive tissue fibrosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What factors are related to the risk and severity of radiation fibrosis syndrome (RFS)?	The total dose of XRT, fraction size, and duration of treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
In which patients is RFS most frequently seen?	Patients who have had treatment for head and neck cancer and those who have received mantle XRT for Hodgkin’s lymphoma.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
How is the onset of RFS classified?	three phases: acutely after treatment, early–delayed (3 months after completion), or delayed (more than 3 months after completion of XRT).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
Where can pathology occur in RFS, and how can it present?	anywhere in the neuromuscular axis and can present as pain, weakness, and/or spasticity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What causes pain in RFS?	Pain is caused by ectopic activity in the sensory nerves within the radiation field.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What causes weakness in RFS?	Weakness is secondary to fibrosis of the nerves and muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What can painful spasms of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles cause?	cervical dystonia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What can spasms of the muscles of mastication cause, and what is the impact?	Spasms can cause trismus, which may lead to decreased PO intake, poor nutritional status, impaired oral hygiene, and impaired verbal expression, negatively impacting quality of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What does the treatment of RFS depend on?	Treatment depends on the tissues affected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What may help improve jaw range of motion in RFS?	Jaw-opening splints (e.g., TheraBite and Dynasplint) may help improve jaw range of motion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What may orthoses address in RFS?	Orthoses may address cervical spine extensor weakness or foot drop.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
Which agents may manage neuropathic pain in RFS?	Neuropathic pain may be managed with agents such as gabapentin, pregabalin, or duloxetine.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What can help address painful spasms in RFS?	Baclofen or tizanidine can help address painful spasms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What may be an option for cervical dystonia or trismus in RFS?	Botulinum toxin injection may be an option for cervical dystonia or trismus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Radiation_Fibrosis_Syndrome
What does the lymphatic system absorb, filter, and transport?	lymphatic fluid.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What can disrupt the lymphatic system?	trauma, surgery, or radiation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
With which cancers is lymphedema most commonly associated?	Lymphedema is most commonly associated with breast cancer and melanoma.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
Can lymphedema occur with other types of cancer?	Yes, lymphedema may occur with any type of cancer following lymphadenectomy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What are the risk factors for lymphedema?	Risk factors include the location of the tumor, type of surgery, the number of lymph nodes removed, the number of nodes returned positive for disease, treatment with XRT, and increased BMI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
How is lymphedema staged?	Lymphedema is staged using the International Society of Lymphology’s descriptive system.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What is Stage 0 lymphedema?	Stage 0 is a subclinical or latent condition; swelling is not evident despite impaired lymphatic transport. Most patients are asymptomatic, but some report a feeling of heaviness in the limb.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What is Stage 1 lymphedema?	Stage 1 is spontaneously reversible, soft, pitting, and resolves after elevation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What is Stage 2 lymphedema?	Stage 2 lymphedema is when the affected limb is firmer due to fibrotic tissue and scarring, and prolonged elevation temporarily reduces swelling.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What is Stage 3 lymphedema?	Stage 3 lymphedema is when the affected limb is grossly enlarged, with hardening and thickening; there is no reduction of lymphedema with prolonged elevation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What are the common presentations of lymphedema?	Presentation includes swelling, feeling of heaviness, and functional impairment of the affected area.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What difference in limb circumference is considered diagnostic for mild lymphedema?	A difference in circumference of 2 cm or greater between involved and uninvolved limbs is considered diagnostic for mild lymphedema.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What is the primary treatment for lymphedema?	Primary treatment includes complete decongestive therapy (CDT) performed by a lymphedema therapist.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What does Phase I (reductive CDT) focus on?	Phase I (reductive CDT) focuses on manual lymphatic drainage (MLD), compression bandaging, therapeutic exercises, and education on skin care.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What happens when maximum volume reduction is achieved in lymphedema treatment?	The patient transitions to Phase II (maintenance CDT), which includes the use of compression garments, self-massage, and exercises.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What has research shown about CDT?	Research has shown CDT to be a safe and well-tolerated treatment for lymphedema.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
How much can compression bandaging combined with MLD reduce lymphedema from baseline?	Compression bandaging combined with MLD has the potential to reduce lymphedema by 30% to 40% from baseline.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Lymphedema
What is the primary cause of radiculopathy in individuals with cancer?	The primary cause of radiculopathy in individuals with cancer is degenerative joint disease; however, impingement due to the cancer itself should be included in the differential.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What imaging is recommended for any patient with known malignancy and worsening neck pain?	MRI																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What type of cancer treatment can cause damage to nerve roots?	Patients with head and neck cancer may have damage to nerve roots from XRT.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What increases the risk for developing rotator cuff dysfunction in cancer patients?	Cancer patients who have undergone a mastectomy or thoracotomy are at an increased risk for developing rotator cuff dysfunction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What additional conditions put patients at higher risk for rotator cuff pathology?	Patients with premorbid C5/C6 radiculopathy or XRT-induced plexopathy are at higher risk for rotator cuff pathology.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
How does pain from rotator cuff dysfunction often present?	Pain secondary to rotator cuff dysfunction often presents as an ache extending over the anterior shoulder and deltoid muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What activities may exacerbate pain from rotator cuff dysfunction?	Overhead activities and movements requiring internal rotation may exacerbate pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What are the physical exam findings for rotator cuff dysfunction?	On physical exam, range of motion will be limited, motor strength will be reduced secondary to pain, and impingement tests will be positive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What are the treatment options for rotator cuff dysfunction?	Treatment options include analgesics, modalities, range of motion/strengthening exercise, and intra-articular injections.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What is axillary web syndrome, and how can it be treated?	Axillary web syndrome, also known as axillary cording, may limit forward flexion of the shoulder secondary to pain and may respond to myofascial release.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What is post-mastectomy pain syndrome (PMPS)?	Post-mastectomy pain syndrome (PMPS) is a chronic neuropathic pain condition that can occur after any surgical procedure of the breast, including mastectomy, lumpectomy, axillary lymph node dissection (ALND), and reconstruction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
When is PMPS diagnosed?	PMPS refers to persistent pain lasting greater than 3 months postoperatively when all other causes, such as infection or tumor recurrence, have been ruled out.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What are the pathophysiological causes of PMPS?	Pathophysiology includes damage to the intercostobrachial nerve, axillary nerve, or chest wall during surgery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What are the risk factors for PMPS?	Risk factors include extensive ALND, severe pain in the acute postoperative period, treatment with adjuvant XRT, younger age at diagnosis, lower socioeconomic status, and anxiety.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What are the pharmaceutical agents used to treat PMPS?	Pharmaceutical agents commonly used in treating neuropathic pain, such as gabapentin, pregabalin, tricyclic antidepressants, serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), lidocaine patches, and analgesic creams, may help.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What may help reduce post-thoracotomy pain syndrome (PTPS)?	Studies have shown that thoracic epidural anesthesia administered prior to surgery may help reduce PTPS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What is the primary cause of PTPS?	Risk factors include poorly controlled preoperative and acute postoperative pain, and the use of video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) procedure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What procedures can help with refractory PTPS pain?	Intercostal nerve blocks																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Upper_Body_Pain_Disorders
What can XRT and chemotherapy cause that increases the risks of infection or bleeding?	XRT and chemotherapy can cause neutropenia and thrombocytopenia, which can increase the risks of infection or bleeding.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Rad_Therapy_Induced_Cytopenia
When should holding therapies be considered due to low platelet counts?	When platelet counts fall below 25,000/μL																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Rad_Therapy_Induced_Cytopenia
When does chemotherapy-induced neutropenia typically occur?	3 to 7 days following the administration of chemotherapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Rad_Therapy_Induced_Cytopenia
What should survivors with leukopenia and compromised immune function avoid?	Survivors with leukopenia and compromised immune function should avoid public gyms and other public places until their white blood cell (WBC) counts return to safe levels.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Rad_Therapy_Induced_Cytopenia
Why is anemia generally less of a concern than thrombocytopenia in cancer patients?	Anemia, unless it is very severe, is generally less of a concern than thrombocytopenia due to the latter’s associated risk of complications such as intracranial hemorrhage and uncontrolled bleeding.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab RehabReadyTags::Cancer_Rehab::Chemo_Rad_Therapy_Induced_Cytopenia
How many new spinal cord injury (SCI) cases are there in the United States each year?	Nearly 17,000 new spinal cord injury (SCI) cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Epidemiology_Traumatic_SCI
What has been the mean age at the time of injury since 2015?	42 years old																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Epidemiology_Traumatic_SCI
What is the male-to-female ratio for spinal cord injuries?	The male-to-female ratio remains roughly 4:1																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Epidemiology_Traumatic_SCI
What is the most common category of spinal cord injury?	Incomplete tetraplegia, which accounts for 45.0% of cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Epidemiology_Traumatic_SCI
What are the percentages for incomplete paraplegia, complete paraplegia, and complete tetraplegia?	Incomplete paraplegia (21.3%), complete paraplegia (20%), and complete tetraplegia (13.3%).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Epidemiology_Traumatic_SCI
Since 2010, what are the most common etiologies of SCI?	The most common etiologies are: vehicular crashes (38%), followed by falls (30.5%), acts of violence (13.5%), sports/recreation (9.0%), medical/surgical causes (5%), and other causes (4%).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Epidemiology_Traumatic_SCI
Which category of SCI has seen an increase in proportion, and which has seen a decrease?	The proportion of injuries from falls has increased, and the proportion from sports has decreased.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Epidemiology_Traumatic_SCI
Which category of SCI is the fastest rising?	Falls are the fastest rising category																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Epidemiology_Traumatic_SCI
Where do the majority of descending motor fibers from the brain cross to become the CST?	The majority of descending motor fibers from the brain cross at the medulla to become the lateral corticospinal tract (CST).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Tracts
What is the path of a small number of CST fibers that do not decussate at the medulla?	They descend via the anterior CST before crossing at the level of the anterior white commissure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Tracts
What is challenged about the lateral CST in many representations of the spinal cord?	The existence of a somatotopic organization of the lateral CST has been challenged.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Tracts
What makes up the ascending dorsal white columns?	The ascending dorsal white columns are made up of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Tracts
Where do the fibers of the dorsal white columns cross?	They cross in the medulla, via the medial lemniscus, then ascend to the thalamus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Tracts
What sensations do the fibers of the dorsal white columns carry?	They carry joint position, vibration, and light touch (LT)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Tracts
What sensations do the spinothalamic tracts carry?	The spinothalamic tracts carry pain, temperature, and nondiscriminative tactile sensations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Tracts
Where do the fibers of the spinothalamic tracts cross to the contralateral side?	They cross shortly after entry to the cord in the ventral white commissure of the spinal cord.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Tracts
According to the International Standards for Neurological Classification of SCI (ISNCSCI), how should the patient be examined?	The patient should be examined in the supine position in the following order.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What is the first step in examining a patient for SCI according to ISNCSCI?	Perform a sensory examination of the 28 dermatomes at key sensory points on each side for pinprick (PP) and light touch (LT). Sensory levels are scored as 0 (absent), 1 (impaired, including hyperesthesia), 2 (normal), or not testable (NT).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How is the ability to discriminate pinprick from light touch scored in ISNCSCI?	The inability to discriminate pinprick from light touch is scored as 0.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What does the sensory examination include according to ISNCSCI?	The sensory examination also includes evaluation of deep anal pressure, determined by a reliable ability to feel the examiner’s finger applying gentle pressure to the anorectal wall (graded as present or absent).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How is the sensory level defined in ISNCSCI?	The sensory level is the most caudal level with intact sensation for both pinprick and light touch on each side, where all rostral sensory levels are also intact.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) key sensory points for C2?	At least 1 cm lateral to the occipital protuberance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for T1?	Medial epicondyle elbow.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for L3?	Medial femoral condyle above the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for C3?	Supraclavicular fossa at midclavicular line.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for T2?	Apex of the axilla.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for L4?	Medial malleolus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for C4?	Over the acromioclavicular joint.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for T4?	Medial to nipple at midclavicular line.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for L5?	Dorsum of the foot at the 3rd metatarsophalangeal joint.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for C5?	Lateral antecubital fossa.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for T10?	Lateral to the umbilicus at midclavicular line.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the selected ASIA key sensory points for S1?	Lateral heel (calcaneus).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What is the second step in examining a patient for SCI according to ISNCSCI?	Perform a motor examination of the 10 key muscle groups on each side, as well as voluntary anal contraction. Muscles are graded from 0 (total paralysis) to 5 (full active ROM against full resistance), or not testable (NT).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How is a palpable or visible contraction graded in ISNCSCI?	A palpable or visible contraction is graded as 1.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How are muscles limited by pain or deconditioning graded in ISNCSCI?	Muscles limited only by pain or deconditioning are graded as 5* instead of 4.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How is the motor level for each side determined in ISNCSCI?
