The motor level for each side is the most caudal myotome with grade 3 or more, where all muscles rostral to it are grade 5.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How is voluntary anal contraction graded in ISNCSCI?	Voluntary anal contraction is graded as present or absent and must be distinguished from reflex contraction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) key muscles for C5?	Elbow flexors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for T1?	Little finger abductors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for L5?	Extensor hallucis longus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for C6?	Wrist extensors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for L2?	Hip flexors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for S1?	Ankle plantar flexors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for C7?	Elbow extensors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for L3?	Knee extensors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for C8?	Flexor digitorum profundus of the third digit.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What are the ASIA key muscles for L4?	Ankle dorsiflexors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How is injury classified as complete or incomplete in ISNCSCI?	Complete injuries have no motor or sensory function, including deep anal sensation, preserved in segments S4–S5. Somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEPs) may be useful in differentiating complete versus incomplete SCI in patients who are uncooperative or unconscious.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How are injuries categorized using the ASIA Impairment Scale (AIS)?	Injuries are categorized as AIS A to E.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What does AIS A indicate?	Complete—No sensory or motor function is preserved in segments S4–S5.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What does AIS B indicate?	Sensory Incomplete—Sensory function is preserved below the single NLI and must include segments S4–S5. No motor function is preserved on either side of the body more than three levels below the motor level.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What does AIS C indicate?	Motor Incomplete—Motor function is preserved below the single NLI, and more than half of the key muscles below the NLI have a muscle grade less than 3/5.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What does AIS D indicate?	Motor Incomplete—Motor function is preserved below the single NLI, and at least half the key muscles below the NLI have a muscle grade greater than 3/5.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What does AIS E indicate?	Normal—Sensory and motor function of the key dermatomes and myotomes per ISNCSCI is normal in all segments.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What is required for a grade of AIS C or D according to ISNCSCI?	There must be voluntary anal contraction OR sensory sparing at the S4–S5 level with sparing of motor function more than three levels below the motor level.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
How is the zone of partial preservation (ZPP) used in ISNCSCI?	The zone of partial preservation (ZPP) is used only for AIS A and is defined as the most caudal partially innervated sensory and motor segments below the sensory and motor levels, respectively. It requires volitional contraction of a key muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Classification_SCI
What is the typical cause and result of Central Cord Syndrome?	Central Cord Syndrome is typically seen in persons with preexisting cervical spondylosis who experience neck hyperextension injuries, resulting in greater upper limb weakness than lower limb, variable sensory loss, and variable effects on bowel, bladder, and sexual function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
"What did Penrod&#x27;s study on Central Cord Syndrome note about patient recovery?"	Penrod retrospectively studied 51 patients with central cord syndrome and noted better overall recovery of ambulation, self-care, and bowel/bladder function in patients aged less than 50 years compared to their older counterparts at time of discharge from rehabilitation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
What are the characteristics and typical cause of Brown-Séquard Syndrome?	Brown-Séquard Syndrome occurs when a hemisection of the spinal cord is damaged, classically due to knife trauma or tumor, resulting in ipsilateral hyperreflexic spastic paralysis and loss of tactile discrimination, vibration sense, and proprioceptive sense at and below the level of injury. Contralaterally, there is loss of pinprick (PP) and temperature sense starting typically at two segments below the level of injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
What are the clinical features and prognosis of pure Brown-Séquard Syndrome?	Pure Brown-Séquard Syndrome is rare and has the best prognosis for functional ambulation among incomplete SCI syndromes. Brown-Séquard-Plus Syndrome includes features of central cord syndrome and is more frequently seen clinically.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
What is the typical cause and clinical presentation of Anterior Cord Syndrome?	The etiology of Anterior Cord Syndrome is typically a vascular lesion in the territory of the anterior spinal artery, causing variable loss of motor function and PP sensation, with relative preservation of proprioception and light touch (LT). Bladder and bowel function are usually affected.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
What is the prognosis for motor recovery in Anterior Cord Syndrome?	The prognosis for motor recovery is generally poor.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
What causes Cauda Equina Syndrome (CES) and what are its manifestations?	Cauda Equina Syndrome (CES) may be due to neural canal compression or fractures of the sacrum or spine at L2 or below, manifesting as lower motor neuron deficits, bladder retention, bowel dysfunction, sexual dysfunction, flaccid lower limb weakness, and saddle anesthesia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
How is CES treated, and what is the potential for recovery?	CES is considered an emergency, thus urgent surgical consultation is indicated. Recovery is possible because the nerve roots can recover.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
What are the causes and symptoms of Conus Medullaris Syndrome?	A pure conus medullaris lesion results in saddle anesthesia and bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction due to cord injury at the S2–S4 segments. Conus lesions due to trauma often result in a mixed upper and lower motor neuron lesion presentation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
What is the prognosis for recovery in Conus Medullaris Syndrome compared to CES?	Prognosis for recovery is poorer than for CES.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::SCI_Clinical_Syndromes
Is there a proven cure for SCI?	Currently, there is no proven cure for SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
What were mega-dose steroids previously reported to be in acute SCI?	Mega-dose steroids were previously reported to be neuroprotective in acute SCI by inhibiting lipid peroxidation and scavenging free radicals.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
What did the second National Acute Spinal Cord Injury Study (NASCIS) demonstrate about steroids in acute SCI?	The study demonstrated improved neurologic outcomes if steroids were administered within 8 hours of injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
Why were the results of the NASCIS study discredited?	The results were found to have methodological flaws and have been largely discredited.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
What is the current status of high-dose methylprednisolone (MP) in acute SCI?	Currently, high-dose MP is considered an optional treatment for acute SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
What other interventions have been investigated as potentially neuroprotective or neuroregenerative agents?	IV GM-1 ganglioside, intralesional activated autologous macrophages, and intralesional stem cells have been investigated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
Have any of the other investigated interventions been proven to be clinically effective for acute SCI?	None of these interventions has been proven to date to be clinically effective for acute SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
What does the current standard of care for acute SCI involve?	The standard of care involves expert medical and surgical care, followed by multidisciplinary restorative rehabilitation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
What is known about the optimal timing for surgery after SCI?	The optimal timing for surgery after SCI is unknown, although early surgery may be superior to delayed surgery because it allows for earlier mobilization and reduction of medical complications.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
What do retrospective data suggest about urgent decompression in the setting of bilateral facet dislocation?	Retrospective data suggest a role for urgent decompression in the setting of bilateral facet dislocation or incomplete SCI with evidence of progressive neurologic deterioration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Acute_treatment_SCI
What percentage of patients who are AIS A at 1 week post-SCI make significant neurologic recoveries?	Only 2% to 3% of patients who are AIS A at 1 week post-SCI make significant neurologic recoveries; that is, improve to AIS D by 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What percentage of key muscles in the ZPP with grade 1 or 2 power at 1 month post-SCI will reach grade 3 at 1 year?	More than 95% of key muscles in the ZPP with grade 1 or 2 power at 1 month post-SCI will reach grade 3 at 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What percentage of the most cephalad grade 0 muscles at 1 month will recover to at least grade 3 at 1 year?	About 25% of the most cephalad grade 0 muscles at 1 month will recover to at least grade 3 at 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
Which sensation is the most likely to recover motor function in the most cephalad grade 0 muscles at 1 month?	Those having pinprick (PP) sensation are the most likely to recover motor function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
During what time period does most upper limb recovery occur in patients with complete tetraplegia?	Most upper limb recovery occurs during the first 6 months, with the greatest rate of change during the first 3 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
Which level is superior in correlating with function: motor level or neurologic/sensory level?	Motor level is superior to the neurologic or sensory level in correlating with function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What percentage of patients with complete paraplegia at 1 week post-SCI have their neurologic level of injury (NLI) unchanged at 1 year?	73% of patients with complete paraplegia at 1 week post-SCI have their NLI unchanged at 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What percentage of patients with complete paraplegia at 1 week post-SCI improve one level at 1 year?	18% of patients with complete paraplegia at 1 week post-SCI improve one level at 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What percentage of patients with complete paraplegia at 1 week post-SCI improve two or more levels at 1 year?	9% of patients with complete paraplegia at 1 week post-SCI improve two or more levels at 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What percentage of persons with complete paraplegia eventually achieve community ambulation?	Only 5% of persons with complete paraplegia eventually achieve community ambulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
How many levels below the initial level do persons with incomplete tetraplegia often recover?	Persons with incomplete tetraplegia often recover multiple levels below the initial level.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
During what time period does the majority of recovery occur in persons with incomplete tetraplegia?	The majority of recovery occurs within the first 6 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What percentage of incomplete tetraplegics recover sufficient motor function to ambulate at 1 year?	46% of incomplete tetraplegics recover sufficient motor function to ambulate at 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What percentage of persons with incomplete paraplegia regain hip flexors and knee extensors (grade ≥3) by 1 year?	As much as 80% of persons with incomplete paraplegia regain hip flexors and knee extensors (grade ≥3) by 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What does recovery of hip flexors and knee extensors in persons with incomplete paraplegia improve?	Recovery of hip flexors and knee extensors improves their likelihood of community-based ambulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What was predictive of eventual functional ambulation in a review of 27 patients who were initially sensory incomplete?	Partial (or greater) preservation of pinprick (PP) sensation below the zone of injury was predictive of eventual functional ambulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What is the prognosis for ambulation in patients with AIS B injuries with PP sparing compared to those with AIS C injuries?	Patients with AIS B injuries with PP sparing converted to AIS D status nearly as frequently as those with AIS C injuries, thus having a favorable prognosis for ambulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
When may the 72-hour post-SCI neurologic examination predict recovery more reliably?	The 72-hour post-SCI neurologic examination may predict recovery more reliably than an examination performed on the day of injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What can signify a lower motor neuron lesion and have implications on bowel, bladder, and sexual function?	Absence of the bulbocavernosus reflex beyond the first few days can signify a lower motor neuron lesion and have implications on bowel, bladder, and sexual function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What are independent negative predictors of motor function at 1 year on MRI?	Presence of hemorrhage and length of edema are independent negative predictors of motor function at 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What correlates with community ambulation in terms of muscle strength?	Strength 3/5 or more in the bilateral hip flexors and the knee extensors on at least one side correlates with community ambulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Prognosis_Recovery_Traumatic_SCI
What is the expected functional outcome for patients with C1–3 SCI?	Dependent for secretion management. Independent with power wheelchair (WC) mobility and pressure relief with enhanced equipment; otherwise dependent for all care but independent for directing care.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Expected_Functional_Outcomes
What is the expected functional outcome for patients with C4 SCI?	May be able to breathe without a ventilator. May use a mobile arm support for limited ADLs if there is some elbow flexion and deltoid strength. May be able to use a sip-puff or head-control WC.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Expected_Functional_Outcomes
What is the expected functional outcome for patients with C5 SCI?	May require assistance to clear secretions. May be independent for feeding after setup and with adaptive equipment, e.g., a long opponens orthosis with utensil slots and mobile arm support. Requires assistance for most upper-body ADLs. Most patients will be unable to perform self-intermittent catheterization. Independent with power WC; some users may be independent with manual WC with hand rim projections on noncarpeted, level, indoor surfaces. Some may drive specially adapted vans.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Expected_Functional_Outcomes
What is the expected functional outcome for patients with C6 SCI?	May use a tenodesis orthosis and short opponens orthosis with utensil slots. Independent with feeding except for cutting food. Independent for most upper-body ADLs after setup and with modifications (e.g., Velcro straps on clothing); assistance to dependent for most lower-body ADLs, including bowel care. Some males may be independent with self-intermittent catheterization (IC) after setup; females are usually dependent. Some patients may be independent for transfers using a sliding board and heel loops, but many will require assistance. May be independent with manual WC, but power WCs are often used, especially for longer distances and outdoors. May drive an adapted van.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Expected_Functional_Outcomes
What is the expected functional outcome for patients with C7 SCI?	Essentially independent for most ADLs, often using a short opponens splint and universal cuff. May require assistance for some lower-body ADLs. Women may have difficulty with IC. Bowel care may be independent with adaptive equipment, but suppository insertion may still be difficult. Independent for mobility at a manual WC level, except for uneven transfers. Patients may be independent with a nonvan automobile with hand controls if the patient can transfer and load/unload the WC.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Expected_Functional_Outcomes
What is the expected functional outcome for patients with C8 SCI?	Completely independent with ADLs including bowel and bladder care and mobility using manual WC and adapted car.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Expected_Functional_Outcomes
What percentage of patients with SCI at T6 or above can experience Autonomic Dysreflexia (AD)?	Autonomic Dysreflexia (AD) can occur in 48% to 85% of patients with SCI at T6 or above.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What systolic blood pressure (SBP) increase may signify AD in SCI patients?	SBPs of 20 to 40 mmHg more than the baseline may signify AD.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What causes reflex sympathetic vasoconstriction (BP ↑) in AD?	A noxious stimulus below the level of injury causes reflex sympathetic vasoconstriction (BP ↑).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
"Why can&#x27;t higher CNS centers directly modulate the sympathetic response in AD?"	Due to the SCI, higher CNS centers cannot directly modulate the sympathetic response.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How does the body attempt to lower BP during AD?	The body attempts to lower BP by carotid and aortic baroreceptor/vagal-mediated bradycardia, but this is usually ineffective.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is the primary treatment for AD?	The primary treatment of AD is removal of the noxious stimulus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is the most common cause of the noxious stimulus in AD?	The most common cause is bladder dysfunction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is the second most common cause of the noxious stimulus in AD?	The second most common cause is bowel distention (e.g., high fecal impaction).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are some other causes of the noxious stimulus in AD?	Other causes can include abdominal emergencies, UTIs, testicular torsion, epididymitis, endometriosis, undiagnosed fractures, DVTs, pressure injury, gout, cellulitis, ingrown toenails, and tight clothing/stockings or splints.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What happens to the risk of osteoporosis and fractures below the level of injury following SCI?	The risk of osteoporosis and fractures is increased below the level of injury following SCI, especially in long bones.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is the thought cause of increased osteoporosis and fractures in SCI patients?	The exact pathogenesis is unknown but is thought to be related to disuse and neural factors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What type of bone is found to be more involved in osteoporosis after SCI?	Trabecular bone has been found to be involved more than cortical bone.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
When is a new steady state achieved between bone resorption and formation after SCI?	A new steady state is achieved about 2 years following SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What can clinical management of bone metabolism in SCI patients include?	Clinical management can include treatment with calcium phosphate, Vitamin D, calcitonin, and bisphosphonates, as well as functional stimulated exercises.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is heterotopic ossification (HO)?	Heterotopic ossification (HO) is the formation of lamellar bone at an abnormal anatomical site, usually in soft tissue, due to the metaplasia of mesenchymal cells into osteoblasts.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How common is HO after SCI?	HO is common after SCI, affecting up to half of patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
When does HO typically begin following injury?	HO begins at approximately 12 weeks following injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
Who is at a higher risk of developing HO?	Those with complete lesions, and those who experience other complications such as spasticity, UTIs, and pneumonia have a higher risk of developing HO.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is the most common site of HO in SCI patients?	The hip is the most common site of HO in SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What percentage of HO patients experience symptoms?	Symptoms occur in less than 20% of patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are some symptoms of HO?	Symptoms can include pain, decreased ROM, and inflammation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is a highly sensitive diagnostic tool for HO?	A triple-phase bone scan is highly sensitive and may be positive well before plain radiographs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What does the initial treatment for HO include?	Initial treatment includes gentle passive ROM of the affected joint and NSAIDs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What have some studies shown to be useful in the treatment of HO?	Some studies have shown bisphosphonates may also be useful.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is a surgical option for HO, and what is a potential issue with this option?	Surgical excision is an option (after HO maturation), but recurrence rates are high.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What common complication of SCI is associated with increased risk factors such as obesity and impaired glucose metabolism?	Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is an increasingly common complication of SCI, associated with increased risk factors such as obesity, abnormal lipid profiles, and impaired glucose metabolism.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What does morbidity and mortality from CVD exceed in the chronic SCI population?	Morbidity and mortality from CVD exceed those caused by pulmonary or renal conditions in the chronic SCI population.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What can upper-tract follow-up for long-term routine urinary tract surveillance include?	Upper-tract follow-up can include renal scan with glomerular filtration rate (GFR) or renal scan with 24-hour Cr clearance yearly to follow renal function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What can renal and bladder ultrasound detect, and how often should it be done?	Renal and bladder ultrasound can detect hydronephrosis and stones and should be done annually.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
When should urodynamics be included in lower-tract evaluation?	Urodynamics should be included once the bladder starts exhibiting uninhibited contractions (or at around 3 to 6 months post-injury) and then as determined by the clinician (often done annually).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How often should routine cystoscopy be performed for patients with chronic indwelling catheter use?	Routine cystoscopy should be performed annually as patients approach 10 years of chronic indwelling catheter use, or sooner (e.g., after 5 years) if there are additional risk factors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are the additional risk factors that might warrant earlier cystoscopy?	Additional risk factors include being a heavy smoker, age &gt; 40 years, and a history of many UTIs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How often is posttraumatic syringomyelia seen clinically in posttraumatic SCI patients?	Posttraumatic syringomyelia may be seen clinically in nearly 3% to 8% of posttraumatic SCI patients, or in up to 20% on autopsy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How soon can posttraumatic syringomyelia develop post-SCI?	It can develop as early as 2 months post-SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are the symptoms of posttraumatic syringomyelia?	Symptoms include pain (often worsened by coughing or straining, but not by lying supine) and worsening neurological function (e.g., ascending sensory loss, progressive weakness including bulbar muscles, increased sweating, orthostasis, and Horner’s syndrome).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is the usual treatment for posttraumatic syringomyelia?	Treatment is usually observational, with surgical interventions considered for large, progressive lesions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What percentage of women with SCI can achieve orgasm?	About 44% to 55% of women with SCI can achieve orgasm.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
When does menses typically return post-SCI for women?	Menses typically returns within 6 months post-SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How is reproductive function affected in women with SCI?	Reproductive function is preserved.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
Why is pregnancy in women with SCI usually classified as high risk?	Pregnancy is classified as high risk due to high rates of complications, including autonomic dysreflexia (AD), infections, and spasticity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are the risks associated with pregnancy in women with SCI?	The incidence of prematurity and small-for-date infants is high, but there is no increase in spontaneous abortions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is recommended during delivery for patients with SCI at T6 or above to prevent AD?	Spinal anesthesia is recommended during delivery for patients with SCI at T6 or above to prevent AD.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What percentage of patients with SCI at T6 or above develop AD during labor?	85% of patients with SCI at T6 or above have been observed to develop AD during labor.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What type of erections can usually be achieved with complete upper motor neuron SCI in males?	Reflexogenic erections can usually be achieved.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How common is ejaculation in males with complete upper motor neuron SCI?	Ejaculation is rare.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What can males with incomplete SCI often achieve regarding sexual function?	Males with incomplete SCI can often achieve reflexogenic erections, and some can achieve psychogenic erections; ejaculation is less rare than for those with complete SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are the sexual function outcomes for males with complete or incomplete injuries below T11?	Complete or incomplete injuries below T11 may result in erections of poor quality and duration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are the treatment options for erectile dysfunction (ED) in males with SCI?	Treatment options include medications, assistive devices, and surgical prosthetic implants.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What medications have been shown to improve ED and patient satisfaction in males with SCI?	Phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil, and vardenafil) have been shown to improve ED and patient satisfaction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are some contraindications for PDE-5 inhibitors?	Contraindications include use of organic nitrates and some alpha blockers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is an effective but invasive treatment for ED in males with SCI?	Direct self-injection of alprostadil (prostaglandin E1) into the corpus cavernosum is highly effective but invasive and carries risks of priapism and penile fibrosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
Why is infertility common after SCI in males?	Infertility is common due to factors such as retrograde ejaculation and poor sperm quantity and motility.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are the requirements for penile vibratory stimulation for ejaculation?	Penile vibratory stimulation for ejaculation requires resolution of spinal shock and an intact ejaculatory reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What is another option for achieving ejaculation in males with SCI, and what does it require?	Electroejaculation (seminal vesicle and prostatic stimulation through the rectum) is another option, which requires general anesthesia for those without a complete SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How is the ejaculate used after electroejaculation?	The ejaculate is collected and processed for intrauterine or in vitro fertilization.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What are the options for restoring triceps function in patients with C5 or C6 SCI?	Triceps function can be restored using a posterior deltoid-to-triceps or a biceps-to-triceps transfer.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
What procedure can restore lateral key grip in a patient with C6 SCI?	The modified Moberg procedure can restore lateral key grip, which involves attachment of the brachioradialis (C5, C6) to the flexor pollicis longus (C8, T1) and stabilization of the thumb carpometacarpal and IP joints.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury RehabReadyTags::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Selected_Issues_SCI
How many people sustained a TBI in 2010?	In 2010, ~2.5 million people sustained a TBI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Introduction_Epidemiology
According to the most recent report to Congress in 2015, what were the most common causes of TBI?	Falls (40.5%), unintentional blunt trauma (15.5%), motor vehicle accidents (MVAs) (14.3%), and assaults (10.7%).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Introduction_Epidemiology
Which age group had the highest rates of hospitalization and death due to TBI?	Adults aged ≥75 years																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Introduction_Epidemiology
What is one of the most preventable causes of TBI?	Alcohol use 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Introduction_Epidemiology
What is Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) and how does it occur?	Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) is the shearing of axons secondary to acceleration-deceleration, rotational forces, and differences in tissue density between the white and gray matter on impact.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What are the effects of Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)?	Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) may cause petechial hemorrhages primarily in the white matters of the brain (corpus callosum, parasagittal white matter, midbrain, pons)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What is a cerebral contusion and how does it occur?	A cerebral contusion is the result of coup–contrecoup injury involving rapid acceleration/deceleration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
Which brain regions are primarily affected by a cerebral contusion?	The orbital/inferior frontal and anterior temporal lobes																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What is a Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH) and how does it occur?	Subdural Hemorrhages (SDHs) are crescent shaped and are the most common bleed in TBI that are due to shearing of bridging veins or arterial vessel damage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
Why are Subdural Hemorrhages (SDHs) more common in the elderly?	SDHs are more common in the elderly due to cerebral atrophy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What is an Epidural Hemorrhage and how does it occur?	An Epidural Hemorrhage is elliptical in shape and commonly due to injury of the middle meningeal artery and a related temporal fracture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
Why can an Epidural Hemorrhage be clinically misleading?	There may be a lucid interval																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What is a Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) and what can it lead to?	A Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) occurs between the pia and the arachnoid space and can lead to hydrocephalus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What causes penetrating injuries in the context of TBI?	Penetrating injuries may be due to localized injuries such as gunshots or shrapnel.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What characterizes secondary injury in TBI?	Secondary injury occurs in response to the primary injury, in hours to days after the TBI. There may be biochemical changes, inflammatory changes, ischemia, hypoxia, or anoxia related to hypoperfusion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What types of edema can occur as a result of TBI and why?	Vasogenic (extracellular) and cytogenic (intracellular) edema may be a result of disruption of the blood–brain barrier, damaged blood vessels, and cytoskeletal membrane integrity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What is the role of biomarkers in TBI?	Biomarkers are currently being developed to identify the presence or extent of brain injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Pathophysiology
What are the three components of the Glasgow Coma scale?	Eye opening, verbal response, and motor response																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What are the categories of TBI severity based on structural imaging?	Mild: Normal, Moderate: Normal or abnormal, Severe: Normal or abnormal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What are the categories of TBI severity based on loss of consciousness?	Mild: &lt;30 minutes, Moderate: 30 minutes–24 hours, Severe: &gt;24 hours.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What are the categories of TBI severity based on alteration of consciousness/mental state?	Mild: &lt;24 hours, Moderate: &gt;24 hours, Severe: &gt;24 hours.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What are the categories of TBI severity based on the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)?	Mild: 13–15, Moderate: 8–12, Severe: 3–8.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What are the categories of TBI severity based on post-traumatic amnesia?	Mild: 0–1 day, Moderate: 1–7 days, Severe: &gt;7 days.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What is post-traumatic amnesia (PTA)?	Post-traumatic amnesia (PTA) is the inability to retain memory after the TBI, such as day-to-day information or ongoing events.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
How is post-traumatic amnesia (PTA) measured?	It is measured by using the Galveston Orientation Amnesia Test (GOAT) or the Orientation Log (O-Log).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What is the Galveston Orientation Amnesia Test (GOAT)?	The GOAT is a series of questions related to orientation and recall of recent events.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What is the Orientation Log (O-Log) and how does it compare to the GOAT?	The O-Log was developed as an alternative to the GOAT and appears to be a better predictor of outcome.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What marks the end of post-traumatic amnesia (PTA)?	The end of PTA is marked by a score of ≥75 on the GOAT or ≥25 on the O-Log on two consecutive days.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What is the Rancho Los Amigos Cognitive Functioning Scale?	The Rancho Los Amigos Cognitive Functioning Scale helps provide generalized descriptions of behaviors commonly seen in TBI patients as recovery progresses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Classification_TBI_Severity
What are some processes influenced by neuroplasticity?	Processes influenced by neuroplasticity include the unmasking of existing connections, long-term potentiation, long-term depression, axonal and dendritic sprouting, and synaptogenesis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What can maladaptive changes result in?	Maladaptive changes can result in negative consequences such as spasticity and seizures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What is diaschisis?	Diaschisis is a decrease in function of an area of uninjured brain that is connected with an area of injured brain due to functional deafferentation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
How does reduction in diaschisis occur?	Gradual reduction in diaschisis occurs through natural neuroplasticity and improved cerebral blood flow.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What is compensation in the context of TBI recovery?	Compensation is the use of alternative strategies to restore lost function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
How are outcomes following TBI commonly measured?	Outcomes following TBI are commonly measured using the Disability Rating Scale (DRS).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What is the Disability Rating Scale (DRS)?	The Disability Rating Scale (DRS) is intended to measure general functional changes over the course of recovery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What does the Disability Rating Scale (DRS) measure?	The Disability Rating Scale (DRS) measures impairment, disability, and handicap.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What factors are associated with worse outcomes in TBI patients?	Factors associated with worse outcomes include age ≤4 years and ≥65 years; presence of brain stem reflexes such as dilated pupils, impaired Doll’s eye, no deviation with caloric testing, and decerebrate &gt; decorticate posturing; lower Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score; bilateral &gt; unilateral findings on brain imaging (brain stem &gt; cerebral); longer duration in a poor arousal state; longer duration of PTA; flaccidity and spasticity; incontinence; lower Functional Independent Measure (FIM) Score; and absence of N20 response on somatosensory evoked potential (SEP).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What is severe disability unlikely when PTA is less than?	Severe disability is unlikely when PTA is &lt; 2 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What is good recovery unlikely when PTA is greater than?	Good recovery is unlikely when PTA is &gt; 3 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Recovery_Outcomes
What is consciousness?	Consciousness is a state of arousal where there is awareness of self and environment, as well as responses to the environment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Disorders_Consciousness
What are coma and vegetative state clinical manifestations of?	Coma and vegetative state are clinical manifestations of damage to the arousal center, the reticular activating system (RAS), and its projections to the cortex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Disorders_Consciousness
What is associated with a longer duration of coma?	A longer duration of coma is associated with a worse outcome.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Disorders_Consciousness
When is severe disability unlikely in relation to coma duration?	Severe disability is unlikely when coma lasts less than 2 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Disorders_Consciousness
When is good recovery unlikely in relation to coma duration?	Good recovery is unlikely when coma lasts longer than 4 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Disorders_Consciousness
What is the JFK Coma Recovery Scale-Revised (CRS-R) helpful for?	The JFK Coma Recovery Scale-Revised (CRS-R) was designed to help differentiate between the vegetative state and MCS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Disorders_Consciousness
How many items are in the JFK Coma Recovery Scale-Revised (CRS-R)?	It is a 23-item scale.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Disorders_Consciousness
What does the JFK Coma Recovery Scale-Revised (CRS-R) measure?	The JFK Coma Recovery Scale-Revised (CRS-R) measures function across six subscales (auditory, visual, motor, oromotor/verbal, communication, and arousal responses), which are hierarchically arranged to correspond to brain stem, subcortical, and cortical functions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Disorders_Consciousness
What role does intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring play in early TBI care?	Intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring may play a role in early TBI care, although there is a lack of high-quality data indicating that routine ICP monitoring in TBI improves clinical outcomes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Acute_Management_TBI
What is the rationale behind ICP monitoring?	The rationale of ICP monitoring is that increased ICPs cause decrease in cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP = mean arterial pressure – ICP).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Acute_Management_TBI
What factors may increase ICP?	ICP may be increased by temperature, stress, stimuli, elevated BP, lying supine, suctioning, or aggressive physical therapy (PT).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Acute_Management_TBI
When is an external ventricular drain placed in TBI patients?	An external ventricular drain is placed in the setting of severe brain injury (e.g., GCS ≤8) when accompanied by edema, compressed basilar cisterns, or clinical decline.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Acute_Management_TBI
How can increased ICPs be managed?	Elevating the head, using diuretics (mannitol) or hypertonic saline, barbiturates/sedatives, neurosurgical decompression with a craniectomy/craniotomy (morbidity can be higher in the elderly), or hyperventilation (used cautiously).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Acute_Management_TBI
What is the normal range of ICP?	The normal range of ICP is 2–5 mmHg.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Acute_Management_TBI
What does treatment of coma and vegetative state generally focus on?	Treatment generally focuses on sensory stimulation (auditory, sensory, vibratory, etc.) and the use of stimulants.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Coma_Veg_State
What stimulants are used in the treatment?	Methylphenidate, amantadine, dopamine agonists, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Coma_Veg_State
What secondary complications should be prevented?	Secondary complications such as skin breakdown and contractures should be prevented.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Coma_Veg_State
What is one of the most common symptoms after a TBI?	Sleep disturbance																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is the first-line management for sleep disturbance after a TBI?	Proper sleep hygiene is first-line management.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
How can regular sleep–wake cycles be reestablished?	By maintaining a schedule, avoiding caffeine and exercise late in the day, and promoting a quiet, restful environment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What should be addressed to improve sleep in TBI patients?	Medication side effects, pain, and other factors inhibiting sleep should be addressed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is the second-line management for sleep disturbance after a TBI?	Medication, starting with melatonin (3–9 mg), which is over-the-counter (OTC).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is Ramelteon?	A melatonin receptor agonist that is more expensive and requires a prescription, but is not necessarily more effective than melatonin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is Trazodone and its common dosage for sleep disturbance in TBI patients?	Trazodone is another common alternative for sleep disturbance, with a dosage of 25–150 mg.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Why should Zolpidem and other “Z-drugs” be avoided in TBI patients?	Because they have benzodiazepine-like sedative/hypnotic effects																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Why should antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) be avoided in TBI patients?	Because they can interfere with memory and new learning.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What stimulants are commonly used to improve alertness in TBI patients?	Amantadine (100–200 mg) and methylphenidate (5–20 mg)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Is methylphenidate safe for patients at risk for seizures?	Yes, methylphenidate does not lower the seizure threshold and is safe for patients at risk for seizure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What other medications can improve alertness and memory in TBI patients?	Bromocriptine (typically 2.5–7.5 mg bid), modafinil, carbidopa, and donepezil can also improve alertness and memory.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is Paroxysmal autonomic instability with dystonia (PAID) syndrome?	A constellation of symptoms consisting of tachycardia, elevated BP, tachypnea, fever, diaphoresis, and dystonia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
How is PAID syndrome treated?	Treatment includes minimizing stressors, addressing underlying medical issues and complications, and using cooling blankets.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What medications are commonly used to treat PAID syndrome?	NSAIDs, lipophilic beta-blockers, bromocriptine, and amantadine for their effect on the hypothalamus, lioresal for spasticity, and dantrolene for malignant hyperthermia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What may cause tachycardia and hypertension in TBI patients?	Catecholamine release and/or deconditioning.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is an option for treating tachycardia and hypertension in TBI patients?	Beta-blockers																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is recommended to preserve joint mobility and prevent secondary complications in TBI patients?	Early and aggressive range of motion therapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Why should typical oral antispasticity medications be avoided in TBI patients?	Due to their side effects.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is an option for local antispasticity treatment in TBI patients?	Botulinum toxin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Which cranial nerve injury is most common and commonly missed in TBI patients?	CN I (olfactory) injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Why should all patients with a TBI be tested for CN I injury?	Because it can affect eating/nutrition.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is the recovery prognosis for CN I injury in TBI patients?	1/3 will regain full CN I function; 1/3 will recover some function; 1/3 will not recover.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Which cranial nerves are commonly injured in TBI patients?	CN I (olfactory), CN VII (facial), and VIII (vestibulocochlear).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is the first-line management of agitation in a TBI patient? 	Optimizing the environment and ruling out other causes of agitation such as medications, hunger, pain, fatigue, seizure, etc. 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What medications can be used for agitations as a second-line measure?	Mood stabilizers (valproic acid, lamotrigine, carbamazapine), atypical antipsychotics (risperidone, olanzapine, quetiapine), antidepressants (SSRIs, buspirone), and lipophilic beta-blockers (propanolol, carvedilol, labetolol)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What are the screenig recommendations for neuroendocrine dysfunction after a TBI?	At 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What labs should be monitored for screening of neuroendocrine dysfunction after TBI?	AM cortisol, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), leutinizing hormone (LH), testosterone, prolactin, insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1), estradiol, and a thyroid panel																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Which electrolyte abnormaility is common after TBI?	Sodium abnormalities																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
How is SIADH treated?	Free water restriction; in more severe cases, hypertonic saline infusion may be required																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What medication is used to treat chronic SIADH?	Demeclocyline (an ADH inhibitor)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What is the treatment for cerebral salt wasting syndrome? 	hydration with isotonic saline																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
What causes Diabetes Insipidus?	Severe damage to the pituitary, with ADH deficiency resulting in reduced total body water																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
How is Diabetes Insipidus treated?	Vasopressin																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Which medications are recommended as anti-seizure prophylaxis for 1 week after moderate-to-severe TBI?	Valproic acid or Levetiracetam																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Which medication is recommended for partial seizures?	Carbamazepine																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
Which medication is recommended for generalized seizures?	Valproic Acid																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
How should late seizures (occuring after day post-TBI) be managed?	With long-term anticonvulsants																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::TBI RehabReadyTags::TBI::Treatment_Medical_Complications_TBI
How is stroke classically characterized?	Neurological deficit attributed to an acute focal injury of the central nervous system by a vascular cause, including cerebral infarction, intracerebral hemorrhage, and subarachnoid hemorrhage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Epidemology_Risk_Factors
What are the two major types of stroke?	Ischemic (87%) and hemorrhagic (13%).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Epidemology_Risk_Factors
What are the percentages of different types of strokes?	32% embolic, 31% large vessel thrombotic, 20% small vessel thrombotic, 10% ICH, and 3% SAH.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Epidemology_Risk_Factors
How are stroke risk factors classified?	Modifiable and non-modifiable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Epidemology_Risk_Factors
What are non-modifiable risk factors for stroke?	Non-modifiable factors include age, race (African Americans &gt; Whites), and family history.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Epidemology_Risk_Factors
What are some modifiable risk factors for stroke?	Modifiable risk factors include hypertension (HTN), transient ischemic attack (TIA) or prior stroke, heart disease, atrial fibrillation, smoking, hyperlipidemia, carotid disease, diabetes mellitus (DM), hypercoagulable states, substance abuse, and physical inactivity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Epidemology_Risk_Factors
How does the risk of stroke differ between men and women?	The risk of stroke is higher for men compared to women in those younger than 75 years of age, but it becomes more common in women at age 75 years and greater.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Epidemology_Risk_Factors
What is the leading cause of long-term disability in the United States?	Stroke remains the leading cause of long-term disability in the United States.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Epidemology_Risk_Factors
What deficits can occur with a Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) stroke?	Deficits can include contralateral hemiplegia/hypesthesia (face and arm worse than leg), contralateral homonymous hemianopia, and ipsilateral gaze preference.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What additional deficits may be seen with a dominant hemisphere MCA stroke?	Receptive aphasia (inferior division of MCA to Wernicke’s area) and/or expressive aphasia (superior division of MCA to Broca’s area).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What additional deficits may be seen with a nondominant hemisphere MCA stroke?	Spatial neglect and anosognosia (lack of awareness or insight).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
"What is Gerstmann&#x27;s syndrome?"	"Gerstmann&#x27;s syndrome (parietal lobe) consists of dyscalculia, finger agnosia, dysgraphia, and inability to distinguish between right and left side of one&#x27;s body."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What deficits can occur with an Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) stroke?	Deficits can include contralateral hemiplegia/hypesthesia (leg worse than arm; face and hand spared), alien arm/hand syndrome, urinary incontinence, gait apraxia, abulia (lack of will or initiative), perseveration, amnesia, paratonic rigidity (Gegenhalten, or variable resistance to passive ROM), and transcortical motor aphasia (with a dominant hemisphere ACA lesion).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What deficits can occur with a Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) stroke?	Deficits can include contralateral homonymous hemianopia, contralateral hemianesthesia, contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemiataxia, and vertical gaze palsy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What are the consequences of dominant-sided lesions in a PCA stroke?	Dominant-sided lesions can lead to amnesia, color anomia, dyslexia without agraphia, and simultagnosia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What are the consequences of nondominant-sided lesions in a PCA stroke?	Nondominant-sided lesions can lead to prosopagnosia (cannot recognize familiar faces).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What is Anton syndrome?	Anton syndrome (cortical blindness, with denial) can occur with a bilateral PCA stroke.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
"What is Balint&#x27;s syndrome?"	"Balint&#x27;s syndrome consists of optic ataxia, loss of voluntary but not reflex eye movements, and an inability to understand visual objects (asimultagnosia)."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What is Déjerine-Roussy syndrome?	Déjerine-Roussy or thalamic pain syndrome can occur with involvement of the thalamogeniculate branch.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
"What is Weber&#x27;s syndrome?"	"Weber&#x27;s syndrome (penetrating branches to the midbrain) consists of ipsilateral cranial nerve III palsy and contralateral limb weakness."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What are the symptoms of lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome?	Symptoms include vertigo, nystagmus, dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome, ipsilateral facial pain or numbness, ipsilateral limb ataxia, and contralateral pain and temperature sensory loss.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What is &quot;locked-in&quot; syndrome?	&quot;Locked-in&quot; syndrome (basilar artery) is due to bilateral pontine infarcts affecting the corticospinal and bulbar tracts, but sparing the reticular activating system. Patients are awake and sensate, but paralyzed and unable to speak. Voluntary blinking and vertical gaze may be intact.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What is Millard-Gubler syndrome?	Millard-Gubler syndrome is a unilateral lesion of the ventrocaudal pons that may involve the basis pontis and the fascicles of cranial nerves VI and VII. Symptoms include contralateral hemiplegia, ipsilateral lateral rectus palsy, and ipsilateral peripheral facial paresis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What are the more common lacunar syndromes?	Pure motor hemiplegia (posterior limb internal capsule [IC]), pure sensory stroke (thalamus or parietal white matter), the dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome (basis pontis), and the hemiparesis-hemiataxia syndrome (pons, midbrain, IC, or parietal white matter).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What causes &quot;pseudobulbar palsy&quot;?	&quot;Pseudobulbar palsy&quot; is caused by anterior internal capsule and corticobulbar pathway lacunes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Selected_Ischemic_Stroke_Syndromes
What is indicated for acute ischemic stroke within 3 hours of symptom onset?	IV tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is indicated for acute ischemic stroke within 3 hours of symptom onset.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What did the 2009 and 2013 AHA/ASA guidelines revise regarding tPA administration?	They revised to expand the window of treatment from 3 hours to 4.5 hours with additional exclusion criteria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
In what highly selective group of patients is intra-arterial fibrinolysis considered?	Considered in patients with major ischemic strokes of &lt;6 hours duration caused by occlusion of the MCA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What are absolute contraindications for the use of tPA?	Head CT positive for blood, severe uncontrolled HTN, BP &gt;185/110, head trauma or stroke in the previous 3 months, thrombocytopenia, platelet count &lt;100k, coagulopathy, INR &gt;1.7, PT &gt;15 seconds, treatment with therapeutic dose of LMWH, direct thrombin inhibitors or Factor Xa inhibitors within the past 24 hours, and blood sugar &lt;50 or &gt;400.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What are relative contraindications for the use of tPA?	Age &gt;80 years, mild/improving stroke symptoms, severe stroke/coma, major surgery within the past 14 days, GI or GU bleed within the past 21 days, seizure at time of stroke onset, MI within the past 3 months, and history of CNS structural lesion (e.g., intracranial neoplasm, AVM, aneurysm).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What is recommended within 24 to 48 hours for patients with acute ischemic strokes not receiving thrombolytics or anticoagulation?	Aspirin is recommended within 24 to 48 hours for these patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What is not recommended as an adjunctive therapy within 24 hours of intravenous thrombolysis?	The administration of acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) or other antiplatelet agents is not recommended.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
With what can aspirin be safely used for DVT prophylaxis?	Low-dose SC heparin or LMWH for DVT prophylaxis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
When is anticoagulation considered in the appropriate clinical settings?	Anticoagulation is considered but not recommended within 24 hours after administration of tPA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
Why may elevated BPs have a protective role initially after a stroke?	Improve perfusion to the ischemic (but un-infarcted) penumbra (Permissive HTN)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What is the goal of &quot;permissive hypertension&quot; after a stroke?	Optimize blood flow during this period.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What do AHA/ASA guidelines recommend regarding antihypertensive therapy within the first 24 hours after symptom onset?	Antihypertensive therapy is not recommended unless SBP &gt;220 and/or DBP &gt;120.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
When should antihypertensive therapy be resumed or started according to AHA/ASA guidelines?	After the initial 24-hour period.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What does the literature generally indicate regarding tighter BP control after the initial 24-hour period?	Prevents recurrent stroke.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What is critical for secondary stroke prevention?	Education on applicable lifestyle and risk factor modifications.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What antiplatelet agents are considered for non-cardioembolic cerebral ischemic events?	ASA, clopidogrel, or a combination of ASA and dipyridamole (Aggrenox).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What is recommended for cardioembolic cerebral ischemic events?	Oral anticoagulation with a target INR of 2.5 (range 2.0–3.0).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What novel treatments are available for secondary stroke prophylaxis?	Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) are now available.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What is considered first-line treatment in secondary stroke prophylaxis?	Statins																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What did the North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial (NASCET) demonstrate?	6 to 10 times reduction in the long-term risk of stroke following carotid endarterectomy (CEA) versus medical management alone for patients with recent stroke or TIA with extracranial internal carotid artery stenosis of 70% to 99%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What was largely dependent on the skill of the surgeon in the NASCET trial?	The benefit of carotid endarterectomy																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
When is carotid endarterectomy indicated?	Stenosis &gt;70%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What condition is relatively common in the general population but has a higher prevalence in patients with cryptogenic stroke?	Patent foramen ovale (PFO).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What should be strongly considered in young patients with cryptogenic stroke?	Paradoxical embolism through a PFO.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
