What are treatment options for PFO?	Treatment options include antiplatelet agents, warfarin, percutaneous device closure, and surgical closure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Ischemic_Stroke_Pharm_Intervention
What are the major causes of death after stroke?	The stroke itself (i.e., recurrent stroke, progressive cerebral edema, and herniation), pneumonia, cardiac disease, and pulmonary embolism (PE).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Postacute_Medical_Complications
What complications are noted during the postacute stroke rehabilitation period?	Pneumonia and pulmonary aspiration, falls, urinary incontinence, DVT, musculoskeletal pain, and central poststroke pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Postacute_Medical_Complications
What typically happens to urinary incontinence post-stroke?	Typically improves but may still be present in 15% to 20% after 6 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Postacute_Medical_Complications
What are some treatments for urinary incontinence post-stroke?	Timed voiding, fluid intake regulation, and treatment of urinary tract infections (UTIs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Postacute_Medical_Complications
What is the prevalence of glenohumeral subluxation in post-stroke patients?	30% to 50% of patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Postacute_Medical_Complications
How can post-stroke shoulder pain be managed during the early rehabilitation phase?	Use of an arm trough or lapboard while sitting, stretching of the shoulder depressors/internal rotators, and avoiding pulling on the affected arm during transfers. Functional electrical stimulation is also frequently used as a treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Postacute_Medical_Complications
What can be helpful if spasticity becomes severe post-stroke?	A subscapularis phenol/botulinum toxin injection can sometimes be helpful if spasticity becomes severe.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Postacute_Medical_Complications
What were the main findings noted by Twitchell in motor recovery after a stroke?	Development of tone and “stereotypic” movements, characterized by a tight coupling of movement at adjacent joints (later termed “synergy” by Brunnstrom), before isolated voluntary motor control was reestablished.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
How does motor control return following a stroke?	Proximally before distally and lower limb function recovers earlier and more completely than upper limb function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
When is full recovery from a stroke usually complete?	Full recovery, when it occurs, is usually complete within 12 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
What are traditional physiotherapeutic approaches used in stroke rehabilitation?	Neurodevelopmental treatment (NDT)/Bobath approach, proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF), and the Brunnstrom approach.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
What do traditional physiotherapeutic approaches focus on?	Stimulating movement when there is weakness/inactivity, inhibiting excessive tone/primitive patterns of movement, and facilitating functional movement patterns.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
Have traditional physiotherapeutic approaches been shown to be superior to modern stroke rehabilitation approaches?	Recent systematic reviews have not shown superiority of traditional physiotherapeutic approaches over more modern stroke rehabilitation approaches.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
What techniques have traditional gait training approaches shown non-superiority or inferiority to?	Traditional gait training approaches have shown non-superiority or inferiority to techniques such as electromyography (EMG) biofeedback, functional training, and body weight–supported treadmill training.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
What are the strongest therapy recommendations in the 2016 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Adult Stroke Rehabilitation and Recovery?	Intensive, repetitive, task-specific training; activities of daily living (ADL) and instrumental activities of daily living (IADL) training tailored to individual needs; and the implementation of appropriate orthoses and other adaptive equipment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
What type of exercises complement task-specific training in stroke rehabilitation?	Strengthening exercises																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
What is Constraint-Induced Movement Therapy (CIMT)?	Therapy that forces a patient to use the affected limb by restraining the unaffected one.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
What does neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) training use and is it recommended?	NMES training uses elements of task-specific training and is generally recommended.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Motor_Recovery_Following_Stroke
What is the overall prognosis for a stroke survivor?	The prognosis for a stroke survivor, overall, is generally good.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What percentage of stroke survivors walk within a year following stroke?	Approximately 80%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What percentage of stroke survivors recover normal swallowing?	85%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What percentage of stroke survivors are able to return to work?	40%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What percentage of stroke survivors are able to return home?	90%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What did the Auckland Stroke Outcomes Study show about the functional outcome of five-year stroke survivors?	Two-thirds had a good functional outcome, defined as a Modified Rankin Scale (MRS) score &lt;3.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What is the Modified Rankin Scale (MRS)?	Outcomes measure for neurological conditions, a 7-point (0–6) ordinal scale, where 0 is no symptoms, 1 is some symptoms but no significant disability, 2 is a slight disability but independent, 3 is a moderate disability requiring some help but able to walk independently, 4 is a moderately severe disability, 5 is a severe disability requiring constant nursing care, and 6 is dead.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What were the findings of the Auckland Study regarding cognitive impairment, recurrent stroke, institutionalization, and depression in five-year stroke survivors?	22.5% had cognitive impairment indicative of dementia, 20% had experienced a recurrent stroke, almost 15% were institutionalized, and 29.6% had symptoms suggesting depression.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What remains the leading cause of long-term disability among adults?	Stroke 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What is generally the most important factor in both neurologic and functional recovery after a stroke?	Initial stroke recovery is generally the most important factor.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
How does neurological recovery compare to functional recovery in terms of timing?	Neurological recovery precedes functional recovery by 2 weeks on average.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
By when is the best neurological recovery seen for 95% of patients?	The best neurological recovery is seen by 11 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
By when is most ADL recovery (by Barthel Index) seen with therapy?	Most ADL recovery is seen by 12.5 weeks with therapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
When does the greatest proportion of recovery in ischemic strokes occur?	3 to 6 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
How long may some patients experience improvement after an ischemic stroke?	Some patients may experience improvement for up to 18 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What factors affect outcome after stroke?	Age, stroke locus, stroke type/severity, comorbidities, complications, acute interventions received (e.g., tPA), and whether an individual received stroke unit care and rehabilitation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What did Paolucci et al. report regarding the functional prognosis in stroke survivors with hemorrhagic versus ischemic stroke?	Better functional prognosis in stroke survivors with hemorrhagic stroke versus ischemic stroke.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What have the Copenhagen Stroke Studies reported about morbidity/mortality and rehabilitation outcomes?	Morbidity/mortality and rehabilitation outcomes are positively affected by special stroke units versus general medical or neurologic units.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What did the Very Early Rehabilitation Trial (AVERT) report about earlier and more intensive mobilization after stroke?	Earlier and more intensive mobilization after stroke is both feasible and improves walking and functional recovery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What did a follow-up RCT by the AVERT group report about a high-dose very early mobilization protocol?	High-dose very early mobilization protocol was associated with reduced odds of a favorable outcome at 3 months (where favorable outcome was defined as MRS &lt;3).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Stroke RehabReadyTags::Stroke::Functional_Outcomes_Following_Stroke
What is frailty related to?	age- and disease-related loss of adaptation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is sarcopenia?	Sarcopenia is an age-related decrease in skeletal muscle mass and function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What decreases with aging in terms of muscle?	Motor unit numbers decrease with aging.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
Which muscle fibers are lost at a greater rate with aging?	Fast-twitch fibers are lost at a greater rate than slow-twitch fibers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is generally associated with sarcopenia?	There is a general association with increased fat mass and abdominal girth.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is the nature of bone tissue?	Bone is a dynamic tissue that undergoes continual remodeling.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What do osteoclasts and osteoblasts do?	Osteoclasts resorb old bone, and osteoblasts form new bone in its place.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does aging affect bone turnover?	There is a reduction in bone turnover rate with aging.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is the effect of reduced bone turnover markers?	It evidences a reduction in bone turnover rate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does the bone matrix half-life change with aging?	The bone matrix half-life is increased.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to bone matrix exposure to damage with aging?	Increased bone matrix half-life increases its exposure to damage and reduces its structural integrity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What balance is disrupted in bone turnover with aging?	There is a disruption in the bone turnover balance, with bone resorption favored over formation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What results from the disruption in bone turnover balance with aging?	This results in cortical and trabecular thinning, a decline in bone mass, and an increased risk of fractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is the function of articular cartilage?	Articular cartilage absorbs compressive loads at joints and withstands shear forces.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What gives articular cartilage its function?	Its function is derived from the extracellular matrix (ECM).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What does the ECM contain?	The ECM contains large hydrophilic proteoglycans.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to proteoglycans when compressed?	Proteoglycans release water when compressed but quickly resorb it back with pressure release.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What else does the ECM contain for joint motion?	The ECM contains a superficial lubricating layer of hyaluronic acid and lubricin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to the ECM with aging?	There is loss of ECM volume and changes in its composition.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does the ECM change with aging?	The ECM undergoes loss and degradation of proteoglycans, increases in collagen cross-links, changes in the superficial lubricating layer, and deposition of calcium crystals.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is the net biomechanical result of ECM changes with aging?	The result is increased stiffness, susceptibility to mechanical failure, and other clinical manifestations of osteoarthropathy/articular degenerative joint disease (DJD).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
Why is DJD common with aging?	DJD is common because the ECM is maintained by chondrocytes, which have a low replication rate, making them susceptible to accumulation of cellular damage and dysfunction over time.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What are common age-related anatomical changes in the neurologic system?	Reduced brain size and weight, primarily due to cortical volume loss.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to the neurologic system with aging?	There is neuronal loss and loss of synaptic interconnectivity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to neurotransmitter production with aging?	decrease																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does brain function change with aging?	Brain function generally remains stable for most of adulthood but declines after a certain age.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What cognitive abilities are typically affected first with aging?	Short-term memory and new learning are typically affected first.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What other changes occur in the neurologic system with aging?	There are slower reaction times, speed of learning, and decreased acuity of the special senses (vision, hearing, balance, smell, and taste).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What may cause age-related visual impairment?	Decreased lens adaptability and/or accumulation of age-related conditions such as macular degeneration, cataracts, and glaucoma.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is presbycusis?	 sensorineural hearing loss caused by aging, characterized by a decreased ability to perceive and discriminate sounds, with higher-pitched frequencies typically lost first.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What are protective mechanisms against functional loss in the CNS?	Redundancy of cells and synaptic connections, synaptogenesis, and neurogenesis, particularly in the hippocampus and basal ganglia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How can physical exercise affect the brain with aging?	Physical exercise can be protective against neuronal loss in areas of the brain involved in memory.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What factors are likely to cause faster or greater neuronal loss with aging?	Alcohol, smoking, and cerebrovascular disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What may decreased peripheral nervous system conduction cause with aging?	Decreased sensory function, slower reflexes, and clumsiness.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What changes in gait characteristics are associated with aging?	Increased double limb support, slower speed, shorter stride length, flexed posture, and broader base of support.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What factors should be considered and addressed when assessing gait decline?	Visual impairment, orthostatic hypotension, cardiovascular disease, peripheral arterial disease, Parkinson’s disease, cerebellar degeneration, normal pressure hydrocephalus, vertebrobasilar insufficiency, vestibular disorders, myelopathy, peripheral neuropathy, arthropathy, fear of falling, and medication side effects.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test used for?	The TUG test is used to assess gait and fall risk.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is considered abnormal in the TUG test?	A time of 14 seconds or more is considered abnormal and associated with an increased risk for falls.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What should be done if examinees demonstrate difficulty performing the TUG?	They should be followed up with a formal physical therapy evaluation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What should be addressed in the home environment for the elderly?	Environmental hazards such as poor lighting and slippery surfaces.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How is gait speed associated with survival in the elderly?	Gait speed has been positively associated with survival in the elderly.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What cardiovascular changes are associated with aging?	Decreased arterial compliance and increased systolic blood pressure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to the left ventricle with aging?	hypertrophies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to myocyte numbers with aging?	decrease																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to the intrinsic heart rate with aging?	decrease																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What happens to sinoatrial node conduction time with aging?	increased.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How is the tachycardic response to exercise affected with aging?	decreased																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does maximal heart rate change with aging?	Maximal heart rate decreases by 6 to 10 beats per minute per decade.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does maximal oxygen consumption change with aging?	Maximal oxygen consumption decreases 5% to 15% per decade after the age of 25 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does decreased baroreceptor sensitivity affect the elderly?	It results in orthostatic hypotension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What pulmonary changes are associated with aging?	Decreased lung surface area, resulting in diminished gas exchange and ventilation/perfusion mismatch.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does lung compliance change with aging?	increases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does thoracic wall mobility change with aging?	Thoracic wall mobility decreases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does respiratory muscle strength change with aging?	Respiratory muscle strength decreases, resulting in greater residual volume and functional residual capacity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What gastrointestinal changes are associated with aging?	Decreased basal pepsin and gastric hydrochloric acid production.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does decreased gastric acid production affect the elderly?	It impairs absorption of vitamin B12, Ca, Fe, Zn, and folic acid.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What can decrease food intake in the elderly?	Weakened taste and odor senses, early satiety, prolonged postprandial satiety, and reduced central feeding drive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How do hepatic mass and blood flow change with aging?	Hepatic mass and blood flow progressively decrease, which affects drug clearance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What renal and urological changes are associated with aging?	Decreases in renal mass, nephron number, renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and bladder distensibility.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How do serum creatinine levels change with aging?	Despite the decrease in GFR, serum creatinine levels typically remain within normal limits due to concurrent loss of muscle mass.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
Why can normal creatinine levels be misleading in the elderly?	They can mask an underlying compromise of renal function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does reduced GFR affect drug clearance?	It affects the drug clearance of many agents such as water-soluble antibiotics, water-soluble beta-blockers, digoxin, diuretics, and NSAIDs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How is the ability to concentrate urine affected with aging?	decreased																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
Is urinary incontinence a part of the normal aging process?	Urinary incontinence is common, although it is not part of the normal aging process.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What endocrine changes are associated with aging?	A significant decrease in reproductive hormones, a mild decrease in many other hormones, and reduced sensitivity of hormone receptors in the end organs to circulating hormones.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
Which hormones typically decrease with age?	Aldosterone, renin, growth hormone, insulin-like growth factor-1, calcitonin, melatonin, prolactin, estrogen, and testosterone.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is seen in terms of glucose tolerance with aging?	Decreased glucose tolerance is seen due to increased peripheral insulin resistance and some decreased insulin secretion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How do cortisol, epinephrine, T3, and T4 levels change with aging?	These levels typically remain unchanged or decrease slightly.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the elderly?	Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
Which hormone levels may increase with age?	Norepinephrine and parathyroid hormone levels may increase with age.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
How does skin change with aging?	Skin becomes frailer with a loss of moisture, blood supply, sensation, and elasticity in connective tissue, as well as thinning of the epidermis, decreased cell replacement, impaired immune response, and wound healing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What are the elderly more prone to due to changes in the skin?	skin injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Aging RehabReadyTags::Aging::Introduction
What is osteoarthritis (OA)?	The most prevalent form of arthritis in the United States.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What causes osteoarthritis?	A disruption of the normal process of degradation and synthesis of articular cartilage and subchondral bone.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What factors are implicated in osteoarthritis?	Biomechanical and biologic factors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What are the risk factors for osteoarthritis?	Age, trauma, obesity, and female gender.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
Is joint involvement in osteoarthritis typically symmetric or asymmetric?	Typically asymmetric.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
Which joints are usually involved in osteoarthritis?	Weight-bearing joints.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is secondary OA?	Cartilage destruction considered as secondary to an underlying systemic disease or local injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the pathogenesis of primary OA?	An intrinsic disease of cartilage with biochemical and metabolic alterations resulting in its breakdown.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
Are there genetic associations with primary OA?	Yes, there are several genetic associations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What joints may be affected by primary OA?	Small distal joints of the hands.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What parts of the joint are involved in osteoarthritis progression?	The entire joint, including subchondral bone, ligaments, capsule, synovial membrane, and periarticular muscles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What signaling molecules and cytokines are related to the progression of OA?	Pro-inflammatory cytokines that induce matrix-degrading enzymes while suppressing matrix synthesis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
How is pain characterized in osteoarthritis?	Pain worsened by joint use and stiffness with inactivity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What are the classification criteria for OA of the hand, hip, and knee?	Various combinations of clinical and radiologic features.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is a consistent feature of osteoarthritis?	Evidence of pain at the specified joint with bony swelling and lack of inflammatory markers in a patient &gt;50 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What are the radiologic confirmations for osteoarthritis?	Joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What have strengthening and aerobic exercises shown in OA management?	To reduce pain and disability while improving quality of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What did the Fitness Arthritis and Seniors Trial (FAST) confirm?	The beneficial effects of quadriceps strengthening and aerobic exercise in patients with knee OA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the effect of a decrease of 2 BMI units over 10 years in women above median BMI?	Decreased the odds of developing OA by over 50%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What exercises may be an alternative for patients poorly tolerant of weight-bearing exercises?	Aquatic exercises.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What physical modalities may improve tolerance and compliance with exercises?	Judicious rest between sessions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
How can a cane help in managing hip and knee OA?	By unloading the joint and making ambulation more bearable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What are the benefits of knee unloading braces and lateral heel wedges?	Reducing stress in the medial knee compartment and relieving pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What are some environmental adaptations for osteoarthritis?	Raising toilet and chair heights.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What are the ACR recommendations for nonpharmacologic management of knee and hip OA?	Participating in cardiovascular/resistance land-based exercise, aquatic exercise, losing weight, using walking aids, and using thermal agents.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What are the initial pharmacologic options for knee and hip OA according to the ACR?	Acetaminophen, oral NSAIDs, tramadol, and intra-articular corticosteroids.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the ACR recommendation for patients aged ≥75 years?	Topical NSAIDs as an option for initial management of knee OA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What treatments are conditionally not recommended by the ACR?	Glucosamine, chondroitin sulfate, and topical capsaicin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
When are opioid analgesics recommended for OA?	For patients who have symptomatic knee or hip OA not adequately responding to other therapies and are unable or unwilling to undergo joint replacement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What should practitioners follow for chronic nonmalignant pain management?	American Pain Society/American Academy of Pain Medicine guidelines.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the second line consideration for knee OA after intra-articular corticosteroids?	Intra-articular hyaluronan viscosupplementation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What did Jevsevar et al. note in their 2015 meta-analysis regarding intra-articular hyaluronan?	No clinically important differences over placebo in high quality studies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the promise of glucosamine/chondroitin in OA treatment?	Preliminary studies appeared promising for short-term symptomatic improvement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What were the results of the GAIT trial on glucosamine/chondroitin?	No benefit in pain, function, or radiologic progression in over 1,500 patients with knee OA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the state of research on acupuncture for OA?	Promising but qualitatively suboptimal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What other complementary treatments are being investigated for OA?	Supplementation with vitamin D, antioxidant vitamins, and curcumin–phosphatidylcholine complex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the UniSpacer and its use in OA?	A device for isolated, moderate, medial compartment OA in the knee.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
"What are the early clinical studies&#x27; outcomes on the UniSpacer?"	High revision rates and only modest relief of pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What are DMOADs?	Disease-modifying osteoarthritis drugs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the potential of intra-articular platelet-rich plasma (PRP) for knee OA?	Viable treatment with symptomatic relief for up to 12 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What population benefits most from intra-articular PRP?	Patients with early degenerative changes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is the risk associated with multiple PRP injections?	Increased risk of local adverse reactions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Osteoarthritis
What is rheumatoid arthritis (RA)?	A chronic systemic inflammatory disorder																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What is the prevalence of RA in the general population?	affecting women more than men, with ~1% prevalence in the United States.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What can RA cause?	An erosive, polyarticular, typically symmetric synovitis with or without extra-articular manifestations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What are less common in RA than articular manifestations?	Extra-articular manifestations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What are classic late physical examination findings in RA?	"Boutonniere&#x27;s, swan neck, or mallet finger deformities, joint deformities, Baker&#x27;s cysts, MCP subluxation with ulnar deviation of the fingers, and DIP joint sparing."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What were introduced in 2010 for the diagnosis of RA?	Modified ACR/European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) classification criteria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What do the 2010 RA classification criteria focus on?	Early inflammatory disease parameters, rather than late-stage features.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What new parameters were added to the RA classification criteria?	Anticitrullinated protein antibody (ACPA) and acute phase reactants ESR and C-reactive protein (CRP).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What has been minimized and eliminated from the RA classification criteria tree algorithm?	The concept of symmetry has been minimized and erosive disease eliminated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What must RA management include?	Both early pharmacologic therapy and nonpharmacologic interventions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What should be regularly practiced in RA management?	ROM exercises and stretching.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What type of exercises are preferred to minimize joint inflammation in RA?	Isometric strengthening exercises.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What are helpful in reducing pain and preventing progression of deformity in RA?	Splints, particularly resting wrist–hand splints and knee or hindfoot splints.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What can be useful in the setting of ulnar deviation in RA?	A dorsal hand orthosis with an ulnar aspect MCP block and individual finger stops.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What should education emphasize in RA management?	Avoidance of overuse and joint protection techniques.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What do current treatment algorithms for RA involve?	Early institution of DMARDs and/or biologics/small molecule therapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What is the primary target for RA treatment?	A state of remission.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What may be helpful symptomatically in mild or early RA disease?	NSAIDs, COX-2 inhibitors, and corticosteroids.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
How are NSAIDs, COX-2 inhibitors, and corticosteroids used in RA?	Only as adjunctive therapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What is the first-line therapy in early RA?	DMARDs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
When are DMARDs initiated in RA?	Within 3 months of disease onset.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What are examples of currently used DMARDs in RA?	Methotrexate (MTX), leflunomide, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
Which DMARD is the most common and best tolerated in RA?	Methotrexate (MTX).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What do biologics significantly inhibit in RA?	Joint damage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
How are biologics often used in RA?	In combination with DMARDs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What do biologics offer in RA?	The most efficient suppression of disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What do biologics include in RA?	TNF-a inhibitors, B-cell depletion, IL-6 and IL-1 inhibitors, and CTLA4-Ig.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What may adverse events of biologics be in RA?	Less common but may be life-threatening.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What is still unclear about biologics in RA?	Long-term effects.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What is the new DMARD subclass therapy in RA?	JAK kinase inhibitors 																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What is the only approved JAK inhibitor for RA?	Tofacitinib (trade name: Xeljanz).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What does tofacitinib selectively inhibit in RA?	JAK 1/JAK3.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What has tofacitinib been shown to be in RA?	Superior to MTX in achieving disease remission.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
How is tofacitinib administered in RA?	Orally.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
How are biologics administered in RA?	Intravenous or subcutaneous medications.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What can be performed to reduce joint destruction and relieve symptoms in RA?	Arthroscopic synovectomy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
Is arthroscopic synovectomy commonly used in the therapy of RA?	No.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What is Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA)?	A common childhood chronic illness affecting some 70,000 to 100,000 persons younger than 16 years of age in the United States.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
How many subtypes of JIA are there?	Seven.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What are the subtypes of JIA?	Systemic, polyarthritis RF positive, polyarthritis RF negative, oligoarthritis (persistent and extended), enthesitis-related arthritis, psoriatic, and undifferentiated.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Rheumatoid_Arthritis
What are seronegative spondyloarthropathies (SpA)?	They include ankylosing spondylitis (AS), psoriatic arthritis (PsA), arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disease, reactive arthritis, and undifferentiated SpA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What are shared clinical manifestations of SpA?	Inflammatory back pain (IBP) with inflammation of the sacroiliac (SI) joints and/or the spine, peripheral arthritis, enthesitis, dactylitis, and uveitis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is ankylosing spondylitis (AS)?	A chronic inflammatory disease of SI joints and spine, may be associated with extra-spinal lesions of the eye, bowel, and heart.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What do patients with AS develop?	Progressive stiffening of the spine; ankylosis (fusion) occurs in about two-thirds of patients after some years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What are the risk factors for AS?	HLA-B27 and male gender.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is the male-to-female incidence ratio in AS?	2:1.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
When is the typical onset of AS?	In late adolescence or early adulthood.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is the average delay in diagnosis from symptom onset in AS?	8 to 9 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What are the initial symptoms of AS?	Pain and stiffness in the buttock or lumbar area, which are worse with inactivity and improve with exercise or hot showers.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is a characteristic early x-ray finding in AS?	Bilateral symmetric sacroiliitis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What can inflammation of the spine lead to in AS?	"Syndesmophyte formation and ultimately to a kyphotic bony ankylosis (&#x27;bamboo spine&#x27;)."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What can progression of spinal inflexibility be followed by in AS?	"Schober&#x27;s test."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What are extra-articular manifestations of AS?	Peripheral large joint arthritis, uveitis, cardiac conduction abnormalities, aortic regurgitation, and pulmonary fibrosis of the upper lobes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
How does uveitis typically present in AS?	Painful, anterior, unilateral, and acute, associated with redness and photophobia, and may progress to blindness.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What does treatment for AS include?	Spinal extension exercises (e.g., swimming and push-ups), expansive chest breathing, pectoral and hip flexor stretching, and prone lying.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What should be recommended for patients with AS regarding their bed?	A hard mattress, preferably without pillows behind the head.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What may reduce pain and symptoms of spinal stiffness in AS?	NSAIDs (e.g., naproxen and indomethacin).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is useful in cases of significant peripheral arthritis in AS?	Sulfasalazine.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What are the characteristics of psoriatic arthritis (PsA)?	Arthritis with psoriasis, nail changes, and enthesitis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is the male-to-female ratio in PsA?	Equal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
When is the peak onset age of PsA?	Between 30 and 55 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What are the five subtypes of PsA?	Asymmetric oligoarthritis, symmetric polyarthritis (RA-like), DIP predominant, spondylitis, and arthritis mutilans.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What are characteristic findings in PsA?	Dactylitis and enthesitis, often of the Achilles tendon.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is characteristic of the DIP predominant subtype of PsA?	Pitting, ridging, and onycholysis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What imaging finding is characteristic of PsA?	"Pencil-in-cup&#x27; deformity."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is the treatment for PsA?	Similar to RA, including NSAIDs, DMARDs, and biologics.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disease?	"Arthritis occurring in the context of Crohn&#x27;s disease or ulcerative colitis."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is reactive arthritis?	Arthritis that develops after an infection, particularly of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is the characteristic triad of reactive arthritis?	Conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What was reactive arthritis previously known as?	"Reiter&#x27;s syndrome."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is the treatment for reactive arthritis?	NSAIDs and physical therapy; antibiotics if an underlying infection is identified.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is undifferentiated SpA?	A form of spondyloarthritis that does not meet criteria for any specific type of SpA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is common in the spectrum of SpA diseases?	Overlap of clinical features.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is important for the management of SpA?	Early diagnosis and appropriate therapy to prevent disease progression and improve quality of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Seronegative_Spondyloarthritis
What is fibromyalgia?	A chronic disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tenderness in localized areas.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are the primary symptoms of fibromyalgia?	Widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tenderness.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are the other symptoms commonly associated with fibromyalgia?	Sleep disturbances, cognitive dysfunction, and a variety of somatic symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the prevalence of fibromyalgia in the general population?	Approximately 2-4%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
Who is more commonly affected by fibromyalgia?	Women, with a female-to-male ratio of about 9:1.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are the diagnostic criteria for fibromyalgia according to the American College of Rheumatology (ACR)?	Widespread pain index (WPI) and symptom severity (SS) scale score.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What does the WPI measure in fibromyalgia?	The number of areas in the body where the patient has felt pain in the past week.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What does the SS scale score measure in fibromyalgia?	The severity of symptoms such as fatigue, waking unrefreshed, and cognitive symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
How is fibromyalgia diagnosed?	Based on patient symptoms and the exclusion of other conditions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are the key components of the management of fibromyalgia?	Patient education, pharmacologic treatments, and nonpharmacologic therapies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of patient education in fibromyalgia management?	Helping patients understand the nature of the disorder and the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are some pharmacologic treatments used for fibromyalgia?	Antidepressants, anticonvulsants, and muscle relaxants.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of antidepressants in fibromyalgia treatment?	To help reduce pain and improve sleep.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of anticonvulsants in fibromyalgia treatment?	To help reduce pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of muscle relaxants in fibromyalgia treatment?	To help improve sleep.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are some nonpharmacologic therapies used for fibromyalgia?	Physical therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and exercise.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of physical therapy in fibromyalgia management?	To help improve physical function and reduce pain.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) in fibromyalgia management?	To help improve coping skills and reduce the impact of symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of exercise in fibromyalgia management?	To help improve physical function, reduce pain, and improve overall well-being.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are some common challenges in the management of fibromyalgia?	Patient adherence to treatment plans and the variability of symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in fibromyalgia management?	To address the various aspects of the disorder and improve overall outcomes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the impact of fibromyalgia on quality of life?	It can significantly affect physical, emotional, and social well-being.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are some common comorbid conditions with fibromyalgia?	Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), migraines, and mood disorders such as depression and anxiety.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
How does fibromyalgia affect sleep?	It often causes sleep disturbances, including difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, and waking unrefreshed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the significance of cognitive dysfunction in fibromyalgia?	It can affect memory, attention, and executive function, impacting daily activities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the importance of addressing comorbid conditions in fibromyalgia management?	To improve overall treatment outcomes and quality of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of stress management in fibromyalgia?	To help reduce symptom severity and improve coping strategies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What are some strategies for stress management in fibromyalgia?	Relaxation techniques, mindfulness, and cognitive-behavioral approaches.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
How can dietary modifications help in fibromyalgia management?	By addressing specific dietary triggers and improving overall nutrition.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of support groups in fibromyalgia management?	To provide emotional support and practical advice from others with the condition.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is the role of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) in fibromyalgia?	To offer additional options for symptom management, such as acupuncture and massage therapy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology RehabReadyTags::Rheumatology::Fibromyalgia
What is multiple sclerosis (MS)?	A chronic inflammatory demyelinating disease of unknown etiology (thought to be immune-mediated) characterized by areas of CNS demyelination that is disseminated in time and space.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
What is the prevalence of MS worldwide?	About 2.5 million people.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
What is the prevalence of MS in the United States?	About 400,000 people.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
What is the female-to-male ratio in MS?	2:1.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
In which demographic is MS most common?	Caucasians.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
When is the onset of MS typically?	Between 20 and 40 years of age.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
What is the mean onset age of MS?	30 years.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
Where are incidence and death rates of MS higher?	In the northern latitudes, although this differential appears to be decreasing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
What are significant factors that increase the risk of developing MS?	Population genetics, association between genes and environment, and socioeconomic status.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
What is the strongest genetic predictor of MS?	HLA-DRB1*1501, which has a two- to fourfold increased risk.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Introduction_Epidemiology
What is the clinical presentation (relapse or exacerbation) of multiple sclerosis (MS)?	Highly variable and depends on the location of CNS lesions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What are the most common initial symptoms of MS?	Sensory disturbances, motor weakness, and visual disturbances.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What are other common symptoms of MS?	Common clinical features include paresthesias, weakness, spasticity, fatigue (may be worsened by heat, i.e., Uhthoff’s phenomenon), vertigo, bladder dysfunction, sexual dysfunction, cognitive changes, depression, dysphagia, neuro- pathic pain, and L’hermitte sign (neck flexion causing electric shock sensation down spine/limbs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is the hallmark of MS?	Episodes of neurological dysfunction that resolve partially or completely.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
How is MS diagnosed?	Primarily based on clinical findings and supported by MRI and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What are the MRI findings in MS?	Demyelinating lesions in the CNS, typically in the periventricular white matter, brainstem, cerebellum, and spinal cord.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is the role of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis in MS diagnosis?	To detect oligoclonal bands and elevated IgG index. Presence of increased protein and oli- goclonal bands (IgG&gt;IgM and IgA) is consistent with MS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is the McDonald Criteria?	A set of guidelines used to diagnose MS based on clinical and radiologic findings.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is the purpose of evoked potential tests in MS diagnosis?	To measure the electrical activity in the brain in response to stimuli and detect demyelination.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is an important differential diagnosis to consider in MS?	Other demyelinating diseases, infections, and metabolic disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is the typical course of relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS)?	Episodes of neurological dysfunction followed by periods of partial or complete recovery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is secondary progressive MS (SPMS)?	A stage of MS that follows RRMS, characterized by a progressive worsening of neurological function over time.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is primary progressive MS (PPMS)?	A type of MS characterized by gradual progression of disability from onset without relapses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is progressive-relapsing MS (PRMS)?	A type of MS characterized by progressive disease from onset with clear acute relapses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS)?	A method of quantifying disability in MS and monitoring changes in the level of disability over time.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Diagnosis_Clinical_Features
What is a clinically isolated syndrome in the context of Multiple Sclerosis (MS)?	It is the first attack compatible with MS (optic neuritis, brainstem syndromes, transverse myelitis), but full diagnostic criteria are not fully met.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What percentage of MS cases are relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS)?	Approximately 85% of cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What characterizes relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS)?	It is defined by acute attacks followed by spontaneous recovery with little or no residual neurologic deficit.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
How does secondary progressive MS (SPMS) develop from RRMS?	Due to the accumulation of damaged tissue over time (10-20 years), most RRMS patients eventually develop a secondary progressive course with remissions (SPMS), plateaus, and gradual worsening.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What is the effect of interferon beta-1b in SPMS?	It may delay the progression of disability in SPMS. (e.g., wheelchair dependence)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What percentage of MS cases are primary progressive MS (PPMS)?	Approximately 10% to 15% of cases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What characterizes primary progressive MS (PPMS)?	It is characterized by an insidious onset with gradual worsening and progressive accumulation of disability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What is the gender prevalence in PPMS?	Male and female prevalence are equal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What are the recommendations for PPMS or SPMS patients?	Annual assessments are recommended to detect/follow disease progression, independent of relapses.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What is progressive relapsing MS?	It is a progressive disease from onset with superimposed acute relapses with or without some recovery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What is a mainstay of acute treatment for MS relapses?	IV steroids (e.g., methylprednisolone IV 500 mg qd for 5 days or 1 g qd for 3 days) followed by oral prednisone taper.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What are the main goals of MS treatment?	Disease-modifying therapy (DMT) to modulate immune response, with the goal of preventing relapses, slowing brain lesion accumula- tion, and reducing disease burden																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What is the role of disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) in MS?	They reduce the frequency and severity of clinical relapses and the development of new lesions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
Name a few disease-modifying therapies used in MS.	Interferon beta-1a, interferon beta-1b, glatiramer acetate, natalizumab, fingolimod, teriflunomide, dimethyl fumarate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What is the recommended approach for treating MS relapses?	High-dose corticosteroids are the standard treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What are some symptomatic treatments used in MS?	Medications for spasticity (e.g., baclofen, tizanidine), pain (e.g., gabapentin, pregabalin), fatigue (e.g., amantadine, modafinil), bladder dysfunction (e.g., oxybutynin), and others.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What is the importance of comprehensive care in MS?	It involves a multidisciplinary approach to manage the complex range of symptoms and improve overall quality of life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What lifestyle modifications are recommended for MS patients?	Regular exercise, a balanced diet, adequate sleep, stress management, and smoking cessation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Clinical_Categories_Treatment
What factors are reported to have a favorable prognosis in MS?	Presentation with sensory symptoms and optic neuritis are favorable prognostically.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Prognosis
What factors are reported to have an unfavorable prognosis in MS?	Unfavorable factors include pyramidal or brainstem lesions, male gender, and older age at onset.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Prognosis
How reliable and accurate are the prognostic factors in MS?	These factors are limited in reliability and accuracy and none has been confirmed as independent prognostic factors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Prognosis
Does higher lesion load at initial diagnosis correlate with worse prognosis in MS?	Although commonly accepted that higher lesion load at initial diagnosis correlates with worse prognosis, some studies suggest MRI lesion load does not necessarily correlate to disease burden.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Prognosis
What impairment correlates with poor prognosis in MS?	Bowel and/or bladder impairment correlates with poor prognosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Prognosis
What relapsing course in MS typically augurs a poorer prognosis?	A relapsing course where there is an incomplete recovery from the first attack, followed by a short interval before the second attack, typically augurs a poorer prognosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis RehabReadyTags::Multiple_Sclerosis::Prognosis
What are movement disorders?	A group of central nervous system (CNS) degenerative diseases associated with involuntary movements or abnormalities of skeletal muscle tone and posture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Definition
How can movement disorders be broadly classified?	They can be broadly classified as hypokinetic (too little) or hyperkinetic (too much) movement disorders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Definition
"What is the predominant area of involvement in Parkinson&#x27;s disease (PD)?"	The basal ganglia, which are primarily inhibitory in function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"Which cells are affected in Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	The dopamine-producing cells (substantia nigra and locus coeruleus) of the basal ganglia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
What results from the degeneration of the nigrostriatal pathway in PD?	It causes decreased dopamine in the corpus striatum, resulting in the loss of inhibitory input to the cholinergic system, allowing excessive excitatory output.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the prevalence of Parkinson&#x27;s disease in the population over 50 years of age?"	PD affects 1% of the population over 50 years of age.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the incidence rate of Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	20/100,000 per year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the male to female ratio in Parkinson&#x27;s disease incidence?"	3:2.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What environmental factors are associated with Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Pesticide and herbicide use.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What percentage of Parkinson&#x27;s disease cases are hereditary?"	5% to 10%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the most common initial symptom of Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Resting tremor (pill-rolling tremor) in the hands, 3 to 5 Hz.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What triad characterizes Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Resting tremor, bradykinesia, and cogwheel rigidity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are features of advanced Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Masked facies, festinating gait (shuffling), and postural instability due to loss of postural reflexes, resulting in falls to the side or backward.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the freezing phenomenon in Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	A transient inability to perform or restart certain tasks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
