"What psychiatric symptoms are associated with Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Depression and psychosis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What percentage of Parkinson&#x27;s disease patients develop dementia?"	40%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What autonomic symptom is common in Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Orthostatic hypotension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the goal of medical treatment in Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	To increase dopamine action and decrease cholinergic effect.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"When should treatment for Parkinson&#x27;s disease be started?"	When symptoms interfere with performing activities of daily living (ADLs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is L-dopa and why is it given with carbidopa in the treatment of Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	L-dopa is the precursor of dopamine. It is given with carbidopa (a dopa decarboxylase inhibitor) to prevent systemic metabolism of L-dopa (e.g., Sinemet).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are dopaminergic agonists used in Parkinson&#x27;s disease treatment?"	Pramipexole (Mirapex), ropinirole (Requip), and rotigotine (Neupro patch).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are the ergot derivatives used in Parkinson&#x27;s disease treatment?"	Bromocriptine (stimulates D2 receptors) and pergolide (stimulates D1 and D2 receptors).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are the non-ergot derivatives used in Parkinson&#x27;s disease treatment?"	Ropinirole (Requip) and pramipexole (Mirapex).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is amantadine and its role in Parkinson&#x27;s disease treatment?"	An antiviral that potentiates the release of endogenous dopamine and has mild anticholinergic activity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are the anticholinergics used in Parkinson&#x27;s disease treatment?"	Trihexyphenidyl (Artane), benztropine (Cogentin), procyclidine, and orphenadrine.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the role of inhibitors of dopamine metabolism in Parkinson&#x27;s disease treatment?"	They inhibit monoamine oxidase (MAO)-B, which is predominant in the striatum.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the role of selegiline and rasagiline in Parkinson&#x27;s disease treatment?"	They decrease oxidative damage in the substantia nigra and slow disease progression.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the role of tolcapone in Parkinson&#x27;s disease treatment?"	A catechol-O-methyltransferase inhibitor that inhibits the metabolism of dopamine in the liver, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and other organs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"When is surgical treatment indicated for Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	In patients with advanced disease in whom medical treatment is ineffective or poorly tolerated. Mostly effective in the relief of tremor.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are the complications of surgical treatment for Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Brain hemorrhage, infection, and device failure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are the types of destructive surgery used in Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Thalamotomy or pallidotomy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is deep brain stimulation in the treatment of Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	An electrode placed into the subthalamic nucleus or ventral intermediate nucleus of the thalamus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are some causes for disability in Parkinson&#x27;s disease? (8 total)"	Social isolation, manual dexterity issues (inability to perform ADLs such as dressing, cutting food, writing, and fine motor skills), stooped posture, slowness of gait, speech impairment, dysphagia, drooling, and psychiatric dysfunction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"How can psychosis in Parkinson&#x27;s disease be treated?"	With quetiapine (Seroquel), clozapine (Clozaril), or pimavanserin (Nuplazid), the only FDA-approved medication.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What is the rationale for rehabilitation in Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Functionally based, objectively assessed using the unified Parkinson’s disease rating scale (UPDRS), which includes assessment of walking speed, distance, backward and forward stepping, ability to navigate obstacles, fine motor tasks, equilibrium, and simultaneous and sequential tasks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are some physical therapy strategies for Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Posture training (hip extension, pelvic tilt, and standing), postural reflexes, ROM (passive/active and relaxation techniques), ambulation with walker, conditioning, Frenkel’s exercises, wobble board or balance feedback trainers, fall prevention, and home assessment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are some occupational therapy strategies for Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Adaptive equipment such as plate guards, cups/utensils with large handles, and swivel forks and spoons. Replacing buttons on clothing with Velcro/zipper closures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
"What are some other rehabilitation strategies for Parkinson&#x27;s disease?"	Swallow evaluation and diaphragmatic breathing exercises to improve dysarthria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hypokinetic_Movement_Disorders_Parkinsons
What conditions are included in hyperkinetic movement disorders?	Tremors, tics, Tourette’s syndrome, dystonia (generalized and focal), dyskinesia, chorea, hemiballismus, myoclonus, and asterixis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is a tremor?	Rhythmic oscillation of a body part.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What percentage of the population experiences tremors?	6%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are the treatment options for essential tremor?	Propranolol, primidone, benzodiazepines (BZDs; alprazolam), anticonvulsants (gabapentin and topiramate), and Botox.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are tics?	Sustained nonrhythmic muscle contractions that are rapid and stereotyped, often occurring in the same extremity or body part during stress.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
"What characterizes Tourette&#x27;s syndrome?"	Involuntary use of obscenities (coprolalia) and obscene gestures (copropraxia).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
"What are the treatment options for Tourette&#x27;s syndrome?"	Neuroleptics (pimozide and haloperidol).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is dystonia?	Slow sustained contractions of muscles, which frequently cause twisting movements or abnormal postures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are the types of dystonia?	Idiopathic, focal (torticollis, blepharospasm, oromandibular dystonia, and writer’s cramp), generalized (Wilson’s disease and lipid storage disorders), neurodegenerative diseases (PD and Huntington’s disease), acquired (perinatal brain injury, CO poisoning, and encephalitis).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are the treatment options for dystonia?	Anticholinergics, baclofen, carbamazepine, clonazepam, and Botox for focal dystonias.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is tardive dyskinesia?	Involuntary choreiform movements of the face and tongue such as chewing, sucking, licking, puckering, and smacking due to hypersensitivity of dopamine receptors due to long-term blockade.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is tardive dyskinesia associated with?	Long-term neuroleptic medication use (20%).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
How has the incidence of tardive dyskinesia changed with new medications?	It has decreased since the advent of atypical neuroleptics such as clozapine, risperidone, and olanzapine.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are the treatment options for tardive dyskinesia?	Benzodiazepines (BZDs).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is ataxia usually associated with?	Cerebellar disease.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are the causes of ataxia?	Stroke, multiple sclerosis (MS), acute/chronic alcohol toxicity, and hereditary (slowly progressive) Friedreich’s ataxia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are the treatment options for ataxia?	Compensatory techniques, gait training, and assistive devices.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is athetosis?	Slow, writhing movements of the limbs, face, and trunk.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is chorea?	Nonstereotyped, unpredictable, jerky movements involving oral structures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is hemiballismus?	Extremely violent flinging of unilateral arm and leg secondary to infarct or bleeding in subthalamic nuclei.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is myoclonus?	Sudden jerky irregular contraction of muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are 5 subtypes of myoclonus?	Can be physiological (sleep jerks and hiccups), essential (increasing with activity), epileptic, symptomatic (part of underlying encephalopathy or stroke), spinal myoclonus (group of muscles innervated by spinal segments; occurs in spinal cord disorders such as tumor, trauma, or MS)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What are the treaments for myoclonus?	Treatment includes clonazepam, valproate, and Keppra																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders RehabReadyTags::Movement_Disorders::Hyperkinetic_Movement_Disorders
What is Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) also known as?	Guillain-Barré syndrome																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What characterizes AIDP?	Ascending paresthesias and weakness that can progress to total body paralysis, autonomic disturbances, and respiratory failure																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
Which pathogens are commonly associated with AIDP (5)?	Campylobacter jejuni, mycoplasma pneumoniae, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Haemophilus influenzae																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What is the global incidence of AIDP?	About 0.4 to 1.7 per 100,000																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What precedes approximately 60% of AIDP cases?	A mild flu-like illness 1 to 4 weeks prior																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What percentage of patients with AIDP will complain of initial muscular aching pain?	More than 50%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
How does the pain in AIDP progress?	It may transition to neuropathic pain as the disease progresses																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
Which muscles and functions are typically spared in AIDP?	Extraocular muscles and sphincter function																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What findings support the diagnosis of AIDP?	Areflexia, progressive weakness in all limbs, relative symmetry of involvement, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cytoalbuminologic dissociation (elevated protein, &lt;10 mononuclear cells/mm3), and electrodiagnostic findings																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What do most cases of AIDP show in electrodiagnostic tests?	Prolonged latency, slowed conduction velocity, conduction block, and temporal dispersion																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What are F-waves useful for in AIDP diagnosis?	Assessing long segments of the nerve, with absent or prolonged F-waves usually being the earliest electrodiagnostic findings																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What happens if there is an axonal component to AIDP?	Motor unit action potentials may have low amplitudes, and there may be denervation on needle testing																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What percentage of patients with AIDP experience respiratory complications?	10% to 30%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What treatments are effective during the evolution of AIDP symptoms?	Plasmapheresis or IV Ig (400 mg/kg/day × 5 days) given within 2 weeks of onset																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
Are glucocorticoids effective for AIDP?	No, glucocorticoids are not effective																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What should early rehabilitation for AIDP emphasize?	Stretching and gradual strengthening, avoiding aggressive therapies that may cause overwork weakness																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What device may be useful for patients with autonomic instability in AIDP?	A tilt table																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
When do most patients with AIDP reach a clinical nadir?	About 4 weeks after the onset of symptoms																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What is the mortality rate for AIDP?	About 3% to 5%, usually due to respiratory or cardiovascular causes from autonomic dysfunction																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
How long can recovery from AIDP take?	Weeks to months, or up to 6 to 18 months if axonal damage has occurred																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What percentage of AIDP patients have a pronounced residual disability?	About 10%, most often lower leg weakness and numbness of the feet																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What percentage of AIDP patients may suffer one or more recurrences of acute polyneuropathy?	About 5% to 10%																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Introduction
What is Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) pathologically similar to?	Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Chronic_Inflammatory_Demyelinating_Polyneuropathy
How does the onset of CIDP compare to AIDP?	CIDP tends to have a slower onset of at least 2 months and may recur multiple times																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Chronic_Inflammatory_Demyelinating_Polyneuropathy
How is the weakness in CIDP described?	Symmetrical, with more distal than proximal muscle involvement																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Chronic_Inflammatory_Demyelinating_Polyneuropathy
What is the primary basis for differentiating between AIDP and CIDP?	Temporal presentation																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Chronic_Inflammatory_Demyelinating_Polyneuropathy
What is the treatment for CIDP?	The same as with AIDP, but CIDP patients with both sensory and motor involvement will respond to high-dose corticosteroids																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Chronic_Inflammatory_Demyelinating_Polyneuropathy
What is the usual regimen for high-dose corticosteroids in CIDP patients?	80 mg prednisone qd, tapered over months to the lowest effective dose																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Chronic_Inflammatory_Demyelinating_Polyneuropathy
What supports the diagnosis of CIDP?	Electrodiagnostics, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings, and nerve biopsy (if indicated)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::AIDP RehabReadyTags::AIDP::Chronic_Inflammatory_Demyelinating_Polyneuropathy
What is spasticity characterized by?	Velocity-dependent increased resistance to passive stretch, associated with exaggerated tendon jerks, resulting from hyperexcitability of the stretch reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Introduction
What syndrome is spasticity a part of?	Spasticity is part of the upper motor neuron (UMN) syndrome.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Introduction
What are the positive symptoms of the upper motor neuron (UMN) syndrome?	Spasticity and uninhibited flexor reflexes in the lower limbs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Introduction
What are the negative symptoms of the upper motor neuron (UMN) syndrome?	Weakness and poor dexterity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Introduction
Why is it important to treat spasticity?	It can impair function within and outside of therapy, including positioning, transfers, and hygiene.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Introduction
What can spasticity produce that makes management more complex?	Spasticity can produce a cycle of symptoms that can make management more complex. (Increased spasticity leading to difficulty in sitting or lying --&gt; Development of pressure sores prone to infections, Difficulty in maintaining hygiene, Reduced mobility, Poor nutrition --&gt; Increased severity of spasticity and spasms, May also lead to contracture.)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Introduction
What are the indications for treating spasticity?	Pain, decreased function, poor hygiene, skin breakdown, poor cosmesis, and poor positioning																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Treatment
What potential factors may exacerbate spasticity?	Pressure ulcers, urinary tract infections (UTIs), bowel impaction, ingrown toenails, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Treatment
What should be addressed before treating any spasticity?	Whether the spasticity may be utilized functionally, such as hypertonia in the lower limbs assisting transfers or gait																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Treatment
What should be the cornerstone for most spasticity treatment programs?	A stretching program																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
What can help preserve ROM by &quot;resetting the muscle spindles&quot;?	Splints, casting, or bracing																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
How can contractures be reduced?	By serially casting a joint, increasing the stretch stepwise for 1 to 2 days at a time																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
What are potential drawbacks of serial casting?	Not always well tolerated and may lead to skin breakdown																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
How can cryotherapy be helpful in treating spasticity?	Reducing the hyperexcitability of the muscle stretch reflex and reducing nerve conduction velocities when applied for more than 15 minutes																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
What can functional electrical stimulation do for spasticity?	Improve function and reduce tone for hours after the stimulation																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
"What is thought to be the mechanism of functional electrical stimulation&#x27;s effect on spasticity?"	Neurotransmitter modulation at the spinal cord level																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
What is hippotherapy and how is it useful for spasticity?	Hippotherapy involves rhythmic movements and is useful in lower limb spasticity reduction																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
What other modalities can be used for spasticity reduction?	Application of tendon pressure, cold, warmth, vibration, massage, low-power laser, and acupuncture																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Physical_Modalities
When may oral medications be indicated for spasticity?	Nonfocal spasticity																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What often limits the efficacy of oral medications for spasticity?	Side effects																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What FDA-approved medications are used for spasticity?	Baclofen, diazepam, dantrolene, and tizanidine																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What off-label medication has shown promising results in treating spasticity in MS patients?	Gabapentin																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What have cannabinoids been investigated for in relation to spasticity?	Potential therapeutic efficacy, especially in MS patients otherwise refractory to treatment																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
How does Botulinum Toxin-A (BTX-A) work?	By irreversibly blocking neuromuscular junction (NMJ) transmission through inhibition of presynaptic acetylcholine (ACh) release																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What conditions is BTX-A FDA approved for?	Blepharospasm, strabismus, cervical dystonia, overactive bladder, urinary incontinence due to detrusor overactivity, severe glabellar frown lines, chronic migraine, severe axillary hyperhidrosis, upper limb spasticity, and lower limb spasticity																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
When is the onset of effect for BTX-A?	Typically 24 to 72 hours																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What is the peak effect time for BTX-A?	2 to 6 weeks																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
How long does clinical efficacy of BTX-A typically last?	Up to 3 to 4 months																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What is the recommended maximum dose of BTX-A?	10 U/kg IM (up to 400 U) per visit																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What interval is recommended between BTX-A sessions to reduce potential antibody formation?	At least 3 months																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What are some contraindications for BTX-A?	Pregnancy, lactation, NMJ disease, social and psychological instability, local skin or muscle infection, history of adverse effect, concomitant aminoglycoside use, and human albumin USP allergy																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What are some advantages of BTX-A over phenol?	Ready diffusion into the injected area, easier injections, and absence of dysesthesias																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What is BTX-B FDA approved for?	Cervical dystonia																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
How does phenol destroy nerves?	dose-dependent manner, with onset within 1 hour and duration that can last years																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What can phenol injections be combined with during a single session?	BTX injections																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What are some advantages of phenol over BTX?	Low cost, lack of antibody formation, and longer duration of effect																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What is a disadvantage of phenol versus BTX?	Greater technical skill involved and potential for dysesthesias																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What is intrathecal baclofen (ITB) indicated for?	Severe spasticity (Ashworth grade ≥3) due to SCI and severe spasticity of cerebral origin																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What is a typical infusion rate for a lumbar ITB pump?	About 600 μg/day																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What must patients be committed to when using an ITB pump?	Being compliant with seeing the physician for refills of the medication																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Pharmaceutical_Options
What types of procedures exist for treating spasticity?	Tendon transfer, tendon/muscle lengthening, and neurosurgical (brain/spinal cord) lesioning																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Surgical_Options
What procedure can be effective for treating the spastic equinovarus foot?	Split anterior tibial tendon transfer (SPLATT)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Surgical_Options
What is done in the SPLATT procedure?	The lateral portion of the split distal anterior tibialis tendon is reattached to the third cuneiform and cuboid bones																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Surgical_Options
What usually accompanies the SPLATT procedure?	Achilles tendon lengthening																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Surgical_Options
What condition may benefit from selective dorsal rhizotomy?	Cerebral palsy (CP)																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Surgical_Options
What does the selective dorsal rhizotomy procedure involve?	Laminectomy and exposure of the cauda equina, followed by individual stimulation of the dorsal rootlets and severing of rootlets that produce abnormal EMG responses																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Surgical_Options
Why are anterior rootlet lesions undesirable in rhizotomy?	Denervation atrophy may follow, with resultant skin breakdown																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Surgical_Options
What are favorable selection criteria for rhizotomy in CP patients?	Spastic CP (without athetosis), age between 3 and 8 years, heterotopic ossification (HO), prematurity, good truncal balance, and a supportive family																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Spasticity RehabReadyTags::Spasticity::Surgical_Options
What activates detrusor muscle stretch receptors?	Bladder distension activates detrusor muscle stretch receptors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
How is feedback provided to the sacral micturition center?	Feedback is provided to the sacral micturition center at spinal segments S2 to S4 via afferent nerves.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What inhibits the sacral micturition center and reflex bladder contraction?	An intact cerebral cortex inhibits the sacral micturition center and reflex bladder contraction.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What stimulates fundal d-receptors and trigonal/bladder neck a-receptors?	Sympathetic efferents (arising from T10 to L2, hypogastric nerve) stimulate fundal d-receptors (relaxation) and trigonal/bladder neck a-receptors (contraction).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What neurotransmitter is involved in bladder storage without leakage?	Norepinephrine is involved in bladder storage without leakage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
At what volume is bladder filling initially sensed?	Approximately 100 mL.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
At what volume is a feeling of fullness typically appreciated?	Approximately 300 to 400 mL.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
How is voluntary continence maintained?	Voluntary continence is maintained via somatic efferents (Onuf’s nucleus, S2–S4, pudendal nerve), which innervate the external urethral sphincter.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What happens during physiological voiding?	The sacral micturition center stimulates detrusor contraction via parasympathetic fibers traveling in the pelvic nerves, releasing acetylcholine that targets cholinergic (muscarinic M2) receptors in the bladder.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What coordinates the interaction between the detrusor and urethral sphincter during voiding?	The pontine micturition center (PMC) coordinates a synergic interaction between the contracting detrusor and a relaxing urethral sphincter.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What mnemonic helps remember the functions of sympathetic and parasympathetic systems in bladder control?	&quot;sympathetic is for storage; parasympathetic is for peeing.&quot;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What compromises cerebral inhibition of the micturition reflex in neurogenic bladder?	A suprapontine lesion (e.g., traumatic brain injury [TBI] or stroke) compromises cerebral inhibition of the micturition reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the clinical manifestations of a suprapontine lesion?	Frequency and incontinence due to detrusor hyperreflexia are the clinical manifestations of a suprapontine lesion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
Why is detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia (DSD) not seen in suprapontine lesions?	Because the PMC’s synergic control of the bladder and sphincter is intact.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the treatment options for neurogenic bladder due to suprapontine lesions?	Treatment options include timed voids (e.g., toileting q2h), urinary collection devices (e.g., condom catheter), and oral anticholinergics to decrease bladder tone and suppress bladder contractions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What disrupts the transmission of cerebral signals inhibiting the micturition reflex in suprasacral spinal cord injury (SCI)?	A suprasacral (subpontine) spinal cord injury (SCI) disrupts the transmission of cerebral signals inhibiting the micturition reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What results from the disruption of the Pontine Micturation Center’s synergic control of the detrusor and sphincter in suprasacral SCI?	It results in detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia (DSD), where the sphincter does not relax during bladder contraction, causing incomplete (or absence of) voiding despite high bladder contraction pressures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the complications of detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia (DSD)?	Complications of DSD include bladder diverticula, vesicoureteral reflux, hydronephrosis, acute kidney injury, pyelonephritis, or nephrolithiasis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
Why may the clinical presentation of complications in patients with SCI be atypical?	Due to sensory impairment, the clinical presentation of these conditions may be atypical in patients with SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What results from chronic detrusor hyperactivity in SCI?	Chronic detrusor hyperactivity results in reflexive bladder contractions with emptying of low bladder volumes, which, over time, can lead to diminished bladder capacity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What factors should determine the management options for neurogenic bladder in suprasacral SCI?	Management options should be determined based on anatomical considerations, history of complications, abilities, goals, motivations, and resources.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
When is intermittent catheterization (IC) recommended?	IC is recommended when an individual has sufficient hand skills or a willing caregiver to perform IC.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What factors may preclude an effective IC program?	Body habitus, spasticity, gender, and urethral anatomical abnormalities may preclude an effective IC program.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
When should alternatives to IC be considered?	Alternatives should be considered when bladder capacity is &lt;200 mL or bladder volumes consistently exceed 500 mL despite adjustments in fluid intake or IC frequency.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
Why might IC be a less appropriate option for some individuals?	A tendency for autonomic dysreflexia may make IC a less appropriate option.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What does clean IC (CIC) consist of?	CIC consists of reusing catheters that are washed with mild soap and water, rinsed thoroughly, air-dried, and stored in a clean, dry towel or bag.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
When should catheters be replaced in CIC?	Catheters may be reused until brittle or visibly defective (e.g., cracked), or if there is buildup of sediment, and are generally replaced every 2 to 4 weeks or more often if needed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
When should sterile IC be considered?	Sterile IC should be considered if CIC results in recurrent symptomatic infections.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What is an option if urethral irritation is suspected to be a cause of recurrent UTIs?	Single-use hydrophilic catheters are an option if urethral irritation is suspected to be a cause of recurrent UTIs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What is an option if hygienic facilities are unavailable for IC?	Touchless catheters are an option if hygienic facilities are unavailable (e.g., during travel or sports activities).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What is reflex voiding with a condom catheter?	Reflex voiding with a condom catheter is an option in males, sometimes requiring an endourethral stent, transurethral surgical sphincterotomy, or pharmacological measures to facilitate urine flow.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What pharmacological measures may be used to facilitate urine flow in reflex voiding with a condom catheter?	Pharmacological measures may include sphincter botulinum toxin injection or oral alpha-adrenergic blockers (ephedrine or phenylpropanolamine).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
When are indwelling catheters considered for neurogenic bladder management?	Indwelling catheters are considered when an individual has poor hand skills, limitations in caregiver availability or willingness, when less invasive methods have been unsuccessful, or in the setting of elevated risk of nephric or urologic complications due to persistently elevated detrusor pressures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the primary disadvantages of an indwelling catheter compared to properly performed IC?	The primary disadvantages are increased risks of infection, autonomic dysreflexia, urolithiasis, bladder neoplasm, and lifestyle issues (e.g., wearing a urinary collection bag).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
Why is routine irrigation with normal saline or sterile water not generally recommended for indwelling catheters?	Routine irrigation is not recommended due to denuding of the uroepithelium.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What risks are associated with indwelling urethral catheters?	Indwelling urethral catheters increase the risk for urethral strictures, hypospadias, prostatitis, and epididymitis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
How should an indwelling catheter be anchored to minimize urethral erosion?	Anchoring the catheter to the thigh or abdomen is recommended to minimize urethral erosion.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
When should suprapubic catheters be considered?	Suprapubic catheters should be considered in the setting of urethral abnormalities or complications, difficulty with urethral catheterization, recurrent urethral catheter obstruction, psychological considerations (e.g., body image or personal preference), or to improve sexual function.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
How often should suprapubic catheters generally be changed?	Suprapubic catheters should generally be changed every 4 weeks, or every 1 to 2 weeks in the setting of catheter encrustation or stones.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the options to enhance storage in neurogenic bladder management?	Options to enhance storage include oral anticholinergics (e.g., oxybutynin or tolterodine), intravesical anticholinergics (e.g., capsaicin or resiniferatoxin), intravesical botulinum toxin injection, and bladder augmentation surgery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the options to facilitate/enhance emptying in neurogenic bladder management?	Options to facilitate/enhance emptying include oral alpha-adrenergic blockers, cutaneous ileovesicostomy, Mitrofanoff appendicovesicostomy, or neurostimulation with implanted sacral nerve modulators (often combined with posterior sacral rhizotomy).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What must be considered when using alpha-adrenergic blockers for neurogenic bladder management?	Alpha-adrenergic blockers must be used with care due to the risk of hypotension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What can cause detrusor areflexia and how may it manifest?	A sacral or peripheral nerve lesion can cause detrusor areflexia, which may manifest as retention, with or without overflow incontinence.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the treatment options for detrusor areflexia?	Treatment options may include Valsalva maneuver, suprapubic pressure (Crede maneuver) or percussion, cholinergic agonists (e.g., bethanechol), CIC, or indwelling catheter.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the overall goals of treatment for neurogenic bladder?	The goals are to preserve renal function, avoid high bladder pressures, incontinence, urinary retention, and infections, and optimize lifestyle and social considerations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
Why is regular monitoring of the upper and lower urinary tracts necessary in neurogenic bladder management?	Regular monitoring is necessary for guiding management, although there is no consensus on the optimal battery of investigations or the frequency of testing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the options to monitor the upper urinary tract in neurogenic bladder management?	Renal scans, CT scans, and intravenous pyelograms are options to monitor the upper tract.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What are the options to monitor the lower urinary tract in neurogenic bladder management?	Urodynamics, cystograms, and cystoscopy are used to monitor the lower tract.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder RehabReadyTags::Neurogenic_Bladder::Introduction
What is aphasia?	Aphasia is an acquired communication disorder caused by brain damage that impairs an individual's ability to produce and/or understand written and/or spoken language.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is the most common cause of aphasia?	Ischemic stroke is the most common cause of aphasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What are other etiologies of aphasia?	Other etiologies include, but are not limited to, hemorrhagic stroke, neoplasm, and central nervous system infections.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How can aphasia be classified?	Aphasia can be classified as fluent or nonfluent.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What characterizes nonfluent aphasia?	Individuals with nonfluent aphasia have difficulty producing words, and sentences are lacking in content.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What characterizes fluent aphasia?	Individuals with fluent aphasia easily produce connected speech and have difficulty understanding the meaning of words.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What do deficits in nonfluent and fluent aphasia reflect?	Deficits in nonfluent and fluent aphasia reflect errors in expressive language (repetition skills, naming skills, and writing) and receptive language (oral comprehension and reading comprehension).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
Can aphasia symptoms co-occur with speech impairments?	Yes, aphasia symptoms can co-occur with speech impairments such as dysarthria and apraxia of speech (AOS).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
"What is Broca&#x27;s aphasia associated with?"	"Broca&#x27;s aphasia is associated with damage to Broca&#x27;s area or Brodmann&#x27;s area 44 in the posterior inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
"What are the characteristics of language in Broca&#x27;s aphasia?"	Language is agrammatic and often limited to nouns and verbs, and verbal output is limited to short phrases and sentences.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
"What skills are often impaired in Broca&#x27;s aphasia?"	"Naming, repetition, and writing skills are often impaired in Broca&#x27;s aphasia."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
"How is auditory comprehension in Broca&#x27;s aphasia?"	Auditory comprehension is relatively intact; however, an individual may have difficulty with syntactically complex speech.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is transcortical motor aphasia associated with?	Transcortical motor aphasia is associated with lesions in the anterior cerebral artery and/or the anterior middle cerebral artery watershed that damage the supplementary motor area and/or connections to the frontal perisylvian speech area.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What are common features of transcortical motor aphasia?	Echolalia and perseveration are common features of transcortical motor aphasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What skills remain relatively intact in transcortical motor aphasia?	Naming, auditory comprehension, and repetition skills remain relatively intact in transcortical motor aphasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is a salient feature of transcortical motor aphasia?	A salient feature of transcortical motor aphasia is difficulty initiating speech and completing a thought.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is transcortical mixed aphasia associated with?	Transcortical mixed aphasia is associated with damage to the anterior and posterior watershed area or multifocal cerebral emboli.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What are the characteristics of language in transcortical mixed aphasia?	Individuals with transcortical mixed aphasia have little-to-no spontaneous verbal speech, severe echolalia, severely impaired auditory comprehension, reading, reading comprehension, and writing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What may be present in individuals with transcortical mixed aphasia?	Visual field deficits may be present in individuals with transcortical mixed aphasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is global aphasia?	Global aphasia is a severe form of nonfluent aphasia with deficits across all modes of communication.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What results in global aphasia?	Global aphasia results from extensive damage to the language centers of the left hemisphere.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What skills are significantly impaired in global aphasia?	Naming, repetition, and auditory comprehension are significantly impaired in global aphasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How might individuals with global aphasia respond to communication?	Individuals with global aphasia may respond to intonation of the voice.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What are common physical deficits in people with global aphasia?	Right-sided hemiparesis and right visual field deficits are common in people with global aphasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
"What is Wernicke&#x27;s aphasia associated with?"	"Wernicke&#x27;s aphasia is associated with insults in the posterior superior temporal gyrus of the left hemisphere of the brain."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
"What are the characteristics of language in Wernicke&#x27;s aphasia?"	Language is notable for severe anomia as evidenced by paraphasic errors and neologisms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
"How are repetition skills and other skills in Wernicke&#x27;s aphasia?"	Repetition skills can be significantly impaired as well as auditory comprehension, reading, and writing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
"Are motor deficits typically associated with Wernicke&#x27;s aphasia?"	"Motor deficits are not typically associated with Wernicke&#x27;s aphasia; however, right visual field deficits may be present."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is anomic aphasia associated with?	Anomic aphasia is associated with lesions in the basal temporal lobe, anterior inferior temporal lobe, the temporo-parieto-occipital junction, and the inferior parietal lobe.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What are the characteristics of language in anomic aphasia?	Individuals with anomic aphasia will typically have normal utterance length; however, circumlocutions may occur.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How are naming and repetition skills in anomic aphasia?	Naming is always impaired, repetition skills are relatively intact, and auditory comprehension is typically functional for everyday conversation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How are oral reading and reading comprehension in anomic aphasia?	Oral reading and reading comprehension skills are not impaired.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is conduction aphasia associated with?	Conduction aphasia is often associated with lesions in the left hemisphere supramarginal gyrus and the arcuate fasciculus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What are the characteristics of spontaneous speech in conduction aphasia?	Spontaneous speech is notable for phonemic paraphasias and word-finding errors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How are repetition skills in conduction aphasia?	Repetition skills are impaired, especially with the repetition of longer words, phrases, and sentences.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
Are individuals with conduction aphasia aware of their errors?	Individuals are typically aware of errors; however, they have significant difficulty self-correcting.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How are writing skills in conduction aphasia?	Deficits in writing are seen in most cases of conduction aphasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is transcortical sensory aphasia linked with?	"Transcortical sensory aphasia is linked with lesions adjacent to Wernicke&#x27;s area in the temporal-occipital or parietal-occipital areas."																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What are the characteristics of language in transcortical sensory aphasia?	Language is fluent and paraphasic errors are typically found.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How are repetition skills in transcortical sensory aphasia?	Repetition skills are relatively intact.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How are reading aloud and comprehension in transcortical sensory aphasia?	Individuals are able to read aloud often without comprehension.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How are naming skills in transcortical sensory aphasia?	Naming skills are often significantly impaired.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What may subcortical aphasia be associated with?	Subcortical aphasia may be associated with damage to the basal ganglia, internal capsule, and left thalamus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What are the characteristics of speech in subcortical aphasia?	Speech is fluent with relatively intact repetition skills.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
How is auditory comprehension in subcortical aphasia?	Auditory comprehension is good for everyday conversation; however, an individual may have difficulty with more complex material.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What common problems are associated with subcortical aphasia?	Articulation errors and word-finding problems are common in subcortical aphasia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What influences aphasia outcomes?	Aphasia outcomes are generally influenced by the site of lesion and severity of brain injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
When does most improvement in aphasia occur?	Most improvement occurs within the first few months and plateaus after 1 year.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What is the role of a speech-language pathologist in aphasia treatment?	A speech-language pathologist assists in recovering linguistic ability and trains family members on the use of communication strategies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Aphasia
What types of neuropathology is the right hemisphere of the brain susceptible to?	The right hemisphere of the brain is susceptible to similar types of neuropathology, such as stroke and tumors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What difficulties do individuals with right hemisphere damage (RHD) typically not have?	Individuals with right hemisphere damage (RHD) typically have little or no difficulty with basic language comprehension and expression.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the characteristics of right hemisphere damage (RHD)?	Characteristics of RHD include deficits in organization, reasoning, sequencing, problem-solving, attention, and pragmatic skills.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is anosognosia?	Anosognosia (denial of illness) may occur in up to 40% of individuals with RHD.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is dysarthria?	Dysarthria is an impairment of the motor functions necessary for speech production resulting in reduced speech intelligibility.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What characterizes the articulatory movements of patients with dysarthria?	The articulatory movements of patients with dysarthria are characterized by weakness, reduction in speed, malcoordination, altered muscle tone, or dyskinetic symptoms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is spastic dysarthria linked to?	Spastic dysarthria is linked to lesions of the upper motor neuron.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the speech characteristics of spastic dysarthria?	The speech characteristics of spastic dysarthria include a strained and harsh voice quality, hypernasality, and slow, monotonous speech.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is the most common type of dysarthria resulting from closed head trauma?	Spastic dysarthria is the most common type of dysarthria resulting from closed head trauma.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What neuromuscular deficits are associated with spastic dysarthria?	Neuromuscular deficits associated with spastic dysarthria include hypertonia, weakness, and reduced range and speed of movement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What conditions are associated with spastic dysarthria?	Spastic dysarthria can be associated with pseudobulbar palsy, stroke, encephalitis, and spastic cerebral palsy.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is hypokinetic dysarthria associated with?	Hypokinetic dysarthria is associated with damage to the basal ganglia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the speech characteristics of hypokinetic dysarthria?	The speech characteristics of hypokinetic dysarthria include reduced loudness, monotone voice, imprecise articulation, and rapid speech rate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What condition typically presents with hypokinetic dysarthria?	Individuals with Parkinson’s disease will typically present with hypokinetic dysarthria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What causes ataxic dysarthria?	Ataxic dysarthria is caused by damage to the cerebellum.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What diseases most commonly result in ataxic dysarthria?	Ataxic dysarthria is most commonly the result of inflammatory and degenerative diseases of the cerebellum.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What leads to the speech characteristics of ataxic dysarthria?	Hypotonia and slow and inaccurate movements of the oral musculature lead to a reduced rate of speech. Excess and equal stress, monotone pitch, monoloudness, and irregular articulatory breakdowns are also characteristics of ataxic dysarthria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What conditions are often linked to ataxic dysarthria?	Ataxic dysarthria is often linked to stroke, tumors, and alcohol abuse.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What causes flaccid dysarthria?	Flaccid dysarthria is caused by damage to the lower motor neuron, most frequently due to damage in the brain stem; however, peripheral nerve damage may also lead to symptoms of flaccid dysarthria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What neuromuscular deficits are associated with flaccid dysarthria?	Neuromuscular deficits associated with flaccid dysarthria include weakness, hypotonia, and fasciculations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What conditions are associated with flaccid dysarthria?	Myasthenia gravis and bulbar palsy are associated with flaccid dysarthria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is hyperkinetic dysarthria associated with?	Hyperkinetic dysarthria is associated with damage to the basal ganglia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What neuromuscular deficits are associated with hyperkinetic dysarthria?	Neuromuscular deficits associated with hyperkinetic dysarthria include abnormal rhythmic or irregular and unpredictable, rapid or slow involuntary movements.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What conditions are associated with hyperkinetic dysarthria?	Huntington’s disease, athetosis, spasmodic dysphonia, tremor, and myoclonus are associated with hyperkinetic dysarthria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What does mixed dysarthria reflect?	The aforementioned dysarthrias reflect damage to a localized or centralized area of the motor speech system.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the speech characteristics of mixed dysarthria?	The speech characteristics of mixed dysarthria include harsh vocal quality, hypernasality, slow rate of speech, and monopitch.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What conditions are associated with mixed dysarthria?	Mixed dysarthria is associated with toxic metabolic conditions, infectious processes, tumors of the brain stem, closed head injuries, neurodegenerative diseases, and multiple cerebral infarcts.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What may treatment of dysarthria include?	Treatment of dysarthria may include a combination of medical intervention, behavioral treatment, and prosthetic management.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the treatment goals for dysarthria?	Treatment goals include modification of respiratory, phonatory, articulatory, and prosodic problems to improve the naturalness of communication.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is apraxia?	Apraxia is impairment in the programming of movements.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is AOS?	AOS is impairment in the ability to plan and execute the motor movements responsible for speech.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
Is AOS related to errors of articulation due to musculature weakness?	No, AOS is unrelated to errors of articulation due to musculature weakness and is independent of impairments in language.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are speech production errors in AOS?	Speech production errors include sound substitutions and distortions, groping, and struggling with attempts at speech.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How do individuals with AOS present in terms of speech rate and intonation?	Individuals with AOS present with a slower rate of speech, with difficulty in increasing or changing the rate when requested, impaired intonation, and fluency problems.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What areas of the brain are implicated in AOS?	AOS has been associated with damage to Broca’s area, the lateral premotor cortex (BA6), anterior insula, supplementary motor area, somatosensory cortex, supramarginal gyrus, and basal ganglia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the etiologies of AOS?	Etiologies include vascular disturbances, trauma, and tumors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How is AOS evaluated?	Evaluation of AOS encompasses assessment of apraxic speech symptoms in a natural context (i.e., conversation) and in structured speech tasks (i.e., repetition of words with varying length and syllable complexity).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is oral apraxia?	Oral apraxia is a disorder of orofacial movements for non-speech gestures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How is oral apraxia assessed?	Assessment of oral apraxia involves examination of the oral musculature during volitional, non-speech oral-facial movement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How should treatment of apraxia be sequenced?	Treatment of apraxia should be sequenced to move from more automatic speech to less automatic speech and eventually spontaneous speech.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What additional modalities may benefit individuals with severe apraxia?	Depending on the severity of symptoms, individuals with apraxia may benefit from using all modalities of communication (verbal expression combined with gestures, writing, or augmentative communication devices).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is neurogenic stuttering?	Neurogenic stuttering is a type of dysfluency associated with neuropathology.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the etiologies of neurogenic stuttering?	Etiologies include stroke, extrapyramidal disease, and drug toxicity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How may neurogenic stuttering be classified?	Neurogenic stuttering may be classified as persistent (associated with bilateral brain damage) or transient (associated with multiple lesions of a single hemisphere).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What treatments may be involved in neurogenic stuttering?	Treatment may involve teaching individuals to reduce their rate of speech, use of delayed auditory feedback, pacing boards, relaxation techniques, and/or biofeedback.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is dysphagia?	Dysphagia involves impairment in the oral, pharyngeal, and/or esophageal stage of swallowing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What cranial nerves are responsible for a functional swallow sequence?	The cranial nerves responsible for a functional swallow sequence are the trigeminal (CN V), facial (CN VII), glossopharyngeal (CN IX), vagus (CN X), accessory (CN XI), and hypoglossal (CN XII).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How does dysphagia in the oral preparatory/oral stages manifest?	Dysphagia in the oral preparatory/oral stages manifests with pocketing of food/liquid material in the oral cavity, reduced mastication, or reduced management of oral secretions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are symptoms of pharyngeal-stage dysphagia?	Symptoms of pharyngeal-stage dysphagia include reduced management of pharyngeal secretions; immediate or delayed coughing or clearing of the throat before or after the swallow; a wet vocal quality; a delayed or absent swallow reflex; and changes in respiration and/or respiratory rate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What may indicate aspiration during eating or drinking?	Coughing while eating or drinking may indicate aspiration (food or liquid falling below the level of the vocal cords and entering the trachea).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How can silent aspiration be detected?	Detection of silent aspiration (food or liquid entering the trachea with no immediate signs) requires an instrumental swallow study.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
Does a diminished or absent gag reflex determine safe swallowing ability?	No, a diminished or absent gag reflex does not determine a person’s ability to safely swallow, and individuals who aspirate may have an intact gag reflex.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What might individuals report that suggests esophageal stage dysphagia?	Individuals may report a globus sensation (feeling of a lump or foreign body in the throat) or endorse episodes of regurgitation during or after meals, chest pain upon swallowing, or an acidic taste in the mouth, which are suggestive of dysphagia related to the esophageal stage of swallow.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the etiologies of dysphagia?	Etiologies can be due to adverse neurological events; degenerative disease; infectious processes; metabolic disorders; and myopathic conditions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are some structural etiologies of dysphagia?	Structural etiologies of dysphagia include a cricopharyngeal bar, Zenker’s diverticulum, oropharyngeal tumor, or skeletal abnormality.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
