How can trauma to the larynx related to intubation manifest?	Trauma to the larynx related to intubation can manifest in difficulty swallowing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is the most common cause of dysphagia?	While the most common cause of dysphagia may be neurologic in nature, medication-related dysphagia is a known cause.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the classifications of drug-related dysphagia symptoms?	Symptoms of drug-related dysphagia can be classified as dysphagia as a side effect of the drug, dysphagia as a complication of the drug’s therapeutic action, and medication-induced esophageal injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How can medications with anticholinergic or antimuscarinic effects cause dysphagia?	Medications that affect the smooth and striated muscles of the esophagus (anticholinergic or antimuscarinic effects) may cause symptoms of dysphagia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How can ACE inhibitors and diuretics result in dysphagia?	ACE inhibitors and diuretics can result in xerostomia (dry mouth) impairing the swallow mechanism.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
Why might antipsychotic or neuroleptic medications affect swallowing?	Antipsychotic or neuroleptic medications may affect swallowing as they can cause xerostomia and movement disorders that impact the muscles of the face, tongue, and pharynx, which are involved in swallowing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How can medications that depress the central nervous system cause dysphagia?	Medications that depress the central nervous system (such as narcotics for pain relief or benzodiazepines for antianxiety) may reduce awareness and voluntary control, causing dysphagia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
How can medications cause injury to the esophagus?	Medications can cause injury to the esophagus due to irritation, especially when an inadequate amount of fluid is taken with the medication and it remains in the esophagus too long.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is the role of a speech-language pathologist in the evaluation of swallowing?	A speech-language pathologist will complete a clinical evaluation of swallowing, which consists of obtaining a comprehensive history of an individual’s past medical and surgical history, current medications, and symptoms and risk factors for dysphagia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is a modified barium swallow (MBS)?	A modified barium swallow (MBS) is a videofluoroscopic exam where an individual ingests barium-impregnated foods and liquids.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What does a modified barium swallow (MBS) assess?	An MBS allows the speech pathologist to assess the type and degree of dysfunction and severity of aspiration.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is Fiberoptic Endoscopic Evaluation of Swallowing With Sensory Testing (FEESST)?	Fiberoptic Endoscopic Evaluation of Swallowing With Sensory Testing (FEESST) is an exam in which a flexible fiberoptic endoscope is passed transnasally, giving a direct visualization of the laryngeal and pharyngeal structures of the swallow.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What does a FEESST provide that an MBS does not?	A FEESST provides visualization of secretions and vocal fold pathology that cannot be detected during an MBS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
When there is concern for esophageal dysphagia, to whom does a speech-language pathologist refer?	The speech-language pathologist will refer to a gastroenterologist for possible diagnostic imaging (such as a barium swallow or esophagram) for a complete evaluation of the structure and function of the esophagus.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What should be considered when developing a treatment plan for dysphagia?	Consideration of food preferences, patient and family wishes regarding oral versus non-oral means of nutrition, and cultural background should be taken into account when developing a treatment plan for dysphagia.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What may be included in an individual’s dysphagia management?	Diet or texture modification (e.g., the use of thickened fluids or pureed foods) to improve oral intake and reduce the potential for aspiration may be included in an individual’s dysphagia management.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What treatments may be required for structural disorders causing dysphagia?	For patients with structural disorders, treatment of the underlying disorder may require surgery (e.g., oropharyngeal tumors) or endoscopic dilation (e.g., esophageal webs or strictures).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What might rehabilitation of the disordered swallow mechanism involve?	Rehabilitation of the disordered swallow mechanism may involve exercises to improve or increase strength and function and/or postural adjustments to improve airway protection.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What is neuromuscular electrical stimulation in the context of dysphagia treatment?	Neuromuscular electrical stimulation is a treatment for dysphagia, which involves eliciting muscular contractions utilizing electrical impulses to improve muscle strength.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What should families and caregivers be educated and trained on once a dysphagia treatment plan is established?	Families and caregivers should be educated and trained to carry over the specific airway protection strategies and/or changes in diet to reinforce safe swallowing in the home.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow RehabReadyTags::Language_Speech_Swallow::Right_Hemisphere_damage
What are the precipitating factors for HO?	Precipitating factors include musculoskeletal trauma (e.g., fracture, burn injury, or joint replacement surgery) and neurological pathology (e.g., spinal cord injury [SCI], stroke, and traumatic brain injury [TBI]).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
What are the risk factors for HO?	Risk factors for HO include prolonged immobilization and degree of spasticity.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
Why do reports of HO incidence in the literature vary?	Reports of incidence in the literature vary depending on the methodology used and whether clinically silent HO is included.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
Where is HO commonly seen in burn injury?	In burn injury, common HO sites include the elbow (the most common site; posterior &gt; anterior), shoulder (adults), and hip (children).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
Does the location of HO necessarily coincide with the area of the burn?	No, HO locations do not necessarily coincide with the area of the burn.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
What percentage of body burn increases the risk for HO?	Burns involving more than 20% of the body have a higher risk for HO.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
Where is HO seen in SCI and TBI?	In SCI and TBI, HO is seen at the hip (anterior &gt; posterior) &gt; knee &gt; elbow &gt; shoulder &gt; feet.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
Which spinal injuries result in a higher risk of HO in SCI?	Injuries to the thoracic and cervical spine result in a higher risk of HO in SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
Where is hip HO commonly seen?	Hip HO is commonly seen following total hip arthroplasty (THA).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
Where may HO occur at the distal end of?	HO may occur at the distal end of amputated limbs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
Where is HO typically seen overall?	Overall, HO is typically seen around large joints and below levels of neurologic injury.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
What are the symptoms of HO?	Symptoms of HO may include edema, pain, and loss of joint mobility (in later stages).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
How can HO be diagnosed if suspected?	If HO is suspected, a plain x-ray or three-phase bone scan may be obtained.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
What is the benefit of a bone scan over an x-ray in diagnosing HO?	The bone scan may be positive at least 1 week before the x-ray is positive; phases 1 and 2 of the bone scan are highly sensitive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
What complications can arise from HO?	Complications of HO include peripheral nerve entrapment, pressure ulcers, and functional impairment if joint ankylosis develops.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Introduction
How long is it recommended to rest the acutely involved joint to reduce inflammation and microscopic hemorrhage?	Resting the acutely involved joint for up to 2 weeks is recommended to reduce inflammation and microscopic hemorrhage.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
What may also be helpful in reducing inflammation?	Ice may also be helpful.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
What type of ROM exercises are recommended to maintain joint mobility?	Gentle and painless (passive and/or active) ROM exercises are recommended to maintain joint mobility.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
When can more aggressive ROM be initiated?	More aggressive ROM may be initiated after the first 2 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
What should be done if erythema or swelling increases during ROM exercises?	ROM exercises must be curtailed if erythema or swelling increases.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
What is prudent if ankylosis is inevitable?	Immobilization in a functional position is prudent if ankylosis is inevitable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
What are the medical options for treating HO?	Medical options include NSAIDs (e.g., indomethacin, 25 mg po tid × ≥6 weeks) or etidronate (e.g., 20 mg/kg po qd × 2 weeks, then 10 mg/kg po qd × 10 weeks; other regimens exist).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
How do NSAIDs help in treating HO?	NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin E2, a major contributor of HO formation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
How does etidronate help in treating HO?	Etidronate is thought to reduce further HO formation by reducing osteoblastic/clastic activity and calcium phosphate precipitation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
Does etidronate treat HO that has already formed?	No, etidronate does not treat HO that has already formed.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
How has radiation therapy been used in treating HO?	Radiation therapy has been used with success to prevent and/or treat HO in post-THA patients, although it is infrequently used.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
When might surgical resection be indicated for HO?	Surgical resection may be indicated to address significant functional limitations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
What are the criteria for an ideal surgical candidate for HO resection?	The ideal surgical candidate has no joint pain or swelling; a normal alkaline phosphatase level (which tends to normalize with maturity); and a three-phase bone scan demonstrating mature HO.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
Why is it important to ensure that HO has reached maturity before resection?	It is important to ensure that the HO has reached maturity before resection because resection of immature HO leads to recurrence rates of nearly 100%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
What is recommended postoperatively within 48 hours after HO resection?	Gentle, early (within 48 hours) postoperative ROM is recommended.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification RehabReadyTags::Heterotopic_Ossification::Treatment
What are the risk factors for DVT?	Risk factors for DVT include prior history of venous thromboembolism (VTE), major trauma, immobility, surgery lasting &gt;2 hours, cancer, long-distance travel, paralysis, spinal cord injury (SCI), prolonged hospitalization, smoking, congestive heart failure, central venous access devices, increased estrogen states, pregnancy, brain injury, stroke, obesity, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and inherited coagulopathies.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Introduction
Where do the majority of DVTs occur?	A majority of DVTs (greater than 90%) occur in the lower limbs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Introduction
What percentage of distal DVTs propagate to proximal veins?	Approximately 25% of distal DVTs propagate to proximal veins.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Introduction
With what are most pulmonary embolisms associated?	Most pulmonary embolisms are associated with proximal DVTs of the lower limbs (above the knee).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Introduction
What has been recognized as a common preventable cause of hospital-related death?	VTE is recognized as a common preventable cause of hospital-related death.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Introduction
What did studies show regarding hospitalized patients and VTE prevention?	Studies have shown that many hospitalized patients do not receive appropriate preventive care.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Introduction
What did Amin et al. (2008) note about inpatients in U.S. hospitals?	Amin et al. (2008) noted that only 33% of inpatients in U.S. hospitals were receiving appropriate VTE prevention.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Introduction
What does Low-Dose Unfractionated Heparin (LDUH) bind with to inhibit clotting factors?	LDUH binds with antithrombin III to inhibit factor Ha (thrombin) and factor Xa (intrinsic clotting pathway).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
How does Low-Molecular-Weight Heparin (LMWH) differ from LDUH in terms of binding and half-life?	LMWH has reduced binding with plasma proteins, resulting in a longer and more predictable half-life.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
In what condition is LMWH contraindicated?	LMWH is contraindicated in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What are the FDA-approved dosages of Enoxaparin (Lovenox) for s/p THA and TKA?	For s/p THA, 40 mg qd is approved, and for s/p TKA, 30 mg bid is approved.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the FDA-approved dosage of Dalteparin (Fragmin) for s/p THA?	Dalteparin (Fragmin), 5,000 U SC qd, is approved by the FDA for s/p THA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What do Vitamin K antagonists (VKAs or Warfarin) inhibit?	VKAs or Warfarin inhibit the Vitamin K-mediated production of procoagulant factors X, IX, VII, and II (extrinsic pathway) and anticoagulant proteins C and S.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the initial paradoxical effect of VKAs and why?	The initial paradoxical procoagulant effect occurs because proteins C and S are depleted first.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What should be given for INRs 5 to 9 without significant bleeding?	For INRs 5 to 9 without significant bleeding, give 1 to 2.5 mg po vitamin K or follow INRs without vitamin K.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the recommended treatment for INRs &gt;9 without significant bleeding?	For INRs &gt;9 without significant bleeding, give 3 to 5 mg po vitamin K and monitor INRs (repeat vitamin K if necessary).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the treatment for elevated INRs with serious bleeding?	For elevated INRs with serious bleeding, give 10 mg vitamin K by slow IV infusion (repeat ql2h if necessary) and supplement with plasma or prothrombin complex concentrate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the dosage of Fondaparinux (Arixtra) for s/p hip fracture surgery (HFS), THA, and TKA?	Fondaparinux (Arixtra), 2.5 mg SC qd, is approved for s/p HFS, THA, and TKA.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What advantages do Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) provide over heparin and warfarin?	DOACs provide the advantage of lower bleeding risk, less need for laboratory monitoring, and improved pharmacokinetic profiles.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
In what conditions are DOACs generally contraindicated?	DOACs are generally contraindicated in settings of prosthetic heart valves, pregnancy, renal impairment, and antiphospholipid syndrome.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the VTE prophylaxis dosage of Dabigatran (Pradaxa) for surgical patients?	For VTE prophylaxis in surgical patients, the dosage is 110 mg given 1 to 4 hours after surgery followed by 220 mg daily for 28 to 35 days (hip replacement) or 10 days (knee replacement).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the treatment and secondary prevention dosage of Dabigatran (Pradaxa) for VTE?	For treatment and secondary prevention of VTE, the dosage is 150 mg BID.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the half-life of Rivaroxaban (Xarelto)?	Rivaroxaban (Xarelto) has a half-life of 7 to 17 hours.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the VTE prophylaxis dosage of Rivaroxaban (Xarelto) for surgical patients?	For VTE prophylaxis in surgical patients, the dosage is 10 mg daily for 35 days (hip replacement) or 10 days (knee replacement).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the treatment and secondary prevention dosage of Rivaroxaban (Xarelto) for VTE?	For treatment and secondary prevention of VTE, the dosage is 15 mg BID with food for 21 days, followed by 20 mg daily with food.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the half-life of Apixaban (Eliquis)?	Apixaban (Eliquis) has a half-life of 5 to 9 hours.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the VTE prophylaxis dosage of Apixaban (Eliquis) for surgical patients?	For VTE prophylaxis in surgical patients, the dosage is 2.5 mg BID for 35 days (hip replacement) or 12 days (knee replacement).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What is the treatment and secondary prevention dosage of Apixaban (Eliquis) for VTE?	For treatment and secondary prevention of VTE, the dosage is 10 mg BID for 7 days, followed by 5 mg BID.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::Selected_Prophylaxis_Options
What are the recommended options for DVT prophylaxis in THA or TKA?	The recommended options for DVT prophylaxis in THA or TKA are LMWH, fondaparinux, adjusted-dose VKA, dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, low-dose ASA, or intermittent pneumatic compression device (IPCD).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What are the recommended options for DVT prophylaxis in Hip Fracture Surgery (HFS)?	The recommended options for DVT prophylaxis in Hip Fracture Surgery (HFS) are LMWH, fondaparinux, LDUH, adjusted-dose VKA, ASA, or an IPCD. LMWH is the preferred choice for THA, TKA, and HFS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What is recommended during the hospitalization following major orthopedic surgery for DVT prophylaxis?	Dual prophylaxis with an antithrombotic agent and an IPCD is recommended during the hospitalization following major orthopedic surgery.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
How should newer generation portable IPCDs be used for DVT prophylaxis?	Newer generation portable IPCDs that record and report wear compliance are recommended, to be worn 18 hours/day, for both inpatient and outpatient use.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What is the recommended duration of prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgery?	The recommended duration of prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgery is a minimum of 10 to 14 days, for up to 35 days.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What are the recommended options for DVT prophylaxis in acutely ill hospitalized medical patients?	For acutely ill hospitalized medical patients at increased risk of thrombosis, LMWH, LDUH (BID or TID dosing), or fondaparinux is recommended. Duration of prophylaxis is not recommended to extend beyond the period of immobilization or acute hospital stay.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
When should mechanical and anticoagulation treatment for DVT prophylaxis be initiated in SCI patients?	Mechanical and anticoagulation treatment should be initiated as early as possible, provided there is no active bleeding, coagulopathy, or other contraindication.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What are the prophylactic options of choice during the acute care phase following SCI?	Intermittent pneumatic devices with or without graduated compression stockings plus LMWH are the prophylactic options of choice during the acute care phase following SCI.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What is not recommended for primary DVT prophylaxis in SCI patients?	UH and warfarin are not recommended for primary prophylaxis unless there is a contraindication for LMWH. Inferior vena cava filters are not recommended for primary prophylaxis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
Is it necessary to routinely screen for DVTs with Doppler ultrasonography in SCI patients?	It is not necessary to routinely screen for DVTs with Doppler ultrasonography in SCI patients.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What are the recommended options for DVT prophylaxis during the rehabilitation phase following SCI?	During the rehabilitation phase following SCI, the recommended options for DVT prophylaxis are LMWH, warfarin, or DOACs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What is the suggested duration of chemoprophylaxis for ASIA A or ASIA B SCI patients with other risk factors?	For ASIA A or ASIA B SCI patients with other risk factors, the suggested duration of chemoprophylaxis is at least 12 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What is the suggested duration of chemoprophylaxis for ASIA A or ASIA B SCI patients without other risk factors?	For ASIA A or ASIA B SCI patients without other risk factors, the suggested duration of chemoprophylaxis is at least 8 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What is the suggested duration of chemoprophylaxis for ASIA C SCI patients?	For ASIA C SCI patients, the suggested duration of chemoprophylaxis is up to 8 weeks.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What is the suggested duration of chemoprophylaxis for ASIA D SCI patients?	For ASIA D SCI patients, chemoprophylaxis is recommended during hospitalization.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Prophylaxis_Selected_Conditions
What is typically used for initial treatment of DVT in the absence of contraindications?	Initial treatment is typically IV heparin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
When is warfarin usually started in the treatment of DVT?	Warfarin is usually started within 24 hours of DVT diagnosis, once the heparin is therapeutic.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
What initial dose of warfarin is preferred and why?	A 5-mg initial dose of warfarin is preferred over a 10-mg dose due to early paradoxical hypercoagulability.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
When is heparin discontinued in DVT treatment?	Heparin is discontinued when the INR has been ≥2 for 2 consecutive days.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
How long is warfarin typically instituted for DVT treatment?	Warfarin is typically instituted for 3 to 6 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
What is an alternative to IV heparin for outpatient treatment of uncomplicated DVT?	Warfarin can be started with a weight-based, therapeutic-dose LMWH bridge instead of IV heparin.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
What are examples of LMWH used for bridging in outpatient DVT treatment?	Examples include enoxaparin, 1 mg/kg SC bid, or dalteparin, 200 U/kg SC qd.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
When can LMWH be discontinued in outpatient DVT treatment?	LMWH can be discontinued after 5 days and when INR &gt;2.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
In which patients may thrombolytics have a role for DVT treatment?	Thrombolytics may have a role in patients with extensive proximal DVT and low bleed risk.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
Why does the treatment of isolated calf DVT remain controversial?	The treatment of isolated calf DVT remains controversial due to the need to balance the risks of proximal propagation and life-threatening embolization with the generally more benign natural history of isolated calf thrombi and the individual patient’s risk factors for propagation and complications from anticoagulation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis RehabReadyTags::Deep_Venous_Thrombosis::DVT_Treatment
What did Kosiak report in 1961 about pressure and muscle histology in rats?	Kosiak reported that just 70 mmHg of pressure applied continuously over 2 hours produced moderate histologic changes in rat muscle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
What did Dinsdale report in 1974 about shear and pressure necessary to disrupt blood flow?	Dinsdale reported that shear can significantly reduce the amount of pressure necessary to disrupt blood flow, facilitating the development of pressure injuries.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
What did the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (AHCPR) publish between 1992 to 1995?	The AHCPR published landmark guidelines on pressure ulcer prevention and treatment.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
What did the 2014 collaboration between NPUAP and other international agencies produce?	The collaboration published a comprehensive clinical practice guideline with 575 evidence-based recommendations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
Why did the NPUAP replace the term pressure ulcer with pressure injury in April 2016?	The term was replaced because stage 1 injuries were described as “ulcers” in the prior staging system.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
How does the NPUAP define a pressure injury?	A pressure injury is defined as localized damage to the skin and/or underlying soft tissue usually over a bony prominence or related to a medical or other device. The injury can present as intact skin or an open ulcer and may be painful. It occurs as a result of intense and/or prolonged pressure or pressure in combination with shear.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
According to NPUAP, what factors may affect the tolerance of soft tissue for pressure and shear?	The tolerance of soft tissue for pressure and shear may be affected by microclimate, nutrition, perfusion, co-morbidities, and the condition of the soft tissue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
How is a Stage 1 Pressure Injury described?	Stage 1 Pressure Injury is described as non-blanchable erythema of intact skin, with a localized area of non-blanchable erythema, which may appear differently in darkly pigmented skin. Presence of blanchable erythema or changes in sensation, temperature, or firmness may precede visual changes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
How is a Stage 2 Pressure Injury described?	Stage 2 Pressure Injury is described as partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, moist, and may also present as an intact or ruptured serum-filled blister. Adipose (fat) is not visible and deeper tissues are not visible.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
How is a Stage 3 Pressure Injury described?	Stage 3 Pressure Injury is described as full-thickness skin loss in which adipose (fat) is visible in the ulcer and granulation tissue and epibole (rolled wound edges) are often present. Slough and/or eschar may be visible.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
How is a Stage 4 Pressure Injury described?	Stage 4 Pressure Injury is described as full-thickness skin and tissue loss with exposed or directly palpable fascia, muscle, tendon, ligament, cartilage, or bone in the ulcer. Slough and/or eschar may be visible.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
How is an Unstageable Pressure Injury described?	Unstageable Pressure Injury is described as full-thickness skin and tissue loss in which the extent of tissue damage within the ulcer cannot be confirmed because it is obscured by slough or eschar.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
How is a Deep Tissue Pressure Injury described?	Deep Tissue Pressure Injury is described as persistent non-blanchable deep red, maroon, or purple discoloration, with intact or non-intact skin and localized area of persistent non-blanchable deep red, maroon, or purple discoloration or epidermal separation revealing a dark wound bed or blood-filled blister.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
What is a Medical Device Related Pressure Injury?	Medical Device Related Pressure Injury describes an etiology resulting from the use of devices designed and applied for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. The resultant pressure injury generally conforms to the pattern or shape of the device and should be staged using the staging system.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
What is a Mucosal Membrane Pressure Injury?	Mucosal Membrane Pressure Injury is found on mucous membranes with a history of a medical device in use at the location of the injury. Due to the anatomy of the tissue, these injuries cannot be staged.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Introduction
What should pressure injury prevention include?	Pressure injury prevention should include appropriate seating/bed equipment, proper positioning, education about pressure relief, and proper skin monitoring.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
How often should weight shifting be done while sitting for pressure injury prevention?	Weight shifting should be done every 15–20 minutes for ≥30 seconds while sitting.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
How often should turning in bed be done for pressure injury prevention?	Turning in bed should be done every 2 hours.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
What additional issues may need to be addressed for pressure injury prevention?	Additional issues that may need to be addressed include nutrition, tissue perfusion, oxygenation, local body heat management, and skin moisture management.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
What does the treatment of pressure injuries include?	The treatment of pressure injuries includes pressure relief, addressing other etiologic factors, treatment of infections, debridement of necrotic tissue, regular wound cleansing, and use of appropriate wound dressings.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
When may a trial of topical antibiotics be helpful in pressure injury treatment?	A trial of topical antibiotics may be helpful in wounds not healing with optimal debridement and cleansing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
Are wound cultures generally thought to be helpful for pressure injury treatment?	Wound cultures are not generally thought to be helpful because most wounds are colonized with bacteria.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
When should systemic antibiotics be reserved for pressure injury treatment?	Systemic antibiotics should be reserved for cases with evidence of osteomyelitis, infectious cellulitis, or systemic infection.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
What modalities have been utilized clinically to accelerate wound repair?	Modalities such as electrical stimulation (ES), ultrasound (US), ultraviolet (UV) light, laser radiation, and hyperbaric O2 have been utilized clinically to accelerate wound repair.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
What effects has electrical stimulation (ES) been shown to have on wound healing?	ES has been shown to reduce infection, improve cellular immunity, increase perfusion, and accelerate cutaneous wound healing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
How may ultrasound (US) facilitate healing?	US may facilitate healing through cavitation and microstreaming, which produce cellular changes and activity alterations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
What is cavitation in the context of ultrasound therapy?	Cavitation is the production and vibration of tiny, micron-sized bubbles within underlying soft tissues.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
What is microstreaming in the context of ultrasound therapy?	Microstreaming is the movement of underlying fluid due to mechanical pressure.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
What recent modality has been employed for wound healing to enhance blood flow and healing?	Low-intensity vibration (LIV) at various frequencies and amplitudes has been employed for wound healing.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
How may surgical flaps expedite the healing of noninfected deep ulcers?	Surgical flaps may expedite the healing of noninfected deep ulcers by filling the void with well-vascularized healthy tissue.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
Are surgical flaps still vulnerable to pressure injury?	Yes, surgical flaps are still vulnerable to pressure injury, particularly during the early healing stages.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury RehabReadyTags::Pressure_Injury::Prevention_Treatment
How can quality in health care be defined?	Quality in health care can be defined as the “direct correlation between the level of improved health services and the desired health outcomes of individuals and populations.”																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What are the six goals around which health care quality is centered?	The six goals are making health care safe, effective, patient-centered, efficient, timely, and equitable.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
How does the U.S. Health and Human Services define Quality Improvement (QI)?	QI “includes systematic and continuous actions that lead to measurable improvement in health care services and the health status of targeted patient groups.”																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
"What did the Institute of Medicine&#x27;s (IOM) 2001 report &quot;Crossing the Quality Chasm&quot; focus on?"	The report focused on reinventing the health care system to “foster innovation and improve the delivery of care.”																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
"What are the six aims outlined in the IOM&#x27;s 2001 report?"	The six aims are safe, effective, patient-centered, timely, efficient, and equitable health care.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What must the health care system be responsive to, according to the IOM report?	The health care system must be responsive to current health care needs and anticipate future needs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What benefits can the implementation of QI projects lead to?	QI projects can lead to improved patient health, efficiency of processes, decrease of waste, improved communication, and proactive problem-solving.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
Where must change be implemented to improve quality in health care?	Change must be implemented within both current microsystems and systems at large.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What are the four key principles for achieving change in QI?	The four key principles are: (a) QI works on systems and processes, (b) the primary focus of QI is the patient’s well-being, (c) QI utilizes a multidisciplinary approach, and (d) QI is data-driven.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What does the principle &quot;QI works on systems and processes&quot; include?	It includes changes that improve performance and are individualized to specific needs.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What does the principle &quot;the primary focus of QI is the patient’s well-being&quot; include?	It includes making health care safe, delivered by competent clinicians, coordinated, and culturally sensitive.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What does the principle &quot;QI utilizes a multidisciplinary approach&quot; include?	It incorporates each team member’s skill set and ideas, creating effective leadership, policies, and procedures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What does the principle &quot;QI is data-driven&quot; include?	It uses quantitative and qualitative measures to understand how current systems are working, barriers, implemented interventions, and their level of success.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
Why are patients undergoing rehabilitation at increased risk for injury?	They are at increased risk as they move through the rehabilitation continuum of care, which includes care in acute inpatient rehabilitation, subacute, outpatient, and home settings.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What types of injuries can occur in the acute inpatient rehabilitation setting?	Injuries can include infections, blood clots, pressure ulcers, adverse effects of medications, and falls.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What types of injuries can occur in the outpatient setting?	Injuries can include trauma from interventional procedures, burns from heat modalities, and falls.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
How can QI methodology be used to minimize the occurrence of injuries in rehabilitation care?	A systems-based approach to identifying and studying the risks for these injuries can serve as the foundation for implementing interventions to minimize their occurrence.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What has increased interest in safety and quality in rehabilitation medicine?	Increased interest comes from requirements by CMS for reporting quality metrics and CARF for collecting outcomes data and engaging in QI activities.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What does the American Board of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation (ABPMR) require for maintenance of certification?	The ABPMR requires the completion of a practice improvement project (PIP) for maintenance of the ABPMR certificate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
How many practice improvement projects are required per cycle for those with certificates issued before 2012?	One project per cycle is required for those with certificates issued before 2012.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
How many practice improvement projects are required per cycle for those with certificates issued in 2012 or beyond?	Two projects per cycle are required for those with certificates issued in 2012 or beyond.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Introduction
What does the implementation of an effective QI project require?	It requires changing the culture and infrastructure of an organization to break down traditional barriers and work toward a common goal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What are the steps typically involved in a QI project?	The steps typically involved are: (a) Identifying the team, (b) Delineating the problem(s) or areas in need of improvement, (c) Identifying variables and benchmarks, (d) Defining the steps in the current process, (e) Identifying barriers and bottlenecks, (f) Brainstorming for possible interventions, (g) Implementing the interventions, (h) Collecting outcomes’ data, (i) Analyzing the data, (j) Communicating the “lessons learned” to stakeholders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What roles might be included in the QI team?	The team may include a day-to-day leader, data entry person, provider champion, operations coordinator, and data specialist.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
Why is having a diverse team important in a QI project?	A diverse team brings unique perspectives, experiences, and backgrounds; staff engagement is paramount for successful implementation of a program.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is the first step in a QI project?	The first step is identifying the team.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What should team members do when delineating the problem(s) or areas in need of improvement?	They should perform a literature search for relevant materials and references.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is the purpose of identifying variables and benchmarks in a QI project?	To assess the outcome.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What should be defined in the current process during a QI project?	The steps in the current process should be defined.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is identified as needing improvement in the current process?	Barriers and bottlenecks are identified.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is the step after identifying barriers and bottlenecks in a QI project?	Brainstorming for possible interventions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is done after brainstorming for possible interventions in a QI project?	Implementing the interventions.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is done after implementing interventions in a QI project?	Collecting outcomes’ data.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is the next step after collecting outcomes’ data in a QI project?	Analyzing the data to confirm that all relevant issues have been addressed and that the intervention was successful.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is the final step in a QI project?	Communicating the “lessons learned” to stakeholders.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What are some selected QI models mentioned?	The Care Model, the Learn Model, Model for Improvement, FADE, and Six Sigma.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
Why is tracking performance over time necessary in a QI project?	It is necessary for the immediate and long-term application of the study.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What are some methods for tracking performance over time in a QI project?	This can be done in a setting of formal and informal communication/meetings, newsletters, and so forth.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What are the three fundamental questions in the Model for Improvement?	The questions are: What are we trying to accomplish? How will we know that a change is an improvement? What change can we make that will result in improvement?																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What does the Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle aim to do?	It aims to test the change in a real work setting, implement the change on a larger scale (pilot population or unit), and finally spread the change.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is the purpose of the “Plan” phase in the PDSA cycle?	The “Plan” phase identifies the question to be answered/changes to be implemented, the people responsible for the project, timeline, and resources/data necessary.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What is done in the “Do” phase of the PDSA cycle?	The “Do” phase entails carrying out the test on a small scale and appropriate data.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What does the “Study” phase of the PDSA cycle include?	The “Study” phase includes the results and data analysis compared with what was predicted during the planning phase, identifying successes, failures, and unintended consequences.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What does the “Act” phase of the PDSA cycle describe?	The “Act” phase describes changes that must be made based on the data; the project may be adapted, adopted, or abandoned.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What does “adapted” mean in the context of the PDSA cycle’s “Act” phase?	Adapted means modifying the change and repeating the cycle.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What does “adopted” mean in the context of the PDSA cycle’s “Act” phase?	Adopted means instituting the change on a larger scale.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
What does “abandoned” mean in the context of the PDSA cycle’s “Act” phase?	Abandoned means restarting the cycle with a new question.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Perform_QI_Project
How can tools for performing a QI project be divided?	They can be divided into improvement situations including working with numbers, working with ideas, or working in teams.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Toolkit
What is a fishbone diagram used for in a QI project?	A fishbone diagram is used to identify and graphically display potential (root) causes for a problem or effect, especially useful if limited quantitative data is available.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Toolkit
How should a problem be framed in a fishbone diagram?	The problem should be framed as a “why” question, which is placed in the head of the diagram, with each root cause aiming to answer the question.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Toolkit
What forms the branches in a fishbone diagram?	The branches are formed by different categories contributing to the problem/effect, such as people, processes, plant, and equipment causes.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Toolkit
What is a control chart used for in a QI project?	A control chart is used to graphically track a process over time in order to recognize and study sources of variation and improve performance.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Toolkit
What is a tree diagram used for in a QI project?	A tree diagram is used to break down a broad goal into smaller, detailed levels of action, which can or should be done to achieve the goal.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Toolkit
What is brainstorming used for in a QI project?	Brainstorming is used to creatively and efficiently amass a large number of ideas on a specific topic, and can be performed in a structured or unstructured environment, silently or out loud.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Toolkit
What is a root cause analysis (RCA)?	A RCA is a retrospective tool used to identify the causes of an adverse event and specific failures that can be modified to prevent the error from occurring again.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What is the goal of the RCA?	The goal is to focus on the causes of the flaw, not blame.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What question does the RCA call into question?	It calls into question “What circumstances led a reasonable person to make reasonable decisions that resulted in an undesirable outcome?”																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
How many individuals typically form the RCA team, and who may it include?	The team is formed by four to six individuals from a variety of disciplines and may also include patients and family members.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What is the first step in performing an RCA?	The first step is to identify what happened accurately and completely.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What is the second step in performing an RCA?	The second step is to determine what should have happened in an ideal situation.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What is the third step in performing an RCA?	The third step is to determine causes and factors that contributed to the event.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What is the fourth step in performing an RCA?	The fourth step is to generate the causal statement (cause, effect, and event).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What is the fifth step in performing an RCA?	The fifth step is to provide recommendations to prevent similar future situations.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What is the sixth step in performing an RCA?	The sixth step is to share the findings and summary with other involved members.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Root_Cause_Analysis
What is the Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)?	The FMEA is a tool that focuses on identifying potential failures in a process and taking proactive measures to avoid such failures, thereby reducing adverse events and potential harms.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Failure_Mode_Effects_Analysis
What does FMEA involve?	FMEA involves describing the steps in the process, what could go wrong, why something would go wrong, and what the consequence of the failure would be.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Failure_Mode_Effects_Analysis
How does FMEA differ from RCA?	In contrast to RCA (reactive), FMEA is a proactive process that seeks to identify potential failures and their effects before the events actually occur																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Failure_Mode_Effects_Analysis
What are transitions in care?	Transitions in care refer to a patient leaving one medical setting and moving to another (e.g., hospital, skilled nursing facility, inpatient rehabilitation facility, home health care, primary care physician).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Transition_Points_Handouts
Why is effective communication necessary during transitions in care?	Effective communication is necessary to avoid confusion about the patient’s condition and medication profile.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Transition_Points_Handouts
What can errors during transitions in care lead to?	Errors can lead to harm/adverse events, duplicative testing, inconsistent monitoring, and generalized medication errors.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Transition_Points_Handouts
What concerns do errors during transitions in care create?	These errors create concerns for patient safety, quality of care and health outcomes, and ultimately dissatisfaction with health care.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Transition_Points_Handouts
What key information should be passed between treatment teams during transitions in care?	Key information should include hospital course and complications, past medical and surgical history, relevant results (laboratory, radiology), operative and procedure reports, medication reconciliation, allergies, advanced directives, and contact information (next of kin).																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Transition_Points_Handouts
What is crucial to ensure safe transitions of care?	Improved communication and verbal discussion of the key elements between providers, patients, and family members is crucial to ensure safe transitions of care.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement RehabReadyTags::Quality_Improvement::Transition_Points_Handouts
which segments are involved in dorsal rhizotomy for managing spasticity in cerebral palsy?	L2 to S1&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
Independent sitting by what age indicates a good prognosis for ambulation in CP?	2 years&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
An infant at birth has weakness in one arm, what should be on the differential diagnoses list?	Congenital brachial plexus palsy																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
MRI is used in congenital brachial plexus palsy to rule out what?	Fractures and neuromas&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
what's the second most common cause of pediatric SCI?	Falls&nbsp;																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy RehabReadyTags::Pediatric_Cerebral_Palsy::Other
What is osteoporosis?	A systemic skeletal disorder characterized by low bone mass, caused by imbalance between bone resorption and bone formation																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Introduction
What are some risk factors for osteoporosis?	age &gt;50 years, female gender, Caucasian race, positive family history, excessive thinness, sedentary lifestyle, immobility, excessive alcohol use, smoking, history of prior fractures, calcium deficiency, decreased estrogen, hyperthyroidism, diabetes, anticonvulsant use, and glucocorticoid use																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Introduction
How is bone mineral density measured? 	A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Introduction
Besides bone mineral density testing, how can osteoporosis be diagnosed clinically?	By history of hip or vertebral fracture during adulthood in the absence of major trauma																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Introduction
What BMD T-scores are considered osteopenia?	A BMD T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Introduction
A BMD T-score below what value is considered osteoporosis?	T-score -2.5 or less																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Introduction
Who does the National Osteoporosis Foundation (NOF) recommend BMD testing for?	All women aged ≥65 years and all men aged ≥70 years, regardless of clinical risk factors as well as postmenopausal women and men aged 50-69 years based on risk factor profile																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Screening
Who should be tested to diagnose and determine the degree of osteoporosis?	Postmenopausal women and men aged ≥50 years who have had an adulthood fracture.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Screening
Who are the NOF treatment guidelines recommended for?	All individuals with or at risk for osteoporosis, but primarily for postmenopausal women and men &gt;50 years of age.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What is the recommended daily intake of calcium for men aged 50 to 70 years according to current NOF guidelines?	1,000 mg/day.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What is the recommended daily intake of calcium for women aged &gt;50 years and men aged &gt;70 years according to current NOF guidelines?	1,200 mg/day.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What are the potential risks of consuming higher amounts of calcium?	Increased risk of kidney stones, cardiovascular disease, and stroke.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What is the recommended daily intake of vitamin D for adults aged &gt;50 years?	800 to 1,000 IU/day.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
For whom is pharmacotherapy recommended according to the NOF guidelines?	Postmenopausal women and men &gt;50 years with any of the following: (a) t-score less than -2.5 at the femoral neck, total hip, or lumbar spine; (b) hip/vertebral fracture; (c) t-score between -1.0 and -2.5 at the femoral neck, hip, or spine, a 10-year probability of a hip fracture ≥3%, or a 10-year probability of a major OP-related fracture ≥20%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What are considered first-line treatments for osteoporosis?	Bisphosphonates such as alendronate and risedronate.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What is the effect of bisphosphonates on BMD within the first 2 years of treatment?	They can increase the BMD by 5% to 10%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
By how much can bisphosphonates reduce vertebral fracture risk?	By 30% to 50%.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
Why did the use of unopposed estrogen for the treatment of osteoporosis fall out of favor?	Because it can increase the risk of cancer, stroke, and venous thromboembolism.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What is the goal of selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as raloxifene?	To maximize the beneficial effect of estrogen on bone while minimizing the deleterious effects on breast and endometrium.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What is the effect of salmon calcitonin (100 IU IM/SQ qd) on BMD and vertebral fracture risk?	It improves BMD and reduces vertebral fracture risk at the lumbar spine, but not at the hip.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What is denosumab and how is it administered?	Denosumab is a RANK ligand inhibitor that inhibits osteoclast development and mitigates bone resorption, administered as 60 mg subcutaneous injection every 6 months.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
When should repeat BMD testing be performed after starting any pharmacologic agent?	1 to 2 years after starting any pharmacologic agent and every 2 years thereafter.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Supplements_Pharmacotherapy
What does the NOF recommend for an exercise prevention program?	Weight-bearing exercises for a total of 30 minutes 5 to 7 days per week and muscle strengthening 2 to 3 days per week.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What interventions may reduce the risk and/or impact of falls?	Appropriate assistive mobility devices, exercise programs, hip padding, and avoidance of medications affecting the CNS.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What has poor back extensor strength been reported to correlate with?	A higher incidence of vertebral fractures.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
How are acute vertebral fractures often managed?	With bed rest, orthotic immobilization, and analgesics																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What types of orthoses may reduce the risk of additional vertebral body fractures?	Rigid orthoses to limit spinal flexion																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What are the mainstays of rehabilitation for vertebral fractures?	Postural training, back extensor exercises, pectoral stretching, walking, or other weight-bearing exercises.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What are percutaneous vertebral augmentation interventions?	Minimally invasive procedures like vertebroplasty and balloon kyphoplasty.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What is the purpose of percutaneous vertebral augmentation interventions?	To provide excellent short-term analgesic relief, although long-term benefits with respect to pain or function have only rarely been noted.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What do percutaneous vertebral augmentation interventions involve?	The injection of polymethyl methacrylate to provide a rigid vertebral reinforcement.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What may be a risk of percutaneous vertebral augmentation interventions?	Increased risk of new vertebral fractures, particularly at adjacent vertebrae.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What are the absolute contraindications for percutaneous vertebral augmentation interventions?	Discitis, osteomyelitis, and sepsis.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
What are the relative contraindications for percutaneous vertebral augmentation interventions?	Significant spinal canal compromise due to bone fragments, fractures older than 2 years, &gt;75% collapse of the vertebral body, fractures above T5, and traumatic compression fractures or disruption of the posterior vertebral body wall.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
How do many physicians limit the use of percutaneous vertebral augmentation procedures in clinical practice?	To fractures that are less than 6 months old.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
When is spine surgery reserved in the management of vertebral fractures?	For rare cases involving neurologic deficits or an unstable spine.																				RehabReadyTags RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis RehabReadyTags::Osteoporosis::Exercise_Rehabilitation
